Year: --

CHINESE HISTORY TIMELINE Work in progress Status: Xia -> Shang - Map only updates in 1600 BC and 1046 BC - Spotty, messy data Zhou -> Warring States (**Best coverage**) - Map is synced after 710 BC with some off-by-one errors -Shows 710 BC map after 1000 BC - Decent data for kings and Dukes - Currently missing rulers who do not have English wikipedia pages - Some text chapters are better dated in chronology than others Qin -> Han - Map ok, some off-by-one errorss - Emperors appear duplicated Three Kingdoms -> Present -Map ok, some off-by-one errors -Missing Chinese names of rulers for portraits -Very messy data -Duplicated rulers PLANS: -Incorporate CBDB prosopographical data to fill out as much of the beurocracy as possible!!!! -Clean up data generally -Clean up UI, maybe add more features

[2306 BC]
[2305 BC]
[2304 BC]
[2303 BC]
[2302 BC]
[2301 BC]
[2300 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 1. Zhou Houji, whose given name was Qi, was the daughter of the You Tai clan, named Jiang Yuan. Jiang Yuan was the primary consort of Emperor Ku. One day, Jiang Yuan went out into the wilderness and saw the footprints of a giant. Delighted, she wanted to step on them, and upon doing so, her body moved as if she were pregnant. After the appointed time, she gave birth to a son. Considering this an ominous sign, she abandoned him in a narrow alley. Horses and cattle passing by avoided trampling him. She then moved him to a forest, but many people from the mountains and forests gathered there and moved him again. Finally, she abandoned him on the ice in a ditch, where birds covered him with their wings. Jiang Yuan considered this a divine intervention and took him in to raise him. Because she had initially intended to abandon him, she named him Qi (meaning "abandoned"). [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 1 (mythic). The ancestors of the Chu state descended from Emperor Zhuanxu Gaoyang. Gaoyang was the grandson of the Yellow Emperor and the son of Changyi. Gaoyang begat Cheng, Cheng begat Juanzhang, and Juanzhang begat Chongli. Chongli served as the Fire Official under Emperor Ku Gaoxin, achieving great merit and illuminating the world. Emperor Ku named him Zhurong. When Gonggong rebelled, Emperor Ku ordered Chongli to suppress him, but he failed to do so completely. Therefore, on the day of Gengyin, the Emperor executed Chongli and appointed his younger brother Wu Hui as Chongli's successor, restoring him to the position of Fire Official, Zhurong.
[2299 BC]
[2298 BC]
[2297 BC]
[2296 BC]
[2295 BC]
[2294 BC]
[2293 BC]
[2292 BC]
[2291 BC]
[2290 BC]
[2289 BC]
[2288 BC]
[2287 BC]
[2286 BC]
[2285 BC]
[2284 BC]
[2283 BC]
[2282 BC]
[2281 BC]
[2280 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 2. Even as a child, Qi possessed the ambition of a giant. In his games, he loved planting hemp and beans, which grew beautifully. As an adult, he became fond of farming, assessing the suitability of the land and cultivating crops where appropriate. The people all followed his example. Emperor Yao heard of this and appointed Qi as the Minister of Agriculture, from which the world benefited, and he was highly regarded. Emperor Shun said, "Qi, when the people first suffered famine, you, Hou Ji, sowed the hundred grains in due season." He enfeoffed Qi at Tai, giving him the title Hou Ji, and bestowing upon him the surname Ji. Hou Ji's rise to prominence occurred during the reigns of Emperors Yao, Yu, and Xia, and he was known for his virtuous conduct throughout these periods.

[2203 BC]
[2202 BC]
[2201 BC]
[2200 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 3. After Houji's death, his son Buzhu succeeded him. In Buzhu's later years, the Xia dynasty declined, neglecting Houji's duties. Buzhu, having lost his position, fled to the Rong and Di tribes. After Buzhu's death, his son Ju succeeded him. After Ju's death, his son Gongliu succeeded him. Although Gongliu lived among the Rong and Di, he restored Houji's work, focusing on agriculture, adapting to local conditions, and sourcing materials from the Qi and Ju rivers across the Wei River. Travelers had provisions, and residents had livestock, and the people benefited from his rule. The people cherished him, and many migrated but returned to him. The rise of the Zhou dynasty began from this time, hence poets sang of his virtues. After Gongliu's death, his son Qingjie succeeded him, establishing the state of Bin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 1 (legendary; Yu/Shun era). Before the Qin dynasty, there was a descendant of Emperor Zhuanxu named Nüxiu. While Nüxiu was weaving, a black bird dropped an egg, which she swallowed, giving birth to Daye. Daye married the daughter of Shaodian, named Nühua. Nühua gave birth to Dafei, who assisted Yu in controlling the floods. After the work was completed, the Emperor bestowed upon him a black jade tablet. Yu accepted it, saying, "It was not I who could have accomplished this, but Dafei who assisted me." Emperor Shun said, "Oh, Fei, you have aided Yu's work; I hereby bestow upon you the title of Zaoyou. Your descendants will be numerous." He then married Dafei to a jade maiden of the Yao clan. Dafei accepted the title and assisted Shun in taming birds and beasts. Many birds and beasts became docile; this Dafei was known as Baiyi. Shun bestowed upon him the surname Ying. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 2 (mythic). Wu Hui begat Lu Zhong. Lu Zhong begat six sons, born via cesarean section. The eldest was Kunwu; the second, Canhu; the third, Pengzu; the fourth, Huiren; the fifth, surnamed Cao; and the sixth, Jilian, surnamed Mi, a descendant of the Chu state. The Kunwu clan served as marquises during the Xia dynasty, but were destroyed by Tang during the reign of Jie. The Pengzu clan served as marquises during the Yin dynasty, but were destroyed at the end of the Yin dynasty. Jilian begat Fuju, and Fuju begat Xuexiong. Their descendants declined, some living in China, others among the barbarians, and their lineage cannot be recorded.

[1768 BC]
[1767 BC]
[1766 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 2 (Xia→Shang transition; traditional). Da Fei had two sons: one named Da Lian, who was actually of the Niaosu clan; the other named Ruomu, who was actually of the Fei clan. His great-grandson was Fei Chang, whose descendants lived either in China or among the barbarians. During the reign of Jie of Xia, Fei Chang left Xia and joined Shang, serving as Tang's charioteer and defeating Jie at Mingtiao. Da Lian's great-grandsons were Meng Xi and Zhong Yan, who had bird bodies and spoke human language. Emperor Tai Wu heard of them and consulted a divination, appointing them as charioteers. The divination was auspicious, so Emperor Tai Wu appointed them as charioteers and married them to him. From Tai Wu onwards, the descendants of Zhong Yan all made contributions to the Yin state, thus the Ying surname became prominent, and they eventually became feudal lords.
[1765 BC]
[1764 BC]

[1601 BC]
[1600 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 4. Qingjie died, and his son Huangpu succeeded him. Huangpu died, and his son Chaifu succeeded him. Chaifu died, and his son Huiyu succeeded him. Huiyu died, and his son Gongfei succeeded him. Gongfei died, and his son Gaoyu succeeded him. Gaoyu died, and his son Yayu succeeded him. Yayu died, and his son Gongshuzulei succeeded him. Gongshuzulei died, and his son Gugong Danfu succeeded him. Gugong Danfu restored the work of Houji and Gongliu, accumulating virtue and practicing righteousness, and the people all revered him. The Xunyu Rongdi attacked him, wanting to obtain wealth, which he gave them. They attacked again, wanting to obtain land and people. The people were all angry and wanted to fight. Gugong said, "When the people establish a ruler, it is to benefit them. Now the Rongdi are attacking and fighting, giving our land and people. Whether the people are with me or with them, what difference is there? The people want to fight because of me, killing fathers and sons to make a ruler, I cannot bear to do it." So he and his private followers left Bin, crossed Qi and Ju, crossed Liangshan, and stopped at the foot of Qi. The people of Bin, supporting the old and the weak, all returned to Duke Gu at the foot of Mount Qi. When neighboring states heard of Duke Gu's benevolence, many also came to him. Thereupon, Duke Gu rejected the customs of the Rong and Di tribes, and built city walls and houses, establishing separate towns for the inhabitants. He appointed five officials. The people all sang and rejoiced, praising his virtue.
[1599 BC]

[1201 BC]
[1200 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 1. The ancestors of the Zhao clan shared a common ancestor with the Qin. During the reign of Zhong Yan, he served as the charioteer of Emperor Da Wu. His descendant, Fei Lian, had two sons. One son, named E Lai, served King Zhou of Shang and was killed by the Zhou dynasty. His descendants then established the Qin dynasty. E Lai's younger brother, Ji Sheng, also descended from him and established the Zhao dynasty.
[1199 BC]
[1198 BC]
[1197 BC]
[1196 BC]
[1195 BC]
[1194 BC]
[1193 BC]
[1192 BC]
[1191 BC]
[1190 BC]

[1152 BC]
[1151 BC]
[1150 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 5. Duke Gu had an eldest son named Taibo, and a second son named Yuzhong. Taijiang gave birth to a younger son named Jili, who married Tairen, both virtuous women. They gave birth to Chang, who was blessed with auspicious signs. Duke Gu said, "There will be one who will rise to prominence in my generation. Will it be Chang?" The eldest sons, Taibo and Yuzhong, knew that Duke Gu wanted to establish Jili as the successor to Chang. So the two fled to the barbarian lands of Jingman, tattooed their bodies and cut off their hair, to yield the throne to Jili. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 1 (very approximate; pre-Zhou conquest). Wu Taibo and his younger brother Zhongyong were both sons of King Tai of Zhou and elder brothers of King Jili. Jili was virtuous and had a sage son, Chang. King Tai wanted to establish Jili and Chang as his successors, so Taibo and Zhongyong fled to the Jingman region, tattooing their bodies and cutting their hair to show they were unfit for service and to avoid Jili. Jili indeed ascended the throne, becoming King Ji, and Chang became King Wen. Taibo, having fled to the Jingman region, called himself Gouwu. The Jingman people admired him and more than a thousand families followed him, establishing him as Wu Taibo.
[1149 BC]
[1148 BC]
[1147 BC]
[1146 BC]
[1145 BC]
[1144 BC]
[1143 BC]
[1142 BC]
[1141 BC]

[1129 BC]
[1128 BC]
[1127 BC]
[1126 BC]
[1125 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 6. When Duke Gu died, Ji Li succeeded him, becoming known as Duke Ji. Duke Ji upheld the ways of Duke Gu and was devoted to righteousness, which earned him the support of the feudal lords.
[1124 BC]
[1123 BC]
[1122 BC]
[1121 BC]
[1120 BC]
[1119 BC]
[1118 BC]
[1117 BC]
[1116 BC]

[1106 BC]
[1105 BC]
[1104 BC]
[1103 BC]
[1102 BC]
[1101 BC]
[1100 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 2.1 (very approximate). Taibo died without an heir, and his younger brother Zhongyong succeeded him, becoming Wu Zhongyong. Zhongyong died, and his son Jijian succeeded him. Jijian died, and his son Shuda succeeded him. Shuda died, and his son Zhouzhang succeeded him.
[1099 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 7. After Gongji's death, his son Chang succeeded him, becoming the Duke of the West. The Duke of the West was called King Wen. He followed the work of Houji and Gongliu, and the laws of Gugong and Gongji. He was benevolent, respectful to the elderly, and kind to the young. He treated the virtuous with courtesy, often neglecting to eat at midday to wait for scholars, which is why many scholars flocked to him. Bo Yi and Shu Qi, residing in Guzhu, heard of the Duke of the West's kindness in caring for the elderly and decided to go and serve him. Tai Dian, Hong Yao, San Yisheng, Yu Zi, and Xin Jia, among others, all went to serve him.
[1098 BC]
[1097 BC]
[1096 BC]
[1095 BC]
[1094 BC]
[1093 BC]
[1092 BC]
[1091 BC]
[1090 BC]
[1089 BC]
[1088 BC]
[1087 BC]
[1086 BC]
[1085 BC]
[1084 BC]
[1083 BC]

[1081 BC]
[1080 BC]
[1079 BC]
[1078 BC]
[1077 BC]

[1075 BC]

[1063 BC]
[1062 BC]
[1061 BC]
[1060 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 1. Taigong Wang Lü Shang was a man from the East Sea. His ancestors had served as the Four Mountains and assisted Yu in controlling the floods, making great contributions. During the Yu and Xia dynasties, they were enfeoffed at Lü or Shen, and their surname was Jiang. During the Xia and Shang dynasties, some of the descendants of Shen and Lü were enfeoffed, while others were made commoners. Shang was a descendant of them. Originally surnamed Jiang, he took his fiefdom's surname, hence the name Lü Shang.
[1059 BC]
[1058 BC]
[1057 BC]
[1056 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 10.1. The following year, we attacked the Quanrong. The following year, we attacked the Mixu. The following year, we defeated the Qi state. When Yin's ancestor Yi heard of this, he was afraid and told Emperor Zhou. Zhou said, "Is there no mandate from Heaven? What can this do!" The following year, we attacked Yu. The following year, we attacked Chonghou Hu. And we built Fengyi, moving the capital from Qixia to Feng. The following year, the Duke of the West died, and Crown Prince Fa ascended the throne, becoming King Wu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 2. Lü Shang, having once been impoverished and old, used fishing to treacherously deceive the Duke of Zhou, the King of Zhou. When the Duke of Zhou was about to go hunting, he consulted a diviner, who said, "What I will catch is neither dragon, nor leopard, nor tiger, nor bear; what I will catch is the assistant of a hegemon." So the Duke of Zhou went hunting and indeed encountered Taigong on the south bank of the Wei River. He spoke with him and was greatly pleased, saying, "My ancestor, Taigong, said, 'A sage will come to Zhou, and Zhou will prosper.' Are you truly him? My ancestor has long awaited you for a long time." Therefore, he called him "Taigong Wang" (meaning "Looking-for-Taigong"), took him home with him, and appointed him as his teacher. [Sima Qian, Shiji 61 — Bo Yi Lie Zhuan] 3.1 (approx; pre-Zhou). Bo Yi and Shu Qi were the two sons of the ruler of Guzhu. Their father wanted to establish Shu Qi as the successor, but upon his death, Shu Qi yielded the throne to Bo Yi. Bo Yi said, "It is my father's command," and fled. Shu Qi also refused to be established and fled. The people of the state then established their middle son as the successor.
[1055 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 8. Chong Houhu slandered the Duke of the West to King Zhou of Yin, saying, "The Duke of the West has accumulated good deeds and virtues, and all the feudal lords are drawn to him, which will be detrimental to the Emperor." King Zhou then imprisoned the Duke of the West in Youli. Hong Yao and his followers were troubled by this. They sought out beautiful women from the Youxin clan, fine horses from the Li Rong, nine chariots from the Youxiong, and other strange objects, and presented them to King Zhou through Fei Zhong, a favorite minister of King Zhou. King Zhou was greatly pleased, saying, "This one item is enough to release the Duke of the West, let alone many others!" He then pardoned the Duke of the West, bestowing upon him bows, arrows, axes, and halberds, enabling him to wage war. It was said, "The one who slandered the Duke of the West was Chong Houhu." The Duke of the West then offered the land west of Luoyang to King Zhou in exchange for the abolition of the punishment of cannon blasting. King Zhou granted his request. 10.2. The following year, we attacked the Quanrong. The following year, we attacked the Mixu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 3. Some say that Taigong was learned and once served King Zhou. When King Zhou was tyrannical, Taigong left him. He traveled among the feudal lords, but found no success, and eventually returned west to the Zhou king. Others say that Lü Shang was a recluse who lived by the sea. When the Zhou king was imprisoned in Youli, San Yisheng and Hong Yao, who knew him well, invited Lü Shang. Lü Shang also said, "I have heard that the Zhou king is virtuous and kind to the elderly; why don't I go to him?" The three men then sought out beautiful women and rare objects for the Zhou king and presented them to King Zhou to redeem him. The Zhou king was then released and returned to his country. Although the reasons for Lü Shang's service to the Zhou differ, he was essentially a teacher of both civil and military affairs. 4. After Zhou Xibo (King Wen of Zhou) escaped from Youli and returned home, he conspired with Lü Shang to cultivate virtue and overthrow the Shang dynasty. Their actions involved much military power and ingenious strategies, hence later discussions of military affairs and the Zhou dynasty's covert power are all attributed to Taigong (Zhou Xibo). After Zhou Xibo's reign ended peacefully, and he resolved the dispute between Yu and Rui, poets referred to him as King Wen, having received the mandate of heaven. He conquered Chong, Mixu, and Quanyi, and built the great city of Fengyi. The world was divided into three, and two of those parts came under Zhou's control, largely due to Taigong's strategies.
[1054 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 9. King Wen of Zhou secretly performed good deeds, and all the feudal lords came to him to settle disputes. Thereupon, the people of Yu and Rui had a case they could not resolve, so they went to Zhou. Upon entering the territory, the farmers all yielded their land borders, and the people all yielded to their elders. The people of Yu and Rui, before even seeing King Wen of Zhou, were ashamed and said to each other, "What we are arguing about is a disgrace to the people of Zhou. Why go there? We will only invite humiliation." So they returned, all yielding to each other as they departed. When the feudal lords heard of this, they said, "King Wen of Zhou is a ruler who has received the Mandate of Heaven." 10.3. The following year, we defeated the Qi state. When Yin's ancestor Yi heard of this, he was afraid and told Emperor Zhou. Zhou said, "Is there no mandate from Heaven? What can this do!" The following year, we attacked Yu. The following year, we attacked Chonghou Hu. And we built Fengyi, moving the capital from Qixia to Feng. The following year, the Duke of the West died, and Crown Prince Fa ascended the throne, becoming King Wu.
[1053 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 10.4. The following year, we attacked the Quanrong. The following year, we attacked the Mixu. The following year, we defeated the Qi state. When Yin's ancestor Yi heard of this, he was afraid and told Emperor Zhou. Zhou said, "Is there no mandate from Heaven? What can this do!" The following year, we attacked Yu. The following year, we attacked Chonghou Hu. And we built Fengyi, moving the capital from Qixia to Feng. The following year, the Duke of the West died, and Crown Prince Fa ascended the throne, becoming King Wu.
[1052 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 10.5. The following year, we attacked the Quanrong. The following year, we attacked the Mixu. The following year, we defeated the Qi state. When Yin's ancestor Yi heard of this, he was afraid and told Emperor Zhou. Zhou said, "Is there no mandate from Heaven? What can this do!" The following year, we attacked Yu. The following year, we attacked Chonghou Hu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 61 — Bo Yi Lie Zhuan] 3.2 (approx; Wen era). Bo Yi and Shu Qi then heard that King Wen of Zhou (Xi Bo Chang) was kind to the elderly, so they went to serve him.
[1051 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 10.6. And we built Fengyi, moving the capital from Qixia to Feng.
[1050 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 10.7. The following year, the Duke of the West died, and Crown Prince Fa ascended the throne, becoming King Wu. 11. King Wen of Zhou reigned for fifty years. While imprisoned in Youli, he expanded the eight trigrams of the I Ching into sixty-four hexagrams. Poets praised him, saying that in the year he received the mandate of heaven, he became king and resolved the dispute between Yu and Rui. He died ten years later and was posthumously named King Wen. He reformed the laws and established a proper calendar. He posthumously honored Gu Gong as King Tai and Gong Ji as King Ji: this signifies that the dynasty's auspicious beginnings trace back to King Tai.
[1049 BC]
[1048 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 12. When King Wu ascended the throne, Taigong Wang was his teacher, Zhou Gongdan was his assistant, and the disciples of Shao Gong and Bi Gong assisted the king. The teacher continued the work of King Wen. 13. In the ninth year, King Wu offered sacrifices at Bi. He inspected his troops in the east and reached Mengjin. He prepared a wooden tablet for King Wen, which was carried in a chariot in the center of the army. King Wu called himself Crown Prince Fa, saying that he was acting on behalf of King Wen in the campaign and dared not act on his own. He then addressed the Sima, Situ, Sikong, and other officials: "Beware! I am ignorant, but because my ancestors had virtuous ministers, and I, a young man, have received their merits, I will establish rewards and punishments to determine their achievements." He then raised his army. The Grand Master Shangfu shouted: "Gather your people and your boats; those who arrive late will be executed." King Wu crossed the river. In the middle of the river, a white fish leaped into the king's boat, and King Wu bent down to catch it and offered it as a sacrifice. After crossing, a fire rose from above and fell to the bottom, reaching Wangwu Mountain, where it transformed into a red crow, its cry like a ghost. At that time, eight hundred lords of the various states gathered unexpectedly at Mengjin. The lords all said, "Zhou can be attacked now." King Wu said, "You do not know the will of Heaven; it is not yet time." He then withdrew his army. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 5. King Wen died, and King Wu ascended the throne. In the ninth year, desiring to emulate King Wen's achievements, he launched an eastern expedition to observe whether the feudal lords would gather. Before the army marched, Grand Master Shangfu, wielding a yellow battle-axe in his left hand and a white banner in his right, swore an oath: "Azure rhinoceros, azure rhinoceros, I command all your people, and your boats and oars; whoever arrives late shall be beheaded!" They then reached Mengjin. Unexpectedly, eight hundred feudal lords gathered. All the feudal lords said, "King Zhou can be attacked." King Wu said, "Not yet." He returned with his army and made this great oath with Grand Master Shangfu.
[1047 BC]
[1046 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 14. Two years later, hearing that King Zhou of Shang's tyranny and depravity had worsened, having killed Prince Bigan and imprisoned Jizi, King Wu's Grand Tutor Ci and Junior Tutor Qiang fled to Zhou with their musical instruments, King Wu then proclaimed to the feudal lords, "Shang has committed grave crimes and cannot be left unpunished." Following the example of King Wen, he led 300 chariots, 3,000 elite warriors, and 45,000 armored soldiers eastward to attack Shang. On the day of Wuwu in the 11th month of the 12th year, the army crossed the Mengjin ferry, and all the feudal lords gathered. They declared, "Be diligent and tireless!" King Wu then made a grand oath, proclaiming to the people: "Now King Zhou of Shang has listened to the words of women, severing himself from Heaven, destroying the three cardinal principles, alienating his royal parents and brothers, abandoning the music of his ancestors, creating licentious music, corrupting righteous music, and pleasing women. Therefore, I now raise my banner to carry out Heaven's punishment. Strive on, my lord, this must not be repeated, nor thrice!" 15. At dawn on the day of Jiazi in the second month, King Wu of Zhou arrived at Muye, the outskirts of Shang, and swore an oath. King Wu held a yellow battle-axe in his left hand and a white banner in his right, waving them around. He said, "People of the far west!" King Wu said, "Alas! I have the chief minister of the state, the ministers of education, war, and public affairs, the chiefs of the army, the commanders of a thousand men and a hundred men, and the people of Yong, Shu, Qiang, Mao, Wei, Lu, Peng, and Pu. Raise your spears, straighten your shields, and stand your lances, and I will swear this oath." The king said, "The ancients said, 'A hen does not crow at dawn. When a hen crows at dawn, the house is ruined.' Now, King Zhou of Yin listens to the words of women, abandoning his ancestors and neglecting their sacrifices, neglecting his family and state, and abandoning his royal parents and brothers. He then rules over the four directions..." "The many criminals who have fled are honored and exiled, trusted and sent, allowing them to tyrannize the people and commit treachery in the Shang state. Now I will issue this oath to carry out Heaven's punishment. Today's matter will be resolved in no more than six or seven steps, then cease. Master, strive on! No more than four, five, six, or seven attacks, then cease. Master, strive on! Be valiant and fierce, like tigers and bears, like jackals and jackals, on the outskirts of Shang, without resistance, you will flee, and you will enslave the western lands. Master, strive on! If you do not strive, you will be punished." After the oath was made, the feudal lords assembled their troops with four thousand chariots and arrayed their army at Muye. 16. When King Zhou of Shang heard that King Wu was coming, he also mobilized 700,000 troops to resist him. King Wu sent his Grand Master Shangfu with a hundred men to meet the army, while he led a large force to attack King Zhou's army. Although King Zhou's army was numerous, they had no will to fight and wanted King Wu to enter quickly. King Zhou's army turned their weapons around to fight, opening the way for King Wu. King Wu charged, and King Zhou's army collapsed and turned against him. King Zhou fled, then went back up to the Deer Terrace, covered himself with his precious jade, and burned himself to death. King Wu held a large white flag and waved it to the feudal lords, who all bowed to him. King Wu then bowed to the feudal lords, and they all followed. King Wu arrived at the Shang Kingdom, where the people of Shang waited for him in the suburbs. King Wu then had his ministers address the people of Shang, saying, "Heaven has bestowed blessings upon us!" The Shang people all bowed twice and kowtowed, and King Wu returned the bow. He then entered the Shang Kingdom and went to the place where King Zhou had died. King Wu shot at him himself, three times, then dismounted, struck him with a light sword, and beheaded him with a yellow axe, and hung the large white flag. Then they came to the two concubines of King Zhou, both of whom had committed suicide. King Wu shot three more arrows, struck them with his sword, and beheaded them with a black battle-axe, hanging a small white flag above their heads. King Wu then led his army back out. 17. The following day, the roads were cleared, and the altars and the palace of King Zhou of Shang were repaired. At the appointed time, a hundred men carrying banners led the way. King Wu's brother, Shu Zhenduo, carried the chariot, Duke Dan of Zhou held the large battle-axe, and Duke Bi held the small battle-axe, flanking King Wu. San Yisheng, Tai Dian, and Hong Yao all held swords to protect King Wu. Upon entering, they stood to the left of the large soldiers south of the altar, with Bi following on the left and right. Mao Shu Zheng carried the clear water, Wei Kangshu sealed the cloth, Duke Shao Shi assisted in the preparation, and Grand Master Shangfu led the sacrificial animals. Yin Yiyi prayed, "The last descendant of King Zhou of Shang, Ji Zhou, has destroyed the virtuous rule of his ancestors, insulted the gods and refused sacrifices, and tyrannized the people of Shang. His deeds are clearly known to the Heavenly Emperor and the Supreme God." King Wu then bowed twice and kowtowed, saying, "I have received a greater mandate to overthrow Yin and receive the mandate of Heaven." King Wu bowed twice more and kowtowed before leaving. 18. King Wu enfeoffed the remaining people of Yin, including Lu Fu, son of King Zhou of Shang. Since Yin was newly established and not yet fully unified, King Wu appointed his brothers Guan Shu Xian and Cai Shu Du to assist Lu Fu in governing Yin. Later, he ordered Duke Shao to release Ji Zi from prison. He ordered Duke Bi to release the prisoners of the people and to mark the gate of Shang Rong. He ordered Nan Gong Kuo to distribute the wealth of the Deer Terrace and the grain of the Giant Bridge to help the poor and weak. He ordered Nan Gong Kuo and Shi Yi to display the Nine Tripods and protect the jade. He ordered Hong Yao to seal the tomb of Bigan. He ordered the priests to offer sacrifices at the army camp. Then he withdrew his troops and returned west. He went on a hunting expedition, recorded political affairs, and wrote the "Wu Cheng" (a military treatise). He enfeoffed the feudal lords, bestowed ancestral vessels, and made utensils to mark the division of Yin. King Wu, remembering the sage kings of the past, bestowed honors upon the descendants of Shennong in Jiao, the descendants of Huangdi in Zhu, the descendants of Emperor Yao in Ji, the descendants of Emperor Shun in Chen, and the descendants of Yu the Great in Qi. He then enfeoffed meritorious officials and advisors, with Grand Master Shangfu being the first to be enfeoffed. He enfeoffed Grand Master Shangfu in Yingqiu, naming it Qi. He enfeoffed his brother, Duke Dan of Zhou, in Qufu, naming it Lu. Duke Shao Shi was enfeoffed in Yan. His younger brother Shu Xian was enfeoffed in Guan, and his younger brother Shu Du in Cai. The rest were enfeoffed in order of rank. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 3.1 (Zhou conquest; King Wu). His great-grandson was Zhongju, who served the Western Rong and guarded the western border. He begat Feilian. Feilian begat Elai. Elai was strong, and Feilian was good at running. Both father and son served King Zhou of Yin with their strength and ability. When King Wu of Zhou attacked King Zhou, he killed Elai. At that time, Feilian was the northern stone tablet for King Zhou. Upon returning, he had nothing to report, so he built an altar on Mount Huotai to report. He obtained a stone coffin with the inscription: "The Emperor ordered Chufu not to participate in the chaos of Yin, and bestowed upon you this stone coffin with the name of Hua." He died and was buried on Mount Huotai. Feilian also had a son named Jisheng. Jisheng begat Mengzeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 2.2. At that time, King Wu of Zhou conquered Yin and sought the descendants of Taibo and Zhongyong, finding Zhouzhang. Zhouzhang was already the ruler of Wu, so he was enfeoffed there. He then enfeoffed Zhouzhang's younger brother Yuzhong in the former Xia territory north of Zhou, making him Yuzhong, and he was listed as a vassal. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 6.1. Two years later, King Zhou killed Prince Bigan and imprisoned Jizi. King Wu was about to attack King Zhou, but the divination by tortoise shell was inauspicious, and a violent storm struck. All the dukes were terrified, but only Taigong strongly persuaded King Wu, so King Wu proceeded. 6.2. On the Jiazi day of the first month of the eleventh year, a vow was made at Muye to attack King Zhou of Shang. King Zhou's army was defeated. King Zhou fled, ascended the Deer Terrace, and King Wu pursued and beheaded him. The next day, King Wu stood at the altar of the god of soil, the dukes offered water, Wei Kangshu sealed the ground with colorful mats, Shi Shangfu led the sacrificial animals, and Shi Yi prepared a prayer to inform the gods of King Zhou's crimes. He distributed money from the Deer Terrace and grain from the Giant Bridge to relieve the poor. He sealed the tomb of Bigan and released Jizi from prison. He moved the Nine Tripods, reformed the Zhou government, and ushered in a new era for the world. Shi Shangfu was largely responsible for the planning. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 1.1. Duke Dan of Zhou was the younger brother of King Wu of Zhou. During the reign of King Wen, Dan was known for his filial piety and benevolence, setting him apart from other sons. When King Wu ascended the throne, Dan consistently assisted him, playing a significant role in affairs. In the ninth year of King Wu's reign, during the eastern campaign to Mengjin, Duke Dan assisted him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 1. Duke Shao shared the same surname as the Zhou dynasty, belonging to the Ji clan. After King Wu of Zhou overthrew King Zhou of Shang, he enfeoffed Duke Shao in the northern Yan region. [Sima Qian, Shiji 61 — Bo Yi Lie Zhuan] 3.3 (approx; conquest of Shang). Upon arriving, King Wen died, and King Wu, carrying a wooden tablet to his head and proclaiming himself King Wen, launched an eastern campaign against King Zhou of Shang. Bo Yi and Shu Qi stopped the king's horse and remonstrated, saying, "Is it filial to leave one's father unburied and then wage war? Is it benevolent to kill one's ruler as a subject?" The attendants wanted to kill them. Taigong said, "These are righteous men," and helped them away.
[1045 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 19. King Wu conquered the rulers of the nine pastures, ascended the hill of Bin, and looked towards the Shang capital. King Wu arrived at Zhou, and from that night he could not sleep. Duke Dan of Zhou approached the king and asked, "Why can't you sleep?" The king replied, "I tell you: Heaven has not blessed Yin. Sixty years have passed since Fa was born, and deer graze in pastures, and wild geese fill the fields. Heaven has not blessed Yin, yet now there is success. Heaven established Yin, and its people numbered three hundred and sixty, neither prominent nor destroyed, until now. I have not yet secured Heaven's protection, how can I sleep!" The king said, "I will secure Heaven's protection, rely on Heaven's house, seek out all evil, and demote the king of Yin. Day and night you have labored to secure my western lands, and I will be honored, and my virtue will be evident. From the Luo River to the Yi River, I will settle easily without being imprisoned, and have the dwelling place of Xia. I look south to the Three Paths, north to the Yuebi, and see the Yellow River, and beyond the Luo and Yi Rivers, not far from Heaven's house." He then established Zhou's residence in Luoyi before leaving. He let his horses roam freely on the sunny side of Mount Hua, and his cattle graze in the peach orchard; he laid down his weapons and dispersed his troops: to show the world that he would no longer be used. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 7. King Wu, having conquered the Shang and established his rule over the world, enfeoffed Grand Master Taigong in Yingqiu, Qi. He traveled eastward to his fiefdom, but his journey was slow. An innkeeper remarked, "I have heard that opportunities are hard to come by and easy to lose. You are sleeping soundly; you are probably not on your way to your fiefdom." Taigong heard this, donned his robes at night, and arrived in his fiefdom at dawn. The Marquis of Lai came to attack, and they contested Yingqiu. Yingqiu bordered Lai. The people of Lai were barbarians; they had come during the chaos of King Zhou's reign, when the Zhou dynasty had just been established, and they were unable to unite the distant lands, thus they contended with Taigong for the fiefdom. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 1.3. In the eleventh year, during the campaign against King Zhou of Shang, reaching Muye, Duke Dan assisted King Wu in composing the Muye Oath. [Sima Qian, Shiji 61 — Bo Yi Lie Zhuan] 3.4 (approx; post-conquest withdrawal). After King Wu quelled the rebellion of Yin, the world submitted to Zhou, but Bo Yi and Shu Qi were ashamed of this. Out of righteousness, they refused to eat Zhou grain and hid in Shouyang Mountain, eating wild vegetables. When they were starving and about to die, they composed a song. His words were: "I climb that western mountain and gather its wild herbs. I replace violence with violence, not knowing that it is wrong. Shennong, Yu, and Xia have suddenly disappeared. Where can I go now? Alas, my life is waning!" He then starved to death on Shouyang Mountain. 4 (discursive; moral reflection). From this perspective, is resentment or evil not evil? 5 (discursive; spans examples across eras). Some say, "Heaven has no favorites, but always favors the virtuous." Were Bo Yi and Shu Qi not virtuous men? They accumulated such benevolence and virtuous conduct, yet starved to death! Moreover, of the seventy disciples, Confucius alone recommended Yan Hui for his love of learning. Yet Hui often went hungry, never tiring of coarse food, and died young. How does Heaven reward the virtuous? Robber Zhi killed innocent people daily, ate human flesh, was violent and tyrannical, gathered thousands of followers and roamed the world, yet he died of old age. What virtue did he possess? This is a particularly egregious example. In recent times, those who behave improperly, deliberately violate taboos, yet live in luxury and enjoy wealth for generations. Some choose their paths carefully, speak only at opportune times, never take shortcuts, and only act out of justice, yet they encounter countless calamities. I am deeply perplexed. Is this so-called Way of Heaven truly right or wrong? 6 (discursive; Confucius quotes). Confucius said, "Those who follow different paths cannot make plans together," meaning each follows their own will. Therefore, he said, "If wealth and honor could be obtained through effort, I would even become a lowly servant. If they cannot be obtained, I will follow my own inclinations." "Only in the cold of winter do we know that the pine and cypress are the last to wither." When the world is corrupt, only then do virtuous people emerge. Is it because their importance is so great, or their insignificance so small? 7 (discursive; incl. later authors cited). A virtuous person grieves for his name to be forgotten after his death. Jia Yi said, "The greedy pursue wealth, the valiant pursue fame, the boastful die for power, and the common people depend on others for survival." "Those of the same kind illuminate each other, and those of the same kind seek each other out." "Clouds follow the dragon, wind follows the tiger, and when a sage arises, all things are revealed." Although Bo Yi and Shu Qi were virtuous, their fame grew even more with the help of Confucius. Although Yan Hui was diligent in his studies, his achievements became more prominent by associating with a worthy successor. The pursuits and choices of reclusive scholars are sometimes so volatile; their names are buried and forgotten—how tragic! Those from humble backgrounds who wish to cultivate their character and establish a name must associate themselves with those who rise to prominence; how can they leave a lasting legacy for posterity?
[1044 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 20. Two years after King Wu conquered Yin, he asked Ji Zi why Yin had perished. Ji Zi could not bear to speak of Yin's evil deeds, but instead advised that the preservation or destruction of a state should be explained. King Wu was also ashamed, so he asked about the ways of Heaven. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 1.4. After defeating the Shang, they entered the Shang palace. Having killed King Zhou, Duke Dan wielded the large axe, while Duke Zhao wielded the small axe, flanking King Wu. 1.5. They offered sacrifices at the altar of the gods of the land, announcing the crimes of King Zhou to Heaven and the people of Shang. They released Ji Zi from prison. They enfeoffed Wu Geng, the son of King Zhou, as his father, and appointed Guan Shu and Cai Shu as his tutors to continue the Shang sacrifices. They enfeoffed meritorious officials and relatives of the same surname. Duke Dan was enfeoffed at Qufu, the former territory of Shao Hao, becoming the Duke of Lu. Duke Dan declined the enfeoffment and remained to assist King Wu.
[1043 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 21. King Wu fell ill. The realm was not yet at peace, and the dukes were fearful. They consulted the oracle, and the Duke of Zhou performed a purification ritual, offering himself as a hostage to succeed King Wu. King Wu recovered. Later, he died, and his son, Prince Song, succeeded him, becoming King Cheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 1.2. In the ninth year of King Wu's reign, during the eastern campaign to Mengjin, Duke Dan assisted him. In the eleventh year, during the campaign against King Zhou of Shang, reaching Muye, Duke Dan assisted King Wu in composing the Muye Oath. After defeating the Shang, they entered the Shang palace. Having killed King Zhou, Duke Dan wielded the large axe, while Duke Zhao wielded the small axe, flanking King Wu. They offered sacrifices at the altar of the gods of the land, announcing the crimes of King Zhou to Heaven and the people of Shang. They released Ji Zi from prison. They enfeoffed Wu Geng, the son of King Zhou, as his father, and appointed Guan Shu and Cai Shu as his tutors to continue the Shang sacrifices. They enfeoffed meritorious officials and relatives of the same surname. 1.6. Duke Dan was enfeoffed at Qufu, the former territory of Shao Hao, becoming the Duke of Lu. Duke Dan declined the enfeoffment and remained to assist King Wu. 2. In the second year after King Wu conquered Yin, the world was not yet at peace. King Wu fell ill and was unwell. His ministers were afraid, so Taigong and Shaogong consulted the oracle. Duke Zhou said, "It is not appropriate to grieve for our former king." Duke Zhou then offered himself as a hostage, set up three altars, stood facing north, wearing a jade disc and holding a jade tablet, and reported to King Tai, King Ji, and King Wen. The historian said, "Your great-grandson, Wang Fa, is diligent but ill. If you three kings have a duty to Heaven to fulfill to your sons, then let Dan replace Wang Fa. Dan is skillful, talented, and capable of serving the spirits. However, Wang Fa is not as talented as Dan and cannot serve the spirits. Therefore, I have been appointed by the Emperor to protect the four directions, so that your descendants may be settled on earth, and the people of the four directions may all revere you. May you not fall from Heaven's mandate, and may my ancestors have a place to rely on forever. Now I will consult the tortoise shell. If you agree, I will return the jade disc and the jade tablet to await your command. If you do not agree, I will discard the jade disc and the jade tablet." The Duke of Zhou had already instructed the historian to inform King Tai, King Ji, and King Wen that he wished to replace King Wu, Fa. So he consulted the three kings by divination. The diviners all said it was auspicious. The Duke of Zhou opened the divination box and saw that it was indeed auspicious. The Duke of Zhou was pleased, opened the divination box, and saw the auspicious sign in the divination. The Duke of Zhou entered to congratulate King Wu, saying, "Your Majesty will be unharmed. You have just received the mandate of heaven from three kings, and your plans will last until the end. This way, you will remember me alone." The Duke of Zhou hid his strategy in a golden box and instructed the guard not to speak of it. The next day, King Wu recovered. 3. After King Wu's death, King Cheng was young and in his prime. Fearing that the world would rebel upon hearing of King Wu's death, the Duke of Zhou ascended the throne and assumed the reins of government in place of King Cheng. Guan Shu and his brothers spread rumors throughout the country, saying, "The Duke of Zhou will bring misfortune to King Cheng." The Duke of Zhou then addressed Taigong Wang and Shaogong Shi, saying, "The reason I did not step down but assumed the reins of government is because I feared the world would rebel against Zhou, and I would have no way to report to my ancestors, King Tai, King Ji, and King Wen. The three kings have long worried and toiled for the world, and now their efforts are finally fulfilled. King Wu died young, and King Cheng is still young; I will bring peace to Zhou, and this is why I have done this." Thus, he finally became the regent for King Cheng, and sent his son, Bo Qin, to be enfeoffed in Lu in his place. The Duke of Zhou admonished Bo Qin, saying, "I am the son of King Wen, the brother of King Wu, and the uncle of King Cheng; I am not lowly in the eyes of the world. Yet, I wash my hair three times, spit out my food three times, and rise three times to await scholars, still fearing I might lose a wise man from the world. When you go to Lu, be careful not to be arrogant because of your state." [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 3. During the reign of King Wen of Zhou, a descendant of Ji Lian was named Yu Xiong. Yu Xiong served King Wen but died young. His son was named Xiong Li. Xiong Li begat Xiong Kuang, and Xiong Kuang begat Xiong Yi. During the reign of King Cheng of Zhou, Xiong Yi was enfeoffed in Chu Man, a place of viscountry lands, with the surname Mi, and resided in Danyang. Xiong Yi, the son of King Bo Qin of Lu, Kang Shu Zi Mou of Wei, Marquis Xie of Jin, and Tai Gong Zi Lü Ji of Qi all served King Cheng.
[1042 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 22.1. When King Cheng was young, the Zhou dynasty had just established itself. Fearing the feudal lords would rebel, the Duke of Zhou assumed the administration of the state. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 4. Guan Shu, Cai Shu, Wu Geng, and others indeed led the Huai Yi in rebellion. The Duke of Zhou, acting on King Cheng's orders, raised an army to the east and issued a great proclamation. He then executed Guan Shu, killed Wu Geng, and exiled Cai Shu. He gathered the remaining people of Yin and enfeoffed Kang Shu in Wei and Wei Zi in Song to continue the Yin sacrifices. The eastern lands of the Huai Yi were pacified, and the rebellion was completed within two years. All the feudal lords submitted to the Zhou dynasty. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 2.1. During the reign of King Cheng, King Shao was appointed one of the Three Dukes: the Duke of Shao governed the area west of Shan; the Duke of Zhou governed the area east of Shan. King Cheng was young, and the Duke of Zhou acted as regent. 2.2. When the Duke of Shao ascended the throne, he was suspicious of him and made a covenant with the Duke of Zhou. The Duke of Zhou did not approve of the Duke of Zhou's appointment. The Duke of Zhou then said, "In the time of Tang, there was Yi Yin, who received divine assistance; in the time of Taiwu, there were Yi Zhi and Chen Hu, who received divine assistance; and Wu Xian governed the royal household; in the time of Zu Yi, there was Wu Xian; and in the time of Wu Ding, there was Gan Ban: leading the Chen dynasty, protecting and governing the Yin dynasty." Then the Duke of Shao was pleased. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 1. Tang Shuyu of Jin was the son of King Wu of Zhou and the younger brother of King Cheng. Initially, when King Wu met with Shuyu's mother, he dreamed that Heaven told him, "I command you to give birth to a son, named Yu, and I will give him Tang." When the son was born, the character "Yu" was written on his hand, so he was named Yu. 2. King Wu died, and King Cheng ascended the throne. A rebellion broke out in Tang, and the Duke of Zhou quelled it. King Cheng was joking with Shu Yu, and he cut a paulownia leaf into a jade tablet and gave it to Shu Yu, saying, "I enfeoff you with this." Shi Yi then requested that a day be chosen to enfeoff Shu Yu. King Cheng said, "I was just joking with him." Shi Yi said, "The Son of Heaven does not speak in jest. His words are recorded by the historian, celebrated with ceremony, and sung with music." Therefore, Shu Yu was enfeoffed in Tang. Tang was located east of the Yellow River and the Fen River, covering an area of one hundred li, hence the name Tang Shu Yu. His surname was Ji, and his given name was Zi Yu.
[1041 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 5.1. Heaven bestowed blessings, and Tang Shu obtained a grain, which, though from a different mother, had the same ear. He presented it to King Cheng, who ordered Tang Shu to give it to the Duke of Zhou in the eastern lands, thus creating the poem "Gifting Grain."
[1040 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 22.2. Guan Shu, Cai Shu, and their brothers, suspecting the Duke of Zhou, rebelled with Wu Geng. The Duke of Zhou, acting on King Cheng's orders, attacked and executed Wu Geng and Guan Shu, and exiled Cai Shu. He appointed Wei Zi Kai to replace the Yin dynasty, establishing the state of Song. He also gathered the remaining Yin people and enfeoffed King Wu's younger brother as Kang Shu of Wei. Tang Shu of Jin obtained fine grain and presented it to King Cheng, who then returned it to the Duke of Zhou at the military camp. The Duke of Zhou received grain from the eastern lands, by order of the King of Lu. Initially, Guan and Cai rebelled against Zhou, and the Duke of Zhou quelled their rebellion, restoring order within three years. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 8. When Taigong arrived in Qi, he reformed the government, adapted to local customs, simplified rituals, promoted commerce and industry, and facilitated the trade of fish and salt. As a result, many people flocked to Qi, making it a powerful state. Later, when King Cheng of Zhou was young, the Guan and Cai tribes rebelled, and the Huai Yi tribes turned against Zhou. King Cheng then sent Duke Kang of Shao to instruct Taigong: "From the sea in the east to the Yellow River in the west, from Muling in the south to Wudi in the north, you have the right to conquer the five marquises and nine earls." Qi thus gained the right to wage war and became a powerful state. Its capital was Yingqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 5.2. The Duke of Zhou, having received the gift of grain, rejoiced in the Son of Heaven's command and composed the poem "Auspicious Grain." The eastern lands gathered the grain, and the Duke of Zhou returned to report to King Cheng, composing a poem for the king, which he named "Owl." The king, however, dared not instruct the Duke of Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 3. When Duke Shao governed the west, he won the hearts of the people. During his tour of the villages, there was a pear tree there. He adjudicated cases and handled government affairs under it, and everyone, from nobles and earls to commoners, was properly appointed, with no one neglecting their duties. After Duke Shao's death, the people missed his governance and cherished the pear tree, daring not to cut it down. They sang its praises, composing the poem "The Sweet Pear Tree."
[1039 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 6. In the second month of the seventh year of King Cheng, on the day of Yiwei, the king marched from Zhou to Feng, and sent the Grand Protector, Duke Shao, to Luoyang to inspect the land. In the third month, the Duke of Zhou went to build the city of Luoyang, and after divining the location, he said it was auspicious, so he established the state there.
[1038 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 22.3. Therefore, he first wrote the Great Proclamation, then the Order of Wei Zi, then the Return of Grain, then the Fine Grain, then the Kang Proclamation, the Wine Proclamation, and the Timber Proclamation; these events are recorded in the Duke of Zhou's writings. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 3.2 (King Cheng era; traditional). Mengzeng was favored by King Cheng of Zhou and became the son of Gaolang. Gaolang begat Hengfu, and Hengfu begat Zaofu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 7. King Cheng grew up and was able to govern. Therefore, the Duke of Zhou returned power to King Cheng, and King Cheng held court. During the Duke of Zhou's tenure as regent, he faced south and relied on the presence of the feudal lords. Seven years later, he returned power to King Cheng, facing north to assume his position as a subject, trembling with awe. 8.1. In the beginning, when King Cheng was young, he fell ill. The Duke of Zhou then threw himself into the river early in the morning, praying to the gods, "Your Majesty is young and lacks understanding; the one who defies the gods' command is Dan." He also hid his plans in his palace. King Cheng's illness improved.
[1037 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 8.2. Later, when King Cheng came to power, some people slandered the Duke of Zhou, who fled to Chu. King Cheng opened his palace and saw the Duke of Zhou's prayer letter. He wept and returned to the Duke of Zhou. 9 (discursive). When the Duke of Zhou returned, he feared that King Cheng, now grown old, might become dissolute and indulge in extravagance. Therefore, he established the system of having many officials and the system of not being idle. Wu Yi said: "As parents, we should strive for a long-lasting career. If our children and grandchildren become arrogant and extravagant, they will ruin their families. How can a son not be careful! In the past, King Zhongzong of Yin was solemn and respectful of the Mandate of Heaven. He governed the people with utmost care and fear, and dared not be idle. Therefore, Zhongzong enjoyed the kingdom for seventy-five years. King Gaozong, on the other hand, worked hard outside the capital for a long time. He associated with petty men and arranged for his ascension to the throne. He was both wise and foolish. He remained silent for three years. When he spoke, he was full of clamor. He dared not be idle and secretly brought peace to the Yin kingdom. No one, large or small, complained. Therefore, Gaozong enjoyed the kingdom for fifty-five years. King Zujia was unjust and treated the king unjustly. He associated with petty men for a long time. He knew the support of petty men and was able to protect and give to the common people. He did not insult the poor and weak. Therefore, Zujia enjoyed the kingdom for thirty-three years." Duo Shi said: "From Tang to Di Yi, all the emperors worshipped the virtues of the king. All the emperors were worthy of Heaven. But the successor King Zhou was licentious and dissolute. He did not care about Heaven or the people. His people all deserved to be punished." (Zhou Duo Shi) "King Wen did not have time to eat even at midday and after sunset, and enjoyed the kingdom for fifty years." This was written to warn King Cheng.
[1036 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 22.4. After seven years of administration, King Cheng grew up, and the Duke of Zhou returned power to King Cheng, assuming the positions of his ministers. 23. King Cheng, while in Feng, ordered Duke Shao to rebuild Luoyi, as King Wu had intended. Duke Zhou again consulted the oracle and inspected the site, and the construction was completed, with the Nine Tripods placed there. He declared, "This is the center of the world; the distances for tribute from all directions are equal." He then composed the proclamations of Shao and Luo. After King Cheng relocated the remnants of the Yin people, Duke Zhou informed him of the king's decree, and appointed many officials and no idle men. Duke Shao served as protector, and Duke Zhou as teacher, leading an eastern campaign against the Huaiyi, destroying Yan, and relocating its ruler, Bo Peng. King Cheng returned from Yan to Zongzhou, where he composed many officials. Having overthrown the Yin mandate, he attacked the Huaiyi, returned to Feng, and established the Zhou officials. He revived rites and music, reformed the system, and the people lived in harmony, with songs of praise flourishing. After King Cheng's campaign against the Eastern Yi, the Xi Shen came to offer congratulations, and the king bestowed upon Rong Bo a gift and a mandate from the Xi Shen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 10. When King Cheng was in Feng, the world was at peace, but the Zhou government was not in order. Therefore, the Duke of Zhou established the Zhou officials, assigning specific roles and responsibilities, and created a system of governance for the benefit of the people. The people said...
[1035 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 11. When the Duke of Zhou was in Feng, he fell ill and was about to die. He said, "You must bury me in Chengzhou to show that I dare not leave King Cheng." After the Duke of Zhou died, King Cheng also declined and buried the Duke of Zhou in Bi, following King Wen, to show that he, the young king, dared not be a subject of the Duke of Zhou. 12.1. After the Duke of Zhou's death, the autumn harvest failed, and a violent storm with thunder and rain struck, flattening all the crops and uprooting all the large trees. The state of Zhou was greatly alarmed. King Cheng, dressed in his court robes, opened a golden-bound book, and the king discovered the Duke of Zhou's account of his supposed success in replacing King Wu. The two dukes and the king then consulted the historian Bai, who said, "It is true. The Duke of Zhou once commanded me not to speak of it."
[1034 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 12.2. King Cheng, holding the book, wept, saying, "From now on, may there be no more erroneous divination! The Duke of Zhou diligently served the royal family, but I, being young, was unaware of it. Today, I am displaying my power to demonstrate the Duke of Zhou's virtue. I, the young king, should welcome him, and my state should also perform the proper rites." The king went to the outskirts of the city, and it rained, the wind reversed, and all the crops rose. The two dukes ordered the people of the state to raise up all the flattened large trees and rebuild them. The harvest was abundant that year. King Cheng then ordered the state of Lu to offer sacrifices to King Wen in the suburbs. Lu then established a system of rites and music for the Son of Heaven to praise the virtue of the Duke of Zhou. 13. When the Duke of Zhou died, his son Bo Qin, who had already been enfeoffed, became the Duke of Lu. When Bo Qin first received his fief in Lu, it took him three years to report back to the Duke of Zhou on his governance. The Duke of Zhou asked, "Why so late?" Bo Qin replied, "I changed their customs and reformed their rites, and only after a three-year mourning period did I abolish them; hence the delay." Taigong was also enfeoffed in Qi, and reported back to the Duke of Zhou on his governance after five months. The Duke of Zhou asked, "Why so quick?" He replied, "I simplified the rites between ruler and subject and followed their customs." Later, upon hearing that Bo Qin's reporting of his governance was delayed, he sighed, "Alas, the future of Lu will surely be subservient to Qi! If governance is not simple and easy to change, the people will not be close to it; if it is simple and approachable to the people, the people will surely turn to it."
[1033 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 14. After Bo Qin ascended the throne, the Guan and Cai tribes rebelled, and the Huaiyi and Xu Rong tribes also rose in rebellion. Bo Qin then led his army to attack them at Xi, where he made the Xi Oath, saying: "Display your armor and armor, none dare to be disobedient. None dare to harm the barbarians. Let your horses and cattle roam freely, and let your servants and concubines flee; do not dare to overstep your bounds, but respectfully return them. None dare to raid or plunder, or scale the walls. The people of Lu have placed your straw, reeds, provisions, and timber at the three suburbs and three tunnels; none dare to fail to provide them. I will build them on the day of Jiaxu and then attack the Xu Rong; none dare to fall behind, or face severe punishment." Having made this Xi Oath, he pacified the Xu Rong and restored order to Lu.
[1032 BC]
[1031 BC]
[1030 BC]
[1029 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 15.1. Duke Boqin of Lu died, and his son, Duke Kao, ascended the throne. Duke Kao died in the fourth year, and his younger brother, Xi, succeeded him, becoming Duke Yang. Duke Yang built a thatched gate. He died in the sixth year, and his son, Duke You, succeeded him. Duke You lived for fourteen years. Duke You's younger brother, Fei, killed Duke You and seized the throne, becoming Duke Wei.
[1028 BC]
[1027 BC]
[1026 BC]
[1025 BC]
[1024 BC]
[1023 BC]
[1022 BC]
[1021 BC]
[1020 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 2. Ji Sheng begat Meng Zeng. Meng Zeng was favored by King Cheng of Zhou and became known as Zhai Gaolang. Gaolang begat Hengfu, and Hengfu begat Zaofu. Zaofu was favored by King Mu of Zhou. Zaofu took a fine steed and, along with three others—Li, Hualiu, and Lüer—from the Peach Forest, presented them to King Mu. King Mu had Zaofu drive him on a western tour, where he met the Queen Mother of the West and was so delighted that he forgot to return home. Meanwhile, King Xu Yan rebelled, and King Mu, riding a thousand-mile horse daily, attacked King Xu Yan and defeated him decisively. Zaofu was then granted the city of Zhao, and thus the Zhao clan originated.
[1019 BC]
[1018 BC]

[1006 BC]
[1005 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 24. When King Cheng was about to die, fearing that Crown Prince Zhao would not be up to the task, he ordered Duke Shao and Duke Bi to lead the feudal lords to assist the Crown Prince and establish him as emperor. After King Cheng died, the two dukes led the feudal lords to present Crown Prince Zhao at the ancestral temple, reiterating the difficult path King Wen and King Wu had taken to establish their kingdoms, emphasizing the importance of frugality, avoiding excessive desires, and governing with unwavering faith, thus fulfilling their dying wishes. Crown Prince Zhao was then established as emperor, becoming King Kang. Upon ascending the throne, King Kang proclaimed to all the feudal lords the achievements of King Wen and King Wu, composing the " Kang Proclamation ." Therefore, during the reigns of King Cheng and King Kang, the world was at peace, and punishments were not used for over forty years. King Kang then ordered Duke Bi, who was in charge of drafting plans, to reside in a separate village near the capital, Chengzhou, and to compose the " Bi Mandate ."
[1004 BC]
[1003 BC]
[1002 BC]
[1001 BC]
[1000 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 15.2. Duke Wei died in the fiftieth year, and his son, Duke Li, ascended the throne. Duke Li died in the thirty-seventh year, and the people of Lu established his younger brother, Ju, as Duke Xian. Duke Xian died in the thirty-second year, and his son, Duke Zhen, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 4. Xiong Yi begat Xiong Ai, Xiong Ai begat Xiong Dan, and Xiong Dan begat Xiong Sheng. Xiong Sheng adopted his younger brother Xiong Yang as his heir. Xiong Yang begat Xiong Qu.
[999 BC]

[978 BC]
[977 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 25. King Kang died, and his son, King Zhao Xia, ascended the throne. During King Zhao's reign, the royal way was in decline. King Zhao went on a southern tour but never returned, dying on the riverbank. His death was not reported, a matter of concealment. His son, Prince Man, was enthroned, becoming King Mu. King Mu was fifty years old when he ascended the throne. The royal way was in decline, and King Mu, lamenting the lack of virtue in the ways of Kings Wen and Wu, ordered Bo Huang to reiterate the administration of the state under the Grand Steward, composing the Huang Mandate. Peace returned.
[976 BC]
[975 BC]
[974 BC]
[973 BC]
[972 BC]
[971 BC]

[951 BC]
[950 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 26. King Mu was about to wage war against the Quanrong when Duke Ji Moufu advised against it, saying, "It is not advisable. The former kings displayed their virtue without observing military campaigns. Armies are only used when they are at rest; when they are used, they are awe-inspiring. If they are observed, they become complacent, and if they are complacent, they lose their power. Therefore, the ode of Duke Wen of Zhou says: 'We sheath our weapons and arrows, we draw our bows and arrows; we seek virtuous conduct, and spread it throughout the land, so that the king may protect it.' The former kings, in their dealings with the people, cultivated their virtue and enriched their nature, provided them with abundant resources and useful tools, clarified the boundaries of benefit and harm, and educated them with culture, so that they would pursue benefit and avoid harm, cherish virtue and fear power. Therefore, they were able to preserve the dynasty and increase its prosperity. In the past, our former kings served Hou Ji." The Yu and Xia dynasties. When the Xia dynasty declined, they abandoned the cultivation of grain and neglected their duties. Our ancestor, King Buzhu, lost his official post and fled to the lands of the Rong and Di tribes. He dared not neglect his duties, but diligently upheld virtue, followed traditions, and revised precepts, working diligently day and night, upholding them with sincerity and loyalty. Generation after generation, they carried on this virtuous legacy, not disgracing their predecessors. As for King Wen and King Wu, they illuminated the brilliance of their predecessors and added benevolence and harmony, serving the gods and protecting the people, who were all delighted. King Di Xin of Shang greatly harmed the people, and the common people could not bear it. They rejoiced in King Wu's example and brought the Rong tribes to Shang. Therefore, our ancestor did not pursue military power, but rather encouraged and cared for the people's grievances and eliminated their harm. Yes. The system established by the former kings was as follows: within the state, the Dianfu (甸服); outside the state, the Houfu (侯服); the Houwei (侯卫) and Binfu (宾服); the Yi and Man (夷蛮) and Yaofu (要服); the Rong and Di (戎翟) and Huangfu (荒服). Those in the Dianfu were to offer sacrifices; those in the Houfu were to perform rituals; those in the Binfu were to enjoy offerings; those in the Yaofu were to pay tribute; and those in the Huangfu were to be kings. There were daily sacrifices, monthly rituals, seasonal offerings, annual tributes, and ultimately, kingship. The former kings' obedience to rituals meant that if they did not offer sacrifices, they would cultivate their intentions; if they did not perform rituals, they would cultivate their words; if they did not enjoy offerings, they would cultivate their writings; if they did not pay tribute, they would cultivate their reputation; if they did not become kings, they would cultivate their virtue. If the order was completed but some were not fulfilled, punishments were imposed. Thus, there were punishments for not offering sacrifices, not performing rituals during war, not enjoying offerings during conquest, not paying tribute during conceding, and not becoming kings after proclamations. Thus, there were punishments. The punishments are based on military force, preparations for conquest, decrees of authority, and proclamations. If decrees are issued and pronouncements are made but not followed, then one should cultivate virtue and not burden the people in distant lands. Therefore, those near will obey, and those far will submit. Now, since the end of the reigns of Da Bi and Bo Shi, the Quanrong clan has come to the king with their duties. The emperor said, "I will surely punish them for not offering tribute, and also observe their military might." Would this not be abandoning the teachings of the former kings, and would the king be on the verge of collapse? I have heard that the Quanrong have established a strong foundation, upholding their old virtues and remaining steadfast to the end; they have the means to defend themselves against us.” The king then attacked them, and returned with four white wolves and four white deer. From then on, those from the remote regions no longer came. 27. If any of the feudal lords are at odds, Marquis Fu speaks to the king, requesting the revision of the penal code. The king says, "Alas! You who govern a state and possess land, I shall inform you of the proper penal code. Now, you are bringing peace to your people. Why choose the wrong person? Why administer the wrong punishment? Why allow the wrong dwelling? When both parties are present, the judge shall hear five arguments. If the five arguments are clear and convincing, they shall be corrected according to the five punishments. If the five punishments are not clear and convincing, they shall be corrected according to the five penalties. If the five penalties are not accepted, they shall be corrected according to the five transgressions. For the faults of the five transgressions, the official prison and the inner prison shall examine the facts of the crime and determine the fault. If there is doubt in the five punishments, there may be a pardon; if there is doubt in the five penalties, there may be a pardon. The investigation shall be thorough. If there is a large number of people who are clear and convincing, the interrogation shall be conducted with due diligence." Without doubt or hesitation, let us uphold the solemnity of Heaven. For those suspected of tattooing, a pardon is granted, with a 100% penalty, subject to verification of the crime. For those suspected of nose amputation, a pardon is granted, with double the penalty, subject to verification of the crime. For those suspected of kneecap amputation, a pardon is granted, with double the penalty, subject to verification of the crime. For those suspected of castration, a pardon is granted, with a 500% penalty, subject to verification of the crime. For those suspected of capital punishment, a pardon is granted, with a 1000% penalty, subject to verification of the crime. The categories of tattooing punishment are 1000, nose amputation punishment is 1000, kneecap amputation punishment is 500, castration punishment is 300, and capital punishment is 200; the five punishments total 3000. This is called the "Fu Xing" (甫刑). [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 3.3 (King Mu era; traditional). Zaofu was favored by King Mu of Zhou for his skill in driving a chariot. He obtained four chariots: Ji, Wenli, Hualiu, and Luer. He went on a western hunting expedition and was so happy that he forgot to return. When King Xu Yan rebelled, Zaofu became King Mu's charioteer and drove back to Zhou, covering a thousand miles in a day to quell the rebellion. King Mu enfeoffed Zaofu with the city of Zhao, and Zaofu's clan thus became the Zhao family. From Feilian's son Jisheng down to Zaofu, five generations later, they settled separately in Zhao. Zhao Shuai was their descendant. Elai Ge was Feilian's son, and he died young. He had a son named Nüfang. Nüfang begat Panggao, Panggao begat Taiji, Taiji begat Dalu, and Dalu begat Feizi. Because of Zaofu's favor, they all received the city of Zhao and adopted the surname Zhao.
[949 BC]
[948 BC]
[947 BC]
[946 BC]
[945 BC]
[944 BC]
[943 BC]
[942 BC]
[941 BC]
[940 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 9. More than a hundred years after the death of Taigong, his son Dinggong Lüji succeeded him. After Dinggong died, his son Yigong De succeeded him. After Yigong died, his son Guigong Cimu succeeded him. After Guigong died, his son Aigong Buchen succeeded him.

[924 BC]
[923 BC]
[922 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 28. King Mu reigned for fifty-five years before his death, and his son, King Gong (Yihu), ascended the throne. King Gong was traveling along the Jing River when Duke Kang of Mi accompanied him. Three women eloped with him. Their mother said, "You must bring them to the king. Animals in groups of three form a herd, people in groups of three form a crowd, and women in groups of three form a 'can' (a type of offering). The king does not take from herds when hunting, does not deign to serve in the public sphere, and does not allow a single clan to accompany him in his chariots. 'Can' is a beautiful thing. The crowd has given you a beautiful thing; what virtue do you possess to deserve it? Even the king cannot bear it, let alone you, a mere clown! A clown who possesses such things will surely perish." Duke Kang did not offer them. A year later, King Gong destroyed Mi. King Gong died, and his son, King Yi (Jian), ascended the throne. During King Yi's reign, the royal family declined, and poets wrote satirical works.
[921 BC]
[920 BC]
[919 BC]
[918 BC]
[917 BC]
[916 BC]
[915 BC]
[914 BC]
[913 BC]
[912 BC]
[911 BC]

[909 BC]

[907 BC]
[906 BC]
[905 BC]
[904 BC]
[903 BC]
[902 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 10. During the reign of Duke Ai, the Marquis of Ji slandered him to the Zhou court, and the Zhou court executed Duke Ai and installed his younger brother Jing as the new ruler, who became Duke Hu. Duke Hu moved the capital to Bopeng, which coincided with the reign of King Yi of Zhou.
[901 BC]
[900 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 3.1 (very approximate; long genealogy). Zhou Zhang died, and his son Xiong Sui succeeded him. Xiong Sui died, and his son Ke Xiang succeeded him. Ke Xiang died, and his son Qiang Jiuyi succeeded him. Qiang Jiuyi died, and his son Yu Qiaoyiwu succeeded him. Yu Qiaoyiwu died, and his son Ke Lu succeeded him. Ke Lu died, and his son Zhou Yao succeeded him. Zhou Yao died, and his son Qu Yu succeeded him. Qu Yu died, and his son Yi Wu succeeded him. Yi Wu died, and his son Qin Chu succeeded him. Qin Chu died, and his son Zhuan succeeded him. Zhuan died, and his son Po Gao succeeded him. Po Gao died, and his son Ju Bei succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 3. Tang Shu's son, Xie, became the Marquis of Jin. The Marquis of Jin's son, Ningzu, became the Marquis of Wu. The Marquis of Wu's son, Furen, became the Marquis of Cheng. The Marquis of Cheng's son, Fu, became the Marquis of Li. The Marquis of Li's son, Yijiu, became the Marquis of Jing. From the Marquis of Jing onwards, their ages can be estimated. From Tang Shu to the Marquis of Jing, there were five generations, but their exact years are unknown. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 5.1. Xiong Qu had a son three years prior.
[899 BC]
[898 BC]
[897 BC]
[896 BC]
[895 BC]
[894 BC]
[893 BC]
[892 BC]
[891 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 29. When King Yi died, his brother Pi Fang ascended the throne as King Xiao. When King Xiao died, the feudal lords reinstated King Yi's crown prince, Xie, who became King Yi.
[890 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 11. Duke Ai's younger brother, Shan Yuan, harbored resentment towards Duke Hu. He and his followers led the people of Yingqiu in an attack, killing Duke Hu and establishing themselves as Duke Xian. In the first year of Duke Xian's reign, he expelled all of Duke Hu's sons and moved the capital to Bopeng, establishing his rule in Linzi.
[889 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 4 (King Xiao of Zhou enfeoffment). Fei Zi lived in Quanqiu, where he loved horses and livestock and was skilled at raising them. The people of Quanqiu told King Xiao of Zhou about this, and King Xiao summoned him to manage the horses between the Qian and Wei rivers. The horses multiplied greatly. King Xiao wanted to make him the heir of Da Luo. The daughter of Marquis Shen married Da Luo and gave birth to a son, Cheng, who became the heir. Marquis Shen then said to King Xiao, "In the past, my ancestor, the daughter of Mount Li, was the wife of Rong Xu Xuan and gave birth to Zhong Ju. Because of kinship, she returned to Zhou and protected the western border, which was peaceful because of her. Now I have married Da Luo and given birth to a son, Cheng. Shen and Luo have remarried, and the western Rong all submit, which is why I am king. Your Majesty should consider this." So King Xiao said, "In the past, Boyi managed livestock for Shun, and the livestock multiplied, so he was given land and the surname Ying. Now his descendants also raise horses for me, so I will grant them land as vassals." He sent the city of Qin to continue the Ying clan's sacrifices, and they were called Qin Ying. He also did not abolish the marriage of Marquis Shen's daughter to Da Luo, in order to make peace with the western Rong.
[888 BC]
[887 BC]
[886 BC]
[885 BC]
[884 BC]
[883 BC]
[882 BC]
[881 BC]
[880 BC]
[879 BC]
[878 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 30. King Yi died, and his son King Li Hu ascended the throne. King Li reigned for thirty years, was greedy for profit, and favored Duke Rong Yi. The Grand Master Rui Liangfu advised King Li, saying, “Will the royal house decline? Rong Gong is fond of monopolizing profits and is unaware of the great calamities. Profit is the source of all things, the foundation of heaven and earth, yet to monopolize it brings countless harms. Heaven and earth and all things will take from it; how can it be monopolized? It incurs much anger and fails to prepare for great calamities. If you teach the king this way, how can the king last long? A true king is one who guides profit and spreads it throughout the realm. He should ensure that gods, men, and all things have their limits, yet still live in constant fear and resentment. Therefore, the * Odes * say, ‘Thinking of Hou Ji, who matched Heaven, established our people, none are without your reach.’ The *Great Odes* say, ‘The bestowal of gifts carries on the Zhou dynasty.’ It is because they did not spread profit and feared difficulties that the Zhou dynasty was able to continue to this day. Now, Your Majesty studies monopolization; is this acceptable? Even a commoner who monopolizes is called a thief; if a king does this, his fate will be bleak. If Rong Gong is employed, the Zhou dynasty will surely perish.” King Li did not listen and ultimately appointed Rong Gong as a high-ranking official, allowing him to wield power.
[877 BC]
[876 BC]
[875 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 5.2. During the reign of King Yi of Zhou, the royal family was weak, and the feudal lords sometimes refused to pay tribute and fought each other. Xiong Qu had won the support of the peaceful people of the Jianghan region, and thus raised an army to attack Yong and Yangchai, reaching as far as E. Xiong Qu said, "I am a barbarian, and I do not deserve the titles and honors of the Central Plains." He then established his eldest son Kang as King Gou Dan, his middle son Hong as King E, and his youngest son Zhici as King Yue Zhang, all residing in the Chu-barbarian lands along the Yangtze River. During the reign of King Li of Zhou, who was tyrannical, Xiong Qu, fearing his attack on Chu, also relinquished his kingship.
[874 BC]
[873 BC]
[872 BC]
[871 BC]
[870 BC]
[869 BC]
[868 BC]
[867 BC]
[866 BC]
[865 BC]
[864 BC]
[863 BC]
[862 BC]
[861 BC]
[860 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 6. Later came Xiong Wukang, who died young. Xiong Qu died, and his son Xiong Zhihong succeeded him. Zhihong died, and his younger brother murdered him and took his place, becoming Xiong Yan. Xiong Yan begat Xiong Yong.
[859 BC]
[858 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 5.1 (Feizi death year). Qin Ying begat Qin Hou. Qin Hou reigned for ten years and died. He begat Gong Bo. Gong Bo reigned for three years and died. He begat Qin Zhong.
[857 BC]
[856 BC]
[855 BC]
[854 BC]
[853 BC]
[852 BC]
[851 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 12.1. In the ninth year, Duke Xian died, and his son, Duke Wu, ascended the throne.
[850 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 3. From Zao Fu down six generations to Yan Fu, also known as Gong Zhong, who served as charioteer during the campaign against the Rong during the reign of King Xuan of Zhou.
