During the Battle of Qianmu, Yan Fu escaped King Xuan's clutches. Yan Fu begat Shu Dai. During Shu Dai's reign, King You of Zhou was tyrannical, so he left Zhou for Jin, served Marquis Wen of Jin, and established the Zhao clan in the state of Jin.
[849 BC]
[848 BC]
[847 BC]
[846 BC]
[845 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 31.1. King Li was tyrannical and extravagant, and the people criticized him. Duke Shao advised him, saying, "The people cannot bear this fate." The king was enraged and obtained a sorcerer from Wei to monitor those who spoke ill of him; anyone who reported him was killed. Slander decreased, and the feudal lords ceased paying homage. In the thirty-fourth year, the king became even more severe, and the people dared not speak, communicating only with their eyes in the streets. King Li was pleased and told Duke Shao, "I have silenced the slander; now they dare not speak." Duke Shao said, "This is like blocking a floodgate. Preventing the people from speaking is more difficult than preventing floods. If a floodgate is blocked, it will burst, causing great harm; the same is true for the people. Therefore, those who manage water must dredge it to guide it; those who govern the people must encourage them to speak. Thus, when the Son of Heaven listens to the government, he has ministers and even lower-ranking officials present poems, blind musicians present songs, historians present books, teachers offer admonitions, blind musicians recite poems, children recite texts, artisans offer advice, commoners relay messages, close ministers offer remonstrances, and relatives supplement the emperor's teachings." "Observe, the blind historians teach, the elders refine, and then the king deliberates, so that things proceed without error. The people have mouths, just as the land has mountains and rivers; resources are produced from them. Just as the plains and marshes are fertile, clothing and food are produced from them. The words spoken by the mouth are the source of good and bad fortune. Doing good and preparing for failure are the means to produce resources, clothing, and food. The people think in their hearts and express it with their mouths, and then act on it. If their mouths are blocked, how much can they achieve?" The king did not listen. As a result, no one in the country dared to speak out.
[844 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 6.1 (Qin Zhong begins; regnal yr 1). Qin Zhong reigned for three years. King Li of Zhou was tyrannical, and some of the feudal lords rebelled. The Western Rong rebelled against the royal family and exterminated the clan of Da Luo at Quanqiu.
[843 BC]
[842 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 12.2. In the ninth year of Duke Wu's reign, King Li of Zhou fled and resided in Zhi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 16.1. In the fourteenth year of Duke Zhen's reign, King Li of Zhou, being tyrannical, fled to Zhi and established the Gonghe Regency. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 4. In the seventeenth year of the reign of King Jing, King Li of Zhou was deluded and tyrannical, and the people rebelled. King Li fled to Zhi, and the ministers took over the administration, hence the name "Gonghe" (Republic). [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 7.1. In the sixth year of Xiong Yong's reign, the Zhou people rebelled and attacked King Li, who fled to Zhi.
[841 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 31.2. After three years, they rebelled and attacked King Li. King Li fled to Zhi. 32. Prince Jing, the crown prince of King Li, hid in the house of Duke Shao. When the people of the state heard of this, they surrounded the house. Duke Shao said, "In the past, I repeatedly advised the king, but the king did not listen, which led to this trouble. Now, if I kill the crown prince, will the king consider me an enemy and be angry? A person who serves his lord should not be angry even in dangerous situations, nor should he be resentful. How much more so should he serve the king!" So he substituted his son for the crown prince, and the crown prince was able to escape. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 12.3. In the tenth year, the royal court was in turmoil, and the ministers took charge of the government, which was called the "Republic." In the twenty-fourth year, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 4. From Duke Shao down nine generations to Marquis Hui. Marquis Hui of Yan lived during the time when King Li of Zhou fled to Zhi and the Gonghe Regency was in effect. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 5. In the eighteenth year, Marquis Jing died, and his son, Marquis Li, succeeded him as Minister of Works. In the fourteenth year of Marquis Li's reign, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne. In the eighteenth year, Marquis Li died, and his son, Marquis Xian, succeeded him as King Ji. In the eleventh year of Marquis Xian's reign, Marquis Mu, King Fei, succeeded him as King Fei.
[840 BC]
[839 BC]
[838 BC]
[837 BC]
[836 BC]
[835 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 7.2. In the tenth year of Xiong Yong's reign, he died, and his younger brother Xiong Yan became his successor.
[834 BC]
[833 BC]
[832 BC]
[831 BC]
[830 BC]
[829 BC]
[828 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 33. The Duke of Shao and the Duke of Zhou served as prime ministers, and the government was called the "Republic." In the fourteenth year of the Republic, King Li died in Zhi. Crown Prince Jing, who grew up in the Duke of Shao's household, was jointly enthroned by the two prime ministers as King Xuan. Upon King Xuan's ascension to the throne, the two prime ministers assisted him, reformed the government, and followed the traditions of Kings Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang. The feudal lords resumed their veneration of Zhou. In the twelfth year, Duke Wu of Lu came to pay homage. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 6.2 (Qin Zhong yr 17; King Li→Gonghe/Xuan context). King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne and appointed Qin Zhong as a high official, who then executed the Western Rong. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 8. Xiong Yan died in the tenth year of his reign. He had four sons: the eldest, Bo Shuang; the middle son, Zhong Xue; the second son, Shu Kan; and the youngest son, Ji Xun. After Xiong Yan's death, his eldest son, Bo Shuang, succeeded him, becoming Xiong Shuang.
[827 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 16.2. In the twenty-ninth year, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 5.1. Marquis Hui died, and his son Marquis Li succeeded him. 5.2. In the same year, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 9.1. In the first year of Xiong Shuang's reign, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne.
[826 BC]
[825 BC]
[824 BC]
[823 BC]
[822 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 6.3 (Qin Zhong yr 23; killed by Rong). The Western Rong killed Qin Zhong. Qin Zhong reigned for twenty-three years and died at the hands of the Rong. He had five sons, the eldest of whom was Duke Zhuang. King Xuan of Zhou then summoned Duke Zhuang and his five brothers, gave them seven thousand soldiers, and sent them to attack the Western Rong, defeating them. He then restored Qin Zhong's lineage and the land of Da Luo at Quanqiu to his family, appointing Qin Zhong as a high official in the western borderlands. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 9.2. In the sixth year, Xiong Shuang died, and his three younger brothers vied for the throne. Zhong Xue died; Shu Kan fled to Pu; and the youngest brother, Ji Xun, ascended the throne, becoming Xiong Xun. In the sixteenth year of Xiong Xun's reign, Duke Huan of Zheng was first enfeoffed in Zheng.
[821 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 7.1 (Duke Zhuang yr 1). Duke Zhuang resided in his former residence, Xiquanqiu, and had three sons, the eldest being Shifu. Shifu said, "The Rong killed my grandfather Zhong; I dare not enter the city unless I kill the Rong king." He then prepared to attack the Rong, yielding the throne to his younger brother, Duke Xiang. Duke Xiang became the crown prince.
[820 BC]
[819 BC]
[818 BC]
[817 BC]
[816 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 13. In the twenty-sixth year, Duke Wu died, and his son, Duke Li Wuji, succeeded him. Duke Li was tyrannical, so Prince Hu returned to Qi. The people of Qi wanted to install him as ruler, so they attacked and killed Duke Li. Prince Hu also died in battle. The people of Qi then installed Prince Li Chi as ruler, who became Duke Wen, and executed seventy people who had killed Duke Li.
[815 BC]
[814 BC]
[813 BC]
[812 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 17. Thirty years later, Duke Zhen died, and his younger brother Ao succeeded him, becoming Duke Wu.
[811 BC]
[810 BC]
[809 BC]
[808 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 6. In the fourth year of Duke Mu's reign, he took Lady Jiang, a woman from Qi, as his wife. In the seventh year, he attacked Tiao. She gave birth to Crown Prince Chou. In the tenth year, he attacked Qianmu and achieved merit. He gave birth to his younger son, named Chengshi. The Jin official Shi Fu said, "How strange is the way Your Majesty named your sons! The Crown Prince is named Chou, which means enemy. The younger son is named Chengshi, which is a grand title, meaning 'to accomplish.' Names are self-given; things are self-determined. Now, the concubine's name is rebellious; how can Jin not descend into chaos from now on?"
[807 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 5.3. In the twenty-first year of Marquis Li's reign, Duke Huan of Zheng was first enfeoffed in Zheng.
[806 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 18.1. In the spring of the ninth year of Duke Wu's reign, Duke Wu, along with his eldest son Kuo and youngest son Xi, went to the Western Zhou court to pay homage to King Xuan. King Xuan favored Xi and wanted to make him the crown prince of Lu. Fan Zhongshan, a minister of Zhou, advised King Xuan, saying, "Deposing the eldest son and establishing the youngest is against the proper order; if this is against the proper order, the king's command will be violated; if the king's command is violated, the king will be punished. Therefore, orders must be obeyed. If orders are not obeyed, the government will not stand; if orders are obeyed but not followed, the people will abandon their ruler. The principle of subordinates serving superiors and the young serving elders is the way to maintain order. Today, the Son of Heaven has established the feudal lords and established their youngest sons, which is to teach the people to rebel. If Lu follows this, the feudal lords will follow suit, and the king's command will be obstructed; if Lu does not follow this and the youngest son is punished, it is to punish the king's command. Punishing him is a mistake, not punishing him is also a mistake. Your Majesty should consider this." King Xuan did not listen and ultimately made Xi the crown prince of Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 9.3. In the twenty-second year, Xiong Xun died, and his son Xiong E ascended the throne.
[805 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 18.2. In the summer, Duke Wu returned home and died, and Xi ascended the throne as Duke Yi.
[804 BC]
[803 BC]
[802 BC]
[801 BC]
[800 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 4. From Uncle Dai onwards, Zhao Zongyi prospered, and five generations later, Zhao Su was born.
[799 BC]
[798 BC]
[797 BC]
[796 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 19.1. In the ninth year of Duke Yi's reign, Bo Yu, the son of Duke Yi's elder brother Kuo, along with the people of Lu, attacked and murdered Duke Yi, and installed Bo Yu as the ruler.
[795 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 14. Duke Wen died in the twelfth year of his reign, and his son, Duke Cheng Tuo, succeeded him. Duke Cheng died in the ninth year of his reign, and his son, Duke Zhuang Gou, succeeded him.
[794 BC]
[793 BC]
[792 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 5.4. In the thirty-sixth year, Marquis Li died, and his son Marquis Qing succeeded him.
[791 BC]
[790 BC]
[789 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 34. King Xuan did not establish a cemetery at Qianmu. Duke Wen of Guo advised against it, but the king did not listen. In the thirty-ninth year, a battle was fought at Qianmu, and the royal army suffered a crushing defeat at the hands of the Rong tribes of the Jiang clan.
[788 BC]
[787 BC]
[786 BC]
[785 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 19.2. Eleven years into Bo Yu's reign, King Xuan of Zhou attacked Lu, killed its ruler Bo Yu, and asked the princes of Lu who could guide and subdue the other feudal lords, to be their successor. Fan Muzhong said, "Cheng, the younger brother of Duke Yi of Lu, is respectful and reverent towards the gods, and honors the elders; in enforcing laws and punishments, he always consults the late Duke Yi's teachings and seeks the truth; he does not interfere with what he asks, nor does he violate what he knows." King Xuan said, "Indeed, he is able to govern his people." He then established Cheng at the Yi Palace, who became Duke Xiao. From then on, many feudal lords rebelled against the king's orders. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 7. In the twenty-seventh year, Marquis Mu died, and his younger brother, Shang Shu, declared himself emperor, while Crown Prince Chou fled. Three years after Shang Shu's death, King Xuan of Zhou died. Four years later, Crown Prince Chou, along with his followers, attacked Shang Shu and established himself as Marquis Wen.
[784 BC]
[783 BC]
[782 BC]
[781 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 36.1. In the forty-sixth year, King Xuan died, and his son, King You, ascended the throne.
[780 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 35. After King Xuan defeated the southern army, he conducted a population assessment in Taiyuan. Zhong Shanfu advised him, "The population cannot be assessed." King Xuan did not listen and proceeded with the assessment. 36.2. In the second year of King You's reign, all three rivers in the Western Zhou Dynasty shook. Bo Yangfu said, "The Zhou Dynasty is doomed. The Qi of Heaven and Earth does not lose its order; if it exceeds its order, the people will be in chaos. When Yang is suppressed and cannot emerge, and Yin is forced and cannot rise, then there will be an earthquake. Now the three rivers are indeed shaking, which means that Yang has lost its place and is filling Yin. When Yang is lost and Yin is present, the plains will surely be blocked; when the plains are blocked, the country will surely perish. Water and soil are used by the people. If the soil has no way to develop, the people will lack resources, and how can the country not perish? In the past, when the Yi and Luo rivers dried up, the Xia Dynasty perished; when the Yellow River dried up, the Shang Dynasty perished. Now the virtue of Zhou is like that of the late Xia and Shang Dynasties, and its rivers and plains are blocked. Blockage will surely lead to drying up. A country must rely on mountains and rivers; when mountains collapse and rivers dry up, it is a sign of the country's demise. When rivers dry up, mountains will surely collapse. If the country perishes, it will not exceed ten years, which is the cycle of fate. What Heaven abandons will not exceed its cycle." In that year, the three rivers dried up, and Mount Qi collapsed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 9.4. In the ninth year of Xiong E's reign, Xiong E died, and his son Xiong Yi ascended the throne, becoming Ruo Ao.
[779 BC]
[778 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 37.1. For three years, King You favored Bao Si. Bao Si gave birth to a son, Bo Fu, and King You wanted to depose the crown prince. The crown prince's mother was the daughter of Marquis Shen, who became queen. Later, King You obtained Bao Si, loved her, and wanted to depose Queen Shen and Crown Prince Yi Jiu, making Bao Si queen and Bo Fu crown prince. The Zhou Grand Historian Bo Yang, reading the Records of the Grand Historian, said, "The Zhou dynasty is doomed." [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 7.2 (Duke Zhuang yr 44; death). Duke Zhuang reigned for forty-four years before his death, and Crown Prince Xiang succeeded him.
[777 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 37.2. Long ago, during the decline of the Xia dynasty, two divine dragons appeared in the Xia emperor's court and said, "We are the two lords of Bao." The Xia emperor consulted the oracle about killing them, removing them, or keeping them, but none of these was auspicious. He then consulted the oracle about their saliva and asked to store it, which was auspicious. So he distributed coins and made a notice to them. The dragons disappeared, but the saliva remained, and they were stored away. After the fall of Xia, this vessel was passed down to the Yin dynasty. After the fall of Yin, this vessel was passed down to the Zhou dynasty. For three dynasties, no one dared to open it, until the end of King Li's reign, when it was opened and examined. The saliva flowed into the courtyard and could not be removed. King Li then ordered a woman to strip naked and shout at it. The saliva transformed into a black turtle and entered the queen's palace. A young concubine in the palace encountered it when she was still a baby, and became pregnant when she reached marriageable age. She gave birth to a child without a husband, and out of fear, abandoned it. During the reign of King Xuan, a children's rhyme went: "Those who wear bows and winnowing baskets will surely bring ruin to the Zhou kingdom." King Xuan heard this and ordered a couple selling such items to be arrested and executed. The couple fled along the road and saw the abandoned child of the palace concubines crying in the night. They took pity on the child and took it in. The couple then fled to Bao. A man in Bao had committed a crime and asked the king to bring him the abandoned child to atone for his sins. This abandoned child came from Bao and became Bao Si. In the third year of King You's reign, the king's concubines saw her and fell in love with her. She gave birth to a son, Bo Fu, and the king deposed Queen Shen and the crown prince, making Bao Si queen and Bo Fu crown prince. The Grand Historian Bo Yang said, "The disaster is complete; there is nothing that can be done!" [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 7.3 (Duke Xiang yr 1). In the first year of Duke Xiang's reign, he married his younger sister, Miao Ying, to King Feng.
[776 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 7.4 (Duke Xiang yr 2). In the second year of Duke Xiang's reign, the Rong besieged Quanqiu, and Shifu attacked them but was captured by the Rong. After a year, he was released.
[775 BC]
[774 BC]
[773 BC]
[772 BC]
[771 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 38. Bao Si did not laugh, but King You desired her to make everyone laugh, so she did not. King You had beacon towers and large drums made; if an enemy approached, the beacon fires would be lit. All the feudal lords arrived, but when they arrived and there was no enemy, Bao Si laughed heartily. King You was pleased and lit the beacon fires several more times. Afterwards, they did not believe it, and the feudal lords increasingly stopped coming. 39. King You appointed Guo Shifu as his minister, who then wielded considerable power, causing widespread resentment among the people. Shifu was a cunning, sycophantic, and greedy man, yet the king employed him. He also deposed Queen Shen and removed the crown prince. Marquis Shen, enraged, allied with the Zeng and the Western Rong tribes to attack King You. King You lit beacon fires to summon troops, but none arrived. They then killed King You at the foot of Mount Li, captured Bao Si, and seized all the Zhou tribute before departing. The feudal lords then joined Marquis Shen in establishing the former crown prince, Yijiu, as King Ping, to continue the Zhou sacrifices. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 7.5 (Duke Xiang yr 7; King You killed). In the spring of the seventh year, King You of Zhou, with the help of Bao Si, deposed the crown prince and installed Bao Si's son as the heir apparent. He repeatedly deceived the feudal lords, who then rebelled. The Western Rong, the Quanrong, along with Marquis Shen, attacked Zhou and killed King You at the foot of Mount Li. Duke Xiang of Qin led troops to rescue Zhou, fighting fiercely and achieving merit. To avoid the Quanrong's threat, Zhou moved east to Luoyi, and [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 15. In the twenty-fourth year of Duke Zhuang's reign, the Quanrong killed King You, and the Zhou dynasty moved its capital east to Luo. Qin was then listed as one of the vassal states. In the fifty-sixth year, Jin assassinated its ruler, Marquis Zhao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 20. In the twenty-fifth year of Duke Xiao's reign, the feudal lords rebelled against Zhou, and the Quanrong killed King You. Qin was then listed as one of the feudal states. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 6. In the twentieth year of Marquis Qing's reign, King You of Zhou was murdered by the Quanrong due to his licentious behavior. Qin was then listed as one of the vassal states. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 8. In the tenth year of Marquis Wen's reign, King You of Zhou was tyrannical, and the Quanrong killed him, forcing the Zhou dynasty to move east. It was then that Duke Xiang of Qin was recognized as a vassal state. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 10. In the twentieth year of Ruo'ao, King You of Zhou was killed by the Quanrong, and the Zhou dynasty moved eastward. At that time, Duke Xiang of Qin was first listed as a feudal lord.
[770 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 40. When King Ping ascended the throne, he moved the capital eastward to Luoyi to ward off the Rong and other invading tribes. During King Ping's reign, the Zhou dynasty was in decline, and the powerful feudal lords annexed the weak. Qi, Chu, Qin, and Jin began to rise to power, and the government was controlled by regional governors. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 7.6 (King Ping accession; Qin enfeoffment context). Duke Xiang escorted King Ping of Zhou with his troops. King Ping enfeoffed Duke Xiang as a feudal lord, granting him land west of Qi. He said, "The Rong are wicked and have invaded and seized my lands of Qi and Feng. If Qin can attack and drive out the Rong, then we will have their lands." He made an oath with them and granted them titles. Duke Xiang then established his state and established diplomatic relations with the other feudal lords, using three each of a chestnut colt, a yellow ox, and a ram to offer sacrifices to the Supreme God at the western altar. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 16. In the sixty-fourth year, Duke Zhuang died, and his son, Duke Li Lufu, succeeded him.
[769 BC]
[768 BC]
[767 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 7.1. In the twenty-fourth year, Marquis Qing died, and his son Marquis Ai succeeded him.
[766 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 7.7 (Duke Xiang yr 12; death). In the twelfth year, he attacked the Rong and reached Qi, where he died. He had a son named Duke Wen.
[765 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.1 (Duke Wen yr 1). In the first year of Duke Wen's reign, he resided in the Western Palace. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 7.2. Marquis Ai died two years later, and his son Marquis Zheng succeeded him.
[764 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 11.1. In the twenty-seventh year, Ruo'ao died, and his son Xiong Kan succeeded him, becoming Xiao'ao.
[763 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.2 (Duke Wen yr 3). In the third year, Duke Wen led 700 soldiers on an eastern hunt.
[762 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.3 (Duke Wen yr 4). In the fourth year, he reached the confluence of the Qian and Wei rivers. He said, "In the past, the Zhou dynasty established a city here for my ancestor, Ying of Qin, who later became a feudal lord." He then divined a place to settle, and the divination indicated good fortune, so he built a city there.
[761 BC]
[760 BC]
[759 BC]
[758 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 11.2. In the sixth year of Xiao'ao's reign, he died, and his son Xiong Xuan succeeded him, becoming Fenmao.
[757 BC]
[756 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.4 (Duke Wen yr 10). In the tenth year, he first established the Fu Altar, using three sacrificial animals. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 17.1. In the ninth year of Duke Li's reign, Duke Yin of Lu ascended the throne.
[755 BC]
[754 BC]
[753 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.5 (Duke Wen yr 13). In the thirteenth year, he first established a historian to record events, and many people were transformed.
[752 BC]
[751 BC]
[750 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.6 (Duke Wen yr 16). In the sixteenth year, Duke Wen led an army to attack the Rong, who were defeated and fled. Duke Wen then gathered the remaining people of Zhou and acquired their land, extending to Qi. He then offered the land east of Qi to Zhou.
[749 BC]
[748 BC]
[747 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.7 (Duke Wen yr 19). In the nineteenth year, he obtained the Chen treasure.
[746 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.8 (Duke Wen yr 20). In the twentieth year, he first enacted the law punishing three generations of a family. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 9. In the thirty-fifth year, Marquis Wen died, and his son, Marquis Zhao, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 11.3. In the thirteenth year of Fenmao's reign, Jin began to fall into chaos due to the Quwo incident.
[745 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 17.2. In the nineteenth year, Duke Huan of Lu murdered his elder brother, Duke Yin, and established himself as the ruler. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 10. In the first year of Marquis Zhao's reign, Marquis Wen's younger brother, Chengshi, was enfeoffed in Quwo. Quwo was larger than Yi. Yi was the capital of the Jin rulers. Chengshi was enfeoffed in Quwo and given the title Huan Shu. Luan Bin, a grandson of Marquis Jing, served as Huan Shu's minister. Huan Shu was fifty-eight years old at the time, and he was virtuous; the people of Jin all followed him. A wise man said, "The chaos in Jin will begin in Quwo. By prioritizing the lesser over the greater and winning the hearts of the people, how can chaos not arise!"
[744 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 21. In the twenty-seventh year, Duke Xiao died, and his son Fuhuang succeeded him, becoming Duke Hui.
[743 BC]
[742 BC]
[741 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 11.4. In the seventeenth year of Fenmao's reign, he died. Fenmao's younger brother, Xiong Tong, murdered Fenmao's son and succeeded him, becoming King Wu of Chu.
[740 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 18. In the twenty-fifth year, the Northern Rong attacked Qi. Zheng sent Prince Hu to rescue Qi, and Qi wanted to marry him to them. Hu said, "Zheng is small and Qi is large, they are no match for us." So he declined.
[739 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.9 (Duke Wen yr 27). In the twenty-seventh year, he attacked the large Zi tree in the southern mountains, which yielded great wealth. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 11. In the seventh year, the Jin minister Pan Fu murdered his lord, Zhao Hou, and welcomed Huan Shu of Quwo. Huan Shu wanted to enter Jin, but the Jin people sent troops to attack him. Huan Shu was defeated and returned to Quwo. The Jin people jointly installed Zhao Hou's son, Ping, as their ruler, who became Xiao Hou. Pan Fu was executed.
[738 BC]
[737 BC]
[736 BC]
[735 BC]
[734 BC]
[733 BC]
[732 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 12. In the eighth year of Duke Xiao's reign, Huan Shu of Quwo died, and his son, Huan Shu Jia, became Duke Zhuang of Quwo. In the fifteenth year of Duke Xiao's reign, Duke Zhuang of Quwo murdered his lord, Duke Xiao of Jin, at Yi. The people of Jin attacked Duke Zhuang of Quwo, but he returned to Quwo. The people of Jin then installed Duke Xiao's son, Xi, as their ruler, who became Duke E.
[731 BC]
[730 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 19. In the thirty-second year, Yi Zhongnian, the younger brother of Duke Li, died. His son was named Gongsun Wuzhi, whom Duke Li loved and allowed to be cared for as if he were the crown prince. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 7.3. Marquis Zheng died thirty-six years later, and his son Marquis Mu succeeded him.
[729 BC]
[728 BC]
[727 BC]
[726 BC]
[725 BC]
[724 BC]
[723 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 20. In the thirty-third year, Duke Li died, and his son, the crown prince, ascended the throne as Duke Xiang.
[722 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 41. In the forty-ninth year, Duke Yin of Lu ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 21. In the first year of Duke Xiang's reign, when he was still the crown prince, he once fought with Wuzhi. After he ascended the throne, he demoted Wuzhi from his rank and attire, which Wuzhi resented. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 23. In the forty-sixth year, Duke Hui died, and his eldest son, Xi, acted as regent, performing the duties of the ruler; he was known as Duke Yin. Initially, Duke Hui's first wife had no children, so his concubine, Shengzi, gave birth to Xi. When Xi grew up, Duke Hui arranged a marriage for him with a woman from Song. The woman from Song arrived and was captivated by him; Duke Hui seized her and married her to him. She gave birth to a son, Yun. He then made the woman from Song his wife and Yun his crown prince. When Duke Hui died, because Yun was young, the people of Lu jointly ordered Xi to act as regent, without mentioning his ascension to the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 8.1. The seventh year of Marquis Mu's reign was also the first year of the reign of Duke Yin of Lu.
[721 BC]
[720 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 42.1. In the fifty-first year, King Ping died, and Crown Prince Xie's father died young. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 12. In the seventeenth year of King Wu's reign, Zhuang Bo of Quwo in Jin assassinated Duke Xiao of Jin, the ruler of the state. In the nineteenth year, Duan, the younger brother of Duke Bo of Zheng, rebelled. In the twenty-first year, Zheng invaded the fields belonging to the Son of Heaven. In the twenty-third year, Wei assassinated its ruler, Duke Huan. In the twenty-ninth year, Lu assassinated its ruler, Duke Yin. In the thirty-first year, Hua Du, the Grand Minister of Song, assassinated its ruler, Duke Shang.
[719 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 42.2. His son Lin was enthroned as King Huan. King Huan was the grandson of King Ping.
[718 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.10 (Duke Wen yr 48). In the forty-eighth year, Duke Wen's crown prince died and was posthumously named Duke Jing. Duke Jing's eldest son became the crown prince; he was Duke Wen's grandson. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 24.1. In the fifth year of Duke Yin's reign, he observed fishing at Tang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 13. Marquis E died in the sixth year of his reign. Upon hearing of Marquis E's death, Zhuang Bo of Quwo raised an army to attack Jin. King Ping of Zhou sent Duke Guo with troops to attack Zhuang Bo of Quwo, who fled to Quwo. The people of Jin then jointly established Guang, the son of Marquis E, as Marquis Ai.
[717 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 43.1. In the third year of King Huan's reign, Duke Zhuang of Zheng paid homage to the king, but King Huan did not show him proper respect.
[716 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 8.11 (Duke Wen yr 50; death). In the fiftieth year, Duke Wen died and was buried in the Western Mountains. Duke Jing's son succeeded him, becoming Duke Ning. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 14. In the second year of Marquis Ai's reign, Zhuang Bo of Quwo died, and his son Cheng succeeded him, becoming Duke Wu of Quwo. In the sixth year of Marquis Ai's reign, Lu assassinated its ruler, Duke Yin. In the eighth year of Marquis Ai's reign, Jin invaded Xingting. Xingting conspired with Duke Wu of Quwo, and in the ninth year, attacked Jin near the Fen River, capturing Marquis Ai. The people of Jin then installed Marquis Ai's son, Xiaozi, as their ruler, becoming Marquis Xiaozi.
[715 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 43.2. In the fifth year, Zheng harbored resentment and exchanged the Xu Field with Lu. The Xu Field was the Tai Mountain Field, used by the Son of Heaven for official business. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 24.2. In the eighth year, he went with the emperor of Zheng to Fang, a town near Mount Tai, and Xutian, which was criticized by gentlemen.
[714 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 9.1 (Duke Xian “Duke Ning” in text; yr 2) (Wikipedia). In the second year of Duke Ning's reign, the Duke moved to Pingyang. He sent troops to attack Dangshe.
[713 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 9.2 (yr 3). In the third year, he fought against Bo, and the King of Bo fled to Rong, thus destroying Dangshe.
[712 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 43.3. In the eighth year, Lu killed Duke Yin and installed Duke Huan as emperor. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 9.3 (yr 4). In the fourth year, Prince Hui of Lu assassinated his ruler, Duke Yin. In the twelfth year, he attacked and captured the Dang clan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 25. In the winter of the eleventh year, Gongzi Hui flattered Duke Yin, saying, "The people favor you, so you should ascend the throne. I will kill Ziyun for you, and you will appoint me as your prime minister." Duke Yin replied, "I have a mandate from my late father. I acted as regent because Yun was young. Now Yun is grown up, and I will spend my old age in the Tuqiu region, and then hand over the reins of government to Ziyun." Hui feared that Ziyun would hear of this and kill him, so he falsely accused Duke Yin to Ziyun, saying, "Duke Yin wants to ascend the throne and has removed you. You should plot against this. I will kill Duke Yin for you." Ziyun agreed. In the eleventh month, Duke Yin offered sacrifices to the Zhong Wu, performed rituals at the Shepu, and stayed at the Wei family's residence. Hui sent men to kill Duke Yin at the Wei family's residence and installed Ziyun as the ruler, who became Duke Huan.
[711 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 26.1. In the first year of Duke Huan's reign, Zheng exchanged a jade disc for the emperor's Xutian field. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 8.2. He died in the eighteenth year, and his son, Marquis Xuan, succeeded him.
[710 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 26.2. In the second year, Zheng presented a bronze tripod, a gift from Song, to the ancestral temple, which was criticized by gentlemen.
[709 BC]
[708 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 27.1. In the third year, he sent Hui to welcome his wife to Qi to become his consort. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 15. In the first year of the reign of Xiao Zi, Duke Wu of Quwo sent Han Wan to kill the captured Marquis Ai of Jin. Quwo grew stronger, and Jin could do nothing about it.
[707 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 43.4. In the thirteenth year, Lu attacked Zheng, and Zheng wounded King Huan with an arrow. King Huan then fled back to Zheng.
[706 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 13.1. In the thirty-fifth year, Chu attacked Sui. Sui said, "I am innocent." Chu said, "We are barbarians. Now the feudal lords are all rebelling and invading each other, or even killing each other. I have worn-out armor and wish to observe the politics of the Central States. I beg the royal court to honor my title." The people of Sui petitioned the court to honor Chu, but the royal court refused and returned to report to Chu.
[705 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 27.2. In the sixth year, the consort gave birth to a son on the same day as Duke Huan, hence the name Tong. When Tong grew up, he became the crown prince. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 16. In the fourth year of the reign of the young prince of Jin, Duke Wu of Quwo lured the young prince of Jin to his death. King Huan of Zhou sent Guo Zhong to attack Duke Wu of Quwo. Duke Wu entered Quwo and then installed Min, the younger brother of Marquis Ai of Jin, as the Marquis of Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 1. Chen Wan was the son of Duke Li of Chen. When Wan was born, the Grand Historian of Zhou passed through Chen, and Duke Li of Chen sent Wan to divine the future. The divination result was Guan (观) changing to Pi (否): "This signifies the glory of the state, and it is advantageous to be a guest of the king. Will he replace Chen as the ruler of the state? Or will he not be here, but in another country? If not himself, then his descendants. If in another country, they will surely be of the Jiang clan. The Jiang clan are descendants of the Four Mountains. Nothing can be greater than two great things; Chen is declining, will this be his rise?"
[704 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 9.4 (yr 12; death). Duke Ning ascended the throne at the age of ten and died after twelve years. He was buried in Xishan. He had three sons: the eldest, Duke Wu, was the crown prince; Duke Wu's younger brother, Duke De, was the son of Lady Lu. He had a son named Chu. After Duke Ning's death, the Grand Masters Fu Ji, Wei Lei, and San Fu deposed the crown prince and installed Chu as the ruler. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 13.2. In the thirty-seventh year, Xiong Tong of Chu angrily said, "My ancestor, Yu Xiong, was the teacher of King Wen, and died young. King Cheng promoted my ancestor and appointed him as a viscount to reside in Chu. The barbarians all submitted, yet the king did not grant him a higher position. I will honor myself." He then declared himself King Wu, made an alliance with the people of Sui, and left. Thus, he began to open up and possess the Pu region.
[703 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 9.5 (Chuzi I yr 1) (Wikipedia). After six years, San Fu and others conspired to have Chu assassinated.
[702 BC]
[701 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 17. In the fourth year of Duke Min of Jin's reign, Song seized Zheng Jizhong and installed Tu as the ruler of Zheng. In the nineteenth year of Duke Min of Jin's reign, Guan Zhifu of Qi murdered his ruler, Duke Xiang.
[700 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 1.1. Guan Zhong, also known as Yi Wu, was a native of Ying Shang. In his youth, he often associated with Bao Shuya, who recognized his talent. Guan Zhong was poor and often took advantage of Bao Shuya, but Bao Shuya always treated him kindly and never held it against him.
[699 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 8.3. Marquis Xuan died in the thirteenth year, and his son, Marquis Huan, succeeded him.
[698 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 9.6 (Chuzi I yr 6; killed). Chu ascended the throne at the age of five and died after six years.
[697 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 44.1. In the twenty-third year, King Huan died, and [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 9.7 (Duke Wu yr 1 restored) (Wikipedia). San Fu and others then reinstated the former crown prince, Duke Wu. 10.1 (Duke Wu yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Wu's reign, he attacked the Pengxi clan, reaching the foot of Mount Hua, and established a palace in Pingyang.
[696 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 44.2. his son, King Zhuang Tuo, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 28. In the sixteenth year, they met in Cao, attacked Zheng, and entered the palace of Duke Li.
[695 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 10.2 (yr 3). In the third year, he executed the three fathers and their three clans, because they had killed their adopted son. Zheng Gaoqumi killed his ruler, Duke Zhao.
[694 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 29. In the spring of the eighteenth year, the Duke was about to embark on a journey and went to Qi with his wife. Shen Xu advised against it, but the Duke did not listen and went to Qi anyway. Duke Xiang of Qi had an affair with the wife of Duke Huan of Lu. The Duke was angry with his wife, and she told the Duke of Qi. In the fourth month of summer, on the day of Bingzi, Duke Xiang of Qi hosted a banquet for the Duke. The Duke was drunk and ordered his son, Peng Sheng, to carry Duke Huan of Lu. Then he ordered Peng Sheng to break the Duke's ribs, and the Duke died in his chariot. The people of Lu reported to Qi, saying, "Our lord feared your power and dared not stay in peace, so he came to perform good rites. Since the rites were completed and he did not return, there is no one to blame but Peng Sheng to remove the disgrace from the other feudal lords." The people of Qi killed Peng Sheng to appease Lu. They established Prince Tong as the crown prince, who became Duke Zhuang. Duke Zhuang's mother, the Lady, stayed in Qi and dared not return to Lu.
[693 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 44.3. In the fourth year of King Zhuang's reign, the Duke of Zhou, Hei Jian, plotted to kill King Zhuang and install Prince Ke as emperor. Xin Bo informed the king, and the king killed the Duke of Zhou. Prince Ke fled to Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 8.4. Marquis Huan died in the seventh year, and his son, Duke Zhuang, succeeded him.
[692 BC]
[691 BC]
[690 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 14. In the fifty-first year, Zhou summoned the Marquis of Sui, who repeatedly urged the establishment of Chu as king. Chu was angered, accusing Sui of betraying it, and attacked Sui. King Wu's army was defeated and the war ended. His son, King Wen of Zhou, Xiong Zi, ascended the throne and established Ying as the capital.
[689 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 30. In the winter of the fifth year of Duke Zhuang's reign, he attacked Wei, and attacked Duke Hui of Wei.
[688 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 10.3 (yr 10). In the tenth year, he attacked the Rong tribes of Gui and Ji, and established them as counties for the first time. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 15.1. In the second year of King Wen's reign, he attacked Shen, passing through Deng. The people of Deng said, "The King of Chu is easy to take," but the Marquis of Deng refused.
[687 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 10.4 (yr 11). In the eleventh year, he established the counties of Du and Zheng as counties for the first time. He destroyed Xiao Guo.
[686 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 11 (Duke Wu yr 12/13 era; Qi turmoil). In the thirteenth year, Guan Zhifu and Lian Cheng, men of Qi, killed their ruler, Duke Xiang, and installed Gongsun Wuzhi as emperor. Jin conquered Huo, Wei, and Geng. Yong Lin of Qi killed Wuzhi, Guan Zhifu, and others, and installed Duke Huan of Qi as emperor. Qi and Jin became powerful states.
[685 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 22. Four years later, Duke Huan of Lu and his wife went to Qi. Duke Xiang of Qi had previously had an affair with the Lady of Lu. The Lady of Lu was Duke Xiang's younger sister; she had married Duke Huan during the reign of Duke Li, and when Duke Huan came, Duke Xiang resumed his affair with her. Duke Huan learned of this and was furious with his wife, who then told Duke Xiang of Qi. Duke Xiang of Qi drank with the Duke of Lu, and when the Duke was drunk, he ordered the strongman Peng Sheng to lift the Duke into his chariot. Peng Sheng then dragged the Duke of Lu to his death, and the Duke was already dead when he got out of the chariot. The people of Lu considered this an injustice, but Duke Xiang of Qi killed Peng Sheng to appease Lu. 25. In the spring of the first year of Duke Huan's reign, Duke Wuzhi of Qi went on a tour of Yonglin. The people of Yonglin had a grudge against Wuzhi, and when he went on the tour, they attacked and killed him. They then told the officials of Qi, "Wuzhi murdered Duke Xiang and seized the throne. I have executed him. You are to appoint a prince who is rightfully yours. I will obey your command." 26. Initially, Duke Xiang, in his drunken stupor, killed Duke Huan of Lu and had an affair with his wife. His killings and executions were numerous and inappropriate. He was also promiscuous with women and frequently deceived his ministers. His brothers, fearing for their lives, sent their second brother, Jiu, to Lu. His mother was a woman from Lu. Guan Zhong and Shao Hu educated him. The third brother, Xiaobai, fled to Ju, where Bao Shu educated him. Xiaobai's mother was a woman from Wei and was favored by Duke Li. From a young age, Xiaobai was fond of the minister Gao Xi. When the people of Yonglin killed Wuzhi and discussed establishing a new ruler, Gao and Guo secretly summoned Xiaobai to Ju. Upon hearing of Wuzhi's death, Lu also sent troops to escort Prince Jiu, while Guan Zhong separately led troops to block the road to Ju, where they shot Xiaobai, hitting his belt hook. Xiaobai feigned death, and Guan Zhong sent a messenger to report to Lu. The messenger from Lu sent Jiu on a delayed journey, arriving in Qi on the sixth day. By then, Xiaobai had already entered Qi, and Gao Xi had installed him as Duke Huan. 27. Duke Huan was tricked into a trap, feigning death to mislead Guan Zhong. Later, he was transported in a warm carriage, with support from Gao and Guo, allowing him to ascend the throne first and send troops to resist Lu. In the autumn, he fought Lu at Ganshi, where the Lu army was defeated and fled, but Qi troops cut off Lu's retreat. Qi sent a letter to Lu saying, "We cannot bear to kill Zi Jiu and his brothers; please let Lu kill them. Zhao Hu and Guan Zhong are enemies; please let them be minced. Otherwise, we will besiege Lu." The people of Lu were alarmed and killed Zi Jiu at Shengdu. Zhao Hu committed suicide, and Guan Zhong requested to be imprisoned. After Duke Huan ascended the throne, he sent troops to attack Lu, intending to kill Guan Zhong. Bao Shuya said, "I am fortunate to have followed you, and you have finally ascended the throne. Your honor is beyond my ability to add to it. If you wish to govern Qi, Gao Xi and I are sufficient. If you aspire to hegemony, Guan Yiwu is indispensable. The state where Yiwu resides is of great importance and cannot be lost." Duke Huan then agreed. He then feigned summoning Guan Zhong to appease him, but in reality, he intended to employ him. Guan Zhong knew of this, so he requested to go. Bao Shuya welcomed Guan Zhong, and upon reaching Tangfu, he was freed from his shackles, purified himself, and met Duke Huan. Duke Huan treated him with great courtesy, appointing him as a high-ranking official and entrusting him with government affairs. 28. After Duke Huan obtained Guan Zhong, he, along with Bao Shu, Xi Peng, and Gao Xi, reformed the government of Qi, united the armies of the five families, established a system of light and heavy taxes on fish and salt to support the poor, and rewarded the virtuous and capable. The people of Qi were all pleased. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 31.1. In the eighth year, Prince Jiu of Qi fled to Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 1.2. Later, Bao Shuya served Prince Xiaobai of Qi, while Guan Zhong served Prince Jiu. When Xiaobai became Duke Huan of Qi, Prince Jiu died, and Guan Zhong was imprisoned. Bao Shuya then recommended Guan Zhong to Duke Huan. 2. Guan Zhong said, “When I was first in dire straits, I once traded with Bao Shu. I took more than my share of the profits, but Bao Shu did not think I was greedy, because he knew I was poor. I once advised Bao Shu on a matter, but I became even poorer. Bao Shu did not think I was foolish, because he knew that there are advantages and disadvantages in life. I was dismissed from office thrice, but Bao Shu did not think I was incompetent, because he knew I was just unlucky. I fled from battle thrice, but Bao Shu did not think I was cowardly, because he knew I had an elderly mother to care for. When Prince Jiu was defeated and Zhao Hu died, I was imprisoned and humiliated. Bao Shu did not think I was shameless, because he knew I was not ashamed of petty achievements but ashamed of not having my name known to the world. My parents gave me life, but Bao Shu truly understands me.”
[684 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 31.2. In the ninth year, Lu wanted to transfer Prince Jiu to Qi, but Duke Huan of Lu refused. Duke Huan then sent troops to attack Lu, and Lu, in a panic, killed Prince Jiu. Zhao Hu died. Qi told Lu to send Guan Zhong to Qi alive. Shi Bo, a man of Lu, said, "Qi wants Guan Zhong, not to kill him, but to employ him. If they employ him, he will become a threat to Lu. It would be better to kill him and give his body to them." Duke Zhuang did not listen and imprisoned Guan Zhong and sent him to Qi. The people of Qi became Guan Zhong's prime minister. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 15.2. In the sixth year, he attacked Cai, captured Marquis Ai of Cai, and brought him back, but later released him. Chu became powerful, dominating the small states along the Yangtze and Han rivers, and all the small states feared it. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 1. Cao Mo was a man of Lu who served Duke Zhuang of Lu with his bravery and strength. Duke Zhuang was fond of strength. Cao Mo served as a general of Lu and fought against Qi, suffering three defeats. Duke Zhuang of Lu was afraid and offered the territory of Suiyi as a peace offering. Cao Mo was then reinstated as a general. 2. Duke Huan of Qi agreed to a meeting with Duke Zhuang of Lu at Ke to form an alliance. After Duke Huan and Duke Zhuang had finished their alliance on the altar, Cao Mo, holding a dagger, threatened Duke Huan. None of Duke Huan's attendants dared to move, and he asked, "What do you want?" Cao Mo replied, "Qi is strong and Lu is weak, and powerful states have been encroaching on Lu's territory. Now, the fall of Lu's city walls threatens Qi's borders. Your Majesty should consider this." Duke Huan then agreed to return all the territories he had seized from Lu. Having spoken, Cao Mo threw down his dagger, descended from the altar, and returned to his place among the ministers, his expression unchanged, his words as before. Duke Huan was furious and wanted to break the agreement. Guan Zhong said, "No. To be greedy for small gains and abandon one's faith with the other states will lose the support of the world. It is better to give in." Therefore, Duke Huan ceded the territories he had seized from Lu, and all the land Cao Mo had lost in three battles was returned to Lu.
[683 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 29. In the second year, he attacked and destroyed Tan, and the ruler of Tan fled to Ju. Initially, when Duke Huan was in exile, he passed through Tan, and Tan was disrespectful, so he attacked it.
[682 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 45.1. In the fifteenth year, King Zhuang died,
[681 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 45.2. and his son, King Li of Qi, ascended the throne. In the third year of King Li's reign, Duke Huan of Qi began to dominate the country. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 5.3. At the meeting at Ke, Duke Huan wanted to break the agreement with Cao Mo, but Guan Zhong honored it, and the feudal lords thus submitted to Qi. Therefore, it is said: "Knowing when to give and when to take is the treasure of governance."
[680 BC]
[679 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 12 (Duke Wu yr 19). In the nineteenth year, Quwo of Jin became the Marquis of Jin. Duke Huan of Qi was the heir apparent at Juan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 32.1. In the thirteenth year, Duke Zhuang of Lu met with Cao Mo at Ke to see Duke Huan of Qi. Cao Mo kidnapped Duke Huan, demanding the land that Lu had seized. After making an alliance, Duke Huan was released. Duke Huan wanted to break the agreement, but Guan Zhong advised against it, and in the end, the seized land was returned to Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 9.1. In the twelfth year of Duke Zhuang's reign, Duke Huan of Qi began his hegemony. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 15.3. In the eleventh year, Duke Huan of Qi began to dominate, and Chu also began to grow powerful.
[678 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 13 (Duke Wu yr 20; death). In the twentieth year, Duke Wu died and was buried in Pingyang, Yong. Initially, he was executed along with sixty-six men. He had one son named Bai, but Bai was not enthroned, and he was instead enfeoffed in Pingyang. His younger brother, Duke De, was enthroned. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 23. Eight years later, they attacked Ji, and Ji moved away from its town. 24.1. In the twelfth year, Duke Xiang initially sent Lian Cheng and Guan Zhifu to garrison Kuiqiu. They were to go when the melons ripened and be replaced when the melons ripened. After a year of garrisoning, the melons ripened, but the Duke did not send a replacement. Someone requested a replacement, but the Duke refused. Therefore, the two men were angry and, with the help of Gongsun Wuzhi, plotted a rebellion. Lian Cheng had a younger cousin in the Duke's palace who was not favored. He sent her to instigate trouble with the Duke, saying, "If the rebellion succeeds, I will make my daughter Lady Wuzhi." 24.2. In the twelfth month of winter, Duke Xiang went to Gufen and went hunting at Peiqiu. He saw a pig, and his attendants called it "Peng Sheng." The Duke was furious and shot it. The pig stood up and cried. The Duke was frightened, fell from his chariot, injured his foot, and lost his shoe. He then whipped the man who had given him the shoe three hundred times. The whipped man left the palace. Wuzhi, Lian Cheng, Guan Zhifu, and others, hearing of the Duke's injury, led their followers to attack the palace. When they encountered Zhu Jufu, Fu said, "Don't enter the Jing Palace, it's not easy to get in." Wuzhi didn't believe him, but Fu showed him his wounds, and then he believed him. They waited outside the palace and ordered Fu to go in first. Fu went in first and hid in a doorway of Duke Xiang's house. After a while, Wuzhi and his men, fearing for their lives, went into the palace. Fu, along with the palace staff and the Duke's favorite ministers, attacked Wuzhi and his men, but they were defeated and all died. Wuzhi went into the palace but couldn't find the Duke. Someone saw a foot in a doorway; upon opening it, they found it was Duke Xiang, and they murdered him. Wuzhi then declared himself the ruler of Qi. 30. Five years later, Qi attacked Lu, and the Lu army was defeated. Duke Zhuang of Lu offered the city of Sui in exchange for peace, which Duke Huan agreed to, and they met at Ke to form an alliance. Just as Lu was about to make the alliance, Cao Mo, holding a dagger, forced Duke Huan to abduct him on the altar, saying, "Reclaim the land Lu has seized!" Duke Huan agreed. Afterwards, Cao Mo removed the dagger and faced north to assume the position of a subject. Duke Huan regretted his decision and wanted to kill Cao Mo instead of giving Lu the land. Guan Zhong said, "To force someone to agree and then betray that promise and kill them would only bring a small satisfaction, but it would also damage the trust of the other lords and lose the support of the world. This is unacceptable." Therefore, Duke Huan, together with Cao Mo, defeated Lu three times in losing the land they had seized. Hearing this, the other lords all trusted Qi and wanted to ally with it. Seven years later, the lords met with Duke Huan at Zhen, and Duke Huan thus began to establish his hegemony. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 18. In the twenty-eighth year of the reign of Duke Huan of Qi, Duke Huan of Qi began to establish his hegemony. Duke Wu of Quwo attacked and destroyed Duke Min of Jin, and presented all his treasures and artifacts to King Li of Zhou as a bribe. King Li appointed Duke Wu of Quwo as the ruler of Jin and listed him among the feudal lords, thus annexing all the lands of Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 16.1. In the twelfth year, he attacked and destroyed Deng.
[677 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 46.1. In the fifth year, King Li died, [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 14.1 (Duke De yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke De's reign, he initially resided at the Dazheng Palace in Yongcheng. He offered three hundred sacrificial animals to the Fu Altar. He then chose to settle in Yong. Later, his descendants watered their horses at the river. The Earls of Liang and Rui came to pay homage. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 32.2. In the fifteenth year, Duke Huan of Qi became the hegemon. In the twenty-third year, Duke Zhuang went to Qi to observe the ancestral rites. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 19. Duke Wu of Quwo had been on the throne for thirty-seven years and was now known as Duke Wu of Jin. Duke Wu of Jin first established his capital in the State of Jin, and before ascending the throne in Quwo, he reigned for thirty-eight years. 20. Duke Wu was the great-grandson of Marquis Mu of Jin and the grandson of Huan Shu of Quwo. Huan Shu was the first to be enfeoffed in Quwo. Duke Wu was the son of Zhuang Bo. From the time Huan Shu was first enfeoffed in Quwo until Duke Wu destroyed Jin, a total of sixty-seven years passed, and he eventually replaced Jin as a vassal state. Duke Wu reigned for two years before his death. He reigned for thirty-nine years, encompassing the years in Quwo, before his death. His son, Duke Xian, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 16.2. In the thirteenth year, he died, and his son Xiong Jian succeeded him, becoming King Zhuang'ao.
[676 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 46.2. and his son, King Hui Lang, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 14.2 (Duke De yr 2; death). In the second year, at the beginning of the winter solstice, he used dogs to ward off evil spirits. Duke De ascended the throne at the age of thirty-three and died two years later. He had three sons: the eldest, Duke Xuan; the middle son, Duke Cheng; and the youngest son, Duke Mu. The eldest son, Duke Xuan, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 21. In the first year of Duke Xian's reign, Tui, the younger brother of King Hui of Zhou, attacked King Hui, who fled and settled in Liyi, Zheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 5. In the sixteenth year of Duke Xian of Jin's reign, Jin attacked Huo, Wei, and Geng, with Zhao Su serving as general in the campaign against Huo. The Duke of Huo fled to Qi. Jin suffered a severe drought, and divination revealed that "Mount Huo is the cause of the disaster." Zhao Su was then sent to Qi to summon the Duke of Huo back to his homeland and restore the ancestral worship of Mount Huo. Jin then enjoyed a bountiful harvest. Duke Xian of Jin bestowed upon Zhao Su the title of Geng.
[675 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 46.3. In the second year of King Hui's reign, King Zhuang's favorite concubine, Yao, gave birth to a son, Tui, who was favored. When King Hui ascended the throne, he seized the power of Yao's ministers to build a hunting park, leading to a rebellion by five officials, including Bian Bo, who plotted to summon troops from Yan and Wei to attack King Hui. King Hui fled to Wen, where he resided in Li, Zheng. He then installed Tui, King Li's younger brother, as king. Yue Ji performed a wide-ranging dance, angering the rulers of Zheng and Guo. In the fourth year, the rulers of Zheng and Guo attacked and killed King Tui, then reinstated him to King Hui. In the tenth year of King Hui's reign, he granted Duke Huan of Qi the title of Earl. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 15.1 (Duke Xuan yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Xuan's reign, Wei and Yan attacked Zhou, deposed King Hui, and installed Prince Tui as emperor. Three years later, the Duke of Zheng and the Duke of Guo killed Prince Tui and brought him to the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 31. In the fourteenth year, Chen Li Gongzi Wan, styled Jingzhong, came to Qi. Duke Huan of Qi wanted to appoint him as a minister, but he declined; instead, he appointed him as the Minister of Works. He was the ancestor of Tian Chengzi Chang. 32. In the twenty-third year, the Shanrong attacked Yan, and Yan appealed to Qi for help. Duke Huan of Qi came to Yan's aid, and subsequently attacked the Shanrong, reaching as far as Guzhu before turning back. Duke Zhuang of Yan then escorted Duke Huan into Qi territory. Duke Huan said, "Unless it is the Son of Heaven, feudal lords should not escort each other beyond their borders. I cannot be disrespectful to Yan." Therefore, he divided the territory that the ruler of Yan had reached with Yan, and ordered the ruler of Yan to restore the policies of Duke Shao, and to pay tribute to Zhou as during the reigns of King Cheng and King Kang. When the feudal lords heard of this, they all followed Qi's lead. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 9.2. In the sixteenth year, he joined forces with Song and Wei to attack King Hui of Zhou. King Hui fled to Wen, and Duke Huan installed his younger brother, Tui, as King of Zhou.
[674 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 9.3. In the seventeenth year, Zheng captured Zhongfu of Yan and brought King Hui to Zhou.
[673 BC]
[672 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 15.2 (Duke Xuan yr 4). In the fourth year, the Mi Altar was built. Duke Xuan fought against Jin at Heyang and won. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 22. Five years later, he attacked the Li Rong tribe and captured Li Ji and her brother, whom he both loved and favored. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 16.3. In the fifth year of Zhuang'ao's reign, he wanted to kill his younger brother Xiong Yun. Yun fled to Sui, and together with Sui, they assassinated Zhuang'ao and established themselves as King Cheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 2.1. Duke Li was the youngest son of Duke Wen of Chen, and his mother was a woman from Cai. After Duke Wen's death, Duke Li's elder brother, Bao, ascended the throne as Duke Huan. Duke Huan was a half-brother. When Duke Huan fell ill, the people of Cai killed Duke Huan, Bao, and the crown prince, Mian, and installed Duke Li as Duke Li.
[671 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 17. In the first year of King Cheng Yun's reign, upon ascending the throne, he spread benevolence and bestowed favors, forging old alliances with the feudal lords. He sent envoys to present gifts to the emperor, who bestowed upon him sacrificial meat and said, "Suppress the chaos of the southern barbarians and do not invade the Central Plains." As a result, the territory of Chu stretched for a thousand li. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 2.2. After ascending the throne, Duke Li married a woman from Cai. This woman had an affair with a man from Cai and frequently returned home; Duke Li also frequently visited Cai. Duke Huan's youngest son, Lin, resented Duke Li for killing his father and brother, and ordered a man from Cai to lure and kill Duke Li. Lin then established himself as Duke Zhuang. Therefore, Chen Wan was unable to ascend the throne and became a high official of Chen. Duke Li's killing was due to his adultery and expulsion from the state; hence, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* states, "The people of Cai killed Chen Wan," indicating the crime committed against him.
[670 BC]
[669 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 33. In the thirty-second year, Duke Zhuang built a platform overlooking the Dang clan. There he saw a woman named Meng, fell in love with her, and promised to make her his wife, swearing an oath by cutting his arm. Meng gave birth to Ban. When Ban grew up, he fell in love with a woman from the Liang clan and went to see her. A groom named Luo was playing with the Liang woman from outside the wall. Ban became angry and whipped Luo. Duke Zhuang heard of this and said, "Luo is strong, so I killed him. It is not right to just whip him and let him go." Ban was not killed. Duke Zhuang then fell ill. Duke Zhuang had three younger brothers: the eldest was Qingfu, the second was Shuya, and the third was Jiyou. Duke Zhuang married a woman from Qi named Ai Jiang. Ai Jiang had no children. Ai Jiang's younger sister, Shu Jiang, gave birth to a son named Kai. Duke Zhuang had no heir and loved Meng, wanting to make her son Ban his heir. Duke Zhuang was ill and asked his brother Shuya about succession. Shuya said, "One successor and one successor is the norm in Lu. Qingfu is alive; he can be the heir. What is your concern?" Duke Zhuang was troubled by Shuya's desire to make Qingfu his heir and withdrew to ask Jiyou. Ji You said, "Please allow me to die to establish Ban as ruler." Duke Zhuang said, "Previously, Shu Ya wanted to establish Qing Fu as ruler, what should we do?" Ji You, following Duke Zhuang's orders, instructed Shu Ya to wait at the Zhenwu clan, and had Zhen Ji force Shu Ya to drink poison, saying, "If you drink this, you will have descendants to offer sacrifices; otherwise, you will die without descendants." Shu Ya then drank the poison and died. Lu established his son as the Shusun clan. On the day of Guihai in the eighth month, Duke Zhuang died, and Ji You finally established his son Ban as ruler, as Duke Zhuang had ordered. During the mourning period, he stayed at the Dang clan's residence. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 23. In the eighth year, Shi Wei advised Duke Wen, "There are many princes in Jin; if they are not punished, chaos will break out." Duke Wen then ordered the execution of all the princes and built a city there, naming it Jiang, thus establishing Jiang as the capital. In the ninth year, the princes of Jin fled to Guo. Guo, for this reason, attacked Jin again but failed. In the tenth year, Jin wanted to attack Guo, but Shi Wei said, "Let's wait until they are in chaos."
[668 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 34. Previously, Qingfu had an affair with Ai Jiang and wanted to install Ai Jiang's younger sister, Kai, as the heir. After Duke Zhuang died, Ji You installed Ban as the heir. On the day of Jiwei in the tenth month, Qingfu sent his groom Luo to kill Duke Ban of Lu at the Dang clan. Ji You fled to Chen. Qingfu then installed Duke Zhuang's son, Kai, as the heir, who became Duke Min.
[667 BC]
[666 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 35. In the second year of Duke Min's reign, Qingfu and Ai Jiang's affair deepened. Ai Jiang and Qingfu plotted to murder Duke Min and install Qingfu as emperor. Qingfu sent Bu Yi to assassinate Duke Min at the Wuwei Gate. Ji You, hearing of this, volunteered to go to Zhu with Duke Min's younger brother, Shen, requesting that Lu grant them entry into the court. The people of Lu wanted to kill Qingfu. Qingfu, fearing for his life, fled to Ju. Thereupon, Ji You brought his son Shen into the court and installed him as Duke Li. Duke Li was also the youngest son of Duke Zhuang. Ai Jiang, fearing for her life, fled to Zhu. Ji You bribed Ju to retrieve Qingfu. Qingfu returned and was killed. Qingfu begged to flee, but was refused. He then sent the minister Xi Si, weeping, to the Ju court. Upon hearing Xi Si's voice, Qingfu committed suicide. Duke Huan of Qi, hearing of Ai Jiang and Qingfu's affair endangering Lu, summoned Qingfu to Zhu and killed him. He returned the body and had it executed in Lu. Duke Li of Lu requested that the body be buried.
[665 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 24. In the twelfth year, Li Ji gave birth to Xi Qi. Duke Xian intended to depose the crown prince, saying, "Quwo is where my ancestors' ancestral temples are located, while Pu borders Qin and Qu borders Di. I fear if my sons are not allowed to reside there." Therefore, he placed Crown Prince Shen Sheng in Quwo, Prince Chong Er in Pu, and Prince Yi Wu in Qu. Duke Xian and Li Ji's son, Xi Qi, resided in Jiang. The state of Jin thus knew that the crown prince would not be established. Crown Prince Shen Sheng's mother was the daughter of Duke Huan of Qi, named Qi Jiang, who died young. Shen Sheng's half-brother was the wife of Duke Mu of Qin. Chong Er's mother was a woman of the Hu clan of Di. Yi Wu's mother was Chong Er's half-brother. Duke Xian had eight sons, and Crown Prince Shen Sheng, Chong Er, and Yi Wu were all virtuous. After obtaining Li Ji, he distanced himself from these three sons.
[664 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 15.3 (Duke Xuan yr 12; death). In the twelfth year, Duke Xuan died. He had nine sons, but none succeeded him; his younger brother, Duke Cheng, was enthroned. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 36 (discursive). Ji You's mother was a woman from Chen, who died in Chen. Chen's former servant escorted Ji You and his son Shen. When Ji You was about to be born, his father, Duke Huan of Lu, had someone divine his fate. The divination said, "It will be a boy, named 'You,' who will reside in the two altars of the state and serve as an advisor to the ducal house. If Ji You dies, Lu will not prosper." When Ji You was born, there was a mark on his palm that read "You," so he was named after it and given the title Cheng Ji. His descendants became the Ji clan, and Qing Fu's descendants became the Meng clan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 9.4. In the twenty-seventh year, the Shanrong invaded Qi, and Duke Huan of Qi came to Yan's aid, then launched a northern expedition against the Shanrong before returning. The ruler of Yan escorted Duke Huan of Qi out of the country, and Duke Huan then ceded the land Yan had acquired to Yan, making Yan jointly pay tribute to the Son of Heaven, as was the custom during the reign of Duke Cheng of Zhou; he also ordered Yan to restore the laws of Duke Shao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 5.2 (note: episode earlier than 5.1). Duke Huan also campaigned against the Shanrong in the north, and Guan Zhong then ordered Yan to restore the policies of Duke Shao.
[663 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 16 (Duke Cheng yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Cheng's reign, the Earls of Liang and Rui came to pay homage. Duke Huan of Qi attacked the Shanrong and camped at Guzhu.
[662 BC]
[661 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 25. In the sixteenth year, Duke Xian of Jin established two armies. The Duke commanded the upper army, Crown Prince Shen Sheng commanded the lower army, Zhao Su drove the chariot, and Bi Wan was on the right wing. They conquered Huo, Wei, and Geng. Upon returning, the Duke built Quwo for the Crown Prince, bestowed Geng upon Zhao Su, and Wei upon Bi Wan, appointing them as high officials. Shi Wei said, "The Crown Prince cannot be established. He has been given the capital city and the position of minister. He has already set the limit for him, how can he be established? It would be better for him to flee and avoid punishment. Wouldn't it be better for him to become Taibo of Wu, at least he would have a good reputation?" The Crown Prince did not listen. Bu Yan said, "Bi Wan's descendants will surely be great. Wan means fullness; Wei means great name. With this as the beginning of the reward, Heaven has opened the way. The Son of Heaven calls the people 'millions of people,' and the feudal lords call the people 'ten thousand people.' Now the mandate is great, following the fullness of the number, so there will surely be many." Initially, Bi Wan consulted the oracle when he was to serve in the state of Jin, and he encountered the hexagram Tun changing to Bi. Xin Liao interpreted it and said, "Auspicious. Tun is firm and Bi is entering, what could be more auspicious? His descendants will surely prosper."
[660 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 17 (Duke Cheng yr 4; death). Duke Cheng died in the fourth year of his reign. He had seven sons, but none of them succeeded him; instead, his younger brother, Duke Mu, was chosen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 33. In the twenty-seventh year, the mother of Duke Min of Lu was named Ai Jiang, who was also the younger sister of Duke Huan. Ai Jiang had an affair with Prince Qingfu of Lu, who then murdered Duke Min. Ai Jiang wanted to install Qingfu as the new ruler, but the people of Lu installed Duke Li instead. Duke Huan summoned Ai Jiang and had her killed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 26. In the seventeenth year, Duke Xian of Jin sent his crown prince, Shen Sheng, to attack Dongshan. Li Ke advised Duke Xian, saying, “The crown prince is responsible for the sacrifices to the gods of the land and grain, and for overseeing the ruler’s meals morning and evening; hence the title ‘Son of the Tomb.’ When the ruler goes out, he guards the tomb; when the ruler guards the tomb, he follows. Following is called ‘Governing the Army,’ and guarding is called ‘Supervising the State,’ this is the ancient system. Leading an army is for planning; swearing oaths in the army is for the ruler and the state to devise strategies; it is not the crown prince’s business. The army is only responsible for issuing commands; if one obeys commands, one lacks authority; if one acts independently, one is unfilial. Therefore, the ruler’s heir is not fit to lead an army. If the ruler loses his position, leading an army will lack authority; what use will he be?” The Duke said, “I have a son, but I do not know who will be the crown prince.” Li Ke did not answer and withdrew to see the crown prince. The crown prince said, “Should I be deposed?” Li Ke said, “Crown prince, strive on! Train him in military affairs; if he is not afraid of this, why should he be deposed? Moreover, you fear being unfilial, not that you will not be able to succeed. Cultivate yourself and do not blame others, then you will avoid trouble.” The crown prince led the army, and the Duke wore a side robe with a gold pendant. Rick feigned illness and refused to follow the Crown Prince. The Crown Prince then attacked Dongshan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 4. When Guan Zhong became the prime minister of Qi, he transformed the small state of Qi, located on the coast, into a prosperous and powerful nation through trade and wealth accumulation, aligning himself with the people's likes and dislikes. Therefore, he said, "When granaries are full, people know etiquette; when food and clothing are plentiful, people know honor and shame; when superiors dress appropriately, family relationships are secure. If the four cardinal virtues are not upheld, the state will perish. His decrees flow like a river, conforming to the people's hearts." Thus, his teachings were humble yet easy to implement. He granted what the people desired and removed what they disliked.
[659 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 18.1 (Duke Mu yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Mu's reign, he personally led an attack on Maojin and won. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 37. In the first year of Emperor Li's reign, Ji You was enfeoffed as the Prefect of Wenyang. Ji You became the Chancellor. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 6. Su Sheng was born to Gong Meng in the first year of the reign of Duke Min of Lu. Gong Meng begat Zhao Cui, whose courtesy name was Ziyu.
[658 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 9.5. In the thirty-third year, he died, and his son, Duke Xiang, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 27. In the nineteenth year, Duke Xian said, "When my ancestors, Duke Zhuang and Duke Wu, punished the rebellion in Jin, Guo always assisted Jin in attacking us and even hid the exiled prince of Jin. As expected, they caused chaos. If we do not punish them, it will leave a worry for our descendants." So he sent Xun Xi with the chariot of Quchan to borrow a route through Yu. Yu granted the route, and then attacked Guo, capturing its Xiayang and returning home.
[657 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 28. Duke Xian privately said to Li Ji, "I want to depose the Crown Prince and replace him with Xi Qi." Li Ji wept and said, "The establishment of the Crown Prince is known to all the feudal lords, and he frequently leads troops, with the people following him. How can you depose the legitimate heir and establish a son of a concubine because of my lowly status? If Your Majesty insists on doing so, I will kill myself." Li Ji praised the Crown Prince in detail, but secretly had someone slander him, intending to install her son as the heir.
[656 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 18.2 (Duke Mu yr 4). In the fourth year, he welcomed his bride to Jin, who was the sister of Prince Shensheng of Jin. That same year, Duke Huan of Qi attacked Chu and reached Shaoling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 29. In the twenty-first year, Li Ji said to the Crown Prince, "Your Majesty dreamt of Qi Jiang. You should quickly offer sacrifices at Quwo and return the offerings to Your Majesty." The Crown Prince then offered sacrifices to his mother, Qi Jiang, at Quwo and presented the sacrificial meat to Duke Xian. Duke Xian was out hunting at that time and left the sacrificial meat in the palace. Li Ji had someone put poison in the sacrificial meat. Two days later, Duke Xian returned from the hunt, and the steward presented him with the sacrificial meat. Duke Xian wanted to feast on it. Li Ji stopped him, saying, "The sacrificial meat came from afar; it should be tested." She offered it to the ground, and the ground sank; she gave it to a dog, and the dog died; she gave it to a minor official, and the minor official died. Li Ji wept, saying, "How can the Crown Prince be so cruel! He even wanted to kill his own father to take his place, how much more so others? Besides, Your Majesty is old, a man nearing the end of his life, unable to wait even a moment before you want to kill him!" She said to Duke Xian, "The Crown Prince's reason for this is nothing more than because of me and Xi Qi. I wish for my son and me to flee to another country, or to commit suicide now, so that my son and I may not be slaughtered by the Crown Prince. At first, when Your Majesty wanted to depose him, I still resented it; but now, I feel utterly ashamed." Upon hearing this, the Crown Prince fled to Xincheng. Duke Xian was furious and executed his tutor, Du Yuankuan. Someone said to the Crown Prince, "It was Li Ji who made this poison, why doesn't Your Majesty resign and clarify the matter?" The Crown Prince said, "My Majesty is old, and without Li Ji, he cannot sleep peacefully or eat heartily. Even if I resign, Your Majesty will be angry. I cannot." Someone said to the Crown Prince, "You can flee to another country." The Crown Prince said, "If I leave with this infamy, who will accept me? I will commit suicide." On the day of Wushen in the twelfth month, Shen Sheng committed suicide in Xincheng. 30. At this time, Chong'er and Yiwu came to court. Someone told Li Ji, "The two princes resent Li Ji for slandering and killing the crown prince." Li Ji was afraid, so she slandered the two princes, "The two princes know about Shen Sheng's sacrificial medicine." The two princes heard this and were afraid. Chong'er fled to Pu, and Yiwu fled to Qu, fortifying their cities and defending them themselves. Initially, Duke Xian had ordered Shi Wei to build cities in Pu and Qu for the two princes, but he failed to complete them. Yiwu told the duke about this, and the duke was angry with Shi Wei. Shi Wei apologized, saying, "There are few bandits in the border cities, what use are they?" He then sang, "Fox fur coat, three dukes in one state, to whom should I follow!" He finally completed the construction of the cities. When Shen Sheng died, the two princes also returned to defend their cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 18. In the sixteenth year, Duke Huan of Qi invaded Chu with his army, reaching Xingshan. King Cheng of Chu sent General Qu Wan to defend against him and formed an alliance with Duke Huan. Duke Huan repeatedly complained that the taxes levied by Zhou were not being paid to the royal court, and Chu agreed to this, so he withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 5.1. In governing, he skillfully turned misfortune into fortune and defeat into victory. He valued the importance of things and carefully weighed the options.
