Duke Huan was truly angry with Shao Ji and attacked Cai in the south. Guan Zhong then used this opportunity to attack Chu, demanding that they pay tribute of the bundled reeds to the Zhou court.
[655 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 3.2. At this time, Duke Xian of Jin destroyed the Northern Yu Duke of Zhou, thus opening the way for Jin's attack on Guo. Ju Bei died, and his son Qu Qi succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 31. In the twenty-second year, Duke Xian was furious that his two sons had left without saying goodbye, and indeed they had a plot. He then sent troops to attack Pu. Bo Di, a eunuch of Pu, ordered Chong'er to commit suicide. Chong'er jumped over the wall, but the eunuch chased after him and cut off his clothes. Chong'er then fled to Di. He sent men to attack Qu, but Qu was defended and could not be taken. 32. That year, Jin again requested passage through Yu to attack Guo. Gong Zhiqi, a high official of Yu, advised the ruler of Yu, saying, "Jin should not be allowed passage; it will only lead to the destruction of Yu." The ruler of Yu replied, "Jin is of the same surname as us; it is inappropriate for them to attack us." Gong Zhiqi said, "Taibo and Yu Zhong were sons of King Tai. Taibo fled, hence the lack of an heir. Guo Zhong and Guo Shu were sons of King Ji, serving as ministers to King Wen. Their merits are recorded in the royal court and stored in the covenant archives. If Guo is to be destroyed, why should we show mercy to Yu? Moreover, can the kin of Yu be as close as the clans of Huan and Zhuang? What crime did the clans of Huan and Zhuang commit that they should be exterminated? Yu and Guo are like lips and teeth; if the lips are gone, the teeth will be cold." The ruler of Yu did not listen and thus agreed to Jin's request. Gong Zhiqi and his clan left Yu. That winter, Jin destroyed Guo, and Duke Chou of Guo fled to Zhou. Upon returning, Jin attacked and destroyed Yu, capturing Duke Chou of Yu and his high official, Jingbo Baili Xi, to be given as a concubine to Qin Mu Ji, and then restored the Yu sacrifices. Xun Xi presented Duke Xian with the chariot that Yu Qu Chan had left behind. Duke Xian laughed and said, "The horse is my horse, but it is old!" 49. Duke Wen of Jin, Chong'er, was the son of Duke Xian of Jin. From a young age, he admired scholars. At the age of seventeen, he had five virtuous men: Zhao Cui; Hu Yanjiu Fan (Duke Wen's maternal uncle); Jia Tuo; Xian Zhen; and Wei Wuzi. Chong'er was already an adult when Duke Xian was the crown prince. When Duke Xian ascended the throne, Chong'er was twenty-one. In the thirteenth year of Duke Xian's reign, due to Li Ji's influence, Chong'er was assigned to defend Pu City against Qin. In the twenty-first year of Duke Xian's reign, Duke Xian killed Crown Prince Shen Sheng. Li Ji slandered him, and Chong'er, fearing for his life, did not leave Duke Xian but remained to defend Pu City. In the twenty-second year of Duke Xian's reign, Duke Xian sent the eunuch Lü Di to hasten Chong'er's death. Chong'er jumped over a wall, and the eunuch chased after him, tearing off his clothes. Chong'er then fled to Di, his mother's country. At that time, Chong'er was forty-three years old. From these five men, along with several dozen others whose names are unknown, they went to Di. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 7. Zhao Cui consulted the oracle regarding Duke Xian of Jin and his princes, and none were auspicious; he consulted the oracle regarding Prince Chong'er, and it was auspicious, so he served Chong'er. Chong'er fled to the Di people due to the chaos caused by Li Ji, and Zhao Cui followed him. The Di attacked Qiangjiuru and captured two women. The Di gave the younger daughter to Chong'er and the elder daughter to Zhao Cui, who bore him a son named Dun. Previously, when Chong'er was in Jin, Zhao Cui's wife had also given birth to Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Yingqi. Zhao Cui followed Chong'er into exile for nineteen years before returning to the country. Chong'er became Duke Wen of Jin, and Zhao Cui became the Grand Master of Yuan, residing in Yuan and handling state affairs. Duke Wen's return to power and eventual hegemony owed much to Zhao Cui's strategies, as detailed in the accounts in the *Annals of Jin*.
[654 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 19 (Duke Mu yr 6; Baili Xi brought). Five years later, Duke Xian of Jin conquered Yu and Guo, capturing the ruler of Yu and his minister Baili Xi, having bribed Yu with jade and horses. After capturing Baili Xi, he made him a concubine for the wife of Duke Mu of Qin. Baili Xi fled Qin to Wan, where he was captured by the common people of Chu. Duke Mu, hearing of Baili Xi's virtue, wanted to redeem him handsomely, but fearing the Chu people would refuse, he sent a messenger to Chu saying, "My concubine, Baili Xi, is here; please redeem him with five sheepskins." The Chu people agreed. At that time, Baili Xi was over seventy years old. Duke Mu released him and discussed state affairs with him. Baili Xi replied, "I am a minister of a fallen state; what is there to ask?" Duke Mu said, "The ruler of Yu did not employ you, hence his exile; it is not your fault." Duke Mu pressed him for answers, and after three days of conversation, Duke Mu was greatly pleased and entrusted him with the administration of the state, bestowing upon him the title of Minister of Five Sheep Skins. Baili Xirang said, “I am not as virtuous as my friend Jian Shu. Jian Shu is wise, but the world does not know him. I was often in distress in Qi and begged for food from the people of Zhi. Jian Shu took me in. I then wanted to serve the ruler of Qi, Wuzhi, but Jian Shu stopped me, and I escaped the troubles in Qi and went to Zhou. Prince Tui of Zhou loved cattle, and I served him by raising cattle. When Tui wanted to employ me, Jian Shu stopped me, and I left, thus avoiding punishment. I served the ruler of Yu, but Jian Shu stopped me. I knew that the ruler of Yu would not employ me, but I was truly seeking personal gain and rank, so I stayed. I listened to his advice twice and escaped; if he didn't employ me once, the ruler of Yu would face trouble. This is why I know he is wise.” Thereupon, Duke Mu sent someone with generous gifts to welcome Jian Shu and appointed him as a high-ranking official. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 33. In the twenty-third year, Duke Xian sent Jia Hua and others to attack Qu, and Qu was defeated. Yi Wu was about to flee to Di. Ji Rui said, "No, Chong'er is already dead. If we go now, Jin will surely send troops to attack Di. Di fears Jin, and disaster will befall them. It is better to flee to Liang. Liang is close to Qin, and Qin is strong. After our lord passes away, we can seek refuge there." So they fled to Liang. In the twenty-fifth year, Jin attacked Di. Because of Chong'er, Di also attacked Jin at Niesang, and Jin's troops withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 19.1. In the eighteenth year, King Cheng led his army north to attack Xu. The ruler of Xu bared his chest in apology, and King Cheng released him.
[653 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 3.1. After Duke Zhuang's death, his younger brother Chujiu was enthroned as Duke Xuan. In the eleventh year of Duke Xuan's reign, he killed his crown prince, Yukou.
[652 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 47.1. In the twenty-fifth year, King Hui died, [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 34. At that time, Jin was powerful, bordering Hexi to the west, bordering Qin, bordering Di to the north, and extending to Henan to the east. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 3.2. Yukou and Wan were in love, and fearing for their lives, Wan fled to Qi. Duke Huan of Qi wanted to appoint him as a minister, but he declined, saying, "As a traveler, I am fortunate to be spared from the burdens of official life; this is a great favor from Your Majesty, and I dare not accept such a high position."
[651 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 47.2. and his son, King Xiang of Zheng, ascended the throne. King Xiang's mother had died young, and his stepmother was Queen Hui. Queen Hui gave birth to Shu Dai, who was favored by King Hui, and King Xiang feared him. Three years later, Shu Dai conspired with the Rong and Di tribes to attack King Xiang. King Xiang wanted to execute Shu Dai, so Shu Dai fled to Qi. Duke Huan of Qi sent Guan Zhong to pacify the Rong in Zhou and Xi Peng to pacify the Rong in Jin. The king treated Guan Zhong with the respect due to a high-ranking official. Guan Zhong declined, saying, "I am but a lowly official, and I have two guardians of the state, Gao Zai, who are high above me. If you come to receive the king's command according to the seasons, how can I be treated with such respect? I dare not refuse." The king said, "Uncle, I admire your merits; do not disobey my command." Guan Zhong then accepted the respect due to a lower-ranking official and returned. Nine years later, Duke Huan of Qi died. Twelve years later, Shu Dai returned to Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 21 (Duke Mu yr 9; Kuiqiu). In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Kuiqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 38.1. In the ninth year, Li Ke of Jin killed his ruler Xi Qi and Zhuo Zi. Duke Huan of Qi, along with Duke Li, quelled the rebellion in Jin, reaching Gaoliang before returning and installing Duke Hui of Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 35. Li Ji's younger brother mourned his son. 36. In the summer of the twenty-sixth year, Duke Huan of Qi convened a grand assembly of the feudal lords at Kuiqiu. Duke Xian of Jin fell ill and traveled behind, but before arriving, he met Zai Kong of Zhou. Zai Kong said, "Duke Huan of Qi is arrogant and does not pursue virtue but rather distant strategies, which displeases the feudal lords. Your Majesty, do not attend the assembly, lest you suffer the same fate as Jin." Duke Xian also fell ill and returned home. His illness worsened, and he said to Xun Xi, "I have chosen Xi Qi as my heir, but he is young, and the ministers are not convinced, fearing that chaos may break out. Can you establish him as heir?" Xun Xi said, "Yes." Duke Xian asked, "How can I prove it?" Xun Xi replied, "By bringing the dead back to life and ensuring the living are not ashamed, that will be the proof." Thus, Xi Qi was placed under Xun Xi's control. Xun Xi became prime minister and managed the state affairs. In the ninth month of autumn, Duke Xian died. Li Ke and Pi Zheng wanted to bring Chong'er (Duke Xian's father) into the inner palace and, with the followers of the three princes, rebelled. They said to Xun Xi, "Three resentments are about to arise, with Qin and Jin supporting them. What will you do?" Xun Xi said, "I cannot betray my late lord's words." In the tenth month, Li Ke killed Xi Qi at the funeral, before Duke Xian was buried. Xun Xi was about to die when someone suggested that Xi Qi's younger brother, Dao Zi, should be made emperor and given tutor status. Xun Xi then made Dao Zi emperor and buried Duke Xian. In the eleventh month, Li Ke assassinated Dao Zi in court, and Xun Xi died for him. A gentleman said, "The poem says, 'Even a flaw in a white jade can be polished, but the flaw in words cannot be undone.' This must be referring to Xun Xi! He did not fail in his words." Initially, when Duke Xian was about to attack the Li Rong, the divination said, "Teeth will bring disaster." After defeating the Li Rong, he captured Li Ji, fell in love with her, and ultimately used her to bring chaos to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 3.3. Duke Huan then appointed him as the Minister of Works. Duke Yizhong of Qi wanted to marry Wan to him, and consulted a divination master. The divination said, "This is like the phoenix soaring, its cries harmonious and melodious. A descendant of the Gui clan will be born in the Jiang clan. Five generations will prosper, and they will become high ministers. After eight generations, none will be able to rival them." Duke Huan then married Wan to Wan. Wan fled to Qi, and Duke Huan of Qi had been on the throne for fourteen years. 4. After his death, he was posthumously honored as Jingzhong. Jingzhong begat his son, Mengyi. When Jingzhong went to Qi, he adopted the surname Tian, using the character Chen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 1.3. Once employed, Guan Zhong governed Qi, and Duke Huan of Qi became a hegemon, uniting the feudal lords nine times and bringing order to the world—all thanks to Guan Zhong's strategies.
[650 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 22 (Duke Mu yr 10; Jin succession crisis). Duke Xian of Jin died. He installed Xi Qi, son of Li Ji, as emperor, but Xi Qi was killed by his minister Li Ke. Xun Xi installed Zhuo Zi as emperor, but Ke killed both Zhuo Zi and Xun Xi. Yi Wu sent someone to Qin to request entry into Jin. Duke Mu of Jin agreed and sent Baili Xi with troops to escort Yi Wu. Yi Wu said, "If I am indeed installed, I will cede eight cities west of the Yellow River to Qin." Upon arrival, he was already installed, but then sent Pi Zheng to apologize to Qin, breaking the agreement by not giving the cities west of the Yellow River and killing Li Ke. Pi Zheng, upon hearing this, was afraid and conspired with Duke Mu, saying, "The people of Jin do not want Yi Wu, but truly want Chong Er. Their breaking of the agreement with Qin and killing Li Ke is all a scheme by Lü Sheng and Que Rui. I hope Your Majesty will quickly summon Lü and Que for profit. Once they arrive, it will be convenient to let Chong Er enter." Duke Mu agreed and sent someone back with Pi Zheng to summon Lü and Que. Lü and Que suspected Pi Zheng of having ulterior motives and then said that Yi Wu had killed Pi Zheng. Pi Zhengzi Pi Bao fled to Qin and said to Duke Mu, "The ruler of Jin is wicked, and the people are not on good terms with him. We should attack him." Duke Mu said, "If the people are not happy, how can they execute their ministers? If they can execute their ministers, that is their way of governing." He did not listen to this advice, but secretly used Bao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 34. In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Wen of Wei faced a rebellion by the Di people and appealed to Qi for help. Qi led the feudal lords to build a city wall at Chuqiu and installed the ruler of Wei on the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 37. Li Ke and others had already killed Xi Qi and Dao Zi, and sent men to welcome Prince Chong'er from Di, intending to establish him as ruler. Chong'er declined, saying, "I fled here against my father's orders, and now that he is dead, I cannot even perform the rites of a son in mourning. How dare I enter! You should establish another son." He returned to report to Li Ke, who then sent men to welcome Yi Wu from Liang. Yi Wu wanted to go, but Lü Sheng and Que Rui said, "There is still a prince within the state who can be established, and it is difficult to trust someone outside. It is not advisable to go to Qin, and to rely on the power of a strong state to enter, which may be dangerous." So he sent Que Rui to bribe Qin generously, saying, "If you are able to enter, we will give Qin the land west of the Yellow River in Jin." He also sent a letter to Li Ke saying, "If you are truly established, please grant your son the fief of Fenyang." Duke Mu of Qin then sent troops to escort Yi Wu to Jin. Duke Huan of Qi, hearing of the internal strife in Jin, also led the feudal lords to Jin. The Qin army and Yi Wu also arrived in Jin, and Qi then sent Xi Peng to meet with Qin to bring Yi Wu in, establishing him as the ruler of Jin, who became Duke Hui. Duke Huan of Qi went to Gaoliang in Jin and then returned home. 38. In the first year of Duke Hui of Jin's reign (1122), Duke Hui sent Pi Zheng to apologize to Qin, saying, "Initially, I promised you the land west of the Yellow River, and now I have been fortunate enough to ascend the throne. However, my ministers said, 'This land belongs to your late father; you are currently in exile. How can you presume to grant it to Qin?' I argued against it but could not obtain it, therefore I apologize to Qin." He also refused to grant Li Ke the city of Fenyang, and instead seized its power. In the fourth month, King Xiang of Zhou sent Duke Ji Fu of Zhou to meet with the officials of Qi and Qin to jointly pay homage to Duke Hui of Jin. Duke Hui, fearing that Li Ke might cause trouble while Chong'er was away, ordered Li Ke to commit suicide. He said to Li Ke, "Without Li Ke, I would not have been able to ascend the throne. However, you have also killed two rulers and one high official. Is it not difficult for a ruler to be a ruler?" Li Ke replied, "Without deposing someone, how can a ruler rise? If you wish to kill him, do you have no excuse? Yet you speak of it! I have received your command." He then fell on his sword and died. Since Pi Zheng's envoy to Qin had not yet returned, the trouble did not occur. 39. The Duke of Jin reburied Crown Prince Shen Sheng. In the autumn, Hu Tu went to the capital and met Shen Sheng. Shen Sheng, carrying him, told him, "Yi Wu was disrespectful. I have been granted permission by the Emperor to cede Jin to Qin, and Qin will then offer sacrifices to me." Hu Tu replied, "I have heard that gods who do not eat are not of their own lineage. Your Majesty, will your sacrifices cease? You should consider this." Shen Sheng said, "Yes, I will again request permission from the Emperor. Ten days later, a shaman will appear before me on the western side of Xincheng." The Emperor granted his request and did not see him. When the appointed time arrived, Shen Sheng went again and told him, "The Emperor has agreed to punish the guilty, and the state of Han will suffer." The children then spread a rhyme: "Crown Prince Gong has been reburied; fourteen years later, Jin will not prosper, but prosperity will reside with the elder brother." [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 19.2. In the twenty-second year, he attacked Huang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 3 (discursive; end-of-Bao-Shu era). When Bao Shu recommended Guan Zhong, he treated him with utmost respect. His descendants held hereditary official positions in Qi, with some having fiefs for over ten generations, and all serving as prominent officials. The world praised Bao Shu's ability to recognize talent more than Guan Zhong's own virtue.
[649 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 35. In the twenty-ninth year, Duke Huan and his wife, Lady Cai, were playing on a boat. Lady Cai, skilled in swimming, accidentally splashed the Duke. Fearing this, the Duke tried to stop her, but she wouldn't stop. He got off the boat, became angry, and returned Lady Cai to him, but the relationship didn't end there. Lady Cai was also angry and married off her daughter to him. Duke Huan heard of this and was furious, so he raised an army to attack. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 40. Pi Zheng, an envoy to Qin, upon hearing of Li Ke's execution, persuaded Duke Mu of Qin, saying, "Lü Sheng, Que Cheng, and Ji Rui are truly disobedient. If you offer them generous bribes and plot with them, sending the Duke of Jin to surrender and bringing Chong'er into the capital, the matter will surely succeed." Duke Mu agreed and sent someone to return with him to Jin, offering the three men generous bribes. The three men said, "The bribes are generous and the words are sweet; Pi Zheng must have betrayed us to Qin." They then killed Pi Zheng, Li Ke, and seven ministers who were part of Pi Zheng's faction. Pi Zheng's son, Bao, fled to Qin, advocating for an attack on Jin, but Duke Mu refused to listen.
[648 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 23 (Duke Mu yr 12). In the twelfth year, Qi Guan Zhong and Xi Peng died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 36. In the spring of the thirtieth year, Duke Huan of Qi led the feudal lords to attack Cai, and Cai was defeated. He then attacked Chu. King Cheng of Chu raised an army and asked, "Why have you crossed our territory?" Guan Zhong replied, "In the past, Duke Kang of Shao instructed my ancestor, Duke Tai, saying, 'If you truly conquer the five marquises and nine earls, you will be able to assist the Zhou dynasty.' He bestowed upon my ancestor a territory extending east to the sea, west to the Yellow River, south to Muling, and north to Wudi. Chu has failed to deliver its tribute of bundled reeds, and the royal sacrifices have been incomplete; therefore, we have come to demand an explanation. King Zhao's southern expedition did not return; therefore, we have come to inquire." The King of Chu said, "The failure to deliver the tribute is my fault; how could I refuse to provide it? As for King Zhao's expedition, which did not return, Your Majesty should inquire at the riverbank." The Qi army advanced and encamped at Xing. In the summer, the King of Chu sent Qu Wan to lead troops to defend against Qi, and the Qi army retreated to Zhaoling. Duke Huan was arrogant towards Qu Wan and his troops. Qu Wan said, "If Your Majesty acts according to the Way, it is acceptable; if not, then Chu will use Fangcheng as a city wall and the Yangtze and Han rivers as moats. How can Your Majesty advance then?" He then made an alliance with Qu Wan and departed. After passing through Chen, Chen Yuan Tao tricked Qi, ordering them to go east, but the deception was discovered. In autumn, Qi attacked Chen. That year, Jin killed Crown Prince Shen Sheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 41. When Duke Hui ascended the throne, he expanded the territory of Qin and Li, and executed seven high-ranking officials. The people of Jin did not support him. Two years later, the Zhou envoy, Duke Shao, visited Duke Hui of Jin and paid respects to him. Duke Hui was arrogant in his manners, and Duke Shao criticized him for it.
[647 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 24 (Duke Mu yr 13; Jin famine grain). Jin suffered a drought and came to request grain. Pi Bao advised Duke Mu not to give it to them, arguing that they should take advantage of the famine to attack. Duke Mu asked Gongsun Zhi, who replied, "Famine is a matter of course; we cannot refuse to give it to them." He then asked Baili Xi, who said, "Yi Wu has offended the ruler, but what crime have the people committed?" Duke Mu then heeded the advice of Baili Xi and Gongsun Zhi and ultimately gave them grain. Using boats and carts, the grain was transported from Yong to Jiang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 42. In the fourth year, Jin suffered a famine and begged Qin for grain. Duke Mu asked Baili Xi, who replied, "Heavenly calamities are frequent, and states rise and fall. It is the way of the state to relieve calamities and help neighboring states. Give it to them." Zheng Zibao of Pi said, "Attack them." Duke Mu said, "If their ruler is wicked, what crime have their people committed!" In the end, he gave them grain, from Yong to Jiang.
[646 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 25.1 (Duke Mu yr 14; Qin famine). In the fourteenth year, Qin suffered a famine and requested grain from Jin. The Duke of Jin consulted his ministers. Guo She said, "Taking advantage of their famine to attack them will bring great victory." The Duke of Jin agreed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 19.3. In the twenty-sixth year, he destroyed Ying.
[645 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 25.2 (Duke Mu yr 15; battle of Han region). In the fifteenth year, Qin raised an army to attack Qin. Duke Mu of Jin dispatched troops, sending Pi Bao as general, while he himself went to attack. On the day of Renxu in the ninth month, Qin clashed with Duke Hui of Jin, Yi Wu, in the Han region. The Duke of Jin abandoned his army to fight Qin for resources, and returned with his horse, Hei. Duke Mu and his men pursued him, but could not capture the Duke of Jin and were instead surrounded by the Jin army. Jin attacked Duke Mu, and he was wounded. Then, three hundred men from Qi who had eaten fine horses charged into the Jin army, breaking the siege and freeing Duke Mu, who was then captured alive. Initially, when Duke Mu lost his fine horses, more than three hundred people from the countryside of Qi found and ate them. Officials pursued and captured them, intending to punish them. Duke Mu said, "A gentleman does not harm people with livestock. I have heard that eating fine horse meat without drinking wine is harmful." He then gave them all wine and pardoned them. Three hundred men, hearing that Qin had attacked Jin, all sought to join him. Upon seeing Duke Mu in distress, they too were ready to fight to the death, to repay the kindness of feeding him horses. Duke Mu then captured the Duke of Jin and brought him back, issuing an order to the state: "I will offer the Duke of Jin as a sacrifice to the Supreme God." The Zhou Emperor, hearing this, said, "Jin is of the same surname as us," and pleaded for the Duke of Jin's return. Yi Wu's sister was also Duke Mu's wife. Upon hearing this, she donned mourning clothes and went barefoot, saying, "My brothers and I could not save you, thus disgracing your command." Duke Mu said, "I have gained the Duke of Jin as a merit, and now the Emperor pleads for me; my wife is worried." He then made an alliance with the Duke of Jin, agreeing to let him return, providing him with a superior lodging and seven kinds of sacrificial animals. In the eleventh month, Duke Yi Wu of Jin was returned. Yi Wu surrendered his land west of the Yellow River and sent his son, Prince Yu, as a hostage to Qin. Qin gave Yu his wife and children, along with a woman from the imperial clan. At that time, Qin's territory extended east to the Yellow River. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 44. In the spring of the sixth year, Duke Mu of Qin led his army to attack Jin. Duke Hui of Jin said to Qing Zheng, "The Qin army is deeply entrenched, what should we do?" Zheng replied, "Qin has been besieging the capital, and you have doubled your bribes; Jin is starving, and Qin has supplied grain, and Qin is starving, and Jin has doubled its bribes. Now they want to take advantage of the famine to attack us: is it not fitting that they are so deeply entrenched?" Jin consulted the oracle for the right charioteer, and both Qing Zheng's interpretations were auspicious. The Duke said, "Zheng is disrespectful." He then ordered Bu Yang to drive the chariot, and his household servants to serve as the right charioteer, and advanced the army. On the day of Renxu in the ninth month, Duke Mu of Qin and Duke Hui of Jin fought a combined battle at Hanyuan. Duke Hui's charioteer could not move, and the Qin army arrived. The Duke was in dire straits and summoned Qing Zheng to drive the chariot. Zheng said, "We did not consult the oracle; is defeat not to be expected?" He then left. He then ordered Liang Yaomi to drive the chariot, and Guo She to serve as the right charioteer, and led Duke Mu of Qin in his chariot. Duke Mu's brave warriors braved the Jin army and defeated them. The Jin army was defeated, and Duke Mu of Qin was lost. Instead, the Duke of Jin was captured and brought back. Qin was going to use this to worship the Supreme God. The sister of the Duke of Jin, who was the wife of Duke Mu, wore mourning clothes and wept. Duke Mu of Qin said, "I thought I would be happy to have the Duke of Jin, but now this is how it is. Moreover, I heard that when Ji Zi met Tang Shu when he was first enfeoffed, he said, 'His descendants will surely be great.' How can Jin be destroyed?" So he made an alliance with the Duke of Jin at the royal city and allowed him to return. The Duke of Jin also sent Lü Sheng and others to inform the people of his state, saying, "Although I have been able to return, I have no face to see the altars of the state. I will choose an auspicious day to establish Zi Yu." When the people of Jin heard this, they all wept. Duke Mu of Qin asked Lü Sheng, "Is Jin at peace?" He replied, "No. The common people are afraid of losing their ruler and relatives, so they do not hesitate to establish Zi Yu, saying, 'We will avenge our enemies, even if it means serving the Rong and Di tribes.' The gentlemen, on the other hand, love their ruler and know their crimes, awaiting Qin's command, saying, 'We will repay kindness.' Because of these two reasons, they are not at peace." So Duke Mu of Qin took Duke Hui of Jin as his host and provided him with seven sacrificial animals. In the eleventh month, the Duke of Jin was returned. Upon arriving in his state, the Duke of Jin executed Qing Zheng and reformed the government and education. He plotted, saying, "With Chong'er abroad, many of the other states are eager to bring him in." He wanted to send someone to kill Chong'er in the Di territory. Chong'er heard of this and went to Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 6.1. Guan Zhong was as wealthy as the royal family, possessing three residences and a double-sided altar, yet the people of Qi did not consider it extravagant. After Guan Zhong's death, the state of Qi followed his policies and remained stronger than the other states.
[644 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 50. Di attacked Jiu Ru and obtained two women: he married the elder to Chong'er, who bore him Bo Tun and Shu Liu; he married the younger to Zhao Cui, who bore him Dun. Five years after Chong'er settled in Di, Duke Xian of Jin died. Li Ke, having already killed Xi Qi and Dao Zi, sent men to welcome Chong'er to the capital, intending to install him as emperor. Chong'er, fearing for his life, firmly declined and dared not enter. Later, Jin welcomed his younger brother Yi Wu to the capital, who became Duke Hui. In the seventh year of Duke Hui's reign, fearing Chong'er, he sent the eunuch Lü Di and some strong men to kill him. Chong'er, hearing this, consulted with Zhao Cui and others, saying, "When I fled to Di, it wasn't because I thought they were useful, but because it was close and easy to communicate with, so I rested there. I've rested there for a long time, and I sincerely wish to move to a powerful state. Duke Huan of Qi is benevolent and aspires to hegemony, and he cares for the feudal lords. Now, hearing of the deaths of Guan Zhong and Xi Peng, he also desires wise advisors. Why don't we go?" So he went. Chong'er said to his wife, "Wait for me for twenty-five years before you marry me." His wife laughed and said, "If you plow for twenty-five years, the cypress trees on my grave will be very tall. However, I will wait for you." Chong'er lived in the Di region for twelve years before leaving. 51. When Chong'er passed through Wei, Duke Wen of Wei did not treat him with courtesy. On his way, he passed through Wulu and, being hungry, begged for food from a rustic. The rustic offered him food in an earthen vessel. Chong'er was furious. Zhao Cui said, "Earth means soil; Your Majesty should accept it with a bow." 52. Upon arriving in Qi, Duke Huan of Qi treated him with great hospitality, marrying him a princess from his own clan and providing him with twenty chariots. Chong'er was content. Two years after Chong'er's arrival in Qi, Duke Huan died, and a civil war broke out involving Shu Dao and others. Duke Xiao of Qi ascended the throne, and the armies of the other states repeatedly arrived. Chong'er remained in Qi for five years. He loved the Qi woman and was determined not to leave. Zhao Cui and Jiu Fan then plotted their departure under a mulberry tree. A servant of the Qi woman overheard them from the mulberry tree and informed her mistress. The mistress then killed the servant and urged Chong'er to leave quickly. Chong'er said, "Life is peaceful and joyful; who knows anything else! I will surely die here; I cannot leave." The Qi woman said, "You are a prince of a state, arriving here in poverty. Several men depend on you for their lives. You do not hurry to return to your country to repay your loyal ministers, but instead cherish your feminine virtues. I am ashamed of you. Moreover, if you do not seek anything, when will you achieve anything?" She then conspired with Zhao Cui and others to get Chong'er drunk and put him on a journey. After traveling a long distance, they awoke, and Chong'er was furious. He drew his spear, intending to kill Jiu Fan. Jiu Fan said, "Killing my son Cheng is Yan's wish." Chong'er said, "If things don't go well, I will eat my uncle's flesh." Jiu Fan said, "If things don't go well, my flesh is foul and disgusting, what is there to eat!" So he stopped and left.
[643 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 37. In the summer of the thirty-fifth year, the feudal lords met at Kuiqiu. King Xiang of Zhou sent Zai Kong to bestow upon Duke Huan a sacrificial offering of Wenwu, a red bow and arrows, and a large road, ordering him not to bow. Duke Huan wanted to accept, but Guan Zhong said, "No," so he bowed and accepted the gifts. In the autumn, he again met with the feudal lords at Kuiqiu, and became even more arrogant. Zhou sent Zai Kong to the meeting. Some of the feudal lords rebelled. Duke Huan of Jin fell ill and later met Zai Kong. Zai Kong said, "Duke Huan of Qi is arrogant, and his brother is unruly." This was agreed upon. That year, Duke Xian of Jin died, and Li Ke killed Xi Qi and Zhuo Zi. Duke Mu of Qin gave his wife to Prince Yi Wu to become the ruler of Jin. Duke Huan then quelled the rebellion in Jin, reaching Gaoliang, where he sent Xi Peng to establish the ruler of Jin before returning. 38. At that time, the Zhou dynasty was weak, and only Qi, Chu, Qin, and Jin were strong. Jin initially participated in the alliance, but Duke Xian died, and the country was in turmoil. Duke Mu of Qin fled to distant lands and did not participate in the alliance with the Central States. King Cheng of Chu initially conquered the Jingman tribes, and the barbarians were left to their own devices. Only Qi participated in the alliance with the Central States, and Duke Huan was able to promote its virtue, so the other feudal lords held a gathering. Thereupon, Duke Huan said: "I have marched south to Zhaoling, and looked towards Xiongshan; I have marched north to Shanrong, Lizhi, and Guzhu; I have marched west to Daxia, and crossed the quicksand; I have bound my horses and suspended my chariots to climb Taihang, and returned to Beiershan. None of the feudal lords have disobeyed me. I have held three military chariot gatherings and six chariot gatherings, and have united the feudal lords nine times, thus restoring order to the world. How is this different from the mandate of heaven received by the three dynasties? I wish to perform the Feng and Shan sacrifices at Mount Tai and Liangfu." Guan Zhong strongly advised against it, but he did not listen; so he persuaded Duke Huan to send rare and exotic creatures from afar so that he could be granted the fiefdom, and Duke Huan then stopped. 39. In the thirty-eighth year, King Xiang of Zhou's younger brother, Dai, conspired with the Rong and Di tribes to attack Zhou. Qi sent Guan Zhong to quell the Rong. Zhou intended to treat Guan Zhong with the respect due to a high-ranking minister, but Guan Zhong bowed deeply and said, "I am but a humble servant, how dare I!" He declined three times before finally accepting the respect due to a lower-ranking minister. In the thirty-ninth year, King Xiang of Zhou's younger brother, Dai, fled to Qi. Qi sent Zhongsun to request the king to apologize on Dai's behalf. King Xiang was angry and refused to listen. 40. In the forty-first year, Duke Mu of Qin captured Duke Hui of Jin, but later released him. That same year, both Guan Zhong and Xi Peng died. When Guan Zhong fell ill, Duke Huan asked, "Who among your ministers is suitable to be your prime minister?" Guan Zhong replied, "No one knows me better than you, my lord." The Duke asked, "What about Yi Ya?" Guan Zhong replied, "To kill one's own son to serve you is against human nature; it is unacceptable." The Duke asked, "What about Kai Fang?" Guan Zhong replied, "To betray one's own family to serve you is against human nature; it is difficult to befriend him." The Duke asked, "What about Shu Dao?" Guan Zhong replied, "To castrate himself to serve you is against human nature; it is difficult to befriend him." After Guan Zhong's death, Duke Huan did not heed his advice and instead favored three of his sons, who then seized power. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 38.2. In the seventeenth year, Duke Huan of Qi died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 45. In the eighth year, the Crown Prince Yu was sent as a hostage to Qin. Initially, when Duke Hui was in exile in Liang, the Duke of Liang married his daughter to him, and they had a son and a daughter. The Duke of Liang consulted the oracle, which predicted that the son would become a minister and the daughter a concubine, hence the son was named Yu and the daughter a concubine.
[642 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 26 (Duke Mu yr 18/20 era). In the eighteenth year, Duke Huan of Qi died. In the twentieth year, Qin conquered Liang and Rui. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 43. Five years later, Qin suffered a famine and requested grain from Jin. The Duke of Jin considered this, and Qing Zheng said, "Qin gained power by breaking its promise of territory. Now that Jin is famined, Qin has lent us grain. Why should we hesitate to give it to them when they are starving? Let's plan this!" Guo She said, "In the past, Heaven bestowed Jin upon Qin, but Qin did not know to take it and instead lent it to us. Today, Heaven bestows Qin upon Jin; can Jin defy Heaven? We should attack them." Duke Hui followed Guo She's advice, refused to give Qin grain, and instead sent troops to attack Qin. Qin was furious and also sent troops to attack Jin.
[641 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 46. Ten years later, Qin destroyed Liang. The ruler of Liang was fond of earthworks and built city moats. The people were exhausted and resentful. The people were often alarmed, saying, "The Qin invaders are coming." The people were fearful and confused, and Qin eventually destroyed Liang.
[640 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 20 (Duke Mu yr 20; expedition vs Jin context). In autumn, Duke Mu personally led an expedition against Jin, and the battle took place at the Yellow River bend. Li Ji of Jin rebelled, Crown Prince Shen was killed in Xincheng, and Chong'er and Yi Wu fled. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 41. In the forty-second year, the Rong attacked Zhou, and Zhou appealed to Qi for help. Qi ordered all the feudal lords to send troops to garrison Zhou. In that year, Prince Chong'er of Jin came, and Duke Huan married him to him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 5. Tian Zhimengyi begat Minmengzhuang, and Tian Minmengzhuang begat Wenzi Xuwu. Tian Wenzi served Duke Zhuang of Qi.
[639 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 48.1. In the thirteenth year, Zheng attacked Hua. The king sent Yousun and Bofu to plead for Hua's release, but the people of Zheng imprisoned them. Duke Wen of Zheng resented King Hui's failure to grant Duke Li permission during his visit, and also resented King Xiang's alliance with Wei and Hua, hence the imprisonment of Bofu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 53. When Chong'er passed through Cao, Duke Gong of Cao was disrespectful, wanting to see Chong'er's conjoined ribs. Cao's minister, Li Fuji, said, "The prince of Jin is virtuous and of the same surname. He has come to visit us in poverty; why are you so disrespectful?" Duke Gong did not heed his advice. Fuji then secretly gave Chong'er food, placing a jade disc beneath it. Chong'er accepted the food and returned the disc. 54. They went to Song. Duke Xiang of Song had just suffered a military setback at Chu and was wounded at Hong. Hearing of Chong'er's wisdom, he treated Chong'er with the courtesy due to a state official. Gongsun Gu, the Sima of Song, was skilled at dealing with Jiu Fan and said, "Song is a small state that has just suffered a setback and is not worthy of seeking entry. Let us go to a larger state instead." So they left. 55. When the prince of Jin passed through Zheng, Duke Wen of Zheng did not treat him with proper respect. Shu Zhan of Zheng advised his lord, saying, "The prince of Jin is virtuous, and his followers are all prime ministers of their respective states, and they are also of the same surname. Zheng originated from King Li, while Jin originated from King Wu." The lord of Zheng said, "Many princes of other states have passed through here; how can we treat them all with proper respect?" Shu Zhan said, "If Your Majesty does not treat him with respect, it would be better to kill him, otherwise he will become a threat to the state in the future." The lord of Zheng did not listen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 20.1. In the thirty-third year, Duke Xiang of Song wished to hold an alliance meeting and summoned the King of Chu. The King of Chu was furious and said, "You summoned me, so I will go and humiliate you." He then went to Meng, where he captured and humiliated Duke Xiang of Song, and then returned him.
[638 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 27.1 (Duke Mu yr 22; Prince Yu flees). In the twenty-second year, Prince Yu of Jin, hearing of the illness of the Duke of Jin, said, "Liang is my maternal family, yet Qin destroyed it. I have many brothers; even after the Duke's death, Qin will surely spare me, while Jin, feeling insignificant, will install another son." Prince Yu then fled back to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 47. In the thirteenth year, Duke Hui of Jin fell ill, and he had several sons. Crown Prince Yu said, "My mother's family is in Liang, which has now been destroyed by Qin. I am outwardly weak against Qin and inwardly without any support from my state. If Your Majesty does not recover, the sick ministers will be less powerful; you should install another prince." He then plotted to flee with his wife back to Jin. The Qin woman said, "You are the crown prince of a state, yet you are disgraced here. Qin has sent a maidservant to serve you to secure your loyalty. If you flee, I will not follow you, nor will I dare to speak of it." Crown Prince Yu then fled back to Jin. In the ninth month of the fourteenth year, Duke Hui died, and Crown Prince Yu ascended the throne, becoming Duke Huai. 56. When Chong'er went to Chu, King Cheng of Chu treated him with the courtesy due to a visiting vassal, but Chong'er declined, saying he dared not accept. Zhao Cui said, "You have been in exile for more than ten years. Small states look down on you, let alone large states. Now that Chu is a large state, it treats you well. You should not refuse; this is Heaven's blessing upon you." So he received him with the courtesy due to a guest. King Cheng treated Chong'er generously, but Chong'er remained very humble. King Cheng said, "If you return to your country, how will you repay me?" Chong'er replied, "Feathers, teeth, horns, jade, and silk are all that Your Majesty has left; I do not know how to repay you." The King said, "Even so, how will you repay me?" Chong'er said, "If it is unavoidable, I will meet Your Majesty with chariots on the plains and marshes, and request that Your Majesty grant me three she (a unit of distance) of retreat." The Chu general Ziyu angrily said, "Your Majesty has treated the Prince of Jin with great kindness, and now Chong'er speaks disrespectfully; I request that he be killed." King Cheng said, "The Prince of Jin is virtuous but has been trapped abroad for a long time; his followers are all pillars of the state. This is Heaven's will; how can he be killed? Besides, how can he be replaced!" After staying in Chu for several months, Prince Yu of Jin fled to Qin, and Qin resented him. Hearing that Chong'er was in Chu, they summoned him. King Cheng said, "Chu is far away; one must travel through several states to reach Jin. Qin and Jin are bordering each other; the ruler of Qin is virtuous. You should go well!" He gave Chong'er a generous send-off. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 20.2. In the thirty-fourth year, Duke Wen of Zheng went south to pay homage to Chu. King Cheng of Chu launched a northern expedition against Song, defeated him at Hong, and wounded Duke Xiang of Song with an arrow. Duke Xiang then fell ill from his wound and died.
[637 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 48.2. The king was furious and planned to use the Di tribes to attack Zheng. Fu Chen advised, "Whenever our Zhou moved east, Jin and Zheng relied on us. The rebellion of Zi Tui was also due to Zheng's pacification; now we abandon them for a small grudge!" The king did not listen. In the fifteenth year, the king surrendered the Di army to attack Zheng. The king was grateful to the Di people and intended to make their daughter his queen. Fu Chen advised, "Ping, Huan, Zhuang, and Hui all received favors from Zheng; Your Majesty should not abandon your close relationship with the Di." The king did not listen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 27.2 (Duke Mu yr 23; Duke Hui of Jin dies). In the twenty-third year, Duke Hui of Jin died, and Prince Yu ascended the throne. Qin, resentful of Prince Yu's departure, welcomed Prince Chong'er of Jin to Chu, and gave him Prince Yu's former wife. Chong'er initially declined, but later accepted. Duke Mu of Jin treated him with great courtesy. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 57. When Chong'er arrived in Qin, Duke Mu of Jin offered him five daughters of his royal clan, including the wife of his late son, Yu. Chong'er was reluctant to accept, but Sikong Jizi said, "Your country is about to be attacked; what more can you offer than your former wife? Accepting her is a way to forge a alliance with Qin and gain entry. You are bound by petty etiquette and forget the greater shame!" So Chong'er accepted. Duke Mu was overjoyed and drank with Chong'er. Zhao Cui sang a poem about millet seedlings. Duke Mu said, "I know you are eager to return to your country." Zhao Cui and Chong'er stepped down, bowed twice, and said, "Your humble servant's reliance on you is like the longing of a hundred grains for timely rain." This was in the autumn of the fourteenth year of Duke Hui of Jin. Duke Hui died in the ninth month, and his son Yu succeeded him. In the eleventh month, Duke Hui was buried. In the twelfth month, the Jin officials Luan and Que, hearing that Chong'er was in Qin, secretly came to persuade Chong'er, Zhao Cui, and others to return to their country, acting as numerous internal allies. Therefore, Duke Mu of Qin sent troops to escort Chong'er back to Jin. When Jin heard of the Qin troops' arrival, it also sent troops to resist them. However, they all secretly knew that Prince Chong'er had entered. Only Lü and Que, former high-ranking officials of Duke Hui, did not want Chong'er to be established as emperor. Chong'er had been in exile for nineteen years before being allowed to return, at which time he was sixty-two years old, and many people of Jin sided with him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 21. In the thirty-fifth year, Prince Chong'er of Jin passed through Chu. King Cheng treated him with the courtesy due to a guest of a feudal lord and gave him a generous send-off to Qin.
[636 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 48.3. In the sixteenth year, the king dismissed the Di queen, and the Di people came to execute her, killing Tan Bo. Fu Chen said, "I have repeatedly advised against this, but to no avail. If I do not go forth, will Your Majesty consider me a traitor?" He then had his entourage executed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 27.3 (Duke Mu yr 24; Chong’er installed). In the spring of the twenty-fourth year, Qin sent a messenger to inform the ministers of Jin that they wished to bring Chong'er to Jin. Jin agreed, and thus sent someone to escort Chong'er. In February, Chong'er ascended the throne as Duke Wen of Jin. Duke Wen then had Prince Yu killed. Prince Yu became Duke Huai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 38.3. In the twenty-fourth year, Duke Wen of Jin ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 48. After Zi Yu's exile, Qin harbored resentment and sought out Prince Chong'er, intending to bring him into Qin. Zi Yu, fearing Qin's attack, ascended the throne. He then ordered all those in the state who had followed Chong'er to meet a deadline; those who failed to arrive by the deadline would have their families exterminated. Hu Tu's sons, Mao and Yan, were with Chong'er in Qin and refused to be summoned. Duke Huai was furious and imprisoned Hu Tu. Hu Tu said, "My sons have served Chong'er for many years; to summon them now would be to teach them to rebel against their ruler. How can I teach them?" Duke Huai ultimately killed Hu Tu. Duke Mu of Qin then sent troops to escort Chong'er into Qin, sending envoys to inform Luan and Que's faction as insiders. They killed Duke Huai at Gaoliang and brought Chong'er into Qin. Chong'er ascended the throne as Duke Wen. 58. In the spring of the first year of Duke Wen's reign, Qin escorted Chong'er to the Yellow River. Jiu Fan said, "I have followed you throughout the world, and I have made many mistakes. I know this, how much more so you! Please allow me to leave." Chong'er replied, "If I return to my country, may the River God see what I will not share with Zi Fan!" He then threw a jade disc into the river as a pledge to Zi Fan. At that time, Jie Zitui was in the boat with them and laughed, saying, "Heaven has truly opened the way for you, but Zi Fan takes credit for it and tries to bribe you. This is truly shameful. I cannot bear to share the same position with you." He then secretly crossed the river. Qin troops besieged Linghu, and the Jin army camped at Luliu. On the day of Xinchou in the second month, Jiu Fan made an alliance with the Qin and Jin officials at Xun. On the day of Renyin, Chong'er entered the Jin army. On the day of Bingwu, he entered Quwo. On the day of Dingwei, he held court at the Wu Palace and ascended the throne as Duke Wen of Jin. All the officials went to see him. Duke Huai fled to Gaoliang. On the day of Wushen, someone was sent to kill Duke Huai. 59. Lü Sheng and Que Rui, former ministers of Duke Huai, were not loyal to Duke Wen. Fearing execution after Duke Wen's ascension, they plotted with their followers to burn down the palace and kill him. Duke Wen was unaware of this. The eunuch Lü Di, who had previously plotted to kill Duke Wen, learned of their scheme and wanted to inform Duke Wen to atone for his past transgressions. He requested an audience with Duke Wen. Duke Wen refused to see him and sent someone to apologize, saying, "Regarding the incident at Pu City, you beheaded Que. Later, when I went hunting with the Di ruler, you came to ask Duke Hui to kill me. Duke Hui promised to come in three days, but you arrived in one. Why so quickly? You should consider this." The eunuch replied, "Having survived the ordeal, I dare not serve you with disloyalty, thus offending you. Now that you have returned to your country, will you not be separated from Pu and Di? Moreover, Guan Zhong shot the hook, and Duke Huan became a hegemon. Now, a man who has suffered the ordeal has informed you of this, but you refuse to see him; disaster is imminent." So he saw him and informed Duke Wen of Lü Sheng, Que Rui, and others. Duke Wen wanted to summon Lü and Que, but Lü and Que had many followers. Fearing that the people of Jin would betray him upon his arrival, Duke Wen traveled incognito and met with Duke Mu of Qin in the capital, unbeknownst to the people. On the day of Ji Chou in the third month, Lü and Que indeed rebelled, burning down the palace and failing to capture Duke Wen. Duke Wen's guards fought against them. Lü and Que led their troops to flee, but Duke Mu of Qin lured them and killed them on the banks of the river. Jin was restored, and Duke Wen was able to return. In the summer, he welcomed his wife to Qin; the woman Qin had given to Duke Wen had become his wife. Qin sent three thousand men as guards to prepare for any potential rebellion in Jin. 60. Duke Wen reformed the government and benefited the people. He rewarded those who had followed him in exile and meritorious officials, granting fiefs to the most meritorious and noble titles to the least. Before the rewards were fully distributed, King Xiang of Zhou, whose brother Dai had fled to Zheng, urgently appealed to Jin for help. Jin had just pacified the region and wanted to send troops, but fearing further unrest, it rewarded the reclusive Jie Zitui, who had followed him in exile but whose reward had not yet arrived. Jie Zitui did not ask for any reward, nor did he receive any. Tui said, “Of the nine sons of Prince Xian, only you remain. Hui and Huai have no relatives, abandoned by both the outside and the inside. Heaven has not abandoned Jin; there will surely be a ruler. Who else but you will preside over the sacrifices of Jin? Heaven has truly opened the way, yet you two or three claim it as your own merit—is this not false? Stealing someone else's property is still called theft; how much more so is it to claim Heaven's merit as one's own merit? Those below bear the blame, while those above reward their wickedness. With superiors and inferiors deceiving each other, it is difficult to live with them!” His mother said, “Why not also seek it? Who will blame you if you die?” Tui said, “To follow suit would be a greater crime. Moreover, if I utter words of resentment, I will not receive any reward.” His mother said, “Let them know as well, what then?” He replied, “Words are the adornment of the body; if one wishes to remain hidden, what use is adornment? Adornment is seeking prominence.” His mother said, “Can you do this? I will hide with you.” He never saw her again until his death. 61. Jie Zitui's followers took pity on him and hung a sign on the palace gate that read: "The dragon wanted to ascend to heaven, with five snakes as its attendants. The dragon has already ascended to the clouds, and four snakes have each entered their respective abodes. One snake alone complains, and its whereabouts remain unknown." Duke Wen came out and saw the sign, saying, "This is Jie Zitui. I was worried about the royal house and had not yet planned for his merit." He sent someone to summon him, but he had disappeared. They then searched for his whereabouts and heard that he had entered the Mianshang Mountains. So Duke Wen encircled the Mianshang Mountains and enfeoffed it as Jie Zitui's land, naming it Jieshan, "to commemorate my mistakes and to honor virtuous men." 62. Hu Shu, a lowly minister who had fled, said, "Your Majesty has bestowed three rewards, yet I have not received any. I dare to beg for forgiveness." Duke Wen replied, "Those who guide me with benevolence and righteousness, and protect me with virtue and kindness, deserve the highest reward. Those who assist me in my conduct and ultimately lead me to success deserve the next highest reward. Those who endure the hardships of arrows and stones, and the toil of horses and sweat, deserve the next highest reward. Those who serve me with their strength but fail to make up for my shortcomings, deserve the next highest reward. After these three rewards, I will now extend my regards to you." The people of Jin, upon hearing this, were all pleased. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 7.1. Chong'er fled to the Di people due to the chaos caused by Li Ji, and Zhao Cui followed him. The Di attacked Qiangjiuru and captured two women. The Di gave the younger daughter to Chong'er and the elder daughter to Zhao Cui, who bore him a son named Dun. Previously, when Chong'er was in Jin, Zhao Cui's wife had also given birth to Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Yingqi. 7.2. Zhao Cui followed Chong'er into exile for nineteen years before returning to the country.
[635 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 49.1. Initially, Queen Hui wanted to establish Prince Dai as king, so she used her faction to open up the Di people, who then entered Zhou. King Xiang fled to Zheng, and Zheng took him to Si. Prince Dai became king and took the Di queen whom King Xiang had dismissed, residing her in Wen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 28.1 (Duke Mu yr 25; King Xiang crisis). That autumn, King Xiang of Zhou's younger brother, Dai, attacked the king with the Di tribes, and the king fled to Zheng. In the twenty-fifth year, the Zhou king sent messengers to inform Jin and Qin of the difficulties. Duke Mu of Qin led troops to assist Duke Wen of Jin in attacking King Xiang and killing the king's younger brother, Dai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 63. In the spring of the second year, the Qin army marched on the Yellow River, intending to enter the capital. Zhao Cui said, "The best way to seek hegemony is to enter the capital and honor the Zhou. Zhou and Jin are of the same surname. If Jin does not enter the capital first, and Qin does so later, there will be no way to command the world. Now, honoring the capital is Jin's advantage." On the day of Jia Chen in the third month, Jin sent troops to Yangfan, besieged Wen, and brought King Xiang of Zhou to the capital. In the fourth month, they killed King Xiang's younger brother, Dai. King Xiang of Zhou granted Jin the land of Yangfan in Henan.
[634 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 49.2. In the seventeenth year, King Xiang appealed to Jin for help, and Duke Wen of Jin accepted the king and executed Uncle Dai. King Xiang then bestowed upon Duke Wen of Jin a jade tablet, a bow and arrows, made him a hegemon, and ceded the lands of Hehe to Jin. In the twentieth year, Duke Wen of Jin summoned King Xiang, and King Xiang met with him at Heyang and Jiantu. All the feudal lords paid homage, and the written record was taboo: "The Heavenly King hunted at Heyang."
[633 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 39. In the thirty-third year, Duke Li died, and his son Xing succeeded him, becoming Duke Wen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 64. In the fourth year, King Cheng of Chu and the other feudal lords besieged Song. Gongsun Gu of Song pleaded with Jin for help. Xian Zhen said, "The opportunity to repay favors and secure hegemony lies now." Hu Yan said, "Chu has just acquired Cao and has recently formed a marriage alliance with Wei. If we attack Cao and Wei, Chu will surely come to their aid, and Song will be spared." Therefore, Jin assembled three armies. Zhao Cui appointed Que Hu to command the central army, with Que Zhen as his assistant; Hu Yan was appointed to command the upper army, with Hu Mao as his assistant, and Zhao Cui was appointed a minister; Luan Zhi commanded the lower army, with Xian Zhen as his assistant; Xun Linfu drove the chariot, and Wei Chou served as the right wing commander: they went to attack. In the twelfth month of winter, the Jin army first captured the mountains east of the mountains, and Zhao Cui was given his original fief. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 22. In the thirty-ninth year, Duke Xi of Lu requested military assistance to attack Qi. Chu sent Marquis Shen to lead troops to attack Qi, seize grain, and imprison Prince Yong, son of Duke Huan of Qi. All seven sons of Duke Huan of Qi fled to Chu, where they were all appointed as high-ranking officials. Chu destroyed the Kui tribe, because the Kui tribe did not worship Zhurong and Yuxiong.
[632 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 28.2 (Duke Mu yr 28; Chengpu). In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Wen of Jin defeated Chu at Chengpu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 40.1. In the first year of Duke Wen's reign, Crown Prince Shangchen of Chu murdered his father, King Cheng, and ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 10.1. In the 26th year of Duke Xiang's reign, Duke Wen of Jin declared himself hegemon at the Jiantu Conference. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 65.1. In the spring of the fifth year, Duke Wen of Jin wanted to attack Cao and asked to pass through Wei, but the people of Wei refused. He then crossed the Yellow River from Henan, invaded Cao, and attacked Wei. In the first month, he captured Wulu. In the second month, the Marquis of Jin and the Marquis of Qi made an alliance at Lianmeng. The Marquis of Wei requested an alliance with Jin, but the people of Jin refused. The Marquis of Wei wanted to ally with Chu, but the people of Wei did not want to, so they sent their ruler to persuade Jin. The Marquis of Wei resided at Xiangniu, and Prince Mai guarded Wei. Chu came to Wei's aid, but it was unsuccessful. The Marquis of Jin besieged Cao. 65.2. On the day of Bingwu in the third month, the Jin army entered Cao and rebuked them for not using Li Fu Ji's words, but instead using three hundred beautiful women in carriages. He ordered the army not to enter Xi Fu Ji's clan to repay their kindness. Chu besieged Song, and Song again appealed to Jin for help. Duke Wen wanted to help Song, but then attacked Chu because Chu had once been kind to him, and he did not want to attack Chu; he also wanted to release Song because Song had once been kind to Jin: he was troubled by this. Xian Zhen said, "If we seize Cao Bo and divide the lands of Cao and Wei to give to Song, Chu will be in a hurry to seize Cao and Wei, so it is advisable to release Song." So Duke Wen followed his advice, and King Cheng of Chu led his troops back. 66.1. The Chu general Ziyu said, "Your Majesty has treated Jin with the utmost kindness. Now, knowing that Chu is in dire need of Cao and Wei, you deliberately attack them, which shows disrespect to Your Majesty." The King replied, "The Marquis of Jin has been in exile for nineteen years, suffering greatly. Now that he has returned to his country, he knows all the strategic locations and can utilize his people. This is a divine favor, and cannot be resisted." Ziyu pleaded, "I do not dare to claim victory, but I wish to silence those who speak ill of others." The King of Chu was angered and gave him a small force. Then Ziyu sent Wanchun to inform Jin, "Please restore the Marquis of Wei and enfeoff Cao. I will also release Song." 66.2. Jiufan said, "Ziyu is impolite. Your Majesty takes one, and I take two. Do not agree." Xianzhen said, "To settle scores is called propriety. Chu's one word determined the fate of three kingdoms; your one word has led to their downfall. We have no propriety. Not agreeing to Chu's request is tantamount to abandoning Song. It would be better to secretly promise Cao and Wei to lure them, seize Wanchun to anger Chu, and then plan our next move after the battle." The Marquis of Jin then imprisoned Wanchun in Wei and secretly promised to restore Cao and Wei. Cao and Wei then broke off relations with Chu. Chu Dechen was enraged and attacked the Jin army, which retreated. A military officer asked, "Why did you retreat?" Duke Wen replied, "When we were in Chu, we agreed to retreat three she (a unit of distance), how can we break that agreement?" The Chu army wanted to leave, but Dechen refused. 66.3. On the day of Wuchen in the fourth month, the Duke of Song, the generals of Qi and Qin, and the Marquis of Jin encamped at Chengpu. On the day of Jisi, they engaged the Chu army in battle, and the Chu army was defeated. Dechen gathered the remaining troops and left. On the day of Jiawu, the Jin army returned to Hengyong and built a royal palace at Jiantu. 67. Initially, Zheng assisted Chu, but Chu was defeated and, fearing defeat, sent someone to request an alliance with the Duke of Jin. The Duke of Jin and the Duke of Zheng formed an alliance. 68. On the day of Dingwei in the fifth month, the captives of Chu were presented to Zhou, consisting of a hundred chariots and a thousand infantry. The Son of Heaven sent Prince Hu to appoint the Marquis of Jin as Earl, bestowing upon him a large carriage, a hundred red bows and arrows, a thousand black bows and arrows, a wine vessel of black millet wine, a jade tablet, and three hundred tiger-like warriors. The Marquis of Jin declined three times before bowing and accepting the gifts. Zhou then issued the edict of Marquis Wen of Jin: "Your Majesty says: Father Yihe, greatly illustrious Wen and Wu, was able to carefully cultivate his virtue, which was manifest above and spread below. At that time, God gathered his mandate upon Wen and Wu, and spared my life, allowing me to continue in the throne forever." Thereupon, the Marquis of Jin was appointed Earl. On the day of Guihai, Prince Hu convened a meeting of the feudal lords at the royal court. 69. The Jin army burned the Chu army, and the fire raged for several days. Duke Wen of Jin sighed. His attendants asked, "You have defeated Chu, yet you are still worried. Why?" Duke Wen replied, "I have heard that only a sage can win battles and secure peace, and that is why I am afraid. Moreover, Ziyu is still alive; how can I be happy?" After Ziyu's defeat and return, King Cheng of Chu was furious that he had not heeded his advice and had been greedy in his war with Jin. He reprimanded Ziyu, who then committed suicide. Duke Wen of Jin said, "I attacked their exterior, and Chu attacked their interior; with internal and external forces working together, we were pleased." 70. In June, the people of Jin re-entered the territory of the Marquis of Wei. On the day of Renwu, the Marquis of Jin crossed the Yellow River northward and returned to his country. When distributing rewards, Hu Yan was placed first. Someone said, "The matter of Chengpu was the work of Xian Zhen." Duke Wen said, "In the matter of Chengpu, Yan persuaded me not to break my promise. Xian Zhen said, 'Military victory is paramount,' and I used this to achieve victory. However, this was only a temporary opinion, while Yan spoke of lasting merit. How can one compare lasting merit with temporary gain? That is why I placed him first." 71. In winter, the Marquis of Jin convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Wen, intending to lead them to pay homage to Zhou. Lacking the strength to do so and fearing some might rebel, he sent a messenger to inform King Xiang of Zhou that he was hunting at Heyang. On the day of Renshen, he then led the feudal lords to pay homage to the king at Jiantu. When Confucius read the Records of the Grand Historian up to Duke Wen, he said, "The feudal lords did not summon the king," and "The king hunted at Heyang," because the Spring and Autumn Annals avoided mentioning these phrases. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 23. In summer, King Cheng attacked Song. Song appealed to Jin for help, and Jin came to Song's aid. King Cheng withdrew and returned home. General Ziyu requested permission to fight, but King Cheng said, "Chong'er has been living in exile for a long time. He has finally returned to his country. This is a blessing from Heaven, and we cannot resist it." Ziyu insisted, so King Cheng took him with him. Jin indeed defeated Ziyu at Chengpu. King Cheng was furious and executed Ziyu.
[631 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 72. On the day of Dingchou, the feudal lords besieged Xu. Cao Bochen said to the Duke of Jin, "Duke Huan of Qi united the feudal lords and established states of different surnames. Now, Your Majesty has held a meeting and destroyed those of the same surname. Cao is a descendant of Shu Zhenduo; Jin is a descendant of Tang Shu. To unite the feudal lords and destroy brothers is against propriety." The Duke of Jin was pleased and restored Cao Bochen's rule. 73. Thus, Jin began to arrange the troops into three lines. Xun Linfu led the middle line, Xian Hu led the right line, and Xian Mie led the left line.
[630 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 28.3 (Duke Mu yr 30; siege of Zheng). In the thirtieth year, Duke Mu assisted Duke Wen of Jin in besieging Zheng. A messenger from Zheng told Duke Mu, "If Zheng is destroyed and Jin is strengthened, Jin will gain, but Qin will not benefit. Jin's strength is Qin's worry." Duke Mu then withdrew his troops and returned home. Jin also withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 42. Forty-three years later. Initially, Duke Huan of Qi had three wives: Lady Wang, Lady Xu, and Lady Cai, all of whom had no children. Duke Huan was fond of women and had many concubines, including six women as his consorts: the eldest, Lady Wei, who gave birth to Wu Gui; the younger, Lady Wei, who gave birth to Duke Hui; Lady Zheng, who gave birth to Duke Xiao, Zhao; Ge Ying, who gave birth to Duke Zhao, Pan; Lady Mi, who gave birth to Duke Yi, Shang Ren; and Song Hua Zi, who gave birth to Prince Yong. Duke Huan and Guan Zhong entrusted Duke Xiao to Duke Xiang of Song, who was to be made crown prince. Yong Wu was favored by Lady Gong of Wei, and through the eunuch Shu Dao, he presented a generous gift to Duke Huan, gaining favor as well. Duke Huan agreed to let him establish Wu Gui as ruler. Guan Zhong died, and all five princes sought to become ruler. On the day of Yi Hai in the tenth month of winter, Duke Huan of Qi died. Yi Ya entered the court and, together with Shu Dao, used the influence of the concubines to kill a group of officials and establish Prince Wu Gui as ruler. Crown Prince Zhao fled to Song. 43. When Duke Huan fell ill, his five sons each formed their own factions and vied for power. When Duke Huan died, they attacked each other, and because the palace was empty, no one dared to lay a coffin inside. Duke Huan's body lay on the bed for sixty-seven days, and maggots crawled out of the door. On the day of Yihai in the twelfth month, without any suspicious action, the coffin was finally moved. On the night of Xinsi, the funeral was held. 44. Duke Huan had more than ten sons, and five were chosen to succeed him: Wu Gui died after three months on the throne, without a posthumous title; next was Duke Xiao; next was Duke Zhao; next was Duke Yi; and next was Duke Hui. In the third month of the first year of Duke Xiao's reign, Duke Xiang of Song led the armies of the feudal lords to escort Prince Zhao of Qi and attack Qi. The people of Qi were afraid and killed their ruler, Wu Gui. The people of Qi were about to install Prince Zhao as the new crown prince, but the followers of the four princes attacked the prince, who fled to Song. Song then fought against the four princes of Qi. In the fifth month, Song defeated the army of the four princes of Qi and installed Prince Zhao as the new crown prince, who became Duke Xiao of Qi. Song attacked Qi because Duke Huan and Guan Zhong were entrusted with the crown prince. Due to the chaos, Duke Huan of Qi was not buried until the eighth month. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 74. In the seventh year, Duke Wen of Jin and Duke Mu of Qin besieged Zheng because Zheng had been disrespectful to Duke Wen during his death and because Zheng had aided Chu at Chengpu. The siege was aimed at capturing Shu Zhan. Upon hearing this, Shu Zhan committed suicide. Zheng presented Shu Zhan to Jin. Jin said, "We will only be satisfied if we capture the ruler of Zheng." Zheng was afraid, so they secretly sent an envoy to Duke Mu of Qin, saying, "Saving Zheng benefits Jin, which is advantageous to Jin, but not to Qin. Why don't you release Zheng and establish an alliance in the east?" Duke Mu of Qin was pleased and withdrew his troops. Jin also withdrew its troops.
[629 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 40.2. Three years later, Duke Wen paid homage to Xiangfu of Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 7.3. Chong'er became Duke Wen of Jin, and Zhao Cui became the Grand Master of Yuan, residing in Yuan and handling state affairs. Duke Wen's return to power and eventual hegemony owed much to Zhao Cui's strategies, as detailed in the accounts in the *Annals of Jin*.
[628 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 50. In the twenty-fourth year, Duke Wen of Jin died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 28.4 (Duke Mu yr 32; Duke Wen of Jin dies). In the winter of the thirty-second year, Duke Wen of Jin died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 75. In the winter of the ninth year, Duke Wen of Jin died, and his son, Duke Xiang, succeeded him. In the same year, the Duke of Zheng also died. 76.1. The people of Zheng may have sold their country to Qin, and Duke Mu of Qin sent troops to attack Zheng. In December, the Qin army passed through our suburbs.
[627 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 29.1 (Duke Mu yr 33; planned Zheng attack). A man from Zheng offered to sell Zheng to Qin, saying, "I will guard the city gates; Zheng can be attacked." Duke Mu asked Jian Shu and Baili Xi, who replied, "To attack someone across several states and a thousand li is rarely profitable. Besides, if someone sells Zheng, how can we be sure that some of our own people haven't informed Zheng of our situation? It's not advisable." Duke Mu said, "You don't understand; I've already made my decision." He then dispatched troops, sending Baili Xi's son Meng Mingshi, Jian Shu's son Xiqishu, and Bai Yibing to lead the army. On the day of their departure, Baili Xi and Jian Shu wept. Duke Mu heard of this and angrily said, "I've dispatched troops, and you're hindering my army by weeping? Why?" The two elders replied, "We dare not hinder Your Majesty's army. When the army departs, your sons go with you; we are old, and if we return late, we fear we won't see you again, so we weep." The two elders withdrew and said to their sons, "Your army will be defeated; you will surely meet with disaster." 29.2 (Duke Mu yr 33; Qin passes Zhou/Hua). In the spring of the thirty-third year, the Qin army advanced eastward, traversing the territory of Jin, and passed through the north gate of Zhou. King Zhou's grandson Man said, "The Qin army is disrespectful; how can we not be defeated?" When the army reached Hua, a merchant from Zheng named Xian Gao, carrying twelve oxen, was about to sell them to Zhou. Upon seeing the Qin soldiers, fearing capture, he offered the oxen, saying, "I heard that a great state intends to punish Zheng. The ruler of Zheng has diligently strengthened his defenses and has sent me with these twelve oxen to reward the soldiers." The three Qin generals said to each other, "We were about to attack Zheng, but Zheng has already realized it; it's too late." They then destroyed Hua. Hua was a border town of Jin. 30 (same year; battle of Xiao aftermath). At that time, Duke Wen of Jin had not yet been buried. Crown Prince Xiang, enraged, said, "Qin insulted my orphan, and took advantage of the mourning to destroy Hua." He then donned mourning clothes, led his troops to intercept the Qin army at the Xiao River, and attacked them, utterly defeating the Qin army; not a single soldier escaped. He captured three Qin generals and brought them back. Duke Wen's wife, a Qin woman, pleaded on behalf of the three Qin generals, saying, "Duke Mu's resentment towards these three men runs deep. I wish to release them so that my lord may have the pleasure of boiling them alive." The Duke of Jin granted her request and released the three Qin generals. When the three generals arrived, Duke Mu, dressed in mourning clothes, greeted them outside the city. He wept before them, saying, "I humiliated you three by not heeding the advice of Baili Xi and Jian Shu. What crime have you committed? You must diligently avenge this disgrace and not slacken." He then restored their official ranks and treated them even better. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 10.2. In the 31st year, the Qin army was defeated at Xiao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 76.2. In the spring of the first year of Duke Xiang's reign, the Qin army passed through Zhou, behaving rudely, and Wangsun Man criticized them. When the army reached Hua, the Zheng merchant Xian Gao was about to trade in Zhou when he encountered them and offered the Qin army twelve oxen as a reward. The Qin army was startled and retreated, destroying Hua and leaving. 77. Jin Xianzhen said, "The Duke of Qin does not heed Jian Shu, thus alienating his people; this is a good opportunity to attack." Luan Zhi said, "We have not yet repaid the kindness our late lord bestowed upon Qin; attacking them is not advisable." Xianzhen said, "Qin insults my orphan and attacks our kinsmen; what virtue can we repay?" So they attacked. Duke Xiang wore mourning clothes and shawls. In the fourth month, they defeated the Qin army at Xiao, capturing three Qin generals: Meng Mingshi, Xi Qishu, and Bai Yibing, and bringing them back. They then used mourning clothes to bury Duke Wen. Duke Wen's wife, a woman from Qin, said to Duke Xiang, "Qin wants to capture these three generals and execute them." The Duke agreed and sent them. Xianzhen heard of this and said to Duke Xiang, "Trouble has arisen." Xianzhen then pursued the Qin generals. The Qin generals crossed the river; they were already on a boat, bowed their heads in apology, and ultimately did not return.
[626 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 45. In the spring of the sixth year, Qi attacked Song because Song had not formed an alliance with Qi. In the summer, Duke Xiang of Song died. In the seventh year, Duke Wen of Jin ascended the throne. 46. Ten years later, Duke Xiao died. His younger brother, Pan, installed Duke Zhao on the throne because Prince Kaifang of Wei had killed Duke Xiao. Duke Zhao was the son of Duke Huan, and his mother was Ge Ying. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 24.1. In the forty-sixth year, King Cheng initially intended to make Shang Chen the crown prince, speaking to the chief minister Zi Shang. Zi Shang said, "Your Majesty is still young, and you have many concubines; to remove him would cause chaos. The Chu state always appoints the youngest. Moreover, Shang Chen has bee-like eyes and a jackal's voice; he is a cruel man and cannot be made crown prince." The king did not listen and made him crown prince. Later, the king wanted to make Zi Zhi the crown prince and remove Shang Chen. Shang Chen heard this but was unsure, so he asked his tutor Pan Chong, "How can I ascertain the truth?" Chong said, "Offer food to the king's favorite concubine, Jiang Mi, but do not show her any respect." Shang Chen followed this advice. Jiang Mi angrily said, "It is no wonder the king wants to kill you and make Zhi the crown prince." Shang Chen told Pan Chong, "It is true." Chong asked, "Can you serve him?" He said, "No." "Can you flee?" He said, "No." "Can you accomplish great things?" He said, "Yes."
[625 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 31 (Duke Mu yr 35). In the thirty-fourth year, Crown Prince Shangchen of Chu murdered his father, King Cheng, and ascended the throne in his place. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 24.2. In the tenth month of winter, Shang Chen surrounded King Cheng with palace guards. King Cheng requested to eat bear paws and die, but this was refused. On the day of Dingwei, King Cheng hanged himself. Shang Chen succeeded him, becoming King Mu.
[624 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 32 (Duke Mu yr 36; Pengya). Duke Mu then sent Meng Mingshi and others to lead troops to attack Jin, and they fought at Pengya. Qin suffered a defeat and withdrew its troops. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 78.1. Three years later, Qin sent Meng Ming to attack Jin, avenging the defeat of Xiao, and captured Wang of Jin. Four years later, Duke Mu of Qin launched a large-scale attack on Jin, crossed the river, captured Wangguan, sealed Xiao's body, and left. Jin was afraid and dared not venture out, so it fortified its city.
[623 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 33 (Duke Mu yr 37; You Yu episode begins). The Rong king sent You Yu to Qin. You Yu's ancestors were from Jin, but he fled to the Rong and could speak the Jin language. Hearing of Duke Mu's virtue, he sent You Yu to observe Qin. Duke Mu showed You Yu palaces and plunder. You Yu said, "If ghosts were to build these, it would be exhausting. If humans were to build them, it would be a burden on the people."
