Duke Mu was puzzled and asked, "China governs with poetry, books, rites, music, and laws, yet it is still often in chaos. Now, the Rong barbarians have none of these; how can they govern? Isn't it difficult?" You Yu laughed and said, "This is precisely why China is in chaos. Since the sage Yellow Emperor established rites, music, and laws, and led by example, he only achieved minor governance. But in later generations, they became increasingly arrogant and licentious. They obstructed the authority of the laws to supervise their subordinates. When the subordinates were exhausted, they harbored resentment towards their superiors, leading to conflict and resentment, usurpation, and even the extermination of clans. All of this is due to such circumstances. The Rong barbarians are different. Their superiors treat their subordinates with pure virtue, and the subordinates serve their superiors with loyalty and trust. The governance of their state is just like that of the Rong barbarians." "To govern oneself without knowing how to govern—this is truly the governance of a sage." Duke Mu then withdrew and asked the Grand Scribe Liao, "I have heard that neighboring states have sages, which is a worry for enemy states. Now, You Yu is virtuous, which is a harm to me. What should I do?" Grand Scribe Liao replied, "The Rong king is hiding in seclusion and has not heard the sounds of China. Your Majesty should send him female musicians to distract him; plead for You Yu to create distance between you; keep him there and do not send him away, so that he misses his appointed time. The Rong king will find this strange and will surely suspect You Yu. When there is a distance between ruler and minister, you can capture him. Moreover, the Rong king loves music and will surely neglect his duties." Duke Mu said, "Excellent." He then sat with You Yu at a side mat, passed around utensils, and ate together, thoroughly investigating the terrain and military strength of the Rong. He then ordered Grand Scribe Liao to send two or eight female musicians to the Rong king. The Rong king accepted them and was pleased, and did not return them for a year. Thus, Qin returned You Yu. You Yu repeatedly advised against this, but to no avail. Duke Mu then repeatedly sent people to try and persuade You Yu, and You Yu finally surrendered to Qin. Duke Mu treated him with the courtesy due to a guest and inquired about the details of the campaign against the Rong. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 41. On the day of Jiawu in the tenth month of the eleventh year, Lu defeated Di at Xian, captured the eldest Di Qiaoru, Fu Fuzhong nephew pounded his throat, killed him with a spear, buried his head at the gate of Ziju, and gave it to Xuanbo. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 25.1. King Mu ascended the throne and gave his crown prince's palace to Pan Chong, appointing him Grand Tutor and entrusting him with the affairs of state.
[622 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 78.2. Five years later, Jin attacked Qin, captured Xincheng, and avenged the defeat at Wangguan. 79. In the sixth year, Zhao Cui's sons Chengzi, Luan Zhenzi, Jiu Jizi Fan, and Huo Bo all died. Zhao Dun succeeded Zhao Cui as regent. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 25.2. In the third year of King Mu's reign, he conquered Jiang. In the fourth year, he conquered Liu and Liao. Liu and Liao were descendants of Gao Yao.
[621 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 51. In the thirty-first year, Duke Mu of Qin died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 34 (Duke Mu yr 39; avenges Xiao—river crossing). In the thirty-sixth year, Duke Mu of Qin further favored Meng Ming and others, sending them to lead troops to attack Jin. They crossed the river, burned the boats, and inflicted a great defeat on the Jin army, capturing Wangguan and Hao to avenge the defeat at Xiao. The Jin people all defended their cities and dared not venture out. Duke Mu then crossed the river at Maojin, sealed the body in Xiao, held a funeral, and wept for three days. He then swore an oath to his army: "Alas, soldiers! Listen carefully, do not clamor. I swear this oath to you. Those who plotted against the ancients, even if their hair turned yellow, had no faults." Because Shen Si did not heed the advice of Jian Shu and Baili Xi, he made this oath so that future generations would remember his mistake. When the gentlemen heard this, they all wept, saying, "Alas! Duke Mu of Qin's generosity towards others ultimately brought him the blessings of Meng Ming." 35.1 (Duke Mu yr 37/39/...; western hegemony). In the thirty-seventh year, Qin, with the help of You Yu's strategy, attacked the Rong king, expanding its territory by twelve states and a thousand li, thus becoming the hegemon of the Western Rong. The Son of Heaven sent Duke Shao to congratulate Duke Mu with gongs and drums. 35.2 (Duke Mu yr 39; death; “Yellow Bird”). In the thirty-ninth year, Duke Mu died and was buried in Yong. One hundred and seventy-seven people died with him, including three virtuous ministers of Qin, Ziyu, named Yanxi, Zhongxing, and Zhenhu. The people of Qin mourned them and composed the poem "The Yellow Bird." A wise man said, "Duke Mu of Qin expanded his territory and increased his state, subduing the powerful Jin in the east and dominating the Rong and Yi in the west. Yet, he did not become the leader of the feudal lords, which is fitting. He died and abandoned his people, taking his virtuous ministers with him. Moreover, even after the death of the former king, he still left behind virtues and laws. How much more so should he take away the virtuous men and ministers whom the people mourn? Therefore, we know that Qin cannot launch another eastern expedition." Duke Mu had forty sons, and his crown prince, Tang, succeeded him, becoming Duke Kang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 10.3. In the 37th year, Duke Mu of Qin died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 80.1. In the seventh year, in the eighth month, Duke Xiang died. His son, Crown Prince Yi Gao, was young. The people of Jin, due to difficulties, wanted to establish an elder ruler. Zhao Dun said, "Establish Duke Xiang's younger brother, Yong. He is virtuous and elder, and the late ruler loved him; moreover, he is close to Qin, and Qin was once friendly. Establishing a virtuous ruler ensures stability, serving an elder ensures obedience, showing love ensures filial piety, and maintaining old friendships ensures peace." Jia Ji said, "His younger brother, Le, is better. Chen Ying is favored by two rulers; if his son is established, the people will surely be at peace." Zhao Dun said, "Chen Ying is of low status, ranking below the ninth person; what power does his son have? Moreover, being favored by two rulers is licentious. As the late ruler, he could not aspire to greatness but instead resided in a small state, which is perverse. A licentious mother and a perverse son have no authority; Chen is small and far away, without support: what can be done?" He sent Shi Hui to Qin to welcome Prince Yong. Jia Ji also sent someone to summon Prince Le to Chen. 80.2. Zhao Dun deposed Jia Ji for killing Yang Chufu. In the tenth month, Duke Xiang was buried. In the eleventh month, Jia Ji fled to Di. That year, Duke Mu of Qin also died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 8. After Zhao Cui rebelled against Jin, the wife of Jin insisted on welcoming the wife of Zhai, and made her son Dun the rightful heir. All three sons of the wife of Jin served him. In the sixth year of Duke Xiang of Jin, Zhao Cui died and was posthumously named Cheng Ji.
[620 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 36.1 (Duke Kang yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Kang's reign, Duke Mu of Jin died the previous year, as did Duke Xiang of Jin. Duke Xiang's younger brother, Yong, was from Qin and was in Qin. Zhao Dun of Jin wanted to establish him as emperor and sent Sui Hui to welcome Yong. Qin sent troops to escort him to Linghu. Jin established Duke Xiang's son and launched a counterattack against the Qin army. The Qin army was defeated, and Sui Hui fled. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 47. In the first year of Duke Zhao's reign, Duke Wen of Jin defeated Chu at Chengpu, and then convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Jiantu to pay homage to Zhou. The emperor appointed Jin as the hegemon. Six years later, the Di invaded Qi. Duke Wen of Jin died. The Qin army was defeated at Xiao. Twelve years later, Duke Mu of Qin died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 42. Initially, during the reign of Duke Wu of Song, the Zhān Mān attacked Song. The Minister of Works, Huang Fu, led an army to defend against them, defeating the Zhān at Changqiu and capturing Chang Zhān Yuan Si. When Jin destroyed Lu, they captured Fēn Ru, the younger brother of Qiao Ru. In the second year of Duke Hui of Qi, the Zhān Mān attacked Qi. Prince Cheng Fu of Qi captured his younger brother Rong Ru and buried his head at the North Gate. The people of Wei captured his youngest brother, Jian Ru. The Zhān Mān thus perished. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 81. In the fourth month of the first year of Duke Ling's reign, Duke Kang of Qin said, "When Duke Wen entered the court, he had no guards, hence the troubles of Lü and Que." He then provided more guards for Prince Yong. The Crown Prince's mother, Mu Ying, embraced the prince day and night, weeping in court, saying, "What crime did the late ruler commit? What crime has his successor committed? He abandoned his rightful heir and sought a ruler elsewhere; where will he be placed?" After leaving court, she took him to Zhao Dun, bowing her head and saying, "The late ruler entrusted this son to you, saying, 'If this son is talented, I will accept his gift; if he is not, I will resent him.' Now that you are dead, your words still echo in my ears, yet you abandon him; what will become of you?" Zhao Dun and the other officials were all troubled by Mu Ying and feared punishment. Therefore, they betrayed their support and installed Prince Yi Gao as Duke Ling. They dispatched troops to resist Qin's escort of Prince Yong. Zhao Dun, as general, went to attack Qin and defeated them at Linghu. Xian Mie and Sui Hui fled to Qin. In the autumn, the rulers of Qi, Song, Wei, Zheng, Cao, and Xu all met with Zhao Dun and formed an alliance at Hu, because Duke Ling had just ascended the throne.
[619 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 52.1. In the thirty-second year, King Xiang died, [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 36.2 (Duke Kang yr 2). In the second year, Qin attacked Jin and captured Wucheng, avenging the defeat at Linghu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 9. Zhao Dun succeeded Cheng Ji as the ruler of Jin for two years before Duke Xiang of Jin died, leaving behind a young crown prince, Yi Gao. Zhao Dun, having endured much hardship for the state, wished to install Duke Xiang's younger brother, Yong, as the new ruler. Yong was then in Qin, and Zhao Dun sent envoys to fetch him. The crown prince's mother wept day and night, repeatedly kowtowing to Zhao Dun, saying, "What crime did our late lord commit that he would release his heir and seek another ruler?" Zhao Dun was troubled, fearing that his clan and officials would attack and kill him. Therefore, he installed the crown prince, who became Duke Ling, and sent troops to resist those who had brought Duke Xiang's brother from Qin. After Duke Ling ascended the throne, Zhao Dun increasingly monopolized state power.
[618 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 52.2. and his son, King Qing, Renchen, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 48. In the fifth month of the nineteenth year, Duke Zhao died, and his son She ascended to the throne as the ruler of Qi. She's mother was not favored by Duke Zhao, and the people of the state did not fear her. Duke Zhao's younger brother, Shangren, vied for the throne after Duke Huan's death but failed. He secretly befriended virtuous men and cultivated affection for the people, who were pleased with him. When Duke Zhao died, his son She ascended the throne, but was weak and vulnerable. He then, along with the people, assassinated Duke She at his grave in ten months, and Shangren then established himself as Duke Yi. Duke Yi was the son of Duke Huan, and his mother was named Mi Ji. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 10.4. In the 40th year, Duke Xiang died, and Duke Huan ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 25.3. In the eighth year, he attacked Chen.
[617 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 36.3 (Duke Kang yr 4). In the fourth year, Jin attacked Qin and captured Shaoliang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 82.1. In the fourth year, Qin attacked Qin and captured Shaoliang. Qin also captured Huang of Jin. In the sixth year, Duke Kang of Qin attacked Jin and captured Jima. Duke Huan of Jin was furious and sent Zhao Dun, Zhao Chuan, and Que Que to attack Qin.
[616 BC]
[615 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 36.4 (Duke Kang yr 6). In the sixth year, Qin attacked Jin and captured Jima. They fought at Hequ and defeated the Jin army. The people of Jin were worried that Sui Hui would cause trouble in Qin, so they sent Wei Chouyu to secretly rebel and conspire with Sui Hui. They tricked Sui Hui and captured him, and Sui Hui then returned to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 82.2. They fought a great battle at Hequ, and Zhao Chuan was the most meritorious. In the seventh year, the six ministers of Jin were worried that Sui Hui was in Qin and often caused trouble for Jin. So they secretly ordered Wei Shouyu to betray Jin and surrender to Qin. Qin sent Sui Hui to Wei, and then captured him and brought him back to Jin.
[614 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 25.4. In the twelfth year, he died. His son, King Zhuang Lü, ascended the throne.
[613 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 52.3. In the sixth year of King Qing's reign, he died, and his son, King Kuang, Ban, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 83.1. Eight years later, King Qing of Zhou died, and the ministers vied for power, so he did not go to the capital. Jin sent Zhao Dun with 800 chariots to quell the Zhou rebellion and install King Kuang. 83.2. That same year, King Zhuang of Chu ascended the throne. Twelve years later, the people of Qi assassinated their ruler, Duke Yi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 26.1. King Zhuang reigned for three years, issuing no decrees and indulging in pleasure day and night. He issued a decree throughout the kingdom: "Anyone who dares to remonstrate will be executed without mercy!" Wu Ju entered to remonstrate. King Zhuang, with a Zheng concubine on his left and a Yue woman on his right, sat amidst the sounds of bells and drums. Wu Ju said, "I wish to offer my advice." He asked, "There is a bird on a hill that has neither flown nor sung for three years. What kind of bird is it?" King Zhuang replied, "If it does not fly for three years, it will soar to the sky; if it does not sing for three years, its song will startle the world. Ju, withdraw; I know the truth."
[612 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 26.2. Several months later, his debauchery intensified. The minister Su Cong then entered to remonstrate. The king said, "Have you not heeded the decree?" Su Cong replied, "To sacrifice myself for the sake of my ruler is my wish." Thereupon, the king stopped the debauchery, resumed government affairs, executed hundreds of people, and promoted hundreds more. He appointed Wu Ju and Su Cong to govern, and the people were greatly pleased. That year, the kingdom was conquered.
[611 BC]
[610 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 49. In the spring of the fourth year of Duke Yi's reign, when Duke Yi was still a prince, he went hunting with the father of Bing Rong. They fought fiercely for the spoils, and Duke Yi lost. After ascending the throne, he cut off the father's foot and made Bing Rong his servant. Yong Zhi's wife was beautiful, and the Duke brought her into his palace, making Yong Zhi his charioteer. In the fifth month, Duke Yi went to Shen Pond. The two men bathed and played. Yong Zhi said, "You with the cut foot!" Bing Rong said, "You who steal a wife!" Both men were disgusted by these words and harbored resentment. They plotted to go with the Duke to the bamboo grove. The two men murdered Duke Yi on his chariot, abandoned it in the bamboo grove, and fled. 50. When Duke Yi ascended the throne, he was arrogant, and the people did not support him. The people of Qi deposed his son and welcomed Prince Yuan from Wei, who then became Duke Hui. Duke Hui was the son of Duke Huan. His mother was a woman from Wei, named Shao Wei Ji, who had stayed in Wei to avoid the chaos in Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 6. Luan Cheng, a high-ranking official of Jin, rebelled in Jin and fled to Qi. Duke Zhuang of Qi treated him with great hospitality. Yan Ying and Tian Wenzi advised against this, but Duke Zhuang did not listen.
[609 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 36.5 (Duke Kang yr 12; death). Duke Kang died in the twelfth year of his reign, and his son, Duke Gong, succeeded him.
[608 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 26.3. In the sixth year, the kingdom attacked Song, capturing five hundred chariots.
[607 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 52.4. In the sixth year of King Kuang's reign, he died, and his younger brother, Yu, ascended the throne, becoming King Ding. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 37.1 (Duke Gong yr 2) (Wikipedia). In the second year of Duke Gong's reign, Zhao Chuan of Jin assassinated his ruler, Duke Ling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 43. In the fifteenth year, Ji Wenzi was sent as an envoy to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 84. In the fourteenth year, Duke Ling grew old and extravagant, levying heavy taxes to build ornate walls. He would shoot people from a platform to observe their dodge. One day, the cook's braised bear paws were undercooked, enraging Duke Ling. He killed the cook and ordered a woman to carry the body out and abandon it before the court. Zhao Dun and Sui Hui repeatedly remonstrated with him, but he wouldn't listen. Later, seeing a dead man's hand, the two again remonstrated. Sui Hui had already remonstrated, but to no avail. Duke Ling was troubled by this and ordered Chu Ni to assassinate Zhao Dun. Zhao Dun opened his door, lived frugally, and Chu Ni withdrew, sighing, "Killing a loyal minister and disobeying the ruler's command are the same crime." He then struck his head against a tree and died. 85.1. Initially, Zhao Dun was often hunting in the mountains when he saw a starving man under a mulberry tree. This starving man was Shi Miming. Zhao Dun gave him some food, and he ate half of it. When asked why, he replied, "I have been serving as an official for three years, and I do not know if my mother is still alive. I wish to give her some." Zhao Dun was moved by his kindness and gave him more rice and meat. Later, Zhao Dun became the steward of Jin, but Zhao Dun no longer knew of him. 85.2. In September, Duke Ling of Jin held a banquet for Zhao Dun, and an ambush was set to attack him. Shi Miming, the steward, knew of this and, fearing Zhao Dun would be too drunk to rise, stepped forward and said, "Your Majesty has bestowed this upon me; three rounds of wine are enough." He intended to use this opportunity to get rid of Zhao Dun, so that he would go first and avoid trouble. After Zhao Dun left, before Duke Ling's ambush could be completed, he first released a dog named Ao. Shi Miming fought and killed the dog for Zhao Dun. Zhao Dun said, "Using a dog to kill a man, even if it is fierce, is useless." However, he did not know that Shi Miming was performing a good deed. Later, Duke Ling released his ambush to chase Zhao Dun away. Shi Miming fought back against Duke Ling's ambush, and the ambush could not advance, allowing Zhao Dun to escape. Zhao Dun asked why, and Shi Miming replied, "I am a starving man under the mulberry tree." When asked his name, Shi Miming did not tell him. The Ming dynasty also perished. 86. Zhao Dun fled, but did not leave the borders of Jin. On the day of Yichou, Zhao Dun's brother, General Zhao Chuan, attacked and killed Duke Ling in Taoyuan and welcomed Zhao Dun back. Zhao Dun was of high rank and enjoyed the support of the people; Duke Ling was young and extravagant, and the people did not support him, so the assassination was easy. Zhao Dun was restored to the throne. The Grand Historian of Jin, Dong Hu, wrote, "Zhao Dun murdered his ruler," and showed it to the court. Zhao Dun said, "The murderer was Zhao Chuan; I am innocent." The Grand Historian said, "You were the chief minister, yet you fled beyond the borders and did not punish the rebellious ruler. Who else but you could have done it?" Confucius heard of this and said, "Dong Hu was a good historian of ancient times; his writing did not conceal anything. Xuanzi was a good minister, but he suffered injustice for upholding the law. It is a pity that he was spared only by leaving the borders." [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 10. Duke Ling reigned for fourteen years, growing increasingly arrogant. Zhao Dun repeatedly remonstrated with him, but Duke Ling ignored him. When eating bear paws, the meat was undercooked, so he killed the cook and carried the body out, where Zhao Dun saw him. Duke Ling, fearing this, wanted to kill Zhao Dun. Zhao Dun, however, was known for his kindness and compassion. Once, a starving man under a mulberry tree, whom he had been feeding, defended him, allowing Zhao Dun to escape. Before he could leave the country, Zhao Chuan assassinated Duke Ling and installed Duke Xiang's younger brother, Hei Tun, as Duke Cheng. Zhao Dun then rebelled again and assumed power. Scholars criticized Zhao Dun, saying, "As the chief minister, he fled the country and failed to punish the rebels," hence the historian recorded, "Zhao Dun murdered his ruler." During the reign of Duke Jing of Jin, Zhao Dun died and was posthumously named Xuan Meng. His son, Shuo, succeeded him. 10.1. When eating bear paws, the meat was undercooked, so he killed the cook and carried the body out, where Zhao Dun saw him. Duke Ling, fearing this, wanted to kill Zhao Dun. Zhao Dun, however, was known for his kindness and compassion. 10.2. Once, a starving man under a mulberry tree, whom he had been feeding, defended him, allowing Zhao Dun to escape.
[606 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 53.1. In the first year of King Ding's reign, King Zhuang of Chu attacked the Rong of Luhun. En route to Luo, he sent someone to inquire about the Nine Tripods. The king sent Wangsun Man to respond with a persuasive argument, and the Chu army withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 37.2 (yr 3). In the third year, King Zhuang of Chu, with his powerful northern army, reached Luo and inquired about the Zhou tripods. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 87. Zhao Dun sent Zhao Chuan to welcome Duke Xiang's younger brother, Hei Tun, to Zhou and establish him as Duke Cheng. 88. Duke Cheng was the youngest son of Duke Wen, and his mother was a woman from Zhou. On the day of Renshen, he went to court at the Wu Palace. 89.1. In the first year of Duke Cheng's reign, the Zhao family was granted the title of royal clan. The state attacked Zheng because Zheng had betrayed Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 27. Eight years later, the King of Zhou attacked the Lu Hun Rong and reached Luoyang, where he reviewed his troops on the outskirts of Zhou. King Ding of Zhou sent Wangsun Man to greet the King of Chu. The King of Chu inquired about the size and weight of the nine tripods, to which the King replied, "Virtue is the foundation, not the tripods." King Zhuang said, "Do not obstruct the nine tripods! The hooked beak of the Chu state is sufficient to make nine tripods." Wangsun Man said, "Alas! Has Your Majesty forgotten this? In the past, during the prosperous times of Yu and Xia, people from afar came to offer gold from the nine provinces, casting tripods to represent various objects, making them complete with all things, so that the people could know the difference between gods and villains. Jie was wicked and corrupt, so the tripods were moved to Yin, where sacrifices were offered for six hundred years. King Zhou of Yin was tyrannical, so the tripods were moved to Zhou. When virtue is bright and clear, even a small thing is weighty; when virtue is wicked and corrupt, even a large thing is light. In the past, King Cheng established the tripods at Jia Ru, divining thirty generations and seven hundred years, which was the mandate of Heaven. Although the virtue of Zhou has declined, the mandate of Heaven has not changed. The weight of the tripods is not something to be questioned." The King of Chu then returned home. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 10.3. Before he could leave the country, Zhao Chuan assassinated Duke Ling and installed Duke Xiang's younger brother, Hei Tun, as Duke Cheng. Zhao Dun then rebelled again and assumed power. Scholars criticized Zhao Dun, saying, "As the chief minister, he fled the country and failed to punish the rebels," hence the historian recorded, "Zhao Dun murdered his ruler." During the reign of Duke Jing of Jin, Zhao Dun died and was posthumously named Xuan Meng. His son, Shuo, succeeded him. 10 (discursive). Duke Ling reigned for fourteen years, growing increasingly arrogant. Zhao Dun repeatedly remonstrated with him, but Duke Ling ignored him. When eating bear paws, the meat was undercooked, so he killed the cook and carried the body out, where Zhao Dun saw him. Duke Ling, fearing this, wanted to kill Zhao Dun. Zhao Dun, however, was known for his kindness and compassion. Once, a starving man under a mulberry tree, whom he had been feeding, defended him, allowing Zhao Dun to escape. Before he could leave the country, Zhao Chuan assassinated Duke Ling and installed Duke Xiang's younger brother, Hei Tun, as Duke Cheng. Zhao Dun then rebelled again and assumed power. Scholars criticized Zhao Dun, saying, "As the chief minister, he fled the country and failed to punish the rebels," hence the historian recorded, "Zhao Dun murdered his ruler." During the reign of Duke Jing of Jin, Zhao Dun died and was posthumously named Xuan Meng. His son, Shuo, succeeded him.
[605 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 28.1. In the ninth year, the Ruo'ao clan was destroyed. Some people slandered the king, and fearing execution, they turned against the king. The king then attacked and exterminated the Ruo'ao clan.
[604 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 37.3 (yr 5; death). Duke Gong died in the fifth year of his reign, and his son, Duke Huan, succeeded him.
[603 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 51. In the second year of Duke Hui's reign, Chang Di came, and Prince Chengfu attacked and killed him, burying him at the north gate. Zhao Chuan of Jin murdered his ruler, Duke Ling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 11.1. Duke Huan died in the sixteenth year, and Duke Xuan succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 89.2. Three years later, the newly enthroned Duke of Zheng allied with Jin and abandoned Chu. Chu was angered and attacked Zheng, and Jin went to its aid.
[602 BC]
[601 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 38.1 (Duke Huan yr 3) (Wikipedia). In the third year of Duke Huan's reign, Jin defeated one of our generals. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 90. In the sixth year, they attacked Qin and captured the Qin general Chi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 28.2. In the thirteenth year, the Shu clan was destroyed.
[600 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 44. In the second month of the eighteenth year, Duke Wen died. Duke Wen had two wives: his eldest wife, a woman from Qi named Ai Jiang, bore him a son named E Ji Shi; his second wife, Jing Ying, was his favorite and bore him a son named Tui. Tui secretly served Xiang Zhong, who wanted to make him the heir apparent, but Shu Zhong said it was not advisable. Xiang Zhong then asked Duke Hui of Qi, who had just ascended the throne and wanted to befriend Lu, so he agreed. In the tenth month of winter, Xiang Zhong killed E Ji Shi and installed Tui as the heir apparent, who became Duke Xuan. Ai Jiang returned to Qi, weeping as she passed through the marketplace, saying, "Heaven! Xiang Zhong has acted unjustly, killing the legitimate heir and installing a son of a concubine!" The people of the marketplace all wept, and the people of Lu called her "Ai Jiang." As a result, the ducal house of Lu weakened, while the three Huan families became powerful. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 91.1. In the seventh year, Duke Cheng vied for power with King Zhuang of Chu and convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Hu. Chen, fearing Chu, did not attend. Jin sent Zhonghang Huanzi to attack Chen, and then to rescue Zheng, fought with Chu and defeated the Chu army. 91.2. In the same year, Duke Cheng died, and his son Duke Jing succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 7. When Wenzi died, he had a son named Huanzi Wuyu. Huanzi Wuyu was strong and served Duke Zhuang of Qi, where he was greatly favored.
[599 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 92. In the spring of the first year of Duke Jing's reign, Xia Zhengshu, a minister of Chen, assassinated his ruler, Duke Ling. The following year, King Zhuang of Chu attacked Chen and executed Zhengshu.
[598 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 29. In the sixteenth year, King Zhuang attacked Chen and killed Xia Zhengshu. Zhengshu had murdered his ruler, hence his execution. After conquering Chen, he immediately enfeoffed it. All the ministers congratulated him, but Shen Shu, who had been sent by Qi at the time, did not offer congratulations. The king asked him why, and Shen Shu replied, "A common saying goes, 'If a cow is led through someone's field, the landowner will take the cow. If it was led through a path, it is not rightful; to take the cow is surely excessive. Moreover, Your Majesty led the feudal lords to attack Chen because of its rebellion, and attacked it with righteousness, yet you greedily enfeoff it. How can you restore order to the world?" King Zhuang then restored the kingdom of Chen to its former ruler. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 11. Zhao Shuo, in the third year of Duke Jing of Jin, served as the general of Jin, leading the army to rescue Zheng, and fought against King Zhuang of Chu on the Yellow River. Shuo married the sister of Duke Cheng of Jin. 12. In the third year of Duke Jing of Jin's reign, the minister Tu Anjia wanted to exterminate the Zhao clan. Initially, when Zhao Dun was alive, he dreamt of Shu Dai holding a jade pendant and weeping bitterly; then he laughed, clapping his hands and singing. Dun consulted the oracle, which showed an ominous sign followed by a good one. Zhao Shi Yuan interpreted the dream, saying, "This dream is very ominous; it does not concern you, but your son, yet it is also your fault. By your grandson's time, the Zhao family will decline further." Tu Anjia, initially favored by Duke Ling, became Minister of Justice under Duke Jing. He plotted rebellion, prosecuting the traitors of Duke Ling and implicating Zhao Dun, then proclaiming to the generals, "Although Dun was unaware, he is still the ringleader of the traitors. Since a subject murdered his ruler, and his descendants are in court, how can he be punished? Please execute him." Han Jue said, "When Duke Ling encountered the traitors, Zhao Dun was away. Our late lord considered him innocent and therefore did not execute him. Now you gentlemen intend to execute his descendants, which is contrary to our late lord's intention and a reckless execution. Reckless execution is called rebellion. If a subject has a great matter and the ruler does not hear of it, it is tantamount to having no ruler." Tu Anjia did not listen. Han Jue urged Zhao Shuo to flee. Shuo refused, saying, "If you will not extinguish the Zhao lineage, I will die without regret." Han Jue agreed and claimed illness to avoid going out. Jia, without being invited, led the generals to attack the Zhao clan at the Lower Palace, killing Zhao Shuo, Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Yingqi, and exterminating their entire clan.
[597 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 53.2. In the tenth year, King Zhuang of Chu besieged Zheng. The ruler of Zheng surrendered, but the siege was later restored. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 52. Ten years later, Duke Hui died, and his son, Duke Qing, succeeded him. Initially, Cui Zhu was favored by Duke Hui. After Duke Hui's death, Gao and Guo, fearing his influence, drove him away, and Cui Zhu fled to Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 45. In the twelfth year of Duke Xuan's reign, King Zhuang of Chu, in his strength, besieged Zheng. Duke Zhuang of Zheng surrendered, and Zheng was restored to its former state. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 93.1. Three years later, King Zhuang of Chu besieged Zheng, and Zheng urgently appealed to Jin for help. Jin sent Xun Linfu to command the central army, Sui Hui to command the upper army, and Zhao Shuo to command the lower army, assisted by Que Ke, Luan Shu, Xian Hu, Han Jue, and Gong Shuo. In June, they reached the Yellow River. 93.2. Hearing that Chu had already subdued Zheng, the Duke of Zheng bared his chest and made an oath before leaving. Xun Linfu wanted to return. Xian Hu said, "Those who come to rescue Zheng must not fail, otherwise they will become disloyal." So they crossed the river. Chu, having already subdued Zheng, wanted to use the excuse of watering their horses in the river to leave. Chu and Jin armies fought a great battle. Zheng, having recently allied with Chu, feared them and instead helped Chu attack Jin. The Jin army was defeated and fled to the river, scrambling to cross, with many people pointing fingers on the boats. Chu captured my general, Zhi Ying. 93.3. Upon returning, Linfu said, "As the commander-in-chief, I deserve to be executed for the army's defeat. I beg to die." Duke Jing wanted to grant his request. Sui Hui said, "In the past, when Duke Wen fought against Chu at Chengpu, King Cheng returned and killed Ziyu, and Duke Wen was pleased. Now that Chu has defeated our army, killing its general is tantamount to helping Chu kill its enemy." So he stopped. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 30. In the spring of the seventeenth year, King Zhuang of Chu besieged Zheng and conquered it after three months. Upon entering through the royal gate, the Earl of Zheng, baring his chest and leading a sheep, greeted him, saying, “I am unworthy of Heaven and incapable of serving my lord. Your anger has extended to my humble state, and this is my fault. How dare I disobey your command! Even if you send me to the South Sea, or bestow concubines upon other lords, I will obey your command. If you do not forget the reigns of Li, Xuan, Huan, and Wu, and do not sever our altars of the state, and allow me to serve you again, that is my wish, not something I dare to hope for. I dare to lay bare my heart.” The ministers of Chu said, “Your Majesty, do not grant this.” King Zhuang said, “If a ruler can humble himself before his people, he will surely be able to trust them. How can we sever our trust?” King Zhuang personally took up his banner, commanded his troops on both sides, and led his army thirty li away before setting up camp, thus granting peace. Pan Wang entered the alliance, and Zi Liang was sent as a hostage. In the sixth month of summer, Jin came to Zheng's aid, fought with Chu, and decisively defeated the Jin army on the riverbank, then returned to Hengyong. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 12.1. Tu Anjia wanted to exterminate the Zhao clan. Initially, when Zhao Dun was alive, he dreamt of Shu Dai holding a jade pendant and weeping bitterly; then he laughed, clapping his hands and singing. Dun consulted the oracle, which showed an ominous sign followed by a good one. Zhao Shi Yuan interpreted the dream, saying, "This dream is very ominous; it does not concern you, but your son, yet it is also your fault. By your grandson's time, the Zhao family will decline further." Tu Anjia, initially favored by Duke Ling, became Minister of Justice under Duke Jing. He plotted rebellion, prosecuting the traitors of Duke Ling and implicating Zhao Dun, then proclaiming to the generals, "Although Dun was unaware, he is still the ringleader of the traitors. Since a subject murdered his ruler, and his descendants are in court, how can he be punished? Please execute him." 12.2. Han Jue said, "When Duke Ling encountered the traitors, Zhao Dun was away. Our late lord considered him innocent and therefore did not execute him. Now you gentlemen intend to execute his descendants, which is contrary to our late lord's intention and a reckless execution. Reckless execution is called rebellion. If a subject has a great matter and the ruler does not hear of it, it is tantamount to having no ruler." Tu Anjia did not listen. Han Jue urged Zhao Shuo to flee. Shuo refused, saying, "If you will not extinguish the Zhao lineage, I will die without regret." Han Jue agreed and claimed illness to avoid going out. Jia, without being invited, led the generals to attack the Zhao clan at the Lower Palace, killing Zhao Shuo, Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Yingqi, and exterminating their entire clan.
[596 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 13. Zhao Shuo's wife, the elder sister of Cheng Gong, was pregnant and fled to the palace to hide. A guest of Zhao Shuo named Gongsun Chujiu said to Zhao Shuo's friend Cheng Ying, "Why don't you die?" Cheng Ying replied, "Shao Shuo's wife is pregnant. If it is a boy, I will raise him; if it is a girl, I will die later." Not long after, Zhao Shuo's wife gave birth to a boy. Tu Anjia heard of this and searched for the child in the palace. The lady placed the child in a crevice and prayed, "If the Zhao clan perishes, let him cry out; if not, let him be silent." When they searched, the child remained silent. Having escaped, Cheng Ying said to Gongsun Chujiu, "If we cannot find him now, we will surely search again. What should we do?" Gongsun Chujiu said, "Which is more difficult, raising an orphan or dying?" Cheng Ying said, "Dying is easy, raising an orphan is difficult." Gongsun Chujiu said, "The late Zhao lord treated you kindly. You insist on doing the difficult thing; I will do the easy thing. Please die first." The two then plotted to take another man's baby, carry it, clothe it in fine clothes, and hide it in the mountains. Cheng Ying went out and falsely told the generals, "I am unworthy and cannot establish the Zhao orphan as heir. Who can give me a thousand pieces of gold, and I will tell you where the Zhao orphan is?" The generals were all pleased and agreed, and set out with their troops to attack Gongsun Chujiu. Chujiu falsely said, "What a despicable man Cheng Ying! He did not die during the Xiagong Rebellion, and conspired with me to hide the Zhao orphan. Now he has betrayed me. Even if I cannot establish him as heir, how can I bear to sell him out!" He held the child and cried out, "Heaven! Heaven! What crime has the Zhao orphan committed? Please spare his life, and kill only Chujiu." The generals refused, and so they killed Chujiu and the orphan. The generals thought the Zhao orphan was truly dead and were all happy. However, the real Zhao orphan was still alive, and Cheng Ying ended up hiding with him in the mountains.
[595 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 95. In the fifth year, he attacked Zheng, in order to aid Chu. At that time, King Zhuang of Chu was powerful, and he used this opportunity to defeat the Jin army on the Yellow River.
[594 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 38.2 (yr 10). In the tenth year, King Zhuang of Chu subdued Zheng and defeated the Jin army on the Yellow River. At that time, Chu was the hegemon and convened an alliance of the feudal lords. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 96.1. In the sixth year, Chu attacked Song. Song pleaded for help from Jin, which wanted to aid them. Bo Zong plotted, saying, "Chu is now favored by Heaven; we cannot withstand them." He then sent Jie Yang to deceive Song into surrendering. 96.2. The people of Zheng captured Jie Yang and handed him over to Chu. Chu rewarded him handsomely and sent him to contradict himself, urging Song to surrender immediately. Jie Yang agreed, and eventually delivered the message to the ruler of Jin. Chu wanted to kill him, but someone advised against it, so Jie Yang was released. In the seventh year, Jin sent Sui Hui to destroy the Red Di. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 31. Twenty years later, King Zhuang besieged Song, ostensibly to kill the Chu envoy. After five months of siege, the city ran out of food, and people resorted to cannibalism, even exchanging children for food and cooking with bones. Song's Hua Yuan came out and explained the situation. King Zhuang exclaimed, "What a wise man!" and withdrew his troops.
[593 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 53. In the first year of Duke Qing, King Zhuang of Chu was strong and attacked Chen; in the second year, he besieged Zheng, and Duke Zheng surrendered, and the state of Zheng was restored. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 94. Four years later, Xian Hu, having led the Jin army to victory with his initial strategy, fled to Di and conspired with them to attack Jin. Jin discovered this and executed Hu, who was the son of Xian Zhen.
[592 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 97. Eight years later, Que Ke was sent to Qi. The mother of Duke Qing of Qi watched from a high tower and laughed. The reason was that Que Ke was hunchbacked, while the envoy from Lu was lame and the envoy from Wei was one-eyed; therefore, Qi also sent someone to guide their guests. Que Ke was furious. Returning to the riverbank, he declared, "If I do not avenge Qi, may the River God watch over me!" Upon arriving in Qi, he petitioned the ruler, intending to attack Qi. Duke Jing, knowing the reason, said, "Your grievances are not enough to trouble the state!" He did not listen. Wen Zi of Wei requested that Que Ke retire, and Que Ke was dismissed, becoming the prime minister.
[591 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 53.3. In the sixteenth year, King Zhuang of Chu died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 46. In the eighteenth year, Duke Xuan died, and his son, Duke Cheng, Heigong, succeeded him as Duke Cheng. Ji Wenzi said, "If I were to kill the legitimate heir and the commoner who lost his great support, it would be Xiangzhong." Xiangzhong established Duke Xuan, and Gongsun Guifu gained favor. Duke Xuan wanted to eliminate the Three Huan families and plotted with Jin to attack them. Duke Xuan died, and Ji Wenzi resented him, so Guifu fled to Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 98. Nine years later, King Zhuang of Chu died. Jin attacked Qi, and Qi sent its crown prince Qiang as a hostage to Jin, after which the Jin army withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 32. In the twenty-third year, King Zhuang died, and his son, King Gong, succeeded him.
[590 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 54. In the spring of the sixth year, the Jin envoy Que Ke went to Qi. The Qi envoy's wife watched from behind a curtain. Que Ke went up, and the wife laughed at him. Que Ke said, "If I don't get revenge, I won't cross the river again!" He returned and requested permission to attack Qi, but the Duke of Jin refused. When the Qi envoys arrived in Jin, Que Ke captured four Qi envoys in Henan and killed them. In the eighth year, Jin attacked Qi. Qi sent Prince Qiang as a hostage to Jin, and the Jin army withdrew. In the spring of the tenth year, Qi attacked Lu and Wei. The officials of Lu and Wei went to Jin to request troops, all through Que Ke. Jin sent Que Ke with 800 chariots as the commander of the central army, Shi Xie as the commander of the upper army, and Luan Shu as the commander of the lower army to rescue Lu and Wei and attack Qi. On the day of Renshen in the sixth month, the Jin army joined forces with the Duke of Qi at Mijixia. On the day of Guiyou, Chen Yulong Pang Choufu served as the right-hand man of Duke Qing of Qi. Duke Qing said, "Charge! Defeat the Jin army at the feast." Que Ke was shot and wounded, and blood flowed to his shoes. Ke wanted to return to the camp, but his charioteer said, "I was wounded twice when I first entered. I dare not speak of my injury, for I fear the soldiers. I beg you to bear with it." So they fought again. In the battle, Qi was in a hurry. Chou Fu, fearing that the Duke of Qi would capture him, changed his position, with Duke Qing on the right. The chariot got tangled in a tree and stopped. Han Jue, a junior general of Jin, ambushed the Duke of Qi's chariot, saying, "My lord has sent me to rescue Lu and Wei," mocking him. Chou Fu made Duke Qing get down to fetch a drink, and then escaped, fleeing into their army. Jin wanted to kill Chou Fu. Chou Fu said, "If I die in place of my lord and am executed, then no future minister will be loyal to his lord." Ke spared him, and Chou Fu escaped and returned to Qi. Then the Jin army pursued Qi to Maling. The Duke of Qi offered to reward him with precious artifacts, but he refused; he insisted on finding Xiao Tongshuzi, the son of Ke, and ordered him to work in the eastern fields of Qi. He replied, “Shuzi, you are the mother of the ruler of Qi. The mother of the ruler of Qi is just like the mother of the ruler of Jin. What will you do with her? Moreover, you attacked with righteousness but then made a violent one. Is that acceptable?” So he agreed and ordered the return of the territories that Lu and Wei had invaded. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 8. After Wu Yu's death, he had two sons, Wu Zikai and Tian Liziqi. Tian Liziqi served Duke Jing of Qi as a high official. He collected taxes from the people using small measures, but distributed grain to them using large measures, thus secretly benefiting the people, and Duke Jing did not prohibit him. As a result, the Tian family gained the hearts of the people of Qi, their clan grew stronger, and the people longed for the Tian family. Yanzi repeatedly advised Duke Jing against this, but Duke Jing did not listen. Later, when Yanzi was sent as an envoy to Jin, he privately told Shu Xiang, "The government of Qi has ultimately fallen into the hands of the Tian family."
[589 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 47.1. In the spring of the second year of Duke Cheng's reign, Qi attacked and captured Long. In the summer, the Duke and Jin defeated Duke Qing of Qi at Ai, and Qi returned the territory that had been seized. In the fourth year, Duke Cheng went to Jin, where Duke Jing of Jin showed no respect for Lu. Lu wanted to break away from Jin and ally with Chu, but someone advised against it, so Lu did not. In the tenth year, Duke Cheng went to Jin again. Duke Jing of Jin died, and Duke Cheng was detained for the funeral, which Lu concealed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 11.2. Duke Xuan died in the fifteenth year, and Duke Zhao succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 99.1. In the spring of the eleventh year, Qi attacked Lu and captured Long. Lu urgently appealed to Wei, and both Wei and Lu appealed to Jin through Que Ke. Jin then sent Que Ke, Luan Shu, and Han Jue with 800 chariots to join Lu and Wei in attacking Qi. 99.2. In the summer, they fought Duke Qing at Ai, wounding and trapping him. Duke Qing then switched places with his right-hand man, went down to get a drink, and escaped. The Qi army was defeated and fled, and Jin pursued them back to Qi. Duke Qing offered precious artifacts to seek peace, but Jin refused. Que Ke said, "I must obtain Xiao Tong's nephew as a hostage." The Qi envoy said, "Xiao Tong's nephew is Duke Qing's mother; Duke Qing's mother is also the mother of the ruler of Jin. Why must we obtain her? It is unjust. Please let us fight again." Jin then agreed to peace and left. 100. The Duke Shen of Chu, Wu Chen, stole Xia Ji and fled to Jin. Jin then appointed Wu Chen as the Grand Master of Xing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 3. Han Shijia: In the eleventh year of Duke Jing's reign, Han Jue and Que Ke led 800 chariots to attack Qi, defeating Duke Qing of Qi at An and capturing Feng Choufu. Thereupon, Jin established six ministers, and Han Jue was placed in the position of one of them, known as Xianzi.
[588 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 101. In the winter of the twelfth year, Duke Qing of Qi went to Jin, intending to honor Duke Jing of Jin as king, but Duke Jing declined. Jin then established the Six Ministers (military officials), with Han Jue, Gong Shuo, Zhao Chuan, Xun Zhui, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Zhan all serving as ministers. Zhi Ying returned from Chu.
[587 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 55. In the eleventh year, the state of Jin established six ministers and rewarded those who had rendered meritorious service. Duke Qing of Qi paid homage to Jin, wishing to honor King Jing of Jin, but Duke Jing dared not accept and returned home. Upon his return, Duke Qing abolished the imperial gardens and parks, reduced taxes, provided relief to orphans and inquired about the sick, and used his savings to help the people, who were greatly pleased. He treated the feudal lords with great courtesy. When Duke Qing died, the people were loyal to him, and the feudal lords no longer dared to offend him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 102. In the thirteenth year, Duke Cheng of Lu paid homage to Jin, but Jin did not show respect. Enraged, Lu withdrew and betrayed Jin. Jin then attacked Zheng and captured Fan.
[586 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 54.1. In the twenty-first year, King Ding died, [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 103. Fourteen years later, Liangshan collapsed. When asked about it, Bo Zong thought it was nothing to be surprised about.
[585 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 54.2. and his son King Jian, Yi, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 3.3. Qu Qi died, and his son Shou Meng succeeded him. Shou Meng succeeded him, and Wu began to grow stronger, claiming the title of king. 4 (discursive summary). From Taibo's establishment of Wu, five generations later, King Wu conquered Yin and enfeoffed his descendants as two: one as Yu, in China; the other as Wu, among the barbarians. Twelve generations later, Jin destroyed Yu, the Chinese state. Two generations after the destruction of Yu, the barbarian state of Wu rose to power. This spans nineteen generations from Taibo to Shoumeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 9. After Yan Ying's death, the Fan and Zhonghang clans rebelled against Jin. Jin attacked them fiercely, and the Fan and Zhonghang clans requested grain from Qi. Tian Qi, wanting to instigate chaos and establish allies among the feudal lords, persuaded Duke Jing, saying, "The Fan and Zhonghang clans have repeatedly shown kindness to Qi; Qi cannot fail to come to their aid." Qi then sent Tian Qi to aid them and provided them with grain.
[584 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 5.1. In the second year of King Shoumeng's reign, Shen Gong Wuchen, a high-ranking official of Chu who had fled to Jin, resented the Chu general Zi Fan. He then traveled from Jin to Wu, where he taught Wu military tactics and chariot warfare. He appointed Shen Gong Wu's son as a messenger for Wu, thus establishing Wu's initial contact with the Central Plains. Wu then attacked Chu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 104. In the sixteenth year, the Chu general Zifan, harboring resentment towards Wuchen, exterminated his entire clan. Wuchen, enraged, sent Zifan a letter saying, "I will surely make you exhausted from running around!" He then requested to be sent as an envoy to Wu, appointing Zifan's son as a Wu messenger to teach Wu how to use chariots and employ troops. Wu and Jin then established diplomatic relations and agreed to attack Chu.
[583 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 105. In the seventeenth year, Zhao Tong and Zhao Kuo were executed, and their clans were exterminated. Han Jue said, "How can the merits of Zhao Cui and Zhao Dun be forgotten? How can their ancestral rites be cut off!" So he reinstated Zhao's son Wu as the successor of Zhao and restored his fiefdom. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 1. Han Shijia: Han Zhixian shared the same surname as Zhou, Ji. His descendants served the state of Jin and were enfeoffed at Hanyuan, becoming known as Han Wuzi. Three generations after Wuzi, there was Han Jue, who adopted the surname Han from his fiefdom. 2. Han Shijia: In the third year of Duke Jing of Jin's reign, Tu Anjia, the Minister of Justice of Jin, plotted a rebellion and executed Zhao Dun, a traitor to Duke Ling. Zhao Dun was already dead, and Tu Anjia intended to kill his son, Zhao Shuo. Han Jue stopped Tu Anjia, but Tu Anjia refused. Han Jue then told Zhao Shuo to flee. Zhao Shuo said, "If you can ensure the Zhao lineage is not cut off, I will die without regret." Han Jue agreed. When Tu Anjia executed the Zhao clan, Han Jue feigned illness and refused to leave the palace. Han Jue knew that Cheng Ying and Gongsun Chujiu had hidden Zhao Wu, the orphan of Zhao. 4. Han Shijia: In the seventeenth year of Duke Jing of Jin's reign, Duke Jing fell ill and consulted the oracle, believing that the failure of his great undertaking was due to the evil spirits causing his death. Han Jue praised the achievements of Zhao Chengji, saying that there would be no more sacrifices to be made thereafter, in order to move Duke Jing's spirit. Duke Jing asked, "Will there still be descendants?" Han Jue then spoke of Zhao Wu, and restored the former Zhao clan's lands and towns, allowing the Zhao clan's sacrifices to continue.
[582 BC]
[581 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 106. In the summer of the nineteenth year, Duke Jing fell ill and installed his crown prince, Shouman, as ruler, who became Duke Li. A month later, Duke Jing died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 14. After fifteen years, Duke Jing of Jin fell ill. He consulted a divination master, who said the oracle was haunted by the unfulfilled descendants of the Great Cause. Duke Jing asked Han Jue, who knew of the existence of the Zhao orphan. Han Jue said, “Among the descendants of the Great Cause whose lineage in Jin has ended, is the Zhao clan? Those who descended from Zhong Yan were all of the Ying surname. Zhong Yan had a human face and a bird's beak. He descended to assist Emperor Da Wu of Yin, and later the Zhou emperors, all of whom possessed virtuous character. Even during the reigns of the tyrannical King You and King Li, Shu Dai left Zhou for Jin, serving the former ruler, Marquis Wen, and continuing to Duke Cheng. Each generation had rendered meritorious service, and their lineage never ceased. Now, our lord alone has destroyed the Zhao clan. The people of the state grieve for them, hence this divination. Your Majesty must consider this.” Duke Jing asked, “Does the Zhao clan still have any descendants?” Han Jue told him the truth. Duke Jing then conspired with Han Jue to install the Zhao orphan, summoning him and hiding him in the palace. When the generals came to inquire about his illness, Duke Jing, using Han Jue's forces to coerce the generals, finally saw the Zhao orphan. The Zhao orphan's name was Wu. Left with no other choice, the generals said, "In the past, the rebellion at Xiagong was orchestrated by Tu Anjia, who falsely claimed to have the emperor's order and commanded all the ministers. Otherwise, who would dare to rebel! If it weren't for your illness, we ministers would have already requested that the Zhao queen be established. Now that you have given your order, it is our wish." Thereupon, they summoned Zhao Wu and Cheng Ying to pay their respects to all the generals, and then, together with Cheng Ying and Zhao Wu, attacked Tu Anjia, exterminating his entire clan. They then restored Zhao Wu's lands and towns to their former status.
[580 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 38.3 (yr 24). In the twenty-fourth year, Duke Li of Jin ascended the throne and formed an alliance with Duke Huan of Qin across the Yellow River. Upon his return, Qin broke the alliance and conspired with the Di to attack Jin.
[579 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 56. In the seventeenth year, Duke Qing died, and his son Duke Ling succeeded him.
[578 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 38.4 (yr 26). In the twenty-sixth year, Jin led the feudal lords to attack Qin, and the Qin army was defeated and fled, pursued to the Jing River before returning. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 107. In the first year of Duke Li's reign, upon ascending the throne, he sought to make peace with the other feudal lords and formed an alliance with Duke Huan of Qin across the river. Upon his return, Qin broke the alliance and conspired with the Di to attack Jin. Three years later, he sent his minister Lü to yield to Qin, and then joined forces with other feudal lords to attack Qin. Reaching Jing, they defeated Qin at Masui and captured their general Cheng Cha.
[577 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 38.5 (yr 27; death). Duke Huan died in the twenty-seventh year of his reign, and his son Duke Jing succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 11.3. Duke Zhao died in the thirteenth year, and Duke Wu succeeded him. 11.4. In that year, Jin destroyed the three powerful ministers.
[576 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 57. In the ninth year of Duke Ling's reign, Luan Shu of Jin assassinated his ruler, Duke Li. In the tenth year, Duke Dao of Jin attacked Qi, and Qi sent Prince Guang as a hostage to Jin. In the nineteenth year, Prince Guang was made crown prince, with Gao Hou as his tutor, and an alliance of feudal lords was convened at Zhongli. In the twenty-seventh year, Jin sent Zhonghang Xianzi to attack Qi. The Qi army was defeated, and Duke Ling fled to Linzi. Yan Ying tried to stop Duke Ling, but he refused, saying, "You have lost your courage!" The Jin army then besieged Linzi, and the city's defenders dared not come out. Jin burned the city walls and withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 108. Five years later, Duke Li thrice rejected the slander of Bo Zong, and Bo Zong was killed. Bo Zong suffered this misfortune because of his outspokenness, and the people of the state did not support Duke Li because of this.
[575 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 47.2. In the fifteenth year, he first met with King Shoumeng of Wu at Zhongli. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 109. In the spring of the sixth year, Zheng, in alliance with Jin and Chu, angered Jin. Luan Shu said, "We cannot afford to lose the feudal lords while we are in power." He then mobilized troops. Duke Li personally led the army, crossing the river in the fifth month. Hearing that Chu troops were coming to their aid, Fan Wenzi urged the Duke to return. He declined, saying, "If we send troops to punish the traitors and are met with strong resistance, we will have no way to command the feudal lords." He then engaged in battle. On the day of Gui Si, an arrow struck King Gong of Chu in the eye, and the Chu army was defeated at Yanling. Zi Fan gathered the remaining troops, patted Xun, and wanted to fight again, which worried Jin. King Gong summoned Zi Fan, but his attendant, Shu Yanggu, offered him wine. Zi Fan was drunk and could not see him. The king was angry, reprimanded Zi Fan, and Zi Fan died. The king then withdrew his troops. Jin thus gained power among the feudal lords, hoping to use this to command the world and seek hegemony. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 33. In the sixteenth year of King Gong's reign, Jin attacked Zheng. Zheng pleaded for help, and King Gong came to its aid. They fought the Jin army at Yanling, where Jin defeated Chu and shot King Gong in the eye. King Gong summoned General Zifan. Zifan was fond of wine, and his follower Shuyang Gu brought him wine until he was drunk. The king was enraged, shot and killed Zifan, and then withdrew his troops.
[574 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 5.2. In the sixteenth year, King Gong of Chu attacked Wu, reaching Hengshan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 48. In the sixteenth year, Xuanbo informed the state of Jin that he wished to execute Ji Wenzi. Wenzi was righteous, and the people of Jin did not allow it. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 110.1. Duke Li had many concubines. Upon returning home, he intended to dismiss all the high officials and install the brothers of his concubines as heirs. One of his favorite concubines' brothers, Xu Tong, had a grudge against Que Zhi. Later, Luan Shu resented Que Zhi for not heeding his advice, which led to the defeat of Chu. Xu Tong then sent someone to secretly apologize to Chu. Chu sent a lie to Duke Li, saying, "In the Battle of Yanling, Que Zhi summoned Chu, intending to rebel, and installed his wife, Zhou, as heir. However, the state was not prepared, so the plan failed." Duke Li informed Luan Shu. Luan Shu said, "It's almost certain! I suggest you send someone to Zhou to investigate." Que Zhi was indeed sent to Zhou. Luan Shu then sent Prince Zhou to see Que Zhi, who was unaware of being betrayed. Duke Li verified this and it was true. He then harbored resentment towards Que Zhi and wanted to kill him.
[573 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 54.3. In the thirteenth year of King Jian's reign, the state of Jin killed its ruler, Duke Li, and welcomed his son Zhou to Zhou, where he was established as Duke Dao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 39.1 (Duke Jing yr 4) (Wikipedia). In the fourth year of Duke Jing's reign, Luan Shu of Jin assassinated his ruler, Duke Li. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 110.2. Eight years later, Duke Li went hunting and drank with his concubines. Que Zhi killed a pig to present to the Duke, but a eunuch snatched it. Que Zhi shot and killed the eunuch. The Duke was furious, saying, "This young man has deceived me!" He intended to execute Que Zhi three times, but did not do so. Que Gou wanted to attack the Duke, saying, "Even if I die, the Duke will be ill." Que Gou arrived and said, "Trust does not betray the ruler, wisdom does not harm the people, and courage does not cause chaos. If I lose these three, who will stand with me? I will die!" On the day of Renwu in the twelfth month, the Duke ordered Xu Tong to lead eight hundred soldiers to attack and kill the three Que. Xu Tong then kidnapped Luan Shu and Zhongxing Yan in court, saying, "If you don't kill these two sons, trouble will surely befall you." The Duke said, "If I kill three ministers in one day, I cannot bear to do so." They replied, "People will be cruel to the ruler." The Duke did not listen and apologized to Luan Shu and others for the crime of killing the Que clan: "The ministers are reinstated." The two sons bowed their heads and said, "How fortunate we are!" The Duke made Xu Tong a minister. 110.3. On the day of Yimao in the intercalary month, Duke Li went to the Jiangli clan. Luan Shu and Zhongxing Yan, with their party, attacked and captured Duke Li, imprisoned him, killed Xu Tong, and sent people to welcome Prince Zhou to Zhou and establish him as the Duke, who became Duke Dao. 111. On the day of Gengshen in the first month of the first year of Duke Dao's reign, Luan Shu and Zhongxing Yan assassinated Duke Li and buried him in a single chariot. Duke Li was imprisoned for six days and died. On the day of Gengwu, ten days later, Zhi Ying welcomed Prince Zhou to Jiang. There, he sacrificed a rooster and made an oath with the officials to establish Zhou as Duke Dao. On the day of Xinsi, he went to the Wu Palace for court audiences. On the day of Yiyou in the second month, he ascended the throne. 112. Duke Dao of Zhou was the grandson of Duke Xiang of Jin, Jie, the youngest son of Duke Xiang. Unable to ascend the throne, he was instead called Huan Shu, whom Duke Huan loved most. Huan Shu begat Hui Bo Tan, who begat Duke Dao of Zhou. Zhou ascended the throne at the age of fourteen. Duke Dao said, “My grandson and father were both unable to ascend the throne and fled to Zhou, where they died as guests. I have always considered myself distant and unlikely to become ruler. Now, the ministers have not forgotten the intentions of Duke Wen and Duke Xiang and have kindly established the descendant of Huan Shu. Thanks to the blessings of the ancestral temple and the ministers, we are able to continue the sacrifices of Jin. How could I not be trembling with fear? Ministers, please assist me!” Thereupon, he expelled seven disloyal men, restored old merits, bestowed favors, and welcomed the descendants of those who had served Duke Wen. In the autumn, he attacked Zheng. The Zheng army was defeated and then marched to Chen.
[572 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 55.1. In the fourteenth year, King Jian died, and his son King Ling (Xie Xin) ascended the throne.
[571 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 49. In the eighteenth year, Duke Cheng died, and his son Ziwu ascended the throne, becoming Duke Xiang. At that time, Duke Xiang was three years old. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 113.1. In the third year, the State of Jin convened a meeting of the feudal lords. Duke Dao asked his ministers who they could rely on, and Qi Xi recommended Jie Hu. Jie Hu was Qi Xi's enemy. He was asked again, and Qi Xi recommended Jie Hu's son, Qi Wu. A wise man said, "Qi Xi can be said to be impartial! He recommends those who are enemies without concealing his own, and recommends those who are sons without concealing his own." At the meeting of the feudal lords, Duke Dao's younger brother, Yang Gan, acted recklessly, and Wei Jiang killed his servant. Duke Dao was furious, and some advised him against it. Duke Dao ultimately recognized Wei Jiang's worth and entrusted him with government affairs, making peace with the Rong tribes, who then became very loyal to him.
[570 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 58. In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Ling initially married a woman from Lu, who bore him a son named Guang, whom he made crown prince. Zhong Ji and Rong Ji were also present. Rong Ji was favored, and Zhong Ji bore him a son named Ya, who was then given to Rong Ji. Rong Ji requested to be made crown prince, and the Duke agreed. Zhong Ji said, "No. Guang's ascension to the throne places him among the feudal lords. If we depose him without cause, Your Majesty will surely regret it." The Duke said, "It is up to me." He then moved Crown Prince Guang eastward and appointed Gao Hou as tutor to Ya, making him crown prince. Duke Ling fell ill, and Cui Zhu welcomed the former crown prince Guang and installed him as crown prince, who became Duke Zhuang. Duke Zhuang killed Rong Ji. In the fifth month, on the day of Ren Chen, Duke Ling died, and Duke Zhuang ascended the throne. He captured Crown Prince Ya at Ju Dou Hill and killed him. In the eighth month, Cui Zhu killed Gao Hou. Hearing of the chaos in Qi, Jin attacked Qi, reaching Gao Tang.
[569 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 59. In the third year of Duke Zhuang's reign, Luan Ying, a high-ranking official of Jin, fled to Qi. Duke Zhuang treated him with great hospitality. Yan Ying and Tian Wenzi advised against this, but the Duke did not listen. In the fourth year, Duke Zhuang of Qi sent Luan Ying to Quwo in Jin as an inside agent, with troops following him. They ascended the Taihang Mountains and entered Mengmen. Luan Ying was defeated, the Qi troops returned, and captured Chaoge. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 50. In the first year of Duke Xiang's reign, Duke Dao of Jin was enthroned. The previous winter, Luan Shu of Jin assassinated his ruler, Duke Li. Four years later, Duke Xiang paid homage to Jin.
[568 BC]
[567 BC]
[566 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 15. When Zhao Wu came of age, Cheng Ying bid farewell to the other officials and said to Zhao Wu, "During the turmoil at the Lower Palace, everyone was willing to die. It wasn't that I couldn't die, but I wanted to establish the Zhao family line. Now that Zhao Wu has been established and is an adult, and has been restored to his former position, I will go down to avenge Zhao Xuanmeng and Gongsun Chujiu." Zhao Wu wept and kowtowed, earnestly pleading, "I am willing to endure hardship to repay you until death, but how can you bear to let me die?" Cheng Ying said, "No. They thought I was capable of accomplishing their task, so they died before me; if I do not repay them, it will be as if my task has failed." He then committed suicide. Zhao Wu wore the mourning clothes of Qi for three years, and a sacrificial town was built for him, with sacrifices offered in spring and autumn, never to be interrupted. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 5. Han Shijia: In the seventh year of the reign of Duke Dao of Jin (10th year), Han Xianzi grew old. Xianzi died, and his son Xuanzi succeeded him. Xuanzi moved to the state.
[565 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 60. In the sixth year, initially, Tang Gong's wife was favored. After Tang Gong died, Cui Zhu took her as his wife. Duke Zhuang had an affair with her, frequently visiting Cui's wife, and even giving away Cui Zhu's hat. The attendant said, "This is unacceptable." Cui Zhu was furious and, taking advantage of the opportunity to attack Jin, wanted to conspire with Jin to attack Qi, but was unable to do so. Duke Zhuang had once flogged the eunuch Jia Ju, who then served him again and helped Cui Zhu to retaliate against the Duke. In the fifth month, the ruler of Ju paid homage to Qi, and Qi hosted a banquet for him on the day of Jiaxu. Cui Zhu claimed illness and did not attend to official duties. On the day of Yihai, the Duke inquired about Cui Zhu's illness and then went to see Cui Zhu's wife. Cui Zhu's wife entered the room, and she and Cui Zhu locked themselves in and did not come out. The Duke leaned against a pillar and sang. The eunuch Jia Ju blocked the Duke and his officials from entering, closed the door, and Cui Zhu's men, armed with weapons, rose up from within. The Duke climbed a platform to plead for a settlement, but was refused; he pleaded to make an oath, but was refused; he pleaded to commit suicide in the temple, but was refused. They all said, "Your subject Cui Zhu is ill and unable to obey orders. He is near the palace. His attendants are vying for his attention, and some are engaging in illicit affairs. He is unaware of the two orders." The Duke climbed over the wall, and an arrow struck him in the thigh. Cui Zhu fell backward, and the Duke was killed. Yan Ying stood outside Cui Zhu's gate and said, "If Your Majesty dies for the state, then die for him; if Your Majesty perishes for the state, then perish for him. But if Your Majesty dies for me, then perish for me. Who but a close friend would dare to entrust this to you?" He opened the gate and entered, lay down on Cui Zhu's body, and wept. He then leaped three times before leaving. People said to Cui Zhu, "You must kill him." Cui Zhu said, "He is the people's hope; sparing him will win the people's hearts."
[564 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 51. Five years later, Ji Wenzi died. He had no concubines to clothe him in silk, no horses to feed him millet, and no gold or jade in his treasury, yet he served three lords. A wise man said, "Ji Wenzi was indeed honest and loyal."
[563 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 113.2. In the eleventh year, Duke Dao said, "Since I employed Wei Jiang, we have convened the feudal lords nine times and made peace with the Rong and Di tribes; this is all thanks to Wei Jiang." He bestowed upon him music, which Wei Jiang declined three times before accepting. In winter, Qin seized Li.
[562 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 39.2 (yr 15). In the fifteenth year, Jin came to the aid of Zheng, defeating the Jin army at Li. At that time, Duke Dao of Jin was the leader of the alliance.
[561 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 6. In the twenty-fifth year, King Shoumeng died. Shoumeng had four sons: the eldest was Zhufan, the second was Yuji, the third was Yumei, and the fourth was Jizha. Jizha was virtuous, and Shoumeng wanted to make him the heir, but Jizha declined. So Shoumeng made his eldest son Zhufan the heir and put him in charge of the affairs of the state.
[560 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 7.1. In the first year of King Zhufan's reign, after the mourning period, Zhufan yielded the throne to Ji Zha. Ji Zha declined, saying, "When Duke Xuan of Cao died, the feudal lords and the people of Cao acted unjustly towards the ruler of Cao, intending to install Zi Zang as the new ruler. Zi Zang resigned to ensure the succession of the new ruler. A gentleman said, 'He has upheld his principles.' Now that you are a righteous successor, who would dare to interfere with your rule? To possess a state is not my principle. Although I am incompetent, I wish to follow Zi Zang's righteousness." The people of Wu insisted on installing Ji Zha, but Ji Zha abandoned his house and went to farm, so they released him. In the autumn, Wu attacked Chu, and Chu defeated our army. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 61. In the year Dingchou, Cui Zhu installed Duke Zhuang's half-brother, Chujiu, as Duke Jing. Duke Jing's mother was the daughter of Shusun Xuanbo of Lu. Upon ascending the throne, Duke Jing appointed Cui Zhu as Right Chancellor and Qing Feng as Left Chancellor. Fearing rebellion, the two chancellors made an oath with the people of the state: "Those who do not side with Cui and Qing shall die!" Yanzi looked up to the heavens and said, "I will only follow those who are loyal to the ruler and benefit the state!" He refused to swear the oath. Qing Feng wanted to kill Yanzi, but Cui Zhu said, "He is a loyal minister; spare him." The Grand Historian of Qi wrote, "Cui Zhu murdered Duke Zhuang," and Cui Zhu killed him. His younger brother wrote a reply, and Cui Zhu killed him as well. His youngest brother wrote a reply, and Cui Zhu spared him again. 62. In the first year of Duke Jing's reign, Cui Zhu had two sons, Cheng and Qiang. After their mother's death, he married a woman from Dongguo, who bore him Ming. The woman from Dongguo then arranged for her former husband's son, Wujiu, and his brother, Yan, to become ministers of the Cui family. Cheng committed a crime, and the two ministers hastily punished him, establishing Ming as crown prince. Cheng requested to retire to Cui [Zhu]'s residence, which Cui Zhu agreed to, but the two ministers refused, saying, "Cui is a ancestral home; it's unacceptable." Cheng and Qiang were enraged and informed Qing Feng. Qing Feng, who had a conflict with Cui Zhu, wanted to bring him down. Cheng and Qiang killed Wujiu and Yan at Cui Zhu's house, and the entire family fled. Cui Zhu, furious and with no one else to help, sent a eunuch to escort him to Qing Feng. Qing Feng said, "Please execute them for my son." He then ordered Cui Zhu to attack the Cui family with his enemy, Lu Pubi, killing Cheng and Qiang, and annihilating the entire Cui family. Cui Zhu's wife committed suicide. Cui Zhu, unable to return home, also committed suicide. Qing Feng became prime minister and seized power. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 52. In the ninth year, they joined forces with Jin to attack Zheng. Duke Dao of Jin presented Duke Xiang with a crown in Wei, and Ji Wuzi accompanied him, performing the rites as his attendant. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 114. In the fourteenth year, the Jin envoy, along with six ministers and other feudal lords, attacked Qin. They crossed the Jing River, inflicted a great defeat on the Qin army, and departed at Yulin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 34. In the thirty-first year, King Gong died, and his son King Kang ascended the throne. King Kang died after reigning for fifteen years, and his son Yuan succeeded him, becoming Jia'ao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 6.2. More than a hundred years later, Yanzi appeared.
[559 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 39.3 (yr 18). In the eighteenth year, Duke Dao of Jin became powerful, frequently convening meetings of the feudal lords and leading them to attack Qin, defeating the Qin army. The Qin army fled, pursued by the Jin troops, who crossed the Jing River and returned to Yulin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 12.1. Duke Wu died in the nineteenth year, and Duke Wen succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 115. In the fifteenth year, Duke Dao asked Shi Kuang about governing the country. Shi Kuang replied, "Only benevolence and righteousness are fundamental." In winter, Duke Dao died, and his son, Duke Ping Biao, succeeded him.
[558 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 63. In the tenth month of the third year, Qing Feng went hunting. Having already killed Cui Zhu, Qing Feng became increasingly arrogant, indulging in wine and hunting, and ignoring government orders. Qing She, who was in charge of the government, had already begun to withdraw from the government. Tian Wenzi said to Huanzi, "Rebellion is about to break out." The Tian, Bao, Gao, and Luan families conspired against the Qing family. Qing She raised an army and surrounded Qing Feng's palace, but the four families' followers attacked and defeated them. Qing Feng returned, but could not enter, and fled to Lu. The people of Qi ceded Lu to Qi, and Qing Feng fled to Wu. Wu gave him Zhu Fang, where he gathered his clan and lived, becoming richer than he had in Qi. That autumn, the people of Qi moved the burial site of Duke Zhuang and mutilated Cui Zhu's corpse in the marketplace to appease the masses. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 53. In the eleventh year, the Three Huan Clan divided into three armies.
[557 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 7.2. In the fourth year, Duke Ping of Jin ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 116. In the first year of Duke Ping's reign, Jin attacked Qi. Duke Ling of Qi fought them but was defeated, and the Qi army fled. Yan Ying said, "Your Majesty is not brave; why not stop the battle?" So Jin left. Jin pursued them, besieged Linzi, and burned and slaughtered the entire city. From Jiao in the east to Yi in the south, Qi defended all its cities, and Jin withdrew its troops.
[556 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 54. In the twelfth year, he paid homage to the Jin court. In the sixteenth year, Duke Ping of Jin ascended the throne. In the twenty-first year, he paid homage to Duke Ping of Jin.
[555 BC]
[554 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 64. In the ninth year, Duke Jing sent Yan Ying to Jin, where Yan Ying privately told Shu Xiang, "The government of Qi has finally fallen to the Tian family. Although the Tian family has no great virtue, they use public power for private gain and are kind to the people, who love them." In the twelfth year, Duke Jing went to Jin, met with Duke Ping, and wanted to attack Yan together. In the eighteenth year, the Duke went to Jin again and met with Duke Zhao. In the twenty-sixth year, while hunting in the suburbs of Lu, he entered Lu and, together with Yan Ying, inquired about the rites of Lu. In the thirty-first year, Duke Zhao of Lu fled to Qi to escape the troubles caused by the Ji family. Qi wanted to enfeoff him with a thousand shrines, but Zi Jia stopped Duke Zhao. Duke Zhao then asked Qi to attack Lu and take Yun to reside in. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 12.2. Duke Wen died in the sixth year, and Duke Yi succeeded him.
[553 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 16. Eleven years after the Zhao family was restored to the throne, Duke Li of Jin killed his minister San Que.
