Luan Shu, fearing repercussions, then murdered his lord Duke Li and installed Zhou, the great-grandson of Duke Xiang, as Duke Dao. As a result, the ministers of Jin gradually became stronger.
[552 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 117.1. In the sixth year, Duke Xiang of Lu paid homage to Jin. Luan Cheng of Jin, having committed a crime, fled to Qi.
[551 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 55. In the twenty-second year, Confucius was born. 55. In the twenty-second year, Confucius was born.
[550 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 39.4 (yr 27). In the twenty-seventh year, Duke Jing went to Jin, made an alliance with Duke Ping, but later betrayed him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 65. In the thirty-second year, a comet appeared. Duke Jing sat in his cypress-covered chamber and sighed, "How magnificent! Who else could have such a sight?" All the ministers wept, but Yanzi laughed, which angered the Duke. Yanzi said, "I laugh at the excessive flattery of the ministers." Duke Jing said, "A comet has appeared in the northeast, in the territory of Qi, and I am worried." Yanzi said, "Your Majesty has high towers and deep ponds, yet you collect taxes as if you cannot, and you fear that punishments will not be enough. A comet is about to appear; what is there to fear?" The Duke asked, "Can we perform a ritual to appease it?" Yanzi said, "A god can be summoned by prayer, and can also be exorcised by ritual. The people suffer and resent in the tens of thousands, and Your Majesty orders one person to perform a ritual; how can that overcome the voices of the masses?" At that time, Duke Jing was fond of building palaces, collecting dogs and horses, indulging in extravagance, and imposing heavy taxes and severe punishments. Therefore, Yanzi used this as a pretext to advise him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 117.2. In the eighth year, Duke Zhuang of Qi secretly sent Luan Cheng to Quwo, with troops following him. The Qi army marched up the Taihang Mountains, and Luan Cheng rebelled from Quwo, attacking Jiang. Jiang was unprepared, and Duke Ping wanted to commit suicide, but Fan Xianzi stopped him and led his men to attack Cheng. Cheng was defeated and fled to Quwo. Quwo attacked Cheng, who died, and the Luan clan was exterminated. Cheng was the grandson of Luan Shu. After entering Jiang, he conspired with the Wei clan. Duke Zhuang of Qi, hearing of Cheng's defeat, returned and seized Chaoge from Jin to avenge the Battle of Linzi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 7. Yan Pingzhongying was a native of Yiwei in Lai. He served Duke Ling, Duke Zhuang, and Duke Jing of Qi, and was highly regarded in Qi for his frugality and diligence. When he became prime minister of Qi, he never ate meat twice a day, and his concubines never wore silk. When he was in court, if the ruler spoke of these matters, he would speak frankly; if he did not speak of them, he would act accordingly. When the state was well-governed, he obeyed orders; when it was not well-governed, he weighed the consequences. In this way, his family became famous among the feudal lords for three generations. 8. Yue Shifu was a virtuous man, imprisoned. Yanzi, while traveling, encountered him on the road, untied his left horse to redeem him, and took him home. Without apologizing, he went into his room. After a while, Yue Shifu asked to sever ties with Yanzi. Yanzi, startled, adjusted his clothes and apologized, saying, "Though I am unkind, I freed you from imprisonment; why do you so quickly seek to sever ties?" Shifu replied, "No. I have heard that a gentleman is humbled by those who do not understand him but trusts those who do. When I was in prison, they did not know me. Since you, sir, have awakened to my faults and redeemed me, you are a true friend; to be a friend who does not respect you is worse than being in prison." Yanzi then invited him in as an honored guest.
[549 BC]
[548 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 55.2. In the twenty-fourth year of King Ling's reign, Cui Zhu of Qi assassinated his ruler, Duke Zhuang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 8. In the thirteenth year, King Zhufan died. He decreed that the throne should be passed to his younger brother Yuji, and that the succession should continue until Jizha, to fulfill the late King Shoumeng's wish and to commend Jizha's righteousness. All the brothers wished to receive the throne, and the order was given to proceed gradually. Jizha was enfeoffed at Yanling, hence the title Yanling Jizi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 56. In the twenty-fifth year, Cui Zhu of Qi murdered his ruler, Duke Zhuang, and installed his younger brother, Duke Jing, as ruler. 56. In the twenty-fifth year, Cui Zhu of Qi murdered his ruler, Duke Zhuang, and installed his younger brother, Duke Jing, as ruler. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 12.3. In the first year of Duke Yi's reign, Cui Zhu of Qi assassinated his lord, Duke Zhuang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 118. Ten years later, Cui Zhu of Qi murdered his ruler, Duke Zhuang. Taking advantage of the chaos in Qi, Jin attacked and defeated Qi at Gaotang, in retaliation for the Battle of Taihang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 10.1. After the death of the crown prince of Duke Jing, a favorite concubine named Rui Zi gave birth to a son named Tu. Duke Jing fell ill and ordered his chancellors, Hui Zi and Gao Zhao Zi, to make Tu the crown prince. Duke Jing died, and the two chancellors, Gao and Guo, established Tu as the crown prince, who became known as Yan Ru Zi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 12.1. Fang Yanzi knelt before Duke Zhuang's corpse and wept, completing the ceremony before leaving.
[547 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 10.2. Tian Qi was displeased and wanted to establish Duke Jing's other son, Yang Sheng, as the crown prince. Yang Sheng was on good terms with Tian Qi. When Yan Ru Zi was established, Yang Sheng fled to Lu. Tian Qi, feigning loyalty to Gao Zhao Zi and Hui Zi, would travel in the imperial carriage at court, saying, "Initially, the ministers did not want to establish Ru Zi. Now that Ru Zi is established, the ruler has appointed his chancellors, and the ministers are all insecure and plotting rebellion." He also deceived the ministers, saying, "Gao Zhao Zi is to be feared; we should strike before he acts." The ministers followed his advice. Tian Qi, Bao Mu, and the ministers led troops into the ducal house and attacked Gao Zhao Zi. Zhao Zi, hearing of this, went with Hui Zi to rescue the duke. The ducal army was defeated. Tian Qi's forces pursued Hui Zi, who fled to Ju, and then returned to kill Gao Zhao Zi. Yan (孺子) [圉] ran to Lu.
[546 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 17. Zhao Wu succeeded Zhao Zong for twenty-seven years, and Duke Ping of Jin ascended the throne. In the twelfth year of Duke Ping's reign, Zhao Wu became the chief minister. In the thirteenth year, Ji Zi of Yanling, Wu, was sent as an envoy to Jin and said, "The administration of Jin will ultimately fall to the descendants of Zhao Wu, Han Xuanzi, and Wei Xianzi." Zhao Wu died and was posthumously honored as Wenzi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 11. Tian Qi sent someone to Lu to welcome Yang Sheng. Yang Sheng arrived in Qi and hid in Tian Qi's house. He invited the officials, saying, "Chang's mother has prepared a fish and beans sacrifice; please come and join the feast." The feast was held at Tian's house. Tian Qi placed Yang Sheng in a bag and put him in the center. He opened the bag, took out Yang Sheng, and said, "This is the ruler of Qi." The officials all bowed in homage. They were about to swear an oath to establish him as ruler when Tian Qi falsely accused, "I conspired with Bao Mu to establish Yang Sheng as ruler." Bao Mu angrily said, "Have the officials forgotten Duke Jing's orders?" The officials wanted to back out, but Yang Sheng bowed his head and said, "If it's acceptable, then establish him; if not, then so be it." Bao Mu, fearing for his own safety, said again, "They are all sons of Duke Jing; why is it unacceptable!" Thus, Yang Sheng was established in Tian Qi's house; he became Duke Dao. He then sent men to move Yan Ruzi to Tai and killed Ruzi Tu. After Duke Dao ascended the throne, Tian Qi became prime minister and monopolized the government of Qi.
[545 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 56.1. In the twenty-seventh year, King Ling died, and his son King Jing ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 9. In the third year of King Yu's reign, Qing Feng, the prime minister of Qi, committed a crime and fled from Qi to Wu. Wu granted Qing Feng the county of Zhufang as a fief, and gave him his daughter in marriage. He became richer than he had been in Qi.
[544 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 10. Four years later, Wu sent Ji Zha to Lu to request to see the music of Zhou. He sang Zhou Nan and Shao Nan, saying, "Beautiful! The foundation has been laid, yet it is not yet complete. Yet they are diligent without complaint." He sang Bei, Yong, and Wei, saying, "Beautiful! Profound! They are concerned but not distressed. I have heard that the virtues of Kang Shu and Wu Gong of Wei were like this; is this the style of Wei?" He sang Wang, saying, "Beautiful! Thoughtful but not afraid; is this the eastern part of Zhou?" He sang Zheng, saying, "It is too small, the people cannot bear it; will it perish first?" He sang Qi, saying, "Beautiful! How vast and magnificent is the great wind! Is this Taigong, who represents the East Sea? The state is immeasurable." He sang Bin, saying, "Beautiful! Expansive and joyful without excess; is this the eastern part of Zhou Gong?" He sang Qin, saying, "This is called the sound of Xia. If one can achieve Xia, then one is great; the ultimate greatness is the old Zhou?" He sang Wei. He said, "How beautiful! Vast and expansive, frugal and easy to manage, acting with virtue as his guide—this is the leader of the alliance." He sang the Tang song. He said, "How profound are his thoughts! Does he possess the legacy of the Tao Tang dynasty? Otherwise, why such distant worries? Who but a descendant of virtuous officials could be like this!" He sang the Chen song. He said, "Without a ruler, how can a state last long?" From Kuai onwards, no one criticized him. He sang the Lesser Odes. He said, "How beautiful! Thoughtful yet unwavering, resentful yet silent—is this the decline of Zhou virtue? Yet, he still possesses the remnants of the former kings." He sang the Greater Odes. He said, "How expansive! How joyful! Curved yet upright—is this the virtue of King Wen?" He sang the praises. He said, “How perfect it is! Straight without arrogance, curved without yielding, near without pressing, far without carrying, moving without being licentious, returning without being weary, sorrowful without being distressed, joyful without being extravagant, using without being insufficient, expansive without being boastful, giving without being wasteful, taking without being greedy, dwelling without being stingy, moving without being drifting. The five tones are harmonious, the eight winds are calm, the rhythm is measured, the order is maintained—this is the common virtue of all.” Seeing the Xiangxie and Nanyue dancers, he said, “Beautiful! I am moved.” Seeing the Dawu dancers, he said, “Beautiful! Is this the grandeur of the Zhou dynasty?” Seeing the Shaohu dancers, he said, “Even the sage’s virtue is great, yet I am ashamed of my own lack of virtue. The sage is difficult to achieve!” Seeing the Daxia dancers, he said, “Beautiful! Diligent without being virtuous! Who but Yu could match him?” Seeing the Zhaoxie dancers, he said, “Virtue is supreme! Great! Like the heavens that cover all, like the earth that bears all. Even the greatest virtue cannot surpass it. This is the ultimate spectacle. If there were other forms of music, I would not dare to watch.” [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 57. In the twenty-ninth year, Wu Yanling Jizi was sent to Lu to inquire about Zhou music. He fully understood its meaning, and the people of Lu respected him. 57. In the twenty-ninth year, Wu Yanling Jizi was sent to Lu to inquire about Zhou music. He fully understood its meaning, and the people of Lu respected him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 12.4. Duke Yi died four years later, and his son, Duke Hui, succeeded him. 13.1. In the first year of Duke Hui's reign, Gao Zhi of Qi fled to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 119. In the fourteenth year, Wu Yanling Jizi came as an envoy and spoke with Zhao Wenzi, Han Xuanzi, and Wei Xianzi, saying, "The administration of Jin will ultimately fall into the hands of these three families." [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 6.1. In the fourteenth year of Duke Ping of Jin, Wu Jizha was sent as an envoy to Jin, saying, "The government of Jin has finally fallen into the hands of Han, Wei, and Zhao." In the twelfth year of Duke Qing of Jin, Han Xuanzi, along with Zhao and Wei, divided ten counties belonging to the Qi and Yangshe clans. In the fifteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Xuanzi and Zhao Jianzi invaded and attacked the Fan and Zhonghang clans. Xuanzi died, and his son Zhenzi succeeded him. Zhenzi moved to Pingyang.
[543 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 11. He went to Lu and then went to Qi. He said to Yan Pingzhong, "You should quickly give up your fief and government. Without a fief and government, you will be spared from trouble. The government of Qi will have a place to belong; until it finds a place, the trouble will not end." Therefore, Yanzi asked Chen Huanzi to give up his government and fief, thus avoiding the trouble caused by Luan Gao.
[542 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 12. He went to Qi and then became an envoy to Zheng. He met Zichan and treated him as an old friend. He said to Zichan, "The rulers of Zheng are extravagant; trouble is imminent, and your rule will inevitably affect you. In governing, you must be cautious and act with propriety. Otherwise, Zheng will be ruined." He then left Zheng and went to Wei. He spoke to Qu Yuan, Shi Gou, Shi, Gongzi Jing, Gongshu Fa, and Gongzi Chao, saying, "Wei has many virtuous men; there is no cause for concern." [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 12. Four years later, Tian Qi died, and his son Chang succeeded him, becoming Tian Chengzi.
[541 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 39.5 (yr 36). In the thirty-sixth year, Prince Wei of Chu assassinated his ruler and established himself as King Ling. Duke Jing's younger brother, Hou Zizhen, was favored and wealthy. Some slandered him, and fearing execution, he fled to Jin with a thousand chariots. Duke Ping of Jin said, "Hou Zizhen is so wealthy, why did he perish?" He replied, "The Duke of Qin is wicked, I fear execution, and wish to return after his descendants." [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 13 (approx.). When the man, Ziwei, was about to lodging in Jin, he heard the sound of a bell and exclaimed, "How strange! I have heard that those who are eloquent but lack virtue will surely be executed. You, sir, have offended the ruler and are here; is fear not enough? And now you dare to rebel? Your presence here is like a swallow nesting in a tent. Can the ruler be happy while in mourning?" He then left. When Wenzi heard of this, he never listened to the zither or lute again for the rest of his life. 16.1 (approx.; reign-year mismatch in text). In the seventh year, Prince Wei of Chu murdered King Jia'ao and ascended the throne as King Ling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 58. In the sixth month of the thirty-first year, Duke Xiang died. In the ninth month, the crown prince died. The people of Lu installed Qi Gui's son, Zhou, as their ruler, who became Duke Zhao. 58. In the sixth month of the thirty-first year, Duke Xiang died. In the ninth month, the crown prince died. The people of Lu installed Qi Gui's son, Zhou, as their ruler, who became Duke Zhao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 35. King Kang favored his younger brothers, Prince Wei, Prince Bi, Prince Xi, and Qi Ji. In the third year of Jia'ao, King Kang appointed Prince Wei, his uncle and younger brother, as Prime Minister, in charge of military affairs. In the fourth year, Wei was sent as an envoy to Zheng, but heard of the king's illness on the way and returned. On the day of Ji-you in the twelfth month, Wei entered to inquire about the king's illness, strangled and murdered him, and then killed his son, Mo Ji Pingxia. He sent an envoy to Zheng. Wu Ju asked, "Who is the successor?" The answer was, "My humble minister Wei." Wu Ju further said, "Wei, the son of King Gong, is the eldest." Prince Bi fled to Jin, and Wei ascended the throne, becoming King Ling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 13. Bao Mu had a feud with Duke Dao of Qi and assassinated him. The people of Qi then enthroned his son, Ren, who became Duke Jian. Tian Changchengzi and Jian Zhi both served as left and right prime ministers to Duke Jian. Tian Changchengzi harbored resentment towards Jian Zhi, who was favored by Duke Jian and could not be removed. Therefore, Tian Changchengzi reinstated the old system of lending grain using large measures and collecting it using small measures. The people of Qi sang a song about this: "Old woman gathering artemisia, go back to Tian Changchengzi!" At court, the Qi official Yu Yang advised Duke Jian: "Tian and Jian cannot coexist; Your Majesty should choose one." The Duke did not listen.
[540 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 14 (approx.). When he arrived in Jin, he said to Zhao Wenzi, Han Xuanzi, and Wei Xianzi, "The state of Jin will be dominated by these three families!" Before leaving, he said to Shu Xiang, "My son, strive on! Your lord is extravagant and has many virtuous officials, and the ministers are all wealthy. The government will be controlled by these three families. My son is upright and will surely think of ways to save yourself from disaster." 15 (approx.). When Ji Zha first went on his mission, he passed through the territory of the ruler of Xu in the north. The ruler of Xu admired Ji Zha's sword but dared not speak of it. Ji Zha knew this, but as an envoy to a superior state, he did not present it. Upon returning to Xu, he found the ruler of Xu had already died. He then untied his precious sword, tied it to a tree near the ruler's tomb, and departed. His followers said, "The ruler of Xu is dead; to whom will you give it?" Ji Zha replied, "No. I had already promised it in my heart; how could I go back on my word because of his death!" [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 18. Wenzi begat Jingshu. During Jingshu's reign, Duke Jing of Qi sent Yan Ying to Jin. Yan Ying spoke with Shu Xiang of Jin. Ying said, "The government of Qi will eventually fall into the hands of the Tian family." Shu Xiang also said, "The government of Jin will fall into the hands of the six ministers. The six ministers are extravagant, and our lord cannot care for them." [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 9. When Yanzi was the prime minister of Qi, his wife, who was serving as his charioteer, peeked at him through the gate. Her husband, as the prime minister's charioteer, carried a large canopy, rode four horses, and was very proud and self-satisfied. When he returned home, his wife asked to leave. The husband asked why. The wife said, "Yanzi is less than six feet tall, yet he serves as prime minister of Qi and his name is renowned among the feudal lords. Today, I observed him going out; his mind was profound, and he always humbled himself. You, on the other hand, are eight feet tall, yet you are merely a servant, and you seem content with yourself. That is why I wish to leave." Afterwards, the husband became more modest. Yanzi was surprised and asked him why. The charioteer told him the truth. Yanzi recommended him to be a high-ranking official.
[539 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 59 (discursive). Duke Zhao was nineteen years old, still possessing the mind of a child. Mu Shu did not wish to establish him as heir, saying, "If the crown prince dies, there is a younger brother who can succeed him; we should not immediately establish the eldest son. When the ages are equal, we should choose a virtuous person; when the righteousness is equal, we should consult the oracle. Now, this young man is not a legitimate heir, and moreover, during mourning, his mind is not filled with grief but rather with joy. If he is established, he will surely bring worry to the Ji family." Ji Wuzi did not listen and ultimately established him as heir. By the time of the burial, the mourning clothes had been changed three times. A wise man said, "This is not a good end." 59 (discursive). Duke Zhao was nineteen years old, still possessing the mind of a child. Mu Shu did not wish to establish him as heir, saying, "If the crown prince dies, there is a younger brother who can succeed him; we should not immediately establish the eldest son. When the ages are equal, we should choose a virtuous person; when the righteousness is equal, we should consult the oracle. Now, this young man is not a legitimate heir, and moreover, during mourning, his mind is not filled with grief but rather with joy. If he is established, he will surely bring worry to the Ji family." Ji Wuzi did not listen and ultimately established him as heir. By the time of the burial, the mourning clothes had been changed three times. A wise man said, "This is not a good end." [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 13.2. In the sixth year, Duke Hui had many favored concubines and wanted to remove the other ministers to install his favorite concubine, Song, as the new ruler. The ministers conspired to kill Song, and Duke Hui, fearing for his life, fled to Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 120. In the nineteenth year, Qi sent Yan Ying to Jin, where he spoke with Shu Xiang. Shu Xiang said, "Jin is in its declining days. The Duke lavishly taxes the construction of palaces and ponds but neglects the affairs of state. The government is in his private hands. How can this last?" Yan Ying agreed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 14. Ziwo was a member of the Jianzhi clan and had a long-standing feud with the Tian family. Tian Bao, a distant relative of the Tian family, favored Ziwo. Ziwo said, "I wish to exterminate the entire Tian clan and replace them with Bao." Bao replied, "I am estranged from the Tian family." Ziwo refused. Later, Bao told the Tian family, "Ziwo is about to kill the Tian family. If they do not act first, disaster will befall them." Ziwo left the palace, and Tian Chang and his three brothers rode there, intending to kill Ziwo. Ziwo closed the gates. Duke Jian was drinking with women at the Tantai Terrace and was about to attack Tian Chang. The Grand Historian Ziyu said, "Tian Chang does not dare to cause trouble; we are merely eliminating a threat." Duke Jian then stopped. Tian Chang went out and, hearing of Duke Jian's anger, feared execution and attempted to flee. Tian Zixing said, "Xu is a traitor." Tian Chang then attacked Ziwo. Ziwo led his followers to attack the Tian family but was defeated and fled. The Tian family's followers pursued and killed Ziwo and Jianzhi.
[538 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 39.6 (yr 39). In the thirty-ninth year, King Ling of Chu became powerful, convening meetings of the feudal lords at Shen, becoming the leader of the alliance, and killing Qing Feng of Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 60.1. In the third year of Duke Zhao's reign, he went to pay homage to Jin and reached the Yellow River. Duke Ping of Jin declined and returned the gifts, which was a disgrace to Lu. In the fourth year, King Ling of Chu convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Shen, but Duke Zhao claimed illness and did not attend. In the seventh year, Ji Wuzi died. In the eighth year, King Ling of Chu summoned Duke Zhao to Zhanghua Terrace. Duke Zhao went to offer congratulations and was bestowed with precious artifacts; however, he later regretted his decision and fraudulently took them back. In the twelfth year, he went to pay homage to Jin and reached the Yellow River, but Duke Ping of Jin declined and returned the gifts. In the thirteenth year, Prince Qiji of Chu murdered his ruler, King Ling, and succeeded him. In the fifteenth year, he went to pay homage to Jin, but Jin kept him to bury Duke Zhao, which was a disgrace to Lu. In the twentieth year, Duke Jing of Qi finished hunting with Yanzi and then went to Lu to inquire about rites. In the twenty-first year, he went to pay homage to Jin and reached the Yellow River, but Jin declined and returned the gifts. 60.1. In the third year of Duke Zhao's reign, he went to pay homage to Jin and reached the Yellow River. Duke Ping of Jin declined and returned the gifts, which was a disgrace to Lu. In the fourth year, King Ling of Chu convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Shen, but Duke Zhao claimed illness and did not attend. In the seventh year, Ji Wuzi died. In the eighth year, King Ling of Chu summoned Duke Zhao to Zhanghua Terrace. Duke Zhao went to offer congratulations and was bestowed with precious artifacts; however, he later regretted his decision and fraudulently took them back. In the twelfth year, he went to pay homage to Jin and reached the Yellow River, but Duke Ping of Jin declined and returned the gifts. In the thirteenth year, Prince Qiji of Chu murdered his ruler, King Ling, and succeeded him. In the fifteenth year, he went to pay homage to Jin, but Jin kept him to bury Duke Zhao, which was a disgrace to Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 36. In the sixth month of the third year of King Ling's reign, an envoy from Chu informed Jin of his intention to convene a meeting of the feudal lords. All the feudal lords met with Chu at Shen. Wu Ju said, "In the past, King Qi of Xia had the feast at Juntai, King Tang of Shang had the mandate at Jingbo, King Wu of Zhou had the oath at Mengjin, King Cheng had the alliance at Qiyang, King Kang had the court at Fenggong, King Mu had the meeting at Tushan, King Huan of Qi had the army at Zhaoling, and King Wen of Jin had the alliance at Jiantu. What use is Your Majesty's? King Ling said, 'I will use Duke Huan.' At that time, Zichan of Zheng was present. Therefore, Jin, Song, Lu, and Wei did not go. King Ling, having already made the alliance, showed arrogance. Wu Ju said, 'Jie held the meeting at Youreng, and the Min rebelled. Zhou held the meeting at Lishan, and the Eastern Yi rebelled. King You held the alliance at Taishi, and the Rong and Di rebelled. Your Majesty, be cautious to the end!'" [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 15. Duke Jian fled, and the followers of the Tian family pursued and captured him in Xuzhou. Duke Jian said, "If I had followed Yu Yang's advice earlier, I wouldn't be in this predicament." Fearing that Duke Jian would be reinstated and then kill them, the followers of the Tian family killed him. Duke Jian reigned for four years before being killed. Thereupon, Tian Chang installed Duke Jian's younger brother, Ao, as Duke Ping. Upon Duke Ping's ascension to the throne, Tian Chang became his prime minister.
[537 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 39.7 (yr 40; death). Duke Jing died after forty years on the throne, and his son, Duke Ai, succeeded him. Hou Zizhen then returned to Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 16.2 (approx.; meeting dated broadly). In the tenth year, King Ling of Chu convened a meeting of the feudal lords to attack Zhu Fang of Wu and to execute Qing Feng of Qi. Wu also attacked Chu, capturing three cities before withdrawing. In the eleventh year, Chu attacked Wu, reaching Yulou. In the twelfth year, Chu attacked again, encamping at Ganxi, where the Chu army was defeated and fled. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 37. In July, Chu, with the troops of the allied states, attacked Wu and besieged Zhufang. In August, they conquered it, imprisoned Qing Feng, and exterminated his clan. They used Feng as a warning, saying, "We should not do what Qing Feng of Qi did—murder his lord and weaken his orphan—and instead form an alliance with the other ministers!" Feng retorted, "It would be better if Wei, a son of King Gong of Chu, murdered Yuan, the son of his lord's elder brother, and replaced him!" Thereupon, King Ling ordered (Qi) Ji to kill him.
[536 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 121. In the twenty-second year, he attacked Yan. In the twenty-sixth year, Duke Ping died, and his son, Duke Zhao, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 16. After Tian Chang killed Duke Jian, fearing that the other feudal lords would jointly punish him, he returned all the territories that Lu and Wei had seized. He made an alliance with the Jin, Han, Wei, and Zhao clans in the west, and established relations with the Wu and Yue clans in the south. He rewarded those who had rendered meritorious service and was close to the people, so Qi was restored to order.
[535 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 13.3. In the fourth year, Gao Yan of Qi went to Jin and requested permission to jointly attack Yan and capture its ruler.
[534 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 66. In the forty-second year, King Helü of Wu attacked Chu and entered Ying. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 13.4. Duke Ping of Jin agreed and joined Qi in attacking Yan, capturing Duke Hui. 13.5. Duke Hui died in Yan. Duke Dao was enthroned in Yan.
[533 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 38 (discursive). Seven years later, at Zhanghua Terrace, an order was issued to fill the void left by the deceased. 39.1. In the eighth year, he sent Prince Qiji to lead troops to destroy Chen.
[532 BC]
[531 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 17.1 (approx.). In the seventeenth year, King Yuji died, and his younger brother Yumei succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 39.2. In the tenth year, he summoned the Marquis of Cai, got him drunk, and killed him. He then sent Qiji to pacify Cai, and he became the Duke of Chen and Cai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 17. Tian Chang said to Duke Ping of Qi, "Your Majesty should implement the virtues that people desire; I will implement the punishments that people abhor." After five years of this, all the power in Qi was in Tian Chang's hands. Tian Chang then executed Bao, Yan, Jian Zhi, and other powerful members of the Qi royal family, and ceded the area from Anping eastward to Langya to Qi as his fief. This fief was larger than the territory Duke Ping had previously occupied.
[530 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 40. In the eleventh year, King Ling attacked Xu to intimidate Wu. King Ling encamped at Ganxi to await them. The king said, "Qi, Jin, Lu, and Wei all received precious vessels as their fiefdoms, but I alone received none. Now I send an envoy to Zhou to request the tripod as a share; will they give it to me?" Xi Fu replied, "They will give it to Your Majesty! In the past, my ancestor, Xiong Yi, lived in seclusion in the Jing Mountains, dwelling in the wilderness with only wild herbs and wild vegetables, traversing mountains and forests to serve the Son of Heaven, using only a peachwood bow and thorn arrows to serve the king. Qi is Your Majesty's maternal uncle; Jin, Lu, and Wei are Your Majesty's maternal brothers; thus Chu received nothing while they all received. Now Zhou will share the service of Your Majesty with these four states." "I will obey your orders without question. How could I possibly covet the tripod?" King Ling said, "In the past, my great-grandfather and uncle Kunwu promised this house. Now the people of Zheng covet its land and refuse to give it to me. If I ask for it now, will they give it to me?" He replied, "Zhou does not covet the tripod, so how could Zheng covet its land?" King Ling said, "In the past, the feudal lords distanced themselves from me but feared Jin. Now I have great cities of Chen, Cai, and Bugeng, and each of them pays taxes to a thousand chariots. Do the feudal lords fear me?" He replied, "Yes, they do!" King Ling was pleased and said, "Xi Fu is good at speaking of ancient events." [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 19. When Zhao Jingshu died, he had a son named Zhao Yang, who became known as Jianzi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 18. Tian Chang then selected women from the state of Qi who were over seven feet tall to form his harem, numbering in the hundreds. He allowed his guests and servants to freely enter and leave the harem. When Tian Chang died, he had over seventy sons.
[529 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 40.1 (Duke Ai yr 8) (Wikipedia). In the eighth year of Duke Ai's reign, Prince Qiji of Chu murdered King Ling and seized the throne, becoming King Ping. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 17.2. In the second year of King Yumei's reign, Prince Qiji of Chu murdered his ruler, King Ling, and took his place. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 41. In the spring of the twelfth year, King Ling of Chu was so engrossed in the affairs of Ganxi that he could not leave. The people of the state suffered from forced labor. Earlier, King Ling had assembled troops at Shen, killing Chang Shouguo, a minister of Yue, and Guan Qi, a minister of Cai. Guan Qi's son, Cong, had fled to Wu and persuaded the King of Wu to attack Chu. He then used the pretext of Prince Qi Ji to summon Prince Bi from Jin. When they arrived at Cai, they joined forces with the armies of Wu and Yue to attack Cai. Prince Bi was ordered to meet with Qi Ji and form an alliance at Deng. They then entered the capital, killed King Ling's crown prince Lu, and installed Prince Bi as king, Prince Zixi as prime minister, and Qi Ji as military commander. First, the royal palace was cleared. Guan Cong followed the army to Ganxi and announced to the Chu people, "The state now has a king. Those who return first will have their titles, fiefs, fields, and houses restored. Those who follow will be relocated." The Chu people all collapsed, abandoned King Ling, and returned home. 42. When King Ling heard of the death of his son, Crown Prince Lu, he threw himself from his chariot and said, "Is this how people love their sons?" His attendant replied, "Indeed." The king said, "I have killed many sons; how could I not have done this?" The Right Minister said, "Please wait outside the city to hear the people's opinions." The king said, "I cannot offend the people." The Minister said, "Let us enter a large county and request military assistance from the feudal lords." The king said, "They have all rebelled." The Minister said again, "Let us flee to the feudal lords to hear the concerns of the great states." The king said, "Great fortune will not come again; I will only bring shame upon myself." Thereupon, the king boarded a boat intending to enter Yan. The Right Minister, realizing the king would not heed his advice and fearing for their lives, also deserted the king. 43. King Ling then secluded himself in the mountains, and no wild man dared to enter his territory. While traveling, the king encountered his former servant, a man named Xuan, and said, "Find me food; I have not eaten for three days." Xuan replied, "The new king has decreed that anyone who dares to disturb or follow the king will have their entire family punished, and they will also have no food." The king then lay down with his head on Xuan's lap. Xuan then replaced himself with soil and fled. When the king awoke, he could not find Xuan and, due to hunger, could not rise. Shen Hai, son of the local official Shen Wuyu, said, "My father twice violated the king's orders, yet the king did not punish him; what greater kindness could there be!" He then sought out the king and found him starving in a marshland, and took him home. In the fifth month of summer, on the day of Gui Chou, the king died at Shen Hai's house. Shen Hai took his two daughters with him and they were buried together. 44. At that time, although the State of Chu had already established Bi as king, they feared the return of King Ling and had not heard of King Ling's death. Therefore, Guan Cong said to the newly appointed King Bi, "If you do not kill Qi Ji, even if you gain the kingdom, you will still suffer misfortune." The king said, "I cannot bear to." Cong said, "The people will bear to see you suffer." The king did not listen and left. Qi Ji returned home. Every night, the people of the state were alarmed, saying, "King Ling has entered!" On the night of Yi Mao, Qi Ji sent boatmen to run down the river and shout, "King Ling has arrived!" The people of the state were even more alarmed. He also sent Man Chengran to tell the newly appointed King Bi and the Prime Minister Zi Xi, "The king has arrived! The people of the state will kill you, and the Sima will arrive! You should plan ahead to avoid humiliation. The anger of the people is like fire and water, and cannot be saved." The newly appointed King Bi and Zi Xi then committed suicide. On the day of Bing Chen, Qi Ji ascended the throne as king, changed his name to Xiong Ju, and became King Ping. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 19. When Tian Chang died, his sons Xiang and Pan succeeded him and became prime ministers of Qi. Chang was posthumously honored as Chengzi.
[528 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 14.1. Duke Dao died in the seventh year, and Duke Gong succeeded him. Duke Gong died in the fifth year, and Duke Ping succeeded him. The Jin ducal house was weak, and the six ministers began to grow powerful. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 45. King Ping, having fraudulently murdered two kings to establish himself, feared rebellion from his people and the other feudal lords, and thus bestowed favors upon the populace. He restored the lands of Chen and Cai and reinstated their rulers as before, and returned the territories seized by Zheng. He cared for the people and reformed the government and education. Wu, due to the chaos caused by Chu, captured five leaders and brought them back. King Ping told Guan Cong, "Do as you please." He wished to appoint Guan Cong as the Diviner, and the king agreed. 46 (discursive). Initially, King Gong had five favored sons, but no suitable successor could be chosen. He then offered sacrifices to the gods, asking them to decide who should rule the state. Secretly, he and Ba Ji buried a jade disc in a room and summoned the five princes to a fast. King Kang straddled one of them, King Ling elbowed him, and Zi Bi and Zi Xi kept their distance. King Ping was young, so he was held and bowed to, pressed down on him. Therefore, King Kang, being the eldest, succeeded to the throne, but his son lost the throne; Wei became King Ling, but was murdered; Zi Bi reigned for more than ten days, but Zi Xi was not allowed to succeed, and both were executed. All four sons died without heirs. Only Qi Ji succeeded to the throne as King Ping, continuing the Chu sacrifices as divinely ordained. 47 (discursive). Initially, when Zibi returned from Jin, Han Xuanzi asked Shuxiang, "Will Zibi succeed?" Shuxiang replied, "No." Xuanzi said, "Those who share the same evil seek each other out, like merchants in a market. Why won't you go?" Shuxiang replied, "If I have no one to share my good, who will share my evil? There are five difficulties in governing a state: having favor but no one to rely on, that's the first; having people but no leader, that's the second; having a leader but no strategy, that's the third; having strategy but no people, that's the fourth; having people but no virtue, that's the fifth. Zibi has been in Jin for thirteen years, and I haven't heard of any alliances between Jin and Chu. He can be said to have no one to rely on; his clan..." To betray one's own family is tantamount to having no master; to act without provocation is tantamount to having no strategy; to be imprisoned for life is tantamount to having no people; to be executed without regard for love is tantamount to having no virtue. The king is tyrannical and unrestrained; Zibi, embroiled in five difficulties, murdered the king—who can save him? Is there a Chu state, perhaps Qiji? The rulers of Chen and Cai, outside Fangcheng, belong to him. Harshness and evil do not arise, thieves remain hidden, private desires are not violated, and the people have no resentment. The gods ordained him, and the people trust him. When the Mi clan is in turmoil, Ji Shi inevitably rises to power—this is the norm in Chu. If Zibi were to hold office, he would be the Right Minister; counting his... "If one is favored and honored, he is a son of a concubine; if he is appointed by the gods, he is further removed from the throne; if the people have no affection for him, how can he stand?" Xuanzi said, "Were not Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin also like this?" Xuanzi replied, "Duke Huan of Qi was the son of Lady Wei, and he was favored by Duke Li. He had Bao Shuya, Bin Xuwu, and Xi Peng as his advisors, Ju and Wei as his external rulers, and Gao and Guo as his internal rulers. He readily accepted good advice and was tireless in bestowing favors. Was it not fitting that he possessed a state? In the past, Duke Wen of Qi was the son of Lady Hu Ji, and he was favored by Duke Xian. He was fond of learning and never tired of it. He was seventeen years old." In that year, there were five men of noble character: the late Grand Masters Ziyu and Zifan were his trusted advisors; Wei Chou and Jia Tuo were his trusted lieutenants; Qi, Song, Qin, and Chu were his external allies; and Luan, Que, Hu, and Xian were his internal allies. For nineteen years, he remained steadfast in his resolve. Even when Hui and Huai abandoned the people, the people followed them. Therefore, was it not fitting that Duke Wen possessed the state? Zibi, however, had no influence over the people and no external support. When he left Jin, Jin did not send him off; when he returned to Chu, Chu did not welcome him. How could he possess the state? Indeed, Zibi did not last long, and the one who succeeded him was Qiji, just as Shuxiang had said.
[527 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 56.2. In the eighteenth year of King Jing's reign, Crown Prince Sheng died young. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 18. Four years later, King Yumei died and intended to pass the throne to his younger brother, Ji Zha. Ji Zha declined and fled. Then the people of Wu said, "The late king decreed that when an elder brother dies, the younger brother should succeed him, and Ji Zha must be appointed. Now that Ji Zha has fled, King Yumei will succeed him. Now that he has died, his son will succeed him." So they established King Yumei's son, Liao, as king. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 48. In the second year of King Ping's reign, he sent Fei Wuji to Qin to find a wife for Crown Prince Jian. The woman was beautiful and came, but before she arrived, Wuji returned first and said to King Ping, "The Qin woman is beautiful; you can marry her yourself, but find another for the Crown Prince." King Ping listened and ultimately married the Qin woman himself; she gave birth to Xiong Zhen. He then arranged another marriage for the Crown Prince. At that time, Wu She was the Crown Prince's Grand Tutor, and Wuji was his Junior Tutor. Wuji was not favored by the Crown Prince and often slandered Crown Prince Jian. Jian was fifteen years old at the time, and his mother was a woman from Cai. He was not favored by the king, and the king gradually distanced himself from Jian.
[526 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 40.2 (yr 11). In the eleventh year, King Ping of Chu sought a woman from Qin to marry his son, Crown Prince Jian. Upon arriving in Qin, he found the woman attractive and married her himself. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 67. In the forty-seventh year, Lu Yanghu attacked his lord but was defeated. He fled to Qi and requested Qi to attack Lu. Baozi advised Duke Jing against this, and Yanghu was imprisoned. Yanghu escaped and fled to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 122. Duke Zhao died in the sixth year. The six ministers were powerful, while the ducal house was weak. His son, Duke Qing, succeeded him.
[525 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 19. In the second year of King Liao's reign, Prince Guang attacked Chu, but was defeated and lost the king's boat. Fearing for his life, Guang attacked Chu again, recovered the king's boat, and returned. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 60.2. In the twentieth year, Duke Jing of Qi finished hunting with Yanzi and then went to Lu to inquire about rites. In the twenty-first year, he went to pay homage to Jin and reached the Yellow River, but Jin declined and returned the gifts. 60.2. In the twentieth year, Duke Jing of Qi finished hunting with Yanzi and then went to Lu to inquire about rites. In the twenty-first year, he went to pay homage to Jin and reached the Yellow River, but Jin declined and returned the gifts.
[524 BC]
[523 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 56.3. In the twentieth year, King Jing loved his son Chao and wanted to make him king, but he died soon after. His son Gai's faction fought for the throne, and the people of the state elected his eldest son Meng as king. Chao attacked and killed Meng. Meng became King Dao. The people of Jin attacked Chao and installed Gai as king, who became King Jing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 49. In the sixth year, Prince Jian was sent to reside in Chengfu to guard the border. Wuji, day and night, slandered Prince Jian to the king, saying, "Since Wuji married the Qin woman, the prince has harbored resentment and cannot help but hope for the king's favor. The king should be wary. Moreover, the prince resides in Chengfu, commands troops, and engages in diplomatic relations with other lords; he intends to invade." King Ping summoned his tutor, Wu She, and reprimanded him. Wu She, knowing of Wuji's slander, said, "How can Your Majesty treat a lowly official as an enemy of your own flesh and blood?" Wuji replied, "If you do not restrain him now, you will regret it." Therefore, the king imprisoned Wu She. [He then summoned Wu She's two sons and informed them that their father would be spared death.] He then ordered Sima Fenyang to summon Prince Jian, intending to execute him. Upon hearing this, the prince fled to Song.
[522 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 40.3 (yr 15; Wu Zixu flees). In the fifteenth year, King Ping of Chu wanted to execute Jian, but Jian fled; Wu Zixu fled to Wu. The Jin ducal house was weak while its six ministers were powerful, and they intended to fight each other internally, thus preventing a prolonged conflict between Qin and Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 50. Wu Ji said, "Wu She has two sons. If they are not killed, they will become a scourge to Chu. Why not spare their father and summon them? They will surely come." So the king sent a messenger to Wu She, saying, "If you can bring your two sons, you will live; if not, you will die." Wu She said, "Shang will come, but Xu will not." The king asked, "Why?" Wu She said, "Shang is honest, loyal to the death, kind, filial, and benevolent. Hearing the summons, he spares his father and will surely come, regardless of death. Xu is intelligent and scheming, brave and boastful. Knowing that coming will mean certain death, he will not come. However, it is this son who will be a worry for Chu." So the king sent someone to summon them, saying, "Come, and I will spare your father." Wu Shang said to Wu Xu, "Hearing that my father is spared, I did not rush to his aid; I did not report my father's execution; I am without strategy; I have the ability to handle affairs; I am wise. My son, go now, and I will return to die." Wu Shang then returned home. Wu Xu drew his bow and arrow, went out to see the messenger, and said, "My father is guilty; why summon his son?" He was about to shoot when the messenger turned and fled. Wu Shang then fled to Wu. When Wu She heard this, he said, "If Xu is killed, the state of Chu is in danger." The people of Chu then killed Wu She and Shang.
[521 BC]
[520 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 20. Five years later, Wu Zixu, a former minister of Chu, came to seek refuge with King Liao, and Prince Guang treated him as a guest. Prince Guang was the son of King Zhufan. He always thought that his father had four brothers, and the throne should pass to the youngest son. If the youngest son refused the throne, his father would ascend the throne first. Even if the throne did not pass to the youngest son, Guang would ascend the throne. He secretly recruited virtuous men, intending to use them to succeed King Liao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 123. In the sixth year of Duke Qing's reign, King Jing of Zhou died, and the princes vied for the throne. The six ministers of Jin quelled the rebellion in the royal court and installed King Jing as king. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 20. During the reign of Zhao Jianzi, in the ninth year of Duke Qing of Jin, Jianzi planned to unite the feudal lords to garrison Zhou. The following year, he entered Zhou to meet King Jing of Zhou, and sent his disciple to pay homage.
[519 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 57.1. In the first year of King Jing's reign, the people of Jin entered King Jing's territory, but Zi Chao declared himself king, and King Jing was not allowed to enter, so he resided in Ze. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 21. In the eighth year, Prince Guang of Wu attacked Chu, defeated the Chu army, and welcomed the mother of the former Crown Prince Jian of Chu back to Wu from Juchao. He then launched a northern expedition, defeating the armies of Chen and Cai. In the ninth year, Prince Guang attacked Chu again, capturing Juchao and Zhongli. Initially, a maiden from the Chu border town of Beiliang and a maiden from a Wu border town quarreled over mulberry leaves. The two families, enraged, killed each other. The chiefs of the border towns of both states, upon hearing this, were enraged and attacked each other, destroying the Wu border town. The King of Wu was furious, and thus attacked Chu, capturing both of its capitals before leaving.
[518 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 22. When Wu Zixu first fled to Wu, he persuaded King Liao of Wu to consider the benefits of attacking Chu. Prince Guang said, "Zu's father and brother were killed by Chu; he only wants revenge. I see no benefit in it." Therefore, Wu Zixu knew that Guang had other ambitions, so he sought out the brave warrior Zhuan Zhu and presented him to Guang. Guang was pleased and made Wu Zixu a guest. Zixu then retired to the fields to farm, awaiting Zhuan Zhu's request.
[517 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 61. In the spring of the twenty-fifth year, mynas came to their nests. Shi Ji said, "The children's rhyme of the time of Emperor Wencheng was: 'When the mynas come to their nests, you are in Ganhou. When the mynas enter their dwelling place, you are in the outer fields.'" 61. In the spring of the twenty-fifth year, mynas came to their nests. Shi Ji said, "The children's rhyme of the time of Emperor Wencheng was: 'When the mynas come to their nests, you are in Ganhou. When the mynas enter their dwelling place, you are in the outer fields.'" [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 124.1. In the ninth year, the Ji family of Lu expelled their ruler, Duke Zhao, who then resided in Ganhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 21. In the twelfth year of Duke Qing of Jin's reign, the six ministers, in accordance with the law, executed the Qi and Yangshe clans, members of the ducal family, and divided their fiefs into ten counties. Each of the six ministers appointed a member of their clan as a high official. As a result, the Jin ducal house became increasingly weak. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 3. One hundred and sixty-seven years later, Wu had the affair of Zhuan Zhu.
[516 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 57.2. In the fourth year, Jin led the feudal lords to enter King Jing's territory in Zhou, and Zi Chao became a subject, while the feudal lords built a city in Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 23.1. In the winter of the twelfth year, King Ping of Chu died. In the spring of the thirteenth year, Wu, wanting to take advantage of Chu's mourning, sent Prince Gaiyu and Zhuyong with troops to besiege the six and four cities of Chu. Wu also sent Ji Zha to Jin to observe the changes among the feudal lords. Chu dispatched troops to cut off Wu's rear, preventing Wu's troops from returning. Then Prince Guang of Wu said, "This opportunity cannot be missed." He told Zhuan Zhu, "What can we gain if we don't demand it! I am the true heir to the throne and should be enthroned; I want to claim it. Even if Ji Zha arrives, he will not depose me." Zhuan Zhu said, "King Liao can be killed. His mother is old and his son is weak, and the two princes are leading troops to attack Chu, which has cut off their route. Now Wu is besieged by Chu externally and lacks any loyal ministers internally; what can they do to me?" Guang said, "My life is your life." [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 62. The Ji and Hou clans fought, the Ji clan using mustard feathers, the Hou clan using golden spurs. Ji Pingzi, enraged, attacked the Hou clan, and Hou Zhaobo, also enraged by Pingzi. Zang Zhaobo's younger brother, Hui, falsely slandered the Zang clan, hiding members of the Ji clan. Zang Zhaobo imprisoned members of the Ji clan. Ji Pingzi, enraged, imprisoned an elderly member of the Zang clan. The Zang and Hou clans reported their troubles to Duke Zhao. On the day of Wuxu in the ninth month, Duke Zhao attacked the Ji clan and captured them. Pingzi ascended the platform and pleaded, "Your Majesty, because of your slander and failure to investigate my crimes, execute me, and I request to be moved to the Yi River." This was not granted. He requested to be imprisoned in Bi, but this was not granted. He requested to flee with five chariots, but this was not granted. Zi Jiaju said, "Your Majesty should grant this request. The power has been in the hands of the Ji clan for a long time; they have many followers, and they will likely conspire together." This was not listened to. Hou said, "We must kill them." Li, a minister of the Shusun clan, said to his followers, "Which is more advantageous, the Ji clan or the Shusun clan?" They all replied, "Without the Ji clan, there is no Shusun clan." Li said, "Indeed, save the Ji clan!" They then defeated the Duke's army. Meng Yizi, hearing of the Shusun clan's victory, also killed Hou Zhaobo. Hou Zhaobo was the Duke's envoy, so the Meng clan obtained him. The three families jointly attacked the Duke, who fled. On the day of Ji Hai, the Duke arrived in Qi. Duke Jing of Qi said, "Please allow me to present a thousand altars to Your Majesty." Zijia said, "Is it acceptable to abandon the legacy of the Duke of Zhou and become a subject of Qi?" So the matter was dropped. Zijia said, "Duke Jing of Qi is untrustworthy; it would be better to go to Jin sooner." This was not followed. When the Duke returned from his visit, the Shusun clan met Pingzi, who bowed deeply. Initially, they intended to welcome Duke Zhao, but Mengsun and Jisun regretted it and stopped. 62. The Ji and Hou clans fought, the Ji clan using mustard feathers, the Hou clan using golden spurs. Ji Pingzi, enraged, attacked the Hou clan, and Hou Zhaobo, also enraged by Pingzi. Zang Zhaobo's younger brother, Hui, falsely slandered the Zang clan, hiding members of the Ji clan. Zang Zhaobo imprisoned members of the Ji clan. Ji Pingzi, enraged, imprisoned an elderly member of the Zang clan. The Zang and Hou clans reported their troubles to Duke Zhao. On the day of Wuxu in the ninth month, Duke Zhao attacked the Ji clan and captured them. Pingzi ascended the platform and pleaded, "Your Majesty, because of your slander and failure to investigate my crimes, execute me, and I request to be moved to the Yi River." This was not granted. He requested to be imprisoned in Bi, but this was not granted. He requested to flee with five chariots, but this was not granted. Zi Jiaju said, "Your Majesty should grant this request. The power has been in the hands of the Ji clan for a long time; they have many followers, and they will likely conspire together." This was not listened to. Hou said, "We must kill them." Li, a minister of the Shusun clan, said to his followers, "Which is more advantageous, the Ji clan or the Shusun clan?" They all replied, "Without the Ji clan, there is no Shusun clan." Li said, "Indeed, save the Ji clan!" They then defeated the Duke's army. Meng Yizi, hearing of the Shusun clan's victory, also killed Hou Zhaobo. Hou Zhaobo was the Duke's envoy, so the Meng clan obtained him. The three families jointly attacked the Duke, who fled. On the day of Ji Hai, the Duke arrived in Qi. Duke Jing of Qi said, "Please allow me to present a thousand altars to Your Majesty." Zijia said, "Is it acceptable to abandon the legacy of the Duke of Zhou and become a subject of Qi?" So the matter was dropped. Zijia said, "Duke Jing of Qi is untrustworthy; it would be better to go to Jin sooner." This was not followed. When the Duke returned from his visit, the Shusun clan met Pingzi, who bowed deeply. Initially, they intended to welcome Duke Zhao, but Mengsun and Jisun regretted it and stopped. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 52. In the thirteenth year, King Ping died. General Zi Chang said, "Crown Prince Zhen is young, and his mother is the woman the former Crown Prince Jian should have married." He wanted to establish the Prime Minister Zi Xi as the new crown prince. Zi Xi was King Ping's half-brother and was known for his righteousness. Zi Xi said, "The state has established laws. Changing the crown prince would cause chaos, and speaking out would lead to execution." So he established Crown Prince Zhen as the new crown prince, who became King Zhao.
[515 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 23.2. On the day of Bingzi in the fourth month, Guang saw armored soldiers in a cave and went to meet King Liao for a drink. King Liao had his troops arrayed along the road. From the palace to Guang's house, the steps, doors, and mats were all occupied by King Liao's relatives, each carrying a spear. Prince Guang feigned a foot ailment and went into a secluded chamber. He instructed Zhuan Zhu to place a dagger inside a roasted fish before eating. Prince Guang then used the dagger to stab King Liao, the blade striking his chest, and he killed King Liao. Prince Guang then succeeded him as king, becoming King Helü of Wu. Helü then appointed Zhuan Zhu's son as his minister. 24. When Ji Zi arrived, he said, "If our former lord has not neglected his sacrifices, if the people have not neglected their ruler, and if the state has its offerings, then he is our lord. Whom would I dare to complain? I grieve for the dead and serve the living, awaiting Heaven's mandate. It is not that I brought chaos upon myself; whoever establishes the throne should follow, for this is the way of our ancestors." He reported back, wept at the tomb of Liao, and returned to his post to await orders. Wu Gongzi Zhuyong and Gai Yu, leading troops, encountered those besieged by Chu. Hearing that Gongzi Guang had murdered King Liao and established himself as emperor, they surrendered to Chu with their troops, and Chu enfeoffed them in Shu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 63. In the spring of the twenty-sixth year, Qi attacked Lu, captured Yun, and settled Duke Zhao there. In the summer, Duke Jing of Qi was about to bring Duke Zhao into the capital, ordering him not to accept any bribes from Lu. Shen Feng and Ru Jia promised Qi ministers Gao He and Zi Jiang five thousand bushels of grain. Zi Jiang said to Duke Jing of Qi, “The ministers are unable to serve the ruler of Lu; this is strange. Duke Yuan of Song went to Jin to seek refuge with Lu, but died on the way. Shusun Zhao Zi sought refuge with his ruler, but died without illness. Have Heaven abandoned Lu? Or has the ruler of Lu offended the spirits? I urge Your Majesty to wait.” Duke Jing of Qi agreed. 63. In the spring of the twenty-sixth year, Qi attacked Lu, captured Yun, and settled Duke Zhao there. In the summer, Duke Jing of Qi was about to bring Duke Zhao into the capital, ordering him not to accept any bribes from Lu. Shen Feng and Ru Jia promised Qi ministers Gao He and Zi Jiang five thousand bushels of grain. Zi Jiang said to Duke Jing of Qi, “The ministers are unable to serve the ruler of Lu; this is strange. Duke Yuan of Song went to Jin to seek refuge with Lu, but died on the way. Shusun Zhao Zi sought refuge with his ruler, but died without illness. Have Heaven abandoned Lu? Or has the ruler of Lu offended the spirits? I urge Your Majesty to wait.” Duke Jing of Qi agreed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 124.2. In the eleventh year, envoys from Wei and Song requested that Jin accept the ruler of Lu. Ji Pingzi secretly bribed Fan Xianzi, who accepted the bribe and then told the ruler of Jin, "The Ji family is innocent." The request was not fulfilled. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 53. In the first year of King Zhao's reign, the people of Chu disliked Fei Wuji because he had slandered Crown Prince Jian, killed Wu She's son and father, and exiled Wan. The sons of the Bo clan of Wan and Zixu all fled to Wu. Wu's army repeatedly invaded Chu, and the people of Chu deeply resented Wuji. The Chu prime minister, Zichang, executed Wuji to appease the people, who were then pleased. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 4. Zhuan Zhu was a native of Wutangyi. When Wu Zixu fled from Chu to Wu, he knew of Zhuan Zhu's abilities. After Wu Zixu met with King Liao of Wu, he persuaded him of the benefits of attacking Chu. Prince Guang of Wu said, "Wu Zixu's father and brothers all died in Chu, yet he speaks of attacking Chu; he only wants to avenge his personal grudges. He is not capable of serving Wu." King Liao of Wu then stopped. Wu Zixu knew that Prince Guang wanted to kill King Liao of Wu, so he said, "Guang has his own ambitions; we cannot persuade him of external matters." He then introduced Zhuan Zhu to Prince Guang. 5. Prince Guang's father was King Zhufan of Wu. Zhufan had three younger brothers: Yuji, Yimei, and Jizi Zha. Zhufan knew that Jizi Zha was virtuous and did not establish a crown prince, but instead passed the throne to his three younger brothers in order, intending to eventually hand over the kingdom to Jizi Zha. After Zhufan died, the throne passed to Yuji. After Yuji died, the throne passed to Yimei. After Yimei died, the throne should have passed to Jizi Zha; however, Jizi Zha fled and refused to be enthroned, so the people of Wu enthroned Yimei's son, Liao, as king. Prince Guang said, "If it is based on the order of brothers, Jizi should be enthroned; if it is based on a son, then Guang is the rightful heir and should be enthroned." Therefore, he secretly cultivated advisors to seek the throne. 6. After Guang obtained Zhuan Zhu, he treated him well as a guest. Nine years later, King Ping of Chu died. In the spring, King Liao of Wu, wanting to take advantage of Chu's mourning, sent his two younger brothers, Prince Gaiyu and Shuyong, with troops to besiege Qian, the capital of Chu; and sent Yanling Jizi to Jin to observe the changes among the feudal lords. Chu sent troops to cut off the route of Wu generals Gaiyu and Shuyong, and the Wu troops could not return. Thereupon, Prince Guang said to Zhuan Zhu, "This opportunity cannot be missed. What can we gain if we do not seek it? Moreover, I am the true heir to the throne and should be enthroned. Even if Jizi comes, he will not depose me." Zhuan Zhu said, "King Liao can be killed. His mother is old and his son is weak, and his two younger brothers are leading troops to attack Chu, cutting off their rear. Now Wu is besieged by Chu from the outside, and internally lacks any upright ministers. There is nothing they can do to me." Prince Guang bowed his head and said, "My life is your life."
[514 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 25. In the first year of King Helu's reign, Wu Zixu was appointed as a messenger to advise on state affairs. After the execution of Bo Zhouli by Chu, his grandson Bo Pi fled to Wu, where he was appointed as a high official. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 64.1. In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Zhao of Jin asked to enter. Ji Pingzi privately stayed with the six ministers of Jin. The six ministers were bribed by the Ji clan to advise the king of Jin. In the twenty-ninth year, Duke Zhao was like a fool. The envoy of Duke Jing of Qi gave him a letter to Duke Zhao, calling himself "the lord". The Duke of Zhao was ashamed of it, and went to Qian Hou in anger. In the thirty-first year, Jin wanted to Nei Zhaogong and summoned Ji Pingzi. Pingzi's cloth clothes are slippery, and he is apologizing for his sins by the Sixth Minister. The six ministers said, "The Jin wants to be the Duke of Zhao, but the people do not obey." The people of Jin stopped. In the 32nd year, Duke Zhao died at the end of Qianhou. The people of Lu jointly established Song, the younger brother of Zhao Gong, as their king, which was Ding Gong. 64.1. In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Zhao of Jin asked to enter. Ji Pingzi privately stayed with the six ministers of Jin. The six ministers were bribed by the Ji clan to advise the king of Jin. In the twenty-ninth year, Duke Zhao was like a fool. The envoy of Duke Jing of Qi gave him a letter to Duke Zhao, calling himself "the lord". The Duke of Zhao was ashamed of it, and went to Qian Hou in anger. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 125. In the twelfth year, Qi Xisun, grandson of the Jin royal family, and Shu Xiang's son, became enemies of the ruler. The six ministers, wanting to weaken the ducal house, then used the law to exterminate his entire clan. They divided his fief into ten counties, appointing the sons of each as high officials. Jin became even weaker, and the six ministers grew powerful. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 6.2. In the fourteenth year of Duke Ping of Jin, Wu Jizha was sent as an envoy to Jin, saying, "The government of Jin has finally fallen into the hands of Han, Wei, and Zhao." In the twelfth year of Duke Qing of Jin, Han Xuanzi, along with Zhao and Wei, divided ten counties belonging to the Qi and Yangshe clans. In the fifteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Xuanzi and Zhao Jianzi invaded and attacked the Fan and Zhonghang clans. Xuanzi died, and his son Zhenzi succeeded him. Zhenzi moved to Pingyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 7. On the day of Bingzi in the fourth month, Prince Guang, armed with armored soldiers, hid in a cave and prepared wine to invite King Liao. King Liao had his soldiers arrayed from the palace to Guang's house, with all of them being his relatives, standing guard on either side of the gates and steps. They all held long spears. When the wine was flowing freely, Prince Guang feigned a foot ailment and went into the cave. He instructed Zhuan Zhu to place a dagger inside a roasted fish and present it to the king. Upon reaching the king, Zhuan Zhu cut open the fish and then stabbed King Liao with the dagger, killing him instantly. The king's attendants also killed Zhuan Zhu, and the royal court was thrown into chaos. Prince Guang then unleashed his hidden armored soldiers to attack King Liao's followers, annihilating them all. He then proclaimed himself king, becoming King Helü. Helü then appointed Zhuan Zhu's son as a high minister.
[513 BC]
[512 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 26.1. In the third year, King Helü of Wu, along with Zixu and Bo Pi, led troops to attack Chu, capturing Shu and killing two princes who had fled Wu. Guang planned to enter Ying, but General Sun Wu said, "The people are weary; it is not advisable yet. We must wait." In the fourth year, they attacked Chu and captured Liuyu. In the fifth year, they attacked Yue and defeated them. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 64.2. In the thirty-first year, Jin wanted to Nei Zhaogong and summoned Ji Pingzi. Pingzi's cloth clothes are slippery, and he is apologizing for his sins by the Sixth Minister. The six ministers said, "The Jin wants to be the Duke of Zhao, but the people do not obey." The people of Jin stopped. In the 32nd year, Duke Zhao died at the end of Qianhou. The people of Lu jointly established Song, the younger brother of Zhao Gong, as their king, which was Ding Gong. 64.2. In the thirty-first year, Jin wanted to Nei Zhaogong and summoned Ji Pingzi. Pingzi's cloth clothes are slippery, and he is apologizing for his sins by the Sixth Minister. The six ministers said, "The Jin wants to be the Duke of Zhao, but the people do not obey." The people of Jin stopped. In the 32nd year, Duke Zhao died at the end of Qianhou. The people of Lu jointly established Song, the younger brother of Zhao Gong, as their king, which was Ding Gong. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 126.1. In the fourteenth year, Duke Qing died, and his son, Duke Ding, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 51. Ten years later, the mother of Crown Prince Jian of Chu was in Juchao, and Wu opened up the territory. Wu sent Prince Guang to attack Chu, who defeated Chen and Cai, and captured Crown Prince Jian's mother. Chu was terrified and besieged Ying. Earlier, a dispute arose between children in the border town of Beiliang of Wu and the border town of Zhongli of Chu over mulberry leaves. The two families became enraged and attacked each other, wiping out the people of Beiliang. The officials of Beiliang were furious and sent their troops to attack Zhongli. The King of Chu, upon hearing this, was enraged and sent his army to destroy Beiliang. The King of Wu, upon hearing this, was also furious and sent his troops, sending Prince Guang to attack Chu through the home of Crown Prince Jian's mother. Zhongli and Juchao were destroyed. Chu, terrified, besieged Ying. 54.1. In the fourth year, the third son of Wu fled to Chu, and Chu enfeoffed him to defend Wu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 1.1. Sun Tzu, a man of Qi, presented his military strategies to King Helü of Wu. Helü said, "I have read all thirteen chapters of your works. May I test your military skills on you?" Sun Tzu replied, "Yes." Helü asked, "May I test them with women?" Sun Tzu said, "Yes." He granted his request and brought out 180 beautiful women from the palace. Sun Tzu divided them into two teams, appointing two of the king's favorite concubines as captains, each carrying a halberd. He instructed them, "Do you know the difference between your heart and the back of your left and right hands?" The women replied, "Yes." Sun Tzu said, "Forward, look at your heart; left, look at your left hand; right, look at your right hand; backward, look at your back." The women replied, "Yes." Once the rules were established, the axes and halberds were set up, and the commands were repeatedly emphasized. Then the drum was sounded on the right, and the women laughed loudly. Sun Tzu said, "The rules are unclear, and the commands are not well understood; this is the general's fault." He repeated the commands three times and sounded the drum on the left, and the women laughed loudly again. Sun Tzu said, "If the rules are unclear and the orders are not well understood, it is the general's fault; if the rules are clear but the soldiers do not follow them, it is the officers' and soldiers' fault." He then intended to execute the two captains. King Helü of Wu, watching from the platform, was greatly alarmed to see his beloved concubines about to be executed. He quickly sent a messenger down to order, "I already know that the general is capable in warfare. Without these two concubines, I cannot enjoy my food. Please do not execute them." Sun Tzu said, "Since I have already been appointed general, a general in the army may disobey the king's orders." He then executed the two captains as a warning. He appointed the next in command, and then the drums were beaten again. The women, on all sides, kneeling and rising, all conformed to the rules and regulations, and dared not utter a sound. Sun Tzu then sent a messenger to report to the king, "The troops are now well-organized. Your Majesty may come down and observe them. They are ready to serve you as you wish, even if it means facing fire and water." King Helü said, "General, please rest and return to your quarters. I do not wish to come down and observe." Sun Tzu said, "Your Majesty merely admires your words but cannot put them into practice." Thus, King Helü realized Sun Tzu's military prowess and ultimately appointed him as general.
[511 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 54.2. In the fifth year, Wu attacked and captured Liu and Qian from Chu.
[510 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 65 (discursive). When Duke Ding was established, Zhao Jianzi asked Shi Mo, "Has the Ji family perished?" Shi Mo replied, "No. Ji You made great contributions to Lu, receiving the position of Shangqing (high minister) from Bi. His descendants, Wenzi and Wuzi, continued to increase their achievements. When Duke Wen of Lu died, Dongmen Sui killed the legitimate heir and installed a concubine's son. As a result, the ruler of Lu lost control of the state. The government was in the hands of the Ji family, and there have been four rulers to date. The people do not know their ruler, so how can they maintain the state? Therefore, a ruler should be careful with his position and title, and should not entrust them to others." 65 (discursive). When Duke Ding was established, Zhao Jianzi asked Shi Mo, "Has the Ji family perished?" Shi Mo replied, "No. Ji You made great contributions to Lu, receiving the position of Shangqing (high minister) from Bi. His descendants, Wenzi and Wuzi, continued to increase their achievements. When Duke Wen of Lu died, Dongmen Sui killed the legitimate heir and installed a concubine's son. As a result, the ruler of Lu lost control of the state. The government was in the hands of the Ji family, and there have been four rulers to date. The people do not know their ruler, so how can they maintain the state? Therefore, a ruler should be careful with his position and title, and should not entrust them to others."
[509 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 26.2. In the sixth year, Chu sent Zichang Nangwa to attack Wu. They met them and attacked, inflicting a great defeat on the Chu army at Yuzhang, capturing Juchao, and returning. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 54.3. In the seventh year, Chu sent Zi Chang to attack Wu, and Wu defeated Chu in Yuzhang.
[508 BC]
[507 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 66. In the fifth year of Duke Ding's reign, Ji Pingzi died. Yang Hu, harboring a private grudge, imprisoned Ji Huanzi, made an alliance with him, and then released him. In the seventh year, Qi attacked Lu and captured Yun, making it Yang Hu's fief in Lu for his administration. In the eighth year, Yang Hu wanted to kill all the members of the Three Huan families and install his favorite son as their successor; Ji Huanzi was about to kill him, but Huanzi escaped by deception. The Three Huan families jointly attacked Yang Hu, who then resided at Yangguan. In the ninth year, Lu attacked Yang Hu, who fled to Qi, and later to the Zhao family of Jin. 66. In the fifth year of Duke Ding's reign, Ji Pingzi died. Yang Hu, harboring a private grudge, imprisoned Ji Huanzi, made an alliance with him, and then released him. In the seventh year, Qi attacked Lu and captured Yun, making it Yang Hu's fief in Lu for his administration. In the eighth year, Yang Hu wanted to kill all the members of the Three Huan families and install his favorite son as their successor; Ji Huanzi was about to kill him, but Huanzi escaped by deception. The Three Huan families jointly attacked Yang Hu, who then resided at Yangguan. In the ninth year, Lu attacked Yang Hu, who fled to Qi, and later to the Zhao family of Jin.
[506 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 40.4 (yr 31; Wu takes Ying). In the thirty-first year, King Helü of Wu and Wu Zixu attacked Chu. The King of Chu fled to Sui, and Wu then entered Ying. The Chu official Shen Baoxu came to report the emergency, having gone without food for seven days and weeping day and night. Qin then dispatched five hundred chariots to rescue Chu, defeating the Wu army. With the Wu army retreating, King Zhao of Chu was able to re-enter Ying. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 27. In the ninth year, King Helü of Wu consulted Wu Zixu and Sun Wu, saying, "You initially advised against entering Ying; what has become of you?" The two replied, "The Chu general Zichang is greedy, and both Tang and Cai resent him. If Your Majesty wishes to launch a major campaign, you must first capture Tang and Cai." Helü agreed, mobilizing his entire army and, together with Tang and Cai, marching west to attack Chu, reaching the Han River. Chu also dispatched troops to resist Wu, arraying themselves along the river. King Helü's brother, Fu, wanted to fight, but Helü refused. Fu said, "Your Majesty has already entrusted my troops; military action is based on profit. What are we waiting for?" He then led his 5,000 men in a surprise attack on Chu, inflicting a great defeat on the Chu army, which fled. King Helü then launched a full-scale pursuit. By the time they reached Ying, Chu had been defeated in five battles. King Zhao of Chu fled Ying to Yun. The younger brother of the Duke of Yun plotted to assassinate King Zhao, and King Zhao and the Duke of Yun fled with him. The Wu army then entered Ying. Wu Zixu and Bo Pi whipped the corpse of King Ping to avenge their father's death. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 14.2. In the eighteenth year of Duke Ping's reign, King Helü of Wu defeated Chu and entered Ying. He died in the nineteenth year, and Duke Jian succeeded him. Duke Jian died in the twelfth year, and Duke Xian succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 55. In the winter of the tenth year, King Helü of Wu, along with Wu Zixu, Bo Yutang, and Cai, attacked Chu. Chu suffered a great defeat, and the Wu army entered Ying, desecrating the tomb of King Ping because of Wu Zixu. When the Wu army arrived, Chu sent Zichang to meet them with troops, forming an array along the Han River. Wu defeated Zichang, who fled to Zheng. The Chu army retreated, and Wu pursued them in victory, fighting five battles to reach Ying. On the day of Ji-mao, King Zhao fled. On the day of Geng-chen, the Wu army entered Ying. 56. King Zhao fled to Yunmeng. The people of Yunmeng, unaware of his identity, shot and wounded him. The king fled to Yun. The younger brother of the Duke of Yun, Huai, said, "King Ping killed my father; now I will kill his son. Is this not acceptable?" The Duke of Yun stopped him, but fearing he might murder King Zhao, he fled with the king to Sui. When the King of Wu heard that King Zhao had gone, he immediately attacked Sui, saying to the people of Sui, "The descendants of Zhou who are enfeoffed in the area between the Yangtze and Han rivers will all be destroyed by Chu." He intended to kill King Zhao. The king's minister, Zi Qi, secretly hid the king, pretending to be king, and said to the people of Sui, "Give me to Wu." The people of Sui consulted the oracle and received an inauspicious result, so they apologized to the King of Wu, saying, "King Zhao has fled and is not in Sui." Wu requested permission to enter and retrieve him themselves, but Sui refused, and Wu withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 1.2.
