He defeated the powerful state of Chu in the west, entered Ying, and intimidated Qi and Jin in the north, making his name known among the feudal lords. Sun Tzu played a significant role in this.
[505 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 28.1. In the spring of the tenth year, Yue heard that the King of Wu was in Ying and that the kingdom was empty, so Yue attacked Wu. Wu sent a separate army to attack Yue. Chu urgently appealed to Qin, and Qin sent troops to aid Chu and attack Wu, and the Wu army was defeated. Helü's brother, Fu, seeing that Qin and Yue had defeated Wu and that the King of Wu was staying in Chu, fled back to Wu and declared himself King of Wu. Helü heard of this and led his army back to attack Fu. Fu was defeated and fled to Chu. King Zhao of Chu was then able to re-enter Ying in the ninth month and enfeoffed Fu Gai at Tangxi, making him the Tangxi clan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 67. In the tenth year, Duke Ding met with Duke Jing of Qi at Jiagu, where Confucius acted as his advisor. Qi intended to attack the ruler of Lu, but Confucius, with proper etiquette, ascended the steps and condemned Qi's debauchery. The Duke of Qi, fearing for his life, stopped the attack, returned the territory he had seized from Lu, and apologized. In the twelfth year, Confucius sent Zhong You to destroy the cities of the Three Huan families and seize their armor and weapons. The Meng family refused to breach the city walls, so Confucius attacked them, but failed and stopped. Ji Huanzi accepted female musicians from Qi, and Confucius departed. 67. In the tenth year, Duke Ding met with Duke Jing of Qi at Jiagu, where Confucius acted as his advisor. Qi intended to attack the ruler of Lu, but Confucius, with proper etiquette, ascended the steps and condemned Qi's debauchery. The Duke of Qi, fearing for his life, stopped the attack, returned the territory he had seized from Lu, and apologized. In the twelfth year, Confucius sent Zhong You to destroy the cities of the Three Huan families and seize their armor and weapons. The Meng family refused to breach the city walls, so Confucius attacked them, but failed and stopped. Ji Huanzi accepted female musicians from Qi, and Confucius departed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 57. When King Zhao of Chu fled Ying, he sent Shen Baoxu to request aid from Qin. Qin sent 500 chariots to aid Chu, and Chu also gathered its remaining scattered troops to join Qin in attacking Wu. In the sixth month of the eleventh year, they defeated Wu at Ji. Meanwhile, King Helü's younger brother, Fu Gai, seeing the Wu army wounded and defeated, fled back and declared himself king. King Helü, upon hearing this, led his army away from Chu and returned to attack Fu Gai. Fu Gai was defeated and fled to Chu, where he was enfeoffed at Tangxi and given the title Tangxi. 58.1. King Zhao of Chu destroyed Tang in the ninth month and returned to Ying.
[504 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 57.3. In the sixteenth year, Zi Chao's followers rebelled again, and King Jing fled to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 28.2. In the eleventh year, the King of Wu sent his crown prince, Fuchai, to attack Chu and capture Fan. Chu, fearing this, abandoned Ying and moved to Ruo. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 58.2. In the twelfth year, Wu attacked Chu again and captured Fan. Chu was afraid, so it abandoned Ying and moved its capital north to Ruo. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 22. Thirteen years later, Yang Hu, a treacherous minister from Lu, came to Zhao Jianzi, who accepted bribes and treated him generously.
[503 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 57.4. In the seventeenth year, Duke Ding of Jin then entered King Jing's territory in Zhou.
[502 BC]
[501 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 40.5 (yr 36; death). Duke Ai reigned for thirty-six years before dying. His son, Prince Yi, died young and could not succeed him; instead, Prince Yi's son became Duke Hui. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 126.2. In the eleventh year of Duke Ding's reign, Lu Yanghu fled to Jin, but Zhao Yang Jianzi spared his life.
[500 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 41.1 (Duke Hui I yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Hui's reign, Confucius served as the prime minister of Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 29 (approx.). In the fifteenth year, Confucius served as prime minister of Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 68. In the forty-eighth year, Confucius met with Duke Ding of Lu at Jiagu. Li Chu said, "Confucius is knowledgeable in propriety but timid. Let us order the people of Lai to perform music, and then seize the Duke of Lu; we can achieve our goals." Duke Jing, fearing Confucius's potential to become the prime minister of Lu and thus fearing his hegemony, followed Li Chu's plan. During the meeting, Lai music was served. Confucius went up the steps, and the officials seized a Lai man and executed him, showing courtesy to Duke Jing. Duke Jing was ashamed, returned the territory he had seized from Lu as an apology, and then withdrew. That same year, Yan Ying died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 68. In the fifteenth year, Duke Ding died, and his son was about to ascend the throne, becoming Duke Ai. 68. In the fifteenth year, Duke Ding died, and his son was about to ascend the throne, becoming Duke Ai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 126.3. In the twelfth year, Confucius became the prime minister of Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 59.1. In the sixteenth year, Confucius served as prime minister of Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 1.1 (legendary ancestry / long-range). King Goujian of Yue was a descendant of Yu the Great and a son of Shao Kang, the emperor of the Xia Dynasty. He was enfeoffed at Kuaiji to uphold the ancestral sacrifices to Yu the Great. He tattooed his body, cut his hair short, and lived a simple life amidst the wild grasses. More than twenty generations later, his descendants reached Yunchang.
[499 BC]
[498 BC]
[497 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 14.3. Zhao Yang of Jin besieged Fan and Zhonghang in Chaoge. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 127.1. In the fifteenth year, Zhao Yang sent Wu, a high-ranking official in Handan, but Wu did not trust him and wanted to kill him. Wu, along with Zhonghang Yin and Fan Jishe, personally attacked Zhao Yang, who fled to Jinyang. Duke Ding besieged Jinyang. 127.2. Xun Li, Han Buxin, and Wei Chi, who were enemies of Fan and Zhonghang, moved their troops to attack them. Fan and Zhonghang rebelled, but the Duke of Jin attacked them and defeated them. Fan and Zhonghang fled to Chaoge and were rescued. Han and Wei apologized to the Duke of Jin on Zhao Yang's behalf, and Zhao Yang was pardoned and reinstated. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 23. Zhao Jianzi fell ill and remained unconscious for five days, causing great fear among the officials. The physician Bian Que examined him and, upon leaving, inquired of Dong Anyu. Bian Que said, "Your blood and qi are flowing smoothly; what is so strange about that! In the past, Duke Mu of Qin experienced something similar, and awoke after seven days. On the day he awoke, he told Gongsun Zhi and Ziyu, 'I am very happy at the Emperor's place. The reason I lingered there is that I have learned something. The Emperor told me: "The state of Jin will be in great chaos, and its people will be uneasy for five generations; after that, it will become a hegemon, but will die before old age; the son of the hegemon will be powerful, and there will be no distinction between men and women in the state.' Gongsun Zhi wrote this down and hid it, and thus the Qin prophecy was revealed. The chaos of Duke Xian, the hegemony of Duke Wen, and Duke Xiang's defeat of the Qin army at Xiao followed by his debauchery—these are things you have heard. Now, Your Majesty's illness is similar; within three days, your illness will surely subside, and when you do, you will surely have something to say." 24. Two and a half days later, Jianzi awoke. He said to his minister, “I was very happy in the Emperor’s palace, roaming with the hundred gods in the heavens. The music was magnificent, with nine melodies and ten thousand dances, unlike the music of the Three Dynasties. Its sound moved people’s hearts. A bear came to my aid, and the Emperor ordered me to shoot it. I hit the bear, and it died. Then a bear came, and I shot it again. I hit the bear, and it died. The Emperor was very pleased and gave me two baskets, each with a saddlebag. I saw my son beside the Emperor, and he gave me a pheasant dog, saying, ‘When your son grows up, I will give this to you.’ The Emperor told me, ‘The state of Jin is about to decline and perish after seven generations. The Ying clan will greatly defeat the Zhou people west of Fan Kui, but they will not be able to take it. Now I think of the merits of Yu Shun, and I will marry my daughter Meng Yao to my seventh-generation descendant.’” Dong Anyu received the words and wrote them down. He told Jianzi about Bian Que’s words, and Jianzi gave Bian Que 40,000 mu of land. 25. Another day, when Jianzi went out, a man blocked his way. He tried to get past him, but the man wouldn't leave. His followers were angry and were about to kill him. The man blocking the way said, "I wish to have an audience with my lord." His followers told him. Jianzi summoned him and said, "Alas, I have someone to see Zizhen." The man blocking the way said, "Dismiss your attendants, I wish to have an audience." Jianzi dismissed his attendants. The official said, "When the lord fell ill, I was by the emperor's side." Jianzi said, "Indeed, that is so. Why did you see me?" The official said, "The emperor ordered the lord to shoot a bear and a brown bear, both of which died." Jianzi said, "Yes, and why?" The official said, "The state of Jin is about to face a great calamity, and the lord is the first to take the lead. The emperor ordered the lord to exterminate two ministers, for the bear and brown bear are their ancestors." Jianzi said, "The emperor gave me two baskets, each with a counterpart. Why?" The official said, "The lord's son will conquer the two states of Di, both of whom are of the Zi surname." Jianzi said, "I saw you by the emperor's side, and the emperor gave me a Di dog, saying, 'When you grow up, I will give it to you.' Why did you say you were given a Di dog?" The official said, "You are the lord's son. The Di dog is the ancestor of the Di. The lord's son will surely succeed him. And when the lord's descendants arrive, they will reform the government, adopt the Hu clothing, and annex the two states of Di." Jianzi asked his surname and then introduced him to his official position. The official in charge said, "I am a commoner, merely conveying the Emperor's command." He then disappeared. The book of Jianzi was stored in the imperial archives. 26.1. Jianzi then told his sons, "I have hidden a precious talisman on Mount Changshan; whoever finds it first will be rewarded." 26.2. The sons rushed to Mount Changshan, searched, but found nothing. Wuxu returned, saying, "I have obtained the talisman." Jianzi said, "Report it to me." Wuxu said, "Go down Mount Changshan to Dai; Dai can be taken." 26.3. Jianzi then realized that Wuxu was indeed virtuous, and thus deposed Crown Prince Bolu and made Wuxu the Crown Prince. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 6.3. In the fourteenth year of Duke Ping of Jin, Wu Jizha was sent as an envoy to Jin, saying, "The government of Jin has finally fallen into the hands of Han, Wei, and Zhao." In the twelfth year of Duke Qing of Jin, Han Xuanzi, along with Zhao and Wei, divided ten counties belonging to the Qi and Yangshe clans. In the fifteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Xuanzi and Zhao Jianzi invaded and attacked the Fan and Zhonghang clans. Xuanzi died, and his son Zhenzi succeeded him. Zhenzi moved to Pingyang.
[496 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 41.2 (yr 5). In the fifth year, the Jin ministers Zhonghang and Fan rebelled against Jin. Jin sent the Zhi clan and Zhao Jianzi to attack them, and the Fan and Zhonghang clans fled to Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 30.1. In the summer of the nineteenth year, Wu attacked Yue, and King Goujian of Yue met them at Zuili. Yue sent a group of warriors to challenge the Wu army, who went to the Wu army three times, shouted, and then committed suicide. The Wu army witnessed this, and Yue then attacked Wu, defeating them at Gusu, wounding King Helu of Wu's finger, and forcing the army to retreat seven li. King Helu died from his wound. Helu then installed Prince Fuchai as crown prince and said to him, "Have you forgotten that Goujian killed your father?" Fuchai replied, "I dare not!" [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 59.2. In the twentieth year, Chu destroyed Dun and Hu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 1.2. During Yunchang's reign, he fought against King Helu of Wu, and the two sides harbored resentment and attacked each other. After Yunchang's death, his son Goujian ascended the throne, becoming King of Yue. 2. In the first year of his reign, King Helü of Wu, upon hearing of Yunchang's death, raised an army to attack Yue. King Goujian of Yue sent his elite warriors to challenge Yue. After three rounds of battle, they reached the Wu camp, where Goujian shouted and then committed suicide. The Wu army witnessed this, and Yue seized the opportunity to launch a surprise attack. The Wu army was defeated at Zuili, and King Helü was wounded by arrows. As Helü lay dying, he told his son Fuchai, "Never forget Yue." [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 27. Two years later, in the fourteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, the Fan and Zhonghang clans rebelled. The following spring, Jianzi said to Wu, a high-ranking official in Handan, "Give me five hundred households of guards, and I will place them in Jinyang." Wu agreed, but upon returning, his father and brothers refused and went back on their word. Zhao Yang arrested Wu and imprisoned him in Jinyang. He then told the people of Handan, "I have a private plan to kill Wu; who do you want to replace him?" He then killed Wu. Zhao Ji and She Bin rebelled in Handan. The Duke of Jin sent Ji Qin to besiege Handan. Xun Yin and Fan Jishe, who were on good terms with Wu, refused to aid Qin and plotted a rebellion, which Dong Anyu learned of. In October, the Fan and Zhonghang clans attacked Zhao Yang, who fled to Jinyang, where the Jin people besieged him. Wei Xiang and others, enemies of Fan Jishe and Xun Yin, plotted to expel Xun Yin and replace him with Liang Yingfu; and to expel Jishe and replace him with Fan Gaoyi. Xun Li said to Duke Wen of Jin, "The ruler commands his ministers that the instigator of rebellion should be executed. Now, three ministers started the rebellion, yet only Zhao Yang is expelled; this is an unfair application of punishment. I request that all of them be expelled." In November, Xun Li, Han Bu Ning, and Wei Duo, acting on the Duke's orders, attacked the Fan and Zhonghang clans, but failed. The Fan and Zhonghang clans then rebelled against the Duke, who defeated them, and the Fan and Zhonghang clans fled. On the day of Dingwei, the two sons fled to Chaoge. Han and Wei petitioned on behalf of the Zhao clan. On the day of Xinwei in December, Zhao Yang entered Jiang and made an alliance at the Duke's palace. The following year, Zhi Bo Wenzi said to Zhao Yang, "Although Fan and Zhonghang are indeed instigating rebellion, An Yu instigated it, which means An Yu conspired with them. The law of Jin states that the instigator of rebellion should be executed. These two have already confessed their crimes, yet An Yu alone remains." Zhao Yang was troubled. An Yu said, "If I die, the Zhao clan will be settled, and the state of Jin will be at peace. My death is too late." He then committed suicide. The Zhao clan informed Zhi Bo, and only then did the Zhao clan find peace.
[495 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 31.1. In the first year of King Fuchai's reign, he appointed the Grand Minister Bo Pi as Grand Steward. Bo Pi was skilled in warfare and archery, and always aspired to avenge Yue. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 59.3. In the twenty-first year, King Helü of Wu attacked Yue. King Goujian of Yue shot and wounded King Wu, who then died. Wu thus harbored resentment towards Yue and did not launch a westward attack on Chu.
[494 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 31.2. In the second year, the King of Wu mobilized his elite troops to attack Yue, defeating them at Fujiao, thus avenging Yue at Gusu. King Goujian of Yue then stationed 5,000 armored soldiers at Kuaiji, and sent the Grand Minister Zhong to negotiate peace through the Grand Steward Bo Pi, requesting to surrender his kingdom as a vassal state. King Wu was about to grant the offer when Wu Zixu advised, "In the past, the Guo clan killed Zhenguan to attack Zhenxun, destroying Emperor Xiang of the Xia dynasty. Emperor Xiang's wife, Hou Min, was pregnant and fled to Youreng, where she gave birth to Shao Kang. Shao Kang became the governor of Youreng. Guo then wanted to kill Shao Kang, who fled to Youyu. Youyu admired the virtues of the Xia dynasty, so they married two of their daughters to Guo and granted him a fief in Lun, giving him a cheng of land and a lv of people. Later, they gathered the Xia people, pacified their officials, and sent someone to lure them away. Thus, they destroyed the Guo clan, restored the achievements of Yu, and worshipped the Xia dynasty to match Heaven, without losing the old artifacts. Now, Wu is not as strong as Guo, and Goujian is greater than Shao Kang. If we do not destroy them now, but instead intend to be lenient with them, is it not difficult? Moreover, Goujian is a man of hardship; if we do not destroy him now, we will surely regret it later." King Wu did not listen but listened to the Grand Minister Pi, and in the end, he granted Yue peace, made an alliance, and withdrew his troops. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 28. Confucius, upon hearing that Zhao Jianzi had not invited the Duke of Jin but instead seized Wu of Handan and secured Jinyang, recorded in the Spring and Autumn Annals, "Zhao Yang rebelled in Jinyang." Zhao Jianzi had a minister named Zhou She, who was fond of offering direct advice. After Zhou She's death, Jianzi was often displeased whenever he attended court, and the officials pleaded for his punishment. Jianzi said, "The officials are not guilty. I have heard that the skin of a thousand sheeps is not as valuable as the armpit of a single fox. When the officials attend court, all I hear are 'yes' and 'yes,' but I do not hear Zhou She's 'earnest words,' and that is why I am worried." From this, Jianzi was able to maintain his allegiance to the Zhao state while also winning the hearts of the Jin people.
[493 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 30.2. Three years later, Yue reported back. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 3.1 (text says “three years later”). Three years later, Goujian heard that King Fuchai of Wu was preparing his troops day and night to retaliate against Yue, and that Yue wanted to attack Wu before it could even begin. Fan Li advised against this, saying, "No. I have heard that weapons are instruments of misfortune, war is against virtue, and contention is the last resort. To plot against virtue, to use weapons of misfortune, and to test oneself in such a perilous endeavor—God forbids such actions, and those who do so will suffer misfortune." King Goujian said, "I have already made my decision," and thus raised an army. 3.2. King Fuchai of Wu, upon hearing this, dispatched all his elite troops to attack Yue, defeating them at Fujiao. King Goujian then took his remaining 5,000 troops and fled to Kuaiji. King Fuchai of Wu pursued and besieged them. 4.1. The King of Yue said to Fan Li, "Because I did not listen to you, I have come to this. What should I do?" Fan Li replied, "Those who are full of pride should give to Heaven; those who are about to collapse should give to man; those who are frugal should give to the land. Offer them humble words and generous gifts. If they refuse, then offer yourself in the market." Goujian said, "Agreed." He then ordered his minister Zhong to make peace with Wu. Zhong knelt and bowed, saying, "Your Majesty, your subject Goujian, has sent your servant Zhong to inform you: Goujian requests to be your subject, and your wife to be your concubine." The King of Wu was about to grant his request. Wu Zixu said to the King of Wu, "Heaven has bestowed Yue upon Wu; do not grant this request." Zhong returned and reported to Goujian. Goujian wanted to kill his wife and children, burn his treasures, and fight to the death. Zhong stopped Goujian, saying, "The Grand Minister of Wu, Pi, is greedy. He can be lured with benefits. Please speak to him privately." So Goujian had Zhong present beautiful women and treasures to the Grand Minister of Wu, Pi. Pi accepted them and then met with Zhong to the King of Wu. Zhong bowed deeply and said, "I beseech Your Majesty to pardon Goujian's crimes and confiscate all his treasures. If you do not pardon him, Goujian will kill all his wives and children, burn his treasures, and lead five thousand men into battle. He will surely prevail." 4.2. Pi then persuaded the King of Wu, saying, "Yue has submitted to us as a vassal state. If you pardon them, it will benefit the country." The King of Wu was about to agree. Zixu advised, "If we do not destroy Yue now, we will surely regret it later. Goujian is a wise ruler, and Zhong and Li are virtuous ministers. If they return to their country, they will cause chaos." The King of Wu did not listen and ultimately pardoned Yue, withdrawing his troops and returning home. 5. When Goujian was trapped at Kuaiji, he sighed and said, "Will this be my end?" Zhong replied, "Tang was imprisoned at Xiatai, King Wen was imprisoned at Youli, Chong'er of Jin fled to Di, and Xiaobai of Qi fled to Ju. In the end, they all became kings and hegemons. From this perspective, how can we be so sure that it is not a blessing?" [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 29. In the eighteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Zhao Jianzi besieged Fan and Zhonghang in Chaoge, and Zhonghang Wenzi fled to Handan. The following year, Duke Ling of Wei died. Jianzi and Yang Hu escorted the Crown Prince Kuai Kui of Wei to Wei, but Wei refused to accept him and instead sent him to Qi.
[492 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 41.3 (yr 10; death). Duke Hui died in the tenth year of his reign, and his son Duke Dao succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 6.1. After Wu pardoned Yue, King Goujian of Yue returned to his country. He then devoted himself to arduous studies, placing a gall bladder by his seat, looking at it whether sitting or lying down, and even tasting it while eating. He said, "Have you forgotten the shame of Kuaiji?" He personally farmed the land, and his wife wove the cloth. They ate no meat, wore no fine clothes, humbled themselves before virtuous men, treated guests generously, helped the poor and mourned the dead, and shared the hardships of the people. He wanted to appoint Fan Li to govern the state, but Fan Li replied, "In matters of war, I am better than Zhong; but in governing the state and winning the hearts of the people, I am better than Zhong." [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 30. In the twenty-first year of Duke Ding of Jin, Jianzi captured Handan, and Zhongxing Wenzi fled to Bairen. Jianzi then besieged Bairen, and Zhongxing Wenzi and Fan Zhaozi fled to Qi. Zhao eventually gained control of Handan and Bairen. The remaining cities of Fan and Zhongxing were incorporated into Jin. Zhao was nominally a minister of Jin, but in reality, it held absolute power in Jin, and its fiefdoms were comparable to those of other feudal lords.
[491 BC]
[490 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 42.1 (Duke Dao yr 2) (Wikipedia). In the second year of Duke Dao's reign, Qi minister Tian Qi murdered his ruler, Ruzi, and installed his elder brother, Yang Sheng, as Duke Dao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 127.3. In the twenty-second year, Jin defeated the Fan and Zhonghang clans, and their two sons fled to Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 6.2. Therefore, the administration of the state was entrusted to the minister Zhong, while Fan Li and the minister Zheji were sent to Wu as hostages. Two years later, Wu returned Fan Li. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 26. Another day, Gu Bu Ziqing met with Jianzi, who summoned all his sons to assess him. Ziqing said, "None of them will become generals." Jianzi said, "Will the Zhao clan be destroyed?" Ziqing said, "I once saw a boy on the road; he is likely your son." Jianzi summoned Ziwuxu. When Wuxu arrived, Ziqing rose and said, "This is truly a general!" Jianzi said, "His mother is lowly, a maidservant from the Di tribe; how can he be noble?" Ziqing said, "Heaven bestows upon him; though lowly, he will surely be noble." From then on, Jianzi summoned all his sons to speak with him, and Wuxu was the most virtuous. Jianzi then told his sons, "I have hidden a precious talisman on Mount Changshan; whoever finds it first will be rewarded." The sons rushed to Mount Changshan, searched, but found nothing. Wuxu returned, saying, "I have obtained the talisman." Jianzi said, "Report it to me." Wuxu said, "Go down Mount Changshan to Dai; Dai can be taken." Jianzi then realized that Wuxu was indeed virtuous, and thus deposed Crown Prince Bolu and made Wuxu the Crown Prince.
[489 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 32.1 (approx.; reign-year based). In the seventh year, King Fuchai of Wu, hearing of the death of Duke Jing of Qi and the ministers' struggle for favor, and the weakness of the new ruler, launched a northern expedition against Qi. Zixu advised, "King Goujian of Yue does not eat the same food twice, nor wear the same clothes twice; he attends to the dead and inquires about the sick, and he also desires to utilize his troops. If this man does not die, he will surely become a threat to Wu. Now, Yue is a thorn in our side, yet Your Majesty does not prioritize it, but instead focuses on Qi. Is this not a mistake?" King Fuchai did not listen and proceeded to the north to attack Qi, defeating the Qi army at Ailing. Upon reaching Zeng, he summoned Duke Ai of Lu and ordered a hundred sacrificial animals. Ji Kangzi sent Zigong to persuade the Grand Minister Pi with the rites of Zhou, and the matter was stopped. He then lingered to conquer territory south of Qi and Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 69. In the fifth year of Duke Ai's reign, Duke Jing of Qi died. In the sixth year, Tian Qi of Qi murdered his ruler, Ruzi. 69. In the fifth year of Duke Ai's reign, Duke Jing of Qi died. In the sixth year, Tian Qi of Qi murdered his ruler, Ruzi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 60. In the spring of the twenty-seventh year, Wu attacked Chen, and King Zhao of Chu came to its aid, stationing his army at Chengfu. In October, King Zhao fell ill in the army camp, and a red cloud, resembling a bird, flew alongside the sun. King Zhao consulted the Grand Historian of Zhou, who said, "This is a calamity for the King of Chu, but it can be transferred to the generals and ministers." Upon hearing this, the generals and ministers offered to pray to the gods themselves. King Zhao said, "The generals and ministers are my pillars of support; how can I transfer this calamity by sacrificing myself?" He refused to listen. A divination revealed that the Yellow River was a source of misfortune, and the ministers requested to pray to the river. King Zhao said, "Since my ancestors received their fiefs, their ambitions have never exceeded the Yangtze and Han rivers, and the Yellow River has not committed any crime." He refused. Confucius, in Chen, heard this and said, "King Zhao of Chu has grasped the great principles. It is fitting that he will not lose his kingdom!" 61. King Zhao fell seriously ill and summoned his princes and ministers, saying, "I, an unworthy ruler, have twice humiliated the Chu army. Now, I am fortunate to die of old age." He offered the throne to his younger brother, Prince Shen, but he refused. He then offered it to his second younger brother, Prince Jie, but that was also refused. Finally, he offered it to his third younger brother, Prince Lü, declining five times before agreeing to be king. On the day of Gengyin, King Zhao died in the army camp. Prince Lü said, "Your Majesty was seriously ill and relinquished your son to the ministers. I agreed to your request to show Your Majesty's favor. Now that Your Majesty is dead, how could I forget Your Majesty's intentions?" He then conspired with Zixi and Ziqi, ambushing the army and blocking the road, welcoming Zhang, the son of the Yue woman, to the throne, who became King Hui. Afterwards, the army withdrew and returned home to bury King Zhao.
[488 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 62.1. In the second year of King Hui's reign, Zixi summoned Sheng, the son of the late Crown Prince Jian of King Ping, to Wu and appointed him as the Grand Master of Chao, known as Lord Bai. Lord Bai was fond of military affairs and treated his subordinates with respect, desiring revenge. In the sixth year, Lord Bai requested permission from the Prime Minister Zixi to attack Zheng. Previously, Lord Bai's father, Jian, had fled to Zheng, where he was killed. Lord Bai fled to Wu, but Zixi summoned him again, hence his resentment towards Zheng and his desire to attack. Zixi agreed but did not send troops.
[487 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 32.2 (approx.). In the ninth year, he led an expedition against Lu, reaching Lu and making an alliance before departing.
[486 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 42.2 (yr 6). In the sixth year, Wu defeated the Qi army. The people of Qi then murdered Duke Dao and installed his son, Duke Jian. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 32.3 (approx.). In the tenth year, he returned after attacking Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 70. In the seventh year, King Fuchai of Wu, in a powerful campaign, attacked Qi and reached Zeng, demanding a hundred sacrificial animals from Lu. Ji Kangzi sent Zigong to persuade King Fuchai and the Grand Minister Pi to submit to him with proper etiquette. King Fuchai said, "I have tattoos, so I am not worthy of such respect." Thus, the matter was dropped. 70. In the seventh year, King Fuchai of Wu, in a powerful campaign, attacked Qi and reached Zeng, demanding a hundred sacrificial animals from Lu. Ji Kangzi sent Zigong to persuade King Fuchai and the Grand Minister Pi to submit to him with proper etiquette. King Fuchai said, "I have tattoos, so I am not worthy of such respect." Thus, the matter was dropped.
[485 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 32.4 (approx.). In the eleventh year, he again launched a northern expedition against Qi. 34. The Qi Bao clan assassinated Duke Dao of Qi. Upon hearing this, the King of Wu wept outside his army gates for three days, and then launched a naval attack on Qi. The Qi forces defeated Wu, and the King of Wu withdrew his troops. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 7. Seven years after Goujian returned from Kuaiji, he comforted his people, intending to use them to avenge Wu. His minister Feng Tong advised, “The state was recently in exile; now, to restore its prosperity and prepare for war will surely frighten Wu, and fear will inevitably lead to trouble. Moreover, a fierce bird will hide before striking. Now, Wu's army is attacking Qi and Jin, harboring deep resentment towards Chu and Yue, its reputation is high throughout the land, yet it has actually harmed the Zhou dynasty. Its virtue is little, its achievements many; it will surely become arrogant and complacent. For Yue's sake, the best course of action is to ally with Qi, befriend Chu, and attach ourselves to Jin to strengthen Wu. Wu's ambitions are broad; it will surely recklessly wage war. If we unite their forces, and the three states attack, Yue can exploit their weakness and defeat them.” Goujian said, “Excellent.”
[484 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 33. King Goujian of Yue led his people to pay homage to Wu, presenting them with generous gifts, which pleased the King of Wu. Only Wu Zixu was fearful, saying, "This is abandoning Wu." He advised, "Yue is in our heartland; now that Qi has gained power, it's like a barren field, useless. Moreover, Pan Geng's proclamation says, 'Do not abandon Yue, for it will rise again.'" The King of Wu did not listen and sent Wu Zixu to Qi. Wu Zixu entrusted his son to the Bao family in Qi and returned to report to the King of Wu. The King of Wu, upon hearing this, was furious and gave Wu Zixu the sword of Shulou to commit suicide. Before dying, Wu Zixu said, "Plant a catalpa tree on my grave, so it can be used to make utensils. Gouge out my eyes and place them at the east gate of Wu, so I can witness Yue's destruction of Wu." [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 71. Wu attacked Lu on behalf of Zou, but upon reaching the city walls, they made an alliance and departed. Qi attacked us and captured three cities. Ten years later, we attacked Qi's southern border. 71. Wu attacked Lu on behalf of Zou, but upon reaching the city walls, they made an alliance and departed. Qi attacked us and captured three cities. Ten years later, we attacked Qi's southern border.
[483 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 42.3 (yr 9; Huangchi). In the ninth year, Duke Ding of Jin and King Fuchai of Wu formed an alliance and fought for supremacy at Huangchi, with Jin ultimately defeating Wu first. Wu became powerful and dominated the Central Plains. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 35. In the thirteenth year, the rulers of Wu, Zhaolu, and Wei met at Tuogao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 8.1. Two years later, the King of Wu was about to attack Qi. Wu Zixu advised, "This is not advisable. I have heard that Goujian does not eat the same food twice, and shares the joys and sorrows of the people. If this man does not die, he will surely become a scourge to the state. Wu has Yue, which is a disease in our heart; Qi and Wu are like scabies. I urge Your Majesty to release Qi and prioritize Yue." The King of Wu did not listen and attacked Qi, defeating it at Ailing, capturing Qi's Gao and Guo, and bringing them back. He then rebuked Wu Zixu. Wu Zixu said, "Your Majesty, do not rejoice!" The king was angry, and Wu Zixu wanted to commit suicide, but the king heard of this and stopped him. The Yue official Zhong said, "I observe that the King of Wu is arrogant. I request to try lending him grain to divine his future." He requested the loan, and the King of Wu was about to grant it, but Wu Zixu advised against it. The king then granted it, and Yue was secretly pleased. Wu Zixu said, "If the king does not heed advice, Wu will be ruined in three years!" The Grand Minister Pi heard this and repeatedly argued with Wu Zixu about the matter.
[482 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 36. In the spring of the fourteenth year, the King of Wu convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Huangchi, intending to dominate China and preserve the Zhou dynasty. On the day of Bingzi in the sixth month (戊), King Goujian of Yue attacked Wu. On the day of Yiyou, five thousand Yue soldiers fought against Wu. On the day of Bingxu, they captured Prince You of Wu. On the day of Dinghai, they entered Wu. The people of Wu reported their defeat to King Fuchai, who was displeased to hear it. Someone leaked the news, and the King of Wu was furious, beheading seven people under his tent. On the day of Xinchou in the seventh month, the King of Wu and Duke Ding of Jin argued over seniority. The King of Wu said, "Among the Zhou dynasty, I am the eldest." Duke Ding of Jin said, "Among the Ji clan, I am the heir." Zhao Yang was furious and planned to attack Wu, so he made Duke Ding of Jin the eldest. The King of Wu had already made an alliance with Jin and wanted to attack Song. The Grand Minister Pi said, "We can win, but we cannot hold the position." So he led his troops back to his country. The country had lost its crown prince, the interior was empty, and the king had been away for a long time, so the soldiers were all exhausted. Therefore, he sent generous gifts to make peace with Yue. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 128. Thirty years later, Duke Ding met with King Fuchai of Wu at Huangchi to compete for supremacy. Zhao Yang was present and ultimately won the bid to become the ruler of Wu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 62.2. In the eighth year, Jin attacked Zheng, and Zheng appealed to Chu for help. Chu sent Zixi to aid Zheng, but Zixi accepted bribes and left. Lord Bai was enraged and, together with the brave and fierce warrior Shi Qi and others, attacked and killed Prime Minister Zixi and Zi Qi at court. They then kidnapped King Hui, imprisoned him in the Gao Palace, and intended to assassinate him. King Hui's follower, Qu Gu, carried the king and fled to the palace of Lady Zhao's wife. Lord Bai then declared himself king. A month later, Ye Gong came to aid Chu, and King Hui's followers joined him in attacking Lord Bai, killing him. King Hui was then restored to the throne. That same year, Chen was conquered and its territory was established. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 8.2 (approx within same crisis). Pi then slandered Wu Zixu, saying, "Wu Zixu appears loyal but is actually cruel. He disregards his father and brothers; how could he care for the king? The king previously wanted to attack Qi, but Zixu strongly advised against it and later achieved merit. He now resents the king. If the king is not prepared for Wu Zixu, he will surely cause trouble." Pi conspired with Feng Tong to slander Wu Zixu to the king. The king initially ignored him, but then sent Wu Zixu to Qi. Upon hearing that Wu Zixu had entrusted his son to the Bao family, the king was furious, saying, "Wu Zixu has indeed deceived me!" Upon his return, the king sent someone to give Wu Zixu the sword of Shulou to commit suicide. Zixu laughed loudly and said, "I commanded Erfu to become the hegemon, and I also established you. You initially wanted to give me half of the Wu kingdom, but I refused. Now you have turned around and killed me because of slander. Alas, alas, one person cannot stand alone!" He told the messenger, "You must take my eyes and place them at the east gate of Wu so that I can watch the Yue army enter!" Thereupon, Wu appointed Pi as its ruler. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 31. In the thirtieth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Duke Ding and King Fuchai of Wu vied for supremacy at Huangchi. Zhao Jianzi followed Duke Ding and eventually became the ruler of Wu. Duke Ding died in the thirty-seventh year, and Jianzi ended the three-year mourning period by only one year. In the same year, King Goujian of Yue destroyed Wu.
[481 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 58. In the thirty-ninth year, Tian Chang of Qi killed his lord, Duke Jian. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 37. In the fifteenth year, Qi Tianchang killed Duke Jian. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 72. Qi attacked Lu. The Ji family employed Ran You, who had rendered meritorious service, and then remembered Confucius. Confucius returned to Lu from Wei. Tian Chang of Qi murdered his ruler, Duke Jian, in Xuzhou. Confucius requested permission to attack Qi, but Duke Ai refused. 72. Qi attacked Lu. The Ji family employed Ran You, who had rendered meritorious service, and then remembered Confucius. Confucius returned to Lu from Wei. Tian Chang of Qi murdered his ruler, Duke Jian, in Xuzhou. Confucius requested permission to attack Qi, but Duke Ai refused. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 14.4. In the twelfth year of Duke Xian's reign, Tian Chang of Qi assassinated his ruler, Duke Jian. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 129. In the thirty-first year, Tian Chang of Qi murdered his ruler, Duke Jian, and installed Duke Jian's younger brother, Ao, as Duke Ping. In the thirty-third year, Confucius died.
[480 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 42.4 (yr 12; Tian Chang murders Duke Jian). In the twelfth year, Qi minister Tian Chang murdered Duke Jian and installed his younger brother, Duke Ping, as his prime minister. In the thirteenth year, Chu destroyed Chen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 61 — Bo Yi Lie Zhuan] 2 (discursive; Confucius quote). Confucius said, "Bo Yi and Shu Qi did not dwell on past wrongs, therefore their resentment was rare." "They sought benevolence and attained it, so what resentment could they possibly have?" I grieve for Bo Yi's intentions, and I find this strange in the lost poem. Its commentary says:
[479 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 59. In the forty-first year, Chu conquered Chen. Confucius died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 73. In the fifteenth year, he sent Zifu Jingbo and Zigong as intermediaries to Qi, and Qi returned the territory he had seized. Tian Chang, the newly appointed prime minister, wanted to establish friendly relations with the feudal lords. 74. Sixteen years later, Confucius died. 73. In the fifteenth year, he sent Zifu Jingbo and Zigong as intermediaries to Qi, and Qi returned the territory he had seized. Tian Chang, the newly appointed prime minister, wanted to establish friendly relations with the feudal lords. 74. Sixteen years later, Confucius died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 14.5. In the fourteenth year, Confucius died. In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Xian died, and Duke Xiao succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 9. After three years, Goujian summoned Fan Li and said, "Wu has already killed Wu Zixu, and there are many flatterers around. Is this acceptable?" Fan Li replied, "Not yet."
[478 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 38 (approx.). In the eighteenth year, Yue grew stronger. King Goujian of Yue led his troops to defeat the Wu army at Lize. Chu destroyed Chen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 69. In the fifty-fifth year, Fan and Zhonghang rebelled against their lord in Jin. Jin attacked them urgently, and they came to request grain. Tian Qi, wanting to cause trouble, formed a faction among the rebel ministers and persuaded Duke Jing, saying, "Fan and Zhonghang have repeatedly been kind to Qi; we cannot leave them unattended." So he sent them to beg for help and delivered grain to them. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 10. The following spring, the King of Wu convened a meeting of the feudal lords at Huangchi. Wu's elite troops accompanied the king, leaving only the elderly, the weak, and the crown prince behind. Goujian again consulted Fan Li, who said, "It is time." He then mobilized 2,000 trained soldiers, 40,000 instructors, 6,000 gentlemen, and 1,000 charioteers to attack Wu. The Wu army was defeated, and the crown prince was killed. Wu appealed to the king for help, but the king, who was at Huangchi with the feudal lords, feared the world would find out and kept it a secret. Having already formed an alliance at Huangchi, the King of Wu sent envoys with generous gifts to request peace with Yue. Yue, realizing it could not destroy Wu either, made peace with Wu.
[477 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 42.5 (yr 14; death). Duke Dao of Qin died in the fourteenth year of his reign, and his son, Duke Ligong, succeeded him. Confucius died in the twelfth year of Duke Dao's reign.
[476 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 60.1. In the forty-second year, King Jing died, [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 39.1. In the twentieth year, King Goujian of Yue again attacked Wu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 63.1. In the thirteenth year, King Fuchai of Wu became powerful, bullying Qi and Jin, and then attacked Chu.
[475 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 60.2. and his son, King Yuanren, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 43.1 (Duke Ligong yr 2) (Wikipedia). In the second year of Duke Li Gong's reign, the people of Shu came to offer bribes. [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 39.2. In the twenty-first year, he besieged Wu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 70. In the summer of the fifty-eighth year, the son of Lady Yan, wife of Duke Jing, died. Duke Jing's favored concubine, Lady Rui, gave birth to Tu. Tu was young, and his mother was of low social status and morally questionable. The officials feared he would become the heir and thus expressed their wish to choose the eldest and most virtuous of their sons as crown prince. Duke Jing, old and averse to discussing succession, and also fond of Tu's mother, wanted to establish her as heir but hesitated to speak of it. He said to the officials, "It's just for fun. What need is there for the state to lack a ruler?" In the autumn, Duke Jing fell ill and ordered Guo Huizi and Gao Zhaozi to establish his youngest son, Tu, as crown prince, banishing the other princes and relocating them to Lai. Duke Jing died, and Crown Prince Tu ascended the throne, becoming known as Yan Ruzi. In the winter, before his burial, the princes, fearing execution, all fled. Tu's half-brothers, Princes Shou, Ju, and Qian, fled to Wei; Princes Zang and Yangsheng fled to Lu. The people of Lai sang a song: "Duke Jing died, yet we were not buried together; the three military strategies were not discussed with us; the army is here, the army is here; are we partisans?" [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 130. In the thirty-seventh year, Duke Ding died, and his son, Duke Chu, succeeded him.
[474 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 11.1. Four years later, Yue attacked Wu again. Wu's soldiers and civilians were exhausted, and their elite troops were all killed by Qi and Jin. Yue defeated Wu and besieged it for three years. Wu's army was defeated, and Yue then sent King Goujian to live in the mountains of Gusu. King Goujian sent Gongsun Xiong, who was bare-chested and crawling on his knees, to plead with King Goujian of Yue, saying, "Your humble servant Fuchai dares to lay bare his heart. In the past, I offended you at Kuaiji, but you dared not disobey my orders and were able to make peace with me and return home. Now Your Majesty has executed me, and I will obey your orders. Do you also wish to pardon my crimes as you did at Kuaiji?" Goujian could not bear it and was about to agree. Fan Li said, “The matter of Kuaiji was a gift from Heaven to Wu, which Wu did not accept. Now Heaven is giving Wu to Yue; how can Yue defy Heaven? Moreover, Your Majesty rises early and retires late, is this not for Wu's sake? You have planned for twenty-two years, and now you abandon it in a single day? Is this acceptable? Furthermore, if Heaven gives something and you do not take it, you will suffer the consequences. ‘The one who cuts the axe handle is not far off from the mark.’ Have you forgotten the earthworm of Kuaiji?” Goujian said, “I wish to listen to your words, but I cannot bear to send your messenger.” Fan Li then sounded the drum to advance the troops, saying, “The King has already entrusted the government to you; the messenger must leave, or he will be punished.” The Wu messenger wept and left. Goujian pitied him and sent someone to tell the King of Wu, “I will place Your Majesty in Yongdong, and grant you a hundred households.”
[473 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 31 — Wu Taibo Shijia] 39.3. On the day of Dingmao in the eleventh month of the twenty-third year, Yue defeated Wu. King Goujian of Yue wanted to relocate King Fuchai of Wu to Yongdong and provide him with a hundred households. King Fuchai of Wu said, "I am old and can no longer serve my sovereign. I regret not heeding Wu Zixu's advice, which has led me to this predicament." He then committed suicide. King Goujian of Yue destroyed Wu, executed the Grand Minister Pi for disloyalty, and returned home. 40 (Sima Qian comment). Sima Qian said: Confucius said, "Taibo can be called the epitome of virtue. He thrice yielded the throne, and the people could not find a better way to praise him." Having read the ancient texts of the Spring and Autumn Annals, I now know that the Yu of China and the Gouwu of the Jingman were brothers. Yanling Jizi's benevolence was boundless, his admiration for righteousness limitless, and he could discern right from wrong from subtle signs. Alas, what a learned and erudite gentleman he was! [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 75. In the twenty-second year, King Goujian of Yue destroyed King Fuchai of Wu. 75. In the twenty-second year, King Goujian of Yue destroyed King Fuchai of Wu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 63.2. In the sixteenth year, Yue destroyed Wu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 11.2. The King of Wu apologized, saying, “I am old and cannot serve Your Majesty!” He then committed suicide. He covered his face and said, “I have no face to see Zixu!” The King of Yue then buried the King of Wu and executed the Grand Minister Pi.
[472 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 12. After Goujian pacified Wu, he led his army north across the Huai River and met with the feudal lords of Qi and Jin at Xuzhou, where he paid tribute to Zhou. King Yuan of Zhou sent someone to bestow upon Goujian a sacrificial offering and appointed him as a hegemon. After Goujian left, he crossed the Huai River southward, ceding the land along the Huai River to Chu, returning the Song territory that Wu had seized to Song, and giving Lu and Si provinces a hundred li to the east. At that time, the Yue army roamed freely east of the Yangtze and Huai Rivers, and all the feudal lords congratulated him, proclaiming him a hegemon. 13.1. Fan Li then left, sending a letter from Qi to the minister Zhong, saying, "When the birds are all gone, the good bow is put away; when the cunning rabbit is dead, the hunting dog is cooked. The King of Yue has a long neck and a bird's beak; he can share hardship, but not joy. Why don't you leave?" Upon seeing the letter, Zhong claimed illness and did not attend court. Some people slandered Zhong, saying he was plotting rebellion. 13.2. The King of Yue then bestowed a sword upon Zhong, saying, "You taught me seven strategies for attacking Wu. I used three of them and defeated Wu. The other four are with you. You will test them for me, as I did with the late king." Zhong then committed suicide.
[471 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 32. In the eleventh year of Duke Chu of Jin, Zhi Bo attacked Zheng. Zhao Jianzi was ill and sent his crown prince, Wuxu, to lead the siege of Zheng. Zhi Bo, drunk, poured wine on Wuxu and attacked him. Wuxu's ministers pleaded for his life. Wuxu said, "The reason Your Majesty dismissed me is because you are tolerant." However, he was still resentful of Zhi Bo. Zhi Bo returned home and then told Jianzi to dismiss Wuxu, but Jianzi refused. Wuxu thus harbored resentment towards Zhi Bo.
[470 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 71. In the spring of the first year of Duke Yan Ruzi's reign, Tian Qi, feigning service to Gao and Guo, would ride in the same carriage to court each time, saying, "If you gain the ruler's favor, the officials will all feel insecure and plot rebellion." He also told the officials, "Gao Zhaozi is to be feared; before he acts, attack him first." The officials followed his advice. In June, Tian Qi and Bao Mu, along with the officials, led troops into the ducal palace and attacked Gao Zhaozi. Zhaozi, upon hearing this, joined Guo Huizi to rescue the duke. The ducal army was defeated, and Tian Qi's followers pursued them. Guo Huizi fled to Ju, where he then turned against and killed Gao Zhaozi. Yan Yu fled to Lu. In August, Qi seized power. Tian Qi, having defeated the two prime ministers, sent someone to Lu to summon Prince Yangsheng. Yangsheng arrived in Qi and secretly hid in Tian Qi's house. On the day of Wuzi in the tenth month, Tian Qi invited the high officials, saying, "Chang's mother has prepared a fish and beans sacrifice; please come to the feast." At the feast, Tian Qi placed Yang Sheng in a bag, seated him in the center, and then opened the bag to reveal Yang Sheng, saying, "This is the ruler of Qi!" All the officials bowed in homage. Just as he was about to make an oath with the officials to establish Yang Sheng as ruler, Bao Mu, drunk, Tian Qi falsely accused the officials, saying, "I conspired with Bao Mu to establish Yang Sheng as ruler." Bao Mu angrily said, "Have you forgotten Duke Jing's command?" The officials looked at each other, seemingly repenting. Yang Sheng stepped forward, bowed his head, and said, "If it's acceptable, then establish him; otherwise, forget it." Bao Mu, fearing trouble, then said again, "They are all sons of Duke Jing; why is it unacceptable?" They then made an oath and established Yang Sheng as ruler, who became Duke Dao. Duke Dao entered the palace and ordered the relocation of Yan Ruzi to Tai, where he was killed under the eaves. He also banished Ruzi's mother, Rui Zi. Rui Zi was of low status, and Ruzi was young, therefore they had no power, and the people of the state despised them. 72. In the first year of Duke Dao's reign, Qi attacked Lu and captured Huan and Chan. Initially, Yang Sheng had fled to Lu, and Ji Kangzi married his younger sister to him. Upon his return and ascension to the throne, Qi sent someone to welcome him. Ji Ji had an affair with Ji Fanghou, revealing their relationship. Lu dared not reciprocate, so Qi attacked Lu and ultimately welcomed Ji Ji back. Ji Ji became a favorite, and Qi returned the territories it had seized from Lu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 19. Fan Li sailed out of Qi, changed his name, and called himself Chi Yi Zi Pi. He farmed on the seashore, working hard and diligently, and he and his son managed their property. Before long, they amassed hundreds of thousands in wealth. The people of Qi, hearing of his virtue, appointed him prime minister. Fan Li sighed, "To accumulate a thousand gold pieces at home, and to rise to the rank of prime minister in office—this is the pinnacle for a commoner. To hold such high rank for too long is inauspicious." He then returned his prime minister's seal, distributed all his wealth among friends and fellow villagers, and, carrying his most precious treasures, traveled leisurely away, stopping at Tao. He believed this to be the center of the world, a place where trade was readily available, and that one could become wealthy there. He then called himself Tao Zhu Gong. He further instructed his father and son to farm and raise livestock, abandoning their homes, waiting for the right time to trade goods, and pursuing a profit of one-tenth. Before long, they amassed a fortune of tens of millions. The world called him Tao Zhu Gong.
[469 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 60.3. In the eighth year of King Yuan's reign, he died, and his son, King Dingjie, ascended the throne.
[468 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 76. In the spring of the twenty-seventh year, Ji Kangzi died. In the summer, Duke Ai was troubled by the Three Huan families and intended to use the other feudal lords to coerce them. The Three Huan families were also troubled by the Duke's rebellion, so there was much discord between the ruler and his ministers. The Duke was traveling on Lingban when he met Meng Wubo in the street, who asked, "May I ask if I will die?" Meng Wubo replied, "I do not know." The Duke intended to use Yue to attack the Three Huan families. In the eighth month, Duke Ai went to Xingshi. The Three Huan families attacked the Duke, who fled to Wei, then to Zou, and finally to Yue. The people of Yue welcomed Duke Ai back, and he died at Youshanshi. His son Ning succeeded him, becoming Duke Dao. 76. In the spring of the twenty-seventh year, Ji Kangzi died. In the summer, Duke Ai was troubled by the Three Huan families and intended to use the other feudal lords to coerce them. The Three Huan families were also troubled by the Duke's rebellion, so there was much discord between the ruler and his ministers. The Duke was traveling on Lingban when he met Meng Wubo in the street, who asked, "May I ask if I will die?" Meng Wubo replied, "I do not know." The Duke intended to use Yue to attack the Three Huan families. In the eighth month, Duke Ai went to Xingshi. The Three Huan families attacked the Duke, who fled to Wei, then to Zou, and finally to Yue. The people of Yue welcomed Duke Ai back, and he died at Youshanshi. His son Ning succeeded him, becoming Duke Dao.
[467 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 73. Baozi and Duke Dao had a falling out and were not on good terms. Four years later, Wu and Lu attacked Qi in the south. Baozi assassinated Duke Dao and fled to Wu. King Fuchai of Wu wept outside the army gate for three days and planned to enter the sea to attack Qi. The people of Qi defeated them, and the Wu army withdrew. Zhao Yang of Jin attacked Qi, but left after reaching Lai. The people of Qi jointly established Duke Dao's son, Ren, as Duke Jian.
[466 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 74. In the spring of the fourth year of Duke Jian's reign, when Duke Jian and his father Yang Sheng were both in Lu, Jian Zhi was favored. Upon ascending the throne, Jian Zhi was put in charge of the government. Tian Chengzi feared him and frequently visited the court. Yu Yang advised Duke Jian, "Tian and Jian cannot coexist; Your Majesty should choose one." Duke Jian did not listen. That evening, Zi Wo was caught red-handed murdering someone by Tian Chengzi. The Tian family was on good terms; one of them, a sick prisoner, gave wine to the guards, got drunk, killed the guards, and escaped. Zi Wo made an alliance with the Tian families at Chen Zong. Initially, Tian Bao wanted to become Zi Wo's subject, and sent Gongsun to speak to Bao, but Bao had a death in his family and stopped. Later, he finally became Zi Wo's subject and gained Zi Wo's favor. Zi Wo said, "I will expel the entire Tian family and establish you as my successor, is that acceptable?" Zi Wo replied, "I have already distanced myself from the Tian family. Besides, there are only a few who have disobeyed; why expel them all!" He then informed the Tian family. Zi Xing said, "If you do not go to the rightful ruler, you will surely suffer misfortune." Zi Xing lodged at the Duke's palace. 75. On the day of Renshen in the fifth month of summer, Chengzi and his brothers, four in their carriages, went to see the Duke. Ziwo, who was in the tent, went out to greet them, and then entered, closing the gate. A eunuch guarded them, and Zixing killed the eunuch. The Duke was drinking with women at the Tantai Terrace, and Chengzi moved to the other rooms. The Duke drew his spear to strike him, but the Grand Historian Ziyu said, "It's not that it's unfavorable, but that we should eliminate a threat." Chengzi went out to the storehouse and heard that the Duke was still angry. As he was about to leave, he said, "Where is there no ruler!" Zixing drew his sword and said, "Xu is a traitor. Who is not Tian Zong? There are those like Tian Zong who will not kill you." So he stopped. Ziwo returned home, and his men attacked the gate and the outer gate, but they could not defeat him, so he left. The Tian family pursued him. The people of Fengqiu captured Ziwo and reported him to the authorities, and he was killed at the Guo Pass. Chengzi was about to kill Dalu Zifang, but Tian Ni pleaded for his life and spared him. He took the Duke's order to retrieve his carriage on the road and exited through the Yong Gate. Tian Bao offered him the carriage, but he refused, saying, "You asked me for it, and now Bao is offering me the carriage; I have a private matter to settle. If I serve you, my lord, and have a private matter with my enemy, how can I face the men of Lu and Wei?"
[465 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 14. When Goujian died, his son Wang Shiyu succeeded him. When Wang Shiyu died, his son Wang Bushou succeeded him. When Wang Bushou died, his son Wang Weng succeeded him. When Wang Weng died, his son Wang Yi succeeded him. When Wang Yi died, his son Wang Zhihou succeeded him. When Wang Zhihou died, his son Wang Wuqiang succeeded him. 18 (summary / evaluative). Fan Li served King Goujian of Yue, enduring hardship and devising strategies with him for over twenty years. They ultimately destroyed Wu, avenging the humiliation of Kuaiji, and led their troops north across the Huai River to threaten Qi and Jin, thus establishing their authority over the Central Plains and upholding the Zhou dynasty. Goujian became a hegemon, and Fan Li was appointed Supreme General. Upon returning to Yue, Fan Li felt it would be difficult to remain under such a prestigious position, and that Goujian was a man who could share hardship but not comfort. He wrote to Goujian, saying, "I have heard that when the ruler is worried, the minister toils; when the ruler is humiliated, the minister dies. When Your Majesty was humiliated at Kuaiji, the reason you did not die was because of this. Now that the humiliation has been avenged, I request to follow you in the punishment at Kuaiji." Goujian said, "I will share the kingdom with you. Otherwise, I will punish you." Fan Li replied, "The ruler commands, and the minister follows his own will." He then packed his precious jewels and jade, and with his private followers, sailed away, never to return. Goujian then designated Mount Kuaiji as Fan Li's fief.
[464 BC]
[463 BC]
[462 BC]
[461 BC]
[460 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 43.2 (yr 16). In the sixteenth year, a trench was dug beside the river. With 20,000 troops, he attacked Dali and captured its royal city. [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 76. On the day of Gengchen, Tian Chang captured Duke Jian in Xuzhou. Duke Jian said, "I followed Yu Yang's advice long ago, but I did not come to this." On the day of Jiawu, Tian Chang murdered Duke Jian in Xuzhou. Tian Chang then installed Duke Jian's younger brother, Ao, as Duke Ping. After Duke Ping ascended the throne, Tian Chang became his prime minister, monopolized the government of Qi, and ceded the area east of Anping in Qi as the fiefdom of the Tian family. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 77 (discursive). During the reign of Duke Dao, the Three Huan families were powerful, and Lu was like a minor marquis, inferior to the Three Huan families. 77 (discursive). During the reign of Duke Dao, the Three Huan families were powerful, and Lu was like a minor marquis, inferior to the Three Huan families. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 20 (approx, later anecdote cycle). Zhu Gong lived in Tao and had a youngest son. When the youngest son grew up, Zhu Gong's middle son committed murder and was imprisoned in Chu. Zhu Gong said, "To die for murder is one's duty. However, I have heard that the son of a man of a thousand pieces of gold does not die in the marketplace." He told his youngest son to go and see him. He then packed a thousand pieces of gold into a coarse container, loaded it onto an oxcart, and was about to send his youngest son away. Zhu Gong's eldest son insisted on going as well, but Zhu Gong refused. The eldest son said, "The eldest son of a family is called the head of the household. Now that my younger brother has committed a crime, you do not send him away, but instead send my younger brother. This is my unfilial act." He wanted to commit suicide. His mother said to him, "If you send your youngest son now, he may not be able to have a middle son. And you will lose your eldest son first. What will you do?" Zhu Gong had no choice but to send his eldest son away, writing a letter to his old friend Zhuang Sheng. It said, "When you arrive, give a thousand pieces of gold to Zhuang Sheng and let him do as he pleases. Be careful not to argue with him." After the eldest son left, he also secretly took several hundred pieces of gold with him. 21. When Zhuangzi arrived in Chu, he found his house near the city wall, overgrown with weeds, and very poor. His eldest son, however, sent a letter with a thousand pieces of gold, just as his father had instructed. Zhuangzi said, "You should leave quickly, and do not linger! Once your younger brother leaves, do not ask why." After the eldest son left, he secretly stayed behind, but did not visit Zhuangzi, and used the money to present to powerful officials in Chu. 22. Although Zhuangzi lived in poverty, he was renowned throughout the country for his integrity and uprightness, and was revered by everyone from the King of Chu down. When Zhu Gong presented him with gold, he did not intend to accept it; he only wanted to return it after the matter was settled as a token of his trust. Therefore, when the gold arrived, he told his wife, "This is Zhu Gong's gold. If you are ill and do not stay up all night, do not touch it when it returns." However, Zhu Gong's eldest son did not understand his meaning and thought that there was nothing wrong with it. 23. Zhuangzi, in his leisure time, went to see the King of Chu and said, "A certain star is so-and-so; this signifies harm to Chu." The King of Chu, who trusted Zhuangzi implicitly, asked, "What should we do now?" Zhuangzi replied, "Only virtue can avert this." The King of Chu said, "Zhuangzi, you are free; I will carry it out." The King then sent an envoy to seal a treasury containing three coins. A noblewoman of Chu, alarmed, told the eldest son of Zhu Gong, "The King is about to grant a pardon." The noblewoman asked, "Why?" The noblewoman replied, "Whenever the King is about to grant a pardon, he always seals a treasury containing three coins. Last night, the King sent an envoy to seal it." The eldest son of Zhu Gong thought that since the pardon was coming, his younger brother should naturally leave. He felt that he had wasted a thousand gold coins on Zhuangzi and had no purpose in doing so. Therefore, he went to see Zhuangzi again. Zhuangzi exclaimed in surprise, "Aren't you leaving?" The eldest son replied, "Not yet. I was initially serving my younger brother, but now that he is considering a pardon, I am taking my leave." Zhuangzi knew that he wanted to get his gold back and said, "Go into the room and take the gold yourself." The eldest son immediately went into the room, took the gold, and left, rejoicing alone. 24. Zhuangzi, ashamed of being betrayed by his son, went to see the King of Chu and said, "I previously spoke of a certain star, and Your Majesty said you wished to repay it with virtuous deeds. Now, as I leave, everyone on the road says that the son of Zhu Gong, a wealthy man from Tao, committed murder and is imprisoned in Chu. His family has bribed Your Majesty's attendants with money, so Your Majesty is not pardoning Chu out of compassion, but because of Zhu Gong's son." The King of Chu was furious and said, "Although I am unworthy, how could I bestow favors because of Zhu Gong's son!" He ordered Zhu Gong's son to be executed, and the next day issued a pardon. Zhu Gong's eldest son then returned home with his brother's remains. 25. When he arrived, his mother and the villagers all grieved for him, but only Zhu Gong laughed and said, "I knew he would kill his brother! It's not that he didn't love his brother, but there was something he couldn't bear. He grew up with me and saw hardship and difficulty in making a living, so he valued giving away wealth. As for his younger brother, he was born into wealth and saw me rich, riding in fine horses and chasing cunning rabbits. He didn't know where wealth came from, so he easily gave it away and didn't cherish it. The reason I wanted to send my younger son away the other day was precisely because he could give away wealth. But the elder could not, so in the end he killed his brother. It's the way things are, and there's nothing to grieve about. I've been looking forward to his death day and night." 26 (summary / evaluative). Therefore, Fan Li moved three times and became famous throughout the world. He did not leave simply because he wanted to, but wherever he stayed, he became famous. He eventually died of old age in Tao, hence the name Tao Zhugong.
[459 BC]
[458 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 131. In the seventeenth year of Duke Chu's reign, Zhi Bo, along with Zhao, Han, and Wei, divided the lands of Fan and Zhonghang as fiefs. Duke Chu was enraged and informed Qi and Lu, intending to use them to attack the four ministers. The four ministers, fearing for their lives, turned against Duke Chu. Duke Chu fled to Qi, but died on the way. Therefore, Zhi Bo then installed Jiao, the great-grandson of Duke Zhao, as the ruler of Jin, who became Duke Ai. 132. Duke Ai's grandfather, Yong, was the youngest son of Duke Zhao of Jin, and was known as Dai Zi. Dai Zi begat Ji. Ji was close to Zhi Bo, but died young. Therefore, Zhi Bo wanted to annex all of Jin, but dared not, and instead installed Ji's son, Jiao, as ruler. At that time, Zhi Bo made all the decisions in Jin, and Duke Ai of Jin could not exercise any control over them. Zhi Bo then possessed the territories of Fan and Zhonghang, becoming the most powerful. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 33. In the seventeenth year of Duke Chu of Jin, Jianzi died, and Crown Prince Wuxu succeeded him, becoming Xiangzi.
[457 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 34. In the first year of Zhao Xiangzi's reign, Yue besieged Wu. Xiangzi lowered the mourning food and sent Chu Long to inquire about the King of Wu.
[456 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 35. Xiangzi's elder sister was formerly the wife of the King of Dai. After Jianzi's burial, before the mourning period was over, Xiangzi went north to the summer palace and requested permission from the King of Dai. He ordered the cooks to serve the King of Dai and his entourage with bronze ladles. While serving, he secretly ordered the stewards to use the ladles to kill the King of Dai and his officials. He then raised an army and pacified the Dai region. When his sister heard of this, she wept and cried out to Heaven, then committed suicide by touching her hairpin. The people of Dai pitied her and named the place where she died "Mount Moji." They then enfeoffed Bolu Zizhou, the son of Xiangzi, as the Lord of Dai. Bolu was Xiangzi's elder brother and the former crown prince. The crown prince died young, so his son was enfeoffed.
[455 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 43.3 (yr 21). In the twenty-first year, the first county of Pinyang was established. Jin captured Wucheng.
[454 BC]
[453 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 61. In the sixteenth year of King Ding's reign, the Three Jin states destroyed Zhi Bo and divided his territory among themselves. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 78. In the thirteenth year, the Three Jin states destroyed Zhi Bo and divided his territory among themselves. 78. In the thirteenth year, the Three Jin states destroyed Zhi Bo and divided his territory among themselves. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 15. In the twelfth year of Duke Xiao's reign, Han, Wei, and Zhao destroyed Zhi Bo and divided his territory, making the three Jin states powerful. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 133. In the fourth year of Duke Ai's reign, Zhao Xiangzi, Han Kangzi, and Wei Huanzi jointly killed Zhi Bo and annexed all of his territory. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 36. After Xiangzi reigned for four years, Zhibo, along with Zhao, Han, and Wei, divided up the former territories of Fan and Zhonghang. Duke Chu of Jin was enraged and informed Qi and Lu, intending to use them to attack the four ministers. The four ministers, fearing for their lives, joined forces to attack Duke Chu. Duke Chu fled to Qi but died on the way. Zhibo then installed Jiao, the great-grandson of Duke Zhao, as Duke Yi of Jin. Zhibo became increasingly arrogant. He requested land from Han and Wei, which they granted. He then requested land from Zhao, which Zhao refused, citing the humiliation of besieging Zheng. Enraged, Zhibo led Han and Wei to attack Zhao. Zhao Xiangzi, fearing for his life, fled to Jinyang. 37. Yuan Guo followed, and later, arrived at Wang Ze, where he saw three people. Those above and below him were visible, while those below were not. He gave Yuan Guo two sections of bamboo, which were not connected. Yuan Guo said, "Give this to Zhao Wuxu for me." When Yuan Guo arrived, he told Xiangzi. Xiangzi spent three days preparing the bamboo, and personally split it open. There was a red inscription that read: "Zhao Wuxu is the envoy of the Marquis of Shanyang of Mount Huotai. On the day of Bingxu in the third month, I will send you to rebel and destroy the Zhi clan. You will also establish a hundred cities for me, and I will grant you the land of the Lin Hu. In later generations, there will be a Kang King, red and black, with a dragon's face and a bird's snout, sideburns and a deer's beard, a large chest and a large belly, a long back and a gait, riding a chariot with a left side, possessing the He Zong, and reaching the Xiu Hun tribes, attacking Jin in the south and destroying Hei Gu in the north." Xiangzi bowed twice and received the command of the three gods. 38. The Three Kingdoms attacked Jinyang for over a year, diverting the Fen River to flood the city, but three sections of the city remained uncontaminated. People cooked in suspended pots and even exchanged children for food. The officials all harbored ulterior motives, and etiquette became increasingly lax; only Gao Gong dared not be disrespectful. Xiangzi, fearing this, secretly sent his minister Zhang Mengtong to negotiate with Han and Wei. Han and Wei conspired with him, and on the day of Bingxu in the third month, the Three Kingdoms turned against and destroyed the Zhi clan, dividing their territory among themselves. When Xiangzi distributed rewards, Gao Gong was given the highest honor. Zhang Mengtong said, "During the Jinyang crisis, only you, Gao Gong, contributed nothing." Xiangzi replied, "When Jinyang was in dire straits, all the officials were lax, but only you, Gao Gong, dared not disrespect your duty as a subject; therefore, I gave you the highest honor." Thus, Zhao gained control of Dai to the north and annexed the Zhi clan to the south, becoming stronger than Han and Wei. He then offered sacrifices to the three gods in a hundred cities, and ordered the original ruler, Huo Tai, to perform sacrifices at Mount Tai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 7. Han Shijia: Zhenzi died, and his son Jianzi succeeded him. Jianzi died, and his son Zhuangzi succeeded him. Zhuangzi died, and his son Kangzi succeeded him. Kangzi, together with Zhao Xiangzi and Wei Huanzi, defeated Zhi Bo and divided his territory, which became larger than that of the other feudal lords. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 20. When Tian Xiangzi became the prime minister of Duke Xuan of Qi, the three Jin states killed Zhi Bo and divided his territory. Xiangzi then appointed all his brothers and relatives as high officials in the capital of Qi, established diplomatic relations with the three Jin states, and even took control of the state of Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 8. More than seventy years later, the Jin dynasty had the story of Yu Rang. 9. Yu Rang was a man from Jin. He had previously served the Fan and Zhonghang families, but remained unknown. He then served Zhi Bo, who greatly respected and favored him. When Zhi Bo attacked Zhao Xiangzi, Zhao Xiangzi conspired with Han and Wei to destroy Zhi Bo, dividing his territory into three. Zhao Xiangzi harbored the deepest resentment towards Zhi Bo and had his head painted black as a drinking vessel. Yu Rang fled to the mountains, saying, "Alas! A man dies for one who understands him, a woman adorns herself for one who appreciates her. Now that Zhi Bo understands me, I will surely die to avenge him, so that my soul may not be ashamed." He then changed his name and disguised himself as a convict, entering the palace to clean the latrines, carrying a dagger to assassinate Xiangzi. When Xiangzi went to the latrine, he was moved and questioned the convict cleaning the latrines. It was Yu Rang, who was carrying a weapon and said, "I wish to avenge Zhi Bo!" The guards wanted to kill him. Xiangzi said, "He is a righteous man, I will carefully avoid him. Moreover, Zhi Bo died without an heir, and his ministers want to avenge him. He is a virtuous man in the world." In the end, he let him go.
[452 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 43.4 (yr 24; partition of Jin moment). In the twenty-fourth year, Jin was in turmoil, killing Zhi Bo and dividing his kingdom among Zhao, Han, and Wei. In the twenty-fifth year, Zhi Kai and his people fled to Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 10. After a while, Yu Rang painted his body with lacquer to make himself look like a vengeful spirit, swallowed charcoal to make himself mute, and became unrecognizable, then went begging in the market. His wife did not recognize him. He met a friend, who recognized him and said, "Aren't you Yu Rang?" He replied, "I am." His friend wept, saying, "With your talent, if you were to submit to Xiangzi, he would surely favor you. With his favor, he could do as he pleases; wouldn't that be easy? Why then do you mutilate yourself to seek revenge against Xiangzi? Isn't that difficult?" Yu Rang said, "Having already submitted to someone, to seek to kill him would be to serve one's lord with two hearts. Moreover, what I am doing is extremely difficult! But the reason I do this is to shame all future generations of ministers who serve their lord with two hearts." 11. After they left, a short while later, when Xiangzi was about to depart, Yu Rang lay in ambush under the bridge he was to cross. When Xiangzi reached the bridge, his horse was startled, and Xiangzi said, "This must be Yu Rang." He sent someone to inquire, and indeed it was Yu Rang. Thereupon, Xiangzi rebuked Yu Rang, saying, "Did you not serve the Fan and Zhonghang clans? Zhi Bo annihilated them all, yet you did not avenge them, but instead submitted to Zhi Bo as a hostage. Zhi Bo is already dead, yet why do you alone harbor such deep resentment towards him?" Yu Rang replied, "When I served the Fan and Zhonghang clans, they treated me like an ordinary person, so I repaid them like an ordinary person. As for Zhi Bo, he treated me like a nobleman, so I repaid him like a nobleman." Xiangzi sighed deeply and wept, saying, "Alas, Yu Rang! Your reputation as Zhi Bo is already established, and my pardon of you is enough. You should consider your own situation; I will not release you again!" He then ordered his troops to surround Yu Rang. Yu Rang said, “I have heard that a wise ruler does not conceal the merits of others, and a loyal minister has the duty to die for his reputation. The former ruler has already pardoned me, and the whole world praises your virtue. As for today’s matter, I am willing to accept my fate, but I wish to ask for your garment to strike him, so that I may express my intention to avenge my enemy. Even in death, I will have no regrets. This is not something I dare to hope for, but I dare to lay bare my heart!” Xiangzi, moved by his righteousness, sent a messenger with the garment to Yu Rang. Yu Rang drew his sword, leaped three times, and struck him, saying, “Now I can repay Zhi Bo!” He then fell to his sword and committed suicide. On the day of his death, the loyal men of Zhao, upon hearing of this, all wept.
[451 BC]
[450 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 77. In the eighth year of Duke Ping's reign, Yue destroyed Wu. He died in the twenty-fifth year of his reign, and his son, Duke Xuan, succeeded him.
[449 BC]
[448 BC]
[447 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 63.3. In the forty-second year, Chu destroyed Cai.
[446 BC]
