[445 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 63.4. In the forty-fourth year, Chu destroyed Qi. It made peace with Qin. At this time, Yue had already destroyed Wu but could not control the area north of the Yangtze and Huai Rivers; Chu invaded eastward, expanding its territory to the Si River.
[444 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 43.5 (yr 33). In the thirty-third year, he attacked Yiqu and captured its king.
[443 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 43.6 (yr 34; eclipse; death). In the thirty-fourth year, there was a solar eclipse. Duke Li Gong died, and his son, Duke Zao, succeeded him.
[442 BC]
[441 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 62.1. In the twenty-eighth year, King Ding died, and his eldest son Quji ascended the throne as King Ai. 62.2. King Ai reigned for three months when his younger brother Shu attacked and killed him, seizing the throne as King Si. 62.3. King Si reigned for five months when his younger brother Wei attacked and killed him, seizing the throne as King Kao. All three kings were sons of King Ding. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 44.1 (Duke Zao yr 2) (Wikipedia). In the second year of Duke Zao's reign, Nanzheng rebelled.
[440 BC]
[439 BC]
[438 BC]
[437 BC]
[436 BC]
[435 BC]
[434 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 134. In the eighteenth year, Duke Ai died, and his son, Duke You, succeeded him.
[433 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 135. During the reign of Duke You, the state of Jin was fearful and turned to the rulers of Han, Zhao, and Wei. Only Jiang and Quwo remained; the rest all submitted to the three Jin states.
[432 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 64. In the fifty-seventh year, King Hui died, and his son King Jian ascended the throne.
[431 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 65.1. In the first year of King Jian's reign, he launched a northern expedition and destroyed Ju.
[430 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 44.2 (yr 13). In the thirteenth year, the Yiqu attacked, reaching the south of the Wei River. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 21.1. After Xiangzi's death, his son Zhuangzi Bai succeeded him. Tian Zhuangzi served as prime minister to Duke Xuan of Qi.
[429 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 44.3 (yr 14; death). In the fourteenth year, Duke Zao died, and his younger brother Duke Huai was enthroned. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 21.2. In the forty-third year of Duke Xuan's reign, he attacked Jin, destroyed Huangcheng, and besieged Yanghu. The following year, he attacked Lu, Ge, and Anling. The following year, he captured one city from Lu.
[428 BC]
[427 BC]
[426 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 63. In the fifteenth year of King Kao's reign, he died, and his son, King Wiryeh, ascended the throne.
[425 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 45 (Duke Huai yr 4; death) (Wikipedia). In the fourth year of Duke Huai's reign, the chief minister and other officials surrounded Duke Huai, who then committed suicide. Duke Huai's crown prince, Zhao Zi, died young, so the ministers installed Zhao Zi's son as Duke Ling. Duke Ling was Duke Huai's grandson. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 22.1. Zhuangzi died, and his son, Taigong He, succeeded him. Tian Taigong served as prime minister to Duke Xuan of Qi.
[424 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 65.2. Eight years later, Marquis Wen of Wei, Han Wuzi, and Zhao Huanzi were first listed as feudal lords.
[423 BC]
[422 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 22.2. In the forty-eighth year of Duke Xuan's reign, he captured a city of Lu. The following year, Duke Xuan met with the people of Zheng at Xicheng. He attacked Wei and captured Wuqiu. In the fifty-first year of Duke Xuan's reign, he died, and Tian Hui returned from Linqiu.
[421 BC]
[420 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 64. King Kao enfeoffed his younger brother in Henan, who became Duke Huan, to continue the official position of the Duke of Zhou. Duke Huan died, and his son Duke Wei succeeded him. Duke Wei died, and his son Duke Hui succeeded him, enfeoffing his youngest son in Gong to serve the king, who was then known as Duke Hui of Eastern Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 39. He later married a woman from the Kongtong clan and had five sons. Because Bo Lu refused to establish a successor, Xiangzi insisted on passing the throne to Bo Lu's son, who was to succeed Cheng Jun. Cheng Jun died first, so Xiangzi replaced Cheng Jun's son, Huan, as crown prince. Xiangzi reigned for thirty-three years before dying, and Huan succeeded him, becoming Marquis Xian.
[419 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 46.1 (Duke Ling yr 6) (Wikipedia). In the sixth year of Duke Ling's reign, Jin built Shaoliang, which was attacked by Qin.
[418 BC]
[417 BC]
[416 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 136. In the fifteenth year, Marquis Wen of Wei ascended the throne. In the eighteenth year, Duke You of Wei committed adultery with a woman, and the thief secretly left the city at night and murdered Duke You. Marquis Wen of Wei used his army to quell the rebellion in Jin and installed Duke You's son, Zhi, as the new ruler, who became Duke Lie.
[415 BC]
[414 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 23. Duke Xuan died, and his son, Duke Kang, succeeded him. Duke Kang reigned for fourteen years, indulging in wine and women, and neglecting state affairs. Therefore, Duke Tai exiled Duke Kang to the sea, providing him with a city to maintain his ancestral sacrifices. The following year, Lu defeated Qi at Pinglu.
[413 BC]
[412 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 46.2 (yr 13; succession crisis). In the thirteenth year, Qin built Jigu. Duke Ling died, and his son, Duke Xian, was not allowed to ascend the throne. Instead, Duke Ling's uncle, Daozi, was installed as Duke Jian. Duke Jian was the younger brother of Zhaozi and the son of Prince Huai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 6. Wu Qi was a native of Wei, skilled in military strategy. He studied under Zengzi and served the ruler of Lu. When the people of Qi attacked Lu, Lu wanted to appoint Wu Qi as general. Wu Qi married a woman from Qi, which aroused suspicion in Lu. Wu Qi, wanting to gain recognition, killed his wife to demonstrate his non-partisanship with Qi. Lu ultimately appointed him general. He then attacked Qi and decisively defeated them. 7. A man from Lu, who disliked Wu Qi, said: "Wu Qi is a suspicious and cruel man. In his youth, his family possessed a fortune of a thousand gold pieces, but his attempts to become an official failed, leading to the ruin of his family. His fellow villagers laughed at him, so Wu Qi killed more than thirty people who had slandered him, and then left east of the city gate of Wei. He bid farewell to his mother, biting his arm and swearing: 'If I do not become a minister, I will never return to Wei.' He then served Zengzi. After a while, his mother died, and Wu Qi never returned. Zengzi despised him and broke off relations with him. Wu Qi then went to Lu to study military strategy and serve the ruler of Lu. The ruler of Lu was suspicious of him, so Wu Qi killed his wife to gain the position of general. Lu is a small state, yet it has a reputation for military victory; this will attract the attention of the other states. Moreover, Lu and Wei are brother states, and if Your Majesty employs Wu Qi, it is tantamount to abandoning Wei." The ruler of Lu was suspicious and dismissed Wu Qi.
[411 BC]
[410 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 40. When Marquis Xian ascended the throne at a young age, he governed Zhongmou.
[409 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 8. Han Shijia: Kangzi died, and his son Wuzi succeeded him. In the second year of Wuzi's reign, he attacked Zheng and killed its ruler, Duke You. In the sixteenth year, Wuzi died, and his son, Marquis Jing, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 8. Wu Qi then heard of Marquis Wen of Wei's virtue and wished to serve him. Marquis Wen asked Li Ke, "What kind of person is Wu Qi?" Li Ke replied, "Wu Qi is greedy and lustful, but in military strategy, even Sima Rangju cannot surpass him." So Marquis Wen appointed him as a general, and they attacked Qin, capturing five cities. 9. When he rose to command, he shared the same clothes and food as the lowest-ranking soldiers. He slept without a mat, traveled without riding a horse, personally carried his own provisions, and shared the hardships with his soldiers. When a soldier had a boil, he would suck the pus from it. The soldier's mother heard this and wept. People said, "Your son is a soldier, yet the general sucks the pus from his own boil; why are you crying?" The mother replied, "It is not so. Years ago, General Wu sucked the pus from my father's boil, and my father fought without turning back, dying at the hands of the enemy. Now General Wu is sucking the pus from my son's boil; I do not know where he will die. That is why I weep."
[408 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 47.1 (Duke Jian yr 6) (Wikipedia). In the sixth year of Duke Jian's reign, officials were first ordered to carry swords. A trench was dug at Luo. A city was built at Chongquan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 66.1. In the twenty-fourth year, King Jian died, and his son, King Sheng, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 41. Xiangzi's younger brother, Huanzi, drove out Marquis Xian and established himself in Dai. He died a year later. The people of the state said that Huanzi's ascension was not Xiangzi's intention, so they conspired to kill Huanzi's son and reinstate Marquis Xian. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 9.1. In the first year of Duke Jing's reign, he attacked Zheng and captured Yongqiu. In the second year, Zheng defeated our Fushu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 10. Marquis Wen appointed Wu Qi as the governor of Xihe to defend against Qin and Han, because Wu Qi was skilled in military tactics, honest and fair, and able to win the hearts of his men.
[407 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 9.2. In the first year of Duke Jing's reign, he attacked Zheng and captured Yongqiu. In the second year, Zheng defeated our Fushu.
[406 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 42. In the tenth year, Duke Wu of Zhongshan was established. In the thirteenth year, he built Pingyi. In the fifteenth year, Marquis Xian died, and his son, Marquis Lieji, succeeded him.
[405 BC]
[404 BC]
[403 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 65. In the twenty-third year of King Weilie's reign, the nine tripods shook. He then appointed Han, Wei, and Zhao as feudal lords. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 16.1. In the fifteenth year, Duke Xiao died, and Duke Cheng succeeded him. In the sixteenth year of Duke Cheng's reign, Duke Min succeeded him. 16.2. In the thirty-first year of Duke Min's reign, Duke Li succeeded him. 16.3. In that year, the three states of Jin were listed as feudal lords. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 137. In the nineteenth year of Duke Lie's reign, King Weilie of Zhou granted the states of Zhao, Han, and Wei the title of feudal lords. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 43. In the first year of Marquis Lie's reign, Marquis Wen of Wei attacked Zhongshan and sent his crown prince to defend it. In the sixth year, Wei, Han, and Zhao all established themselves as feudal lords and posthumously honored Xianzi as Marquis Xian. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 10. Han Shijia: In six years, Zhao and Wei were both recognized as feudal lords. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 12. More than forty years later, the incident involving Nie Zheng occurred in Zhi. 13. Nie Zheng was a man from Shenjing Village in Zhi County. He killed someone to escape revenge and, along with his mother and sister, went to Qi County to make a living as a butcher.
[402 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 66. In the twenty-fourth year, he died, and King Zian arrogantly ascended the throne. That year, King Sheng of Chu was murdered by thieves. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 66.2. In the sixth year of King Sheng's reign, he was murdered by thieves, and his son, King Dao (Xiong Yi), succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 14. After a long time, Yan Zhongzi of Puyang served Marquis Ai of Han, and had a falling out with Xia Lei, the Chancellor of Han. Fearing execution, Yan Zhongzi fled, seeking someone who could avenge Xia Lei. Upon arriving in Qi, some people there said that Nie Zheng was a brave warrior who had hidden himself among butchers to avoid his enemies. Yan Zhongzi went to his door to invite him, returning several times before finally preparing wine to feast Nie Zheng's mother. When the wine was flowing freely, Yan Zhongzi presented a hundred yi of gold as a birthday gift to Nie Zheng's mother. Nie Zheng was astonished by his generosity and firmly thanked Yan Zhongzi. Yan Zhongzi insisted on offering his gift, but Nie Zheng declined, saying, "I am fortunate to have an elderly mother. My family is poor, and I work as a dog butcher while traveling, so I can earn enough to support her daily. My mother is well cared for, and I dare not accept your gift, Zhongzi." Yan Zhongzi dismissed the others and spoke to Nie Zheng, saying, "I have an enemy, and I have traveled to many states; however, upon arriving in Qi, I heard of your high moral character, so I offered you one hundred gold pieces to cover your humble expenses and to foster our friendship. How could I possibly have any ulterior motives?" Nie Zheng replied, "The reason I humble myself and take up this lowly butcher's post is solely to support my elderly mother; with her alive, I dare not offer myself to anyone." Yan Zhongzi insisted on declining, and Nie Zheng ultimately refused to accept it. Nevertheless, Yan Zhongzi treated him with the utmost courtesy before departing.
[401 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 15. After a long time, Nie Zheng's mother died. After her burial and the mourning period, Nie Zheng said, "Alas! I am but a commoner, a butcher wielding a knife; while Yan Zhongzi is a high-ranking official of a feudal lord, who traveled a great distance to pay homage to me. My treatment of him has been utterly insignificant; I have done nothing of great merit to deserve this. Yet Yan Zhongzi offered a hundred gold pieces to celebrate my mother's birthday. Though I refused, it shows his deep understanding of me. A wise man, driven by resentment or petty grievances, befriends even the poor and humble; how could I remain silent? Furthermore, the other day I asked him to come, but he only said it was because of my elderly mother; now that she has passed away, I will serve those who understand me." He then went west to Puyang to see Yan Zhongzi, saying, "The reason I refused you before was solely because of my mother; now, unfortunately..." "Your mother passed away peacefully. Who is the one Zhongzi wishes to avenge? Please allow me to do so!" Yan Zhongzi explained in detail: "My enemy is Xia Lei, the Chancellor of Han. Xia Lei is also the uncle of the King of Han. His clan is large and his residence is heavily guarded. I wanted to send someone to assassinate him, but none of them succeeded. Now, Your Majesty is fortunate to have not abandoned me. Please allow me to send more chariots and strong men to assist Your Majesty." Nie Zheng said: "Han and Wei are not far apart. Now, to kill the Chancellor, who is also a relative of the King, this situation cannot be handled by many people. If many people are involved, there will be risks and losses. If risks and losses occur, the matter will be exposed. If the matter is exposed, the entire state of Han will become your enemy. Wouldn't that be perilous?" He then dismissed the chariots and men and left alone. 16. Arriving in Han with his sword, Nie Zheng found the Han chancellor, Xia Lei, seated in his residence, surrounded by numerous guards armed with weapons. Nie Zheng rushed in, ascended the steps, and assassinated Xia Lei, causing chaos among the guards. Nie Zheng shouted, killing dozens of men in the process. He then gouged out his own eyes, disemboweled himself, and died. 17. Han took Nie Zheng's body and displayed it in the marketplace, asking around but no one knew who his father was. So Han went to the county to buy his body, offering a thousand gold pieces to anyone who could identify the killer of Xiang Xialei. For a long time, no one knew. 18. When Zheng's sister, Rong, heard that someone had assassinated the Chancellor of Han, but the assassin was not found and the state did not know his name, they displayed his body and put a thousand pieces of gold on the market. She then went to the town and said, "Could this be my brother? Alas, Yan Zhongzi knows my brother!" She immediately rose and went to Han, to the market, and there indeed was Zheng. She lay prostrate on the body and wept bitterly, saying, "This is the Nie Zheng from Shenjing Village in Zhi." The people in the market all said, "This man was a tyrannical Chancellor of our state. The king has put a thousand pieces of gold on his name. Have you not heard of this, madam? How dare you..." "Have you come to know him?" Rong replied, "I have heard of it. However, the reason I suffered such disgrace and was relegated to the marketplace was because my elderly mother was fortunately still alive, and I was unmarried. Now that my mother has passed away, and I am already married, Yan Zhongzi discovered my brother's plight and befriended him. His kindness is immense. What can I do? A man will die for one who understands him. Now, because I am still alive, he has severely punished himself to sever ties with her. How can I fear the punishment that awaits me after my death, and how can I possibly erase my brother's name from history?" The people of Han were greatly shocked. He cried out to Heaven three times, and died in sorrow beside Zheng in the town. 19. When the states of Jin, Chu, Qi, and Wei heard of this, they all said, "It's not just that Zheng is capable; his sister was also a virtuous woman. If Zheng had truly known that his sister had no will to endure hardship and would not have suffered the pain of exposing her body to the elements, and would have braved thousands of miles of peril to have her name inscribed on the altar, even if both he and his sister had been executed in the marketplace of Han, he might not have dared to give himself to Yan Zhongzi. Yan Zhongzi can truly be said to have a good eye for talent and the ability to attract capable men!"
[400 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 78. Duke Xuan died in the fifty-first year of his reign, and his son, Duke Kang, succeeded him. Tian Hui rebelled against Linqiu. In the second year of Duke Kang's reign, Han, Wei, and Zhao were first listed as feudal lords. In the nineteenth year, Tian He, the great-grandson of Tian Chang, became a feudal lord and moved Duke Kang's residence to the seashore. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 79.1. In the thirty-seventh year, Duke Dao died, and his son Jia succeeded him, becoming Duke Yuan. Duke Yuan died in the twenty-first year, and his son Xian succeeded him, becoming Duke Mu. Duke Mu died in the thirty-third year, and his son Fen succeeded him, becoming Duke Gong. Duke Gong died in the twenty-second year, and his son Tun succeeded him, becoming Duke Kang. Duke Kang died in the ninth year, and his son Yan succeeded him, becoming Duke Jing. Duke Jing died in the twenty-ninth year, and his son Shu succeeded him, becoming Duke Ping. At that time, all six states claimed the title of king. 79.1. In the thirty-seventh year, Duke Dao died, and his son Jia succeeded him, becoming Duke Yuan. Duke Yuan died in the twenty-first year, and his son Xian succeeded him, becoming Duke Mu. Duke Mu died in the thirty-third year, and his son Fen succeeded him, becoming Duke Gong. Duke Gong died in the twenty-second year, and his son Tun succeeded him, becoming Duke Kang. Duke Kang died in the ninth year, and his son Yan succeeded him, becoming Duke Jing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 66.3. In the second year of King Dao's reign, the three Jin states attacked Chu, reaching Chengqiu before turning back. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 11. Han Shijia: In the ninth year, Zheng besieged my Yangdi. Marquis Jing died, and his son, Marquis Lie, succeeded him.
[399 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 47.2 (yr 16; death). He died in the sixteenth year, and his son, Duke Hui, succeeded him.
[398 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 66.4. In the fourth year, Chu attacked Zhou. Zheng killed Ziyang.
[397 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 12.1. In the third year of the reign of Marquis Lie, Nie Zheng killed Xia Lei, the Chancellor of Han. In the ninth year, Qin attacked Yiyang and captured six cities. In the thirteenth year, Marquis Lie died, and his son, Marquis Wen, succeeded him. That same year, Marquis Wen of Wei died.
[396 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 11. After the death of Marquis Wen of Wei, Wu Qi served his son, Marquis Wu. Marquis Wu sailed down the West River. Midway, he looked back and said to Wu Qi, "How magnificent is the fortification of our mountains and rivers! This is the treasure of the State of Wei!" Wu Qi replied, "Virtue, not strategic advantage, is paramount. In the past, the Sanmiao people had Dongting Lake to their left and Pengli Lake to their right, but they did not cultivate virtue and righteousness, and Yu destroyed them. The Xia dynasty under Jie had the Yellow River and the Ji River to his left and Mount Tai and Mount Hua to his right, with Yique Pass to his south and Yangchang Pass to his north; he governed without benevolence, and Tang exiled him. The Yin dynasty under Zhou had Mengmen Pass to its left and Mount Taihang to its right, with Changshan Mountain to its north and the Yellow River flowing through its south; he governed without virtue, and King Wu killed him. From this, we can see that virtue, not strategic advantage, is paramount. If you, my lord, do not cultivate virtue, all those on this boat will become enemies." Marquis Wu said, "Excellent."
[395 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 44. Marquis Lie, fond of music, said to his chancellor, Gong Zhonglian, "I have a favorite; may I bestow upon him a high position?" Gong Zhonglian replied, "Wealth is acceptable, but nobility is not." Marquis Lie said, "Very well. I will grant each of the two singers from Zheng, Qiang and Shi, ten thousand mu of land." Gong Zhonglian said, "Agreed," but refused. A month later, Marquis Lie came from Dai and inquired about the singers' land. Gong Zhonglian said, "I have sought it, but none are suitable." After a while, Marquis Lie asked again. Gong Zhonglian still refused and then feigned illness to avoid court. The ruler of Fanwu came from Dai and said to Gong Zhong, "You truly love goodness, but I do not know how to uphold it. Now, Gong Zhonglian, you have been chancellor of Zhao for four years; have you produced any successful candidates?" Gong Zhonglian replied, "Not yet." The ruler of Fanwulian said, "Niu Chu, Xun Xin, and Xu Yue are all suitable." Gong Zhonglian then recommended three men. At court, Marquis Lie again asked, "What about the singers' land?" Gong Zhonglian replied, "I will have them select the best among them." Niu Chu served Marquis Lielian with benevolence and righteousness, and persuaded him with the principles of kingship; Marquis Lielian readily agreed. The next day, Xun Xin attended to the emperor, and he was tasked with selecting and training virtuous and capable officials, and appointing them to official positions. The next day, Xu Yue attended to the emperor, and he was tasked with frugality and thrift, and with assessing merit and virtue. All gifts were given generously, and the emperor was pleased. Marquis Lie sent a messenger to the prime minister, saying, "The singing field should be discontinued." The emperor appointed officials to manage cattle and livestock, made Xun Xin the Commandant of the Capital, and Xu Yue the Grand Historian, and bestowed upon the prime minister two sets of robes.
[394 BC]
[393 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 66.5. In the ninth year, Chu attacked Han and captured Fushu.
[392 BC]
[391 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 66.6. In the eleventh year, the three Jin states attacked Chu, defeating Chu at Daliang and Yuguan. Chu bribed Qin generously and made peace with them. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 12.2. In the third year of the reign of Marquis Lie, Nie Zheng killed Xia Lei, the Chancellor of Han. In the ninth year, Qin attacked Yiyang and captured six cities. In the thirteenth year, Marquis Lie died, and his son, Marquis Wen, succeeded him. That same year, Marquis Wen of Wei died.
[390 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 12. Wu Qi was appointed governor of Xihe and gained great renown. When Wei appointed a chancellor, Tian Wen was appointed. Wu Qi was displeased and said to Tian Wen, "May I discuss our achievements?" Tian Wen replied, "Yes." Wu Qi said, "In commanding the three armies, making the soldiers willing to die for their cause, and deterring enemy states from plotting against us, who can compare to me?" Tian Wen replied, "I am not as good as you." Wu Qi said, "In governing the officials, being close to the people, and filling the treasury, who can compare to me?" Tian Wen replied, "I am not as good as you." Wu Qi said, "In guarding Xihe, preventing Qin troops from advancing eastward, and gaining the allegiance of Han and Zhao, who can compare to me?" Tian Wen replied, "I am not as good as you." Wu Qi said, "In these three aspects, you are inferior to me, yet you hold a higher position than me. Why is that?" Tian Wen said, "When the ruler is young and the state is in doubt, the ministers are not yet loyal, and the people do not trust you, at that time, should the responsibility be entrusted to you or to me?" Wu Qi remained silent for a long time, then said, "It should be entrusted to you." Tian Wen said, "This is why I am above you." Wu Qi then realized that he was not as good as Tian Wen.
[389 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 138.1. In the twenty-seventh year, Duke Lie died, and his son, Duke Xiao, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 45. In the ninth year, Marquis Lie died, and his younger brother, Duke Wu, succeeded him. Duke Wu died in the thirteenth year, and Zhao reinstated Marquis Lie's son, Zhang, who became Marquis Jing. In the same year, Marquis Wen of Wei died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 13. After Tian Wen's death, Gongshu became prime minister, married a princess of Wei, and harmed Wu Qi. Gongshu's servant said, "Wu Qi will easily leave." Gongshu asked, "Why?" The servant replied, "Wu Qi is honest and upright, but also fond of fame. You, sir, first spoke to Marquis Wu, saying, 'Wu Qi is a virtuous man, but your state is small and borders the powerful Qin. I fear he will not be loyal.' Marquis Wu immediately asked, 'Why?' You then told Marquis Wu, 'Try inviting him to marry the princess. If Wu Qi is loyal, he will accept. If not, he will refuse. Divinate this.' You then summoned Wu Qi and took him home, and then made the princess angry and disrespect you. When Wu Qi sees the princess's contempt for you, he will surely refuse." Thus, Wu Qi, seeing the princess's disrespect for the Wei prime minister, indeed refused Marquis Wu. Marquis Wu was suspicious but did not believe him. Fearing punishment, Wu Qi left and went to Chu.
[388 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 48.1 (Duke Hui II yr 12) (Wikipedia). In the twelfth year of Duke Hui's reign, his son Chu was born.
[387 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 48.2 (yr 13; Shu/Nanzheng; death). In the thirteenth year, he attacked Shu and captured Nanzheng. Duke Hui died, and Chu succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 12.3. In the third year of the reign of Marquis Lie, Nie Zheng killed Xia Lei, the Chancellor of Han. In the ninth year, Qin attacked Yiyang and captured six cities. In the thirteenth year, Marquis Lie died, and his son, Marquis Wen, succeeded him. That same year, Marquis Wen of Wei died.
[386 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 32 — Qi Taigong Shijia] 79. In the twenty-sixth year, Duke Kang died, and the Lü family's ancestral rites ceased. The Tian family then ruled the state of Qi, with King Wei of Qi becoming the most powerful ruler in the land. 80. Sima Qian said: When I went to Qi, I traveled from Mount Tai to Langya, and northward to the sea. The land stretched for two thousand li, fertile and expansive. Its people were broad-minded and often shrewd, which was their nature. With the wisdom of Taigong in establishing the foundation of the state, and the prosperity of Huan Gong in implementing benevolent policies, it was fitting that they became hegemons at the alliance of feudal lords. How magnificent! Truly, this was the style of a great nation! [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 46. In the first year of the reign of Marquis Jing, Prince Wu Chao rebelled, but failed and fled to Wei. Zhao then established its capital in Handan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 24. Three years later, Taigong met with Marquis Wen of Wei at Zhuoze and requested to be recognized as a feudal lord. Marquis Wen of Wei then sent an envoy to the Zhou emperor and other feudal lords, requesting that Tian He, the prime minister of Qi, be established as a feudal lord. The Zhou emperor granted his request. In the nineteenth year of Duke Kang's reign, Tian He was established as the Marquis of Qi and placed in the Zhou court, marking the beginning of the first year.
[385 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 49 (Chuzi II yr 2; drowned) (Wikipedia). In the second year of Chu Zi's reign, the chief minister changed his mind and welcomed Duke Xian, the son of Duke Ling, to the west of the Yellow River and installed him as emperor. Chu Zi and his mother were killed and drowned beside the Abyss. Qin had changed rulers many times in the past, and the relationship between the ruler and his ministers was chaotic. Therefore, Jin became strong again and seized the land west of the Yellow River from Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 47. In the second year, we defeated Qi at Lingqiu. In the third year, we came to Wei's aid at Linqiu, inflicting a great defeat on the Qi army. In the fourth year, Wei defeated our Tutai. We built Gangping to invade Wei. In the fifth year, Qi and Wei attacked Zhao on behalf of Wei, capturing our Gangping. In the sixth year, we borrowed troops from Chu to attack Wei, capturing Jipu. In the eighth year, we captured Huangcheng of Wei. In the ninth year, we attacked Qi. Qi attacked Yan, and Zhao came to Yan's aid. In the tenth year, we fought against Zhongshan at Fangzi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 13.1. In the second year of Marquis Wen's reign, he attacked Zheng and captured Yangcheng. He then attacked Song, reaching Pengcheng and capturing the ruler of Song. In the seventh year, he attacked Qi, reaching Sangqiu. Zheng rebelled against Jin. In the ninth year, he attacked Qi again, reaching Lingqiu. In the tenth year, Marquis Wen died, and his son, Marquis Ai, succeeded him. 13.2. In the second year of Marquis Wen's reign, he attacked Zheng and captured Yangcheng. He then attacked Song, reaching Pengcheng and capturing the ruler of Song. In the seventh year, he attacked Qi, reaching Sangqiu. Zheng rebelled against Jin. In the ninth year, he attacked Qi again, reaching Lingqiu. In the tenth year, Marquis Wen died, and his son, Marquis Ai, succeeded him.
[384 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.1 (Duke Xian [later] yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Xian's reign, he was executed.
[383 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.2 (yr 2). In the second year, he fortified Liyang.
[382 BC]
[381 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.3 (yr 4; Duke Xiao born). In the fourth year, on the day of Gengyin in the first month, Duke Xiao was born. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 66.7. In the twenty-first year, King Dao died, and his son, King Su (Zang), succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 14. King Dao of Chu had long admired Wu Qi's wisdom and appointed him prime minister upon his arrival. He clarified laws and decrees, abolished unnecessary official positions, and dismissed distant members of the royal family to support soldiers engaged in battle. His aim was to strengthen the army and suppress those who spread rumors and advocated diplomacy. As a result, he pacified the Baiyue in the south, annexed Chen and Cai in the north, repelled the three Jin states, and launched a western campaign against Qin. The other states feared Chu's strength. Therefore, the nobles and relatives of Chu all wanted to harm Wu Qi. When King Dao died, the royal family and ministers rebelled and attacked Wu Qi. Wu Qi fled to the king's corpse and lay prostrate there. Those who attacked Wu Qi then shot and stabbed him, also hitting King Dao. After King Dao was buried, the crown prince ascended the throne and ordered the chief minister to execute all those who had shot Wu Qi and hit the king's corpse. More than seventy families were exterminated or killed for shooting Wu Qi. 15 (authorial). Sima Qian said: The common understanding of military strategy relies heavily on Sun Tzu's Thirteen Chapters and Wu Qi's Art of War, which are widely available and therefore not discussed here. Instead, we will focus on their practical applications. As the saying goes, "He who can do it may not be good at talking about it, and he who can talk about it may not be good at doing it." Sun Tzu's strategies against Pang Juan were clear, yet he could not avert disaster before Pang Juan's execution. Wu Qi persuaded Zhuge Liang that strategy was inferior to virtue, yet he implemented these principles in Chu, and his cruelty and lack of compassion led to his own demise. How tragic!
[380 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 1. Su Qin was a native of Luoyang in the Eastern Zhou Dynasty. He studied under a master in Qi and learned from Master Guigu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 1. Zhang Yi was a man from Wei. He initially studied under Master Guigu alongside Su Qin, and in their scholarship, Su Qin himself admitted that he was inferior to Zhang Yi.
[379 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 13.3. In the second year of Marquis Wen's reign, he attacked Zheng and captured Yangcheng. He then attacked Song, reaching Pengcheng and capturing the ruler of Song. In the seventh year, he attacked Qi, reaching Sangqiu. Zheng rebelled against Jin. In the ninth year, he attacked Qi again, reaching Lingqiu. In the tenth year, Marquis Wen died, and his son, Marquis Ai, succeeded him.
[378 BC]
[377 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 67.1. In the fourth year of King Su's reign, Shu attacked Chu and captured this region. Chu then built a defensive pass to resist them. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 13.4. In the second year of Marquis Wen's reign, he attacked Zheng and captured Yangcheng. He then attacked Song, reaching Pengcheng and capturing the ruler of Song. In the seventh year, he attacked Qi, reaching Sangqiu. Zheng rebelled against Jin. In the ninth year, he attacked Qi again, reaching Lingqiu. In the tenth year, Marquis Wen died, and his son, Marquis Ai, succeeded him.
[376 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 139. In the second year of Duke Jing's reign, after the conquest of Jin by Marquis Wu of Wei, Marquis Ai of Han, and Marquis Jing of Zhao, the state divided its territory into three parts. Duke Jing was then relocated to a lower-ranking household, and the state ceased to offer sacrifices to the emperor. 140. Sima Qian said: Duke Wen of Jin was considered a wise ruler in ancient times. He lived in exile for nineteen years, enduring hardship and poverty. Even upon ascending the throne and distributing rewards, he forgot Jie Zitui (Duke Wen's courtesy name). How much more so would an arrogant ruler forget such a ruler? After Duke Ling was murdered, the reigns of Dukes Cheng and Jing were harsh, and Duke Li was extremely cruel. The ministers feared execution, and disaster struck. After Duke Dao, the dynasty declined daily, and the six ministers seized power. Therefore, the way of a ruler in governing his subjects is indeed not easy! [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 48. In the eleventh year, Wei, Han, and Zhao jointly destroyed Jin and divided its territory. They attacked Zhongshan and fought again at Zhongren. In the twelfth year, Marquis Jing died, and his son, Marquis Cheng, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 13.5. In the second year of Marquis Wen's reign, he attacked Zheng and captured Yangcheng. He then attacked Song, reaching Pengcheng and capturing the ruler of Song. In the seventh year, he attacked Qi, reaching Sangqiu. Zheng rebelled against Jin. In the ninth year, he attacked Qi again, reaching Lingqiu. In the tenth year, Marquis Wen died, and his son, Marquis Ai, succeeded him. 14.1. In the first year of Marquis Ai's reign, he divided the state of Jin with Zhao and Wei. In the second year, he destroyed Zheng and moved the capital to Zheng.
[375 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 49. In the first year of Marquis Cheng's reign, Prince Sheng and Marquis Cheng vied for the throne, causing chaos. In the second year, in June, it snowed. In the third year, Tai Wuwu became prime minister. They attacked Wei, capturing seventy-three villages. Wei defeated Lin. In the fourth year, they fought Qin at Gao'an and defeated them. In the fifth year, they attacked Qi at Juan. Wei defeated Huai. They attacked Zheng, defeated it, and gave it to Han, who then gave it to their eldest son. In the sixth year, Zhongshan built the Great Wall. They attacked Wei, defeated Yuze, and besieged King Hui of Wei. In the seventh year, they invaded Qi, reaching the Great Wall. They attacked Zhou with Han. In the eighth year, they divided Zhou with Han. In the ninth year, they fought Qi at Axia. In the tenth year, they attacked Wei and captured Zhen. In the eleventh year, Qin attacked Wei, and Zhao came to its aid at Shi'a. In the twelfth year, Qin attacked Shaoliang of Wei, and Zhao came to its aid. In the thirteenth year, Duke Xian of Qin sent his chief minister Guo to attack Shaoliang of Wei, capturing its crown prince and Cuo. Wei defeated Hui and captured Pilao. Marquis Cheng and Marquis Zhao of Han met at Shangdang. In the fourteenth year, he joined forces with Han to attack Qin. In the fifteenth year, he assisted Wei in attacking Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 14.2. In the first year of Marquis Ai's reign, he divided the state of Jin with Zhao and Wei. In the second year, he destroyed Zheng and moved the capital to Zheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 25.1. In the second year of Duke Tai of Qi's reign, He died, and his son, Duke Huan of Qi, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 2. Zhang Yi had already learned how to persuade the feudal lords. Once, he was drinking with the Prime Minister of Chu when the Prime Minister lost a jade disc. His retainers suspected Zhang Yi, saying, "Zhang Yi is poor and unscrupulous; he must have stolen the Prime Minister's jade disc." They seized Zhang Yi, whipped him hundreds of times, but he refused to confess, so they released him. His wife said, "Alas! If you hadn't studied and traveled to persuade the feudal lords, how could you have suffered such humiliation?" Zhang Yi said to his wife, "Look, is my tongue still there?" His wife laughed and said, "Yes, it is." Zhang Yi said, "That's enough."
[374 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 67. King An reigned for twenty-six years before his death, and his son, King Lie, succeeded him. In the second year of King Lie's reign, the Zhou Grand Historian Dan met with Duke Xian of Qin and said, "Initially, Zhou and Qin were united and then separated. After five hundred years of separation, they were reunited. After seventeen years of reunification, a hegemon will emerge." [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.4 (yr 11; prophecy). In the eleventh year, the Grand Historian Dan of Zhou met with Duke Xian and said, "Zhou was once united with Qin, then separated. After five hundred years of separation, they reunited, and after seventy-seven years, a hegemon will emerge."
[373 BC]
[372 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 17.1. In the thirtieth year of Duke Li's reign, he defeated Qi at Linying. Duke Li died, and Duke Huan ascended the throne. Duke Huan died in the eleventh year of his reign, and Duke Wen ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 2. After traveling for several years, he returned home exhausted. His brothers, sisters-in-law, wives, and concubines all secretly laughed at him, saying, "The customs of the Zhou people are to manage their property, engage in commerce and industry, and make a living by pursuing two-tenths of their wealth. Now you have abandoned your livelihood to indulge in empty talk; is it not fitting that you are in trouble?" Su Qin heard this and felt ashamed and saddened. He then secluded himself in his room and read extensively. He said, "A scholar has already bowed his head to receive books, but if he cannot use them to gain honor, what use are they, even if they are numerous?" Thereupon, he obtained the * Zhou Shu* (Book of Zhou ) and secretly studied it. After a year, he went out to ponder it and said, "This can be used to persuade the rulers of the present age." He then sought to persuade King Xian of Zhou. King Xian's attendants, who were familiar with Su Qin, all looked down on him and did not believe him.
[371 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 67.2. In the tenth year, Wei captured Luyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 15. Han Shijia: In the sixth year, Han Yan murdered his ruler, Marquis Ai. His son, Marquis Yi, then ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 25.2. In the fifth year of Duke Huan of Qi's reign, Qin and Wei attacked Han, and Han sought help from Qi. Duke Huan of Qi summoned his ministers and consulted them, saying, "Should we help them early or late?" Zou Ji said, "It is better not to help them." Duan Ganpeng said, "If we do not help them, Han will be defeated and fall into Wei's hands. It is better to help them." Tian Chensi said, "Your plan is flawed! If Qin and Wei attack Han and Chu, Zhao will surely come to their aid. This is Heaven giving Yan to Qi." Duke Huan said, "Excellent." He then secretly informed the envoy from Han and sent him away. Han, believing it had received Qi's aid, fought against Qin and Wei. Chu and Zhao, upon hearing this, indeed raised troops to come to its aid. Qi then raised troops to attack Yan and captured Sangqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 3. He then went west to Qin. Duke Xiao of Qin died. He said to King Hui, "Qin is a country surrounded by mountains on all sides, bordered by the Wei River, with the Guanzhong Plain to the east, Hanzhong to the west, Ba and Shu to the south, and Dai and Mazhou to the north. This is a land of plenty. With the large number of Qin's soldiers and people, and the teachings of its military strategy, it can conquer the world and rule as emperor." King Hui of Qin said, "Without fully developed feathers, one cannot soar high; without clear understanding of principles, one cannot conquer other countries." He was currently executing Shang Yang and disliked debaters, so he did not employ them.
[370 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 67.3. In the eleventh year, King Su died without an heir, and his younger brother Xiong Liangfu was enthroned as King Xuan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 2. After Sun Tzu's death, more than a hundred years later came Sun Bin. Bin was born in Ajuan, and was also a descendant of Sun Tzu. Sun Bin once studied military strategy with Pang Juan. After Pang Juan served Wei and became a general under King Hui, he considered himself inferior to Sun Bin and secretly summoned him. When Bin arrived, Pang Juan, fearing he was more capable than himself, became resentful and had both of Sun Bin's feet cut off and tattooed, intending to hide him from everyone. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 4. The Zhao state was located east of Zhao. Zhao Suhou appointed his younger brother Cheng as prime minister, giving him the title of Lord Fengyang. Lord Fengyang was displeased with him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 3. Su Qin had already persuaded the King of Zhao to agree to a marriage alliance, but fearing that Qin might attack the other states and break the agreement, and realizing there was no one else who could be of use to Qin, he sent someone to subtly suggest to Zhang Yi, "You were once on good terms with Su Qin, and now Qin is in power. Why don't you go and seek an audience with them to fulfill your wishes?" Zhang Yi then went to Zhao and went to see Su Qin. Su Qin instructed his servants not to grant him an audience and kept him waiting for several days. Finally, he saw Zhang Yi, seated him below the hall, and fed him with the food of servants and concubines. He then repeatedly rebuked Zhang Yi, saying, "With your talent and ability, you have brought this humiliation upon yourself. I would rather be unable to speak and yet you become rich and powerful; you are not worthy of my attention." Zhang Yi then left. Zhang Yi, having come thinking of an old friend and seeking benefit, was instead humiliated. Enraged, he realized that none of the other states were worth serving, only Qin could bring Zhao suffering, and thus he went to Qin. 4. Su Qin then told his retainer, "Zhang Yi is a worthy man of the world, far surpassing my own abilities. Now, I am fortunate to have him employed first, and among those who can wield power in Qin, only Zhang Yi is truly capable. However, he is poor and has no means to advance his career. I fear he will be tempted by small gains and thus fail to achieve his ambitions, so I summoned and humiliated him to provoke his ambition. Please secretly serve him for me." He then spoke to King Zhao, who provided Zhang Yi with gold, coins, carriages, and horses, and sent someone to secretly follow him, sharing his quarters and gradually approaching him. Zhang Yi was then given carriages, horses, gold, and horses, and whatever he desired was provided for without being informed. Thus, Zhang Yi was able to meet King Hui of Qin. King Hui appointed him as a guest minister and conspired with him to attack the other states.
[369 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.1. In the tenth year, King Lie died, and his younger brother Bian ascended the throne as King Xian. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.5 (yr 16; winter blossoms). In the sixteenth year, peach blossoms bloomed in winter. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 50. In the sixteenth year, Jin was divided with Han and Wei, and the ruler of Jin was enfeoffed with the surname Duan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 16.1. In the second year of Marquis Yi's reign, Wei defeated us at Maling. In the fifth year, we met with King Hui of Wei at Zhaiyang. In the ninth year, Wei defeated us at Hui. In the twelfth year, Marquis Yi died, and his son Marquis Zhao succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 5. Su Qin's retainer then took his leave. Zhang Yi said, "I owe your rise to prominence and am about to repay your kindness. Why do you leave?" The retainer replied, "I do not know you, but Su Qin does. Su Qin was worried that Qin's attack on Zhao would lead to the failure of the treaty, and he believed that no one but you could gain control of Qin. Therefore, he was angered by you and sent me to secretly provide you with funds and to implement Su Qin's strategies. Now that you have employed me, I wish to return and report back." Zhang Yi said, "Alas, this was within my own plans, yet I did not realize it. I am far less astute than Su Qin! I am newly employed; how could I possibly plan against Zhao? Please apologize to Su Qin for me. When Su Qin was in power, how dare I speak? And even with Su Qin still alive, how could I possibly be capable?" After Zhang Yi became the prime minister of Qin, he wrote a proclamation to the prime minister of Chu, saying, "When I first drank with you, I did not steal the jade, yet you flogged me. If you guard your country well, I will steal the city!"
[368 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 5. I traveled to Yan, and it took more than a year before I was able to see him again. I told Marquis Wen of Yan, "To the east of Yan are Korea and Liaodong, to the north are the Linhu and Loufan, to the west are Yunzhong and Jiuyuan, and to the south are the Yi River and the Yellow River. The territory is more than two thousand li, with hundreds of thousands of armored soldiers, six hundred chariots, and six thousand cavalry. The grain supply lasts for several years. To the south are the abundance of Jieshi and Yanmen, and to the north are the benefits of dates and chestnuts. Even if the people do not farm, they will have enough to eat of dates and chestnuts. This is what is called a land of plenty." 6. In times of peace and tranquility, where no army is ever defeated or generals killed, there is none more valiant than Yan. Does Your Majesty know the reason for this? The reason Yan does not attack and be armed is because Zhao protects its southern border. In the five battles between Qin and Zhao, Qin won twice and Zhao won three. Qin and Zhao perished, but Your Majesty preserved Yan and controlled its rear. This is why Yan does not attack. Moreover, when Qin attacked Yan, it crossed Yunzhong and Jiuyuan, passed Dai and Shanggu, covering thousands of miles. Even if it captured Yan, Qin could not hold it. It is clear that Qin could not harm Yan. Now, when Zhao attacks Yan, it issues orders and commands, and within ten days, hundreds of thousands of troops are already at Dongyuan. Crossing the Yutuo and fording the Yi River, within four or five days, they are at the capital. Therefore, it is said that when Qin attacks Yan, the battle is fought a thousand miles away; when Zhao attacks Yan, the battle is fought within a hundred miles. There is no better strategy than to worry about the dangers a hundred miles away and focus on the dangers a thousand miles away. Therefore, I wish Your Majesty would establish friendly relations with Zhao, unify the world, and then Yan will surely be free from trouble. 7. Marquis Wen said, “What you say is acceptable, but my country is small, bordered by the powerful Zhao to the west and Qi to the south, both of which are powerful states. If you insist on forming an alliance to secure Yan, I will offer my country in exchange for that.”
[367 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.6 (yr 18). In the eighteenth year, rain fell on Liyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 51. In the seventeenth year, Marquis Cheng met with King Hui of Wei at Ge Nie. In the nineteenth year, he met with Qi and Song at Pinglu, and with Yan at A. In the twentieth year, Wei presented Rongchuan, which was then used to build the Tantai Terrace. In the twenty-first year, Wei besieged Handan. In the twenty-second year, King Hui of Wei captured Handan, and Qi also defeated Wei at Guiling. In the twenty-fourth year, Wei returned Handan to Handan, and an alliance was formed with Wei on the Zhang River. Qin attacked Lin. In the twenty-fifth year, Marquis Cheng died. Prince Xian and Crown Prince Su vied for the throne; Xian was defeated and fled to Han. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 8. So Su Qin was provided with carriages, horses, gold, and silk to go to Zhao. Since Lord Fengyang had already died, Su Qin then said to Marquis Su of Zhao, “All the ministers, officials, and commoners of the world admire your virtuous conduct and have long wished to serve you and pledge their loyalty. However, because you, Lord Fengyang, have not fulfilled your duties, your guests and scholars have not dared to dedicate themselves to serving you. Now that Lord Fengyang has abandoned his residence, you are now again connecting with the people and scholars. Therefore, I dare to offer my humble opinion.” 9. My humble advice to Your Majesty is that nothing is better than ensuring the people's well-being and eliminating any need for them to be involved in any conflict. The foundation of ensuring the people's well-being lies in choosing your allies wisely. If you choose wisely, the people will be at peace; if you choose unwisely, they will be in constant unrest. Let me address the external threats: Qi and Qin are two enemies, and the people cannot be at peace. If you rely on Qin to attack Qi, the people cannot be at peace; if you rely on Qi to attack Qin, the people cannot be at peace. Therefore, rulers who plot against others and conquer other states often utter words to sever ties with their allies. I urge Your Majesty to refrain from uttering such words. Let me distinguish between black and white, which is simply yin and yang. If Your Majesty truly listens to my advice, Yan will surely offer you lands of fine furs, dogs, and horses; Qi will surely offer you seas of fish and salt; Chu will surely offer you orchards of oranges and pomelos; Han, Wei, and Zhongshan can all be made to offer you provisions and gifts; and your relatives, fathers, and brothers can all be enfeoffed as marquises. The cession of territory and the offering of benefits were what the Five Hegemons sought by defeating armies and capturing generals; the enfeoffment of marquises and noble relatives were what Tang and Wu sought by punishing murderers and vying for power. Now Your Majesty can enjoy both without lifting a finger, and this is what I wish for Your Majesty.
[366 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 10. If Your Majesty allies with Qin, Qin will surely weaken Han and Wei; if you allies with Qi, Qi will surely weaken Chu and Wei. If Wei is weak, it will cede the land beyond the Yellow River; if Han is weak, it will offer sacrifices to Yiyang; if Yiyang offers sacrifices, Shangjun will be cut off; if the land beyond the Yellow River is ceded, the roads will be blocked; if Chu is weak, it will have no allies. These three strategies must be carefully considered. 11. If Qin attacks Zhidao, Nanyang will be in danger; if it seizes Han and Baozhou, Zhao will take up arms; if it takes Wei and Juan, Qi will surely pay homage to Qin. If Qin desires to have all of Shandong, it will surely raise an army against Zhao. If Qin's army crosses the river and the Zhang River and takes Fanwu, then the army will surely fight at Handan. This is what I worry about for you, my lord.
[365 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 16.2. In the second year of Marquis Yi's reign, Wei defeated us at Maling. In the fifth year, we met with King Hui of Wei at Zhaiyang. In the ninth year, Wei defeated us at Hui. In the twelfth year, Marquis Yi died, and his son Marquis Zhao succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 12. At this time, no state in Shandong is stronger than Zhao. Zhao has a territory of over two thousand li, hundreds of thousands of armored soldiers, a thousand chariots, ten thousand cavalry, and enough grain to last for several years. To the west lies Changshan, to the south the He and Zhang rivers, to the east the Qing River, and to the north the state of Yan. Yan is a weak state and not to be feared. Qin has harmed the world more than Zhao, yet Qin dares not launch a military campaign against Zhao. Why? Because it fears the advice of Han and Wei regarding its future. Thus, Han and Wei are Zhao's southern shield. When Qin attacks Han and Wei, there are no major mountains or rivers to hinder them; they gradually erode their territory until they reach the capital. Han and Wei cannot withstand Qin and will inevitably become its subjects. If Qin does not have the support of Han and Wei, then disaster will surely befall Zhao. This is what I, your subject, worry about for you, my lord. 13. I have heard that Yao had no three men to share, Shun had no land to his name, yet he possessed the world; Yu had no hundred men to his name, yet he became king of the feudal lords; Tang and Wu had no more than three thousand soldiers, no more than three hundred chariots, and no more than thirty thousand troops, yet they became emperors: truly they understood the way. Therefore, a wise ruler assesses the strength of his enemy and the competence of his soldiers, and even before the two armies are evenly matched, the outcome of victory or defeat, survival or death, is already clear in his mind. How can he let the opinions of the masses obscure his decisions and make decisions in the dark?
[364 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.2. In the fifth year of King Xian's reign, he congratulated Duke Xian of Qin, who then proclaimed himself Hegemon. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.7 (yr 21; Shimen). In the twenty-first year, he fought Jin at Shimen, beheading 60,000, and the emperor congratulated him with embroidered robes. [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 138.2. In the ninth year of Duke Xiao's reign, Marquis Wu of Wei, newly enthroned, attacked Handan but was defeated and forced to retreat. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 68.1. In the sixth year of King Xuan's reign, the Zhou emperor congratulated Duke Xian of Qin. Qin began to regain its strength, while the three Jin states grew increasingly powerful, with King Hui of Wei and King Wei of Qi being particularly strong. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 14. I have surmised that the land of the empire is five times that of Qin, and that the armies of the other states are ten times that of Qin. If the six states were united and attacked Qin from the west, Qin would surely be defeated. Now, we are turning west to serve Qin and becoming its subjects. How can the difference between defeating others and being defeated by others, between serving others and being served by others, be compared? 15. The men of Heng all desire to cede the lands of the feudal lords to Qin. If Qin succeeds, then they will build high terraces and beautiful palaces, where one can hear the sounds of flutes and zithers. In front of them will be towering buildings and behind them will be beautiful women. The country will suffer from Qin's troubles but will not share in their worries. Therefore, the men of Heng are busy day and night using Qin's power to intimidate the feudal lords in order to obtain land. I hope Your Majesty will consider this carefully.
[363 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 16. I have heard that wise rulers eliminate suspicion and slander, banish rumors, and close the gates of factions. Therefore, I have already presented my loyal advice to Your Majesty on expanding your territory and strengthening your army. Thus, I humbly suggest that Your Majesty unite Han, Wei, Qi, Chu, Yan, and Zhao to form an alliance against Qin. Let all the generals and ministers of the realm meet on the Huan River, exchange credentials, and swear an oath by gutting a white horse. The agreement should state: 'If Qin attacks Chu, Qi and Wei will each send elite troops to assist it; Han will cut off its supply lines; Zhao will cross the Yellow River and the Zhang River; and Yan will defend the north of Changshan. If Qin attacks Han and Wei, Chu will cut off its rear; Qi will send elite troops to assist it; Zhao will cross the Yellow River and the Zhang River; and Yan will defend the north of Changshan.' If Qin attacks Qi, then Chu will cut off its rear, Han will defend Chenggao, Wei will block its roads, Zhao will cross the Yellow River and the Zhang and Bo Passes, and Yan will send elite troops to assist it. If Qin attacks Yan, then Zhao will defend Changshan, Chu will send troops to Wu Pass, Qi will cross the Bohai Sea, and Han and Wei will both send elite troops to assist it. If Qin attacks Zhao, then Han will send troops to Yiyang, Chu will send troops to Wu Pass, Wei will send troops outside the Yellow River, Qi will cross the Qing River, and Yan will send elite troops to assist it. If any of the feudal lords does not comply with the agreement, the armies of the five states will jointly attack them. If the six states form alliances to befriend Qin, then Qin's army will certainly not dare to cross the Hangu Pass to harm the mountains east of the Yellow River. In this way, the hegemony will be achieved. 17. King Zhao said, "I am young and have only recently established my kingdom. I have never heard of any long-term plans for the state. Now, Your Excellency intends to preserve the world and bring peace to the feudal lords. I respectfully follow you with my kingdom." He then decorated a hundred carriages, provided a thousand taels of gold, a hundred pairs of white jade, and a thousand bolts of brocade to win over the feudal lords.
[362 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.8 (yr 23; Shaoliang). In the twenty-third year, he fought Wei and Jin at Shaoliang, capturing their general Gongsun Cuo. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 17.2. In the same year, Duke Xian of Qin died. Qin grew increasingly powerful. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 16.3. In the second year of Marquis Yi's reign, Wei defeated us at Maling. In the fifth year, we met with King Hui of Wei at Zhaiyang. In the ninth year, Wei defeated us at Hui. In the twelfth year, Marquis Yi died, and his son Marquis Zhao succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 18. At that time, the Zhou emperor presented sacrificial offerings of civil and military officials to King Hui of Qin. King Hui sent Xi Shou to attack Wei, captured the general Long Jia, seized Diaoyin in Wei, and intended to send troops eastward. Su Qin, fearing that Qin troops would reach Zhao, provoked Zhang Yi and sent him to Qin.
[361 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 50.9 (yr 24; death; Duke Xiao succeeds). In the twenty-fourth year, Duke Xian died, and his son Duke Xiao ascended the throne at the age of twenty-one. 51.1 (Duke Xiao yr 1; geopolitical overview) (Wikipedia). In the first year of Duke Xiao's reign, there were six powerful states east of the Yellow River and the mountains, along with Qi Wei, Chu Xuan, Wei Hui, Yan Dao, Han Ai, and Zhao Chenghou. There were also more than ten smaller states between the Huai and Si rivers. Chu and Wei bordered Qin. Wei built a Great Wall, extending north of the Luo River from Zheng, with Shangjun as its capital. Chu extended south of Hanzhong to Ba and Qianzhong. The Zhou dynasty was weakened, and the feudal lords vied for power, vying for control. Qin, located in the remote Yongzhou, did not participate in the alliances of the central states and was treated by the barbarians. Duke Xiao then bestowed favors, aided the orphans and widows, recruited soldiers, and clearly defined rewards for merit. 51.2 (same year; Duke Xiao edict). He issued an edict throughout the kingdom, saying: "In the past, my Duke Mu, from the border of Qi and Yong, cultivated virtue and practiced military prowess. He pacified the chaos in Jin in the east, using the Yellow River as the boundary, and dominated the Rong and Di tribes in the west, expanding the territory by a thousand li. The Son of Heaven bestowed upon him the title of Hegemon, and all the feudal lords offered their congratulations. He laid the foundation for future generations, which was very glorious. However, in the past, the reigns of Duke Li, Duke Zao, Duke Jian, and Duke Chu caused unrest in the country, and the state was troubled internally, leaving no time for foreign affairs. The three Jin states attacked and seized the land west of the Yellow River from my late lord, and the feudal lords despised Qin, which was extremely shameful. When Duke Xian ascended the throne, he pacified the borders, moved the capital to Liyang, and wanted to launch an eastern expedition to recover the former lands of Duke Mu and restore Duke Mu's policies. I have always cherished the intentions of my late lord, and it pains me deeply. If any of my guests and ministers can devise an extraordinary plan to strengthen Qin, I will bestow upon them high office and share land with them." Thereupon, he sent troops to the east to besiege Shan City and to the west to kill the Rong king. 52 (Duke Xiao yr 1; Shang Yang arrives). Upon hearing of this order, Wei Yang went west to Qin and, through Jing Jian, sought an audience with Duke Xiao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 79.2. Duke Jing died in the twenty-ninth year, and his son Shu succeeded him, becoming Duke Ping. At that time, all six states claimed the title of king. 79.2. Duke Jing died in the twenty-ninth year, and his son Shu succeeded him, becoming Duke Ping. At that time, all six states claimed the title of king. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 52. In the first year of Duke Su's reign, he seized the throne of Duke Duan of Jin and exiled him to Tunliu. In the second year, he encountered King Hui of Wei at Yin Jin. In the third year, Prince Fan attacked Handan but was defeated and died. In the fourth year, he paid homage to the emperor. In the sixth year, he attacked Qi and captured Gaotang. In the seventh year, Prince Ke attacked Shouyuan of Wei. In the eleventh year, Duke Xiao of Qin sent Shang Yang to attack Wei, capturing its general Prince Ang. Zhao attacked Wei. In the twelfth year, Duke Xiao of Qin died, and Shang Yang also died. In the fifteenth year, the construction of Shouling was completed. King Hui of Wei died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 17.1. In the first year of Duke Zhao's reign, Qin defeated us at Xishan. In the second year, Song captured Huangchi. Wei captured Zhu. In the sixth year, they attacked Eastern Zhou and captured Lingguan and Xingqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 1.1. Lord Shang was a son of a concubine of the Duke of Wei, named Yang, surnamed Gongsun, whose ancestors were originally of the Ji clan. From a young age, Yang was fond of the study of law and administration, and served as a junior official under the Duke of Wei, Gongshu Zuo. Gongshu Zuo recognized his talent but did not promote him. 1.2. When Gongshu Zuo fell ill, King Hui of Wei personally visited him and inquired about his health, saying, "Gongshu, your illness is becoming increasingly serious; what will become of the state?" Gongshu Zuo replied, "My junior official, Gongsun Yang, though young, possesses extraordinary talent. I urge Your Majesty to appoint him to a high position." The king remained silent. 1.3. As the king was about to leave, Gongshu Zuo dismissed his attendants and said, "If Your Majesty does not appoint Yang, you must kill him and prevent him from leaving the country." The king agreed and departed. 1.4. Gongshu Zuo summoned Yang and said, “Just now, the king asked who could be prime minister, and I suggested you, but the king's expression was disapproving. I always put the king before myself, so I told the king that if he didn't employ me, he should kill me. The king agreed. You should leave quickly, or you will be captured.” Yang said, “If the king cannot heed your words to appoint me, how can he also heed your words to kill me?” He ultimately did not leave. 1.5. After King Hui left, he said to his attendants, “Gongshu is very ill. It is sad that he wants me to entrust the kingdom to Gongsun Yang. Is this not absurd?” 2.1. After Gongshu's death, Gongsun Yang heard that Duke Xiao of Qin had issued an order seeking worthy men throughout the country, intending to revive the legacy of Duke Mu and reclaim the lost territories in the east. He then traveled west to Qin and, through Jing Jian, a favored minister of Duke Xiao, requested an audience with the Duke. Duke Xiao met with Wei Yang and spoke for a long time, but Duke Xiao frequently dozed off and did not listen. After the meeting, Duke Xiao angrily said to Jing Jian, "Your guest is a charlatan; how can he be of any use!" Jing Jian rebuked Wei Yang. Wei Yang said, "I tried to persuade you of the way of the emperor, but your mind remained unmoved." 2.3. Five days later, he again requested an audience with Wei Yang. 2.4. Wei Yang met with Duke Xiao again, and his understanding had improved, but he still did not achieve his goal. After the meeting, Duke Xiao again rebuked Jing Jian, who in turn rebuked Wei Yang. Wei Yang said, "I tried to persuade you of the way of the king, but you did not understand. Please allow me to see you again." Wei Yang met with Duke Xiao again, who appreciated his advice but did not employ him. He then left. Duke Xiao said to Jing Jian, "Your guest is excellent; you may speak with him now." Yang replied, "I spoke to you about the way of hegemony, and you intend to employ him. If you see me again, I will know." 2.5. Wei Yang then saw Duke Xiao again. The Duke spoke with him, unaware that he had stepped forward onto the mat. They spoke for several days without tiring of each other. Jing Jian said, "How did you please my lord? You are the source of his joy." Yang replied, "I spoke to you about the way of emperors, comparing it to the Three Dynasties, but you said, 'It is too far off; I cannot wait. Moreover, wise rulers achieve fame and renown throughout the world in their lifetime; how can they patiently wait for decades or centuries to become emperors?' Therefore, I spoke to you about the art of strengthening the state, and you were greatly pleased. However, it is still difficult to compare its virtue to that of the Yin and Zhou dynasties." [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 19. So King Xuan of Han said, "Han has the fortified passes of Gong and Chenggao to the north, the strategic passes of Yiyang and Shangban to the west, the Wan, Rang, and Wei rivers to the east, and Xing Mountain to the south. Its territory spans over nine hundred li, and it has hundreds of thousands of armored soldiers. All the strongest bows and crossbows in the land come from Han. The commanders of the Xizi and Shaofu, when facing the enemy, can shoot from six hundred paces away. Han soldiers can shoot with leaping speed, firing a hundred shots in a row without stopping. Those at a distance are pierced through the chest, and those at close range are struck in the heart. The swords and halberds of Han soldiers all come from the Ming Mountain..." Tangxi, Moyang, Hefu, Dengshi, Wanfeng, Longyuan, and Tai'a are all formidable warriors, capable of cutting through oxen and horses on land and swans and geese on water. When facing the enemy, they can cleave through heavily armored and iron-clad figures, and are fully equipped with weapons like the legendary swords and spears. Even with the bravery of the Han soldiers, clad in strong armor, armed with powerful crossbows and sharp swords, one man could easily be worth a hundred. Yet, given the strength of Han and Your Majesty's wisdom, you have turned west to serve Qin, surrendering without hesitation, bringing shame upon your state and becoming a laughingstock to the world. There is nothing greater than this. Therefore, I urge Your Majesty to consider this carefully. 20. Your Majesty serves Qin, and Qin will surely demand Yiyang and Chenggao. If you follow suit now, they will again demand land next year. If you give in, you will have no land to supply them; if you refuse, you will lose your previous gains and suffer future disasters. Moreover, Your Majesty's land is finite, but Qin's demands are endless. To resist endless demands with finite land is what is meant by creating resentment and sowing disaster. Without a fight, your land will be diminished. I have heard a proverb that says, 'Better to be the head of a chicken than the tail of an ox.' Now you are serving Qin with your arms crossed, how are you any different from the tail of an ox? With Your Majesty's wisdom and the power of the strong Han army, to have the name of a tail of an ox is shameful on Your Majesty's behalf. 21. King Han then became enraged, raised his arms, glared, and, with his hand on his sword, looked up to the sky and sighed, saying, "Although I am unworthy, I certainly cannot serve Qin. Now, my lord has decreed that I should respectfully serve the state and follow the teachings of King Zhao."
[360 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.3. In the ninth year, he presented sacrificial meat offerings to Duke Xiao of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 53 (Duke Xiao yr 2). In the second year, the emperor presented a sacrificial offering. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 17.2. In the first year of Duke Zhao's reign, Qin defeated us at Xishan. In the second year, Song captured Huangchi. Wei captured Zhu. In the sixth year, they attacked Eastern Zhou and captured Lingguan and Xingqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 22. He further said to King Xiang of Wei: "Your Majesty's lands extend south to Honggou, Chen, Runan, Xu, Yan, Kunyang, Zhaoling, Wuyang, Xindu, and Xinqi; east to Huai, Ying, Zhuozao, and Wuxu; west to the Great Wall; and north to Hewai, Juan, Yan, and Suanzao, covering a thousand li. Though the names of the lands are small, the number of fields, houses, and dwellings is so vast that there is no shortage of grazing land. The people are numerous, and the number of carriages and horses is endless, moving day and night, bustling about as if there were three armies. I humbly estimate that Your Majesty's kingdom is no less than that of Chu. However, the people of Heng are afraid that Your Majesty will associate with the powerful and ruthless Qin to invade the world, and that you will eventually suffer the consequences of Qin's actions, disregarding the potential harm. To use the power of Qin to coerce one's lord from within is a crime no greater than this. Wei is a powerful state in the world, and Your Majesty is a wise ruler. Yet now you intend to face west and serve Qin, claiming to be an eastern vassal state, building an imperial palace, receiving official robes and belts, and offering sacrifices to the Spring and Autumn Annals. I humbly feel ashamed for Your Majesty." 23. I have heard that King Goujian of Yue, with only 3,000 exhausted soldiers, captured King Fuchai at Gansui; and King Wu of Zhou, with 3,000 soldiers and 300 chariots, subdued King Zhou of Shang at Muye. It was not merely that their soldiers were numerous, but that they were able to wield their power. Now, I have heard that Your Majesty's army comprises 200,000 warriors, 200,000 servants, 200,000 elite troops, 100,000 laborers, 600 chariots, and 5,000 cavalry. This far surpasses that of King Goujian and King Wu of Yue. Yet, you listen to the opinions of your ministers and wish to submit to Qin. Submitting to Qin inevitably means ceding territory as a form of payment; thus, the country will be weakened even before the war is fought. All those ministers who advocate submitting to Qin are treacherous, not loyal. For a subject to cede territory from his lord for diplomatic gain, to steal momentary glory without considering the consequences, to destroy the public good for personal benefit, to leverage the power of Qin externally to coerce his lord internally, and to demand territorial concessions—I urge Your Majesty to carefully consider this matter. 24. The Book of Zhou says: 'If it continues unabated, what can be done? If a large yak is not felled, an axe will be needed.' If we are not sure about the future, there will be great trouble later. What can we do? If Your Majesty can listen to your minister, and the six states become allies, and concentrate their efforts and minds, then there will surely be no threat from the powerful Qin. Therefore, the King of Zhao of my humble state has sent me to offer my foolish plan and present a clear agreement, which Your Majesty will then convey.
[359 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 25. The King of Wei said, "I am unworthy and have never heard of your enlightened teachings. Now, Your Majesty has instructed them with the edict of the King of Zhao, and I urge them to respectfully comply with the state's wishes." 26. Dong Shuo said to King Xuan of Qi: "Qi is bordered by Mount Tai to the south, Langya to the east, the Qinghe River to the west, and the Bohai Sea to the north. It is a land of four strategic passes. Qi covers more than two thousand li, has hundreds of thousands of armored soldiers, and its grain is piled high like mountains. Its three armies are excellent, and its five families' troops advance like arrows, fight like thunder, and disperse like wind and rain. Even in times of military service, it has never crossed Mount Tai, the Qinghe River, or the Bohai Sea. In Linzi, there are seventy thousand households. I estimate that each household has no fewer than three men, which is 3 x 7 = 2." One hundred and ten thousand soldiers, not even needing to be dispatched from distant counties, yet the army of Linzi already numbered two hundred and ten thousand. Linzi was extremely wealthy and prosperous; its people all played the flute and zither, strummed the qin and struck the zhu, engaged in cockfighting and dog racing, and played liubo and cuju. On the roads of Linzi, cart wheels clattered, people's shoulders rubbed together, their robes forming curtains, their raised sleeves forming canopies, their sweat pouring like rain; every household was prosperous, everyone was content, and their spirits were high. With Your Majesty's wisdom and Qi's strength, no one in the world could rival you. Now you turn west and serve Qin; I, your subject, am ashamed for Your Majesty.
[358 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 54 (Duke Xiao yrs 2–4 compressed; reforms begin). For three years, Wei Yang persuaded Duke Xiao to reform the laws and revise the punishments, focusing on agriculture internally and encouraging rewards and punishments for those who died in battle externally. Duke Xiao approved of this. Gan Long, Du Zhi, and others disagreed and argued against it. In the end, Wei Yang's laws were implemented, and the people suffered greatly. After three years, the people found them convenient. Duke Xiao then appointed Wei Yang as the Left Chancellor. This story is mentioned in the sayings of Shang Yang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 27. The reason why Han and Wei fear Qin so much is because they share a border with Qin. If their armies clash, the outcome of a battle, even a single day's fighting, will determine their survival or destruction. If Han and Wei were to win against Qin, half their army would be lost, and their borders would be indefensible; if they were to lose, their states would be in grave danger and destruction would follow. This is why Han and Wei value fighting Qin so much, and are reluctant to become its subjects. But Qin's attack on Qi is different. It crosses the borders of Han and Wei, passes through the roads of Wei and Yangjin, and traverses the perilous Kangfu Pass. Chariots cannot travel side by side, and cavalry cannot ride side by side. A hundred men guard the pass, and a thousand dare not cross. Even if Qin wants to penetrate deeper, it hesitates, fearing that Han and Wei will plot against it. Therefore, it is fearful and hesitant, arrogant and unwilling to advance. It is clear that Qin cannot harm Qi. 28. To fail to fully grasp Qin's inability to subdue Qi, and yet to wish to submit to it from the west, is a mistake on the part of the ministers. Now, we have the power of a strong state without the pretense of serving Qin. Therefore, I urge Your Majesty to consider this carefully. 29. The King of Qi said, “I am not wise, and I live in a remote coastal state, bordering a country in the far east. I have never heard of your teachings. Now, Your Majesty, please convey the edict of the King of Zhao to him, and he should respectfully obey with the state.”
