[357 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 26. In the sixth year, the state of Wei was rescued. Duke Huan died, and his son King Wei ascended the throne in Qi. In the same year, the former Duke Kang of Qi died without an heir, and all the fiefs were given to the Tian family. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 30. Then, the Southwesterner spoke to King Wei of Chu, saying, “Chu is the most powerful state in the world, and Your Majesty is the most virtuous king. To the west are Qianzhong and Wujun, to the east are Xiazhou and Haiyang, to the south are Dongting and Cangwu, and to the north are Xingsai and Xunyang. The territory spans over five thousand li, with a million armored soldiers, a thousand chariots, ten thousand cavalry, and enough grain to last ten years. This is the foundation of a hegemon. With the strength of Chu and the wisdom of Your Majesty, no one in the world can rival you. Now you wish to turn west and serve Qin, then all the other feudal lords will turn west and pay homage at the foot of Zhangtai.” 31. Nothing Qin can harm more than Chu. If Chu is strong, Qin will be weak, and vice versa. They cannot coexist. Therefore, for Your Majesty's sake, the best course of action is to ally with Qin and isolate it. If Your Majesty does not ally with Qin, Qin will surely raise two armies, one to march out of Wuguan and the other to descend into Qianzhong. Then Yan and Ying will be in turmoil.
[356 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 39 — Jin Shijia] 138.3. In the seventeenth year, Duke Xiao died, and his son, Duke Jing, ascended the throne. This was also the first year of King Wei of Qi's reign. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 17.3. In the first year of Duke Zhao's reign, Qin defeated us at Xishan. In the second year, Song captured Huangchi. Wei captured Zhu. In the sixth year, they attacked Eastern Zhou and captured Lingguan and Xingqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 27.1. In the first year of King Wei of Qi's reign, the three Jin states, due to Qi's mourning, attacked Lingqiu. Three years later, the three Jin states destroyed Jin and divided its territory. Six years later, Lu attacked us, entering Yangguan. Jin attacked us, reaching Boling. Seven years later, Wei attacked us, capturing Xueling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 3. An envoy from Qi went to Liang. Sun Bin, disguised as a convict, secretly met with him and persuaded him to surrender. The envoy was impressed and secretly took him to Qi. Tian Ji, a general of Qi, treated him well and as a guest. Tian Ji often raced and shot arrows with the princes of Qi. Sun Bin noticed that their horses were not far apart in speed, but that they were of different grades: superior, middle, and inferior. Sun Bin then said to Tian Ji, "If you shoot arrows again, I can make you win." Tian Ji believed him and raced arrows with the king and the princes, winning a thousand pieces of gold. When the race was about to begin, Sun Bin said, "Now, use your inferior horse against their superior horse, your superior horse against their middle horse, and your middle horse against their inferior horse." After the three races, Tian Ji lost once but won twice, ultimately winning the king's thousand pieces of gold. Tian Ji then recommended Sun Bin to King Wei. King Wei inquired about military strategy and appointed him as his teacher. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 3.1. Duke Xiao employed Wei Yang, who wanted to reform the laws but feared public criticism. 3.2. Wei Yang said, "Hesitation leads to no reputation, hesitation leads to no achievement. Moreover, those with lofty conduct are often criticized by the world; those with unique insights are often resented by the people. The foolish are blind to accomplished things, while the wise see things before they arise. The people cannot be consulted on the beginning, but they can share in the success. Those who discuss the highest virtue do not conform to popular opinion, and those who achieve great things do not consult the masses. Therefore, if a sage can strengthen the state, he does not follow the old ways; if he can benefit the people, he does not adhere to the established rites." Duke Xiao said, "Good." 3.3. Gan Long said, "Not so. A sage teaches the people without changing the laws, and a wise person governs without changing the laws. Teaching according to the people leads to success without labor; governing according to the laws leads to officials becoming accustomed and the people becoming at peace." Wei Yang said, "What Long says is true." This is common parlance. Ordinary people are content with old customs, and scholars are immersed in what they have heard. These two types are fit to hold office and abide by the law, but they are not suitable to discuss matters outside the law. The Three Dynasties ruled with different rites, and the Five Hegemons became hegemons with different laws. The wise create laws, the foolish are bound by them; the virtuous change rites, the unworthy are constrained by them.” 3.4. Du Zhi said, “If the benefit is not a hundredfold, do not change the law; if the merit is not tenfold, do not change the tools. Following the ancient ways is without fault, adhering to rites is without evil.” Wei Yang said, “There is no single way to govern the world, and no single way to benefit the state. Therefore, Tang and Wu did not follow the ancient ways and yet became kings, while the Xia and Yin dynasties did not change their rites and perished. Those who oppose the ancient ways should not be criticized, but those who adhere to rites are not necessarily praised.” 3.5. Duke Xiao said, “Excellent.” He appointed Wei Yang as Left Chancellor, and he finally established the decree for the reform. 4. The people were organized into groups of ten and five, with mutual responsibility among the officials in charge of herding and managing. Those who failed to report wrongdoing were to be cut in half at the waist; those who reported wrongdoing received the same reward as those who beheaded an enemy; those who concealed wrongdoing were punished the same as those who surrendered to the enemy. Those with two or more sons who did not separate were to have their taxes doubled. Those with military merit were to receive higher ranks according to their achievements; those who engaged in private fights were to be punished according to the severity of their crimes. Those who diligently pursued their primary occupations, producing abundant grain and silk, were to be reinstated. Those who engaged in secondary occupations or were lazy and impoverished were to be taken into custody as dependents. Members of the imperial clan, without military merit, were not to be registered as members of the imperial family. The ranks and grades of nobility were clearly defined, with land, houses, servants, and clothing assigned according to their respective status. Those with merit were to be honored, while those without merit, even if wealthy, would receive no recognition or glory. 5.1. The decree was prepared but not yet promulgated. Fearing the people would not believe it, the decree was erected at the south gate of the capital city, with a height of three zhang (approximately 10 meters). Ten gold coins were offered to anyone who could move it to the north gate. The people were puzzled and none dared to move it. The decree was then announced: "Fifty gold coins will be given to anyone who can move it." 5.2. One person moved it, and fifty gold coins were immediately given to him, to demonstrate that the decree was not false. Finally, the decree was issued. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 32. I have heard that it is better to govern before chaos arises and to prepare for what is yet to come. If we only worry about trouble after it has already occurred, it will be too late. Therefore, I hope Your Majesty will consider this carefully as soon as possible. 33. If Your Majesty would heed my advice, I request that the states east of the mountains offer their seasonal tributes to Your Majesty, entrusting them with the affairs of the state, the maintenance of ancestral temples, the training of soldiers, and the strengthening of the army, all to be employed by Your Majesty. If Your Majesty would adopt my humble plan, then the beautiful women and exquisite music of Han, Wei, Qi, Yan, Zhao, and Wei would surely fill the harem, and the camels and fine horses of Yan and Dai would surely fill the outer stables. Thus, if we unite, we will become the King of Chu; if we achieve our goal, we will become the Emperor of Qin. Now, abandoning the cause of hegemony and gaining only the title of servant, I humbly believe that Your Majesty should not do this. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 6. The states of Ju and Shu attacked each other, each seeking urgent assistance from Qin. King Hui of Qin wanted to send troops to attack Shu, but considered the roads treacherous and difficult to traverse. Furthermore, Han was also invading Qin. King Hui considered attacking Han first, then Shu, but feared this would be disadvantageous. He also considered attacking Shu first, but feared Han would exploit Qin's weaknesses. He hesitated and could not make a decision. Sima Cuo and Zhang Yi debated before King Hui. Sima Cuo advocated attacking Shu, while Zhang Yi said, "It would be better to attack Han." The king said, "Please allow me to hear your reasoning." 7. Yi said, “By befriending Wei and Chu, sending troops to the Three Rivers region, blocking the entrance to Shigu, and securing the road to Tunliu, Wei will cut off Nanyang, Chu will approach Nanzheng, and Qin will attack Xincheng and Yiyang, thus threatening the outskirts of the two Zhou states. This will allow Qin to punish the Zhou king and invade the lands of Chu and Wei. Knowing it cannot save Zhou, the Nine Tripods and other precious artifacts will surely be brought forth. By seizing the Nine Tripods, examining maps and records, and holding the emperor hostage to command the world, none will dare disobey – this is the path to kingship. Now, Shu is a remote western state inhabited by the Rong and Di tribes. Exhausting our troops and manpower will not bring us fame, nor will acquiring its lands bring us profit. I have heard that those who contend for fame do so in the court, and those who contend for profit do so in the marketplace. Now, the Three Rivers region and the Zhou capital are the court and marketplace of the world, yet Your Majesty does not contend for them, but instead contends with the Rong and Di tribes. This is far removed from the path to kingship.” 8. Sima Cuo said, "No. I have heard that those who wish to enrich their country must expand its territory, those who wish to strengthen their army must enrich their people, and those who wish to become kings must cultivate their virtue. When these three resources are complete, kingship will follow. Now, Your Majesty's territory is small and your people are poor, therefore I wish to first engage in the easier task. Shu is a remote western country, and the leader of the Rong and Di tribes, which has experienced the chaos of Jie and Zhou. If Qin were to attack it, it would be like sending jackals to chase a flock of sheep. Taking its territory would be enough to expand the country, and taking its wealth would be enough to enrich the people and strengthen the army. Without harming the people, they would already be subdued. Taking down a country would not be considered tyrannical by the world, and taking all the benefits from the Western Sea would not be considered a crime by the world." "For greed, I could gain both fame and power in one fell swoop, and also have the reputation of suppressing violence and stopping chaos. Now, attacking Han and kidnapping the emperor will bring infamy, but may not even bring profit, and will also be labeled as unjust. Attacking what the world does not want is dangerous. Your Majesty, I request to know the reason: Zhou is a royal family of the world; Qi is an ally of Han. Zhou knows it has lost the Nine Tripods, and Han knows it has lost the Three Rivers. They are conspiring to join forces to seek relief from Chu and Wei by relying on Qi and Zhao, giving the tripods to Chu and land to Wei. Your Majesty cannot stop them. This is what I mean by danger. It would be better to attack Shu and secure peace." 9. King Hui said, "Good, I will listen to you." He then raised an army to attack Shu, and in the tenth month, he captured it, thus pacifying Shu. He demoted the King of Shu and changed his title to Marquis, and appointed Chen Zhuang as the prime minister of Shu. After Shu came under Qin's control, Qin became increasingly powerful and wealthy, and looked down on the other feudal lords.
[355 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.1 (Duke Xiao yr 7). In the seventh year, he met with King Hui of Wei at Duping. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 6.1. After a year of implementation, thousands of Qin citizens in the capital complained about the inconvenience of the initial decree. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 34. Qin is a nation of tigers and wolves, with the ambition to devour the world. Qin is the enemy of the world. The people of Heng all desire to cede land from the other states to serve Qin, which is what is meant by nurturing an enemy while serving a foe. For a subject to cede land from his lord to appease the powerful and wolves-like Qin and invade the world will ultimately bring trouble upon him, without regard for the consequences. To use the power of Qin to coerce one's lord to cede land is the greatest act of treason and disloyalty, nothing could be more egregious. Therefore, if the states align themselves with Chu, they will cede land to serve Chu; if they unite with Qin, Chu will cede land to serve Qin. These two strategies are vastly different. Which one should Your Majesty choose? Therefore, the King of Zhao of my humble state has sent me to offer my foolish plan and present a clear treaty, which Your Majesty will then issue. 35. The King of Chu said, “My kingdom borders Qin to the west, and Qin harbors ambitions to conquer Ba and Shu and annex Hanzhong. Qin is a nation of tigers and wolves, and cannot be befriended. Han and Wei are also threatened by Qin, and cannot be trusted with deep strategies. If we were to engage in deep strategies, we risk betraying them and surrendering to Qin. Thus, before any plans are even launched, my kingdom is already in danger. I myself believe that Chu cannot defeat Qin; and my internal discussions with my ministers are unreliable. I cannot sleep soundly or eat with relish, and my heart is as precarious as a tattered banner. Now, Your Majesty desires to unify the world, unite the feudal lords, and save my kingdom from peril. I will humbly offer my state and follow your lead.”
[354 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.2 (yr 8). In the eighth year, he fought against Wei at Yuanli and distinguished himself. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 4. Later, Wei attacked Zhao, and Zhao, in dire straits, sought help from Qi. King Wei of Qi wanted to appoint Sun Bin as general, but Sun Bin declined, saying, "A man who has been punished is not suitable." Therefore, Tian Ji was appointed general, and Sun Tzu served as strategist, residing in a baggage cart and devising plans. Tian Ji wanted to lead troops to Zhao, but Sun Tzu said, "To resolve a chaotic situation, one does not need to use a lever; to save a fight, one does not need to fight hand-to-hand. Strike at the weak points and exploit the vulnerabilities; when the situation is blocked and the enemy is constrained, the situation will resolve itself. Now, Liang and Zhao are attacking each other; their light and elite troops will be exhausted on the outside, and their old and weak will be worn out on the inside. Your Majesty should lead your troops swiftly to Daliang, seize its streets, and attack its weak points. They will surely abandon Zhao to save themselves. This way, we can lift the siege of Zhao in one fell swoop and capture the enemy from Wei." Tian Ji followed his advice, and Wei indeed withdrew from Handan and fought Qi at Guiling, inflicting a great defeat on the Liang army. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 36. Thus, the six states united and joined forces. Su Qin served as the leader of the alliance and also as the prime minister of all six states.
[353 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 37. Su Qin reported to the King of Zhao, then passed through Luoyang. His carriages, horses, and baggage were numerous, and many envoys from various feudal lords escorted him, raising suspicions about the king. King Xian of Zhou, hearing of this, was terrified and cleared the road, sending people to offer him a feast outside the city. Su Qin's brothers, wife, and sister-in-law glanced sideways, not daring to look him in the eye, and prostrated themselves to serve him food. Su Qin laughed and said to his sister-in-law, "Why were you so arrogant before and so respectful now?" His sister-in-law, dressed in a hushed manner, covered her face with the ground and apologized, saying, "I saw that you, young master, are of high rank and have much wealth." Su Qin sighed and said, "For a person, wealth and honor make relatives fearful, while poverty and lowliness make them disrespectful; how much more so for ordinary people! Even if I had two acres of land outside Luoyang, how could I wear the seals of the prime ministers of six states!" He then distributed a thousand gold pieces to his relatives and friends. Initially, when Su Qin went to Yan, he borrowed a hundred coins as capital, and after gaining wealth and honor, he repaid the debt with the hundred gold pieces. He repaid all those he had ever met with kindness. One of his followers, however, had not yet received a repayment, so he stepped forward and spoke of it. Su Qin said, “I have not forgotten you. When you came to Yan with me, you repeatedly wanted to leave me at the Yi River. At that time, I was in distress, so I looked up to you longingly. That is why I have come to you. Now you have also found your place.” 38. After Su Qin secured an alliance with the six states, he returned to Zhao, whereupon Marquis Su of Zhao bestowed upon him the title of Marquis of Wu'an. He then sent the alliance treaty to Qin. For fifteen years, Qin's troops dared not venture into Hangu Pass. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 10. In the tenth year of King Hui of Qin's reign, Prince Hua and Zhang Yi besieged Puyang, which was eventually captured. Zhang Yi then suggested that Qin restore its alliance with Wei and send Prince Yao as a hostage to Wei. Zhang Yi then advised the King of Wei, "The King of Qin has treated Wei very well; Wei should not be disrespectful." Wei then entered Shangjun and Shaoliang to apologize to King Hui of Qin. King Hui then appointed Zhang Yi as his prime minister and renamed Shaoliang to Xiayang.
[352 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.3 (yr 10). In the tenth year, Wei Yang was appointed Grand Minister of Works and led troops to besiege Anyi, which Wei surrendered. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 11. Yi Xiangqin was four years old when he established King Hui as king. After a year, he became a general of Qin and captured Shan. He then built the fortress of Shangjun.
[351 BC]
[350 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.4 (yr 12; Xianyang; 41 counties). In the twelfth year, he built Xianyang and constructed Jique, and Qin moved its capital there. He merged the small villages and settlements into large counties, each with one magistrate, totaling forty-one counties. He opened up the fields. He crossed the Luo River to the east. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 15 (Warring States-era, very approximate span). During the reign of King Wuqiang, Yue launched a northern expedition against Qi and a western expedition against Chu, vying for power with the Central Plains. During the reign of King Wei of Chu, Yue attacked Qi in the north. King Wei of Qi sent a messenger to the King of Yue, saying, "If Yue does not attack Chu, it will neither be a great king nor a small hegemon. The reason Yue does not attack Chu is because it cannot obtain Jin. Han and Wei are unwilling to attack Chu. If Han attacks Chu, it will annihilate its army and kill its general, then Ye and Yangdi will be in danger; if Wei also annihilates its army and kills its general, then Chen and Shangcai will be uneasy. Therefore, the two Jin states' service to Yue will not lead to the annihilation of their armies and the killing of their generals, and even the efforts of Ma Han will be ineffective. What is the most important thing about obtaining Jin?" The King of Yue replied, "What I seek from Jin is not to engage in direct combat." And what about besieging cities and towns? I wish Wei would gather troops under Daliang, and I wish Qi would test its strength in Nanyang and Ju, gathering troops in the borders of Chang and Tan. Then, beyond Fangcheng, there would be no south; the Huai and Si rivers would be no east; the lands of Shang, Yu, Xi, Li, and Zonghu, and to the left of Xialu, would be insufficient to defend against Qin; and the Jiangnan and Si rivers would be insufficient to defend against Yue. Then Qi, Qin, Han, and Wei would gain the favor of Chu, and the two Jin states would divide the land without fighting, gaining without cultivating it. Instead of doing this, they would lay down their swords in the rivers and mountains to serve Qi and Qin. What they are waiting for is such a miscalculation. What can be done? "This is the king!" The Qi envoy said, "Fortunately, Yue has not perished! I do not value his use of wisdom as easily as seeing a hair but not the eyelash. Now, Your Majesty knows Jin's miscalculation but does not know Yue's own faults; this is mere observation. What Your Majesty awaits from Jin is not the strength of Ma Han, nor is it something that can be joined in an alliance; it is to divide the Chu forces. Now that the Chu forces have been divided, why wait for Jin?" The King of Yue said, "What then?" He said, "The three great ministers of Chu have deployed nine armies to besiege Quwo and Yuzhong in the north, extending 3,700 li to Wujia Pass, with Jingcui..." "Your army has gathered in Lu, Qi, and Nanyang in the north. Is there any greater force than this? Moreover, what Your Majesty seeks is to fight Jin and Chu; if Jin and Chu do not fight, Yue's army will not rise. This shows you know two things but not ten. If you do not attack Chu now, I know that Yue will neither become a king nor a hegemon. Fuchou, Pang, and Changsha are Chu's grain; Jingzeling is Chu's resources. Yue's army is spying on the Wujia Pass; these four cities will no longer pay tribute to Ying. I have heard that if one plans to become a king but fails, the disadvantage is that one can become a hegemon. However, if one does not become a hegemon, it is because the way of the king has been lost. Therefore, I urge Your Majesty to turn your attention to attacking Chu." [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 6.2. Then, the crown prince broke the law. Wei Yang said, "The law is not being enforced because those above are breaking it." He intended to punish the crown prince, but as the heir apparent, he could not be punished. Instead, he punished his tutor, Gongzi Qian, and tattooed his teacher, Gongsun Jia. The next day, all the people of Qin obeyed the decree. 7.2. After three years, he built the Jique Palace in Xianyang, and Qin moved its capital there from Yong. He also prohibited fathers, sons, and brothers from sleeping in the same room. He gathered small towns and villages into counties, appointing magistrates and assistant magistrates, making a total of thirty-one counties. He opened up fields and marked their boundaries, and taxes were equitable. He standardized the weights and measures. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 12.1. Two years later, he was sent to meet with the ministers of Qi and Chu at Nie Sang. He returned east and was dismissed from his post as prime minister. He then became prime minister of Wei and sided with Qin, intending to have Wei submit to Qin first so that the other states would follow suit. The King of Wei refused to listen to Zhang Yi. The King of Qin was furious and attacked and seized Quwo and Pingzhou from Wei, secretly increasing Zhang Yi's favor even further. Zhang Yi was ashamed and had no way to repay Qin.
[349 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 7.3. After four years of implementation, Prince Qian violated the agreement again and was punished by having his nose cut off.
[348 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.5 (yr 14). In the fourteenth year, he first established a tax system. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 19.1. In the tenth year, Han Ji murdered her ruler, Duke Dao. In the eleventh year, Marquis Zhao went to Qin. In the twenty-second year, Shen Buhai died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin came and captured Yiyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 27.2. Nine years later, Zhao attacked us, capturing Zhen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 7.4. After five years, the people of Qin became rich and powerful, and the emperor presented sacrificial meat to Duke Xiao, and all the feudal lords offered their congratulations. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 12.2. He remained in Wei for four years until King Xiang of Wei died, and King Ai ascended the throne. Zhang Yi again tried to persuade King Ai, but the king refused. Therefore, Zhang Yi secretly ordered Qin to attack Wei. Wei fought Qin and was defeated.
[347 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 19.2. In the tenth year, Han Ji murdered her ruler, Duke Dao. In the eleventh year, Marquis Zhao went to Qin. In the twenty-second year, Shen Buhai died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin came and captured Yiyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 13. The following year, Qi again defeated Wei at Guanjin. Qin, intending to attack Wei again, first defeated Han Shenchai's army, beheading 80,000, causing panic among the feudal lords. Zhang Yi then advised the King of Wei, saying, "Wei's territory is less than a thousand li, and its army numbers no more than 300,000. The land is flat, allowing all the feudal lords to converge from all directions, without the limitations of famous mountains or great rivers. From Zheng to Liang is only two hundred li; chariots and men can travel there without waiting for any effort. Liang borders Chu to the south, Han to the west, Zhao to the north, and Qi to the east. Soldiers are stationed in all directions, and those guarding the outposts number no less than 100,000. Liang's terrain is naturally a battlefield. If Liang allies with Chu to the south but not with Qi, then Qi will attack its east; if it allies with Qi to the east but not with Zhao, then Zhao will attack its north; if it does not ally with Han, then Han will attack its west; if it is not friendly with Chu, then Chu will attack its south: this is what is meant by the path of division." 14. "Moreover, the reason why the feudal lords follow us is to secure the state, honor the ruler, strengthen the army, and make a name for themselves. Now, we follow you to unite the world, we have made a pact of brotherhood, and we sacrificed a white horse to swear an oath on the banks of the Huan River to strengthen our bond. Yet even brothers who share the same parents still fight over money. How can you expect to rely on deceit and falsehood to betray the remnants of Su Qin's schemes? It is clear that your plan will not succeed."
[346 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 6.3. After ten years, the people of Qin were greatly pleased. No one picked up lost items on the road, there were no thieves in the mountains, and every family was well-off. The people were brave in public battles but timid in private fights, and the villages and towns were well-governed. Some of the Qin citizens who had initially complained about the decree now spoke of its convenience. 6.4. Wei Yang said, "These are all people who disrupt order," and relocated them all to the border cities. Afterward, no one dared to criticize the decree. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 15. "If Your Majesty does not serve Qin, Qin will send troops to attack the area beyond the Yellow River, occupying Juan, Yan, [Yan], and Suanzao, and seize Yangjin from Wei. Then Zhao will not be able to go south, and if Zhao does not go south, Liang will not be able to go north. If Liang does not go north, the supply routes will be cut off, and if the supply routes are cut off, Your Majesty's country will be in grave danger. Qin will then attack Liang after defeating Han. Han will be afraid of Qin, and Qin and Han will become one. The fall of Liang can be imminent. This is what I worry about for Your Majesty." 16. "For Your Majesty's sake, there is no better course of action than to serve Qin. If we serve Qin, Chu and Han will certainly not dare to act; without the threat of Chu and Han, Your Majesty can sleep soundly, and the country will be free from worry."
[345 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 53. In the sixteenth year, Marquis Su toured Daling. When he passed through Lumen, a man named Dawuwu stopped his horse and said, "The farming is urgent. If you don't work for a day, you won't eat for a hundred days." Marquis Su got out of his carriage and thanked him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 17. "Moreover, none of the states that Qin desires to weaken is Chu, and none of the states that can weaken Chu is Liang. Although Chu has a reputation for wealth and power, it is in reality weak; although its soldiers are numerous, they are easily defeated and prone to retreat, unable to fight sturdily. If Liang were to send all its troops south to attack Chu, victory would be assured. By ceding Chu to Liang and weakening Chu to benefit Qin, we could shift the blame to our own country and secure peace—this would be a wise move. If Your Majesty does not listen to me, Qin will send its armored soldiers eastward to attack. Even if you wish to serve Qin, it will be impossible." 18. "Moreover, those who follow others often eloquently, but few are truly credible. One can be granted a title of nobility by persuading a mere prince. Therefore, all the eloquent scholars in the world wring their hands and glare with hatred day and night to advocate for the convenience of following them and to persuade the ruler. The ruler appreciates their eloquence and is swayed by their words. How can he not be bewildered?" 19. "I have heard that a single feather can sink a boat, a multitude of light objects can break an axle, and a multitude of words can melt metal and destroy bones. Therefore, I urge Your Majesty to carefully consider this matter and grant me the honor of being exiled to Wei."
[344 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.4. In the twenty-fifth year, Qin convened a meeting of the feudal lords with Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 18. Han Shijia: For eight years, Shen Buhai served as prime minister of Han. He cultivated skills and promoted morality, and the country was well-governed, so the other states did not invade or attack him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 20.1. King Ai then broke his promise and, through Zhang Yi, requested peace with Qin. Zhang Yi returned and became prime minister of Qin again.
[343 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.5. In the twenty-sixth year, Zhou presented Hegemony to Duke Xiao of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.6 (yr 19). In the nineteenth year, the emperor bestowed honors upon the hegemons. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 20.2. Three years later, Wei broke with Qin and joined Qin's alliance. Qin attacked Wei and captured Quwo. The following year, Wei returned to Qin's service.
[342 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.7 (yr 20). In the twentieth year, all the feudal lords offered congratulations. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 54. For seventeen years, they besieged Wei Huang, but failed to capture it. They then built the Great Wall. [Sima Qian, Shiji 65 — Sunzi Wu Qi Lie Zhuan] 5. At the age of thirteen, Wei and Zhao attacked Han, and Han appealed to Qi for help. Qi sent Tian Ji to lead the army, which marched straight to Daliang. Wei general Pang Juan heard of this and abandoned Han, returning home. By then, the Qi army had already passed and was heading west. Sun Tzu said to Tian Ji, "The soldiers of the three Jin states are known for their fierceness and bravery, and they look down on Qi. Qi is known for its cowardice. A skilled strategist can exploit this situation to his advantage. Military strategy dictates that a general who rushes for profit from a hundred li away will be defeated, and a half-destroyed army will arrive from fifty li away. Let the Qi army enter Wei territory and set up 100,000 cooking fires the next day, 50,000 the following day, and 30,000 the day after that." Pang Juan marched for three days, then was overjoyed, saying, "I knew the Qi army was cowardly. After three days in our territory, more than half of their soldiers have deserted." He then abandoned his infantry and, with his elite troops, pursued them at twice the speed. Sun Tzu estimated that they would reach Maling by evening. The road to Maling was steep, with many narrow passes on either side, suitable for an ambush. So he cut down a large tree, whitened it, and wrote on it, "Pang Juan will die under this tree." So he ordered ten thousand skilled archers of the Qi army to lie in ambush along the road, with the instruction, "At dusk, when the fire is lit, we will all fire." Pang Juan indeed arrived at night under a piece of wood and found a white book. He then lit a candle to read it. Before he finished reading, the ten thousand Qi archers fired simultaneously, throwing the Wei army into chaos. Pang Juan, realizing his strategy had failed and his army defeated, committed suicide, saying, "I have thus earned the name of a mere scoundrel!" The Qi army, taking advantage of their victory, utterly defeated Pang Juan's army and captured the Wei crown prince, Shen, bringing him back home. Sun Bin thus became famous throughout the land, and his military strategies were passed down through generations. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 8.1. The following year, Qi defeated Wei's army at Maling, captured its crown prince Shen, and killed General Pang Juan.
[341 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 55.8 (yr 21). Qin sent Prince Shaoguan to lead an army to meet with the feudal lords at Fengze and pay homage to the emperor. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 28. Since King Wei first ascended the throne, he neglected governance, entrusting affairs to his ministers. For nine years, the various states attacked, and the people suffered. King Wei then summoned the magistrate of Jimo and said, “Since you took office in Jimo, slanderous rumors have been circulating daily. However, I sent men to inspect Jimo, and found the fields cultivated, the people prosperous, the officials without outstanding duties, and the east at peace. This shows you did not serve my advisors to seek praise.” He then granted him a fief of ten thousand households. He summoned the magistrate of A and said, “Since you took office in A, praise has been heard daily. However, I sent men to inspect A, and found the fields uncultivated and the people impoverished. In the past, when Zhao attacked Zhen, you could not come to its aid. When Wei captured Xueling, you were unaware. This shows you used bribes to enrich my advisors to seek praise.” That day, he had the magistrate of A boiled alive, along with all those who had praised him. He then raised an army to attack Zhao and Wei in the west, defeated Wei at Zhuoze, and besieged King Hui. King Hui requested to offer Guan as a peace offering, and the people of Zhao returned to Changcheng. The state of Qi was terrified, and everyone dared not conceal their faults, striving to be entirely honest. Qi was greatly improved. When the feudal lords heard of this, none dared to send troops to Qi for more than twenty years. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 8.2. The same year, Wei Yang advised Duke Xiao, saying, "The relationship between Qin and Wei is like a person suffering from a heart ailment. Either Wei will annex Qin, or Qin will annex Wei. Why? Wei is located west of Ling'e, with its capital at Anyi, bordering Qin by the river and exclusively possessing the advantages of the lands east of the mountains. When it benefits, it invades Qin to the west; when it is weakened, it seizes land to the east. Now, with Your Majesty's wisdom and virtue, the state prospers. Wei suffered a great defeat at the hands of Qi in previous years, and the other states have turned against it. We should take this opportunity to attack Wei. Wei cannot withstand Qin and will inevitably move east. Moving east, Qin will have the advantage of the river and mountains, and can then control the other states from the east—this is the way of an emperor." Duke Xiao agreed and sent Wei Yang to lead the attack on Wei. Wei sent Prince Ang to lead the attack. After the armies met, Wei Yang sent a letter to the Wei general, Prince Ang, saying, "I was on good terms with you, but now we are both generals of our respective states. I cannot bear to attack you. Let us meet face to face, make an alliance, drink a feast, and then cease hostilities to ensure peace between Qin and Wei." Prince Ang agreed. After the alliance was formed and the feast was held, Wei Yang ambushed and captured Prince Ang, then attacked his army, utterly defeating it and returning it to Qin. King Hui of Wei suffered repeated defeats at the hands of Qi and Qin, leaving his country depleted and weakened daily. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 21. Qin wanted to attack Qi, and Qi and Chu formed an alliance. Therefore, Zhang Yi went to serve as prime minister of Chu. King Huai of Chu, hearing of Zhang Yi's arrival, emptied the best lodging for him and said, "This is a remote and backward country; how can you teach it?" Zhang Yi advised the king, "If Your Majesty would listen to me and close the borders to Qi, I will offer six hundred li of land in Shangyu, and allow a Qin woman to become Your Majesty's concubine. Qin and Chu will then marry, becoming brother states forever. This would weaken Qi in the north and strengthen Qin in the west; there is no better plan." The king was overjoyed and agreed. All the ministers congratulated him, except for Chen Zhen, who offered condolences. The King of Chu angrily said, "I gained six hundred li of land without raising an army, and all my ministers congratulated me, but you alone are lamenting. Why is that?" Chen Zhen replied, "No, in my opinion, the land of Shangyu cannot be obtained, and Qi and Qin must unite. If Qi and Qin unite, disaster will surely follow." The King of Chu asked, "Do you have an explanation?" Chen Zhen replied, "The reason Qin values Chu is because of its alliance with Qi. If we close the borders and sever the alliance with Qi, Chu will be isolated. Why would Qin covet an isolated state and give it six hundred li of land in Shangyu? If Zhang Yi goes to Qin, he will surely betray Your Majesty. This would mean severing the alliance with Qi in the north and creating trouble for Qin in the west, and the armies of both countries will surely come together. A wise ruler would do better to secretly unite with Qi while openly severing it, and send someone to accompany Zhang Yi. If they give us the land, it is not too late to sever the alliance with Qi; if they do not give us the land, we can secretly plot against them." The King of Chu said, "I wish you, Chen Zi, would keep your mouth shut and wait until I obtain the land." He then gave Zhang Yi the seal of the prime minister and gave him a generous bribe. Thereupon, he closed the borders and severed the alliance with Qi, and sent a general to accompany Zhang Yi. 22.1. Zhang Yi arrived in Qin, feigning a mishap and falling from his carriage, and did not attend court for three months. The King of Chu, upon hearing this, said, "Does Zhang Yi think I haven't severed ties with Qi enough?" He then sent a brave warrior to Song, borrowed a tally from Song, and used it to insult the King of Qi. The King of Qi was furious, humbled himself, and submitted to Qin. With Qin and Qi forming an alliance, Zhang Yi went to court and told the Chu envoy, "I have a fief of six li, which I wish to offer to Your Majesty's court." The Chu envoy replied, "I received orders from Your Majesty to give six hundred li of land in Shangyu; I have no knowledge of six li." He returned to report to the King of Chu, who was enraged and launched an attack on Qin. Chen Zhen said, "Can I speak? It would be better to cede land to Qin as a bribe, join forces with them, and attack Qi. This way, we give land to Qin and receive compensation from Qi, and our kingdom can still survive." The King of Chu did not listen and ultimately sent troops, dispatching General Qu Gai to attack Qin.
[340 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 56 (Duke Xiao yr 22; Maling). In the twenty-first year, Qi defeated Wei at Maling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 68.2. In the thirtieth year, Qin enfeoffed Wei Yang in Shang and invaded Chu from the south. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 7.1. Therefore, Yang was appointed Grand Minister of Works. He led troops to besiege Anyi, the capital of Wei, and the city surrendered. 8.3. Fearing this, he sent an envoy to cede the land west of the Yellow River to Qin as a peace offering. Wei then abandoned Anyi and moved its capital to Daliang. King Hui of Liang said, "I regret not heeding the advice of Gongshu Zuo." 8.4. After Wei Yang's victory over Wei, Qin enfeoffed him with fifteen towns in Yu and Shang, bestowing upon him the title of Lord Shang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 22.2. Qin and Qi jointly attacked Chu, beheading 80,000, killing Qu Gai, and seizing Danyang and Hanzhong. Chu then launched another attack on Qin, reaching Lantian, where a great battle ensued, resulting in a major defeat for Chu. Consequently, Chu ceded two cities to Qin to settle the score.
[339 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 57 (Duke Xiao yr 23; Prince Ang captured). In the twenty-second year, Wei Yang attacked Wei and captured Prince Ang of Wei. Wei Yang was then enfeoffed as a marquis and given the title Lord Shang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 68.3. In that year, King Xuan died, and his son, King Wei Xiong Shang, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 9.1. During Shang Yang's ten years as prime minister of Qin, many members of the royal family and nobles harbored resentment. Zhao Liang met with Shang Yang. Lord Shang said, "Yang was introduced to the court by Meng Lan Gao. Now Yang requests to befriend Zhao Liang. Is this permissible?" Zhao Liang replied, "I dare not accept such a request. Confucius said, 'Those who promote the virtuous advance, those who gather the unworthy retreat.' I am unworthy, therefore I dare not accept this command. I have heard it said, 'To occupy a position that is not rightfully yours is to covet position; to possess a name that is not rightfully yours is to covet fame.' If I were to hear your words, I fear I would also be coveting position and fame. Therefore, I dare not accept your command." Lord Shang said, "Do you not appreciate my governance of Qin?" 9.2. Zhao Liang replied, "To listen inwardly is called wisdom; to examine oneself is called insight; to conquer oneself is called strength. Emperor Shun said, 'Humility is the highest virtue.' You should follow the way of Emperor Shun and not ask me any more questions." 9.3. Lord Shang said, "Initially, Qin was governed by the Rong and Di peoples, where fathers and sons were not distinguished and lived in the same room. Now I have reformed their teachings, distinguishing between men and women, and have built the Ji Que, resembling the states of Lu and Wei. Observe my governance of Qin, how does it compare to the Five Goats?" "Is the Grand Master virtuous?" Zhao Liang replied, "A thousand sheepskins are not as valuable as a single fox's lining; a thousand men's 'yes' are not as valuable as a single scholar's 'honest' words. King Wu prospered because of his outspokenness, while King Zhou of Yin perished because of his inflexibility. If Your Majesty does not criticize King Wu, then I request to speak frankly all day without being punished. Is that acceptable?" Shang Yang said, "There is such a saying: 'Words that appear refined are flowery, words that are sincere are truthful, bitter words are medicine, and sweet words are remedy.' If you, Master, are truly willing to speak frankly all day, then you are the medicine for Yang. Yang will serve you..." "What more can you say?" 9.4. Zhao Liang replied, "The Five Rams Minister was a lowly man from Chu. Hearing of Duke Mu of Qin's virtue, he wished to meet him. Having no means of transport, he ate porridge among Qin guests, wearing coarse clothes and eating oxen. After a year, Duke Mu learned of him, lifted him from the jaws of an ox, and placed him above the common people. No one in Qin dared to hope for such a position. He served as prime minister of Qin for six or seven years, then launched an eastern campaign against Zheng, thrice installed the ruler of Jin, and once saved Chu from disaster. He issued edicts within the borders, and the people of Ba paid tribute; he bestowed virtue upon the feudal lords, and..." Eight Rong tribes submitted. Upon hearing this, You Yu cordially requested an audience. When the Five Goat Minister served as Prime Minister of Qin, he did not ride in a carriage when weary, nor did he use a canopy in the heat. When traveling throughout the state, he did not use a chariot, nor did he wield weapons. His achievements were stored in the treasury, and his virtues were passed down to posterity. When the Five Goat Minister died, men and women of Qin wept, children ceased singing songs, and those pounding grain stopped their pestles. This was the virtue of the Five Goat Minister. Now, when you meet the King of Qin, it is because of your favorite, Jing Jian, that you are his master, not for the sake of reputation. Qin neglects the people's welfare, instead constructing the Ji Gate on a grand scale; this is not a form of merit. The punishment of tattooing the crown prince's tutor, a cruel and cruel punishment that breeds resentment and future calamities, is akin to accumulating evil. Education should be more profound than commands, and the people should more readily obey decrees. Now, Your Majesty further establishes external trade, which is not the way to educate. Furthermore, Your Majesty faces south and calls yourself "I, the Lonely One," daily punishing the noble princes of Qin. The Book of Poetry says: "Even a rat has a body; a man without manners, a man without manners, why not die quickly?" Judging from the poem... " This is not the way to prolong life. Prince Qian has remained secluded for eight years, and you have also killed Zhu Huan and tattooed Gongsun Jia. The Book of Poetry says, 'He who gains the support of the people prospers; he who loses the support of the people perishes.' These things are not the way to gain the support of the people. When you go out, there are more than ten carriages behind you, with armored soldiers in the chariots, strong men with bulging flanks serving as attendants, and those holding spears and halberds running alongside the carriages. If even one of these things is not provided, you will certainly not go out. The Book of Documents says, 'He who relies on virtue prospers; he who relies on strength perishes.' Your life is as precarious as morning dew; do you still wish to prolong your life? Why not return to your fifteen capitals, cultivate your garden in a remote village, and persuade the King of Qin to honor the scholars in seclusion, care for the elderly and orphans, respect fathers and elder brothers, order the meritorious, and honor the virtuous? This way you can have some peace. You still covet the wealth of Shangyu, indulge in the teachings of Qin, and harbor the resentment of the people. If the King of Qin were to suddenly abandon his guests and cease holding court, how insignificant would Qin's reasons for taking you down be? Your demise is imminent." Lord Shang did not heed this advice. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 23. Qin wanted the land of Qianzhong from Chu, offering to exchange it for the land beyond Wuguan Pass. The King of Chu said, "I do not wish to exchange land; I wish to receive Zhang Yi and offer the land of Qianzhong in return." The King of Qin wanted to send him away but hesitated to speak. Zhang Yi then volunteered to go. King Hui of Chu said, "The King of Chu is angry that you betrayed him by offering the land of Shangyu; he is now willing to give it to you." Zhang Yi said, "Qin is strong and Chu is weak. I am good to Jin Shang, and Shang serves Lady Zheng Xiu of Chu, who obeys all his words. Moreover, I am on a mission to Chu with Your Majesty's authority; how dare Chu punish me? Even if they punish me, I will gain the land of Qianzhong for Qin; this is my greatest wish." He then went to Chu. When King Huai of Chu arrived, he imprisoned Zhang Yi and intended to kill him. Jin Shang said to Zheng Xiu, "Do you also know how lowly you are to the King?" Zheng Xiu replied, "Why?" Jin Shang said, "The King of Qin greatly admires Zhang Yi but does not wish to release him. Now, he intends to bribe Chu with six counties of Shangyong, send a beautiful woman to Chu, and have a skilled singer from the palace as a concubine. The King of Chu values the land and respects Qin, so the Qin woman will surely be elevated while your wife will be dismissed. It would be better to speak to King Huai and release him." Thereupon, Zheng Xiu spoke to King Huai day and night, saying, "Ministers serve their masters. Now, the land has not yet been ceded to Qin, and Qin has sent Zhang Yi, who is very respectful to Your Majesty. If Your Majesty kills Zhang Yi without proper courtesy, Qin will surely be furious and attack Chu. I request that my son and I move to the south of the Yangtze River, so that we may not be preyed upon by Qin." King Huai regretted his decision, pardoned Zhang Yi, and treated him with the same lavish hospitality as before.
[338 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 59 (Duke Xiao death; Huiwen succeeds; Shang Yang executed) (Wikipedia). Duke Xiao died, and his son, Duke Huiwen, ascended the throne. That year, Wei Yang was executed. When Yang first implemented the laws for Qin, they were not enforced, and the crown prince violated them. Yang said, "The failure to enforce the laws stems from the influence of the nobles and relatives. If Your Majesty truly wishes to enforce the laws, start with the crown prince. The crown prince cannot be tattooed; instead, tattoo his tutor." As a result, the laws were widely enforced, and Qin became well-governed. When Duke Xiao died and the crown prince ascended the throne, many members of the royal family resented Yang. When Yang fled, they accused him of rebellion and ultimately had him torn apart by chariots as a warning to the Qin state. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 80.1. In the twelfth year of Duke Ping's reign, King Hui of Qin died. In the twenty-second year, Duke Ping died, and his son Jia succeeded him, becoming Duke Wen. In the seventh year of Duke Wen's reign, King Huai of Chu died in Qin. In the twenty-third year, Duke Wen died, and his son Chou succeeded him, becoming Duke Qing. 80.1. In the twelfth year of Duke Ping's reign, King Hui of Qin died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 68 — Shang Jun Liezhuan] 10.1. Five months later, Duke Xiao of Qin died, and the crown prince ascended the throne. Gongzi Qian and his followers accused Shang Yang of plotting a rebellion, and officials were dispatched to arrest him. 10.2. Shang Yang fled to the border and sought lodging at an inn. The innkeeper, unaware of his identity, said, "According to Shang Yang's law, anyone who lodges a place without proper identification will be punished." Shang Yang sighed, "Alas, the flaws of the law have reached this point!" 10.3. He then went to Wei. The people of Wei resented his deception of Gongzi Ang and the subsequent defeat of their army, and refused to accept him. Shang Yang wanted to go to another state. The people of Wei said, "Shang Yang is a traitor to Qin. Qin is strong, and the traitor has entered Wei; it is unacceptable for him not to return." They then went to Qin. 10.4. After Shang Yang returned to Qin, he fled to Shangyi, and together with his followers, led the city's troops north to attack Zheng. Qin sent troops to attack Shang Yang, killing him at Mianchi in Zheng. King Hui of Qin had Shang Yang torn apart by chariots as a warning, saying, "No one is more rebellious than Shang Yang!" He then exterminated Shang Yang's entire family. 11 (authorial). Sima Qian said: "Shang Yu was by nature a mean and ruthless man. His attempt to persuade Duke Xiao with imperial strategies, relying on unfounded rumors, was contrary to his true nature. Furthermore, his rise to power through the influence of a favorite minister, his punishment of Prince Qian, his deception of the Wei general Ang, and his disregard for Zhao Liang's advice all demonstrate Shang Yu's lack of compassion. I have read Shang Yu's writings on opening up new avenues, cultivating land, and waging war, and they are consistent with his actions. He ultimately earned a bad reputation in Qin, and there is good reason for it!" [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 39. Later, Qin sent Xi Shou to deceive Qi and Wei, instructing them to jointly attack Zhao, intending to break the alliance. Qi and Wei attacked Zhao, and the King of Zhao rebuked Su Qin. Su Qin was afraid and requested to be sent as an envoy to Yan, promising to report back to Qi. Su Qin left Zhao, and the alliance was dissolved. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 24. After Zhang Yi left, he heard of Su Qin's death and then advised the King of Chu, saying, "Qin occupies half the land of the world, its army rivals four other states, it is protected by natural barriers and bordered by the Yellow River, with four fortified passes. We have over a million elite soldiers, a thousand chariots, ten thousand cavalry, and mountains of grain. Our laws are clear, and our soldiers are willing to die for their cause. Our ruler is wise and strict, and our generals are intelligent and martial. Even without raising our armor, we can sweep through the perils of Changshan and surely break the spine of the world. Those who submit later will perish first. Moreover, following the king is no different from leading a flock of sheep to attack a tiger; it is clear that a tiger and sheep cannot fight. Now, Your Majesty is giving sheep to a tiger, and I humbly believe that Your Majesty's plan is flawed." 25. "Whenever the most powerful states in the world are either Qin or Chu, or Chu or Qin, their rivalry is irreconcilable. If Your Majesty does not side with Qin, Qin will seize Yiyang, cutting off Han's access to the upper reaches of the land. If Qin conquers Hedong and takes Chenggao, Han will surely become a vassal state, and Liang will follow suit. If Qin attacks Chu's west, and Han and Liang attack its north, how can the state not be in danger?"
[337 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 60.1 (King Huiwen yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of King Huiwen's reign, the people of Chu, Han, Zhao, and Shu came to pay homage. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 55. In the eighteenth year, Qi and Wei attacked us, and we diverted the Yellow River to flood them, forcing their retreat. In the twenty-second year, Zhang Yi became the prime minister of Qin. Zhao Ci fought against Qin and was defeated. Qin killed Zhao Ci west of the Yellow River and seized Lin and Lishi from us. In the twenty-third year, Han Ju fought against Qi and Wei and died in Sangqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 19.3. In the tenth year, Han Ji murdered her ruler, Duke Dao. In the eleventh year, Marquis Zhao went to Qin. In the twenty-second year, Shen Buhai died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin came and captured Yiyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 40. King Hui of Qin married his daughter to the Crown Prince of Yan. That same year, Marquis Wen died, and the Crown Prince ascended the throne as King Yi of Yan. Shortly after King Yi's ascension, King Xuan of Qi, taking advantage of Yan's mourning period, attacked Yan and seized ten cities. King Yi said to Su Qin, "When you first arrived in Yan, the late King provided you with funds to meet with Zhao, thus forming an alliance of six states. Now Qi has attacked Zhao first, and then comes to Yan. Because of you, the world will laugh at us. Can you help Yan obtain the lost territory?" Su Qin was greatly ashamed and said, "I will take it for Your Majesty." [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 26. "Furthermore, those who follow the weak to attack the strong, who rashly engage in battle without considering the enemy, and who frequently wage war despite their own poverty, are destined for ruin. I have heard that one should not challenge those whose soldiers are inferior, nor should one engage in prolonged battles with those whose provisions are insufficient. Those who follow the weak, who use eloquent and empty rhetoric to appear virtuous to their ruler, who speak of the benefits but not the harms, will ultimately suffer the same fate as Qin, and there will be no time to remedy the situation. Therefore, I urge Your Majesty to consider this carefully." 27. "To the west of Qin lies Ba and Shu. Large ships laden with grain set out from Wenshan, sailing down the Yangtze River to Chu, a distance of over three thousand li. Small boats carry soldiers, each carrying fifty men and three months' worth of provisions. They float on the water, traveling over three hundred li a day. Although the distance is great, it requires no oxen or horses, and they reach Yuguan in less than ten days. If Yuguan is alarmed, all cities east of the border will be fortified, and Qianzhong and Wujun will no longer belong to the king. Qin will raise its army and march out of Wuguan, attacking from the south, cutting off the northern lands. Qin's attack on Chu will be a crisis within three months, while Chu awaits the aid of the other states for more than half a year. This is why their situations are not mutually reinforcing. Relying on the aid of weak states and forgetting the threat of powerful Qin is what I worry about for Your Majesty."
[336 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.6. In the thirty-third year, he congratulated King Hui of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 60.2 (yr 2). In the second year, the emperor offered congratulations. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 41. When Su Qin met King Qi, he bowed twice, prostrating himself in celebration and then looking up in mourning. King Qi asked, "Why is there such a swift combination of celebration and mourning?" Su Qin replied, "I have heard that the reason a starving person does not eat a crow's beak is because it would only fill their stomach and bring them the same suffering as starvation. Now, although Yan is weak, it is the son-in-law of the King of Qin. Your Majesty benefits from its ten cities and will forever be an enemy of the powerful Qin. If you were to send the weak Yan in a flock of geese while the powerful Qin were to exhaust its rear, thus attracting the best troops in the world, it would be like eating a crow's beak." King Qi's expression changed drastically, and he asked, "Then what should we do?" Su Qin replied, "I have heard that in ancient times..." Those skilled in managing affairs can turn misfortune into fortune and defeat into victory. If Your Majesty truly heeds my advice, I will return the ten cities of Yan. Yan, having gained ten cities without cause, will surely rejoice; the King of Qin, knowing that the ten cities of Yan are being returned because of him, will also surely rejoice. This is what is meant by abandoning enmity and gaining a close friend. Since both Yan and Qin serve Qi, Your Majesty's commands throughout the land will be obeyed by all. Thus, Your Majesty, by using empty words to ally with Qin, will gain the world with ten cities. This is the achievement of a hegemon.” The King said, “Excellent.” And so he returned the ten cities of Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 28. "Your Majesty once fought against the Wu people, winning three out of five battles, but your army was wiped out; you then defended Xincheng, causing great suffering to the people. I have heard that those who achieve great merit are easily endangered, and those whose people are impoverished resent their rulers. To defend a merit that is easily endangered while going against the will of the powerful Qin, I fear for Your Majesty." 29. "The reason why Qin did not send troops to Hangu Pass for fifteen years to attack Qi and Zhao is that it harbored a conspiracy to unite the hearts of the people. Chu once fought with Qin in Hanzhong, where the Chu army was defeated, and more than seventy of the marquises died holding their jade tablets, thus losing Hanzhong. The King of Chu was furious and raised an army to attack Qin, fighting at Lantian. This is what is meant by two tigers fighting. Qin and Chu are exhausted, while Han and Wei can preserve their rear. There is no danger in this situation. I hope Your Majesty will consider this carefully."
[335 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 60.3 (yr 3). In the third year, the king was crowned. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 19.4. In the tenth year, Han Ji murdered her ruler, Duke Dao. In the eleventh year, Marquis Zhao went to Qin. In the twenty-second year, Shen Buhai died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin came and captured Yiyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 29. Zou Jizi presented his zither to King Wei, who was pleased and entertained him in the right chamber. A short while later, the king played the zither, and Zou Jizi pushed open the door and entered, exclaiming, "Excellent zither playing!" The king was displeased, put down the zither, and drew his sword, saying, "Master, you are so oblivious to my appearance, how do you know it is excellent?" Zou Jizi replied, "The large strings, deep and warm like spring, represent the ruler; the small strings, sharp and clear, represent the minister; the deep, resonant notes represent government decrees; the harmonious sounds, large and small complementing each other, turning right and wrong without harming each other, represent the four seasons: this is how I know it is excellent." The king said, "Excellent music." Zou Jizi said, "Not only music, but governing the state and pacifying the people are all contained within it." The king was again displeased. The king said, "If we speak of the principles of the five tones, there is truly no one like you, Master. But if we speak of governing a state and pacifying the people, what need is there for the music of the strings and the paulownia?" Zou Jizi replied, "The large string, deep and warm like spring, represents the ruler; the small string, sharp and clear, represents the minister; the deep pull and the pleasant release represent government decrees; the harmonious sound of the strings, large and small complementing each other, turning and twisting without harming each other, represents the four seasons. The harmony without chaos is the means of governance and prosperity; the interconnectedness and directness are the means of survival and destruction. Therefore, it is said that when the music of the zither is harmonious, the world is at peace. And for governing a state and pacifying the people, nothing surpasses the five tones." The king said, "Excellent." [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 42. Some people slandered Su Qin, saying, "He is a treacherous and fickle minister who will betray his country and cause chaos." Su Qin, fearing punishment, returned home, and the King of Yan refused to reinstate him. Su Qin met with the King of Yan and said, "I am but a lowly man from Eastern Zhou, without any merit, yet Your Majesty personally bows to me in the temple and treats me with courtesy in the court. Now, I have repelled the Qi army for Your Majesty and captured ten cities, which should strengthen our bond. Yet Your Majesty refuses to appoint me; people will surely use this distrust to harm Your Majesty. My distrust is Your Majesty's blessing. I have heard that loyalty and trustworthiness are for self-preservation; ambition is for the benefit of others. Moreover, my advice to the King of Qi was not deceitful. I abandoned my elderly mother in Eastern Zhou, thus abandoning my self-preservation..." "And to advance and strive. Now there are those as filial as Zeng Shen, as incorruptible as Boyi, and as trustworthy as Wei Sheng. What do you think of having these three to serve Your Majesty?" The king said, "That is sufficient." Su Qin said, "As filial as Zeng Shen, he would not leave his parents even for a single night. How can Your Majesty make him walk a thousand miles to serve the weak and endangered king of Yan? As incorruptible as Boyi, he would not become the heir of the ruler of Guzhu, nor would he serve King Wu. He refused a title and starved to death at the foot of Shouyang Mountain. With such incorruptibility, how can Your Majesty make him walk a thousand miles to advance and strive?" "How could such a man be so trustworthy? He was like Wei Sheng, who made an appointment with a woman under a bridge. The woman didn't come, and even when the water rose, he didn't leave, eventually dying while embracing a pillar. If such a man possessed such integrity, how could Your Majesty possibly order him to walk a thousand miles to repel the powerful army of Qi? This is what I mean by offending one's superior through loyalty and trustworthiness." The King of Yan said, "If one is not loyal and trustworthy, how can one be offended for loyalty and trustworthiness?" Su Qin replied, "No. I have heard of a guest who was serving as an official far away, and his wife was having an affair. When her husband came to visit, the other man was worried, but the wife said, 'Don't worry, I have already prepared medicinal wine.'" "Wait for him." Three days later, her husband indeed arrived, and the wife instructed her concubine to bring him medicated wine. The concubine wanted to tell him that the wine contained medicine, but feared he would drive away the mistress; she wanted not to tell him, but feared he would kill the master's father. So she pretended to freeze and threw away the wine. The master's father was furious and had her flogged fifty times. Thus, the concubine froze and spilled the wine, saving the master's father above and the mistress below, yet she could not escape the flogging. How could loyalty and trust be considered innocent? My fault, unfortunately, is like this!" The King of Yan said, "Sir, return to your former post." He treated him even more generously. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 30. "If Qin attacks Weiyang and Jin with its armored armor, it will surely be a major threat to the world. Your Majesty should raise all your troops to attack Song. In just a few months, Song can be taken. Once Song is taken, you can turn east and then all twelve vassal states along the Si River will be yours."
[334 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.7. In the thirty-fifth year, he presented sacrificial meat offerings to King Hui of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 60.4 (yr 4). In the fourth year, the emperor presented sacrificial offerings to the civil and military officials. Qi and Wei were declared kings. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 69. In the sixth year of King Wei's reign, King Xian of Zhou presented sacrificial meat to King Hui of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 56. In the twenty-fourth year, Marquis Su died. Qin, Chu, Yan, Qi, and Wei each sent ten thousand elite troops to attend his funeral. His son, King Wuling, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 20.1. In the twenty-fifth year, a drought struck, and a high gate was built. Qu Yijiu said, "Marquis Zhao does not leave this gate. Why? Because it is not the right time. What I mean by 'right time' is not the exact day; people sometimes have advantages and sometimes disadvantages. Marquis Zhao has had advantages before, but he did not build the high gate. Last year, Qin captured Yiyang, and this year there is a drought. Marquis Zhao does not use this time to relieve the people's urgent needs, but instead indulges in extravagance. This is what is meant by 'when the time is not right, one should act when it is not right.'" In the twenty-sixth year, the high gate was completed, and Marquis Zhao died, indeed never leaving this gate. His son, King Xuanhui, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 30. Zou Jizi received the seal of office as prime minister after three months. Chunyu Kun, upon seeing him, said, "Well said! I have some foolish thoughts, which I wish to present." Zou Jizi said, "I will humbly accept your instruction." Chunyu Kun said, "To gain wholeness is to prosper; to lose wholeness is to perish." Zou Jizi said, "I will humbly accept your command and will not deviate from it." Chunyu Kun said, "A thorny axle is slippery, but it cannot be used to pierce a hole." Zou Jizi said, "I will humbly accept your command and will serve you diligently." Chunyu Kun said, "A bow is bound together with glue and dry material, but it cannot seal gaps." Zou Jizi said, "I will humbly accept your command and will diligently serve the people." Chunyu Kun said, "Even a worn-out fox fur coat cannot be patched with a yellow dog's skin." Zou Jizi said, "I respectfully accept your order. Please carefully select virtuous men and do not mix petty men among them." Chunyu Kun said, "A large cart cannot carry its usual load without being balanced; a zither cannot produce its five notes without being balanced." Zou Jizi said, "I respectfully accept your order. Please carefully uphold the law and supervise corrupt officials." After Chunyu Kun finished speaking, he hurried out. Upon reaching the gate, he faced his servant and said, "This man, when I spoke five subtle words to him, responded to me as readily as an echo. This man will surely be enfeoffed soon." After a period of time, he was enfeoffed in Xiapi and given the title of Marquis Cheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 43. Yi Wangmu, the wife of Marquis Wen, had an affair with Su Qin. King Yan knew of this and treated Su Qin with even greater favor. Su Qin, fearing execution, persuaded King Yan, saying, "If I remain in Yan, I cannot make Yan important, but if I go to Qi, Yan will surely be important." King Yan said, "I will do as you say, sir." Thereupon, Su Qin pretended to have offended Yan and fled to Qi, where King Xuan of Qi appointed him as a guest minister. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 31. "Among all the people in the world who relied on trust and kinship, Su Qin was enfeoffed as the Marquis of Wu'an and appointed Prime Minister of Yan. He secretly conspired with the King of Yan to attack and destroy Qi and divide its territory. He then feigned a crime and fled to Qi, whereupon the King of Qi accepted him and appointed him Prime Minister. After two years, the truth came out, and the King of Qi was furious, having Su Qin torn apart by chariots in the marketplace. It is clear that it was impossible for a fraudulent Su Qin to manage the world and unify the feudal lords." 32. "Now Qin and Chu share a border and are therefore close allies. If Your Majesty would truly listen to my advice, I request that the Crown Prince of Qin be sent as a hostage to Chu, and the Crown Prince of Chu be sent as a hostage to Qin. I also request that a woman from Qin be given to Your Majesty as a concubine, and that a city of ten thousand households be made into a fiefdom for Your Majesty's use. We shall remain brothers and never attack each other. I believe there is no better plan than this."
[333 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.1 (King Huiwen yr 5). In the fifth year, Xi Shou, a man from Yin Jin, was appointed Grand Minister of Works. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 70. In the seventh year, Tian Ying, father of Lord Mengchang of Qi, deceived Chu. King Wei of Chu attacked Qi and defeated them at Xuzhou, ordering Qi to pursue Tian Ying. Tian Ying was afraid, so Zhang Chou falsely told the King of Chu, "The reason Your Majesty won the battle at Xuzhou was because you did not employ Tian Panzi. Panzi has rendered meritorious service to the state, and the people serve him. Tian Ying was not good and instead employed Shen Ji. Shen Ji has no ministers to support him, and the people do not serve him, so Your Majesty was victorious. Now Your Majesty pursues Tian Ying, and Tian Ying pursues him, then Panzi will surely employ him. He will then fight his soldiers against Your Majesty, which will certainly not be in Your Majesty's favor." Therefore, the King of Chu did not pursue him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 16. Therefore, Yue released Qi and attacked Chu. King Wei of Chu raised an army to attack Yue, defeated Yue, killed King Wuqiang, seized all of Wu's territory up to Zhejiang, and defeated Qi in Xuzhou. As a result, Yue was scattered, and its various clans vied for power, some becoming kings and others becoming rulers, living along the southern coast of the Yangtze River and paying homage to Chu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 57. In the first year of King Wuling's reign, Lord Yangwen, Zhao Bao, served as prime minister. King Xiang of Liang and his crown prince succeeded to the throne, while King Xuan of Han and his crown prince Cang came to pay homage at Xin Palace. King Wuling was young and unable to rule, so he had three learned teachers and three advisors to oversee his conduct. When he began to rule, he first inquired about Fei Yi, a noble minister of the late king, and promoted him; he also paid monthly respects to the three elderly men of the state who were eighty years old. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 20.2. In the twenty-fifth year, a drought struck, and a high gate was built. Qu Yijiu said, "Marquis Zhao does not leave this gate. Why? Because it is not the right time. What I mean by 'right time' is not the exact day; people sometimes have advantages and sometimes disadvantages. Marquis Zhao has had advantages before, but he did not build the high gate. Last year, Qin captured Yiyang, and this year there is a drought. Marquis Zhao does not use this time to relieve the people's urgent needs, but instead indulges in extravagance. This is what is meant by 'when the time is not right, one should act when it is not right.'" In the twenty-sixth year, the high gate was completed, and Marquis Zhao died, indeed never leaving this gate. His son, King Xuanhui, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 33. King Huai of Chu, having already obtained Zhang Yi, again offered the land of Qianzhong to Qin and intended to grant it. Qu Yuan said, "Your Majesty was previously deceived by Zhang Yi. When Zhang Yi arrived, I thought Your Majesty should cook him alive. Now, even if you cannot bear to kill him, you should also listen to his heretical words. This is unacceptable." King Huai said, "Granting Zhang Yi and obtaining Qianzhong is a great benefit. To later betray that would be unacceptable." Therefore, he ultimately granted Zhang Yi's request and formed an alliance with Qin.
[332 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.2 (yr 6). In the sixth year, Wei annexed Yin Jin, which was renamed Ning Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 31. In the twenty-third year of King Wei's reign, he met with the King of Zhao at Pinglu. In the twenty-fourth year, he met with the King of Wei at a hunting expedition in the suburbs. The King of Wei asked, "Does Your Majesty also possess any treasures?" King Wei replied, "No." The King of Liang said, "Even in my small kingdom, I possess ten pearls, each an inch in diameter, which illuminate the front and back of twelve chariots. How can a kingdom of ten thousand chariots be without any treasures?" King Wei replied, "The treasures I possess differ from Your Majesty's. My minister, Tanzi, was sent to guard the southern city, and the Chu people dared not raid eastward, and the twelve vassal states along the Si River all came to pay homage. My minister, Zi, was sent to guard Gaotang, and the Zhao people dared not fish eastward in the river. My official, Qianfu, was sent to guard Xuzhou, and the Yan people offered sacrifices at the north gate, and the Zhao people offered sacrifices at the west gate, with over seven thousand families migrating to follow him. My minister, Zhongshou, was sent to guard against thieves, and no one picked up lost items on the road. These treasures illuminate a thousand miles, far exceeding the value of twelve chariots!" King Hui of Liang was ashamed and left displeased. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 44. When King Xuan of Qi died, King Min ascended the throne. King Min was advised to give King Min a lavish funeral to demonstrate filial piety, and to build grand palaces and large gardens to demonstrate his power and influence, intending to weaken Qi and subjugate Yan. When King Yi of Yan died, King Kuai of Yan became king. Afterwards, many officials of Qi vied for Su Qin's favor, and someone sent an assassin to kill Su Qin. The assassin survived and fled. The King of Qi sent men to find the assassin, but they could not find him. As Su Qin was about to die, he said to the King of Qi, "When I die, have me torn apart by chariots and displayed in the marketplace, saying, 'Su Qin has caused chaos in Qi for Yan.' Then my assassin will surely be found." So the king did as he said, and the assassin who killed Su Qin indeed appeared, and the King of Qi executed him. When Yan heard of this, they said, "How great is Qi's revenge for Su Qin!" [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 34. Zhang Yi went to Chu, and then went to Han, where he advised the King of Han: "Han is a treacherous mountainous region. The only grains grown there are beans and wheat. The people's diet consists mostly of beans and broad bean soup. If there is a bad harvest one year, the people will go hungry. The land is no more than nine hundred li in circumference, and there is no food for two years. I estimate that Your Majesty's army, even at its full strength, numbers no more than three hundred thousand, and even that includes servants and laborers. Aside from those guarding the border posts and fortifications, there are no more than two hundred thousand soldiers. Qin, on the other hand, has over a million armored soldiers, a thousand chariots, ten thousand cavalry, and a formidable army of elite warriors." Those with halberds piercing their chins and brandishing spears were countless. The Qin horses were excellent, and the Qin soldiers numerous; those who could leap three fathoms in a row were too many to count. The soldiers from Shandong, clad in armor and helmets, engaged in battle, while the Qin soldiers, stripped of their armor and barefoot, charged at the enemy, carrying severed heads on their left and live captives on their right. The Qin soldiers and the soldiers from Shandong were like Meng Ben and a coward; their combined strength was like Wu Huo and an infant.
