To fight against Meng Ben and Wu Huo's soldiers against a weak, unyielding state was like placing a thousand-pound weight on a bird's egg—a certain doom.
[331 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.3 (yr 7). In the seventh year, Prince Ang fought against Wei, capturing its general Long Jia and beheading 80,000. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 58. In the third year, he entered the city of Hao. In the fourth year, he met with Han at Qushu. In the fifth year, he married Han's daughter. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 45. After Su Qin's death, his deeds were exposed. The Queen of Qi, upon hearing this, harbored deep resentment towards Yan. Yan was greatly fearful. Su Qin's younger brother was named Dai, and Dai's younger brother, Su Li, upon seeing his brother Su Qin, also studied under him. After Su Qin's death, Dai sought an audience with the King of Yan, intending to follow precedent. He said, "I am a humble man from Eastern Zhou. I have heard that Your Majesty's righteousness is extremely lofty. I am not clever enough, so I abandoned my hoe and weeds to seek Your Majesty's favor. Upon arriving in Handan, what I saw was inferior to what I had heard in Eastern Zhou, yet I secretly harbored my ambitions. Upon arriving at the Yan court, observing Your Majesty's ministers and officials, I realized Your Majesty is a wise king indeed." The King of Yan asked, "What kind of wise king do you speak of?" Dai replied, "I have heard that a wise king seeks to hear of his faults, not his virtues. I request to hear of Your Majesty's faults. Qi and Zhao are Yan's enemies; Chu and Wei are Yan's allies. Now Your Majesty uses your enemies to attack..." "To aid the state is not to benefit Yan. Your Majesty should consider this carefully; this is a miscalculation. Those who have not reported this are not loyal ministers." The king said, "Qi is indeed my enemy, and I wish to attack it, but I am troubled by the state's exhaustion and insufficient strength. If you can use Yan to attack Qi, I will entrust the entire state to you." The minister replied, "Of the seven Warring States, Yan is the weakest. It cannot fight alone, but if it allies with any state, it will be powerful. If it allies with Chu to the south, Chu will be powerful; if it allies with Qin to the west, Qin will be powerful; if it allies with Han and Wei in the center, Han and Wei will be powerful. Moreover, if the state it allies with is powerful, it will surely make Your Majesty powerful. Now, Qi is a powerful state..." And yet, it was for its own use. For five years, it attacked Chu in the south, exhausting its resources; for three years, it besieged Qin in the west, its soldiers exhausted; in the north, it fought Yan, annihilating three armies and gaining two generals. Yet, with the remaining troops, it marched south to the Great Song with five thousand chariots, encompassing twelve other states. This is what its ruler desired, but its people were exhausted—how could it be worth taking? Moreover, I have heard that frequent battles weary the people, and prolonged wars exhaust the army.” The King of Yan said, “I have heard that Qi possesses the Qingji and Zhuohe rivers for defense, and the Great Wall and massive defenses for protection. Is this truly the case?” He replied, “The timing is not right. Even with the Qingji and Zhuohe rivers...” "Evil is not enough to secure a stronghold! The people are exhausted; even with the Great Wall and massive defenses, how can they be a barrier? Moreover, if the army does not attack from the west of the Ji River in the future, it will be to defend against Zhao; if the army does not attack from the north of the Ji River, it will be to defend against Yan. Now, the west of the Ji River and the north of the Ji River have been completely occupied, and the borders are exhausted. A proud ruler is bound to be greedy for profit, and a minister who brings ruin to a country is bound to be greedy for wealth. If Your Majesty can shamelessly send your son, mother, and brother as hostages, and use precious jewels and jade to serve those around you, they will be grateful to Yan and will lightly destroy Song, then Qi will surely perish." The King of Yan said, "I will ultimately receive the mandate of Heaven through you." Yan then sent one of its sons as a hostage to Qi. Su Li, through the Yan hostage, sought an audience with the King of Qi. The King of Qi resented Su Qin and wanted to imprison Su Li. The Yan hostage apologized and thus became a subject of Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 35. "The ministers and feudal lords, not considering the scarcity of their territory, listened to the sweet words and flattering rhetoric of others, forming cliques to embellish each other, all proclaiming, 'Listen to my plan, and we can dominate the world.' There is no one more deceiving and misleading a ruler than this, who disregarded the long-term interests of the state and listened to short-term advice." 36. "If Your Majesty does not serve Qin, Qin will seize Yiyang with its armored forces, cut off the upper reaches of Han, and take Chenggao and Xingyang to the east. Then the Hongtai Palace and the Sanglin Garden will no longer belong to Your Majesty. If Chenggao is blocked and the upper reaches of Han are cut off, Your Majesty's kingdom will be divided. Serving Qin first will bring peace, while not serving Qin will bring danger. To create disaster and seek reward is a shallow plan that breeds deep resentment. To oppose Qin and submit to Chu, even if you wish to avoid destruction, is impossible."
[330 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.4 (yr 8). In the eighth year, Wei annexed the Hexi region. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 32. In the twenty-sixth year, King Hui of Wei besieged Handan, and Zhao sought help from Qi. King Wei of Qi summoned his ministers and consulted them, saying, "Should we rescue Zhao or not?" Zou Jizi said, "It is better not to rescue." Duan Ganpeng said, "Not rescuing is unjust and also disadvantageous." King Wei asked, "Why?" He replied, "If Wei annexes Handan, what benefit will it bring to Qi? Moreover, if we rescue Zhao and then encamp on its outskirts, it means that Wei will be safe without Zhao's attack. Therefore, it is better to attack Xiangling in the south to provoke Wei, and then, after capturing Handan, take advantage of Wei's weakness." King Wei followed his advice. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 46. The prime minister of Yan, Zizhi, married Su Dai, but desired power in Yan. He sent Su Dai to serve as a hostage to the king of Qi. Qi sent Su Dai to inform Yan, and King Kuai of Yan asked, "Will the King of Qi become a hegemon?" The king replied, "No." The king asked, "Why?" The king replied, "Because he does not trust his ministers." Therefore, the king of Yan exclusively trusted Zizhi, and later abdicated, plunging Yan into chaos. Qi attacked Yan, killing King Kuai and Zizhi. Yan established King Zhao, and Su Dai and Su Li dared not enter Yan, ultimately returning to Qi, where they were treated well. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 37. "Therefore, for Your Majesty's sake, there is no better plan than to serve Qin. What Qin desires most is to weaken Chu, and the only one capable of weakening Chu is Han. It is not because Han is stronger than Chu, but because of its geographical location. Now, Your Majesty should turn west and serve Qin in order to attack Chu, and the King of Qin will surely be pleased. Attacking Chu to gain territory, turning misfortune into favor with Qin, there is no better plan than this."
[329 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.5 (yr 9). In the ninth year, Wei crossed the river and captured Fenying and Pishi. Wei met with the King of Wei. Wei besieged Jiao and forced it to surrender. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 71. In the eleventh year, King Wei died, and his son, King Huai Xiong Huai, ascended the throne. Upon hearing of the death of Chu, Wei attacked Chu and captured Xingshan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 33. Later, Marquis Cheng, Zou Ji, and Tian Ji became enemies. Gongsun Yue said to Marquis Cheng, "Why don't you plan to attack Wei? Tian Ji will surely lead the attack. If you win and achieve merit, your plan will be successful; if you lose, he will either die on the front lines or be defeated, and your fate will be in your hands." Marquis Cheng then advised King Wei to send Tian Ji south to attack Xiangling. In October, Handan fell, and Qi then launched an attack on Wei, inflicting a great defeat on them at Guiling. Qi then became the strongest among the feudal lords, proclaiming itself king to command the world. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 47. Su Dai passed through Wei, and Wei was captured by Yan. A messenger from Qi told the King of Wei, "Qi requests to enfeoff Lord Jingyang with land in Song, but Qin will surely refuse. It's not that Qin doesn't want to possess Qi and gain Song, but rather that it doesn't trust the King of Qi and Su Dai. Now, Qi and Wei are so at odds, Qi will not deceive Qin. If Qin trusts Qi, Qi and Qin will unite, and Lord Jingyang will have Song land, which is not beneficial to Wei. Therefore, Your Majesty should send Su Dai east; Qin will then doubt Qi and distrust Su Dai. If Qi and Qin do not unite, the world will remain unchanged, and the formation of an attack on Qi will be inevitable." So Su Dai was sent east. He went to Song, and Song treated him well. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 38. King Han listened to Zhang Yi's advice. Zhang Yi returned and reported, and King Hui of Qin enfeoffed Zhang Yi with five cities, bestowing upon him the title of Lord Wuxin. He then sent Zhang Yi eastward to persuade King Min of Qi, saying, "No country in the world is stronger than Qi. Its ministers, fathers, brothers, and relatives are wealthy and prosperous. However, those who advise Your Majesty are all concerned with immediate gains, disregarding the benefits for generations to come. Those who advise Your Majesty invariably say, 'To the west of Qi lies the powerful Zhao, and to the south, Han and Liang. Qi is a country bordering the sea, with vast territory, a large population, and a strong and brave army. Even if there were a hundred Qin states, what could they do to Qi?' Your Majesty values their words but does not consider their practicalities. Those who follow others, forming factions and forming cliques, all believe that following them is the right thing to do." I have heard that Qi and Lu fought three battles, with Lu winning all three. Yet, Qi subsequently perished, though it had the reputation of victory, its reality was one of national ruin. Why was this? Because Qi was large and Lu was small. Now, the relationship between Qin and Qi is similar to that between Qi and Lu. Qin and Zhao fought on the banks of the Yellow River and the Zhang River, and Zhao won again; they fought at Fanwu, and Zhao won again. After these four battles, Zhao lost hundreds of thousands of soldiers, and only Handan remained. Though it had the reputation of victory, its state was destroyed. Why was this? Because Qin was strong and Zhao was weak.
[328 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.6 (yr 10). In the tenth year, Zhang Yi became Prime Minister of Qin. Wei annexed fifteen counties of Shangjun. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 80.2. In the twenty-second year, Duke Ping died, and his son Jia succeeded him, becoming Duke Wen. In the seventh year of Duke Wen's reign, King Huai of Chu died in Qin. In the twenty-third year, Duke Wen died, and his son Chou succeeded him, becoming Duke Qing. 80.2. In the twenty-second year, Duke Ping died, and his son Jia succeeded him, becoming Duke Wen. In the seventh year of Duke Wen's reign, King Huai of Chu died in Qin. In the twenty-third year, Duke Wen died, and his son Chou succeeded him, becoming Duke Qing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 72.1. In the first year of King Huai's reign, Zhang Yi became the prime minister of King Hui of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 21.1. In the fifth year of King Xuanhui's reign, Zhang Yi became the prime minister of Qin. In the eighth year, Wei defeated my general Han Ju. In the eleventh year, you proclaimed yourself king. You met with Zhao at Qushu. In the fourteenth year, Qin attacked and defeated my Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 48. Qi attacked Song, and Song was in dire straits. Su Dai then sent a letter to King Zhao of Yan, saying: 49. To hold a high position in the state of Yan while being held hostage in Qi is a sign of low status and little power; to assist Qi in attacking Song while serving as its chieftain is a drain on the people and a costly endeavor; to destroy Song, cripple Chu north of the Huai River, and enrich Qi, will only strengthen the enemy and harm the state: all three are devastating consequences for the nation. Yet, Your Majesty's intention in pursuing this strategy is to gain the trust of Qi. Qi's distrust of Your Majesty and its growing resentment towards Yan demonstrate a flawed plan. Adding Song to the north of the Huai River strengthens a state of ten thousand chariots, and Qi's annexation only adds to Qi's power. Adding Lu and Wei to the seven hundred li square of northern barbarians strengthens a state of ten thousand chariots, and Qi's annexation only adds to Qi's power. Even with the strength of one Qi, Yan is still powerless; now, with three Qi threatening Yan, the calamity will be immense. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 39. "Now Qin and Chu are marrying off their daughters and taking wives, becoming like brothers. Han has offered Yiyang; Liang has offered the land beyond the Yellow River; Zhao has paid tribute at Mianchi and ceded the Yellow River to serve Qin. If Your Majesty does not serve Qin, Qin will drive Han and Liang to attack the southern lands of Qi, and will send all of Zhao's troops across the Qing River, pointing towards Bo Pass. Linzi and Jimo will no longer belong to Your Majesty. If your country is attacked even once, even if you wish to serve Qin, it will be impossible. Therefore, I hope Your Majesty will consider this carefully."
[327 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.7 (yr 11). In the eleventh year, Yiqu was established. Jiao and Quwo were returned to Wei. The ruler of Yiqu became a subject. Shaoliang was renamed Xiayang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 34. In the thirty-third year, he killed his minister, Mou Xin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 50. Although wise men can turn misfortune into fortune and defeat into victory, Qi Zi, who was originally a poor scholar, sold his wares for ten times the price; and King Goujian of Yue, who, after taking refuge in Kuaiji, quelled the rebellion of the powerful Wu and became the hegemon of the world, are examples of those who turned misfortune into fortune and defeat into victory. 51. If Your Majesty wishes to turn misfortune into fortune and defeat into victory, then there is no better course of action than to provoke and honor the hegemon Qi, send its envoys to form an alliance with the Zhou court, burn the Qin tally, and declare, "The best course of action is to defeat Qin; the next best is to keep it as a guest for a long time." Qin will then use this guest as leverage to await defeat, and the King of Qin will surely be troubled by this. For five generations, Qin has attacked the other states, but now it is under the control of Qi. If the King of Qin's ambition is to thoroughly defeat Qi, he will not hesitate to sacrifice his own state for this purpose. Why doesn't Your Majesty send a debater to persuade the King of Qin with these words: "Yan and Zhao defeated Song and enriched Qi, yet they are now treated as inferiors. Yan and Zhao do this not out of self-interest, but out of necessity, because they do not trust Your Majesty. Why doesn't Your Majesty send trustworthy individuals to receive Yan and Zhao, and have Lord Jingyang and Lord Gaoling arrive before them? If Qin changes its mind, they can be used as hostages, and Yan and Zhao will then trust Qin. Qin will become the Western Emperor, Yan the Northern Emperor, and Zhao the Central Emperor, establishing three emperors to command the world. If Han and Wei do not obey, Qin will attack them; if Qi does not obey, Yan and Zhao will attack them. Who in the world would dare disobey? With the world submitting, Han can be driven out." Wei, in its attack on Qi, declared, "They will surely reclaim the lands of Song and return the lands north of the Huai River to Chu." Reclaiming the lands of Song and returning the lands north of the Huai River to Chu would benefit Yan and Zhao; establishing three emperors together would also be what Yan and Zhao desire. Having truly gained their benefits and achieved their desires, Yan and Zhao would discard Qi as easily as discarding worn-out shoes. If we do not subdue Yan and Zhao now, Qi will surely become hegemon. If the other states support Qi but the king does not follow, the state will be attacked; if the other states support Qi but the king follows, the state's reputation will be diminished. If we subdue Yan and Zhao now, the state will be secure and its reputation will be elevated; if we do not subdue Yan and Zhao, the state will be in danger and its reputation will be diminished. A wise man would not abandon prestige and security for danger and despair.” The King of Qin, upon hearing this, would surely feel as if his heart had been pierced. Why then does the king not send a debater to persuade Qin with these words? Qin will surely take Qi, and Qi will surely attack. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 40. The King of Qi said, "Qi is a remote and humble place, and we live in seclusion on the eastern sea. We have never heard of the long-term benefits of governing the state." So he granted Zhang Yi's request.
[326 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 61.8 (yr 12/13 stem-date mention; kings declared). In the twelfth year, the first month of the year of the twelfth lunar month. On the day of Wuwu in the fourth month of the thirteenth year, the ruler of Wei became King, and Han also became King. Wei sent Zhang Yi to conquer Shan and surrender its people to Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 52. To conquer Qin was to forge a strong alliance; to attack Qi was to pursue legitimate interests. To value strong alliances and pursue legitimate interests is the way of a sage king. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 41. Zhang Yi left and went west to speak to the King of Zhao, saying: "The King of Qin has sent me to offer my humble advice to Your Majesty. Your Majesty has gathered the world under your rule, and for fifteen years, the Qin army has dared not leave Hangu Pass. Your Majesty's power extends to the east of the mountains, and my humble state is filled with fear and submission. We have strengthened our armor and weapons, adorned our chariots and cavalry, practiced archery and horsemanship, diligently cultivated the land and stored grain, guarding our borders. We live in fear and do not dare to waver, only hoping that Your Majesty will correct our mistakes."
[325 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 68.8. In the forty-fourth year, King Hui of Qin proclaimed himself King. Afterwards, all the feudal lords proclaimed themselves Kings. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 72.2. Four years later, King Hui of Qin officially became king. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 21.2. In the fifth year of King Xuanhui's reign, Zhang Yi became the prime minister of Qin. In the eighth year, Wei defeated my general Han Ju. In the eleventh year, you proclaimed yourself king. You met with Zhao at Qushu. In the fourteenth year, Qin attacked and defeated my Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 35. In the thirty-fifth year, Gongsun Yue again said to Marquis Cheng Ji, "Why don't you send someone with ten gold pieces to the market to divine, saying, 'I am Tian Ji. I have won three battles in a row, and my fame is known throughout the world. I wish to accomplish great things. Is this auspicious or inauspicious?'" The diviner left, and Gongsun Yue then ordered his men to arrest the diviner and verify his words at the king's court. Tian Ji heard of this and led his followers to attack Linzi, demanding Marquis Cheng's return. They were defeated and fled. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 53. King Zhao of Yan admired the book and said, "Our ancestors once had a virtuous relationship with the Su family, but the Su family left Yan during the rebellion of Zizhi. If Yan wishes to avenge itself against Qi, there is no one but the Su family." So he summoned Su Dai, treated him well again, and conspired with him to attack Qi. In the end, Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 42. "Now, with Your Majesty's power, you have conquered Ba and Shu, annexed Hanzhong, encompassed the Zhou and Shang dynasties, moved the Nine Tripods, and guarded the Baima Ferry. Although Qin is remote and distant, it has long harbored resentment and anger. Now Qin has worn-out armor and dilapidated soldiers, and is stationed at Mianchi. We wish to cross the river and the Zhang River, occupy Fanwu, and meet at Handan. We wish to engage in battle on the Jiazi day to rectify the affairs of King Zhou of Yin. I respectfully send this envoy to inform your attendants first." 43. "All those whom Your Majesty trusts and follows rely on Su Qin. Su Qin misled the feudal lords, making right appear wrong and wrong appear right, intending to rebel against Qi, and ultimately causing his own execution by dismemberment in the marketplace. It is clear that the world cannot be unified. Now, Chu and Qin are brother states, yet Han and Liang are called vassals of the eastern frontier, and Qi is offering land for fish and salt. This is cutting off Zhao's right arm. If one cuts off one's right arm and fights with others, loses one's allies and lives alone, how can one expect to avoid danger?"
[324 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 36. In the thirty-sixth year, King Wei died, and his son King Xuan ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 54. After a long time, Qin summoned the King of Yan. The King of Yan wanted to go, but Su Dai advised him, saying, "Chu lost its kingdom after acquiring Zhi, and Qi lost its kingdom after acquiring Song. Why can't Qi and Chu serve Qin because they have Zhi and Song? It's because those who have contributed to Qin are Qin's deepest enemies. Qin's conquest of the world was not based on righteousness, but on tyranny. Qin's tyranny serves as a warning to the world." [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 44. "Now Qin has dispatched three generals: one army blocks the Wu Road, informing Qi to raise an army to cross the Qing River and station troops east of Handan; another army is stationed at Chenggao, driving the Han and Liang armies beyond the river; and the third army is stationed at Mianchi. They have allied with the four states to attack Zhao. If Zhao is defeated, Qin will surely divide its territory into four parts. Therefore, I dare not conceal my intentions and have informed my advisors beforehand. I humbly suggest to Your Majesty that the best course of action is to meet the King of Qin at Mianchi, meet face to face, and agree to a ceasefire. I hope Your Majesty will consider this plan." 45. King Zhao said, “During the reign of the late king, Lord Fengyang held absolute power and deceived the late king, monopolizing affairs. I, as his tutor, did not participate in state affairs. The late king abandoned his ministers, and I, being young, have been busy with ancestral rites. I have always harbored doubts and believe that not serving Qin is not in the long-term interest of the state. Therefore, I wish to change my mind, cede territory to atone for my past mistakes, and serve Qin. I was just about to depart when I heard the messenger's clear edict.” King Zhao agreed to Zhang Yi's request, and Zhang Yi departed.
[323 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 73. In the sixth year, the Chu envoy, Pillar of State Zhao Yang, led troops to attack Wei, defeating it at Xiangling and capturing eight cities. He then moved his troops to attack Qi, causing the King of Qi great distress. Chen Zhen happened to be serving as an envoy of Qin to Qi. The King of Qi asked, "What should we do?" Chen Zhen replied, "Your Majesty, do not worry, I will order them to withdraw." He then went to see Zhao Yang in his army and said, "I wish to hear about the laws of Chu. How is one who defeats an army and kills its general rewarded?" Zhao Yang replied, "Their official position is Grand Pillar of State, and they are granted the highest rank and the title of Holding a Jade Tablet." Chen Zhen asked, "Is there anything more prestigious than this?" Zhao Yang replied, "The Prime Minister." Chen Zhen said, "Now that you are the Prime Minister, this is the highest rank in the country. Let me use an analogy. Someone gave their servants a cup of wine. The servants said to each other, 'Several people will drink from this, it's not enough to share. Let's draw snakes on the ground, and whoever finishes first wins...'" "He drank alone." One man said, "My snake is finished first." He raised his wine cup and stood up, saying, "I can add feet to it." After he had added feet, a man snatched the wine from him and drank it, saying, "Snakes don't have feet. Now you've added feet, so it's no longer a snake." He continued, "Now you, my lord, are serving as prime minister of Chu and attacking Wei, defeating their army and killing their generals. Your achievements are immense, and nothing can be more illustrious than this. Now you move your troops to attack Qi. If you defeat Qi, your rank and title will not be increased; if you fail, you will die and lose your title, and you will be disgraced by Chu. This is the saying about adding feet to a snake. It would be better to withdraw your troops and benevolent towards Qi. This is the way to maintain composure." Zhao Yang said, "Excellent." He then withdrew his troops. 74. The rulers of Yan and Han first proclaimed themselves kings. Qin envoy Zhang Yi met with the rulers of Chu, Qi, and Wei, and they formed an alliance by biting mulberry trees. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 59. Eight years later, Han attacked Qin but was defeated and retreated. The five states offered themselves as kings, but Zhao alone refused, saying, "Without the substance, how dare I claim the title!" He then ordered the people of his state to address him as "Your Majesty." [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 37. In the first year of King Xuan's reign, Qin employed Shang Yang. Zhou then presented Bo to Duke Xiao of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 55. He told Chu: 'The armored soldiers of Shu can travel by boat on the Wen River, then down the Xia River to the Yangtze River, reaching Ying in five days. The armored soldiers of Hanzhong can travel by boat from Ba, then down the Xia River to the Han River, reaching Wuzhu in four days. I have amassed armored soldiers east of Wan and then down to Sui. The wise cannot devise a plan, and the brave cannot retaliate. I am as easily defeated as a falcon. Your Majesty wishes to wait for the world to attack Hangu Pass. Is this not too far-fetched?' For this reason, the King of Chu served Qin for seventeen years. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 46. The ruler of Yan in the north spoke to King Zhao of Yan, saying, "Your Majesty's closest confidant is none other than Zhao. Long ago, Zhao Xiangzi married his sister to the King of Dai, intending to annex Dai. He arranged to meet the King of Dai at the pass of Gouzhu. He then ordered craftsmen to make a golden goblet with a long tail, so it could be used to strike someone. While drinking with the King of Dai, he secretly told the cook, 'When the wine is flowing freely, bring in a hot drink, then turn the goblet around and strike him.' So, when the wine was flowing freely and a hot drink was brought in, the cook brought it and, turning the goblet around, struck the King of Dai, killing him. The king's skull was splattered on the ground. His sister, hearing of this, touched her hairpin and stabbed herself. Therefore, there is still a mountain called Moji Mountain to this day. The death of the King of Dai is known throughout the land." 47. "Your Majesty is well aware of the King of Zhao's tyranny and lack of allegiance. Do you really consider the King of Zhao worthy of your trust? Zhao raised an army to attack Yan, besieged the Yan capital again, and kidnapped Your Majesty. Your Majesty then ceded ten cities to appease him. Now the King of Zhao has already gone to court at Mianchi, offering sacrifices to Qin along the Yellow River. If Your Majesty does not serve Qin, Qin will send troops to Yunzhong and Jiuyuan, drive out Zhao, and attack Yan. Then the Yi River and the Great Wall will no longer belong to Your Majesty."
[322 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 21.3. In the fifth year of King Xuanhui's reign, Zhang Yi became the prime minister of Qin. In the eighth year, Wei defeated my general Han Ju. In the eleventh year, you proclaimed yourself king. You met with Zhao at Qushu. In the fourteenth year, Qin attacked and defeated my Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 38. In the second year, Wei attacked Zhao. Zhao allied with Han and joined forces to attack Wei. Zhao suffered a defeat and fought at Nanliang. King Xuan summoned Tian Ji to restore him to his former position. Han requested aid from Qi. King Xuan summoned his ministers and discussed, "Should we aid them early or late?" Zou Jizi said, "It is better not to aid them." Tian Ji said, "If we do not aid them, Han will be defeated and surrender to Wei. It is better to aid them early." Sun Tzu said, "If we aid Han and Wei before their armies are fully engaged, it means we are taking over Wei's army on behalf of Han, and thus becoming subservient to Han. Moreover, Wei has the ambition to destroy Han. If Han sees its fate, it will surely turn east and plead with Qi. We should strengthen our alliance with Han and delay accepting Wei's defeat, thus gaining both substantial benefits and a prestigious reputation." King Xuan said, "Excellent." He then secretly informed Han's envoy and sent him away. Han, relying on Qi, suffered five defeats and eventually surrendered its kingdom to Qi. Qi, having raised an army, appointed Tian Ji and Tian Ying as generals, with Sun Tzu as commander-in-chief, to rescue Han and Zhao in order to attack Wei. They inflicted a great defeat on Wei at Maling, killing its general Pang Juan and capturing Wei's crown prince Shen. Subsequently, the kings of the three Jin states all paid homage to the King of Qi at Bowang through Tian Ying, forming an alliance before departing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 56. Qin Zheng told Han: 'I started from Shaoqu and cut off the main road in one day. I started from Yiyang and attacked Pingyang, and within two days I had exhausted all the routes. I separated the two Zhou states and attacked Zheng, and within five days the entire state was conquered.' Han agreed and thus followed Qin's example. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 48. "Moreover, at present, Zhao is still a prefecture or county to Qin, and dares not rashly raise an army to attack. If Your Majesty serves Qin, the King of Qin will surely be pleased, and Zhao will not dare to act rashly. Thus, we have the support of the powerful Qin in the west, and no threat from Qi and Zhao in the south. Therefore, I hope Your Majesty will consider this carefully." 49.1. The King of Yan said, "I live in a remote and uncivilized place. Even though I am a grown man, I am as small as an infant, and my words are insufficient to be adopted in righteous plans. Now, Your Excellency has kindly instructed me. I request to face west and serve Qin, offering five cities at the end of Mount Heng." The King of Yan agreed. Yi returned to report, but before he reached Xianyang,
[321 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 69.1. In the forty-eighth year, King Xian died, and his son, King Shenjing, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 57. Qin Zheng warned Wei: 'I will capture Anyi, block the halberds of the women, and subdue the Han clan at Taiyuan. I will take Zhi, pass through Nanyang, encircle Ji, and encompass both Zhou. Riding the Xia River, floating in light boats, with crossbows in front and halberds behind, I will breach the Yingkou Pass, and Wei will have no Daliang; I will breach the Baima Pass, and Wei will have no Waihuang or Jiyang; I will breach the Suxu Pass, and Wei will have no Xu or Dunqiu. If we attack by land, we will strike Henan; if we attack by water, we will destroy Daliang.' Wei agreed and followed Qin's advice. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 49.2. King Hui of Qin died, and King Wu ascended the throne. King Wu had disliked Zhang Yi since he was crown prince, but after he ascended the throne, many ministers slandered Zhang Yi, saying, "He is untrustworthy, and those around him betray the country to gain favor. Qin will surely use him again, and I fear we will become a laughingstock to the world." When the other feudal lords heard that Zhang Yi had the ability to defy King Wu, they all abandoned Heng and rejoined him.
[320 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 18.1. In the nineteenth year of Duke Wen's reign, King Wei of Qi died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 58. Qin wanted to attack Anyi, but fearing that Qi would come to its aid, it entrusted Song to Qi. It said, 'The King of Song is wicked. He made a wooden figure to represent me and shot arrows at its face. My territory is remote and my troops are far away, so I cannot attack. If Your Majesty can defeat Song and take it, I will take it for myself.' After Qin captured Anyi, it blocked the woman's halberd and then used the defeat of Song as a crime against Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 50. In the first year of King Wu of Qin's reign, the ministers harbored deep resentment towards Zhang Yi, and then Qi Rang arrived. Fearing execution, Zhang Yi said to King Wu, "I have a foolish plan, and I wish to offer it." The king asked, "What is it?" Zhang Yi replied, "For the sake of Qin's state, a great upheaval in the east is necessary for Your Majesty to seize more land. I have heard that King Shi of Qi despises me, and wherever I am, he will surely raise an army to attack. Therefore, I offer my humble self to Liang, and Qi will surely raise an army to attack Liang. The armies of Liang and Qi will be locked at the city walls, unable to separate. Your Majesty can then use this opportunity to attack Han, enter the Three Rivers region, and then march out of Hangu Pass without attacking, thus approaching Zhou. The sacrificial vessels will surely be brought out. By holding the emperor hostage and controlling the maps and records, this is the path to royal success." King Wu of Qin agreed and prepared thirty chariots, heading to Zhang Yi's Liang. Qi indeed raised an army to attack. King Ai of Liang was terrified. Zhang Yi said, "Your Majesty, do not worry. Please order the Qi troops to withdraw." He then sent his retainer, Feng Xi, to Chu, and then to Qi, where Feng Xi went to Qi and said to the King of Qi, "Your Majesty despises Zhang Yi; however, it is still quite generous of Your Majesty to entrust Yi to Qin!" The King of Qi said, "I despise Yi. Wherever Yi is, Qin will surely raise an army to attack me. How can I entrust Yi to Qin?" Zhang Yi replied, "This is precisely Your Majesty's entrustment to Yi. When Yi went out, he made a pact with the King of Qin, saying, 'For Your Majesty's sake, if there is a great upheaval in the east, then Your Majesty can cede more land. Now, Your Majesty despises Yi. Wherever Yi is, Qin will surely raise an army to attack me. Therefore, Yi..." "I wish to beg for my unworthy body to go to Liang, and Qi will surely raise an army to attack me. The armies of Qi and Liang will be tied down at the city walls and unable to move apart. Your Majesty can then use this opportunity to attack Han, enter the Three Rivers region, and march out of Hangu Pass without attacking, so as to confront Zhou. The sacrificial vessels will surely be brought out. By holding the Son of Heaven hostage and examining the maps and records, this is the way to achieve kingship." The King of Qin agreed, and thus prepared thirty chariots to enter Liang. Now that Yi has entered Liang, if Your Majesty indeed attacks him, it means Your Majesty is weakening your own country internally while attacking other countries externally, expanding your neighboring enemies to strengthen your own internal power, and thus gaining the trust of the King of Qin with Yi. This is what I mean by 'entrusting Yi'." The King of Qi said, "Good." He then ordered the troops to be withdrawn.
[319 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 21.4. In the fifth year of King Xuanhui's reign, Zhang Yi became the prime minister of Qin. In the eighth year, Wei defeated my general Han Ju. In the eleventh year, you proclaimed yourself king. You met with Zhao at Qushu. In the fourteenth year, Qin attacked and defeated my Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 59. Qin wanted to attack Han, but fearing that the world would come to its aid, it entrusted Qi to the world. It said: 'The King of Qi has made four agreements with me and has deceived me four times. He will surely lead the world to attack me three times. There is no Qi without Qin, and no Qin without Qi. We must attack him and destroy him.' After obtaining Yiyang and Shaoqu, and bringing Lin and Lishi to its aid, it used the destruction of Qi as a crime against the world. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 51. Zhang Yi served as prime minister of Wei for one year before dying in Wei.
[318 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 75.1. In the eleventh year, Su Qin rallied the six states east of the mountains to jointly attack Qin, with King Huai of Chu as the leader. Upon reaching Hangu Pass, Qin dispatched troops to attack the six states, and all the armies of the six states withdrew, except for Qi, which lagged behind. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 60. In the ninth year, together with Han and Wei, we attacked Qin. Qin defeated us, beheading 80,000. Qi defeated us at Guanze. In the tenth year, Qin captured our Zhongdu and Xiyang. Qi defeated Yan. The prime minister of Yan, Zizhi, became the ruler, but the ruler became a subject. In the eleventh year, the king summoned Prince Zhi from Han and established him as the King of Yan, sending Yue Chi to escort him. In the thirteenth year, Qin captured our Lin and took General Zhao Zhuang prisoner. The kings of Chu and Wei came, passing through Handan. In the fourteenth year, Zhao He attacked Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 60. Qin wanted to attack Wei and strengthen Chu, so it entrusted Nanyang to Chu, saying, 'I have already severed ties with Han. If destroying Junling and blocking Menghe benefits Chu, I will keep it for myself.' Wei abandoned its alliance with Qin and then used the blocking of Menghe as a crime against Chu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 52. Chen Zhen was a persuader. He and Zhang Yi both served King Hui of Qin and were highly regarded, vying for his favor. Zhang Yi, displeased with Chen Zhen, said to the King of Qin, "Zhen values gifts over envoys, intending to establish friendly relations between Qin and Chu. Now, Chu is not benevolent towards Qin but benevolent towards Zhen, which means Zhen considers himself generous while neglecting Your Majesty. Moreover, Zhen wishes to leave Qin for Chu; why doesn't Your Majesty grant his request?" The King asked Chen Zhen, "I have heard that you wish to leave Qin for Chu; is that true?" Zhen replied, "Yes." The King said, "Zhen's words are indeed true." Zhen said, "Not only do I know this, but all those who follow the Way know it. In the past, Wu Zixu was loyal to his lord, and the world vied to have him as a minister; Zeng Shen was filial to his parents, and the world wished to have him as a son. Therefore, servants sold without leaving their neighborhoods are good servants; wives given away to marry in the countryside are good wives. Now, Zhen is not loyal to his lord; how can Chu consider Zhen loyal? If loyalty is met with rejection, where else can Zhen go but Chu?" The King agreed with his words and treated him well.
[317 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 75.2. In the twelfth year, King Min of Qi defeated the armies of Zhao and Wei, and Qin also defeated Han, thus vying for supremacy with Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 22. Han Shijia: In the sixteenth year, Qin defeated our Xiuyu and captured the Han generals Geng and Shencha at Zhuoze. The Han state was in dire straits. Gongzhong said to the King of Han, "Our allies are not to be relied upon. Qin has long desired to attack Chu. Your Majesty would be better off using Zhang Yi to make peace with Qin, bribing them with a famous capital and armor, and joining them in their southern campaign against Chu. This is a strategy of exchanging one for two." The King of Han said, "Excellent." He then warned Gongzhong to proceed, intending to go west to negotiate with Qin. The King of Chu, upon hearing this, was greatly alarmed and summoned Chen Zhen to inform him. Chen Zhen said, “Qin has long desired to attack Chu. Now, having obtained the capital of Han and its armored forces, Qin and Han will join forces to attack Chu. This is what Qin has prayed for and sought. Now that they have obtained it, Chu will surely attack. Your Majesty, listen to my advice to alert the entire border, raise an army to rescue Han, order chariots to fill the roads, send out trusted ministers, provide them with many chariots, and offer generous gifts, so that they will believe in Your Majesty's intention to rescue them. Even if Han does not listen to me, Han will surely be grateful to Your Majesty and will not come in droves. This will cause Qin and Han to be at odds, and although the army arrives, Chu will not be greatly harmed. If Han listens to me and breaks off peace with Qin, Qin will be furious and harbor deep resentment towards Han. Han will then be on friendly terms with Chu in the south, and will look down on Qin; looking down on Qin, their response to Qin will be disrespectful. Thus, Chu can avoid disaster through the combined forces of Qin and Han.” The King of Chu said, “Excellent.” He then alerted the entire border, raised an army to rescue Han, ordered chariots to fill the roads, sent out trusted ministers, provided them with many chariots, and offered generous gifts. Gong Zhong said to the King of Han, "Although my country is small, it has already mobilized all its resources. I wish that the great power would pursue its ambitions against Qin, and I will sacrifice Chu for Han." The King of Han was overjoyed upon hearing this and stopped Gong Zhong's mission. Gong Zhong said, "No. Qin is attacking us with real force, while Chu is coming to our aid with empty promises. If Your Majesty relies on Chu's empty reputation and lightly breaks off relations with the powerful enemy Qin, Your Majesty will become a laughingstock. Moreover, Chu and Han are not brotherly states, nor have they made any prior agreement to attack Qin. Since the attack is already taking shape, sending troops under the pretense of rescuing Han must be Chen Zhen's scheme. Furthermore, Your Majesty has already sent someone to inform Qin; if you do not act now, you are deceiving Qin. If you lightly deceive the powerful Qin and trust the strategists of Chu, I fear Your Majesty will regret it." The King of Han did not listen and severed ties with Qin. Qin was furious and increased its forces to attack Han. A great battle ensued, and Chu's aid did not reach Han. In the nineteenth year, Qin decisively defeated Han at Anmen. Crown Prince Cang was sent as a hostage to Qin to make peace. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 61. The army was trapped in the forest, and the states of Yan and Zhao were heavily involved. Jiaodong was entrusted to Yan, and Jixi was entrusted to Zhao. They had already obtained a deal with Wei, and when they reached Prince Yan, they used Xishou's troops to attack Zhao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 53. After residing in Qin for a year, King Hui of Qin finally appointed Zhang Yi as his prime minister, while Chen Zhen fled to Chu. Chu did not value him highly and sent Chen Zhen as an envoy to Qin. Passing through Liang, he wished to see Xi Shou. Xi Shou declined to see him. Chen Zhen said, "I have come on business. If you do not see me, I will depart and cannot wait for another day." Xi Shou then saw him. Chen Zhen said, "Why do you enjoy drinking so much?" Xi Shou replied, "Nothing." Chen Zhen said, "May I ask to help you avoid trouble?" Xi Shou asked, "How?" Xi Shou replied, "Tian Xu has proposed a alliance among the feudal lords, but the King of Chu is suspicious and does not believe it. You have told the King, 'I have connections with the Kings of Yan and Zhao, and they have repeatedly sent messengers saying, "If there is nothing to discuss, why do you not see me?" They wish to visit the King. Although the King has agreed, please do not use many carriages, but only thirty carriages, which can be displayed in the courtyard to clearly explain to Yan and Zhao.' The messengers from Yan and Zhao heard of this, rushed to inform their kings, and sent men to welcome Xi Shou. The King of Chu was furious upon hearing this, saying, "Tian Xu made an agreement with me, yet Xi Shou went to Yan and Zhao; this is deceiving me." He was enraged and refused to listen to the matter. Qi, hearing that Xi Shou was heading north, sent someone to entrust the matter to him. Xi Shou then set off, and all matters concerning the prime ministers of the three states were decided by Xi Shou. Zhen then went to Qin.
[316 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 81. In the second year of Duke Qing's reign, Qin captured Ying, the capital of Chu, and King Qing of Chu moved east to Chen. In the nineteenth year, Chu attacked us and captured Xuzhou. In the twenty-fourth year, King Kaolie of Chu conquered and destroyed Lu. Duke Qing died and was exiled to Xiayi, where he became a family member, and the Lu ancestral rites ceased. Duke Qing died in Ke. 81. In the second year of Duke Qing's reign, Qin captured Ying, the capital of Chu, and King Qing of Chu moved east to Chen. In the nineteenth year, Chu attacked us and captured Xuzhou. In the twenty-fourth year, King Kaolie of Chu conquered and destroyed Lu. Duke Qing died and was exiled to Xiayi, where he became a family member, and the Lu ancestral rites ceased. Duke Qing died in Ke. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 39. In the seventh year, he met with the King of Wei at Ping'an. The following year, he met again at Zhen. King Hui of Wei died. The following year, he met with King Xiang of Wei at Xuzhou, where the feudal lords met as kings. In the tenth year, Chu besieged Xuzhou. In the eleventh year, he joined Wei in attacking Zhao, but Zhao breached the Yellow River to flood Qi and Wei, and the war ended. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 62. When the army was wounded at Qiaoshi and defeated at Yangma, and Wei was heavily relied upon, Ye and Cai were entrusted to Wei. Having already made peace with Zhao, Wei was then coerced, and Wei refused to cede territory. When in dire straits, the Empress Dowager's brother, Marquis Rang, was sent to make peace, and Ying deceived both his maternal uncle and mother. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 54. The states of Han and Wei were at war with each other for a year without resolution. King Hui of Qin wanted to come to their aid and consulted his advisors. Some said it would be better to aid them, while others said it would be better not to. King Hui could not make a decision. When Chen Zhen arrived in Qin, King Hui asked, "When you left me for Chu, did you miss me?" Chen Zhen replied, "Has Your Majesty heard of Zhuang Xi, the man from Yue?" The king said, "No." Chen Zhen said, "Zhuang Xi served as a high-ranking official in Chu, holding the title of 'Jade Official.' After a while, he fell ill. The King of Chu said, 'Xi was originally a lowly man from Yue, but now he serves as a high-ranking official in Chu, holding wealth and honor. Does he miss Yue?' Zhong Xie replied, 'When people miss their old friends, it is because they are ill. If he misses Yue, he will sing the Yue dialect; if he doesn't miss Yue, he will sing the Chu dialect.' A messenger was sent to listen, and he still preferred the Yue dialect. Now, even though I have been banished to Chu, how can I not hear the Qin dialect?' King Hui said, 'Excellent. Now, Han and Wei are attacking each other, and the conflict has lasted for a year. Some say it is better for me to come to their aid, while others say it is better not to. I cannot decide. I hope you can advise me.'" "In your spare time, I would like to offer you a plan for me." Chen Zhen replied, "Has anyone ever heard of Bian Zhuangzi's story of stabbing a tiger? Zhuangzi wanted to stab a tiger, but a servant stopped him, saying, 'Two tigers are about to eat a cow. When they eat something sweet, they will fight. If they fight, the larger one will be injured, and the smaller one will die. If you stab the injured one, you will surely gain fame for killing two tigers in one fell swoop.' Bian Zhuangzi thought this was reasonable and waited. After a while, the two tigers indeed fought, the larger one was injured, and the smaller one died. Zhuangzi stabbed the injured one, and in one fell swoop, he indeed achieved the feat of killing two tigers. Now, Han and Wei are attacking each other, and it will not be resolved for a year. This will surely result in the great state being injured and the small state being destroyed. If you attack the injured one, you will surely gain two benefits in one fell swoop. This is similar to Zhuangzi's story of stabbing a tiger. How is this different from what your subject and king do?" King Hui said, "Excellent." In the end, he did not come to the rescue. The great state was indeed injured, and the small state was destroyed. Qin raised an army and attacked, and won a great victory. This was Chen Zhen's plan.
[315 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 69.2. King Shenjing reigned for six years before dying, and his son, King Nan, succeeded him. During King Nan's reign, the Eastern and Western Zhou were divided. King Nan moved the capital to the Western Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 63. Those who go to Yan say 'to Jiaodong,' those who go to Zhao say 'to Jixi,' those who go to Wei say 'to Ye and Cai,' those who go to Chu say 'to block Menghe,' and those who go to Qi say 'to Song.' This will surely make their words flow like a cycle, their military tactics as swift as slaying a hawk, and neither their mother nor their uncle can control them. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 55. Xi Shou was a man from Yin Jin in Wei, named Yan, surnamed Gongsun. He was not on good terms with Zhang Yi.
[314 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 64. In the battles of Longjia, Anmen, Fengling, Gaoshang, and Zhaozhuang, Qin killed millions of people from the three Jin states. Those who survive are now the orphans of Qin's dead. Beyond the Yellow River, in the land of Shangluo, the three rivers of Jin suffered calamity, half of the three Jin states were wiped out. Qin's calamity was so great. And those from Yan and Zhao who served Qin all used their power to serve Qin and please their lords. This is what I find most worrying. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 56. Zhang Yi served as the prime minister of Wei under the Qin dynasty. Xi Shou, however, was not pleased with this arrangement. Therefore, he sent someone to tell Han Gongshu, "Zhang Yi has already allied with Qin and Wei. He has said, 'Wei will attack Nanyang, and Qin will attack Sanchuan.' The reason the King of Wei values Zhang Yi is to gain control of Han. Furthermore, Han has already conquered Nanyang. Why don't you entrust it to Xi Shou as a further contribution? Then the alliance between Qin and Wei can be solidified. Wei will then surely plot against Qin and abandon Zhang Yi, while taking Han and continuing the alliance." Gongshu thought this was a good idea and entrusted Zhang Yi to Xi Shou as a reward. Zhang Yi indeed became the prime minister of Wei. Zhang Yi then left.
[313 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 76. In the sixteenth year, Qin wanted to attack Qi, but Chu allied with Qi. King Hui of Qin was troubled by this, so he announced that Zhang Yi should be dismissed as prime minister and sent Zhang Yi south to see the King of Chu. Zhang Yi said to the King of Chu, "No one in my kingdom's kingdom appreciates Your Majesty more than you, and even I, who would most like to serve as a gatekeeper, would not do so before Your Majesty. No one in my kingdom's kingdom hates the King of Qi more than you, and even I, who would most like to serve as a gatekeeper, would not do so before you. But Your Majesty has allied with you, so my kingdom's kingdom cannot serve you, and I, too, cannot serve as a gatekeeper. Your Majesty has closed the borders to Qi for my sake. Now, I have sent an envoy to the west with Zhang Yi to take the six hundred li of land in Shangyu that Qin had divided between Chu and Qi. In this way, Qi will be weakened. This way, Qi will be weakened in the north, Qin will be benevolent in the west, and Shangyu will be privately owned and enriched. This plan achieves three benefits in one go." King Huai of Qin was overjoyed and appointed Zhang Yi as prime minister, holding daily banquets with him and declaring, "I have regained my land in Shangyu." All the ministers congratulated him, but Chen Zhen alone mourned. King Huai asked, "Why?" Chen Zhen replied, "The reason Qin values Your Majesty so much is because Your Majesty possesses Qi. Now, the land is not yet obtained, and the alliance with Qi has already been severed, leaving Chu isolated. Why would Qin value an isolated state? They will surely despise Chu. Moreover, if we first offer the land and then sever ties with Qi, Qin will not follow our plan. If we sever ties with Qi first and then demand the land, we will surely be deceived by Zhang Yi. If Your Majesty is deceived by Zhang Yi, Your Majesty will surely resent him. If you resent him, then Qin will cause trouble in the west, and the alliance with Qi will be severed in the north. If Qin causes trouble in the west and the alliance with Qi is severed in the north, then the armies of both countries will surely arrive. Therefore, I offer my condolences." King Huai did not listen and instead sent a general to the west to receive the fiefdom. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 61. In the sixteenth year, King Hui of Qin died. The king toured the Daling Mausoleum. One day, the king dreamt of a maiden playing the zither and singing a poem: "Beautiful maiden, radiant and graceful, her face like the blossoming of a sweet potato. Alas, fate! There was no one like me, Ying!" Another day, the king was drinking and merry, repeatedly mentioning his dream, hoping to see her face again. Wu Guang heard of this and, through his wife, took his daughter, Wa Ying, as his concubine. This was Meng Yao. Meng Yao was greatly favored by the king and became Queen Hui. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 40. In the eighteenth year, King Xuan favored scholars and persuaders. Seventy-six men, including Zou Yan, Chunyu Kun, Tian Pian, Jie Zi, Shen Dao, and Huan Yuan, were all granted official ranks and appointed as senior officials, not for official duties but for intellectual pursuits. As a result, the Jixia Academy in Qi flourished again, with hundreds or even thousands of scholars. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 57. The King of Yiqu paid homage to Wei. Xi Shou, hearing that Zhang Yi had returned to Qin as prime minister, was furious. Xi Shou then said to the King of Yiqu, "The journey is too long to cross again; please allow me to discuss matters." He replied, "If China is at peace, Qin can burn down your country; if it is at war, Qin will send envoys and offer heavy gifts to your country." Later, five states attacked Qin. At this time, Chen Zhen said to the King of Qin, "The King of Yiqu is a wise ruler among the barbarians; it would be better to bribe him to appease his ambitions." The King of Qin said, "Excellent." He then sent a thousand bolts of embroidered silk and a hundred women to the King of Yiqu. The King of Yiqu summoned his ministers and plotted, saying, "Is this what Gongsun Yan meant by this?" He then raised an army to attack Qin and utterly defeated the Qin general Li Bo.
[312 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.1 (King Huiwen yr 25; “renamed the first year” note). Fourteen years later, it was renamed the first year. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 77. Zhang Yi arrived in Qin, feigning drunkenness and falling from his carriage. He claimed illness and, within three months, could not obtain the land. The King of Chu said, "Does Zhang Yi think I'm being disrespectful by severing ties with Qi?" He then sent the brave warrior Song Yi to the north to humiliate the King of Qi. The King of Qi was furious, broke the Chu tally, and allied with Qin. With Qin and Qi united, Zhang Yi rose to court and said to the Chu general, "Why don't you accept the land? From so-and-so to so-and-so, it's six li in length." The Chu general replied, "I was given six hundred li, not six li." He immediately returned to report to King Huai. King Huai was enraged and raised an army to attack Qin. Chen Zhen then said, "Attacking Qin is not the right plan. It would be better to use a bribe of a famous city to attack Qi. This way, we would repay Qin for our loss, and our country could still be spared. Now, Your Majesty has severed ties with Qi and is now deceiving Qin. This means I have united Qin and Qi to bring the armies of the world upon us, and our country will surely suffer greatly." The King of Chu did not listen, broke off peace with Qin, and sent troops west to attack Qin. Qin also sent troops to attack him. 78. In the spring of the seventeenth year, we fought Qin at Danyang. Qin decisively defeated our army, beheading 80,000 soldiers and capturing over 70 men, including our Grand General Qu Gai and Deputy General Feng Hou Chou. They then seized the Hanzhong prefecture. King Huai of Chu was furious and mobilized all his troops to attack Qin again. We fought at Lantian and suffered a major defeat for the Chu army. Hearing of Chu's predicament, Han and Wei attacked Chu from the south, reaching as far as Deng. Upon hearing this, Chu withdrew its troops. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 62. In the seventeenth year, the king went out of the nine gates and built a platform in the wilderness to look out over the borders of Qi and Zhongshan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 23. Han Shijia: In the twenty-first year, he joined forces with Qin to attack Chu, defeating the Chu general Qu Gai and beheading 80,000 at Danyang. In the same year, King Xuanhui died, and Crown Prince Cang ascended the throne as King Xiang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 65. King Zhao of Yan failed. Su Dai regained his favor in Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 58. After Zhang Yi's death, Xi Shou became the prime minister of Qin. He once wore the seals of prime minister of five states and served as the chief of the alliance.
[311 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.2 (yr 26). In the second year, Zhang Yi met with ministers from Qi and Chu at Niesang. 63 (King Hui dies; succession). King Hui died, and his son King Wu ascended the throne. Han, Wei, Qi, Chu, and Yue all became his subjects. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 79. In the eighteenth year, Qin sent an envoy to negotiate a renewed alliance with Chu, offering half of Hanzhong in exchange for peace. The King of Chu said, "I wish to gain Zhang Yi, not land." Upon hearing this, Zhang Yi requested to go to Chu. The King of Qin said, "Chu is willing to submit to you, what should we do?" Zhang Yi replied, "I have a good relationship with my advisor Jin Shang, who is also well-connected with Zheng Xiu, the King of Chu's favorite concubine. She always listens to my advice. Furthermore, I previously served as an envoy to Chu to negotiate the alliance. Now, with Qin and Chu locked in a great war, there is bad blood, and I cannot absolve Chu without personally apologizing. Moreover, with Your Majesty present, Chu should not dare to take me. If you truly wish to kill me for the sake of the state, that is my desire." Zhang Yi then went to Chu. 80. When Zhang Yi arrived, King Huai refused to see him and imprisoned him, intending to kill him. Zhang Yi secretly consulted with Jin Shang, who pleaded with King Huai, saying, "By detaining Zhang Yi, the King of Qin will surely be angry. The world will see that Chu has no Qin, and will look down on Your Majesty." Jin Shang also said to Lady Zheng Xiu, "The King of Qin greatly favors Zhang Yi, yet Your Majesty wants to kill him. We are now going to bribe Chu with six counties of Shangyong, send a beautiful woman to the King of Chu, and make a skilled singer from the palace his concubine. The King of Chu values this land, and the Qin woman will surely be highly regarded, and Your Majesty will surely reject her. Your Majesty, you should speak to the King and have him released." Zheng Xiu ultimately spoke to the King, and Zhang Yi was released. After Zhang Yi's release, King Huai treated him well. Zhang Yi then persuaded the King of Chu to break with the treaty and form a marriage alliance with Qin. After Zhang Yi left, Qu Yuan came from Qi and advised the King, "Why not execute Zhang Yi?" King Huai regretted his decision and sent men to pursue Zhang Yi, but they could not catch him. That same year, King Hui of Qin died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 63. In the eighteenth year, King Wu of Qin and Meng Shuo lifted the Red Tripod with Dragon Pattern, and King Wu died from a broken kneecap. King Zhao sent Zhao Gu, the prime minister of Dai, to welcome Prince Ji from Yan, send him back, and establish him as King of Qin, who became King Zhao.
[310 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.3 (yr 27). In the third year, the crown princes of Han and Wei came to court. Zhang Yi became prime minister of Wei. 64.1 (King Wu yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of King Wu's reign, he met with King Hui of Wei at Linjin. He executed Zhuang, the prime minister of Shu. Zhang Yi and Wei Zhang both marched east to Wei. He attacked Yiqu, Dan, and Li. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 19. In the twenty-ninth year, Duke Wen died, and the crown prince ascended the throne, becoming King Yi. 20.1. When King Yi first ascended the throne, King Xuan of Qi attacked Yan because of the loss of Yan, taking ten cities. Su Qin persuaded Qi to return the ten cities to Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 64. In the first month of spring in the nineteenth year, the Great Court convened at Xin Palace. Fei Yi was summoned to discuss the affairs of the realm, a discussion that lasted five days. The king then campaigned northwards through the Zhongshan region, reaching Fangzi, then Dai, extending north to Wuxian, west to the Yellow River, and ascending Huanghua Mountain. He summoned Lou Huan and said, “My late king, adapting to the changing times, expanded the southern borders, relying on the natural defenses of the Zhang and Fu rivers, establishing the Great Wall, and conquering Lin and Guo Lang, defeating the Lin people at Ren, yet his achievements were incomplete. Now, Zhongshan lies in our heartland, bordered by Yan to the north, Hu to the east, and the Lin Hu, Loufan, Qin, and Han to the west, without strong military support. This threatens the survival of the state. What can we do? A great reputation inevitably carries the burden of outdated customs. I wish to adopt the Hu clothing.” Lou Huan said, “Good.” The ministers all disagreed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 66. When the Yan envoy tried to persuade the feudal lords to form alliances like Su Qin, some agreed and some didn't, but the world thus revered Su Qin's alliances. Both Dai and Li died of old age, but their names became famous among the feudal lords.
[309 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 64.2 (yr 2; dual prime ministers). In the second year, he first established the position of prime minister, appointing Bili Ji and Gan Mao as left and right prime ministers. Zhang Yi died in Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 81. In the twentieth year [6], King Min of Qi, desiring to be the leader of the alliance, disliked the alliance between Chu and Qin. He sent a messenger to the King of Chu, saying: "I am concerned that Chu is not discerning of your esteemed position. Now, King Hui of Qin is dead, King Wu has ascended the throne, Zhang Yi has fled to Wei, and Chuli Ji and Gongsun Yan are employed, and Chu serves Qin. Chuli Ji is on good terms with Han, and Gongsun Yan is on good terms with Wei; Chu will surely serve Qin, and Han and Wei, fearing this, will inevitably seek an alliance with Qin through these two. Then Yan and Zhao should also serve Qin. If the four states contend for Qin's favor, Chu will become a mere prefecture. Why doesn't Your Majesty ally with me?" "If you forcefully subdue Han, Wei, Yan, and Zhao, and unite them to uphold the Zhou dynasty, then you can settle your military affairs, allow the people to rest, and command the world. No one will dare disobey, and your name will be established. If you lead the other feudal lords to attack Qin, you will surely defeat it. If you seize the lands of Wuguan, Shu, and Han, privatize the wealth of Wu and Yue, and monopolize the benefits of the rivers and seas, and if Han and Wei cede Shangdang, and you advance westward to Hangu Pass, then Chu will be a million strong. Moreover, you have deceived Zhang Yi, lost the territory of Hanzhong, and suffered heavy losses at Lantian. The whole world is filled with anger towards you. Now you wish to serve Qin first! I urge Your Majesty to consider this carefully." 82. The King of Chu had already intended to make peace with Qin, but upon seeing the letter from the King of Qi, he hesitated and consulted his ministers. Some ministers advocated peace with Qin, while others said to listen to Qi. Zhao Ju said, "Even if Your Majesty were to take land from Yue in the east, it would not be enough to wash away the shame; you must take land from Qin to truly wash away the shame before the other states. Your Majesty would be better off strengthening your alliance with Qi and Han to gain the support of Chuli Ji. In this way, Your Majesty can use the influence of Han and Qi to acquire land. Qin destroyed Yiyang in Han, yet Han still served Qin because the tomb of its former king was in Pingyang, and Qin's Wusui was only seventy li away, hence Han still feared Qin. Otherwise, if Qin attacked Sanchuan, Zhao attacked Shangdang, and Chu attacked the area beyond the Yellow River, Han would surely perish. Chu's rescue of Han could not prevent its destruction, but..." "The one who will preserve Han is Chu. Han has already obtained Wusui from Qin, using the rivers and mountains as a barrier. No one has repaid its kindness more generously than Chu. I believe that Han will surely be eager to serve Your Majesty. The reason Qi trusts Han is because Prince Mo of Han is the prime minister of Qi. Han has already obtained Wusui from Qin, and Your Majesty greatly favors him, sending him to rely on the combined power of Qi and Han for Chuli Ji. With the combined power of Qi and Han, his lord will not dare to abandon him. Now, if Chu is added to his power, Chuli Ji will surely speak to Qin and reclaim the territory that Chu has seized." Therefore, King Huai agreed, and ultimately did not ally with Qin, but instead allied with Qi to be on good terms with Han. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 65. Then Fei Yi attended to the king, who said, “The achievements of Jian and Xiangzhu are remarkable, and the benefits to the Hu and Di tribes are considerable. A minister should uphold the virtues of filial piety, brotherly love, respect for elders and juniors, and the duty of benefiting the people and the ruler; these are the two aspects of a minister's role. Now I wish to follow in the footsteps of Xiangzhu, establishing a presence in the lands of the Hu and Di, but I will never see this again. By weakening the enemy, I can achieve more with less effort, thus avoiding the burden on the people and continuing the legacy of past merits. Those who achieve great feats bear the burden of outdated customs; those with unique wisdom invite the resentment of the people. Now I intend to teach the people Hu clothing, riding, and archery, but the world will surely criticize me. What should I do?” Fei Yi replied, “I have heard that doubt leads to failure.” "I doubt that I will adopt the Hu clothing. Since the king has already decided to abandon the concerns of outdated customs, he is unlikely to care about the opinions of the world. Those who discuss the highest virtue do not conform to popular opinion, and those who achieve great feats do not consult the masses. In the past, Shun danced among the Miao people, and Yu stripped naked before the state; this was not to indulge desires or seek pleasure, but to discuss virtue and establish merit. The foolish achieve their goals in secret, while the wise see what is yet to come. So why should the king have any doubts?" The king said, "I do not doubt the adoption of Hu clothing, but I fear the world will laugh at me. The joy of the madman is lamented by the wise; what the foolish laugh at is understood by the virtuous. If there are those in the world who will follow me, the success of the Hu clothing is yet to be seen. Even if the world laughs at me, I will surely possess the lands of the Hu and Zhongshan." Therefore, he adopted the Hu clothing.
[308 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.4 (yr 29). In the fifth year, the king toured to the North River. 64.3 (yr 3; Yiyang campaign begins). In the third year, he met with King Xiang of Han outside Linjin. Nan Gong Jie died, and Bili Ji became prime minister of Han. King Wu said to Gan Mao, "I wish to allow carriages to cross the three rivers and spy on the Zhou court; I will die without regret." That autumn, he sent Gan Mao and Shuzhang Feng to attack Yiyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 66. The king sent Prince Cheng to say, “I have adopted the Hu clothing to attend court, and I also wish that you, my uncle, would wear it. Families obey their relatives, and states obey their rulers; this has been the common practice throughout history. A son should not betray his parents, and a subject should not disobey his ruler; this is the universal principle between brothers. Now, I have established a system for changing clothing, but you, my uncle, do not comply. I fear the world will criticize this. There are constant principles in governing a state, with the benefit of the people as the foundation; there are rules in governance, with the implementation of orders as paramount. Virtue is first discussed among the lowly, and administrative authority is first established in the trust of the noble. The intention behind adopting the Hu clothing is not to indulge desires or seek personal pleasure; but rather to ensure that actions have limits and achievements have results. Only when things are accomplished and established is it considered good. I fear that you, my uncle, are going against the principles of governance, and I wish to assist you in your decision. Furthermore, I have heard that those who act for the benefit of the state are without evil, and those who rely on noble relatives are not burdened by fame. Therefore, I wish to emulate you, my uncle.” "The purpose is to accomplish the task of adopting the Hu clothing. I sent a messenger to visit my uncle and request to wear it." Prince Cheng bowed twice and said, "I have indeed heard of Your Majesty's adoption of Hu clothing. I am unworthy, but I am ill and unable to attend to your needs. Since Your Majesty commands me, I dare to answer and offer my utmost loyalty. I have heard that China is the abode of wisdom and intelligence, the gathering place of all things and resources, the place where sages teach, where benevolence and righteousness are practiced, where poetry, books, rites, and music are used, where extraordinary skills are tested, where distant lands are observed and visited, and where barbarians practice righteousness. Now Your Majesty abandons this and adopts the clothing of distant lands, changes ancient teachings, alters ancient ways, goes against the hearts of the people, angers scholars, and alienates China. Therefore, I urge Your Majesty to consider this matter." The messenger reported this. The king said, "I have indeed heard of my uncle's illness; I will go myself to request his adoption." [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 24.1. In the fourth year of King Xiang's reign, he met with King Wu of Qin at Linjin. That autumn, Qin sent Gan Mao to attack Yiyang. In the fifth year, Qin captured Yiyang, beheading 60,000. King Wu of Qin died. In the sixth year, Qin returned to Wusui. In the ninth year, Qin again captured Wusui. In the tenth year, Crown Prince Ying went to Qin and returned home. In the eleventh year, Qin attacked him and captured Rang. Together with Qin, they attacked Chu and defeated the Chu general Tang Mei.
[307 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 64.4 (yr 4; Yiyang taken; King Wu dies). In the fourth year, he captured Yiyang, beheading 60,000. He crossed the river and fortified Wusui. The crown prince of Wei came to pay homage. King Wu was strong and fond of games; strongmen Ren Bi, Wu Huo, and Meng Shuo all rose to high positions. The king and Meng Shuo lifted a tripod, and the king's leg broke. In August, King Wu died. Meng Shuo was exterminated. King Wu took a woman from Wei as his queen, but had no children. He installed his half-brother as king, who became King Zhaoxiang. King Zhaoxiang's mother was from Chu, surnamed Mi, and was known as Empress Dowager Xuan. When King Wu died, King Zhaoxiang was a hostage in Yan. The people of Yan sent him back, and he was able to ascend the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 67. Wang then went to the home of Prince Cheng and requested permission to serve him, saying, "Clothing is for practical use; rites are for practical matters. The sage observes the local customs and adapts them accordingly, establishing rites based on circumstances, thus benefiting his people and enriching his state. Those who cut their hair and tattoo their bodies, wear crossed arms and left-fastening robes, are the people of the Yue and Ou tribes. Those with black teeth and carved foreheads, wearing hats with sorghum tassels, are the people of the Great Wu kingdom. Therefore, their ceremonial robes are not uniform, yet their convenience is the same. Different regions require different practices, and different matters require different rites. Thus, the sage, if it can truly benefit his state, does not use a single method; if it can truly benefit his people..." Things differ according to custom. Even with one teacher, Confucian scholars may find customs different; while China shares the same rites, its teachings may diverge. How much more so in the remote mountains and valleys? Therefore, the wise cannot agree on who to follow or who to abandon; the virtuous cannot agree on what to wear near or far. Remote villages are often different, and distorted learning often leads to debate. To not doubt what one does not know, and not condemn what differs from one's own, is to be open-minded and strive for the best for all. What you, Uncle, speak of are customs; what I speak of is how to regulate customs. In the east of our country are the Yellow River and the Bo River, the same as those of Qi and Zhongshan, where there is no use for boats. From Changshan to Dai and Shangdang... To the east lie the borders of Yan and Donghu, and to the west, the borders of Loufan, Qin, and Han. We currently lack cavalry and archery preparations. Therefore, I have no boats or oars. How will the people living along the river defend the Yellow River and the Luo River? We must change our clothing and cavalry to defend against the borders of Yan, the Three Hu, Qin, and Han. Furthermore, in the past, Lord Jian failed to block Jinyang and Shangdang, while Lord Xiang united the Rong and replaced the Hu to repel them. This is clear to both the wise and the foolish. Previously, Zhongshan, relying on the strong army of Qi, invaded our land, imprisoned our people, and diverted water to besiege Hao. If not for the spirits of the state, Hao would have been... "It is almost impossible to defend it. The late king despised it, and the grievance could not be avenged. Now, with the preparation of cavalry and archery, we can take advantage of the terrain of Shangdang in the near term, and avenge the grievance of Zhongshan in the far term. But you, Shu, follow the customs of the Central Plains and go against the wishes of Jian and Xiang, and dislike the name of changing clothes to forget the shame of the Hao incident. This is not what I, the king, wish for." Gongzi Cheng bowed twice and kowtowed, saying, "Your subject is foolish and does not understand the king's righteousness. I dare to speak of what is commonly known, and this is my fault. Now that Your Majesty intends to follow the wishes of Jian and Xiang and comply with the will of the late king, how dare I disobey your command!" He bowed twice and kowtowed. Then he was granted Hu clothing. The next day, he wore it to court. Thus, the decree on Hu clothing was issued. 68. Zhao Wen, Zhao Zao, Zhou Yi, and Zhao Jun all advised the king against wearing foreign clothing, insisting on adhering to the existing customs. The king replied, "The former kings did not follow the same customs, so what ancient laws are there? Emperors did not imitate each other, so what rituals are there to follow? Fu Xi and Shennong taught without being punished; Huangdi, Yao, and Shun punished without anger. By the time of the Three Kings, laws were established according to the times, and rituals were created according to circumstances. Laws and regulations each followed their proper use, and clothing and tools each suited their purpose. Therefore, rituals need not be uniform, and the convenience of the state does not necessarily require antiquity. The rise of sages did not follow one another, and the decline of the Xia and Shang dynasties did not change their rituals. Therefore, reversing antiquity is not necessarily wrong, but adhering to rituals is not necessarily commendable. Moreover, those who wear strange clothing have licentious intentions." If Zou and Lu had no extraordinary conduct, and the people of Wu and Yue had no outstanding scholars, then Zou and Lu would have no remarkable people. Furthermore, the sages consider clothing beneficial to themselves and rituals convenient. The rules of advancement and retreat, and the regulations of clothing, are for regulating the common people, not for judging the virtuous. Therefore, regulating the common people follows the customs, while the virtuous adapt to change.
