Hence the proverb says, "He who uses books to drive horses cannot fully understand their nature; he who uses the past to govern the present cannot grasp the changes in circumstances." The merit of following the law is insufficient to elevate the world; the learning of the ancients is insufficient to govern the present. You are not up to this." Therefore, he adopted the Hu clothing and recruited riders and archers. 69. In the twentieth year, the king conquered the Zhongshan region, reaching Ningjia; he then conquered the Hu region to the west, reaching Yuzhong. The King of Linhu presented horses. Upon returning, he sent Lou Huan to Qin, Qiu Ye to Han, Wang Ben to Chu, Fu Ding to Wei, and Zhao Jue to Qi. Zhao Gu, the prime minister of Dai, who was in charge of the Hu, summoned their troops. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 24.2. In the fourth year of King Xiang's reign, he met with King Wu of Qin at Linjin. That autumn, Qin sent Gan Mao to attack Yiyang. In the fifth year, Qin captured Yiyang, beheading 60,000. King Wu of Qin died. In the sixth year, Qin returned to Wusui. In the ninth year, Qin again captured Wusui. In the tenth year, Crown Prince Ying went to Qin and returned home. In the eleventh year, Qin attacked him and captured Rang. Together with Qin, they attacked Chu and defeated the Chu general Tang Mei.
[306 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.5 (yr 31). In the seventh year, Yue Chi became prime minister of Qin. Han, Zhao, Wei, Yan, and Qi, along with the Xiongnu, jointly attacked Qin. Qin sent General Ji to fight at Xiuyu, capturing their general Shenchai, defeating Prince Ke of Zhao and Crown Prince Huan of Han, and beheading 82,000. 65.1 (King Zhaoxiang yr 1) (Wikipedia). In the first year of King Zhaoxiang's reign, Yan Junji became prime minister. Gan Mao was exiled to Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 70. In the twenty-first year, the king attacked Zhongshan. Zhao Yi commanded the right wing, Xu Jun the left wing, and Gongzi Zhang the central wing, all under the king's command. Niu Jian commanded the chariots and cavalry, and Zhao Xi commanded the Hu and Dai armies. Zhao Yi and his army joined forces at Quyang, capturing Danqiu, Huayang, and Chizhi Pass. The king's army captured Hao, Shiyi, Fenglong, and Dongyuan. Zhongshan offered four cities in peace, which the king granted, and the war ended. In the twenty-third year, the king attacked Zhongshan again. In the twenty-fifth year, Queen Hui died. The king sent Zhou Yi, dressed in Hu clothing, to tutor Prince He. In the twenty-sixth year, the king attacked Zhongshan again, expanding its territory north to Yan and Dai, and west to Yunzhong and Jiuyuan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 24.3. In the fourth year of King Xiang's reign, he met with King Wu of Qin at Linjin. That autumn, Qin sent Gan Mao to attack Yiyang. In the fifth year, Qin captured Yiyang, beheading 60,000. King Wu of Qin died. In the sixth year, Qin returned to Wusui. In the ninth year, Qin again captured Wusui. In the tenth year, Crown Prince Ying went to Qin and returned home. In the eleventh year, Qin attacked him and captured Rang. Together with Qin, they attacked Chu and defeated the Chu general Tang Mei.
[305 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 70. When the crown prince of Duke Wu of Western Zhou died, he had five sons of concubines, and no suitable successor was chosen. Sima Jian said to the King of Chu, "It would be better to provide land to Prince Jiu and request a crown prince on his behalf." Zuo Cheng said, "No. If Zhou does not listen, it means that you, Duke Wu, know your predicament and have a strained relationship with Zhou. It would be better to ask the ruler of Zhou which one he wishes to establish as crown prince, and then subtly inform Jian. Jian will then request that Chu (He) [provide land] to that one." Indeed, Prince Jiu was established as crown prince. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.6 (yr 32). In the eighth year, Zhang Yi returned to prime minister of Qin. 65.2 (yr 2; comet; executions). In the second year, a comet appeared. The eldest son of the commoner, Zhuang, along with ministers, feudal lords, and princes, rebelled and were all executed. Empress Huiwen and others also met untimely deaths. Empress Daowu returned to Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 83.1. In the twenty-fourth year, Qi broke away from Chu and allied with Qin. King Zhaoxiang of Qin, newly enthroned, offered generous bribes to Chu. Chu sent a bride to Chu.
[304 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.7 (yr 33; Shu conquered). In the ninth year, Sima Cuo attacked and destroyed Shu. They conquered Zhongdu and Xiyang of Zhao. 65.3 (yr 3; crowned; meets Chu king). In the third year, the king was crowned. He met with the King of Chu at Huangji and with Chu at Shangyong. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 83.2. In the twenty-fifth year, King Huai of Chu entered into an alliance with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Huangji. Qin then re-established its alliance with Chu at Shangyong.
[303 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.8 (yr 34). In the tenth year, Crown Prince Cang of Han came as a hostage. They conquered Shizhang of Han. They defeated the Zhao general Ni. They conquered twenty-five cities of Yiqu. 65.4 (yr 4; Puban; comet). In the fourth year, Puban was captured. A comet appeared. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 83.3. In the twenty-sixth year, Qi, Han, and Wei, betraying Chu's allies, allied with Qin, and the three states jointly attacked Chu. Chu sent its crown prince as a hostage to Qin to plead for help. Qin then dispatched its guest minister Tong with troops to rescue Chu, and the three states withdrew their armies. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 24.4. In the fourth year of King Xiang's reign, he met with King Wu of Qin at Linjin. That autumn, Qin sent Gan Mao to attack Yiyang. In the fifth year, Qin captured Yiyang, beheading 60,000. King Wu of Qin died. In the sixth year, Qin returned to Wusui. In the ninth year, Qin again captured Wusui. In the tenth year, Crown Prince Ying went to Qin and returned home. In the eleventh year, Qin attacked him and captured Rang. Together with Qin, they attacked Chu and defeated the Chu general Tang Mei.
[302 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.9 (yr 35). In the eleventh year, Zeli Ji attacked Jiao of Wei and brought it to surrender. They defeated Anmen of Han, beheading 10,000, and their general Xishou fled. Prince Tong was enfeoffed in Shu. The ruler of Yan yielded to his minister Zizhi. 65.5 (yr 5; Wei homage). In the fifth year, the King of Wei came to pay homage at Yingting and again with Wei at Puban. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 84.1. In the twenty-seventh year, a Qin official had a private feud with the Crown Prince of Chu, who killed him and fled back home. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 24.5. In the fourth year of King Xiang's reign, he met with King Wu of Qin at Linjin. That autumn, Qin sent Gan Mao to attack Yiyang. In the fifth year, Qin captured Yiyang, beheading 60,000. King Wu of Qin died. In the sixth year, Qin returned to Wusui. In the ninth year, Qin again captured Wusui. In the tenth year, Crown Prince Ying went to Qin and returned home. In the eleventh year, Qin attacked him and captured Rang. Together with Qin, they attacked Chu and defeated the Chu general Tang Mei.
[301 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.10 (yr 36; Linjin meeting). In the twelfth year, the king met with the King of Liang at Linjin. General Ji attacked Zhao and captured the Zhao general Zhuang. Zhang Yi became the prime minister of Chu. 65.6 (yr 6; Shu rebellion). In the sixth year, Marquis Hui of Shu rebelled, and Sima Cuo pacified Shu. The eldest son of the commoner, Huan, attacked Chu, beheading 20,000. Lord Jingyang was held hostage in Qi. There was a solar eclipse, and the daytime was dark. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 84.2. In the twenty-eighth year, Qin, together with Qi, Han, and Wei, attacked Chu, killing the Chu general Tang Mei and capturing Chongqiu before departing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 24.6. In the fourth year of King Xiang's reign, he met with King Wu of Qin at Linjin. That autumn, Qin sent Gan Mao to attack Yiyang. In the fifth year, Qin captured Yiyang, beheading 60,000. King Wu of Qin died. In the sixth year, Qin returned to Wusui. In the ninth year, Qin again captured Wusui. In the tenth year, Crown Prince Ying went to Qin and returned home. In the eleventh year, Qin attacked him and captured Rang. Together with Qin, they attacked Chu and defeated the Chu general Tang Mei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 41. Nineteen years later, King Xuan died, and his son King Min ascended the throne.
[300 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.11 (yr 37; Danyang; Hanzhong). In the thirteenth year, the chief minister Zhang attacked Chu at Danyang, capturing its general Qu Gai and beheading 80,000. He also attacked Chu's Hanzhong, taking 600 li of land and establishing the Hanzhong Commandery. Chu besieged Yongshi, and Qin sent the chief minister Ji to assist Han in attacking Qi in the east, and then to assist Wei in attacking Yan. 65.7 (yr 7; Xincheng; deaths). In the seventh year, Xincheng was captured. Zili Zi died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 20.2. Ten years later, the ruler of Yan became king. Su Qin had an affair with the wife of Duke Wen of Yan and feared execution, so he persuaded the king to send Qi to act as a spy, intending to cause chaos in Qi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 84.3. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin attacked Chu again, inflicting a major defeat on Chu, killing 20,000 Chu soldiers and killing our general Jing Que. King Huai was terrified and sent his crown prince as a hostage to Qi to seek peace. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 25. Han Shijia: In the twelfth year, Crown Prince Ying died. Prince Jiu and Prince Ji Shi vied for the position of Crown Prince. At that time, Ji Shi was a hostage in Chu. Su Dai said to Han Jiu, "Ji Shi has fled to Chu, and the King of Chu is eager to bring him in. Now, Chu has over 100,000 troops outside Fangcheng. Why don't you order the King of Chu to build a capital of ten thousand households near Yongshi? Han will surely raise troops to rescue him, and you will surely lead them. You can then use the troops of Han and Chu to support Ji Shi and bring him in. He will definitely listen to you and will surely enfeoff you with a title from both Chu and Han." Han Jiu followed his plan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 42. In the first year of King Min's reign, Qin envoy Zhang Yi met with the ruling officials of the various states at Niesang. In the third year, Tian Ying was enfeoffed in Xue. In the fourth year, a bride was sent to Qin. In the seventh year, Qin allied with Song to attack Wei, defeating them at Guanze. [Sima Qian, Shiji 69 — Su Qin Lie Zhuan] 67 (authorial). Sima Qian wrote: Su Qin and his two brothers all traveled among the feudal lords to gain fame, their skills excelling in persuasion and strategy. However, Su Qin was imprisoned and died, and the world laughed at him, refusing to study his methods. Yet, many different accounts of Su Qin exist, and events from different times that resemble his are attributed to him. Su Qin rose from humble beginnings to unite six states into a powerful alliance; this demonstrates his extraordinary wisdom. Therefore, I have listed his actions and arranged them chronologically, so that he may not be the only one to suffer such ill repute. [Sima Qian, Shiji 70 — Zhang Yi Lie Zhuan] 59 (authorial). Sima Qian said: The three Jin states were full of strategists, and those who advocated siding with the powerful Qin were mostly from the three Jin states. Zhang Yi's actions were even more egregious than Su Qin's, yet the world disliked Su Qin because he died first, while Zhang Yi exposed Su Qin's shortcomings to support his arguments and establish his own way of balancing power. In short, these two were truly men who brought ruin upon themselves! [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 1. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Fan Sui was a man from Wei, whose courtesy name was Shu. He traveled among the feudal lords, wanting to serve the King of Wei, but his family was poor and he had no means to support himself, so he first served Xu Jia, a senior official in Wei.
[299 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 62.12 (yr 38; Zhaoling; Shu surrender). In the fourteenth year, Qin attacked Chu and captured Zhaoling. Dan, Li, and Zhuang, the prime minister of Shu, killed the Marquis of Shu and surrendered. 65.8 (yr 8; allied attack Fangcheng). In the eighth year, General Mi Rong was sent to attack Chu, and Xinshi was captured. Qi sent Zhang Zi, Wei sent Gongsun Xi, and Han sent Bao Yuan to jointly attack Fangcheng of Chu, capturing Tangmei. Zhao defeated Zhongshan, and its ruler died, eventually dying in Qi. Prince Jin of Wei and Prince Chang of Han became feudal lords. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 20.3. King Yi died in the twelfth year of his reign, and his son, Kuai of Yan, succeeded him. 21.1. After Yan Kuai ascended the throne, the people of Qi killed Su Qin. While Su Qin was in Yan, he married his prime minister, Zi Zhi, and Su Dai became acquainted with Zi Zhi. 21.2. After Su Qin's death, King Xuan of Qi reinstated Su Dai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 84.4. In the thirtieth year, Qin attacked Chu again, capturing eight cities. King Zhaoxiang of Qin sent a letter to King Huai of Chu, saying: "Initially, I and Your Majesty swore an oath of brotherhood at Huangji, with the Crown Prince as a hostage, and we were extremely pleased. However, the Crown Prince murdered one of my important ministers, and fled without apologizing. I was truly enraged and sent troops to invade Your Majesty's borders. Now I hear that Your Majesty has sent the Crown Prince as a hostage to Qi to seek peace. My country and Chu share a border, and we have a long-standing kinship through marriage. Now that Qin and Chu are not on good terms, I have no way to command the other states. I wish to meet Your Majesty at Wuguan Pass, to make a face-to-face agreement, and then depart. This is my wish. I dare to report this to you." King Huai of Chu, upon seeing the letter from the King of Qin, was troubled. He wanted to go, but feared being deceived; he did not go, but feared Qin's anger. Zhao Ju said, "Your Majesty should not go, but instead send troops to defend yourself. Qin is like a tiger and a wolf, not to be trusted, and harbors ambitions to annex the other states." Prince Huai's son, Zilan, advised the king to go, saying, "How can we sever Qin's goodwill!" So he went to meet King Zhaoxiang of Qin. King Zhao tricked a general into ambushing Chu at Wuguan Pass, and the general proclaimed himself King of Qin. When the King of Chu arrived, the general closed Wuguan Pass and then accompanied him west to Xianyang. The King of Chu paid homage at Zhangtai, treating him like a vassal lord, without the proper courtesies. King Huai of Chu was furious and regretted not heeding Zhao's advice. Qin then detained the King of Chu, demanding the cession of the Wu and Qianzhong prefectures. The King of Chu wanted to form an alliance, but Qin wanted the land first. The King of Chu angrily said, "Qin has deceived me and now demands land from me!" He refused to comply. Qin then detained him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 71. On the day of Wushen in the fifth month of the twenty-seventh year, a grand court was held at the Eastern Palace, the throne was passed down, and Prince He was established as king. After the audience at the royal ancestral temple, the king went forth to hold court. All the high officials became his subjects, and Fei Yi became the prime minister and tutor to the king. This was King Huiwen. King Huiwen was the son of Queen Hui, Wuwa. King Wuling called himself the Lord Father. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 26. Han Shijia: Chu besieged Yongshi, and Han sought help from Qin. Before Qin could act, Qin sent Gongsun Mei to Han. Gongzhong asked, "Do you think Qin will come to Han's aid?" Gongzhong replied, "The King of Qin said, 'Please allow me to pass through Nanzheng and Lantian, and send troops to Chu to await you,' which is likely unwise." Gongzhong asked, "Do you think it will come to fruition?" Gongzhong replied, "The King of Qin will surely follow the old strategy of Zhang Yi. When King Wei of Chu attacked Liang, Zhang Yi said to the King of Qin, 'If we attack Wei with Chu, Wei will be defeated and fall into Chu's hands. Han will then be an ally, leaving Qin isolated. It would be better to send troops to them, and in the ensuing great battle between Wei and Chu, Qin can take the land west of the Yellow River and return.' Now, Qin outwardly speaks of allegiance to Han, but in reality, it is befriending Chu. If you await Qin's arrival, you will surely rashly engage in battle with Chu. Chu will secretly gain..." "If Qin does not employ you, it will surely be easy for you to contend with me. If you defeat Chu in battle, then you will ride with me through Chu, passing through the Three Rivers before returning. If you lose to Chu in battle, Chu will block the Three Rivers and defend them, and you will be unable to come to my aid. I am secretly worried for you. Sima Geng rebelled three times in Ying, and Gan Mao met with Zhao Yu in Shangyu. Their talk of seizing the imperial seal seems to be an agreement." Gong Zhong was afraid and asked, "Then what should we do?" He replied, "You will surely prioritize Han over Qin, and yourself over Zhang Yi. You would be better off quickly forming an alliance between Qi and Chu, and Qi and Chu will surely entrust their states to you. What you dislike about Zhang Yi is actually not without Qin as well." Thereupon, Chu lifted the siege of Yongshi. 27. Han Shijia: Su Dai then said to Mi Rong, the younger brother of the Queen Dowager of Qin, "Gongshu Boying fears that Qin and Chu are like lice and fleas within each other. Why don't you ask Chu for a hostage for Han? If the King of Chu agrees to send a hostage to Han, then Gongshu Boying will know that Qin and Chu don't care about lice and fleas, and will surely unite Han with Qin and Chu. Qin and Chu will then use Han to pressure Wei, and Wei will not dare to unite with Qi, leaving Qi isolated. If you then ask Chu for a hostage for Qin, and Chu refuses, they will harbor resentment towards Han. Han will then use Qi and Wei to besiege Chu, and Chu will surely value you highly. By leveraging the power of Qin and Chu to accumulate virtue in Han, Gongshu Boying will surely treat you with the respect due to a state." Thus, the lice and fleas were not able to return to Han. Han established Jiu as the crown prince. The kings of Qi and Wei came. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 2. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Xu Jia was sent as an envoy to Qi by King Zhao of Wei, with Fan Sui accompanying him. They stayed for several months without receiving a reply. King Xiang of Qi, hearing of Sui's eloquence, sent someone to bestow upon Sui ten catties of gold and a cow and wine, which Sui declined. Xu Jia, upon learning this, was furious, believing Sui had informed Qi of Wei's secrets, thus receiving the gifts. He ordered Sui to accept the cow and wine and return the gold. Upon returning home, still enraged by Sui, he reported this to the Prime Minister of Wei, a prince named Wei Qi. Wei Qi was enraged and ordered his servants to flog Sui, breaking his ribs and teeth. Sui feigned death, then wrapped him in a bamboo mat and placed him in the latrine. His guests, drunk, urinated on Sui, thus humiliating him as a warning to others, preventing further slander. Sui, emerging from the mat, said to the guard, "If you release me, I will repay you handsomely." The guard then requested that the dead body be removed from the mat. Wei Qi, drunk, said, "That's enough." Fan Sui was released. Later, Wei Qi regretted it and summoned him again. Zheng Anping, a man from Wei, heard of this and seized Fan Sui, who fled and went into hiding, changing his name to Zhang Lu.
[298 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 65.9 (yr 9; Mengchang as PM). In the ninth year, Lord Mengchang, Xue Wen, came to serve as prime minister of Qin. Huan attacked Chu, captured eight cities, and killed its general Jing Kuai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 85. The ministers of Chu were troubled by this and conspired, saying, "Our king is trapped in Qin and cannot return. He is forced to cede territory, and the crown prince is held hostage in Qi. If Qi and Qin conspire together, Chu will be without a state." They then wanted to install Prince Huai, who was still in the state, as king. Zhao Ju said, "Both the king and the crown prince are trapped by the feudal lords. Now, to disobey the king's orders and install his son, which is inappropriate." So he pretended to go to Qi. King Min of Qi said to his minister, "It would be better to keep the crown prince and ask Chu for the land north of the Huai River." The minister said, "No, if we install a king in Ying, it would be like me holding an empty hostage and committing an unjust act in front of the world." Someone said, "No. If we install a king in Ying, we can negotiate with the new king and say, 'Give me the eastern state, and I will kill the crown prince for the king. Otherwise, I will join the three states in installing him.' Then we will surely get the eastern state." The king of Qi eventually followed his minister's plan and returned the crown prince of Chu. Crown Prince Heng arrived and was installed as king, becoming King Qingxiang. He then reported to Qin, "Thanks to the spirits of the state, the state has a king." 86.1. In the first year of King Qingxiang's reign, Qin demanded land from King Huai, but to no avail. Chu then established a new king to appease Qin. King Zhaoxiang of Qin was enraged and sent troops out of Wuguan to attack Chu, inflicting a crushing defeat on the Chu army, beheading 50,000 and capturing fifteen cities before departing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 72. The Master Father, wanting his son to govern the state, disguised himself as a barbarian and led officials to conquer the northwestern barbarian lands. His plan was to attack Qin directly from Yunzhong and Jiuyuan in the south. Therefore, he falsely claimed to be an envoy and entered Qin. King Zhaoxiang of Qin was unaware of this, but then found the man's imposing appearance unusual, not befitting a subject. He ordered his men to pursue him, but the Master Father had already escaped the pass. Upon questioning, it was indeed the Master Father. The people of Qin were greatly astonished. The Master Father's purpose in entering Qin was to survey the terrain and observe the King of Qin's character. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 28.1. In the fourteenth year, he joined forces with the Kings of Qi and Wei to attack Qin, and camped at Hangu Pass. In the sixteenth year, Qin annexed the area beyond the Yellow River and Wusui. King Xiang died, and his son, Crown Prince Jiu, ascended the throne as King Li. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 3. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... At this time, King Zhaoxiang of Qin sent a messenger named Wang Ji to Wei. Zheng Anping disguised himself as a soldier and served Wang Ji. Wang Ji asked, "Is there a wise man in Wei who I can travel west with?" Zheng Anping replied, "There is a Mr. Zhang Lu in my village who wishes to see you and discuss matters of the world. However, he has a grudge and dares not see you during the day." Wang Ji said, "Bring him here tonight." Zheng Anping and Zhang Lu met with Wang Ji that night. Before they finished speaking, Wang Ji learned of Fan Sui's virtue and said, "Sir, wait for me south of the Three Pavilions." They made a private appointment and then parted ways. 4. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Wang Ji left Wei and took Fan Sui with him to Qin. Upon reaching the lake, they saw carriages and cavalry approaching from the west. Fan Sui asked, "Who are those coming?" Wang Ji replied, "The Qin Chancellor, Marquis Rang, is traveling east to the counties." Fan Sui said, "I've heard that Marquis Rang holds absolute power in Qin and dislikes entertaining guests from other states. This might humiliate me; I'd rather hide in the carriage." A short while later, Marquis Rang indeed arrived, greeted Wang Ji, and then stood in the carriage, saying, "What changes have occurred in the east?" Wang Ji replied, "Nothing." Marquis Rang then said to Wang Ji, "Did you bring any guests from other states with you? It's pointless; it will only cause chaos in other states." Wang Ji replied, "I dare not," and then departed. Fan Sui said, "I've heard that Marquis Rang is a wise man, but he is slow to act. The villagers may have suspected someone was in the carriage and forgotten to check." So Fan Sui got out of the carriage and ran, saying, "He will surely regret this." After traveling more than ten li, he indeed sent his riders back to search the carriage, but there was no guest, so the matter was dropped. Wang Ji then went with Fan Sui to Xianyang.
[297 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 65.10 (yr 10; King Huai detained). In the tenth year, King Huai of Chu went to Qin to pay homage, and Qin detained him. Xue Wen accepted the offer of gold to be released. Lou Huan became prime minister. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 86.2. The following year, King Huai of Chu fled back to Chu. Qin discovered this and blocked the Chu road. King Huai, fearing for his life, fled to Zhao via a side road to seek his return. The King of Zhao, Zhufu, was in Dai, and his son, King Hui, had just ascended the throne and was acting as regent. Fearing for his life, Zhufu dared not approach the King of Chu. The King of Chu intended to flee to Wei, but Qin pursued him. He then returned to Qin with a Qin envoy. King Huai subsequently fell ill. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 73. In the second year of King Huiwen's reign, the King Father traveled to a new territory, then went to Dai, where he encountered the King of Loufan at the West River and captured his troops. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 5. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... The messenger had already been informed, and the messenger said, "In Wei there is a man named Zhang Lu, a renowned debater. He said, 'The Qin king's kingdom is as precarious as a pile of eggs; with my help, it will be safe. However, this cannot be recorded in writing.' Therefore, I brought this message with me." The Qin king did not believe him and sent him to be provided with food and provisions. He waited for orders for over a year.
[296 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 65.11 (yr 11; coalition reaches Yanshi). In the eleventh year, the five states of Qi, Han, Wei, Zhao, Song, and Zhongshan jointly attacked Qin, reaching Yanshi before turning back. Qin made peace with Han and Wei over Hebei and Fengling. A comet appeared. King Huai of Chu fled to Zhao, but Zhao refused to accept him and returned him to Qin. He died there and was buried in Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 21.3. In the third year of Yan Kuai's reign, he joined forces with Chu and the three Jin states to attack Qin, but was defeated and returned. 21.4. Zi Zhi served as prime minister of Yan, holding a high position and making decisive decisions. 21.5. Su Dai was sent as an envoy of Qi to Yan. The King of Yan asked, "What do you think of the King of Qi?" Su Dai replied, "He will certainly not become a hegemon." The King of Yan asked, "Why?" Su Dai replied, "He does not trust his ministers." Su Dai intended to provoke the King of Yan to enhance Zi Zhi's prestige. 21.6. Therefore, the King of Yan greatly trusted Zi Zhi. 21.7. Zi Zhi then gave Su Dai one hundred gold pieces and allowed him to act as he pleased. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 86.3. In the third year of King Qingxiang's reign, King Huai died in Qin, and Qin returned his remains to Chu. The people of Chu all mourned him, as if grieving for a relative. As a result, the other states no longer supported Qin. The Qin and Chu states severed ties. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 74. In the third year, he conquered Zhongshan and moved its king to Fushi. He established Lingshou, and the northern regions followed him, making the Dai road much more accessible. Upon his return, he rewarded the people, granted a general amnesty, held a five-day feast, and enfeoffed his eldest son, Zhang, as the Lord of Dai Anyang. Zhang was naturally extravagant and resented his brother's succession. Furthermore, the ruler sent Tian Buli to serve as Zhang's chancellor. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 28.2. In the fourteenth year, he joined forces with the Kings of Qi and Wei to attack Qin, and camped at Hangu Pass. In the sixteenth year, Qin annexed the area beyond the Yellow River and Wusui. King Xiang died, and his son, Crown Prince Jiu, ascended the throne as King Li.
[295 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 65.12 (yr 12; Rang Hou as PM; grain). In the twelfth year, Lou Huan was dismissed, and Marquis Rang, Wei Ran, became prime minister. Qin granted Chu 50,000 shi of grain. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 22.1. Lu Maoshou advised the King of Yan, "It would be better to cede the kingdom to your prime minister, Zizhi. People call Yao a wise ruler because he offered the throne to Xu You, who refused. Thus, Yao had the name of ceding the throne but did not actually lose it. Now, Your Majesty, if you cede the kingdom to Zizhi, Zizhi will certainly not dare to accept it. This would mean Your Majesty is acting in accordance with Yao." 22.2. The King of Yan then entrusted the kingdom to Zizhi, who became very powerful. Someone said, "Yu recommended Yi, and then appointed Qi as an official. When Qi grew old, Yu deemed Qi unfit to govern the kingdom and passed it on to Yi. Later, Qi and his allies attacked Yi and seized the throne. The world said that Yu nominally passed the throne to Yi, but in reality, he made Qi take it for himself. Now, Your Majesty says you are entrusting the kingdom to Zizhi, but all the officials are former sons of the Crown Prince. This means that you are nominally entrusting the kingdom to Zizhi, but in reality, the Crown Prince is in power." 22.3. The King then confiscated the seals of office from officials of 300 shi and above and presented them to Zizhi. Zizhi then ruled as king, while Kuai, in his old age, did not attend to government affairs but instead served as a minister. All state affairs were decided by Zizhi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 75. Li Dui said to Fei Yi, "Prince Zhang is strong and arrogant, with many followers and a strong desire for power. Is he perhaps harboring selfish motives? Tian Buli is a ruthless and arrogant man. If these two get along, they will surely plot against each other, and one of them will seek personal gain. Petty people are driven by desires, quick to anger and shallow in their schemes. They only see the benefits and ignore the harms. They push each other down, and all will fall into the trap of disaster. In my opinion, this will not last long. You bear heavy responsibilities and wield great power. This is the beginning of chaos and the source of disaster. You will be the first to suffer. The benevolent love all things, and the wise prepare for calamity before it takes shape. How can one govern a country without benevolence and wisdom? Why don't you feign illness and stay home, and pass the reins of government to Prince Cheng? Don't become a source of resentment, and don't become a ladder for disaster." Fei Yi said, "No, in the past, the Lord Father..." Wang, entrusting Yi with the task, said: "Do not change your mind, do not deviate from your plans, hold fast to one heart, and die with the world at large." Yi bowed twice to receive the order and registered it. Now, fearing the consequences of disrespect, he forgot his registration; what could be a greater change? To advance and receive a strict order, to retreat and be incomplete, what could be a greater transgression? A minister who changes his mind and betrays his duty is not tolerated by punishment. As the proverb says, "The dead are brought back to life, and the living have no shame." My words have already been spoken; if I wish to uphold my words, how can I uphold my own life? Moreover, it is difficult for a loyal minister to achieve integrity, and it is difficult for a faithful minister to achieve virtue through repeated efforts. You have been kind to me and have been loyal to me, but I have something to say before, and I will never forget it." Li Dui said, "Yes, you should strive for it! I have only seen you this year." He wept and left. Li Dui met with Prince Cheng several times to prepare for the matter of Tian's disrespect.
[294 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.1 (King Zhaoxiang yr 13). In the thirteenth year, Xiang Shou attacked Han and captured Wushi. Zuo Geng Bai Qi attacked Xincheng. Wu Dafu Li fled to Wei. Ren Bi became the governor of Hanzhong. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 76. One day, Fei Yi said to Xin Qi, "Gongzi and Tian Buli are truly worrisome. Their words of righteousness are virtuous, but their deeds are wicked; they are neither sons nor subjects. I have heard it said that treacherous ministers in court are the bane of the state; slanderous ministers in the inner court are the scourges of the ruler. This man is greedy and ambitious, ingratiating himself with the ruler internally while acting tyrannically externally. He easily manipulates orders, arbitrarily issuing commands; it is not difficult for him to do so. Disaster will soon befall the state. I am now deeply worried about him, forgetting sleep at night and forgetting to eat when hungry. We must be vigilant against thieves coming and going. From now on, if anyone summons the king, they must see me. I will personally confront them; only then will the king enter without cause." Xin Qi said, "Excellent! I have heard this!" [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.1. Bai Qi was a native of Mei. Skilled in warfare, he served King Zhaoxiang of Qin. 1.2. In the thirteenth year of King Zhaoxiang's reign, Bai Qi became the Left Grand Master and led an attack on Xincheng of Han. That year, Marquis Rang, the Prime Minister of Qin, appointed Ren Bi as the Governor of Hanzhong.
[293 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 71. Eight years later, Qin attacked Yiyang, and Chu came to its aid. Chu, however, considered Zhou's allegiance to Qin and intended to attack it. Su Dai, on behalf of Zhou, advised the King of Chu: "Why is Zhou a threat to Qin? It is because Qin considers Zhou's allegiance to Qin greater than Chu's, intending to force Zhou into Qin's hands; hence the term 'Zhou-Qin.' Knowing this is unavoidable, Zhou will inevitably submit to Qin, thus allowing Qin to extract Zhou's essence. For Your Majesty's sake, if Zhou is on good terms with Qin, then do so; if not, then speak well of Zhou to distance yourself from Qin. Once Zhou is cut off from Qin, it will surely enter Ying." [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.2 (yr 14; Yique; 240,000). In the fourteenth year, Zuo Geng Bai Qi attacked Han and Wei at Yique, beheading 240,000, capturing Gongsun Xi, and taking five cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 87.1. In the sixth year, Qin sent Bai Qi to attack Han at Yique, achieving a great victory and beheading 240,000. Qin then sent a letter to the King of Chu, saying, "Chu has betrayed Qin, and Qin will lead the other states to attack Chu, vying for a single day's life. We hope Your Majesty will instruct your soldiers to fight a joyful battle." King Qingxiang of Chu was troubled by this and plotted to make peace with Qin again. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 77. In the fourth year, the court officials gathered, and Lord Anyang also came to pay homage. The King ordered the king to listen to the court proceedings, while he himself observed the etiquette of the officials and members of the royal family from the sidelines. He saw that the king's eldest son, Zhang, was dignified and humbled, bowing to the north as a subject, subservient to his younger brother. He felt pity for him and thus considered dividing Zhao and making Zhang king of Dai. However, the plan was abandoned before it was finalized. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 29.1. In the third year of King Li's reign, he sent Gongsun Xi to lead Zhou and Wei to attack Qin. Qin defeated 240,000 of our troops and captured Xi at Yique. In the fifth year, Qin captured Wan. In the sixth year, he ceded 200 li of land to Qin at Wusui. In the tenth year, Qin defeated our army at Xiashan. In the twelfth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Western Zhou and assisted Qin in attacking Qi. Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. In the fourteenth year, he met with Qin at Zhou Xian. In the twenty-first year, he sent Bao Juan to rescue Wei, but he was defeated by Qin and Juan fled to Kaifeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.3. The following year, Bai Qi became the Left Attendant and attacked Han and Wei at Yique, beheading 240,000 and capturing their general Gongsun Xi, taking five cities. He was then promoted to Grand Commandant. He crossed the river and captured the area east of Anyi in Han, reaching Ganhe. The following year, Bai Qi became Grand General. He attacked Wei, capturing it and taking 61 cities, large and small. The following year, Bai Qi, along with the guest minister Cuo, attacked and captured Yuancheng. Five years later, Bai Qi attacked Zhao and captured Guanglang City. Seven years later, Bai Qi attacked Chu and captured five cities, including Yan and Deng. The following year, he attacked Chu again, capturing Ying, burning Yiling, and then advancing east to Jingling. The King of Chu fled Ying, moving east to Chen. Qin established Nanjun as part of Qin. Bai Qi was then promoted to Lord Wu'an. Lord Wu'an conquered Chu and pacified the Wu and Qianzhong commanderies. In the 34th year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked Wei, captured Huayang, fled Mangmao, and captured generals of the Three Jin states, beheading 130,000. He fought against Zhao general Jia Yan, drowning 20,000 of his soldiers in the river. In the 43rd year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked Hanxing City, capturing five cities and beheading 50,000. In the 44th year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked the Taihang Road in Nanyang, cutting it off.
[292 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.3 (yr 15; attacks Wei/Chu). In the fifteenth year, Grand General Bai Qi attacked Wei, captured Yuan, and then returned it. He attacked Chu and captured Wan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 18.2. Twenty-eight years later, Su Qin first came to see Duke Wen and persuaded him. Duke Wen sent carriages, horses, gold, and silk to Zhao, which were accepted by Marquis Su of Zhao. He then formed an alliance with the six states, making them the leaders of the alliance. King Hui of Qin gave his daughter to the Crown Prince of Yan in marriage. 23.1. Three years later, the state was in great chaos, and the people lived in fear. General Shi Bei conspired with Crown Prince Ping to attack Zizhi. The generals told King Min of Qi, "Go and attack; we will surely defeat Yan." King Min then sent someone to tell Crown Prince Ping of Yan, "I have heard of the Crown Prince's righteousness. He intends to abandon private interests and establish public good, to uphold the proper relationship between ruler and subject, and to clarify the roles of father and son. My state is small and not worthy of such a position. However, I will follow the Crown Prince's orders." The Crown Prince then gathered his supporters and a large army. General Shi Bei besieged the palace and attacked Zizhi, but failed. General Shi Bei and the people then turned against Crown Prince Ping. General Shi Bei was killed as a warning. 23.2. The conflict lasted for several months, with tens of thousands dead. The people were terrified and their will was broken. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 87.2. In the seventh year, Chu welcomed a bride to Qin, and Qin and Chu were at peace again. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 78. When the King and his retinue visited Shaqiu and the other palaces, Prince Zhang, along with his followers and Tian Buli, rebelled, falsely claiming it was the King's order to summon the King. Fei Yi entered first and killed them. Gao Xin then fought the King. Prince Cheng and Li Dui arrived from their own kingdom, raised troops from four cities to resist the rebellion, killed Prince Zhang and Tian Buli, annihilated their followers, and stabilized the royal court. Prince Cheng became prime minister, known as Lord Anping, and Li Dui became Minister of Justice. After Prince Zhang's defeat, he fled to the King, who opened the gates. Cheng and Dui then besieged the King's palace. After Prince Zhang's death, Prince Cheng and Li Dui plotted, saying, "Since we besieged the King because of Zhang, we will lift our troops, and we will be doomed." So they besieged the King. They ordered those in the palace to "leave last, or be doomed," and everyone in the palace left. The King wanted to leave but could not, and also had no food. He ate a goat's rooster, and after more than three months, he starved to death in the Shaqiu palace. After the King's death was confirmed, his funeral was held and the news was sent to the feudal lords. 79 (discursive). At that time, the king was young, and Cheng and Dui held power. Fearing execution, they besieged the King. The King initially made his eldest son Zhang the crown prince, but later he married Wu Wa, whom he loved dearly and kept out of the palace for several years. She gave birth to a son, He, so the King deposed Crown Prince Zhang and installed He as king. After Wu Wa died, his love for her waned, and he pitied the former crown prince, wanting to make both kings. He hesitated and could not decide, so a rebellion broke out, resulting in the deaths of both father and son, becoming a laughingstock to the world. How tragic! [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.4. The following year, Bai Qi became the Left Attendant and attacked Han and Wei at Yique, beheading 240,000 and capturing their general Gongsun Xi, taking five cities. He was then promoted to Grand Commandant. He crossed the river and captured the area east of Anyi in Han, reaching Ganhe. The following year, Bai Qi became Grand General. He attacked Wei, capturing it and taking 61 cities, large and small. The following year, Bai Qi, along with the guest minister Cuo, attacked and captured Yuancheng. Five years later, Bai Qi attacked Zhao and captured Guanglang City. Seven years later, Bai Qi attacked Chu and captured five cities, including Yan and Deng. The following year, he attacked Chu again, capturing Ying, burning Yiling, and then advancing east to Jingling. The King of Chu fled Ying, moving east to Chen. Qin established Nanjun as part of Qin. Bai Qi was then promoted to Lord Wu'an. Lord Wu'an conquered Chu and pacified the Wu and Qianzhong commanderies. In the 34th year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked Wei, captured Huayang, fled Mangmao, and captured generals of the Three Jin states, beheading 130,000. He fought against Zhao general Jia Yan, drowning 20,000 of his soldiers in the river. In the 43rd year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked Hanxing City, capturing five cities and beheading 50,000. In the 44th year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked the Taihang Road in Nanyang, cutting it off.
[291 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.4 (yr 16). In the sixteenth year, Zuo Geng Cuo captured Zhi and Deng. Ran Mian was enfeoffed as a prince, and Gongzi Shi Wan, Gongzi Kui Deng, and Ran Tao of Wei were made vassals. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 23.3. Mencius said to King Min of Qi, "Now is the time to attack Yan, just as it was during the reigns of King Wen and King Wu. We must not miss this opportunity." [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 29.2. In the third year of King Li's reign, he sent Gongsun Xi to lead Zhou and Wei to attack Qin. Qin defeated 240,000 of our troops and captured Xi at Yique. In the fifth year, Qin captured Wan. In the sixth year, he ceded 200 li of land to Qin at Wusui. In the tenth year, Qin defeated our army at Xiashan. In the twelfth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Western Zhou and assisted Qin in attacking Qi. Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. In the fourteenth year, he met with Qin at Zhou Xian. In the twenty-first year, he sent Bao Juan to rescue Wei, but he was defeated by Qin and Juan fled to Kaifeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.5. The following year, Bai Qi became the Left Attendant and attacked Han and Wei at Yique, beheading 240,000 and capturing their general Gongsun Xi, taking five cities. He was then promoted to Grand Commandant. He crossed the river and captured the area east of Anyi in Han, reaching Ganhe. The following year, Bai Qi became Grand General. He attacked Wei, capturing it and taking 61 cities, large and small. The following year, Bai Qi, along with the guest minister Cuo, attacked and captured Yuancheng.
[290 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.5 (yr 17). In the seventeenth year, the Lord of Chengyang came to court, and the Lord of Dongzhou also came to court. Qin renamed Yuan as Puban and Pishi. The king went to Yiyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 29.3. In the third year of King Li's reign, he sent Gongsun Xi to lead Zhou and Wei to attack Qin. Qin defeated 240,000 of our troops and captured Xi at Yique. In the fifth year, Qin captured Wan. In the sixth year, he ceded 200 li of land to Qin at Wusui. In the tenth year, Qin defeated our army at Xiashan. In the twelfth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Western Zhou and assisted Qin in attacking Qi. Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. In the fourteenth year, he met with Qin at Zhou Xian. In the twenty-first year, he sent Bao Juan to rescue Wei, but he was defeated by Qin and Juan fled to Kaifeng.
[289 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.6 (yr 18; bridge breach). In the eighteenth year, Cuo attacked Yuan and Heyong, and captured them by breaching the bridge.
[288 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.7 (yr 19; “Western Emperor”). In the nineteenth year, the king became the Western Emperor, and Qi became the Eastern Emperor, and both were removed from their posts. Lü Li came to surrender. Qi defeated Song, and the King of Song died in Wei. Ren Bi died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 88. Eleven years later, Qi and Qin each proclaimed themselves emperors; a month later, they reverted to the title of emperor and king. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 80. (After the death of the King's father, King Huiwen ascended the throne.) In the fifth year, he joined forces with Yan, Mo, and Yi. In the eighth year, he marched south of the city to Xingtang. In the ninth year, Zhao Liang, as general, joined forces with Qi to attack Han, reaching the foot of Lu Pass. In the tenth year, Qin declared itself the Western Emperor. In the eleventh year, Dong Shu and the Wei clan attacked Song, capturing Heyang from Wei. Qin captured Baoyang. In the twelfth year, Zhao Liang, as general, attacked Qi. In the thirteenth year, Han Xu, as general, attacked Qi. The princess died. In the fourteenth year, Chancellor Yue Yi led Zhao, Qin, Han, Wei, and Yan to attack Qi, capturing Lingqiu. He met with Qin at Zhongyang. In the fifteenth year, King Zhao of Yan came to see him. Zhao, Han, Wei, and Qin jointly attacked Qi; the King of Qi was defeated and fled, while Yan advanced deep into enemy territory alone, capturing Linzi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 43. In the twelfth year, Qin attacked Wei. Chu besieged Yongshi, and Qin defeated Qu Gai. Su Dai said to Tian Zhen, "I wish to have an audience with you, Your Excellency. Your actions are very successful, bringing benefit to Chu, whether it succeeds or fails. Just now, as I stood at the gate, a guest said that the King of Wei said to Han Feng and Zhang Yi, 'We are about to capture Zhuzao, but Qi troops are advancing again. If you come to my aid, it will be fine; if you do not come to my aid, I will not be able to capture it.' This is merely a pretext. If Qin and Han's troops do not advance eastward, within ten days, Wei will switch sides and align with Qin, and Qin will expel Zhang Yi, thus ending their alliance." "Qi and Chu, this matter will be accomplished." Tian Zhen asked, "How can we prevent the east from being reached?" He replied, "When Han Feng rescued Wei, he would not have said to the King of Han, 'Feng is for Wei,' but rather, 'Feng will use the troops of Qin and Han to push back Qi and Song in the east. Feng will then gather the troops of the three states, ride the chariot of Qu Gai, and cede the south to Chu. Therefore, all the land will surely be obtained.' Similarly, when Zhang Yi rescued Wei, he would not have said to the King of Qin, 'Yi is for Wei,' but rather, 'Yi will use the troops of Qin and Han to push back Qi in the east.'" Song, Yi, will gather the armies of the three states, ride the swift horse of Qu Gai, and annex the south to Chu. In name, he will preserve a fallen state; in reality, he will conquer the Three Rivers and return. This is the way of a true king. The Duke ordered the King of Chu to give land to the Han state, thus securing peace with Qin. He said to the King of Qin, "I request to give land to Han, and Your Majesty will use it to grant the Three Rivers. Han's army will not be needed, and you will gain land from Chu." What did Han Feng's words about the eastern troops mean to Qin? He said, "Qin's army will not be needed, and you will gain the Three Rivers. You will attack Chu and Han to put Wei in a difficult position. Wei will not dare to move east, thus isolating Qi." "What was Zhang Yi's statement regarding the eastern troops? He said, 'Qin and Han desire land, but their armies are well-organized. Their influence extends to Wei, giving Wei the means to avoid losing Qi and Chu.' Wei then shifted the blame for Qin and Han's conflict with Qi and Chu. The King of Chu desired land but could not obtain it. Your Excellency, by ordering Qin and Han to abandon their troops, secured the land—a great act of virtue. The Kings of Qin and Han, coerced by Han Feng and Zhang Yi, sent their eastern troops to subdue Wei. Your Excellency consistently held the left-hand contract to hold Qin and Han accountable. This demonstrates your goodwill towards Your Excellency and your dislike of Zhang Yi."
[287 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.8 (yr 20; tours). In the twentieth year, the king went to Hanzhong, and then to Shangjun and Beihe. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 81. In the sixteenth year, Qin, together with Zhao, repeatedly attacked Qi, causing great distress to the people of Qi. Su Li sent a letter to the King of Zhao on behalf of Qi, saying: 82. Your servant has heard that the virtuous rulers of old did not spread their virtues throughout the land, nor did they instill their teachings in the people, nor did they offer sacrifices to the spirits in a regular manner. When sweet dew fell and timely rains arrived, the harvests were plentiful and the people were free from disease, the people praised this, but the wise rulers did not consider this. 83. Your Excellency's virtuous conduct and achievements are not merely due to your favor towards Qin; your resentment and anger are not solely stemming from your long-standing conflict with Qi. Qin and Zhao are allied, yet Qin is using force to levy troops from Han. Does Qin truly love Zhao? Or does it truly hate Qi? A wise ruler should discern the extremes of such matters. Qin does not love Zhao but hate Qi; it desires to destroy Han and annex the two Zhou states, thus using Qi as a bargaining chip for the world. Fearing things will not go as planned, it sends troops to coerce Wei and Zhao. Fearing the world will fear it, it sends hostages as a show of force. Fearing the world will quickly rebel, it levies troops from Han to intimidate it. It feigns virtue to befriend the state, but in reality, it attacks and weakens Han. I believe Qin's strategy must be based on this. Indeed, some things have different strengths but share the same fate. Chu's prolonged attack led to the fall of Zhongshan; now, Qi's prolonged attack will surely lead to the fall of Han. By defeating Qi, Your Majesty can share the spoils with the other six states. By destroying Han, Qin can monopolize it. By seizing the two Zhou states and taking the sacrificial vessels from the west, Qin can keep them all for itself. In terms of land tax and merit, whose gain is greater, Your Majesty's or Qin's? 84. The strategist advised: "Han lost the Three Rivers region, Wei lost the State of Jin; the market and court have not yet changed, but disaster has already struck." Yan has conquered all of Qi's northern territory, only 300 li from Shaqiu and Julu. Han's Shangdang is only 100 li from Handan. Yan and Qin are plotting to seize the King's lands, a mere 300 li away. Qin's Shangjun is near Tingguan, 1500 li from Yuzhong. Qin is using three commanderies to attack the King's Shangdang; west of Yangchang and south of Juju, it is no longer yours. Beyond Juju, Changshan is cut off and defended, a 300-li passage to Yan. The horses of Dai and the dogs of Hu will not go east, and the jade of Kunshan will not be produced; these three treasures are also no longer yours. The King has long been attacking Qi, and now he is following the powerful Qin in attacking Han; this disaster is inevitable. I urge the King to consider this carefully. 85. Moreover, Qi's reason for attacking was to serve Your Majesty; the whole world followed suit to plot against Your Majesty. The alliance between Yan and Qin was finalized, and the military campaign was imminent. The five states divided the land among the kings, yet Qi broke the alliance and sacrificed itself for Your Majesty's sake. Its western troops were used to restrain the powerful Qin, Qin deposed its emperor and sued for submission, and Qi returned Gaoping and Genrou to Wei, and Yifen and Xianyu to Zhao. Qi's service to Your Majesty should have been exemplary, yet now it has committed a crime. I fear that those who serve Your Majesty in the future will not dare to act with certainty. I urge Your Majesty to consider this carefully. 86. If Your Majesty does not join the world in attacking Qi, the world will surely regard Your Majesty as righteous. If Qi cherishes its state and serves Your Majesty generously, the world will surely respect Your Majesty's righteousness. If Your Majesty uses the world's favor to befriend Qin, and Qin is tyrannical, and Your Majesty uses the world's power to restrain it, then the reputation and favor of the world will be controlled by Your Majesty. Therefore, Zhao stopped and apologized to Qin for not attacking Qi.
[286 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.9 (yr 21; Anyi surrendered). In the twenty-first year, Qin mistakenly attacked Wei's Henan region. Wei surrendered Anyi, and Qin recruited its people, granting them titles and pardoning criminals to relocate there. The Lord of Jingyang was enfeoffed in Wan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 87. The king encountered the King of Yan. Lian Po led an army to attack Xiyang of Qi and captured it. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 29.4. In the third year of King Li's reign, he sent Gongsun Xi to lead Zhou and Wei to attack Qin. Qin defeated 240,000 of our troops and captured Xi at Yique. In the fifth year, Qin captured Wan. In the sixth year, he ceded 200 li of land to Qin at Wusui. In the tenth year, Qin defeated our army at Xiashan. In the twelfth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Western Zhou and assisted Qin in attacking Qi. Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. In the fourteenth year, he met with Qin at Zhou Xian. In the twenty-first year, he sent Bao Juan to rescue Wei, but he was defeated by Qin and Juan fled to Kaifeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 44. In the thirteenth year, King Hui of Qin died. In the twenty-third year, Qin defeated Chu at Chongqiu. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin sent Lord Jingyang as a hostage to Qi. In the twenty-fifth year, Qin returned Lord Jingyang to Qin. Lord Mengchang, Xue Wen, entered Qin and became its prime minister. Wen later fled. In the twenty-sixth year, Qi, Han, and Wei jointly attacked Qin, reaching Hangu Pass. In the twenty-eighth year, Qin and Han made peace beyond the Yellow River, and the war ended. In the twenty-ninth year, Zhao killed its ruler. Qi assisted Zhao in destroying Zhongshan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.6. Five years later, Bai Qi attacked Zhao and captured Guanglang City.
[285 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.10 (yr 22; Meng Wu attacks Qi). In the twenty-second year, Meng Wu attacked Qi. Hedong was divided into nine counties. Qin met with the King of Chu in Wan and with the King of Zhao in Zhongyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 89.1. In the fourteenth year, King Qingxiang of Chu met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Wan and established a marriage alliance. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 88. In the seventeenth year, Yue Yi led the Zhao army to attack Wei Boyang. Qin, resentful that Zhao had not joined them in attacking Qi, attacked Zhao and captured two of our cities. In the eighteenth year, Qin captured our Shicheng. King Zhao returned to Weidongyang, diverted the Yellow River, and attacked the Wei clan. A great flood occurred, and the Zhang River overflowed. Wei Ran came to serve as prime minister of Zhao. In the nineteenth year, Qin (defeated) [captured] two of our cities. Zhao gave Wei Boyang. Zhao She led an army to attack Qi's Maiqiu and captured it.
[284 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.11 (yr 23; states attack Qi). In the twenty-third year, Wei Sili, along with the three Jin states and Yan, attacked Qi, defeating it west of the Ji River. The King met with the King of Wei in Yiyang and with the King of Han in Xincheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 23.4. The king then ordered Zhang Zi to lead the troops of the five capitals, along with the troops from the northern regions, to attack Yan. The soldiers did not fight, the city gates were not closed, King Kuai of Yan died, and Qi won a great victory. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 89.2. In the fifteenth year, the King of Chu, together with Qin, the three Jin states, and Yan, attacked Qi and captured Huaibei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 29.5. In the third year of King Li's reign, he sent Gongsun Xi to lead Zhou and Wei to attack Qin. Qin defeated 240,000 of our troops and captured Xi at Yique. In the fifth year, Qin captured Wan. In the sixth year, he ceded 200 li of land to Qin at Wusui. In the tenth year, Qin defeated our army at Xiashan. In the twelfth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Western Zhou and assisted Qin in attacking Qi. Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. In the fourteenth year, he met with Qin at Zhou Xian. In the twenty-first year, he sent Bao Juan to rescue Wei, but he was defeated by Qin and Juan fled to Kaifeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 45. In the thirty-sixth year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin became the Eastern Emperor, and King Zhaoxiang of Qin became the Western Emperor. Su Dai came from Yan and entered Qi, where he was received at the east gate of Zhanghua. King Qi said, "Ah, good, you've come! Qin sent Wei Ran to present the emperor. What do you think of this?" Su Dai replied, "Your Majesty's question to me came at the time of my death, and the source of the trouble is still faint. I hope Your Majesty will accept it but not mention it fully. If Qin mentions it, the world will be at peace. If Your Majesty then mentions it, there will be no heir. Moreover, there is no harm in relinquishing the title of emperor. If Qin mentions it, the world will hate it. If Your Majesty does not mention it, you will win over the world. This is a great advantage. Furthermore, with two emperors in the world, will Your Majesty respect Qi or Qin?" King Qi said, "I respect Qin." Su Dai asked, "If you release the emperor, will the world love Qi or Qin?" King Qi said, "They will love Qi and hate Qin." Su Dai asked, "If the two emperors make a pact to attack Zhao, which is more beneficial, attacking Jie Song?" King Qi said, "Attacking Jie Song is more beneficial." Su Dai replied: "If Qi were to become emperor alongside Qin, the world would respect Qin and despise Qi. If Qi were to relinquish its emperor status, the world would love Qi and hate Qin. Attacking Zhao would be less advantageous than attacking Jie Song. Therefore, I urge Your Majesty to relinquish the emperor to win over the world, break the alliance with Qin, and avoid further conflict. Your Majesty can then use this opportunity to attack Song. With Song, the southern border of Wei is in danger; with the west of the Ji River, the eastern border of Zhao is in danger; with the north of the Huai River, the eastern border of Chu is in danger; with Tao and Pinglu, the gates of Liang will remain closed. Relinquishing the emperor and granting him the opportunity to attack Jie Song will enhance the nation's prestige and its reputation. Yan and Chu will submit, and the world will dare not disobey. This is the way of Tang and Wu. Respecting Qin is for the sake of prestige, and then the world will hate it. This is what is meant by using humility to achieve superiority. I urge Your Majesty to consider this carefully." Thereupon, Qi relinquished its emperor status and became a kingdom, and Qin also relinquished its imperial position.
[283 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.12 (yr 24; Wei’s Ancheng; Daliang). In the twenty-fourth year, Qin met with the King of Chu in Yan and then in Rang. Qin captured Wei's Ancheng, reaching Daliang, but Yan and Zhao came to its aid, and the Qin army withdrew. Wei Ran was dismissed as prime minister. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 23.5. Two years after the death of Yanzi, the people of Yan jointly established Prince Ping as their crown prince, who became King Zhao of Yan. 24. After King Zhao of Yan conquered Yan, he ascended the throne and humbly offered generous gifts to attract talented individuals. He said to Guo Wei, "Qi attacked and destroyed Yan because of the chaos in my country. I know very well that Yan is small and weak, and cannot retaliate. However, it is my wish to find virtuous men to govern the country together and to avenge the shame of my late king. If you see someone suitable, please serve him." Guo Wei replied, "If Your Majesty truly wishes to attract talented people, you should start with me. Moreover, those more virtuous than me are not far away!" Thereupon, King Zhao rebuilt a palace for Guo Wei and treated him as his teacher. Yue Yi came from Wei, Zou Yan from Qi, and Ju Xin from Zhao; scholars flocked to Yan. King Kuai of Yan died to inquire after the king's fate and shared the joys and sorrows of the people. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 89.3. In the sixteenth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Yan. That autumn, he met again with the King of Qin at Rang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 46. In the thirty-eighth year, Qin attacked Song. King Zhaoxiang of Qin angrily said, "I love Song as much as I love Xincheng and Yangjin. Han Nie is my friend, yet he attacks what I love. Why?" Su Dai, on behalf of Qi, said to the King of Qin, "Han Nie's attack on Song is for the sake of Your Majesty. Qi is strong, and with Song as its ally, Chu and Wei will surely be afraid. Fearing this, they will surely turn west to Qin. Thus, Your Majesty can cede Anyi without expending a single soldier or losing a single warrior. This is what Han Nie prayed to Your Majesty." The King of Qin said, "I am troubled by the difficulty in understanding Qi. One side follows the other; what is the reason for this?" Su Dai replied, "Can the states of the world know Qi's will? Qi is attacking Song." "They knew that serving Qin would allow them to rely on the power of a state with ten thousand chariots, and that if they did not serve Qin in the west, Song would be insecure. All the old, wandering scholars of China, with their accumulated wisdom, wished to break away from the alliance between Qi and Qin. Among those who fled west, not one spoke of benevolence towards Qi; among those who fled east, not one spoke of benevolence towards Qin. Why? Because none of them desired an alliance between Qi and Qin. How could Jin and Chu be wise while Qi and Qin were foolish! If Jin and Chu unite, they will surely discuss Qi and Qin; if Qi and Qin unite, they will surely plot against Jin and Chu. Let this be the basis for our decision." The King of Qin said, "Yes." Thus, Qi attacked Song, and the King of Song fled, dying in Wen. Qi then seized the land north of the Huai River from Chu, and invaded the three Jin states in the west, intending to annex the Zhou dynasty and become the Son of Heaven. The rulers of Zou and Lu, the lords of the Si River region, all submitted to Qi, and the other lords were terrified. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 1. Lian Po was a virtuous general of Zhao. In the sixteenth year of King Huiwen of Zhao, Lian Po led Zhao to attack Qi, achieving a great victory, capturing Yangjin, and was appointed as a high minister, becoming renowned among the feudal lords for his courage. Lin Xiangru was a native of Zhao, serving as a retainer of Miao Xian, the eunuch in charge of Zhao's court. 2. During the reign of King Huiwen of Zhao, the Zhao king acquired the He Shi Bi jade from Chu. King Zhaoxiang of Qin, upon hearing this, sent a letter to the King of Zhao, offering fifteen cities in exchange for the jade. The King of Zhao consulted with his general Lian Po and other ministers: if they gave it to Qin, they feared they would not receive the cities and would only be deceived; if they did not give it, they feared Qin's army would attack. Unable to decide, they sought someone to relay the message to Qin, but found none. The eunuch official Miao Xian said, "My retainer Lin Xiangru can be sent." The king asked, "How do you know?" Miao Xian replied, "I once committed a crime and secretly planned to flee to Yan. My retainer Lin Xiangru stopped me, saying, 'How do you know the King of Yan?' I told him, 'I once accompanied Your Majesty to a meeting with the King of Yan at the border. The King of Yan privately grasped my hand and said, "I wish to be friends." I know this, and therefore wish to go.' Lin Xiangru said to him, 'Zhao is strong while Yan is weak, and Your Majesty is favored by the King of Zhao; therefore, the King of Yan wishes to befriend you.'" "Now you have fled from Zhao to Yan. Yan fears Zhao and will certainly not dare to detain you, but will bind you and return you to Zhao. You would be better off baring your chest and kneeling before the executioner's axe to plead guilty, then you may be spared." I followed his advice, and Your Majesty also pardoned me. I secretly believe that he is a brave and resourceful man, and should be employed." So the king summoned him and asked Lin Xiangru, "The King of Qin is offering fifteen cities in exchange for my jade disc. Should we grant it?" Xiangru replied, "Qin is strong and Zhao is weak; we cannot refuse." The king said, "What if they take my jade disc but not my cities?" Xiangru said, "If Qin demands the jade disc in exchange for Zhao's cities, the fault lies with Zhao. If Zhao gives the jade disc but Qin does not give Zhao the cities, the fault lies with Qin. Between these two options, it is better to agree and incur Qin's fault." The king asked, "Who can be sent as an envoy?" Xiangru said, "If Your Majesty has no one else, I am willing to take the jade disc as an envoy. If the cities are given to Zhao, the jade disc will remain in Qin; if the cities are not given, I will return the jade disc to Zhao intact." The King of Zhao then sent Xiangru westward to Qin with the jade disc. 3. King Qin met Sima Xiangru at the Zhangtai Terrace. Sima Xiangru presented the jade disc to King Qin. King Qin was overjoyed and passed it around to show his concubines and attendants, who all shouted "Long live the King!" Seeing that the King of Qin had no intention of returning the cities to Zhao, Sima Xiangru stepped forward and said, "The jade disc has a flaw; please point it out to Your Majesty." The King handed over the disc, but Sima Xiangru, holding it, stood back against a pillar, his hair standing on end in anger, and said to the King of Qin, "Your Majesty desired the jade disc and sent a letter to the King of Zhao. The King of Zhao summoned all his ministers to discuss the matter, and they all said, 'Qin is greedy and relies on its strength. They are asking for the jade disc with empty words; returning the cities is unlikely.' They decided against giving the jade disc to Qin. I believe that even commoners do not deceive each other, let alone great states! Moreover, it is unacceptable to offend the powerful Qin for the sake of a single jade disc. Therefore, the King of Zhao fasted for five days and sent me with the jade disc and a letter, bowing respectfully in the court. Why? To uphold the dignity of a great state and show respect. Now that I have arrived, Your Majesty greeted me with great arrogance; having obtained the jade disc, you passed it to a beautiful woman to mock me. I see that Your Majesty has no intention of returning the cities to the King of Zhao, so I have taken the jade disc again. If Your Majesty insists on pressuring me, my head and the jade disc will be smashed against this pillar!" Sima Xiangru held the jade disc, glaring at the pillar, as if to strike it. Fearing that Zhao would break the jade disc, the King of Qin declined the offer but insisted on giving it to Zhao. He summoned his officials to examine the map and pointed out fifteen cities to be given to Zhao from that direction onward. Sima Xiangru realized that the King of Qin was only pretending to give the cities to Zhao, and that it was impossible to obtain them in reality. So he said to the King of Qin, "The He Shi Bi jade disc is a treasure known throughout the world. The King of Zhao was afraid and dared not refuse to present it. When the King of Zhao sent the jade disc, he fasted for five days. Now Your Majesty should also fast for five days and hold a grand banquet in the court before I dare to present the jade disc." The King of Qin considered this and realized that he could not forcibly take it from Zhao. He agreed to fast for five days and lodged Sima Xiangru at Guangcheng Pass. Sima Xiangru knew that although the King of Qin fasted, he would definitely break his promise and not give the cities. So he had his follower dress in coarse clothes, carry the jade disc, and escape through a side road, returning the jade disc to Zhao. 4. After fasting for five days, the King of Qin held a grand ceremony for the nine guests in the court and summoned Lin Xiangru, the envoy from Zhao. Upon arrival, Xiangru said to the King of Qin, “Since Duke Mu of Qin, more than twenty rulers have come before, and none have ever upheld their promises. I was truly afraid of being deceived by Your Majesty and betraying Zhao, so I sent someone to return the jade disc to Zhao. Moreover, Qin is strong and Zhao is weak. Your Majesty sent a single envoy to Zhao, and Zhao immediately presented the jade disc. Now, with Qin's strength, if you first cede fifteen cities to Zhao, how dare Zhao retain the jade disc and offend Your Majesty? I know that the crime of deceiving Your Majesty deserves death. I beg to face the boiling cauldron. I only ask Your Majesty and your ministers to discuss this matter.” The King of Qin and his ministers looked at each other and laughed. Some of his attendants wanted to take Xiangru away, but the King of Qin said, “If we kill Xiangru now, we will ultimately not obtain the jade disc, and we will sever the friendship between Qin and Zhao. It would be better to treat him generously and send him back to Zhao. Would the King of Zhao deceive Qin for the sake of a single jade disc?” He then received Xiangru in court, completed the formalities, and sent him away. 5. After Xiangru returned, the King of Zhao considered him a virtuous minister who had not brought shame upon the other states, and appointed him as a high-ranking official. Qin did not give the city to Zhao, and Zhao ultimately did not give Qin the jade disc. 6.1. Afterwards, Qin attacked Zhao and captured Shicheng.
[282 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.13 (yr 25). In the twenty-fifth year, Qin captured two cities of Zhao. Qin met with the King of Han in Xincheng and with the King of Wei in Xinmingyi. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 29.6. In the third year of King Li's reign, he sent Gongsun Xi to lead Zhou and Wei to attack Qin. Qin defeated 240,000 of our troops and captured Xi at Yique. In the fifth year, Qin captured Wan. In the sixth year, he ceded 200 li of land to Qin at Wusui. In the tenth year, Qin defeated our army at Xiashan. In the twelfth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Western Zhou and assisted Qin in attacking Qi. Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. In the fourteenth year, he met with Qin at Zhou Xian. In the twenty-first year, he sent Bao Juan to rescue Wei, but he was defeated by Qin and Juan fled to Kaifeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 47. In the thirty-ninth year, Qin came to attack and captured nine of my cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 6.2. The following year, Qin attacked Zhao again and killed 20,000 people.
[281 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 76. In the thirty-fourth year, Su Li said to the ruler of Zhou, "Qin's defeat of Han and Wei, its capture of Shi Wu, and its northern conquest of Zhao Lin and Lishi were all due to Bai Qi. He is skilled in warfare and also has the mandate of Heaven. Now he is leading troops out of the border to attack Liang. If Liang falls, Zhou will be in danger. Why don't you send someone to persuade Bai Qi?" Su Li replied, "In Chu there is a man named Yang Youji, who is a skilled archer. He can shoot a willow leaf from a hundred paces away and hit it every time. Thousands of people watch and all say he is a good archer. One man stands beside him and says, 'Good, you can be taught to shoot.' Yang Youji gets angry, puts down his bow and grips his sword, and says, 'How can you teach me to shoot?' The man says, 'It is not that I can teach you to support your left and right. To shoot a willow leaf from a hundred paces away and hit it every time, without proper rest, will soon become weak and tired. If you pull the bow and arrow hook, and miss the first shot, all your shots will be wasted.' Now, the defeat of Han and Wei, the capture of Shi Wu, and the northern conquest of Zhao Lin and Lishi are all thanks to your great achievements." Now you are leading troops out of the border again. After two weeks, you will betray Han and attack Liang, but you will fail in one fell swoop, and all your previous efforts will be in vain. You would be better off feigning illness and not going out.” [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.14 (yr 26). In the twenty-sixth year, Qin pardoned criminals and relocated them to Rang. Hou Ran was reinstated as prime minister. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 90 (discursive). In the eighteenth year, a man from Chu had a fondness for shooting wild geese with a weak bow and a small noose. King Qingxiang heard of this and summoned him to inquire. The man replied, "My hobby of shooting wild geese and snipes is merely the use of small arrows; how can it be worthy of Your Majesty's praise? Moreover, Chu is great, and Your Majesty is wise; what you shoot is not merely these. In the past, the Three Kings used archery to capture those of virtue, and the Five Hegemons used archery to capture those of the Warring States. Thus, Qin, Wei, Yan, and Zhao are like wild geese; Qi, Lu, Han, and Wei are like blue-headed birds; Zou, Fei, Tan, and Pi are like snipes. Others are not worth shooting. You see six pairs of birds; what will Your Majesty take? Why doesn't Your Majesty use a sage as a bow and a brave warrior as a noose, and shoot them at the right time? These six pairs can be easily captured and carried away." Its joy is not merely the pleasure of the morning and evening, nor is its gain merely the bounty of wild geese and ducks. If the king were to draw his bow and shoot south of Wei's Daliang, thus severing its right arm and directly subjugating it to Han, then the route to China would be cut off and the Shangcai prefecture would be destroyed. If he were to shoot east of Yu, thus severing Wei's left elbow and attacking Dingtao from the outside, then Wei's eastern borders would be abandoned and the two prefectures of Da Song and Fangyu would be taken. Moreover, with Wei's two arms severed, it would be overthrown; if it were to attack Tan, Daliang could be obtained. King Wang Qing captured Lantai, watered his horses at the West River, and secured Daliang for Wei—this is the joy of a single action. If the king truly loves hunting and never tires of it, then he should produce a precious bow and reforge it. We will capture the pheasant in the East Sea, and build the Great Wall as a defense. We will shoot at Dongju in the morning, set out from Peiqiu in the evening, and reach Jimo at night. Looking back at the Wu Road, the eastern part of the Great Wall will be secured, and the northern part of Mount Tai will be raised. We will establish a western border with Zhao and extend north to Yan. With the three kingdoms spreading their influence, the alliance will be formed without any prior agreement. We will travel north to Liaodong in Yan and south to Kuaiji in Yue; this is the joy of a second campaign. As for the twelve vassal states along the Si River, they can be easily subdued in a single day. Now, Qin's defeat of Han is a long-term worry; it has gained many cities but dares not defend them. Its attack on Wei has been fruitless, and its attack on Zhao is hampered by its own weakness. The might and strength of Qin and Wei are exhausted; the former territories of Chu—Hanzhong, Xi, and Li—can be regained. Your Majesty should take out your precious bow and newly acquired arrows, cross the Meng Pass, and await Qin's weariness. The lands east of the mountains and the Yellow River region can then be unified. The people will be weary and the masses will rest; then you can face south and proclaim yourself king. Therefore, it is said that Qin is a great bird, dwelling on the seas, standing facing east, its left arm holding the southwest of Zhao, its right arm supporting Chu's Yan and Ying, its chest striking Han and Wei, its head bowed in the center. Its position is advantageous, its power and terrain favorable; if it spreads its wings and soars like a crane, covering three thousand li, then Qin cannot easily provoke it to attack at night.” This was said to provoke King Xiang. King Xiang then summoned Chu and spoke with him, saying, "The late King was deceived by Qin and died abroad; there is no greater resentment than this. Even a commoner with a grudge can avenge himself before a king, as exemplified by Bai Gong and Wu Zixu. Now, Chu has a territory of five thousand li and a million armored soldiers, enough to roam freely across the plains. Yet, to sit idly by and suffer humiliation is something Your Majesty should not do." Thereupon, King Xiang sent envoys to the other feudal lords, renewing their alliance, intending to attack Qin. Upon hearing this, Qin dispatched troops to attack Chu. 91 (discursive). Chu wanted to ally with Qi and Han to attack Qin, and thus intended to plot against Zhou.
