King Nan of Zhou sent Duke Wu to say to Zhao Zi, the prime minister of Chu, "The three states use their armies to carve up Zhou's suburbs for easy transport, and use southern weapons to elevate Chu. I think this is wrong. If a ruler is murdered and a minister usurps the throne, the powerful states will not be friendly; if the many threaten the few, the small states will not submit. If the powerful states are not friendly and the small states are not submitting, then we cannot achieve anything. Without achieving anything, we cannot harm the people. The rhetoric of plotting against Zhou is not a valid justification." Zhao Zi said, "If you want to plot against Zhou, then you cannot. But why can't Zhou be attacked?" He replied, "An army should not attack unless it is five times strong, and a city should not be besieged unless it is ten times strong. You know that Zhou is divided into twenty Jin states. Han once humiliated Jin with two hundred thousand troops. The elite soldiers died and the middle soldiers were wounded, but Jin did not fall. You know that you did not use a hundred Han states to plot against Zhou. To enmity with Zhou and Han to suppress the ambitions of Zou and Lu, and to sever ties with Qi, will cause you to lose face throughout the world. This is a dangerous situation. If you weaken Zhou and Han to strengthen the Three Rivers region, then the area outside Fangcheng will surely be weakened by Han." "Alas. How do we know this is so? The land of Western Zhou, even with its strengths and weaknesses, is no more than a hundred li. Though nominally the ruler of all under heaven, dividing its territory is insufficient to enrich the state, and gaining its people is insufficient to strengthen its army. Even without attacking, it is considered regicide. Yet, rulers who love to indulge in war, and ministers who delight in attack, when issuing orders to wage war, never fail to consider Zhou as their ultimate goal. Why is this? Seeing the sacrificial vessels there, they desire the arrival of the vessels and forget the chaos of regicide. Now, Han has the vessels in Chu; I fear the world will use the vessels to enmity against Chu. Let me use an analogy. Tiger meat is gamey, and its weapons are sharp, yet people still attack it. But if a deer in a swamp were to wear a tiger's skin, people would attack it ten thousand times more fiercely than the tiger. Dividing Chu's land is enough to enrich the state; defeating Chu's reputation is enough to honor the ruler. Now you intend to kill and destroy the ruler of all under heaven, seize the vessels passed down through three dynasties, swallow three wings and six wings, to elevate the ruler of the world—what is this if not greed? The Book of Zhou says, ' To rise up, one must have a prelude ,' therefore, when the vessels are in the south, the army will arrive." Thus, Chu's plan was abandoned.
[280 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 72. Qin intended to use the passage between Zhou and Han to attack Han. Zhou feared that if it granted permission, it would be afraid of Han; if it refused, it would be afraid of Qin. Shi Yan advised the ruler of Zhou, "Why not send someone to tell Gongshu of Han, 'Qin dares to sever ties with Zhou and attack Han because it trusts Eastern Zhou? Why don't you give Zhou land and send a hostage to Chu?' Qin will surely suspect Chu of not trusting Zhou, and Han will not attack. Also, tell Qin, 'Han is forcibly giving Zhou land to make Zhou suspicious of Qin, and Zhou dares not refuse.' Qin will then have no excuse to force Zhou to refuse, thus giving land to Han and submitting to Qin." [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.15 (yr 27). In the twenty-seventh year, Qin mistakenly attacked Chu. Qin pardoned criminals and relocated them to Nanyang. Bai Qi attacked Zhao, replacing Guanglang City. Qin also sent Sima Cuo from Longxi, using Shu as a springboard to attack Chu's Qianzhong, which was captured. [Sima Qian, Shiji 33 — Lu Zhougong Shijia] 82. From the Duke of Zhou to the Duke of Qing, there were thirty-four generations in Lu. 83 (authorial). The Grand Historian Sima Qian said: I have heard Confucius say, "How greatly the way of Lu has declined! The banks of the Zhu and Si rivers are now filled with quarrels." Looking at the time of Qingfu, Shuya, and Duke Min, how chaotic it was! The events surrounding Duke Huan; Xiangzhong killing the legitimate heir and installing a concubine; the three families bowing to the north as subjects, personally attacking Duke Zhao, who fled. They followed the proper etiquette of yielding and abdication, yet how perverse their actions were! 82. From the Duke of Zhou to the Duke of Qing, there were thirty-four generations in Lu. 83 (authorial). The Grand Historian Sima Qian said: I have heard Confucius say, "How greatly the way of Lu has declined! The banks of the Zhu and Si rivers are now filled with quarrels." Looking at the time of Qingfu, Shuya, and Duke Min, how chaotic it was! The events surrounding Duke Huan; Xiangzhong killing the legitimate heir and installing a concubine; the three families bowing to the north as subjects, personally attacking Duke Zhao, who fled. They followed the proper etiquette of yielding and abdication, yet how perverse their actions were! [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 92.1. In the nineteenth year, Qin attacked Chu, and the Chu army was defeated, ceding Shangyong and the northern lands of Hanbei to Qin.
[279 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.16 (yr 28; Yan/Deng). In the twenty-eighth year, Grand General Bai Qi attacked Chu, capturing Yan and Deng, and pardoning criminals to relocate there. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 25.1. In the twenty-eighth year, the State of Yan was wealthy, and its soldiers were eager for battle and reckless. Therefore, Yan appointed Yue Yi as its supreme commander and conspired with Qin, Chu, and the three Jin states to attack Qi. The Qi army was defeated, and King Min fled into exile. 25.2. The Yan army pursued the fleeing enemy, reaching Linzi, seizing all of Qi's treasures, and burning its palaces and ancestral temples. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 92.2. In the twentieth year, Qin general Bai Qi captured Xiling. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.7. Seven years later, Bai Qi attacked Chu and captured five cities, including Yan and Deng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 7. The King of Qin sent an envoy to the King of Zhao, requesting a friendly meeting at Mianchi, west of the Yellow River. The King of Zhao, fearing Qin, hesitated to go. Lian Po and Lin Xiangru advised, "If Your Majesty does not go, it will show Zhao's weakness and cowardice." The King of Zhao then went, with Lin Xiangru accompanying him. Lian Po escorted him to the border and bid farewell to the King, saying, "Your Majesty, after completing the formalities of the meeting, return within thirty days. If you do not return within thirty days, we request that the Crown Prince be established as King, to thwart Qin's ambitions." The King agreed and met with the King of Qin at Mianchi. The King of Qin, in high spirits after drinking, said, "I have heard that the King of Zhao is fond of music; please play the zither." The King of Zhao played the zither. The Qin scribe recorded, "On such and such a day, the King of Qin and the King of Zhao met and drank; the King of Qin ordered the King of Zhao to play the zither." Lin Xiangru stepped forward and said, "The King of Zhao has heard that the King of Qin is skilled in Qin music; please play the zither for the King of Qin's entertainment." The King of Qin was angry and refused. Lin Xiangru then stepped forward with the zither and knelt to plead with the King of Qin. The King of Qin refused to strike the zither. Lin Xiangru said, "Within five paces, I, Lin Xiangru, will splatter Your Majesty with my blood!" His attendants tried to kill him, but Lin Xiangru glared and shouted, and they all retreated. The King of Qin was displeased and struck a wine pot. Lin Xiangru then summoned the Zhao historian to write, "On such and such a day, the King of Qin struck a wine pot for the King of Zhao." The Qin ministers said, "We request to offer fifteen cities of Zhao as a birthday gift to the King of Qin." Lin Xiangru also said, "We request to offer Xianyang, the capital of Qin, as a birthday gift to the King of Zhao." The King of Qin finished his wine, but ultimately could not gain the upper hand over Zhao. Zhao also heavily fortified its army to await Qin, but Qin dared not move. 8. After returning to Zhao, Lin Xiangru was appointed as a high-ranking minister due to his great contributions, ranking above Lian Po. Lian Po said, "I am a general of Zhao, with great merit in attacking cities and fighting in the field, while Lin Xiangru has only achieved his merit through words, yet he ranks above me. Moreover, Xiangru is of lowly birth; I am ashamed and cannot bear to be below him." He declared, "If I see Xiangru, I will surely humiliate him." Upon hearing this, Xiangru refused to attend meetings. Every time Xiangru went to court, he would feign illness, not wanting to contend with Lian Po for rank. Later, when Xiangru went out and saw Lian Po, he turned his carriage away and hid. Then his retainers remonstrated, saying, "The reason we left our relatives to serve you, my lord, was solely because we admire your noble character. Now you are ranked alongside Lian Po, yet when Lian Po utters harsh words, you cower in fear. Even a commoner would be ashamed of such behavior, let alone a general! We are unworthy, and we beg to resign." Lin Xiangru firmly stopped them, saying, "In your opinion, how does General Lian compare to the King of Qin?" They replied, "He is not as good." Xiangru said, "Even with the King of Qin's might, I dared to rebuke him in court and humiliate his ministers. Though I am incompetent, do I alone fear General Lian? I think that the reason the powerful Qin dares not attack Zhao is solely because of the two of us. If two tigers fight, they cannot both survive. My reason for doing this is to prioritize the nation's urgent needs over personal grudges." When Lian Po heard this, he bared his chest, carried a bundle of thorns, and went to Lin Xiangru's door through his guests to apologize. He said, "I am a lowly person, unaware of the general's great magnanimity." In the end, they became close friends, even willing to die for each other.
[278 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.17 (yr 29; Ying taken; Nanjun). In the twenty-ninth year, Grand General Bai Qi attacked Chu again, capturing Ying and establishing it as Nanjun, causing the King of Chu to flee. The King of Zhou arrived. The King met with the King of Chu at Xiangling. Bai Qi was appointed Lord Wu'an. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 92.3. In the twenty-first year, Qin general Bai Qi then captured Ying and burned the tomb of the former king at Yiling. King Xiang of Chu's army dispersed and ceased fighting, retreating northeast to Chencheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 48. Forty years later, Yan, Qin, Chu, and the three Jin states conspired, each sending elite troops to attack and defeat Qi west of the Ji River. King Min withdrew. Yan general Yue Yi then entered Linzi and seized all of Qi's treasures and artifacts. King Min fled to Wei. The ruler of Wei opened a palace for him, acknowledging him as a vassal and sharing his possessions. King Min was disrespectful, and the people of Wei invaded his territory. King Min fled to Zou and Lu, displaying arrogance. The rulers of Zou and Lu refused to receive him, so he fled to Ju. Chu sent Nao Chi with troops to rescue Qi, and he became King Min's prime minister. Nao Chi then killed King Min and shared the stolen land and artifacts with Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.8. The following year, he attacked Chu again, capturing Ying, burning Yiling, and then advancing east to Jingling. 1.9. The King of Chu fled Ying, moving east to Chen. Qin established Nanjun as part of Qin. Bai Qi was then promoted to Lord Wu'an. Lord Wu'an conquered Chu and pacified the Wu and Qianzhong commanderies.
[277 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.18 (yr 30; Qianzhongjun). In the thirtieth year, Shu Governor Ruo attacked Chu, capturing Wujun and establishing Qianzhongjun in Jiangnan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 92.4. In the twenty-second year, Qin again captured Wu and Qianzhong commanderies. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 49. After King Min was assassinated, his son Fa Zhang changed his name to Jia Yong, the Grand Historian of Ju. Grand Historian Jiao's daughter, finding Fa Zhang's appearance extraordinary, took pity on him and secretly provided him with food and clothing, and they had an affair. After Nao Chi left Ju, the people of Ju and the exiled officials of Qi gathered to seek out Prince Min, wanting to install him as king. Fa Zhang, fearing execution, waited a long time before daring to declare, "I am Prince Min." Thereupon, the people of Ju jointly established Fa Zhang, who became King Xiang. They protected the city of Ju and proclaimed throughout Qi: "The King has been established in Ju." [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 1.1. Lord Wuji of Wei was the youngest son of Prince Zhao of Wei and the half-brother of King Anli of Wei. After King Zhao's death, King Anli ascended the throne and enfeoffed the prince as Lord Xinling.
[276 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.19 (yr 31). In the thirty-first year, Bai Qi attacked Wei, capturing two cities. The Chu people rebelled against Jiangnan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 93.1. In the twenty-third year, King Xiang gathered troops from the eastern regions, acquiring over 100,000 men. He then reclaimed fifteen towns along the Yangtze River that Qin had seized from him, establishing them as prefectures to defend against Qin.
[275 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 73. Qin summoned the ruler of Western Zhou, but the ruler of Western Zhou disliked going. Therefore, he sent someone to tell the King of Han, "Qin has summoned the ruler of Western Zhou to attack Your Majesty's Nanyang. Why doesn't Your Majesty send troops to Nanyang? The ruler of Zhou will use this as an excuse to Qin. If the ruler of Zhou does not go to Qin, Qin will certainly not dare to cross the river and attack Nanyang." [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.20 (yr 32; Rang Hou vs Wei). In the thirty-second year, Chancellor Rang Hou attacked Wei, reaching Daliang, defeating Bao Yuan, beheading 40,000, and Yuan fled. Wei ceded three counties to sue for peace. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 29.7. In the third year of King Li's reign, he sent Gongsun Xi to lead Zhou and Wei to attack Qin. Qin defeated 240,000 of our troops and captured Xi at Yique. In the fifth year, Qin captured Wan. In the sixth year, he ceded 200 li of land to Qin at Wusui. In the tenth year, Qin defeated our army at Xiashan. In the twelfth year, he met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Western Zhou and assisted Qin in attacking Qi. Qi was defeated, and King Min fled. In the fourteenth year, he met with Qin at Zhou Xian. In the twenty-first year, he sent Bao Juan to rescue Wei, but he was defeated by Qin and Juan fled to Kaifeng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 50. After King Xiang ascended the throne, he made the daughter of the Grand Historian his queen, who became Queen Jun. She bore him a son, Jian. The Grand Historian Jiao said, "This woman married without a matchmaker; she is not of my lineage and has disgraced my family." He never saw Queen Jun again for the rest of his life. Queen Jun was virtuous and did not lose the proper conduct of a son because she did not see him.
[274 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.21 (yr 33; Huayang etc). In the thirty-third year, Guest Minister Hu (Shang) [Yang] attacked and captured Juan, Caiyang, and Changshe in Wei. He attacked Mangmao Huayang, defeating it and beheading 150,000. Wei ceded Nanyang to sue for peace. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 51. In the fifth year of King Xiang's reign in Ju, Tian Dan defeated the Yan army at Jimo, welcomed King Xiang back to Ju, and then entered Linzi. All the former Qi territories were restored to Qi. Qi then enfeoffed Tian Dan as Lord Anping.
[273 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 77. In the forty-second year, Qin broke the Huayang Treaty. Ma Fan said to the King of Zhou, "Please order Liang to fortify Zhou." He then said to the King of Liang, "If the King of Zhou dies, then I will surely die. I will offer the Nine Tripods to Your Majesty, and Your Majesty will accept the Nine Tripods and plot against me." The King of Liang said, "Good." So he sent soldiers with him, saying he would garrison Zhou. Then he said to the King of Qin, "Liang is not garrisoning Zhou, but intending to attack Zhou. Your Majesty should send troops to the border to observe." Qin indeed sent troops. He then said to the King of Liang, "The King of Zhou is very ill. I have requested to return later. Now Your Majesty has sent soldiers to Zhou, and the other feudal lords are all suspicious. If we act later, they will not believe us. It would be better to have the soldiers fortify Zhou to conceal any trouble." The King of Liang said, "Good." So he ordered the fortification of Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.22 (yr 34; Shangyong commandery). In the thirty-fourth year, Qin, Wei, and Han merged Shangyong into one commandery, and Nanyang's dismissed officials relocated there. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 25.3. Of the Qi cities that did not fall, only Liao, Ju, and Jimo remained; the rest all fell to Yan in six years. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 30. Han Shijia: In the twenty-third year, Zhao and Wei attacked Huayang. Han appealed to Qin for help, but Qin refused to come to its aid. The Chancellor of Han said to Chen Shi, "The situation is urgent. I hope you, sir, though ill, will travel for one night." Chen Shi met with Marquis Rang. Marquis Rang said, "Is the situation urgent? That is why I sent you." Chen Shi replied, "It is not urgent." Marquis Rang angrily said, "Is this the kind of person who can act as your envoy? People from all directions have come to inform our state of a great urgency, yet you come saying it is not urgent. Why is that?" Chen Shi said, "If Han were in dire need, they would change their allegiance and follow others. Because it is not urgent, I have come again." Marquis Rang said, "You do not need to see the king. Please send troops to rescue Han now." They arrived in eight days and defeated Zhao and Wei at the foot of Huayang. That year, King Li died, and his son, King Huanhui, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.1. In the 34th year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked Wei, captured Huayang, fled Mangmao, and captured generals of the Three Jin states, beheading 130,000. He fought against Zhao general Jia Yan, drowning 20,000 of his soldiers in the river. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 1.3. Because of his resentment towards Qi of Wei, Qin troops besieged Daliang, defeated Wei's army at Huayang, and fled Mang Mao. King Wei and the prince were troubled by this.
[272 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.23 (yr 35; attack Yan). In the thirty-fifth year, he assisted Han, Wei, and Chu in attacking Yan. Nanyang Commandery was first established. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 26.1. In the seventh year of King Wucheng's reign, Tian Dan of Qi attacked us and captured Zhongyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 93.2. In the twenty-seventh year, he sent 30,000 men to assist the three Jin states in attacking Yan. He then made peace with Qin again, and sent his crown prince to Qin as a hostage. Chu sent the Left Minister to serve the crown prince in Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 31.1. In the first year of King Huanhui's reign, Qin attacked Yan. In the ninth year, Qin captured Xing and fortified the area near Fen. In the tenth year, Qin attacked us at Taihang, and the governor of Shangdang surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. In the fourteenth year, Qin captured Shangdang from Zhao, killing over 400,000 soldiers of Ma Fu at Changping. In the seventeenth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu. In the twenty-second year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin captured Chenggao and Xingyang. In the twenty-sixth year, Qin completely captured Shangdang. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin captured thirteen cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 1.2. At that time, Fan Sui fled Wei to Qin as prime minister.
[271 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 6. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... At that time, King Zhao had reigned for thirty-six years. He captured Yan and Ying from Chu in the south, and King Huai of Chu died in exile in Qin. Qin defeated Qi in the east. King Min once proclaimed himself emperor, but later relinquished it. He repeatedly besieged the three Jin states. He grew weary of all the debaters in the land and had no one to believe him. 7. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Marquis Rang, also known as Lord Huayang, was the younger brother of Queen Dowager Xuan, the mother of King Zhao. Lord Jingyang and Lord Gaoling were both younger brothers of King Zhao, sharing the same mother. Marquis Rang served as chancellor, and these three men took turns leading generals. They each had fiefdoms, and due to the Queen Dowager's influence, their private wealth surpassed that of the royal family. When Marquis Rang became a general of Qin, he intended to bypass Han and Wei to attack Gangshou of Qi, hoping to expand his fiefdom of Tao. Fan Sui then submitted a memorial stating: 8. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Your Majesty, I have heard that when a wise ruler establishes a government, those who have rendered meritorious service must be rewarded, and those who are capable must be appointed to official positions. Those who exert great effort receive generous stipends, those who achieve numerous merits receive high ranks, and those who can govern the masses hold high office. Therefore, the incompetent dare not assume office, and the capable cannot be concealed. If you find my words acceptable, I wish to implement them and further benefit your rule; if you find my words unacceptable, then keeping me here indefinitely is futile. As the saying goes, "A mediocre ruler rewards those he loves and punishes those he hates; a wise ruler is different. Rewards are always given to those who have rendered meritorious service, and punishments are always handed down to those who have committed crimes." Now, my mind is insufficient to withstand scrutiny, and my will is not strong enough to withstand the axe and halberd. How dare I test Your Majesty with doubtful matters! Even if you consider me a lowly person and treat me with contempt, are you not so sure that those who do not value me will not betray Your Majesty? 9. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Furthermore, I have heard that the Zhou dynasty possessed the whetstone, the Song dynasty the jadeite, the Liang dynasty the celery, and the Chu dynasty the uncarved block. These four treasures are born of the earth, yet were lost by skilled craftsmen, and thus became renowned artifacts throughout the land. Therefore, are those discarded by sage kings simply insufficient to enrich the state? 10. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Your Majesty, I have heard that those who are generous to their families take from the state, and those who are generous to the state take from the feudal lords. If there is an enlightened ruler, the feudal lords cannot monopolize such generosity. Why? Because they must relinquish their own glory. A good physician knows the life or death of a patient, and a wise ruler understands success and failure. He acts when it is beneficial, abandons when it is harmful, and tries things only when in doubt. Even if Shun and Yu were resurrected, they could not change this. I dare not record the most profound truths in books, nor are the shallow ones worth heeding. Perhaps I am foolish and do not conform to Your Majesty's heart? Or perhaps my words are too lowly to be of use? If not, I wish to be granted a little leisure to travel and observe, and to see Your Majesty's countenance. If my words are ineffective, I beg to submit to the executioner's blade. 11. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... King Zhaoxiang of Qin was greatly pleased and thanked Wang Ji, then sent a carriage to summon Fan Sui. 12. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Thus, Fan Sui was granted an audience at the detached palace, feigning ignorance of the inner palace and entering without permission. When the king arrived, the eunuchs, angered, chased him away, announcing, "The king has arrived!" Fan Sui then feigned ignorance, saying, "Where in Qin can Qin find a king? Qin only has the Queen Dowager and Marquis Rang." He intended to provoke King Zhao. When King Zhao arrived, he heard Fan Sui arguing with the eunuchs and immediately welcomed him, apologizing, "I have long been entitled to receive this mandate, but due to the urgent situation with Yiqu, I pleaded with the Queen Dowager day and night; now that the Yiqu matter is resolved, I am finally able to receive this mandate. I am ashamed of my incompetence and respectfully observe the courtesies of a guest." Fan Sui declined the offer. Those who witnessed Fan Sui's audience that day were all visibly shaken and their expressions changed. 13. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... The King of Qin dismissed his attendants, leaving the palace empty. The King of Qin knelt and asked, "Sir, what would you do to instruct me?" Fan Sui replied, "Yes, yes." After a while, the King of Qin knelt again and asked, "Sir, what would you do to instruct me?" Fan Sui replied, "Yes, yes." This happened three times. King Qin knelt and said, "Sir, is it unfortunate that you have instructed me?" Fan Sui replied, "I dare not say so. I have heard that when Lü Shang met King Wen, he was merely a fisherman fishing on the banks of the Wei River. At that time, their relationship was distant. Yet, after being persuaded, he was appointed Grand Tutor and taken home with him, for his words were profound. Therefore, King Wen thus gained merit from Lü Shang and eventually became the king of the world. If King Wen had distanced himself from Lü Shang and had not spoken deeply with him, then Zhou would have lacked the virtue of an emperor, and Kings Wen and Wu would have had no one to help him achieve his royal ambitions. Now, I am a minister in exile, with a distant relationship with Your Majesty, yet what I wish to present are all matters of correcting Your Majesty. I am merely a kinsman, wishing to offer my foolish loyalty, but I do not know Your Majesty's heart. This is why Your Majesty asked me three questions and I dared not answer. It is not that I am afraid to speak." I dare to speak out. I know that what I say today may lead to my execution tomorrow, yet I dare not shirk my duty. If Your Majesty heeds my words, death will not trouble me, exile will not worry me, and even disguising myself as a leper or going mad will not be a disgrace. Moreover, even the sages of the Five Emperors, the benevolent rulers of the Three Kings, the wise rulers of the Five Hegemons, the powerful Wu Huo and Ren Bi, and the bravery of Cheng Jing, Meng Ben, Wang Qingji, and Xia Yu all died. Death is inevitable for all men. If, given this inevitable situation, I can still contribute to Qin in some way, this is my greatest wish. What then should I fear? Wu Zixu, laden with provisions, left Zhaoguan, traveling by night and hiding by day, until he reached Lingshui, where he had nothing to eat. He prostrated himself, bowed deeply, bared his chest, played the flute, and begged for food in the Wu market. Yet, he eventually brought prosperity to the Wu state, and Helü became its hegemon. If I were to have the same wisdom as Wu Zixu, and instead imprison him, never to be seen again, then my words would be fulfilled. What more could I ask for? Ji Zi and Jie Yu painted their bodies black to appear lecherous and let their hair grow long to appear mad, offering no benefit to their ruler. If I could follow in Ji Zi's footsteps and serve a worthy ruler, it would be my greatest honor. What shame could I possibly have? My only fear is that after my death, the world, seeing my loyalty and sacrifice, would be silenced and unwilling to follow Qin. Your Majesty fears the Empress Dowager's severity above and is misled by the treacherous ministers below. Residing deep within the palace, never leaving the care of your protectors, you will ultimately... "I am confused and have no way to expose my wickedness. The greatest danger is the destruction of the ancestral temples, and the least is that I myself will be left alone and in danger. This is what I fear. As for poverty and humiliation, or the danger of death, I dare not fear. If I die and Qin is well-governed, then my death is better than my life." The King of Qin knelt and said, "What are you saying, sir! Qin is a remote and distant state, and I am foolish and unworthy. You have been fortunate enough to be here with me. It is Heaven's way of protecting the ancestral temples of the former king because I have offended you. I have received your mandate, which is Heaven's way of favoring the former king and not abandoning his orphan. How can you say such things, sir! No matter how small or large the matter, from the Queen Mother to the ministers, I wish you would teach me everything so that I have no doubts." Fan Sui bowed, and the King of Qin also bowed. 14. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Fan Sui said, “Your Majesty’s kingdom is fortified on all four sides. To the north are Ganquan and Gukou, to the south are the Jing and Wei rivers, to the right are Long and Shu, and to the left are Guan and Ban. It has a million soldiers and a thousand chariots. When the opportunity is favorable, it attacks; when the opportunity is unfavorable, it defends. This is the land of a king. The people are timid in private battles but brave in public wars. These are the people of a king. Your Majesty possesses both of these. With the bravery of Qin’s soldiers and the number of its chariots and cavalry, to govern the other states is like using Han Lu to catch a lame rabbit. The hegemony of Qin can be achieved, but none of your ministers are in the right position. To this day, the kingdom has been closed for fifteen years, and no one dares to spy on the east of the mountains. This is because Rang Hou’s plans for Qin have been disloyal, and Your Majesty’s plans have failed.” The King of Qin knelt and said, “I wish to hear about the failures in my plans.” [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 9.1. That year, Lian Po attacked Qi in the east and defeated one of its armies.
[270 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 74. When Eastern Zhou and Western Zhou were at war, Han came to the aid of Western Zhou. Someone advised the King of Han on behalf of Eastern Zhou, saying, "Western Zhou was once the land of the Son of Heaven, possessing many famous artifacts and treasures. If Your Majesty holds back your troops and does not send troops, you can win the favor of Eastern Zhou, and the treasures of Western Zhou will surely be exhausted." 78. In the forty-fifth year, a Qin retainer of the Zhou ruler said to Zhou Ju, "You should praise the King of Qin for his filial piety, and then offer to provide land for the Queen Dowager. The King of Qin will surely be pleased, and you will have an alliance with Qin. If the alliance is good, the Zhou ruler will surely reward you. If the alliance is bad, those who advised the Zhou ruler to enter Qin will surely be punished." Qin attacked Zhou, and Zhou Ju said to the King of Qin, "Those who plan for Your Majesty should not attack Zhou. Attacking Zhou will not bring any real benefit, but it will intimidate the world. If the world intimidates Qin with its reputation, it will surely unite with Qi in the east. Then, the army will be at war with Zhou. If the world unites with Qi, then Qin will no longer be a king. The world wants to humiliate Qin, so it advises Your Majesty to attack Zhou. If Qin unites with the world, then your orders will not be obeyed." [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.24 (yr 36; Zao attacks Qi). In the thirty-sixth year, the guest minister Zao attacked Qi, capturing Gang and Shou, and giving them to Marquis Rang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 2 (discursive; ~during his �retainers� prime). The prince was benevolent and treated scholars with humility and courtesy, regardless of their virtue or lack thereof. He never dared to be arrogant because of his wealth and status. As a result, scholars from thousands of miles around flocked to him, and he had three thousand retainers. At that time, the other feudal lords, because of the prince's virtue and the large number of his guests, dared not attack Wei for more than ten years. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 15. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... However, many people around him were eavesdropping, and Fan Sui was afraid, so he dared not speak of internal affairs, but first spoke of external matters, in order to observe the King of Qin's reaction. Yin Jin said, “The Marquis of Rang’s attack on Gangshou of Qi by bypassing Han and Wei is not a wise plan. A small force would not be enough to harm Qi, while a large force would harm Qin. I believe Your Majesty’s plan is to send a small force to take all the troops of Han and Wei, which is unjust. Now, seeing that the allies are not on good terms, is it acceptable to attack a country that borders another? This is a poor strategy. In the past, King Min of Qi attacked Chu from the south, defeating its army and killing its generals, expanding its territory by a thousand li, yet Qi gained not an inch of land. Did Qi not want to gain land? But the circumstances prevented it. When the other states saw Qi’s weakness and the discord between its ruler and ministers, they raised an army to attack Qi and defeated it greatly. The soldiers were humiliated and the army was exhausted, all blaming their king, saying, ‘Who devised this plan?’ The king said, ‘Wenzi did it.’ The ministers rebelled, and Wenzi fled. The reason for the great defeat in attacking Qi was that Qi attacked Chu and enriched Han and Wei. This is what is meant by borrowing the enemy’s army and supplying them with the enemy’s provisions. Your Majesty would be better off making distant alliances and attacking nearby enemies.” "If you gain an inch, it is your inch; if you gain a foot, it is your foot. Now, to abandon this and launch a distant attack is surely a mistake! Moreover, in the past, the state of Zhongshan was only five hundred li in size, which Zhao alone annexed. Zhao achieved great success, gained fame, and benefited from it. No one in the world could harm it. Now, Han and Wei are located in the heart of China and are the pivot of the world. If Your Majesty wishes to become a hegemon, you must befriend China to make it the pivot of the world, and use it to intimidate Chu and Zhao. If Chu is strong, it will ally with Zhao; if Zhao is strong, it will ally with Chu. If both Chu and Zhao are allied, Qi will surely be afraid. If Qi is afraid, it will surely use humble words and heavy gifts to appease Qin. If Qi is allied, Han and Wei can then be captured." King Zhao said, "I have long wished to befriend Wei, but Wei is a fickle state, and I cannot befriend it. May I ask how I should befriend Wei?" Fan Sui replied, "Your Majesty should use humble words and heavy gifts to appease it; if that is not possible, then cede territory to it as a bribe; if that is still not possible, then raise an army and attack it." The King said, "I respectfully accept your advice." He then appointed Fan Sui as a guest minister to advise on military matters. Finally, following Fan Sui's advice, he sent the Grand Master Wan to attack Wei and capture Huai. Two years later, he captured Xingqiu. 16. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... The guest minister Fan Sui then advised King Zhao, saying, "The terrain of Qin and Han is intertwined like embroidered silk. Qin's possession of Han is like a tree with a worm, or a person with a disease in their heart and abdomen. If the world remains unchanged, all is well; but if the world changes, what would be a greater calamity for Qin than Han? Your Majesty should consider conquering Han." King Zhao said, "I really want to conquer Han, but Han will not listen. What should I do?" Fan Sui replied, "How can Han not listen? If Your Majesty sends troops to attack Xingyang, the roads to Gong and Chenggao will be blocked; if you cut off the Taihang Mountains to the north, the army of Shangdang will not be able to advance. If Your Majesty raises troops to attack Xingyang, Han's country will be divided into three. Han will surely perish. How can it not listen? If Han listens, then the matter of hegemony can be considered." The king said, "Excellent." He then wanted to send an envoy to Han. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 9.5. The following year, Zhao She defeated the Qin army at Eyu. 10 (undated anecdote; placed ~end of Eyu sequence). Zhao She was a tax collector in Zhao. When the family of Lord Pingyuan refused to pay taxes, Zhao She enforced the law and executed nine of Lord Pingyuan's associates. Lord Pingyuan was furious and intended to kill Zhao She. Zhao She then said, "You are a noble prince in Zhao. If you allow your family to disobey the law, the law will be weakened. If the law is weakened, the state will be weak. If the state is weak, the other states will attack. If the other states attack, Zhao will be destroyed. How can you then be so wealthy? With your noble status, if you uphold the law, there will be harmony between the people. If there is harmony, the state will be strong. If the state is strong, Zhao will be secure. And you, as a noble relative, will not be less important than anyone else in the world." Lord Pingyuan thought this was wise and reported it to the king. The king employed Zhao She to manage the state's taxes, and the taxes became very fair, the people became wealthy, and the treasury was full. 11. When Qin attacked Han, they camped at Eyu. The king summoned Lian Po and asked, "Can we save them?" Lian Po replied, "The road is long, treacherous, and narrow; it is difficult to save them." The king then summoned Yue Cheng and asked him the same question, which was exactly what Lian Po had said. The king then summoned Zhao She and asked him the same question, which was exactly what Lian Po had said. Zhao She replied, "The road is long, treacherous, and narrow; it is like two rats fighting in a hole. The braver one will win." The king then ordered Zhao She to lead the army to save Han. 12. The army was thirty li from Handan when Zhao She issued an order to the troops: "Anyone who offers military advice will be executed." The Qin army camped west of Wu'an. The Qin army raised its drums and rallied its troops, causing the roof tiles of Wu'an to shake. A soldier in the army suggested urgently rescuing Wu'an, but Zhao She immediately executed him. The army fortified its walls and remained there for twenty-eight days without advancing, then further strengthened its defenses. Qin Xian came to visit, and Zhao She treated him well and sent him away. Xian reported this to the Qin general, who was overjoyed, saying, "The army didn't advance even thirty li from the capital, yet they strengthened their defenses; Eyu is not Zhao territory." Having already sent Qin Xian away, Zhao She rolled up his armor and rushed towards Eyu, arriving in two days and one night. Now, skilled archers are fifty li from Eyu before the army is stationed there. When the fortifications were completed, the Qin people, hearing of this, arrived in full armor. The soldier Xu Li requested military advice, and Zhao She said, "Let him in." Xu Li said, "The Qin army did not expect the Zhao army to arrive here. Their momentum is strong. General, you must gather your forces to meet them. Otherwise, you will surely be defeated." Zhao She said, "I accept your command." Xu Li said, "I request to be executed by being taken hostage." Zhao She said, "You shall then be in Handan." Xu Li again requested advice, saying, "Whoever occupies the northern mountain first will win; those who arrive later will be defeated." Zhao She agreed and immediately sent ten thousand men to attack. The Qin army arrived late and could not ascend the mountain. Zhao She then unleashed his troops to attack them, inflicting a great defeat on the Qin army. The Qin army broke free and fled, and Zhao She lifted the siege of Eyu and returned home. 13. King Huiwen of Zhao bestowed upon Zhao She the title of Lord Ma Fu and appointed Xu Li as the Grand Commandant. Zhao She then held the same rank as Lian Po and Lin Xiangru.
[269 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 3. The prince was playing a game with King Wei when a signal fire was lit in the north, announcing, "The Zhao invaders are approaching and will soon cross the border." King Wei released the game and wanted to summon his ministers for advice. The prince stopped the king, saying, "King Zhao is merely hunting; he is not invading." The game resumed as before. The king was afraid, and his mind was not on the game. After a while, another message came from the north, saying, "King Zhao is merely hunting; he is not invading." King Wei was greatly surprised and asked, "How did you know this, prince?" The prince replied, "One of my retainers is deeply versed in King Zhao's secret affairs. He reports to me everything King Zhao does, and that's how I know." From then on, King Wei feared the prince's wisdom and ability and dared not entrust him with the affairs of state. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 17. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Fan Sui grew increasingly close to him, and having served him for several years, he casually asked to speak, saying: "When I lived in Shandong, I heard of Tian Wen in Qi, but never of a king; I heard of the Queen Dowager, Marquis Rang, Hua Yang, Gao Ling, and Jing Yang in Qin, but never of a king. A king is one who wields absolute power, one who can control profit and loss, and one who wields the power of life and death. Now, the Queen Dowager acts arbitrarily without regard for consequences, Marquis Rang goes on envoys without reporting back, Hua Yang and Jing Yang act without restraint, and Gao Ling advances and retreats without consulting anyone. With these four powerful figures in place, how can the state not be in danger?" This has never happened before. For this reason, the four nobles are subservient, which is what is meant by "no king." Then how can power not be usurped, and how can decrees be issued by the king? I have heard that a good ruler consolidates his authority internally and strengthens his power externally. The Marquis of Rang, as an envoy, wields the king's weight, making decisions among the feudal lords, distributing tallies throughout the land, and governing when attacking other states—none dare disobey. Victory in battle brings profit to Tao, and the state is subdued by the feudal lords; defeat breeds resentment among the people, and disaster befalls the state. The Book of Poetry says, "The tree laden with fruit spreads its branches..." Those who pluck its branches wound its heart; those who expand its capital endanger its state; those who honor its ministers demean its ruler. Cui Zhu, Nao Chi, and Guan Qi shot the king in the thigh, ripped out his tendons, and hung him from the temple beam; he died the following day. Li Dui, in charge of Zhao, imprisoned the king's father in Shaqiu, where he starved to death after a hundred days. Now, I have heard that the Queen Dowager of Qin and Marquis Rang are in power, assisted by Gaoling, Huayang, and Jingyang; yet, there was no King of Qin. These are also like Nao Chi and Li Dui. Moreover, the reason why the three dynasties perished was that the rulers monopolized power, indulged in wine, galloping, and hunting. He neglected state affairs. Those appointed to his posts were jealous of the virtuous and capable, manipulating subordinates and deceiving superiors for their own selfish gain, neglecting the king's plans. The king remained oblivious, thus losing his kingdom. Now, from officials of high rank to high ministers, and even those around the king, all are former ministers. Seeing the king standing alone in court, I fear for Your Majesty. For ten thousand generations to come, the Qin kingdom will not belong to any prince or descendant.” King Zhao, upon hearing this, was greatly frightened and said, “Excellent.” He then deposed the Queen Dowager and banished Ranghou, Gaoling, Huayang, and Jingyang Jun to the border. The King of Qin then appointed Fan Sui as prime minister. He confiscated Ranghou's seal and sent him back to Tao, ordering the county officials to provide carts and oxen for his relocation; there were over a thousand carts. Upon arriving at the pass, the gatekeepers inspected his treasures, finding them more precious and rare than those in the royal collection. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 9.2. Two years later, Lian Po again attacked Qi and captured it.
[268 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.25 (yr 38; Eyu fails). In the thirty-eighth year, Zhong Geng Hu (Shang) [Yang] attacked Zhao's Eyu, but failed to capture it.
[267 BC]
[266 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.26 (yr 40; crown prince Dao dies). In the fortieth year, Crown Prince Dao died in Wei and was buried in Zhiyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 89. Twenty years later, Lian Po led an army to attack Qi. The king met King Zhaoxiang of Qin outside the West River. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 18. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Qin enfeoffed Fan Sui in response, bestowing upon him the title of Marquis Ying. This occurred in the forty-first year of King Zhaoxiang of Qin's reign. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 9.3. Three years later, Lian Po attacked and captured Fangling and Anyang of Wei. 14.1. Four years later, King Huiwen of Zhao died,
[265 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 75. Wang Nan said to Cheng Jun, "When Chu besieged Yongshi, Han sent armor and grain to Eastern Zhou. The ruler of Eastern Zhou was afraid and summoned Su Dai to tell him. Dai said, 'Why should Your Majesty worry about this? I can make Han not send armor and grain to Zhou, and I can also help Your Majesty obtain Gaodu.' The ruler of Zhou said, 'If you can do this, I will give you the kingdom.' Dai met with the prime minister of Han and said, 'Chu besieged Yongshi for three months, but now it has been five months and they still cannot take it. This shows that Chu is in trouble. Now, Prime Minister, you are sending armor and grain to Zhou, which is to tell Chu that it is in trouble.' The prime minister of Han said, 'Good. The envoy has already gone.' Dai said, 'Why not give Gaodu to Zhou?' The prime minister of Han was furious and said, 'I have already given plenty of armor and grain to Zhou. Why give Gaodu to Zhou?' Dai said, 'Giving Gaodu to Zhou is a roundabout way to enter Han. Qin will be furious when it hears about this and will not communicate with Zhou's envoy. That is why Gaodu was able to survive in Zhou. Why not give it to them?' The prime minister said, 'Good.' They indeed gave Gaodu to Zhou." [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.27 (yr 41; Wei attacked). In the summer of the forty-first year, Qin attacked Wei, capturing Xingqiu and Huai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 90. In the twenty-first year, Zhao moved his capital to the west of Wuping on the Zhang River. In the twenty-second year, a great plague struck. Prince Dan was made crown prince. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 52. In the fourteenth year, Qin attacked Gangshou. In the nineteenth year, King Xiang died, and his son Jianli was born. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 19. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... When Fan Sui became prime minister of Qin, Qin appointed him as Zhang Lu, but Wei was unaware of this and believed that Fan Sui had long been dead. Wei heard that Qin was about to launch an eastern attack on Han and Wei, so Wei sent Xu Jia to Qin. Fan Sui, upon hearing this, disguised himself and, dressed in tattered clothes, strolled leisurely to the Qin residence to meet Xu Jia. Xu Jia, seeing him, exclaimed in surprise, "Uncle Fan, are you well?" Fan Sui replied, "Yes." Xu Jia laughed and said, "Uncle Fan, do you have something to say to Qin?" He replied, "No. I was fortunate enough to be favored by the prime minister of Wei the other day, so I fled here. How could I dare to say anything!" Xu Jia asked, "What brings you here, Uncle?" Fan Sui replied, "I am a hired laborer." Xu Jia felt sorry for him and invited him to sit and eat, saying, "Uncle Fan, how impoverished you are!" He then took a silk robe and gave it to him. Xu Jia then asked, "Do you know Zhang Jun, the Prime Minister of Qin? I have heard that he is favored by the King, and all matters of the realm are decided by the Prime Minister. Now, my fate depends on Zhang Jun. Do you have any guests who are familiar with the Prime Minister?" Fan Sui replied, "Your master knows him well. Only I have the opportunity to meet him. I will ask to see Zhang Jun on your behalf." Xu Jia said, "My horse is sick, and the axle of my carriage is broken. I cannot go out without a large carriage drawn by four horses." Fan Sui said, "I would like to borrow a large carriage drawn by four horses from your master for you." 20. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Fan Sui returned to fetch a large carriage drawn by four horses, which Xu Jia then drove to the Qin Prime Minister's residence. Those in the residence who recognized him all hid. Xu Jia found this strange. Upon reaching the gate of the Prime Minister's residence, Fan Sui said to Xu Jia, "Wait for me; I will go in first to speak with the Prime Minister." Xu Jia waited at the gate, holding the carriage for a long time, then asked the gatekeeper, "Why hasn't Fan Shu come out?" The gatekeeper replied, "There is no Fan Shu." Xu Jia said, "The one who rode in with me earlier." The gatekeeper said, "That is our Prime Minister, Zhang Jun." Xu Jia was greatly alarmed, realizing he had been betrayed. He then bared his chest and walked on, apologizing to the gatekeeper. Thereupon, Fan Sui had a large tent and many people waiting, and they saw him. Xu Jia bowed deeply and confessed his guilt, saying, "I never expected you, sir, to rise to such a high position. I dare not read any more books, nor concern myself with any affairs of the world. I am guilty of being boiled alive; I beg to retreat to this land of barbarians, leaving my fate entirely to you!" Fan Sui asked, "How many crimes have you committed?" Xu Jia replied, "Even if you were to cut off a hair to add to my crimes, it would still not be enough." Fan Sui said, "Your crimes are three. In the past, during the reign of King Zhao of Chu, Shen Baoxu repelled the Wu army for Chu..." The King of Chu granted Bao Xu a fief of five thousand households in Jing, but Bao Xu declined, choosing to have his ancestral tombs enshrined in Jing. Now, the tombs of Sui's ancestors are also in Wei. You previously accused Sui of having ulterior motives towards Qi and thus disliked Sui towards both Wei and Qi; this is your first offense. When Wei and Qi insulted me in the latrine, you did not stop; this is your second offense. Furthermore, they drowned me while drunk; how could you bear to do that? This is your third offense. However, the reason you escaped death is because you lingered over the silk robe, showing affection for an old friend; therefore, I released you.” He then apologized and left. He went to report this to King Zhao, who dismissed him and sent him back to Xu Jia. 21. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Xu Jia declined Fan Sui's offer of farewell. Fan Sui lavishly prepared food and drink, inviting all the envoys from various states and seating them in the hall. Xu Jia, however, sat below Fan Sui, with beans placed before him, which two tattooed men fed to his horse. Fan Sui repeatedly said, "Tell the King of Wei to bring me Wei Qi's head immediately! Otherwise, I will slaughter the entire city of Daliang." Xu Jia returned and told Wei Qi. Wei Qi, terrified, fled to Zhao and hid with Lord Pingyuan. 22. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... After Fan Sui became prime minister, Wang Ji said to him, "There are three things that are unpredictable, and three things that are beyond our control. The emperor's sudden death is the first unpredictable event. Your Majesty's sudden death from your residence is the second. Your envoy's sudden death in a ditch is the third. If the emperor's sudden death were to happen, Your Majesty, though you may resent me, there would be nothing you can do. If Your Majesty suddenly died from your residence, Your Majesty, though you may resent me, there would be nothing you can do. If your envoy suddenly died in a ditch, Your Majesty, though you may resent me, there would be nothing you can do." Fan Sui was displeased and went to speak to the king, saying, "Without Wang Ji's loyalty, no one could have been a subject at Hangu Pass; without Your Majesty's wisdom, no one could have valued me. Now I hold the position of prime minister and the rank of marquis, while Wang Ji's official position is still only that of a minor official; this is not what a subject should do." King Zhao summoned Wang Ji and appointed him governor of Hedong, but he did not submit any reports for three years. He then appointed Zheng Anping, whom King Zhao made general. Fan Sui then distributed all his family's wealth to repay those who had wronged him. He would repay even the smallest kindness, and avenge even the slightest grievance. 23. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... In the second year of Fan Sui's tenure as Prime Minister of Qin, and the forty-second year of King Zhaoxiang of Qin, he launched an eastern expedition against Han, capturing Shaoqu and Gaoping. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 14.2. and his son, King Xiaocheng, ascended the throne.
[264 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.28 (yr 42; Anguo crown prince). In the forty-second year, Lord Anguo became Crown Prince. In October, Empress Dowager Xuan died and was buried in Lishan, Zhiyang. In September, Marquis Rang was exiled to Tao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 31.2. In the first year of King Huanhui's reign, Qin attacked Yan. In the ninth year, Qin captured Xing and fortified the area near Fen. In the tenth year, Qin attacked us at Taihang, and the governor of Shangdang surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. In the fourteenth year, Qin captured Shangdang from Zhao, killing over 400,000 soldiers of Ma Fu at Changping. In the seventeenth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu. In the twenty-second year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin captured Chenggao and Xingyang. In the twenty-sixth year, Qin completely captured Shangdang. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin captured thirteen cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.11. In the 43rd year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked Hanxing City, capturing five cities and beheading 50,000. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 24. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... When King Zhaoxiang of Qin heard that Wei Qi was with Lord Pingyuan, he wanted to avenge him on behalf of Fan Sui. So he wrote a fine letter to Lord Pingyuan, saying, "I have heard of your noble character and wish to be your friend, even if we are just commoners. If you happen to visit me, I would like to have a ten-day drinking party with you." Lord Pingyuan feared Qin and thought it was a good idea, so he went to Qin to see King Zhaoxiang. King Zhao and Lord Pingyuan drank for several days. King Zhao said to Lord Pingyuan, "In the past, King Wen of Zhou had Lü Shang as his Grand Duke, and Duke Huan of Qi had Guan Zhong as his Uncle. Now, Lord Fan is also my uncle. Lord Fan's enemy is in your house. I wish to send someone back to retrieve his head; otherwise, I will not let you out of the pass." Lord Pingyuan said, "To associate with the noble is to be lowly; to associate with the rich is to be poor. Wei Qi is a friend of my brother. If he were here, I would not let him out, and now he is not with me." King Zhao then sent a letter to King Zhao, saying, "Your brother is in Qin, and Lord Fan's enemy, Wei Qi, is in Lord Pingyuan's house. Your Majesty, send someone quickly to retrieve his head; otherwise, I will raise an army to attack Zhao, and I will not let your brother out of the pass." King Xiaocheng of Zhao then sent troops to besiege Lord Pingyuan's house. In the midst of the chaos, Wei Qi escaped at night and met with Zhao's Prime Minister, Yu Qing. Yu Qing, realizing that King Zhao could not be persuaded, resigned his position as prime minister and fled with Wei Qi. While traveling, he realized that none of the other states could be reached quickly, so he went to Daliang, intending to use Lord Xinling to escape to Chu. Lord Xinling, hearing of this, feared Qin and hesitated to meet him, asking, "What kind of person is Yu Qing?" Hou Ying, who was nearby, said, "It is indeed difficult to know a person, and even more difficult to know a person. Yu Qing, in his humble attire, met King Zhao once and was bestowed with a pair of white jade discs and a hundred yi of gold; at the second meeting, he was appointed a high minister; at the third meeting, he finally received the prime minister's seal and was enfeoffed as a marquis of ten thousand households. At that time, the whole world knew of him. Wei Qi, in dire straits, visited Yu Qing, yet Yu Qing dared not value his rank and emoluments, resigning his position as prime minister and abandoning his marquisate to travel freely. He sought out a poor scholar and returned to you, sir, who asked, 'What kind of person is he?' It is indeed difficult to know a person, and even more difficult to know a person!" Lord Xinling was greatly ashamed and rode to the fields to welcome him. When Wei Qi heard that Lord Xinling was initially difficult to meet, he became enraged and committed suicide. Upon hearing this, the King of Zhao finally obtained Wei Qi's head and sent it to Qin. King Zhaoxiang of Qin then released Lord Pingyuan back to Zhao. 25. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... In the 43rd year of King Zhao's reign, Qin attacked and captured Fenxing in Han, and then built a city on Guangwu above the river.
[263 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.29 (yr 43; Bai Qi vs Han). In the forty-third year, Lord Wu'an Bai Qi attacked Han, capturing nine cities and beheading 50,000. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 94. In the thirty-sixth year, King Qingxiang fell ill, and the crown prince died and returned home. In the autumn, King Qingxiang died, and Crown Prince Xiong Yuan succeeded him, becoming King Kaolie. King Kaolie appointed Zuo Tu as prime minister and enfeoffed him with the state of Wu, giving him the title of Lord Chunshen. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 91. In the twenty-third year, Lou Chang led an attack on Wei's Ji, but failed to capture it. In December, Lian Po led an attack on Ji and captured it. In the twenty-fourth year, Lian Po led an attack on Wei's Fangzi, captured it, and then retreated through the city. He then attacked and captured Anyang. In the twenty-fifth year, Yan Zhou led an attack on Changcheng and Gaotang, capturing them. He joined forces with Wei to attack Qin. Qin general Bai Qi defeated our Huayang, and we gained a general. In the twenty-sixth year, we captured the land of Ou Dai of the Donghu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 31.3. In the first year of King Huanhui's reign, Qin attacked Yan. In the ninth year, Qin captured Xing and fortified the area near Fen. In the tenth year, Qin attacked us at Taihang, and the governor of Shangdang surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. In the fourteenth year, Qin captured Shangdang from Zhao, killing over 400,000 soldiers of Ma Fu at Changping. In the seventeenth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu. In the twenty-second year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin captured Chenggao and Xingyang. In the twenty-sixth year, Qin completely captured Shangdang. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin captured thirteen cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 1.12. In the 44th year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi attacked the Taihang Road in Nanyang, cutting it off.
[262 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.30 (yr 44; Nan taken). In the forty-fourth year, Qin attacked Han's Nan (Yang) and captured it. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 95. In the first year of King Kaolie's reign, the state of Nazhou was annexed by Qin to achieve peace. At that time, Chu became increasingly weak. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 2. In the forty-fifth year, Qin attacked Yewang, the capital of Han. Yewang surrendered to Qin, and the road to Shangdang was cut off. Its governor, Feng Ting, consulted with the people, saying, "The road to Zheng is now cut off; Han can no longer be our people. Qin's army advances daily, and Han cannot respond. It would be better to surrender Shangdang to Zhao. If Zhao accepts us, Qin will be angry and attack Zhao. Zhao, weakened by the war, will surely ally with Han. If Han and Zhao become one, we can withstand Qin." He then sent a messenger to Zhao. King Xiaocheng of Zhao consulted with Lord Pingyang and Lord Pingyuan. Lord Pingyang said, "It is better not to accept. Accepting it will bring more harm than good." Lord Pingyuan said, "It is convenient to accept a prefecture without cause." Zhao accepted it, and subsequently enfeoffed Feng Ting as Lord Huayang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 9.4. Four years later, Lin Xiangru led an attack on Qi, but stopped at Pingyi.
[261 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.31 (yr 45; Ben attacks Han). In the forty-fifth year, the five grand masters Ben attacked Han, capturing ten cities. Lord Yeyang Kui was exiled to his country but died before arriving. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 92. In the twenty-seventh year, he was moved to Wuping South of the Zhang River. Zhao Bao was enfeoffed as the Lord of Pingyang. The Yellow River overflowed its banks, causing a great flood. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 3. In the forty-sixth year, Qin attacked and captured Goushi and Lin of Han.
[260 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 26.2. In the thirteenth year, Qin defeated Zhao at Changping with over 400,000 troops. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 101. In the seventh year [month], Lian Po was dismissed and Zhao Kuo replaced him as general. The Qin army besieged Zhao Kuo, who surrendered with his army. More than 400,000 soldiers were all buried alive. The king regretted not listening to Zhao Bao's plan, which led to the disaster at Changping. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 31.4 ([text year-count differs]). In the first year of King Huanhui's reign, Qin attacked Yan. In the ninth year, Qin captured Xing and fortified the area near Fen. In the tenth year, Qin attacked us at Taihang, and the governor of Shangdang surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. In the fourteenth year, Qin captured Shangdang from Zhao, killing over 400,000 soldiers of Ma Fu at Changping. In the seventeenth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu. In the twenty-second year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin captured Chenggao and Xingyang. In the twenty-sixth year, Qin completely captured Shangdang. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin captured thirteen cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 4.1. In the forty-seventh year, Qin sent Wang He, the Left Grand Master, to attack Han and capture Shangdang. The people of Shangdang fled to Zhao. The Zhao army was stationed at Changping to control the people of Shangdang. 4.2. In April, Wang He attacked Zhao. Zhao sent Lian Po as general. Zhao soldiers attacked Qin scouts, and the Qin scouts killed Zhao's deputy general, Qie. 4.3. In June, they captured the Zhao army, taking two fortified posts and four officers. 4.4. In July, the Zhao army built fortifications and defended them. Qin attacked their fortifications again, taking two officers, defeating their formation, and seizing the western fortifications. Lian Po fortified his positions and awaited Qin. Qin challenged him several times, but the Zhao army did not come out. The King of Zhao repeatedly expressed his displeasure. 4.5. Meanwhile, the Marquis of Yingxiang of Qin sent someone with a thousand gold pieces to Zhao to offer a bribe, saying, "What Qin fears most is only Zhao Kuo, the son of Ma Fu, as general. Lian Po is easy to deal with and will soon surrender." The King of Zhao was already angry that Lian Po's army had suffered many losses and defeats, and that he had fortified his positions and dared not fight. Hearing the Qin bribe, he then replaced Lian Po with Zhao Kuo to attack Qin. When Qin heard that Ma Fuzi was going to be the general, they secretly appointed Wu'an Jun Bai Qi as the supreme commander. Wang He was appointed as the deputy commander, and an order was issued that anyone in the army who dared to reveal Wu'an Jun's command would be executed. 4.6. When Zhao Kuo arrived, he led troops to attack the Qin army. The Qin army feigned defeat and fled, deploying two surprise troops to ambush them. The Zhao army pursued their victory, chasing them to the Qin fortified walls. The walls were strong and they could not enter. Meanwhile, 25,000 Qin surprise troops cut off the Zhao army's rear, and another 5,000 cavalry cut off the Zhao army's supply lines. The Zhao army was divided in two, and their supply lines were cut off. Qin then sent out light troops to attack. The Zhao army suffered a defeat and built fortified walls to hold out, awaiting reinforcements. 4.7. When the King of Qin heard that Zhao's supply lines were cut off, he personally went to Henan, bestowing each citizen a rank of nobility and ordering all those over fifteen years of age to go to Changping to block Zhao's reinforcements and food supplies. 5.1. By September, the Zhao soldiers had gone without food for forty-six days, and they all secretly killed and ate each other. They attacked the Qin fortifications, attempting to break out. 5.2. They formed four groups, attacking in four or five waves, but could not break through. 5.3. Their general, Zhao Kuo, led his elite troops in a desperate battle, but the Qin army shot and killed him. 5.4. Zhao Kuo's army was defeated, and 400,000 soldiers surrendered to Lord Wu'an. Lord Wu'an devised a plan: "Qin has already captured Shangdang, and the people of Shangdang are unwilling to serve Qin and have returned to Zhao. The Zhao soldiers are fickle. If we do not kill them all, they may cause chaos." 5.5. Therefore, he used deception to bury them alive, leaving only 240 youngest members to return to Zhao. In total, 450,000 heads were taken and prisoners were captured. The people of Zhao were greatly shocked. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 6.1. In the twentieth year of King Anli of Wei, King Zhaoxiang of Qin had already defeated the Zhao army at Changping and then advanced to besiege Handan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 26. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Five years later, King Zhaoxiang, following Ying Hou's advice, allowed a traitor to betray Zhao. Because of this, Zhao replaced Lian Po with Ma Fu's son as general. Qin decisively defeated Zhao at Changping and then besieged Handan. Later, King Zhaoxiang had a falling out with Bai Qi, the Marquis of Wu'an, and had him killed. He then appointed Zheng Anping to attack Zhao. Zheng Anping was besieged by Zhao and, in desperation, surrendered to Zhao with 20,000 troops. Ying Hou, sitting on a withered mat, pleaded guilty. According to Qin law, those who appointed someone poorly were punished according to their crimes. Therefore, Ying Hou's crime was punishable by the extermination of his entire family. King Zhaoxiang, fearing to offend Ying Hou, issued an order throughout the kingdom: "Anyone who dares to speak of Zheng Anping's affairs will be punished according to their crimes." He also increased the food and provisions bestowed upon the Prime Minister Ying Hou daily to appease him. Two years later, Wang Ji, the governor of Hedong, colluded with other states and was executed for his crimes. Ying Hou grew increasingly resentful. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 14.3. Seven years later, Qin and Zhao armies met at Changping. At that time, Zhao She had already died, and Lin Xiangru was seriously ill. Zhao sent Lian Po to lead an attack on Qin. Qin repeatedly defeated the Zhao army, and the Zhao army fortified its defenses and refused to fight. Qin challenged them several times, but Lian Po refused to engage. 14.4. King Zhao believed Qin's rumors. Qin's rumors said, "What Qin dislikes is only Zhao Kuo, the son of Zhao She, the Lord of Ma Fu, as general." King Zhao then appointed Kuo as general, replacing Lian Po. Lin Xiangru said, "Your Majesty appoints Kuo based on his reputation, like trying to play a zither with its strings glued shut. Kuo can only read his father's books and records, but he doesn't know how to adapt to changing circumstances." King Zhao did not listen and appointed him as general. 15 (background reflection; dated to Changping decision). Zhao Kuo studied military strategy from a young age and spoke of military affairs with such confidence that no one in the world could rival him. He once discussed military matters with his father, Zhao She, who could not refute him but did not consider his arguments insightful. When Kuo's mother asked She the reason, She replied, "War is a matter of life and death, yet Kuo speaks of it so lightly. If Zhao does not appoint Kuo as general, all will be well; but if they insist on appointing him, Kuo will surely be the one to defeat the Zhao army." When Kuo was about to depart, his mother wrote to the king, saying, "Kuo should not be made general." The king asked, "Why?" She replied, "When I served his father, he was a general. He personally served him food and drink to dozens of people and had hundreds of friends. All the rewards bestowed by Your Majesty and the royal family were given to the officers and soldiers. On the day he received his command, he did not concern himself with family matters. Now, Kuo has become a general. He faces east to pay homage, and none of the officers and soldiers dare to look him in the eye. The gold and silk bestowed by Your Majesty are hoarded at home, and he spends his days buying up convenient fields and houses. How does Your Majesty see him as a different father? Father and son are of different minds. I beg Your Majesty not to send him." The king said, "Mother, please disregard this. I have already made my decision." Kuo's mother then said, "If Your Majesty ultimately sends him and he is not up to par, will I not be implicated?" The king agreed. 16.1. After Zhao Kuo replaced Lian Po, he completely changed the military regulations and replaced the officers. Qin general Bai Qi, hearing of this, launched a surprise attack, feigning defeat and retreat, cutting off the enemy's supply lines and splitting their army in two, causing the soldiers to lose heart. After more than forty days, the army was starving. Zhao Kuo led his elite troops in a desperate battle, and the Qin army shot and killed him. Zhao Kuo's army was defeated, and hundreds of thousands surrendered to Qin, who buried them all alive. Zhao suffered a total loss of 450,000 men.
[259 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.32 (yr 47; Shangdang surrenders). In the forty-seventh year, Qin attacked Han's Shangdang, which surrendered to Zhao. Qin then attacked Zhao, and Zhao sent troops to attack Qin, resulting in a confrontation. Qin sent Lord Wu'an Bai Qi to attack, inflicting a great defeat on Zhao at Changping, killing over 400,000 of their soldiers. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 26.3. In the fourteenth year, King Wucheng died, and his son, King Xiao, ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 93. In the twenty-eighth year, Lin Xiangru attacked Qi and reached Pingyi. He dismantled the nine gates of the main city north of the city. Gongsun Cao, the Lord of Cheng'an of Yan, assassinated his king. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin and Han attacked each other and besieged Eyu. Zhao sent Zhao She as general to attack Qin, and he defeated the Qin army at Eyu. Zhao She was then granted the title of Lord Ma Fu. 102. King Huan refused to listen to Qin, and Qin besieged Handan. Fu Bao, Wang Rong, and Su She, magistrates of Wuyuan, led the people of Yan in rebellion against Yan territory. Zhao enfeoffed Lord Chunshen, the prime minister of Chu, with Lingqiu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 53. In the sixth year of King Jianli's reign, Qin attacked Zhao, and Qi and Chu came to its aid. Qin's plan was: "If Qi and Chu come to Zhao's aid, they will withdraw their troops; if they do not, we will continue the attack." Zhao had no food and requested grain from Qi, but Qi refused. Zhou Zi said, "It would be better to grant their request to withdraw Qin's troops. If they refuse, Qin's troops will not retreat, and Qin's plan will succeed while Qi and Chu's plan will fail. Moreover, Zhao is to Qi and Chu as a shield as lips are to teeth; if the lips are gone, the teeth will be cold. If Zhao is destroyed today, Qi and Chu will suffer tomorrow. Furthermore, the task of rescuing Zhao should be like offering a leaky jar to a scorched pot. Rescuing Zhao is a noble act; repelling Qin's troops is a glorious act. To righteously rescue a dying state and powerfully repel the mighty Qin army, yet to prioritize saving grain over this, is a mistake for a ruler." King Qi did not listen. Qin defeated Zhao at Changping with over 400,000 troops and then besieged Handan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 6.1. In October of the forty-eighth year, Qin reconquered Shangdang Commandery. Qin divided its army into two: Wang He attacked and captured Pilao; Sima Geng pacified Taiyuan. 6.2. Han and Zhao, fearing for their lives, sent Su Dai with generous gifts to persuade Qin's Lord Xiang Yu, saying, "Has Lord Wu'an captured Ma Fuzi?" Su Dai replied, "Yes." Su Dai then asked, "Will you besiege Handan?" Su Dai replied, "Yes." Su Dai continued, "If Zhao falls, the King of Qin will become king, and Lord Wu'an will become one of the Three Dukes. Lord Wu'an has won over seventy cities for Qin, pacified Yan, Ying, and Hanzhong in the south, and captured Zhao Kuo's army in the north. Even the achievements of Zhou, Shao, and L� Wang cannot surpass these. Now that Zhao has fallen and the King of Qin has become king, Lord Wu'an will surely become one of the Three Dukes. Can you be subordinate to him? Even if you have no desire..." "Therefore, we have no other choice. Qin once attacked Han, besieged Xingqiu, and afflicted Shangdang. The people of Shangdang all rebelled and joined Zhao. The world has long been unwilling to be Qin's subjects. Now, if Zhao is destroyed, the northern lands will fall to Yan, the eastern lands to Qi, and the southern lands to Han and Wei. How many people will you gain? Therefore, it would be better to cede them now, so as not to benefit Lord Wu'an." 6.3. Thereupon, Lord Ying said to the King of Qin, "Qin's army is exhausted. Please grant Han and Zhao the cession of territory in exchange for peace, and allow the soldiers to rest." The King agreed and ceded Yuanyong from Han and six cities from Zhao in exchange for peace. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 27. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... King Zhao sighed in court. Marquis Ying stepped forward and said, "I have heard that 'When the ruler is worried, the subject is disgraced; when the ruler is disgraced, the subject dies.' Now Your Majesty is worried in court; I dare to ask for your forgiveness." King Zhao said, "I have heard that Chu's iron swords are sharp, but its entertainers are clumsy. A sharp iron sword makes the soldiers brave, while clumsy entertainers show foresight. If one uses foresight to control brave warriors, I fear Chu is plotting against Qin. Without prepared resources, one cannot respond to emergencies. Now, Lord Wu'an is dead, and Zheng Anping and others have rebelled. We have no good generals within and many enemy states without. This is why I am worried." He intended to encourage Marquis Ying. Marquis Ying was afraid and did not know what to do. Cai Ze heard of this and went to Qin. 28. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Cai Ze was a man from Yan. He traveled extensively, seeking guidance from numerous feudal lords, both high and low, but without success. He then became a court advisor under Tang Ju, who said, "I heard that you, sir, advised Li Dui, saying, 'Within a hundred days, he will hold the reins of the state.' Is this true?" Cai Ze replied, "Yes." Tang Ju then asked, "What about me?" Cai Ze scrutinized him and laughed, saying, "Sir, you have a broad nose, large shoulders, a gaunt face, a furrowed brow, and cramped knees. I've heard that sages don't use physiognomy; could it be you?" Cai Ze, knowing Tang Ju was joking, said, "Wealth and honor are my own; what I don't know is longevity. I wish to hear about it." Tang Ju said, "Sir, your lifespan will be forty-three years from now." Cai Ze laughed, thanked him, and left, telling his charioteer, "I will carry a large, fat horse, ride swiftly, carry a golden seal, wear a purple ribbon, bow before the ruler, eat meat, and enjoy wealth and honor; forty-three years will be enough." He went to Zhao, but was banished. He then went to Han and Wei, where he was caught stealing his cooking pot on the road. Upon hearing that Yinghou had appointed Zheng Anping and Wang Ji, both of whom had committed serious crimes in Qin, Yinghou felt ashamed and Cai Ze then went west to Qin. 29. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Before meeting King Zhao, the king sent a messenger to declare to Lord Ying, "Cai Ze, a guest of Yan, is a brilliant and eloquent man of great talent and wisdom. If he were to meet the King of Qin, the king would surely imprison you and seize your throne." Lord Ying, upon hearing this, said, "I know the affairs of the Five Emperors and Three Dynasties, and the doctrines of the Hundred Schools of Thought. I have refuted all the arguments of the masses. How could he possibly imprison me and seize my throne?" He then sent for Cai Ze. When Cai Ze entered, he bowed to Lord Ying. Lord Ying was already displeased, and upon seeing him, he became even more arrogant. Lord Ying then rebuked him, saying, "You once declared that you wished to replace me as prime minister of Qin. Is that true?" He replied, "Yes." Lord Ying said, "Please tell me your reasons." Cai Ze said, "Alas, why did you only realize this so late! In the order of the four seasons, those who succeed depart. Humans are born with strong bodies, agile hands and feet, keen senses, and wise minds. Is this not the desire of every scholar?" Lord Ying said, "Yes." Cai Ze said, "To be benevolent and righteous, to practice the Way and bestow virtue, to gain favor throughout the world, to be loved and respected by all, and to be desired as a ruler—is this not the ideal state of being?" Lord Ying said, "Yes."
