Cai Ze continued, "Wealth, honor, and glory; to govern all things and ensure that each finds its proper place; long life and a full lifespan; the world continuing the dynasty and upholding the cause, passing it down endlessly; pure name and true virtue, its influence flowing for thousands of miles, praised generation after generation without end, as enduring as heaven and earth: is this not the embodiment of morality and the auspicious and virtuous deeds of the sages?" Lord Ying said, "Yes." 30. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Cai Ze said, "As for Shang Yang of Qin, Wu Qi of Chu, and Dafu Zhong of Yue, wouldn't they also be desirable in their eventual downfall?" Ying Hou, knowing Cai Ze intended to use him to persuade him, falsely replied, "Why not? When Gongsun Yang served Duke Xiao, he was utterly selfless and devoted to the public good, disregarding personal interests. He used torture to deter evil, and enforced rewards and punishments to achieve order. He revealed his innermost thoughts, showed his true feelings, endured resentment and blame, deceived old friends, seized Prince Ang of Wei, secured the Qin state, benefited the people, and ultimately became a Qin general who defeated the enemy and expanded Qin's territory by a thousand li. When Wu Qi served King Dao, he ensured that private interests did not harm the public good, and he did not resort to slander..." One must not conceal loyalty, speak without seeking personal gain, act without seeking favor, not act easily for the sake of danger, and not shy away from difficulties in upholding righteousness. Even for a powerful and hegemonic state, one should not fear calamity. When the minister Zhong served the King of Yue, though his lord was in distress and humiliation, he remained loyal and steadfast; though his lord was about to perish, he did his utmost to remain loyal; though his lord was about to die, he did not abandon him; though he achieved success, he was not arrogant; though he was rich and powerful, he was not complacent. These three men truly exemplify the utmost righteousness and the highest integrity of loyalty. Therefore, a gentleman dies for righteousness, regarding death as returning home; a life of disgrace is not as good as a life of honor. A scholar may indeed sacrifice his life to achieve fame; though it is for righteousness, even death is without regret. Why is this not possible? 31. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Cai Ze said, “A wise ruler and virtuous ministers are the greatest blessing for the world; an enlightened ruler and upright ministers are the blessing for the nation; a kind father and filial son, a trustworthy husband and a chaste wife are the blessing for the family. Therefore, Bi Gan was loyal but could not save Yin; Wu Zixu was wise but could not save Wu; Shen Sheng was filial but the state of Jin was in chaos. These were all cases where there were loyal ministers and filial sons, yet the state was destroyed and in chaos. Why? Because there was no enlightened ruler or virtuous father to listen to them. Therefore, the world regards their rulers and fathers as disgrace and pities their ministers and sons. Now, Shang Yang, Wu Qi, and Da Fu Zhong were good ministers; but their rulers were not. Therefore, the world praises these three for their achievements but not for their virtue. Did they yearn to die without encountering the right world? If one waits until death to establish loyalty and fame, then Wei Zi is not benevolent enough, Confucius is not sage enough, and Guan Zhong is not great enough. When people establish merit, do they not aim for perfection? Those who achieve perfection in both body and name are the best. Those whose name is worthy of emulation but whose body dies are next best. Those whose name is disgraceful but whose body is intact are the worst.” Thereupon, Ying Hou praised him. 32. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Cai Ze, having a moment of leisure, said, "Shang Yu, Wu Qi, and Daifu Zhong were all worthy of praise for their loyalty and dedication as ministers. Hong Yao served King Wen, and the Duke of Zhou assisted King Cheng; were they not also loyal and virtuous? In terms of ruler and minister, how do Shang Yu, Wu Qi, and Daifu Zhong compare to Hong Yao and the Duke of Zhou?" Ying Hou replied, "Shang Yu, Wu Qi, and Daifu Zhong are inferior." Cai Ze said, "Then, Your Majesty, you are benevolent and loyal, cherishing old friends. Your wise and virtuous ministers are as close as glue, never betraying your meritorious officials. How do you compare to Duke Xiao of Qin, King Dao of Chu, and the King of Yue?" Ying Hou said, "I do not know." Cai Ze said, "Now, Your Majesty's loyalty to ministers is no better than that of Duke Xiao of Qin, King Dao of Chu, and the King of Yue. Your Majesty's wisdom is sufficient to ensure the safety and well-being of Your Majesty and to govern effectively." "You have brought order and strengthened the army, quelled strife and resolved difficulties, expanded the land and increased grain production, enriched the country and families, strengthened the ruler, respected the state and glorified the ancestral temples, and none in the world dared to offend him. Your power shakes the land and your achievements extend far and wide, your fame will be passed down for a thousand generations. How do you compare to Shang Yang, Wu Qi, and Da Fu Zhong?" Ying Hou replied, "No." Cai Ze said, "Now, your loyalty to your ministers and your remembrance of old friends are not as great as those of Duke Xiao, King Dao, and Goujian, and your achievements, trust, and favor are not as great as those of Shang Yang, Wu Qi, and Da Fu Zhong. However, your rank and wealth surpass those of these three, yet you do not retire. I fear the consequences will be greater than those of these three. I am deeply concerned for you. As the saying goes, 'The sun at its zenith begins to decline, the full moon begins to wane.' Things at their peak will decline; this is the constant law of nature. Advancement and retreat, waxing and waning..." Adapting to changing times is the constant way of the sage. Therefore, "When the state is well-governed, serve; when the state is poorly governed, withdraw from public life." The sage said, "The flying dragon in the sky is auspicious to see a great man." "Wealth and honor gained unjustly are to me like floating clouds." Now, Your Majesty's grievances have been avenged and your kindness repaid; your desires are fulfilled, yet you have no plan to change course. I humbly believe this is unacceptable. Furthermore, the kingfisher, swan, rhinoceros, and elephant, though in their circumstances, were not immune to death, but they perished because they were tempted by bait. The wisdom of Su Qin and Zhi Bo was not insufficient to avoid humiliation and death, but they died because they were obsessed with insatiable greed. Therefore, the sage establishes rites and regulates desires, takes from the people with moderation, uses them at the right time, and employs them with restraint. Thus, his will is not excessive, his actions are not arrogant, and he is always in harmony with the Way without straying from it. Therefore, the world continues his rule without interruption. In the past, Duke Huan of Qi united nine times... The feudal lords, having unified the world, reached the Kuiqiu Assembly, but their arrogance led to the rebellion of nine states. King Fuchai of Wu, whose army was invincible, was so powerful and arrogant that he looked down upon the other feudal lords, even belittling Qi and Jin, ultimately leading to his death and the downfall of his kingdom. Xia Yu and the Grand Historian, whose shouts and cries terrified the army, died at the hands of ordinary men. All these examples illustrate the dangers of taking advantage of one's peak without returning to reason, and failing to embrace humility and frugality. Shang Yang, however, for Duke Xiao of Qin, clarified laws, prohibited wrongdoing, ensured rewards for those in high positions, punished those guilty, balanced power, rectified weights and measures, adjusted the scales, and abolished the traditional land division system. This allowed the people to focus on their livelihoods and unify their customs, encouraging farming and cultivating the land. Each household was free of distractions, and the people were trained in warfare. Thus, when the army moved, the territory expanded; when the army rested, the state prospered. Therefore, Qin became invincible, established its authority among the feudal lords, and became the Qin dynasty. The nation's achievements were complete, yet he was executed by being torn apart by chariots. Chu, with its vast territory spanning thousands of miles and a million soldiers wielding halberds, was challenged by Bai Qi, who led tens of thousands of troops. In one battle, he captured Yan and Ying, and burned Yiling. In another, he conquered Shu and Han in the south. He then crossed Han and Wei to attack the powerful Zhao, burying Ma Fu alive in the north, slaughtering over 400,000 people at Changping, where blood flowed like rivers and the roar of battle was deafening. He then besieged Handan, enabling Qin to establish its imperial dynasty. Chu and Zhao were the most powerful states in the land and enemies of Qin. From then on, Chu and Zhao were terrified and dared not attack Qin, all thanks to Bai Qi's power. He personally conquered over seventy cities; his achievements were complete, yet he was executed by being given a sword at Duyu. Wu Qi established laws for King Dao of Chu, diminishing the power of ministers, dismissing the incompetent, abolishing the useless, reducing unnecessary officials, and curbing private interests. The request to the gate, following the customs of Chu, prohibited travelers from entering, focused on cultivating the land and fighting, conquered Yangyue in the south, annexed Chen and Cai in the north, broke the scattered alliances, silenced those who spread rumors, banned factions to encourage the people, stabilized the government of Chu, made its army awe-inspiring throughout the world, and subdued the feudal lords. The work was accomplished, yet it ultimately crumbled. The minister Zhong, for the King of Yue, devised a profound and far-sighted plan, averting the danger at Kuaiji, turning defeat into survival, and humiliation into glory. He cultivated the land, opened up new fields, planted grain, led the people from all directions, and united the efforts of all, assisting the wise Goujian, avenging the enmity of Fuchai, and finally capturing the powerful Wu. Yue became a hegemon. The achievements were evident and the trust was established, yet Goujian ultimately betrayed and killed him. These four men, having achieved success, did not leave, and thus met their doom. This is what is meant by trusting but unable to yield, going forth but unable to return. Fan Li knew... He, transcending the world, lived a life of seclusion, like Tao Zhugong. Have you not observed those who gamble? Some desire a large bet, others a share of the spoils; these are all things you clearly understand. Now, as Prime Minister of Qin, your plans never leave your seat, your strategies never depart from the court, you control the feudal lords from your seat, you benefit the Three Rivers region, you strengthen Yiyang, you breach the perilous Yangchang Pass, you block the Taihang Road, and you cut off the routes of Fan and Zhonghang, preventing the six states from forming an alliance. A thousand-mile-long plank road connects to Shu and Han, making the world fear Qin. Qin's desires are fulfilled, and your achievements are immense. This is also the time for Qin to share the spoils. If you do not resign, you will become like Shang Yang, Bai Juyi, Wu Qi, and Dafu Zhong. I have heard it said, "Looking into water reveals one's appearance; looking into people reveals good or bad fortune." The Book of Documents says, "One cannot remain in a position of power for long after achieving success." The calamity of the four men... "Where shall you reside? Why not take this opportunity to relinquish your position as prime minister, yielding it to a worthy successor, and retire to a secluded life by the river? You would surely possess the integrity of Boyi, and remain a loyal subject for generations. You would be known as the sovereign for generations, and you would have the humility of Xu You and Yanling Jizi, and the longevity of the tall pine tree. Which would be better than ending in misfortune? Where shall you reside? Unable to restrain yourself, unable to make a decision, you will surely suffer the same fate as your four sons. The Book of Changes says, ' The dragon that soars too high will have regrets .' This refers to one who is unable to descend from a high position, unable to yield even when trusting, and unable to return even when going forth. I hope you will consider this carefully!" Yinghou said, "Excellent. I have heard that 'If one desires but does not know when to stop, one will lose what one desires; if one has but does not know when to stop, one will lose what one has.' I am honored by your instruction, sir, and I respectfully accept your guidance." Thereupon, he invited him to sit down, treating him as an honored guest. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 16.2. The following year, Qin troops besieged Handan for over a year, almost unable to escape.
[258 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.33 (yr 48; Handan campaign begins). In the tenth month of the forty-eighth year, Han surrendered Yong. The Qin army was divided into three armies. Lord Wu'an returned. Wang He was about to attack Zhao (Wu'an) Pi Lao, and captured it. Sima Geng pacified Taiyuan in the north and took all of Han's Shangdang. In the first month, the army withdrew and resumed defense of Shangdang. In the tenth month, the fifth-ranking official Ling attacked Zhao's Handan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 27.1. In the first year of King Xiao's reign, the Qin siege of Handan was lifted. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 103. In the eighth year, Lord Pingyuan went to Chu to request aid. Upon his return, Chu came to his aid, and Wei Prince Wuji also came to his aid, thus lifting the siege of Handan by Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 6.4. In the first month, all troops were withdrawn. 6.5. Lord Wu'an heard of this, and from then on, a grudge arose between him and Lord Ying. 7.1. In September, Qin launched another attack, sending Wang Ling, a high-ranking official, to attack Handan, the capital of Zhao. At that time, Wang Ling was ill and unable to lead the army. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 4.1. In Wei there was a recluse named Hou Ying, seventy years old, poor, who worked as a gatekeeper at the Yi Gate of Daliang. 4.2. The prince heard of him and went to invite him, intending to offer him a generous gift. Hou Ying refused, saying, "I have cultivated myself with integrity for decades, and I will not accept your wealth because of my poverty as a gatekeeper." The prince then held a grand banquet for his guests. After everyone was seated, the prince, with his entourage, left the left seat vacant and personally went to welcome Hou Ying. Hou Ying, adjusting his tattered clothes, rode directly to the prince and took the seat of honor, not yielding, wanting to observe the prince. The prince held the reins even more respectfully. 4.3. Hou Ying then said to the prince, "I have a guest in the market butcher's quarters; I wish you would deign to take my carriage to see him." The prince led his carriage into the market, and Hou Ying dismounted to meet his guest, Zhu Hai. Hou Ying deliberately stood for a long time, speaking with the guest and subtly observing the prince. The prince's expression became even more amiable. At that time, the hall was filled with Wei generals, ministers, members of the royal family, and guests, all waiting for the prince to raise his cup. The people of the market all watched the prince holding the reins. The entourage secretly cursed Hou Ying. Hou Sheng, seeing that the prince's expression remained unchanged, declined the guests and got into his carriage. Upon arriving home, the prince led Hou Sheng to the seat of honor and praised all the guests, who were all astonished. When the wine was flowing freely, the prince rose and offered a toast to Hou Sheng. Hou Sheng then said to the prince, "Today, I, Ying, have already done enough for you, my lord. I am but a gatekeeper at Yimen, yet you personally went to greet me in your carriage amidst the crowd. It would have been inappropriate for you to overstep your bounds, but you did. However, I wished to associate myself with your reputation, so I stood for a long time in the marketplace, allowing passersby to observe you. The more they watched, the more respectful you became. The people of the marketplace now consider me a petty person, but regard you as a virtuous gentleman who can humble himself before scholars." Thereupon, the wine was stopped, and Hou Sheng was thus treated as the honored guest. 5. Hou Sheng said to the prince, "The butcher I passed by was Zhu Hai. He is a wise man, but no one in the world knows him, so he hides in the butcher's quarters." The prince went to invite him several times, but Zhu Hai did not thank him again, which puzzled the prince. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 33. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... A few days later, he entered the court and said to King Zhaoxiang of Qin, "A new guest named Cai Ze has recently come from Shandong. He is an eloquent man, knowledgeable in the affairs of the Three Kings, the achievements of the Five Hegemons, and the changes in the world. He is capable of governing the Qin state. I have met many people, but none can compare to him. I dare to report this to King Zhaoxiang." King Zhaoxiang summoned him, spoke with him, and was greatly pleased, appointing him as a guest minister. Ying Hou then feigned illness and requested to return to his position as prime minister. King Zhaoxiang forced Ying Hou to rise, but Ying Hou then claimed to be ill and refused to return. Fan Sui was dismissed as prime minister, and King Zhaoxiang, having just been persuaded by Cai Ze's plan, appointed him as prime minister of Qin, and he went east to reclaim the Zhou dynasty. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 16.3. Only the intervention of the states of Chu and Wei relieved the siege. King Zhao, remembering the earlier words of Zhao Kuo's mother, ultimately did not execute him.
[257 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 79. In the fifty-eighth year, the three states of Jin opposed Qin. Zhou sent his prime minister to Qin, but due to Qin's perceived weakness, he was sent back. A guest said to the prime minister, "The strength of Qin is uncertain. Qin wants to know the situation of the three states. You should quickly see the King of Qin and say, 'Please allow me to hear about the changes in the east.' The King of Qin will surely value you. If he values you, Qin will value Zhou, and Zhou will use this to take over Qin; if Qi values you, then Zhou will have the resources to take over Qi. This shows that Zhou will never lose the friendship with important states." Qin believed Zhou and sent troops to attack the three states of Jin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.34 (yr 49; reinforcements; generals). In the first month of the forty-ninth year, more soldiers were sent to assist Ling. Ling fought poorly and was dismissed, and Wang He replaced him as general. In the tenth month, General Zhang Tang attacked Wei, but Cai Wei Juan did not defend it and was executed. In the tenth month of the fiftieth year, Lord Wu'an Bai Qi was convicted of a crime and demoted to a common soldier, then transferred to Yinmi. Zhang Tang attacked Zheng and captured it. In the twelfth month, more soldiers were sent to the vicinity of Fencheng. Lord Wu'an Bai Qi was convicted of a crime and died. He attacked Handan but failed to capture it, so he left and fled back to Fencheng. In the second month, he attacked the Jin army, beheading six thousand, and causing twenty thousand Jin and Chu soldiers to drown in the river. He attacked Fencheng and then followed Tang to capture Ningxinzhong, which was renamed Anyang. The first bridge across the river. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 96.1. In the sixth year, Qin besieged Handan, and Zhao appealed to Chu for help. Chu sent General Jingyang to rescue Zhao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 7.2. In January of the forty-ninth year, Wang Ling attacked Handan but made little progress. Qin then sent more troops to assist him. Five officers of Wang Ling's army were killed. Wang Ling recovered from his illness, and 7.3. the King of Qin wanted to replace him as general. Wang Ling said, "Handan is not easy to attack. Moreover, reinforcements from other states have arrived, and those states have long resented Qin. Although Qin has defeated the army at Changping, more than half of Qin's soldiers have died, and the country is depleted. To fight for another's capital across the rivers and mountains, with Zhao responding internally and the other states attacking externally, will surely defeat Qin's army. This is unacceptable." The King of Qin appointed him himself, but he did not go. He then sent Ying Hou to request him to go, but Wang Ling ultimately declined, claiming illness. 8.1. King Zhaoxiang of Qin sent Wang He to replace Ling as general, and in August and September they besieged Handan, but could not capture it. 8.2. Chu sent Lord Chunshen and the Prince of Wei with hundreds of thousands of troops to attack the Qin army, inflicting heavy losses on the Qin army. Lord Wu'an said, "Qin did not heed my advice; what will become of us now!" 8.3. King Zhaoxiang of Qin, upon hearing this, was furious and forcibly summoned Lord Wu'an, who then claimed to be ill. Lord Yinghou pleaded with him to rise, but he refused. 8.4. Therefore, Lord Wu'an was demoted to a common soldier and exiled to Yinmi. Lord Wu'an was ill and unable to go. 8.5. Three months later, the allied states launched a fierce attack on the Qin army, which was repeatedly repelled, and messengers arrived daily. 8.6. King Zhaoxiang of Qin then sent someone to dismiss Bai Qi, forbidding him from staying in Xianyang. 8.7. After Lord Wu'an departed, he traveled ten li west of Xianyang's west gate to Duyu. King Zhaoxiang of Qin, along with Lord Yinghou and other ministers, discussed the matter, saying, "Bai Qi's exile shows he is still resentful and has much to say." 8.8. King Zhaoxiang then sent a messenger to give him a sword, and he committed suicide. 8.9. Lord Wu'an drew his sword to commit suicide, saying, "What crime have I committed against Heaven to deserve this?" After a long while, he said, "I deserve to die. In the Battle of Changping, hundreds of thousands of Zhao soldiers surrendered, and I tricked them and buried them all alive. That is enough to warrant death." He then committed suicide. Lord Wu'an died in the eleventh month of the fiftieth year of King Zhaoxiang of Qin. He died unjustly, and the people of Qin pitied him, and his villages and towns all offered sacrifices to him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 6.2. The elder sister of the prince, the wife of Lord Pingyuan, the younger brother of King Huiwen of Zhao, repeatedly sent letters to 6.3. the King of Wei and the prince, requesting aid from Wei. The King of Wei sent General Jin Bi with 100,000 troops to rescue Zhao. The King of Qin sent an envoy to the King of Wei, saying, "I will capture Zhao soon, and any of the other states that dare to come to its aid will be attacked first after Zhao is captured." The King of Wei was afraid and sent someone to stop Jin Bi, leaving his army encamped at Ye, ostensibly to rescue Zhao, but in reality, he was holding both sides and observing the situation. The envoys of Lord Pingyuan, a constant stream of officials, visited Wei and rebuked the prince, saying, "The reason I, Sheng, allied with you through marriage was because of your noble character and ability to help those in distress. Now, Handan will surrender to Qin soon, and Wei's aid will not come. Where is your ability to help those in distress? Moreover, even if you disregard me and abandon me to surrender to Qin, do you not pity your sister?" The prince was troubled by this and repeatedly pleaded with the King of Wei, with his guests and debaters offering countless arguments. King Wei feared Qin and ultimately did not heed the prince's advice. The prince, realizing he could not obtain the prince's favor from the king, decided not to live alone but to ensure Zhao's demise. He then invited guests and gathered over a hundred chariots and horses, intending to go with them to the Qin army and die alongside Zhao. 7.1. Passing through Yimen, the prince met Hou Sheng and explained his intention to die for the Qin army. He then took his leave, and Hou Sheng said, "My lord, please do your best; this old minister cannot follow you." After traveling several miles, the prince felt displeased and said, "I have treated Hou Sheng with utmost care, as everyone in the world knows. Now that I am about to die, Hou Sheng has not uttered a single word to see me off. Have I failed him?" He then turned his carriage back and asked Hou Sheng about it. Hou Sheng laughed and said, "I knew you would return, my lord." Hou Sheng said, "My lord admires scholars, and his name is known throughout the land. Now, in this time of trouble, you have no other reason to go to the Qin army. It is like throwing meat to a hungry tiger—what good will that do? Why bother with guests? However, my lord has treated me well, and since I did not see you off, I know you resent my departure and have returned." The prince bowed twice and then asked... 7.2. Hou Sheng then dismissed the others and whispered, "I've heard that Jin Bi's military tally is always kept in the king's bedchamber, and Ru Ji, being the king's favorite, has easy access to the bedchamber and is capable of stealing it. I've also heard that Ru Ji's father was murdered, and Ru Ji has supported him for three years. From the king down, everyone wants to avenge her father, but none can. Ru Ji wept for the prince, and the prince sent a guest to behead the murderer and present the head to Ru Ji. Ru Ji is willing to die for the prince, without hesitation, but she has no way to do so. If the prince sincerely asks Ru Ji for help, she will surely agree. Then, with the tiger tally, we can seize Jin Bi's army, rescue Zhao in the north, and repel Qin in the west—this is the kind of campaign that the Five Hegemons would wage." The prince followed his plan and asked Ru Ji for help. Ru Ji indeed stole Jin Bi's military tally and gave it to the prince. 8. As the prince was about to depart, Hou Sheng said, "When a general is in the field, he may disobey orders from his lord for the sake of the state. If you, my lord, obtain the tally, and Jin Bi refuses to provide you with troops and then requests them again, the situation will surely be perilous. My guest, the butcher Zhu Hai, can accompany you; he is a strong and capable man. If Jin Bi listens, great; if he does not, you can send him to attack." The prince then wept. Hou Sheng said, "Does the prince fear death? Why are you weeping?" The prince replied, "Jin Bi is a seasoned general; I fear he will not listen and will surely kill me. That is why I weep, not because I fear death." The prince then invited Zhu Hai. Zhu Hai laughed and said, "I am but a butcher in the marketplace, yet the prince has repeatedly spared my life. The reason I did not repay his kindness was that I thought small gestures were useless. Now that the prince is in danger, this is the time for me to serve him." He then went with the prince. The prince went to thank Hou Sheng. Hou Sheng said, "I should go, but I am too old. Please allow me to count the days until the day you arrive at Jin Bi's army, then I will face north and commit suicide to see you off." The prince then departed. 9.1. Upon arriving at Ye, he forged an order from the King of Wei to replace Jin Bi. Jin Bi, having obtained the tally, became suspicious. He raised his hand to the prince and said, "Now I command 100,000 troops, stationed on the border, a vital responsibility for the state. How can you expect me to replace you alone?" The prince seemed unwilling to listen. Zhu Hai, carrying a forty-pound iron mace, killed Jin Bi, and the prince then took command of Jin Bi's army. He ordered his troops, "If both father and son are in the army, the father returns home; if both brothers are in the army, the elder brother returns home; if an only son has no brothers, he returns home to care for them." He selected 80,000 soldiers and advanced to attack the Qin army. The Qin army withdrew, and the prince was able to relieve Handan and save Zhao. The King of Zhao and Lord Pingyuan personally welcomed the prince at the border. Lord Pingyuan, carrying an arrow, led the way for the prince. The King of Zhao bowed twice and said, "Since ancient times, no wise man has surpassed the prince." At that time, Lord Pingyuan dared not compare himself to others. The prince made a farewell to Hou Sheng. Upon arriving at the army camp, Hou Sheng indeed committed suicide facing north.
[256 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 80. In the fifty-ninth year, Qin captured the city of Hanyang and its millet. Western Zhou, fearing for its own safety, betrayed Qin and formed an alliance with other states, leading the elite army of the realm out of Yique to attack Qin, preventing Qin from reaching Hanyang. King Zhaoxiang of Qin was enraged and sent General Jiu to attack Western Zhou. The ruler of Western Zhou fled to Qin, bowed his head in remorse, and surrendered all thirty-six of his cities and thirty thousand people. Qin accepted the surrender and returned the ruler to Zhou. 81.1. After the deaths of King Nan of Zhou, the people of Zhou fled eastward. Qin seized the Nine Tripods and other precious artifacts, and relocated the Duke of Western Zhou to Danhu. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 67.1 (King Zhaoxiang yr 51). In the fifty-first year, General Jiu attacked Han, capturing Yangcheng and Fushu, and beheading 40,000. He attacked Zhao, capturing over twenty counties and taking 90,000 heads. The ruler of Western Zhou betrayed Qin, forming an alliance with the other states, and led the elite troops of the realm out of Yique to attack Qin, ordering Qin not to communicate with Yangcheng. Qin then sent General Jiu to attack Western Zhou. The ruler of Western Zhou fled and surrendered, bowing his head in repentance, and surrendering all thirty-six cities and thirty thousand people. The King of Qin accepted the surrender and returned the ruler to Zhou. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 96.2. In the seventh year, he arrived at Xinzhong. The Qin army withdrew. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 104. In the tenth year, Yan attacked Changzhuang and captured it in May. Zhao generals Yue Cheng and Qing She attacked and defeated Qin's Xinliang army. The crown prince died. Qin attacked and captured Western Zhou. Tu Fuqi was exiled. In the eleventh year, Yuanshi was fortified and Shangyuan was established. Lord Wuyang, Zheng Anping, died, and his territory was recovered. In the twelfth year, Handan was burned down. In the fourteenth year, Lord Pingyuan, Zhao Sheng, died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 54.1. In the sixteenth year, Qin destroyed Zhou. The Queen died. In the twenty-third year, Qin established the Eastern Commandery. In the twenty-eighth year, the King paid homage to Qin, and King Zheng of Qin held a banquet in Xianyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 10.1. King Wei was furious that Prince Zizhi had stolen his military tally and falsely accused Jin Bi of murder, a fact Prince Zizhi himself was aware of. Having already repelled Qin and saved Zhao, King Wei sent a general to return the army to Wei, while Prince Zizhi alone remained in Zhao with a guest. King Xiaocheng of Zhao, grateful for Prince Zizhi's act of falsely seizing Jin Bi's troops to save Zhao, consulted with Lord Pingyuan and enfeoffed Prince Zizhi with five cities. Upon hearing this, Prince Zizhi became arrogant and self-satisfied. A guest advised him, "Some things cannot be forgotten, and some things cannot be ignored. You should not forget the kindness shown to you by the lady; you should forget the kindness shown to others. Moreover, by falsely accusing King Wei of seizing Jin Bi's troops to save Zhao, you have rendered meritorious service to Zhao, but you are not a loyal subject to Wei. You, Prince Zizhi, are arrogant and self-satisfied; I urge you not to do so." Prince Zizhi then stood in self-reproach, seemingly unable to forgive himself. King Zhao swept the steps to welcome him, treating him with the courtesy due to a host, and led Prince Zizhi to the west steps. Prince Zizhi demurred and declined, ascending the east steps instead. He confessed his sins, admitting his failure to Wei and his lack of service to Zhao. King Zhao served him wine until dusk, but could not bear to offer the five cities, citing the prince's reluctance. The prince ultimately remained in Zhao. 10.2. King Zhao granted the prince Hao as his fief, and Wei also offered him Xinling. The prince remained in Zhao.
[255 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 66.35 (yr 51-ish compressed; executions; Anyang bridge). In the tenth month of the forty-eighth year, Han surrendered Yong. The Qin army was divided into three armies. Lord Wu'an returned. Wang He was about to attack Zhao (Wu'an) Pi Lao, and captured it. Sima Geng pacified Taiyuan in the north and took all of Han's Shangdang. In the first month, the army withdrew and resumed defense of Shangdang. In the tenth month, the fifth-ranking official Ling attacked Zhao's Handan. In the first month of the forty-ninth year, more soldiers were sent to assist Ling. Ling fought poorly and was dismissed, and Wang He replaced him as general. In the tenth month, General Zhang Tang attacked Wei, but Cai Wei Juan did not defend it and was executed. In the tenth month of the fiftieth year, Lord Wu'an Bai Qi was convicted of a crime and demoted to a common soldier, then transferred to Yinmi. Zhang Tang attacked Zheng and captured it. In the twelfth month, more soldiers were sent to the vicinity of Fencheng. Lord Wu'an Bai Qi was convicted of a crime and died. He attacked Handan but failed to capture it, so he left and fled back to Fencheng. In the second month, he attacked the Jin army, beheading six thousand, and causing twenty thousand Jin and Chu soldiers to drown in the river. He attacked Fencheng and then followed Tang to capture Ningxinzhong, which was renamed Anyang. The first bridge across the river. 67.2 (yr 52; nine tripods taken). In the fifty-second year, the people of Zhou fled east, and their nine tripods were taken to Qin. The early Zhou dynasty collapsed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 27.2. He died three years later, and his son, King Xi, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 11. The prince heard that there were two recluses in Zhao, Mao Gong and Xue Gong, hidden among gamblers and in the homes of peddlers. The prince wished to meet them, but they both hid themselves and refused to see him. The prince, having learned their whereabouts, strolled over and befriended the two men, enjoying himself immensely. Lord Pingyuan, hearing of this, said to his wife, "I first heard that your brother, the prince, was unparalleled in the world. Now I hear that he foolishly associates with gamblers and peddlers. The prince is a vain man." His wife told the prince this. The prince then apologized to his wife and left, saying, "I first heard of Lord Pingyuan's virtue, which is why I betrayed the King of Wei to rescue Zhao, to praise Lord Pingyuan. Lord Pingyuan's outings are merely a display of extravagance; he does not seek out worthy men. When I was in Daliang, I often heard of the virtue of these two men, but upon arriving in Zhao, I feared I would not be able to meet them. Even if I were to associate with them, I feared they would not want me. Now Lord Pingyuan considers me a disgrace; I am not worthy to associate with them." He then disguised himself and left. His wife told Lord Pingyuan everything. Lord Pingyuan then removed his hat and apologized, insisting that the prince stay. When Lord Pingyuan's retainers heard of this, half of them left Lord Pingyuan and went to the young master. Scholars from all over the world also went to the young master, and the young master became a favorite of Lord Pingyuan's guests. [Sima Qian, Shiji 79 — Fan Sui and Cai Ze Liezhuan] 34. Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Cai Ze served as prime minister of Qin for several months, but some people disliked him. Fearing execution, he resigned due to illness and returned to his post as prime minister, taking the title of Lord Gangcheng. He lived in Qin for more than ten years, serving King Zhaoxiang, King Xiaowen, and King Zhuangxiang. He eventually served the First Emperor of Qin and became Qin's envoy to Yan. Three years later, Yan sent Prince Dan as a hostage to Qin. 35 (discursive). Fan Sui and Cai Ze... Sima Qian said: Han Fei said, "Long sleeves are good for dancing, and much money is good for trading," how true this is! Fan Sui and Cai Ze were considered all kinds of debaters, yet they traveled among the feudal lords until old age without finding success. This was not because their strategies were incompetent, but because their persuasiveness was weak. When these two men, having traveled to Qin, successively became ministers and achieved great merit throughout the land, it was certainly due to the difference in power. However, even scholars sometimes find their paths cross by chance. Many virtuous men, like these two, could not fully realize their potential; how can we possibly recount them all? But how could these two men have been motivated without facing hardship?
[254 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 105. In the fifteenth year, Wei Wen enfeoffed Chancellor Lian Po as Lord Xinping. King Yan ordered Chancellor Li Fu to persuade Xiang to prepare wine for King Zhao with 500 gold pieces. Xiang returned and reported to King Yan, saying, "The able-bodied men of Zhao have all died at Changping; their orphans are not yet grown. We can attack them." King Yan summoned Lord Changguo, Yue Xian, and asked him. Yue Xian replied, "Zhao is a country constantly at war; its people are skilled in warfare. We cannot attack them." King Yan said, "If I attack a smaller force with a larger one, two against one, is that acceptable?" Yue Xian replied, "No." King Yan said, "If I attack a smaller force with five against one, is that acceptable?" Yue Xian replied, "No." King Yan was furious. All the ministers thought it was acceptable. The Yan army raised two armies with 2,000 chariots. Li Fu led the attack on Hao, and Qing Qin led the attack on Dai. Lian Po, as the general of Zhao, defeated and killed Li Fu, and captured Qing Qin and Yue Xian.
[253 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 68.1 (yr 53). In the fifty-third year, guests came from all over the world. After the death of King Wei, Qin sent an envoy to attack Wei and capture the city of Wu. King Han came to court, and Wei surrendered its kingdom and submitted to his orders. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 106. In the sixteenth year, Lian Po besieged Yan. Yue Cheng was appointed Lord Wuxiang. In the seventeenth year, the acting prime minister and general Lord Wuxiang attacked Yan and besieged its state. In the eighteenth year, Yanling Jun led troops to assist Wei in attacking Yan, following the prime minister Lord Xinping. Qin captured thirty-seven cities from Yuci. In the nineteenth year, Zhao and Yan exchanged land: Zhao gave Longdui, Fenmen, and Linle to Yan; Yan gave Ge, Wuyang, and Pingshu to Zhao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 17. Five years after the siege of Handan was lifted, Yan, following the advice of Li Fu, said, "The strong men of Zhao have all perished at Changping, and their orphans are not yet grown," and launched an attack on Zhao. Zhao sent Lian Po as general, who attacked and decisively defeated the Yan army at Hao, killing Li Fu, and then besieged Yan. Yan ceded five cities to sue for peace, which Zhao granted. Zhao then appointed Lian Po as Lord Xinping and acting prime minister. 18.1. When Lian Po was dismissed from his post at Changping and returned home, he had lost power, and all his former retainers had left. When he was reinstated as a general, his retainers returned. Lian Po said, "My retainers have left!" One of them replied, "Alas! Why did you realize this so late? In this world, relationships are based on market principles. When you are powerful, I follow you; when you are powerless, I leave. This is the natural order. What is there to complain about?"
[252 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 68.2 (yr 54). In the fifty-fourth year, the king went to the suburbs to meet the Supreme God at Yong.
[251 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 68.3 (yr 56; Zhaoxiang dies). In the autumn of the fifty-sixth year, King Zhaoxiang died, and his son King Xiaowen ascended the throne. He honored the eight daughters of Tang as the Dowager Queen of Tang and buried them together with the former king. King Han wore mourning clothes and went to the ancestral temple to pay his respects. All the feudal lords sent their generals and ministers to pay their respects and oversee the funeral arrangements. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 28.1. In the fourth year of King Xi's reign, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. 28.2. King Xi of Yan ordered his minister, Li Fu, to make an alliance with Zhao, offering 500 gold pieces as a gift of wine to the King of Zhao. 28.3. Li Fu returned and reported to King Xi, "The able-bodied men of Zhao have all died at Changping, and his orphans are still young; we can attack them." King Xi summoned Lord Changguo, Yue Xian, and asked him. Yue Xian replied, "Zhao is a country that has fought four wars; its people are skilled in warfare, and we cannot attack it." King Xi said, "I will attack one with five." Yue Xian replied, "No." King Xi was furious, but all his ministers thought it was a good idea. He then raised two armies with 2,000 chariots; Li Fu led the attack on Hao, and Qing Qin attacked Dai. 28.4. Only the Grand Master Jiang Qu said to King Xi, "Making an alliance with someone, offering 500 gold pieces as a gift of wine to their king, only to have the messenger report back and turn against them, is inauspicious; the war will be unsuccessful." King Xi did not listen and personally led a detachment to follow. Jiang Qu pulled on King Xi's ribbon to stop him, saying, "Your Majesty must not go yourself; going will be unsuccessful." King Xi stepped on his foot. Jiang Qu wept and said, "I did not act for myself, but for the king!" [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 96.3. In the twelfth year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died, and the King of Chu sent Lord Chunshen to offer condolences in Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 94. In the thirty-third year, King Huiwen died, and his son, Prince Dan, ascended the throne as King Xiaocheng. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 31.5. In the first year of King Huanhui's reign, Qin attacked Yan. In the ninth year, Qin captured Xing and fortified the area near Fen. In the tenth year, Qin attacked us at Taihang, and the governor of Shangdang surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. In the fourteenth year, Qin captured Shangdang from Zhao, killing over 400,000 soldiers of Ma Fu at Changping. In the seventeenth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu. In the twenty-second year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin captured Chenggao and Xingyang. In the twenty-sixth year, Qin completely captured Shangdang. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin captured thirteen cities.
[250 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 69 (King Xiaowen yr 1; dies after 3 days) (Wikipedia). In the first year of King Xiaowen's reign, he pardoned criminals, honored meritorious officials of the previous king, rewarded relatives, and relaxed restrictions on imperial gardens. After the mourning period ended, King Xiaowen ascended the throne on the day of Ji Hai in the tenth month, and died on the day of Xin Chou three days later. His son, King Zhuangxiang, succeeded him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 28.5. The Yan army reached Songzi, and Zhao sent Lian Po as general, who defeated Li Fu at Hao. [Yue Cheng] defeated Qing Qin (Yue Cheng) at Dai. Yue Xian fled to Zhao. Lian Po pursued him for over five hundred li and besieged his state. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 95. In the first year of King Xiaocheng's reign, Qin attacked and captured three cities. The newly enthroned King of Zhao, with the Queen Dowager in power, was further pressured by Qin. Zhao sought help from Qi, which said, "We will only send troops if Chang'an Jun is offered as a hostage." The Queen Dowager refused, but her ministers strongly advised against it. The Queen Dowager declared to her attendants, "Anyone who mentions Chang'an Jun as a hostage again, I will spit in their face." The Left Minister, Chu Long, requested an audience with the Queen Dowager, who, in a fit of anger, allowed him to enter. He slowly approached and sat down, apologizing, "This old minister has a foot ailment and cannot walk quickly, thus I have been unable to see you for a long time. I humbly apologize, but I fear Your Majesty is suffering, therefore I wish to see you." The Queen Dowager said, "This old minister relies on a palanquin to travel." She asked, "Is your appetite diminished?" He replied, "I rely on porridge." He said, "This old minister has little appetite when idle, but I force myself to walk three or four li a day, which slightly improves my appetite and is good for my health." The Queen Dowager said, "This old minister cannot." The Queen Dowager's displeasure lessened slightly. Zuo Shigong said, "My humble son, Shuqi, is the youngest and most unworthy. I am old and frail, and I secretly pity and love him. I wish to fill the vacancy of the Black Robe and guard the palace, even at the risk of my life." The Empress Dowager said, "You are granted my request. How old is he?" He replied, "Fifteen years old. Though young, I wish to entrust him to you before he dies." The Empress Dowager said, "Do men also love their youngest sons?" He replied, "More than women." The Empress Dowager laughed and said, "Women are quite different." He replied, "I secretly believe that your love for the Queen of Yan is greater than that for Lord Chang'an." The Empress Dowager said, "You are mistaken. It is not as great as Lord Chang'an's love." Zuo Shigong said, "Parents who love their children plan far ahead for them. When the Queen of Yan was sent off, she held his heels and wept, thinking of his distant journey and grieving for him. After he left, it was not that she did not miss him; during sacrifices, she prayed, 'May he never return.' Was this not a long-term plan, for the continuation of her descendants?" "Is it the king?" The Queen Dowager said, "Yes." The Left Master said, "From three generations ago, among the descendants of the ruler of Zhao who were marquises, are there any still living ones?" He said, "No." He said, "Besides Zhao, are there any other marquises still living?" He said, "This old woman has not heard of any." He said, "This is because those who are close to the ruler suffer misfortune themselves, and those who are distant suffer misfortune to their descendants. Are the sons of rulers who are marquises not good? They hold high positions but have no merit, receive generous stipends but have no labor, and yet they possess many powerful weapons. Now, you have honored Lord Chang'an with a high position and granted him fertile land and many powerful weapons, but you have not yet made him contribute to the country. If the emperor were to die, how would Lord Chang'an entrust himself to Zhao? This old minister thinks that your plan for Lord Chang'an is short-sighted, so I think you do not love him as much as the Queen of Yan." The Queen Dowager said, "Very well, let the prince do as he pleases." So she arranged for Lord Chang'an to have a hundred chariots and send him as a hostage to Qi, and the Qi army then came out.
[249 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 81.2. Seven years later, King Zhuangxiang of Qin destroyed Eastern (Western) Zhou. Both Eastern and Western Zhou fell to Qin, and Zhou ceased to be worshipped. [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 70.1 (King Zhuangxiang yr 1; Eastern Zhou annexed) (Wikipedia). In the first year of King Zhuangxiang's reign, a general amnesty was granted to criminals, meritorious officials of the former kings were honored, and benevolence was bestowed upon relatives and friends and benefits were extended to the people. The ruler of Eastern Zhou conspired with other feudal lords against Qin, but Qin sent its prime minister, Lü Buwei, to execute him and annex his entire kingdom. Qin did not extinguish the Zhou's ancestral sacrifices, granting the land of Yangren to the ruler of Zhou to continue his ancestral rites. Meng Ao was sent to attack Han, and Han surrendered Chenggao and Gong. Qin's borders extended to Daliang, and the Sanchuan Commandery was established for the first time. [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 28.6. The Yan people sued for peace, but the Zhao people refused, insisting that Jiang Qu be placed in charge of the peace. The Yan prime minister placed Jiang Qu in charge of the peace. 28.7. Zhao listened to Jiang Qu and lifted the siege of Yan. 29.1. In the sixth year, Qin conquered Eastern (Western) Zhou and established the Sanchuan Commandery. In the seventh year, Qin captured thirty-seven cities of Yuci from Zhao and established the Dayuan Commandery. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 96. When Ziyi heard this, he said, "Even the son of a ruler, a member of his own flesh and blood, cannot uphold the honor without merit, the stipend without labor, and the preciousness of gold and jade. How much less can I?" [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 31.6. In the first year of King Huanhui's reign, Qin attacked Yan. In the ninth year, Qin captured Xing and fortified the area near Fen. In the tenth year, Qin attacked us at Taihang, and the governor of Shangdang surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. In the fourteenth year, Qin captured Shangdang from Zhao, killing over 400,000 soldiers of Ma Fu at Changping. In the seventeenth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu. In the twenty-second year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin captured Chenggao and Xingyang. In the twenty-sixth year, Qin completely captured Shangdang. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin captured thirteen cities.
[248 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 70.2 (yr 2; Meng Ao vs Zhao). In the second year, Meng Ao was sent to attack Zhao, and Taiyuan was captured.
[247 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 70.3 (yr 3; cities taken; eclipse note). In the third year, Meng Ao attacked and captured Gaodu and Ji of Wei. He attacked Yuci, Xincheng, and Langmeng of Zhao, capturing thirty-seven cities. A solar eclipse occurred in the fourth month. (In the fourth year) Wang He attacked Shangdang. The Taiyuan Commandery was established for the first time. Wei general Wuji led troops from five states to attack Qin, but Qin retreated beyond the Yellow River. Meng Ao was defeated and withdrew. 70.4 (yr 4; King dies; Zheng succeeds). On the Bingwu day of the fifth month, King Zhuangxiang died, and his son Zheng ascended the throne, becoming Qin Shi Huang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 97. Lord Tian Dan of Qi led the Zhao army to attack Zhongyang of Yan and captured it. He then attacked Zhuren of Han and captured it. Two years later, Queen Huiwen died. Tian Dan became prime minister. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 12. The prince remained in Zhao for ten years without returning. When Qin heard that the prince was in Zhao, it launched a relentless eastward campaign against Wei. The King of Wei was alarmed and sent an envoy to summon the prince. Fearing the king's wrath, the prince warned his retainers, "Anyone who dares to act as an envoy to the King of Wei will be put to death." His guests all turned against Wei and went to Zhao, none daring to persuade the prince to return. Mao Gong and Xue Gong went to see the prince and said, "The reason you are valued in Zhao and renowned among the feudal lords is solely because of your presence in Wei. Now Qin is attacking Wei, and Wei is in dire straits, yet you show no concern. If Qin were to destroy Daliang and raze the ancestral temples of your ancestors, how would you face the world?" Before they finished speaking, the prince's expression changed drastically, and he immediately ordered his carriage to return to Wei to rescue it. 13.1. When the King of Wei met the prince, they wept together. The King then bestowed upon the prince the seal of the Supreme General, and the prince took command. In the thirtieth year of King Anli of Wei, the prince sent envoys to inform all the feudal lords. Upon hearing of the prince's generalship, each feudal lord dispatched generals and troops to aid Wei. 13.2. The prince led the armies of five states and defeated the Qin army beyond the Yellow River, forcing Meng Ao to flee. He then pursued the victorious Qin army to Hangu Pass, where he suppressed the Qin troops, who dared not venture out. At that time, the prince's prestige shook the world. Guests from the feudal lords presented him with military strategies, which the prince named and attributed to them all. Thus, the common people referred to it as the "Military Strategies of the Prince of Wei." [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 18.2. Six years later, Zhao sent Lian Po to attack Fanyang of Wei, and he captured it.
[246 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 29.2. In the ninth year, King Zheng of Qin ascended the throne. In the tenth year, Zhao sent Lian Po to attack Fanyang, which was captured. King Xiaocheng of Zhao died, and King Daoxiang of Zhao ascended the throne. Zhao sent Yue Cheng to replace Lian Po, but Lian Po refused and attacked Yue Cheng. Yue Cheng fled, and Lian Po fled to Daliang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 96.4. In the sixteenth year, King Zhuangxiang of Qin died, and King Zhao Zheng of Qin ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 31.7. In the first year of King Huanhui's reign, Qin attacked Yan. In the ninth year, Qin captured Xing and fortified the area near Fen. In the tenth year, Qin attacked us at Taihang, and the governor of Shangdang surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. In the fourteenth year, Qin captured Shangdang from Zhao, killing over 400,000 soldiers of Ma Fu at Changping. In the seventeenth year, Qin captured Yangcheng and Fushu. In the twenty-second year, King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. In the twenty-fourth year, Qin captured Chenggao and Xingyang. In the twenty-sixth year, Qin completely captured Shangdang. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin captured thirteen cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 14.1. The King of Qin was troubled by this, so he sent ten thousand catties of gold to Wei to find a guest from Jin Bi, who then slandered the prince to the King of Wei, saying, "The prince has been in exile for ten years, and now he is a general of Wei, with all the generals of the other states under his command. The other states only know the prince of Wei, not the King of Wei. The prince also intends to take this opportunity to establish himself as king, and the other states, fearing his power, are about to jointly support him." Qin sent envoys several times to spread rumors, falsely congratulating the prince on his ascension to the throne of Wei. The King of Wei heard these slanders daily and could not help but believe them. In the end, he sent someone to replace the prince as general.
[245 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 19.1. King Xiaocheng of Zhao died,
[244 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 29.3. In the twelfth year, Zhao sent Li Mu to attack Yan and captured Wusui and Fangcheng. Ju Xin, formerly from Zhao, was on good terms with Pang Nuan, but later fled to Yan. Yan saw that Zhao was repeatedly besieged by Qin, and Lian Po had left, so they appointed Pang Nuan as general, intending to use Zhao's forces to attack Zhao. They asked Ju Xin, who said, "Pang Nuan is easy to deal with." Yan sent Ju Xin to attack Zhao, but Zhao sent Pang Nuan to attack, capturing 20,000 Yan troops and killing Ju Xin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 19.2. and his son King Daoxiang ascended the throne, replacing Lian Po with Yue Cheng. Lian Po was enraged and attacked Yue Cheng, who fled. Lian Po then fled to Daliang in Wei. 22 (≈date; early phase of Li Mu frontier command). Li Mu was a capable general on the northern border of Zhao. He was stationed at Dai and Yanmen to defend against the Xiongnu. He appointed officials at his own discretion, and all market taxes were collected into the Mo Treasury to fund the soldiers' expenses. He slaughtered several oxen daily to feed his soldiers, trained them in archery and horsemanship, maintained strict watchtowers, conducted frequent espionage, and treated his soldiers generously. He issued a pact: "If the Xiongnu invade, immediately enter and secure your position; anyone who dares to capture prisoners will be executed." Whenever the Xiongnu invaded, they maintained strict watchtowers and immediately entered to secure their position, daring not to fight. This continued for several years without any losses. However, the Xiongnu considered Li Mu cowardly, and even the Zhao border troops thought their general was cowardly. The King of Zhao reprimanded Li Mu, but Li Mu remained unchanged. The King of Zhao was angry and summoned him, replacing him with another general. 25.1. In the first year of King Daoxiang of Zhao, after Lian Po fled to Wei, Zhao sent Li Mu to attack Yan, capturing Wusui and Fangcheng.
[243 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 98. Four years later, the king dreamt of wearing a robe with one side hanging down, riding a flying dragon to heaven, but fell before reaching the top, and saw piles of gold and jade like mountains. The next day, the king summoned the diviner Gan to interpret the dream, who said: "Dreaming of wearing a robe with one side hanging down signifies misfortune. Dreaming of riding a flying dragon to heaven but falling before reaching the top signifies having spirit but no substance. Seeing piles of gold and jade like mountains signifies worry." [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 14.2. The prince, knowing he had been ruined again by slander, feigned illness and stopped attending court. He spent his nights drinking with his guests, indulging in fine wine and frequenting women. He indulged in this drinking and revelry day and night for four years, eventually dying from alcoholism. That same year, King Anli of Wei also died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 19.3. The following year, Zhao appointed Li Mu as general to attack Yan, capturing Wusui and Fangcheng. 23 (≈date; after Li Mu’s recall). For over a year, the Xiongnu frequently attacked, and the king would engage them in battle. Each battle ended in defeat, with heavy losses and the border areas unable to cultivate land or raise livestock. The king again requested Li Mu's assistance. Li Mu refused to leave his residence, insisting on being ill. The king then forced him to rise again and appoint him to lead the troops. Li Mu said, "If Your Majesty insists on employing me, I will do as before, and only then will I dare to obey your command." The king agreed.
[242 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 29.4. Qin captured twenty cities of Wei and established the Dong Commandery. In the nineteenth year, Qin captured nine cities of Ye from Zhao. King Daoxiang of Zhao died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 15.1. Upon hearing of the death of the prince, Qin sent Meng Ao to attack Wei, capturing twenty cities and establishing the Eastern Commandery. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 20 (≈date; during Qin pressure in Daoxiang reign). Lian Po had been stationed in Liang for a long time, but Wei could not trust him. Zhao had been repeatedly besieged by Qin troops, and the King of Zhao longed to regain Lian Po's services, as did Lian Po. The King of Zhao sent an envoy to see if Lian Po was still capable. Guo Kai, Lian Po's enemy, bribed the envoy with gold to slander him. When the Zhao envoy met Lian Po, Lian Po ate a dou of rice and ten jin of meat in one meal, donned his armor, and mounted his horse to show he was still capable. The Zhao envoy returned and reported to the King: "General Lian, though old, still eats well, but while sitting with me, he defecated three times in a short time." The King of Zhao, thinking him too old, did not summon him. 25.2. Two years later, Pang Nuan defeated the Yan army and killed Ju Xin.
[241 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 96.5. In the twenty-second year, he joined forces with other states to attack Qin, but was defeated and withdrew. Chu moved its capital east to Shouchun, naming it Ying. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 99. Three days later, an envoy from Feng Ting, the governor of Shangdang, arrived and said, "Han was unable to defend Shangdang and surrendered it to Qin. Its officials and people are all content to serve Zhao and do not wish to serve Qin. There are seventeen cities and towns; we wish to surrender them to Zhao with two bows, so that the King may bestow them upon the officials and people." The King was overjoyed and summoned Lord Pingyang Bao, asking him, "Feng Ting has surrendered seventeen cities and towns; what do you think of accepting them?" The envoy replied, "A sage greatly dislikes unearned gain." The King said, "If people appreciate my virtue, how can you say it's unearned?" The envoy replied, "Qin has been encroaching on Han's territory, cutting off all communication between them; they have already considered themselves guilty." And the land of Shangdang. The reason why the Han family did not submit to Qin was that they wanted to shift the blame onto Zhao. Qin would labor for them while Zhao would reap the benefits. Even a powerful state cannot gain from a weak one, and a weak one cannot gain from a powerful one. How can this not be considered an unjust benefit? Moreover, Qin uses the water from the cattle fields to supply grain and gradually encroach upon Zhao. If they fight with double the strength, they will divide the land of a superior state. Their policies are effective, and we cannot make things difficult for them. We must not accept their offer.” The king said, “If we send an army of a million to attack now, we will not gain a single city even after more than a year. Now, if they offer seventeen cities and towns as tribute to our country, this is a great benefit.” 100. After Zhao Bao left, the king summoned Lord Pingyuan and Zhao Yu and informed them. Zhao Bao replied, "We sent an army of a million to attack, and after more than a year we had not captured a single city. Now we have gained seventeen cities and towns without lifting a finger. This is a great advantage, and we must not miss it." The king said, "Excellent." He then ordered Zhao Sheng to accept the land and told Feng Ting, "Your Majesty, I, Sheng, am an envoy from my kingdom. You have been sent by my king to deliver a message: you will be granted the title of Grand Administrator of a Prefecture with ten thousand households, and the title of County Magistrate of a Prefecture with one thousand households, all of whom will be hereditary marquises. All officials and commoners will receive three additional ranks of nobility. If the officials and commoners live in harmony, each will be rewarded with six gold pieces." Feng Ting wept and refused to see the envoy, saying, "I will not do three unjust things: to defend the land for my lord without fighting to the death is unjust; to enter Qin and disobey my lord's orders is unjust; to sell my lord's land and eat it is unjust." Zhao then sent troops to capture Shangdang. General Lian Po led the army to Changping. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 21 (≈date; after move to Chu). When Chu heard that Lian Po was in Wei, they secretly sent someone to welcome him. Lian Po had served as a general of Chu for a time, but had achieved no merit. He said, "I want to use a man from Zhao." Lian Po died in Shouchun. 24 (≈date; major anti-Xiongnu victory placed late in this sequence). Li Mu arrived and, as agreed, proceeded with the plan. For several years, the Xiongnu gained nothing and eventually became fearful. Their border soldiers, receiving daily rewards but not using them, all yearned for battle. Therefore, Li Mu selected 1,300 chariots, 13,000 cavalry, 50,000 soldiers of varying ranks, and 100,000 archers, training them all in combat. He also allowed livestock to graze freely, and the fields were filled with people. When the Xiongnu made a small incursion, feigning defeat, he abandoned several thousand men to their defenses. Upon hearing this, the Chanyu (Xiongnu ruler) led a large army to attack. Li Mu employed numerous surprise attacks, deploying his left and right flanks to strike, utterly defeating and killing over 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry. He also destroyed the Chanlan, defeated the Donghu, and subjugated the Linhu, forcing the Chanyu to flee. For the next ten years or so, the Xiongnu dared not approach the border cities of Zhao.
[240 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 17 (discursive; authorial reflection placed after narrative). Sima Qian said: When I passed by the ruins of Daliang, I inquired about the so-called Yimen. Yimen is the east gate of the city. Among the princes of the world, there are those who admire scholars, but Lord Xinling's willingness to associate with hermits in caves and not be ashamed to befriend those of lower status is not without reason. His reputation among the feudal lords is well-deserved. Whenever Emperor Gaozu passed by, he ordered the people to offer sacrifices there without ceasing.
[239 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 32. Han Shijia: In the thirty-fourth year, King Huanhui died, and his son King An ascended the throne.
[238 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 97.1. In the twenty-fifth year, King Kaolie died, and his son, King You, ascended the throne. Li Yuan killed Lord Chunshen.
[237 BC]
[236 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 9.1. Wang Jian was a native of Dongxiang, Pinyang. He was fond of military affairs from a young age and served Qin Shi Huang. 9.2. In the eleventh year of Qin Shi Huang's reign, Jian led an attack on Zhao's capital, Eyu, which he captured, taking nine cities.
[235 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 97.2. In the third year of King You's reign, Qin and Wei attacked Chu. Qin Chancellor Lü Buwei died. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 25.3. Seven years later, Qin defeated and killed Zhao general Hu Zhe at Wusui, beheading 100,000.
[234 BC]
[233 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 107. Twenty years later, King Zheng of Qin ascended the throne. Qin captured my Jinyang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 33 ([approx; Han Fei date]). Han Shijia: In the fifth year of King An's reign, Qin attacked Han. Han was in dire straits and sent Han Fei to Qin. Qin detained Han Fei and then killed him. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 25.4. Zhao then appointed Li Mu as Grand General, who attacked the Qin army at Yi'an, inflicting a major defeat on the Qin army and forcing the Qin general Huan Yi to flee. Li Mu was enfeoffed as Lord Wu'an.
[232 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 29.5. In the twenty-third year, Crown Prince Dan was held hostage in Qin, but fled back to Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 108. In the twenty-first year, King Xiaocheng died. Lian Po led an army to attack Fanyang and captured it. He then replaced King Xiaocheng with Yue Cheng, but Lian Po attacked Yue Cheng, who fled. Lian Po then fled to Wei. His son, Yan, succeeded him, becoming King Daoxiang.
[231 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 109. In the first year of King Daoxiang's reign, he made great preparations against Wei. He wanted to open the road between Pingyi and Zhongmou, but failed.
[230 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 29.6. In the twenty-fifth year, Qin captured and destroyed King An of Han, establishing Yingchuan Commandery. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 97.3. In the ninth year, Qin destroyed Han. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 110. In the second year, Li Mu led an army to attack Yan, capturing Wusui and Fangcheng. Qin summoned Lord Chunping and detained him. Xie Jun advised Marquis Wenxin, saying, "Lord Chunping is greatly favored by the King of Zhao, who also appointed him as a courtier. They conspired together, saying, 'If Lord Chunping enters Qin, Qin will surely detain him,' and thus they brought him into Qin. If you detain him now, you are severing ties with Zhao and the courtier's plan will succeed. You should send Lord Chunping away and leave him in Pingdu. Lord Chunping is trustworthy in his words and deeds; the king will surely cede Zhao generously to redeem Pingdu." Marquis Wenxin said, "Excellent," and sent him away. Han Gao was fortified. [Sima Qian, Shiji 45 — Han Shijia] 34. Han Shijia: In the ninth year, Qin captured King An and annexed all his territory, which became Yingzhou Commandery. Han Sui perished. 35 ([eval @ end]). Han Shijia: Sima Qian said: Han Jue's gratitude to Duke Jing of Jin, his inheritance of Zhao Gu's son Wu, and his fulfillment of the righteousness of Cheng Ying and Gongsun Chujiu were acts of unseen virtue throughout the land. The Han family's contributions to Jin were not particularly great. Yet, together with Zhao and Wei, they remained feudal lords for more than ten generations—was this not fitting? [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 54.2. In the thirty-fifth year, Qin destroyed Han. In the thirty-seventh year, Qin destroyed Zhao. In the thirty-eighth year, Yan sent Jing Ke to assassinate the King of Qin, but the King of Qin discovered the plot and killed Jing Ke. The following year, Qin defeated Yan, and the King of Yan fled to Liaodong. The following year, Qin destroyed Wei, and Qin troops camped at Lixia. In the forty-second year, Qin destroyed Chu. The following year, King Jia of Dai was captured, and King Xi of Yan was destroyed. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 25.5. Three years later, Qin attacked Fanwu, but Li Mu defeated the Qin army and retreated south to defend against Han and Wei.
[229 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 9.3. In the eighteenth year, Jian again led an attack on Zhao. After a year, he conquered Zhao, the King of Zhao surrendered, and the entire Zhao territory was pacified and established as a prefecture. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 26.1. In the seventh year of King Qian of Zhao's reign, Qin sent Wang Jian to attack Zhao, while Zhao dispatched Li Mu and Sima Shang to defend against him. Qin, along with Guo Kaijin, a favorite minister of King Qian of Zhao, spread rumors that Li Mu and Sima Shang intended to rebel. King Qian then replaced Li Mu with Zhao Cong and the Qi general Yan Ju. Li Mu refused the order, and Zhao secretly captured and executed him. Sima Shang was deposed.
[228 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 29.7. In the twenty-seventh year, Qin captured King Qian of Zhao and destroyed Zhao. Prince Jia of Zhao declared himself King of Dai. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 97.4. In the tenth year, King You died, and his half-brother You succeeded him, becoming King Ai. After reigning for more than two months, King Ai's half-brother Fu Chu and his followers attacked and killed him, installing Fu Chu as king. That year, Qin captured King Qian of Zhao. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 111. In the third year, Pang Nuan led an army to attack Yan, capturing its general Ju Xin. In the fourth year, Pang Nuan led the elite forces of Zhao, Chu, Wei, and Yan to attack Qin Zui, but failed to capture it; he then moved to attack Qi, capturing Rao'an. In the fifth year, Fu Di was appointed general and resided in Pingyi; Qing She led the army outside the Dongyang River to defend the river bridge. In the sixth year, he was enfeoffed as the Lord of Chang'an in Rao. Wei and Zhao were in Ye. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 9.4. The following year, Yan sent Jing Ke as a traitor to Qin, and the King of Qin sent Wang Jian to attack Yan. King Xi of Yan fled to Liaodong, and Jian then pacified Yan and Ji before returning. Qin sent Jian's son, Wang Ben, to attack Jing, whose army was defeated. [Sima Qian, Shiji 81 — Lian Po and Lin Xiangru] 26.2. Three months later, Wang Jian launched a swift attack on Zhao, decisively defeating and killing Zhao Cong, capturing King Qian of Zhao and his general Yan Ju, and thus destroying Zhao. 27 (authorial comment; dated to end of narrative). Sima Qian said: "Knowing death inevitably leads to courage. It is not death itself that is difficult, but how one faces death. When Lin Xiangru held the jade disc and glared at the pillar, and rebuked the King of Qin's attendants, the only consequence was execution. Yet, some scholars were cowardly and dared not act. Xiangru, however, displayed his courage and prestige, earning the respect of an enemy state. He then yielded the throne to Po, and his reputation soared to the heights of Mount Tai. His wisdom and courage in this situation can be said to have been combined!"
[227 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 30.1. Seeing that Qin was about to conquer the six states, and that Qin's army was approaching the Yi River, disaster was about to befall Yan. Prince Dan secretly raised twenty strong men and sent Jing Ke to present the map of Dukang to Qin, intending to assassinate the King of Qin. The King of Qin discovered this, killed Jing Ke, and sent General Wang Jian to attack Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 98.1. In the first year of King Fuchu's reign, Prince Dan of Yan sent Jing Ke to assassinate the King of Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 20. More than 220 years later, the Qin dynasty had the story of Jing Ke. 21. Jing Ke was a man of Wei. His ancestors were originally from Qi, but they moved to Wei, where the people of Wei called him Qing Qing. When he went to Yan, the people of Yan called him Jing Qing. 26.1. Shortly after, Prince Dan of Yan, who had been a hostage in Qin, returned to Yan. Prince Dan had previously been a hostage in Zhao, where King Zheng of Qin was born, and the two had been on good terms in their youth. When Zheng became King of Qin, Dan was sent as a hostage. King Zheng treated Prince Dan poorly, so Dan harbored resentment and fled back to Yan. Upon his return, he sought to avenge the King of Qin, but Yan's state was too small and lacked the power. 34. He then went to Qin, carrying a thousand pieces of gold and other valuables, and generously gifted Meng Jia, a favorite minister of the King of Qin. Meng Jia spoke first to the King of Qin, saying, “The King of Yan is truly terrified of Your Majesty’s power and dares not raise an army to oppose your officers. He wishes to make his entire kingdom a vassal, ranking among the other feudal lords, paying tribute like a prefecture, and being allowed to maintain the ancestral temples of his former king. He is too afraid to speak for himself, so he has respectfully cut off Fan Yuqi’s head and presented the map of Dukang in Yan, sealed in a box. The King of Yan bowed and presented it to Your Majesty, and sent an envoy to inform you. Your Majesty’s command is at your disposal.” The King of Qin was overjoyed upon hearing this. He donned his court robes, arranged for nine officials to receive the Yan envoy at the Xianyang Palace. Jing Ke carried the box containing Fan Yuqi’s head, while Qin Wuyang carried the map in its case, proceeding in turn. Upon reaching the steps, Qin Wuyang’s face changed color and he trembled with fear, which puzzled the assembled ministers. Jing Ke glanced at Wu Yang and smiled, then stepped forward and said, "This is a lowly barbarian from the northern frontier. I have never seen the Son of Heaven before, hence my trembling. I beg Your Majesty to grant me this favor so that I may complete my mission before you." The King of Qin said to Jing Ke, "Take the map that Wu Yang is holding." Jing Ke took the map and presented it to the King of Qin. The King of Qin unrolled the map, and as it was unrolled, a dagger was revealed. Jing Ke then grabbed the King of Qin's sleeve with his left hand and thrust the dagger at him with his right. Before it reached him, the King of Qin was startled and pulled himself up, tearing his sleeve. He drew his sword, but it was long and held firmly in its sheath. In his haste and panic, the sword was too strong to be drawn immediately. Jing Ke pursued the King of Qin, who ran around a pillar. The assembled officials were all astonished, caught off guard, and lost their composure. According to Qin law, officials attending the court were not allowed to carry any weapons; the palace guards, carrying weapons, were stationed below the throne and could not ascend without an imperial edict. In this urgent situation, there was no time to summon the guards, thus allowing Jing Ke to pursue the King of Qin. The soldiers, in their panic, had no way to strike Jing Ke, and resorted to hand-to-hand combat. At that moment, the court physician Xia Wuqie used his medicine bag to throw Jing Ke. The King of Qin was running around a pillar, and the soldiers, in their panic and confusion, didn't know what to do. His attendants said, "Your Majesty, draw your sword!" He drew his sword and struck Jing Ke, severing his left thigh. Jing Ke, crippled, then drew his dagger and stabbed the King of Qin, missing his target and striking a pillar instead. The King of Qin struck Jing Ke again, inflicting eight wounds. Knowing his mission had failed, Jing Ke leaned against the pillar, laughing, and cursing, "The reason this failed was because I wanted to kidnap him alive, to obtain a treaty to report to the Crown Prince." Then his attendants rushed forward and killed Jing Ke. The King of Qin remained displeased for a long time. Later, when the merits were tallied, the officials and those who were to be seated were rewarded accordingly, and Xia Wuqie was given two hundred yi of gold, saying, "Wuqie loves me; he threw Jing Ke with his medicine bag."
[226 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 30.2. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin attacked and captured Ji, the King of Yan fled, and moved to Liaodong. He beheaded Prince Dan and presented him to Qin. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 98.2. The following year, Qin sent a general to attack Chu, inflicting a major defeat on the Chu army and destroying more than ten cities. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 22. Jing Ke was fond of reading and swordsmanship. He tried to persuade Duke Yuan of Wei with his skills, but Duke Yuan did not accept his advice. Later, Qin attacked Wei, established Dongjun, and moved a branch of Duke Yuan of Wei to Yewang. 26.2. Subsequently, Qin sent troops eastward daily to attack Qi, Chu, and the three Jin states, gradually encroaching upon the other states, and even reaching Yan. The ruler and ministers of Yan feared impending disaster. Prince Dan was troubled by this and consulted his tutor, Ju Wu. Wu replied, "Qin's territory spans the entire land, threatening the states of Han, Wei, and Zhao.
