To the north lies the fortified Ganquan and Gukou passes, to the south the fertile Jing and Wei rivers, and it controls the riches of Ba and Han. To the right are the mountains of Long and Shu, and to the left the natural defenses of Guan and Xiao. Its people are numerous and its soldiers are well-trained, with ample military strength. If it intends to expand its territory, then the area south of the Great Wall and north of the Yi River remains unsettled. How can we, with our grievances of being bullied, dare to provoke its rebellious nature?" Dan asked, "Then what is the way?" Wu replied, "Please allow me to devise a plan." 27. While the prince was at leisure, Qin general Fan Yuqi offended the King of Qin and fled to Yan. The prince took him in and sheltered him. Ju Wu advised, "This is unacceptable. The King of Qin is already tyrannical and harbors deep resentment towards Yan, which is enough to chill his heart. How much more so would he be afraid if he heard of General Fan's whereabouts? This is like 'offering meat to a hungry tiger's path,' and disaster will surely follow! Even if there were Guan Zhong and Yan Ying, they could not devise a plan for this. I urge the prince to quickly send General Fan into the Xiongnu to silence him. We should then form an alliance with the three Jin states in the west, ally with Qi and Chu in the south, and bribe the Chanyu in the north. Only then can we make our move." The prince said, "Grand Tutor's plan takes a long time, and I am worried that it will not be implemented even for a moment. Moreover, this is not the only concern. General Fan was impoverished throughout the land and sought refuge with Dan. Dan did not abandon his benevolent alliance with the Xiongnu simply because he was forced by the powerful Qin." "This is the time when Gu Dan will die. I hope the Grand Tutor will reconsider." Ju Wu said, "To seek safety through danger, to create misfortune for the sake of fortune, to have shallow plans yet deep resentment, to form alliances with one person while disregarding the great harm to the country—this is what is meant by 'aiding misfortune with resentment.' If you burn a feather on a furnace, nothing will happen. And what about the Qin, with its fierce and ruthless forces, acting out of resentment and violence? There is a Mr. Tian Guang in Yan, a man of profound wisdom and courage, with whom one can make plans." The Crown Prince said, "I wish to befriend Mr. Tian through the Grand Tutor, is that possible?" Ju Wu said, "I respectfully agree." He went out to see Mr. Tian and said, "The Crown Prince wishes to consult with you on matters of state." Tian Guang said, "I respectfully obey your instruction." He then went to see him. 28. The Crown Prince, eager to please, led the way, kneeling to cover the mat. Once Tian Guang was seated, and with no one else around, the Crown Prince rose from his seat and said, "Yan and Qin cannot coexist; I hope you will take this into consideration." Tian Guang replied, "I have heard that a fine steed, in its prime, can gallop a thousand miles in a day; but when it ages, even a slow horse will outpace it. Now, Your Highness has heard of my prime, unaware that my spirit has already faded. Nevertheless, I dare not presume to concern myself with state affairs, but my friend Jing Ke can be employed." The Crown Prince said, "I wish to befriend Jing Ke through you, is that possible?" Tian Guang replied, "I respectfully agree," and immediately rose and hurried out. The Crown Prince saw him off at the gate and warned him, "What Dan reported, sir, is a matter of great importance to the state. I beg you not to divulge it!" Tian Guang bowed and smiled, saying, "Yes." He then hunched over and met Jing Ke, saying, "You and I are good friends, and everyone in Yan knows this. Now the Crown Prince, hearing of my prime, is unaware of my declining health and has instructed me, 'Yan and Qin cannot coexist. I hope you will take heed of this.' I have secretly spoken to you about this to the Crown Prince. I hope you will visit the Crown Prince at the palace." Jing Ke replied, "I will obey your instructions." Tian Guang said, "I have heard that a wise man conducts himself in a way that does not arouse suspicion. Now the Crown Prince has told me, 'What I have said is a matter of great importance to the state. I beg you not to divulge it.' This shows that the Crown Prince suspects me. To conduct oneself in a way that arouses suspicion is not the way of chivalry." He then attempted suicide to provoke Jing Ke, saying, "I beg you to quickly visit the Crown Prince and tell him that I am dead, thus making it clear that I will not speak of this." He then cut his own throat and died. 29. Jing Ke then met with the Crown Prince and told him that Tian Guang was dead, conveying his words. The Crown Prince bowed twice and knelt, crawling on his knees and weeping. After a while, he said, "The reason I warned Mr. Tian not to speak was to facilitate our great plan. Now Mr. Tian has shown his silence through death; is this what I truly intended?" Jing Ke sat down, and the Crown Prince rose from his seat and bowed deeply, saying, "Mr. Tian was unaware of my incompetence, yet I dared to speak before him. This is Heaven's way of showing pity for Yan and not abandoning its orphan. Now Qin has a greedy heart, and its desires are insatiable. It will not be satisfied until it has conquered all the land under heaven and made all the kings within the seas its subjects. Now Qin has captured the King of Han and annexed all his territory. It has also raised an army to attack Chu in the south and Zhao in the north; Wang Jian is leading hundreds of thousands of troops to defend Zhang and Ye, while Li Xin has marched out from Taiyuan and Yunzhong. Zhao cannot withstand Qin and will inevitably become a vassal state. If it becomes a vassal state, disaster will befall Yan." "Yan is small and weak, repeatedly afflicted by war. Now, the entire state is insufficient to withstand Qin. The other states submit to Qin, none dare to form an alliance. My private plan is foolish: if we can truly obtain the bravest warriors in the land to send to Qin, we can offer them great rewards; the King of Qin is greedy, and he will surely get what he desires. If we can indeed kidnap the King of Qin and force him to return all the territories seized by the other states, like Cao Mo did with Duke Huan of Qi, that would be excellent; if not, then we should assassinate him. With Qin's generals commanding troops abroad and internal strife, the ruler and his ministers will distrust each other. Using this to persuade the other states to form an alliance, Qin will surely be defeated. This is my greatest wish, but I do not know who to entrust this task to. Only Jing Ke can attend to it." After a long while, Jing Ke said, "This is a matter of great importance to the state. I am incompetent and fear I am unfit to undertake this task." The Crown Prince bowed deeply, earnestly pleading not to refuse, and then agreed. Thereupon, Jing Ke was honored as a high minister and housed in the best quarters. The Crown Prince visited him daily, providing him with the finest food and rare delicacies, and offering him carriages, horses, and beautiful women to do as he pleased, to satisfy his desires. 35. King Qin was enraged and sent more troops to Zhao, ordering Wang Jian to lead an army to attack Yan. In October, they captured Ji. King Xi of Yan, Crown Prince Dan, and others led their elite troops east to Liaodong. Qin general Li Xin pursued King Xi relentlessly. King Jia of Dai then sent a letter to King Xi of Yan, saying, "The reason Qin is pursuing Yan so aggressively is because of Crown Prince Dan. If Your Majesty truly kills Dan and presents him to King Qin, King Qin will surely relent, and the state will be able to enjoy its sacrifices." Later, Li Xin pursued Dan, who hid in the Yan River. King Xi then sent an envoy to kill Crown Prince Dan, intending to present him to Qin. Qin again advanced and attacked. Five years later, Qin finally destroyed Yan and captured King Xi of Yan.
[225 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 30.3. In the thirtieth year, Qin destroyed Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 98.3. In the third year, Qin conquered Wei. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 9.5. Qin then attacked Wei, the King of Wei surrendered, and the Wei territory was pacified. [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 15.2. Afterwards, Qin gradually eroded Wei's territory, and after eighteen years, captured the King of Wei and massacred the inhabitants of Daliang. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 23. Jing Ke once traveled to Yuci and discussed swordsmanship with Gai Nie. Gai Nie glared at him angrily. After Jing Ke left, someone suggested that he be summoned back. Gai Nie said, "Previously, there was something I disagreed with during our swordsmanship discussion, so I glared at him. If I go, he should leave; I dare not keep him." He sent a messenger to the host, but Jing Ke had already left Yuci. When the messenger returned and reported back, Gai Nie said, "He has indeed left; I glared at him earlier!" 30. After a long while, Jing Ke showed no intention of leaving. Qin general Wang Jian defeated Zhao, captured the King of Zhao, and took all of Zhao's territory, advancing north to conquer lands as far as the southern border of Yan. Crown Prince Dan, fearing for his life, pleaded with Jing Ke, saying, "The Qin army will cross the Yi River at any moment. Even if I wished to serve you for a long time, how could I?" Jing Ke replied, "If it weren't for Your Highness's words, I would have wished to meet them. Now, if I go without fulfilling my promise, Qin cannot be befriended. General Fan is being offered a reward of a thousand catties of gold and a fief of ten thousand households by the King of Qin. If I could obtain General Fan's head and the map of Dukang in Yan, and present them to the King of Qin, he would surely be pleased to see me, and I would then have a way to repay him." The Crown Prince said, "General Fan came to Dan in dire straits. Dan cannot bear to harm the feelings of an elder for his own selfish reasons. I urge Your Highness to reconsider!" 31. Jing Ke, knowing the Crown Prince was reluctant, secretly met with Fan Yuqi and said, "Qin has treated you terribly, General. Your parents and clan have all been slaughtered. Now I hear they are offering a thousand catties of gold and ten thousand households for your head. What should we do?" Yuqi looked up to the sky, sighed, and wept, saying, "Every time I think of this, it pains me to the bone, but I know not what to do!" Jing Ke said, "I have a suggestion that can resolve the troubles of Yan and avenge you, General. What do you think?" Yuqi stepped forward and asked, "What should I do?" Jing Ke said, "I wish to present your head to the King of Qin. The King of Qin will surely be pleased and see me. I will grab his sleeve with my left hand and stab his chest with my right. Then you will avenge your death and the shame of Yan's humiliation will be gone. Does the General have any interest in this?" Fan Yuqi bared his shoulder, grabbed his arm, and stepped forward, saying, "This is what I have been grieving for day and night! Now I have finally heard your advice!" He then committed suicide. The Crown Prince heard of this, rushed to the scene, prostrated himself before the body, and wept bitterly. Since there was nothing that could be done, he then sealed the letter containing Fan Yuqi's first letter. 32. So the Crown Prince sought out the sharpest dagger in the land and obtained one from Lady Xu of Zhao. He paid a hundred gold pieces for it and had a craftsman temper it with poison. He tested it on a person, and anyone touched by blood died instantly. He then prepared it to send Jing Ke away. In Yan, there was a brave warrior named Qin Wuyang, thirteen years old, who had killed someone, and no one dared to look him in the eye. The Crown Prince appointed Qin Wuyang as his assistant. Jing Ke was waiting for someone to accompany him; however, the man lived far away and had not yet arrived, so he prepared the journey. After a while, they still hadn't departed. The Crown Prince, suspecting that Jing Ke had changed his mind, pleaded again, "The day is almost over. Does Jing Ke have any intention of going? I beg to send Qin Wuyang first." Jing Ke was furious and rebuked the Crown Prince, saying, "What kind of Crown Prince sends me away? Anyone who goes and doesn't return is a coward! I'm only going to the unpredictable and powerful Qin with a dagger. The reason I'm staying is to wait for my guest to go with me. Now that the Crown Prince is delaying, I must take my leave!" He then departed. 33. The Crown Prince and his guests, those who knew of the matter, all wore white robes and hats to see him off. Upon reaching the Yi River, after the farewell ceremony, as they took their leave, Gao Jianli played the zither, and Jing Ke sang along, a mournful tune, which moved all the warriors to tears. Then he sang again: "The wind howls, the Yi River is cold, the brave warrior departs, never to return!" He sang again in a mournful, somber tone, and all the warriors glared, their hair standing on end, their fists clenched. Then Jing Ke boarded his chariot and departed, never looking back.
[224 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 98.4. In the fourth year, Qin general Wang Jian defeated our army at Qi and killed General Xiang Yan. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 10.1. After Qin Shi Huang destroyed the three Jin states and drove away the King of Yan, he repeatedly defeated the Chu army. Qin general Li Xin, young and brave, once led several thousand soldiers to pursue Prince Dan of Yan to the Yan River, ultimately capturing him. Qin Shi Huang considered him wise and courageous. Therefore, 10.2. Qin Shi Huang asked Li Xin, "I intend to attack Chu. How many men do you think I would need?" Li Xin replied, "No more than 200,000." 10.3. Qin Shi Huang then asked Wang Jian, who said, "No less than 600,000." Qin Shi Huang said, "General Wang is old and timid! General Li is indeed strong and brave; his words are correct." 10.4. He then sent Li Xin and Meng Tian with 200,000 men to attack Chu in the south. Wang Jian's advice was not heeded, and he feigned illness, retiring to Pinyang. Li Xin attacked Pingyu, and Meng Tian attacked Qin, inflicting a great defeat on the Chu army. Li Xin then attacked Yan and Ying, capturing them. He then led his army west to meet Meng Tian at Chengfu. 10.5. The Chu people pursued him relentlessly for three days and three nights, inflicting a great defeat on Li Xin's army, breaching both walls, killing seven commanders, and the Qin army fled. 11.1. Upon hearing this, the First Emperor was furious. He personally rushed to Pinyang and met with Wang Jian, saying, "Because I did not heed your advice, General, Li Xin has indeed humiliated the Qin army. Now I hear that the Chu army is advancing westward daily. Although you are ill, General, how can you bear to abandon me?" Wang Jian replied, "This old minister is ill and confused. I only ask Your Majesty to choose a more capable general." 11.2. The First Emperor said, "That's enough, General, do not speak further!" Wang Jian said, "If Your Majesty must use me out of necessity, then no less than 600,000 men will suffice." The First Emperor said, "I will heed your advice, General." 11.3. Thereupon, Wang Jian led 600,000 troops, and the First Emperor personally escorted him to Ba Shang. 11.4. Before departing, Wang Jian requested many beautiful fields, houses, gardens, and ponds. The First Emperor said, "General, you are leaving. Why worry about poverty?" Wang Jian replied, "As Your Majesty's general, even with merit, I will not be enfeoffed as a marquis. Therefore, now that Your Majesty favors me, I am requesting gardens and ponds as an inheritance for my descendants." The First Emperor laughed heartily. After Wang Jian reached the pass, he sent messengers back to request five more groups of fine fields. 11.5. Someone said, "General, your request for a loan is excessive." 11.6. Wang Jian replied, "No. The King of Qin is timid and distrustful. Now he has emptied the Qin army and entrusted it entirely to me. If I don't ask for more land and houses to secure my descendants' livelihood, wouldn't that make the King of Qin suspicious of me?" [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 24. When Jing Ke was traveling in Handan, Lu Goujian challenged him to a game of chance. They argued over who was on the right. Lu Goujian became angry and scolded him. Jing Ke silently fled and never met him again.
[223 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 40 — Chu Shijia] 99. In the fifth year, Qin generals Wang Jian and Meng Wu conquered the State of Chu, captured King Fuchu of Chu, and destroyed Chu, naming it the [Chu] Commandery. 100 (discursive). Sima Qian wrote: When King Ling of Chu convened the feudal lords at Shen, executed Qing Feng of Qi, built the Zhanghua Terrace, and sought the Nine Tripods of Zhou, he aspired to rule the world. Yet, he starved to death at the home of Shen Hai, becoming a laughingstock to the world. His conduct was utterly flawed; how tragic! How can one not be cautious in the face of power? Qi Ji established the dynasty amidst chaos, indulging in debauchery with Qin women—how utterly disgraceful! He nearly brought about the downfall of his kingdom twice! [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 12.1. Wang Jian indeed replaced Li Xin in attacking Jing. Upon hearing that Wang Jian had increased his army's strength, Jing mobilized its entire force to resist Qin. 12.2. When Wang Jian arrived, he fortified his defenses and refused to fight. The Jing soldiers repeatedly challenged Qin, but none came out. Wang Jian provided daily rest and bathing for his troops, treating them well and feeding them, even sharing meals with them. 12.3. After a while, Wang Jian sent someone to inquire about the army's games. The reply was, "They are playing stone throwing and leaping." Wang Jian then said, "The soldiers are ready." Jing challenged Qin several times, but Qin did not engage, so Jing withdrew eastward. 12.4. Wang Jian then led his troops in pursuit, ordering his strongest warriors to attack, and decisively defeated the Jing army. 12.5. Reaching south of Qin, he killed their general Xiang Yan, and the Jing army fled in defeat. Qin then took advantage of the victory to conquer and pacify the cities and towns of Jing. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 25. When Jing Ke arrived in Yan, he took a liking to a dog butcher and Gao Jianli, a skilled zither player. Jing Ke was fond of wine, and he spent his days drinking with the dog butcher and Gao Jianli in the Yan marketplace. When they were drunk, Gao Jianli would play the zither, and Jing Ke would sing along in the marketplace, enjoying themselves immensely. Afterwards, they would weep, oblivious to those around them. Although Jing Ke frequented taverns, he was a profound and bookish man; among the feudal lords he visited, he befriended all the virtuous and wise men. When he arrived in Yan, the recluse Tian Guang treated him well, recognizing him as no ordinary man.
[222 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 34 — Yan Shijia] 31.1. In the thirty-third year, Qin conquered Liaodong, captured King Xi of Yan, and finally destroyed Yan. 31.2. In the same year, Qin general Wang Ben also captured King Jia of Dai. 32 (commentary; after 31). Sima Qian said: Duke Shao was truly benevolent! If even a humble scholar like Ba Tang could reflect upon this, how much more so the man himself? Yan (north) was threatened by barbarian tribes to the outside, and beset by Qi and Jin to the inside. Caught between powerful states, it was the weakest and had nearly perished several times. Yet, its state and sacrifices continued for eight or nine hundred years, and among the Ji clan, it was the last to fall. Was this not due to the valor of Duke Shao? [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 112. In the ninth year, Zhao attacked Yan and captured Li and Yangcheng. Before the war was over, Qin attacked Ye and captured it. King Daoxiang died, and his son King Youmou ascended the throne. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 12.6. A year later, Qin captured King Fuchu of Jing and pacified the land, establishing prefectures and counties. Qin then launched a southern campaign against the rulers of the Baiyue. Meanwhile, Wang Jian's son, Wang Ben, along with Li Xin, conquered and pacified the lands of Yan and Qi.
[221 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 71 (Qin Shi Huang unifies; summary) (Wikipedia). Qin Shi Huang reigned for twenty-six years, initially unifying the empire into thirty-six commanderies, and was known as the First Emperor. He died fifty-one years later, and his son Huhai ascended the throne as the Second Emperor. Three years later, the feudal lords rose in rebellion against Qin. Zhao Gao killed the Second Emperor and installed Ziying. Ziying reigned for a little over a month before the feudal lords executed him, thus destroying Qin. This account is found in the Annals of the First Emperor. [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 113. In the first year of King Youmou's reign, he built a city called Bairen. In the second year, Qin attacked Wucheng, and Hu Zhe led his army to its rescue, but his army was defeated and he died there. [Sima Qian, Shiji 46 — Tian Jingzhong Wan Shijia] 55. In the forty-fourth year, Qin troops attacked Qi. King Qi, heeding the advice of his minister Hou Sheng, surrendered to Qin without fighting. Qin captured King Jian and exiled him to Gong. Qi was then destroyed and reduced to a prefecture. The entire realm was unified under Qin, and King Zheng of Qin proclaimed himself Emperor. Initially, King Junhou was wise and cautious in serving Qin, maintaining good relations with the other states. Qi was located on the eastern coast, and Qin attacked the three Jin states (Jin, Yan, and Chu) day and night. Each of the five states came to Qin's aid, thus King Jian was spared from war for over forty years. After King Junhou's death, Hou Sheng became the prime minister of Qi. He received much bribes from Qin and sent many guests to Qin, which in turn gave him more money. These guests then rebelled, urging the king to abandon his allegiance to Qin and neglect preparations for war, failing to aid the five states in their attack on Qin. Thus, Qin was able to destroy the five states. With the five states destroyed, Qin troops entered Linzi, and the people dared not resist. King Jian then surrendered and was exiled to Gong. Therefore, the people of Qi resented King Jian for not joining forces with the other feudal lords to attack Qin earlier, and for listening to treacherous ministers and guests, which led to the downfall of their country. They sang a song: "Pine or cypress? Are those who live with Jian guests?" They were angry at Jian for his ill-fated use of guests. 56 (authorial). Sima Qian said: Confucius became fond of the Book of Changes in his later years. The art of the Book of Changes is profound and far-reaching; who but a learned and talented person can pay attention to it? The divination of Tian Jingzhong Wan by Sima Qian of the Zhou Dynasty can be traced back ten generations; when Wan fled to Qi, Yi Zhong also divined the same thing. The reason why Tian Qi and Chang offended two rulers and monopolized the government of Qi was not necessarily due to the gradual development of events, but rather because they seemed to follow auspicious omens. [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 13. In the twenty-sixth year of Qin Shi Huang's reign, he unified the world. The Wang and Meng families made the greatest contributions and their names will be remembered by later generations. [Sima Qian, Shiji 86 — Assassins Lie Zhuan] 36. The following year, Qin unified the world and established the emperor. Qin then expelled Prince Dan and the followers of Jing Ke, who all fled. Gao Jianli changed his name and became a common laborer, hiding in the home of a man in Songzi. After a long time, he suffered greatly while working. He heard a guest in the manor playing the zither and lingered nearby, unable to leave. He would often remark, "He has good and bad points." His followers told his master, "That mediocre man is a connoisseur of music, secretly gossiping." The manor's father-in-law summoned him to play the zither. Everyone present praised his playing and offered him wine. But Gao Jianli, fearing the endless uncertainty of his long hiding, withdrew, took out his zither and fine clothes from their case, changed his appearance, and returned. All the guests were astonished, bowing respectfully and treating him as an honored guest. He was made to play the zither and sing, and all the guests left weeping. The man in Songzi told the story to his guests, and it reached the ears of Qin Shi Huang. Qin Shi Huang summoned him, and someone recognized him, saying, "It is Gao Jianli." The Qin emperor, appreciating his skill in playing the zither, granted him a general pardon and blindfolded him. He was then made to play the zither, and every time, his playing was praised. As Gao Jianli drew closer, he placed lead in the zither, then advanced further and raised the zither to strike the Qin Emperor, but missed. Consequently, Gao Jianli was executed, and Gao Jianli was never again allowed to approach any of the feudal lords. 37. Lu Goujian had already heard of Jing Ke's assassination attempt on the King of Qin, and privately thought, "Alas, what a pity he didn't master the art of swordsmanship! How I misjudged him! When I rebuked him earlier, he thought I was not human!" 38 (authorial). Sima Qian said: The world's accounts of Jing Ke, particularly the claim that "millet rained from the sky and horses grew horns" upon receiving Prince Dan's command, are exaggerated. The account of Jing Ke wounding the King of Qin is also incorrect. Gongsun Jigong, Dong Sheng, and Xia Wuqie, who were friends with him, knew the whole story and recounted it to me as follows. Of the five men from Cao Mo to Jing Ke, some succeeded, some failed, but their intentions were clear, they did not betray their will, and their names have been passed down through the ages. How could this be mere fabrication!
[220 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 114. In the third year, Qin attacked Chili and Yi'an. Li Mu led his army to fight at Feixia and repelled them. He was then enfeoffed as the Marquis of Wu'an. In the fourth year, Qin attacked Fanwu. Li Mu fought against them and repelled them.
[219 BC]
[218 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 115. In the fifth year, a great upheaval occurred in Dai, from Lexu in the west to Pingyin in the north. Most of the houses and walls were destroyed, and the ground cracked open 130 paces east to west. In the sixth year, a great famine struck, and the people spread rumors that "Zhao is the cause of the cries, and Qin is the cause of the laughter." When they did not believe it, they looked at the ground and saw that it was covered with hair.
[217 BC]
[216 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 116. In the seventh year, the Qin army attacked Zhao. Zhao's generals Li Mu and Sima Shang led the attack. Li Mu was executed, Sima Shang was dismissed, and Zhao's generals Cong and Yan Ju replaced him. Zhao's army was defeated, and Yan Ju fled. King Qian surrendered.
[215 BC]
[214 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 43 — Zhao Shijia] 117. In the tenth month of the eighth year, Handan was taken over by Qin. 118 (authorial). The Grand Historian Sima Qian said: "I heard Feng Wangsun say: 'King Qian of Zhao was born to a courtesan and was favored by King Daoxiang. King Daoxiang deposed his legitimate son Jia and installed Qian as king. Qian was of bad character and believed slander, so he executed his good general Li Mu and appointed Guo Kai.' How absurd this is! After Qin captured Qian, the exiled ministers of Zhao jointly installed Jia as king. After six years of rule, Qin advanced its troops, defeated Jia, and then destroyed Zhao, turning it into a prefecture."
[213 BC]
[212 BC]
[211 BC]
[210 BC]
[209 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 14.1. During the reign of Qin Er Shi, Wang Jian and his son Ben were both dead, and the Meng clan was also destroyed. When Chen Sheng rebelled against Qin, Qin sent Wang Jian's grandson, Wang Li, to attack Zhao, besieging the King of Zhao and Zhang Er at Julu. Someone said, "Wang Li is a famous general of Qin. Now he leads the powerful Qin army to attack the newly established Zhao; he will surely conquer it." The guest said, "No. A general who has served three generations is bound to fail. Why? Because he has killed and fought many, and his descendants will suffer misfortune. Now, Wang Li has served three generations of generals."
[208 BC]
[207 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 73 — Bai Qi and Wang Jian] 14.2. Not long after, Xiang Yu came to the rescue of Zhao, attacked the Qin army, and indeed captured Wang Li. Wang Li's army then surrendered to the other feudal lords. 15 (authorial). Sima Qian said: There's a saying, "Even a foot has its shortcomings, and an inch has its strengths." Bai Qi was adept at predicting enemy moves and adapting to changing circumstances, his ingenious strategies were endless, and his fame shook the world; yet he couldn't save Ying Hou from his predicament. Wang Jian, as a Qin general, pacified the six states. At that time, Jian was a veteran general, and the First Emperor studied under him; yet he couldn't help Qin establish its virtue and solidify its foundation, instead seeking favor and ultimately meeting his demise. And when his grandson Wang Li was captured by Xiang Yu, wasn't it fitting? Each of them had their weaknesses.
[206 BC]
[205 BC]
[204 BC]
[203 BC]
[202 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 41 — Yue Shijia] 17.1 (late survival tradition; very approximate). Seven generations later, the Min King Yao assisted the feudal lords in conquering Qin. 17.2. Emperor Gaozu of Han reinstated Yao as King of Yue to serve the Yue queen. The Eastern Yue and the Min King were both his descendants. 27 (Sima Qian commentary). Sima Qian said: "Yu's achievements were immense. He dredged the nine rivers and settled the nine provinces, bringing peace and prosperity to the Xia people to this day. His descendant, Goujian, endured hardship and toil, ultimately destroying the powerful Wu state. He then marched north to inspect the Central Plains, honoring the Zhou dynasty and proclaiming himself a hegemon. Can Goujian not be considered virtuous? He inherited the legacy of Yu. Fan Li moved three times, each time achieving great fame, his name enduring through the ages. With such ministers and rulers, how could they not be renowned?"
[201 BC]
[200 BC]
[199 BC]
[198 BC]
[197 BC]
[196 BC]
[195 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 77 — Wei Gongzi Liezhuan] 16. When Emperor Gaozu was young and in humble circumstances, he often heard of the prince's virtue. After he ascended the throne, whenever he passed through Daliang, he would always offer sacrifices to the prince. In the twelfth year of Emperor Gaozu's reign, after returning from the battle against Ying Bu, he established five families to guard the prince's tomb, and they would offer sacrifices to the prince every year in the four seasons.

[112 BC]
[111 BC]
[110 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 4 — Zhou Benji] 82. The Grand Historian Sima Qian said: Scholars all say that Zhou attacked King Zhou of Shang and resided in Luoyi, but this is not the case. King Wu built the city, and King Cheng sent Duke Shao to divine the location, where the Nine Tripods were placed. Zhou then returned to Feng and Hao as its capital. After the Quanrong defeated King You, Zhou moved east to Luoyi. The so-called "Duke Zhou buried me in Bi" refers to Bi, which is located in Du, southeast of Hao. Qin destroyed Zhou. More than ninety years after the rise of Han, the emperor was about to perform the Feng ceremony at Mount Tai. He made an eastern tour to Henan, seeking the descendants of Zhou. He enfeoffed his descendant with thirty li of land in Jia, calling him Lord Zhouzi Nan, and placed him among the marquises to continue the sacrifices to his ancestors. [Sima Qian, Shiji 61 — Bo Yi Lie Zhuan] 1 (authorial/discursive; Sima Qian). Scholars, though possessing vast knowledge of classical texts, still rely on the Six Arts for verification. While the Book of Poetry and the Book of Documents are incomplete, the writings of the Yu and Xia dynasties are still readable. When Yao was about to abdicate, he offered the throne to Shun. Between Shun and Yu, the provincial governors and ministers all recommended him, and he was put to trial in office. After serving for decades and achieving notable results, he was finally granted the reins of government. This demonstrates the immense power and authority of the ruler, and the difficulty of passing on the throne. Some say that Yao offered the throne to Xu You, but Xu You refused, ashamed, and fled into seclusion. During the Xia dynasty, there were Bian Sui and Wu Guang. Why are these mentioned? The Grand Historian Sima Qian said: "I climbed Mount Ji, and there is said to be the tomb of Xu You on it." Confucius listed the ancient benevolent sages and virtuous men, such as Wu Taibo and Boyi, in detail. I have heard of the supreme righteousness of Bian Sui and Wu Guang, yet their writings are rarely seen. Why is this?
[109 BC]
[108 BC]
[107 BC]
[106 BC]
[105 BC]
[104 BC]
[103 BC]
[102 BC]
[101 BC]
[100 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 62 — Guan Yan Lie Zhuan] 10 (authorial). Sima Qian said: I have read Guan Zhong's works on "Governing the People," "Mountains and Mountains," "Riding Horses," "Light and Heavy Matters," and "The Nine Offices," as well as the "Annals of Yanzi," and found their descriptions to be very detailed. Having seen that he wrote these books, I wished to examine his deeds, so I have compiled his biography. As for his books, many exist in the world, so I will not discuss them, but rather focus on his anecdotes. 11 (authorial; discursive). Guan Zhong was considered a virtuous minister by the world, yet Confucius belittled him. Did he think that the Zhou dynasty was in decline, and that even though Duke Huan was virtuous, he did not strive to become a true king, but instead became a hegemon? The saying goes, "One should follow what is good and correct what is bad, so that superiors and inferiors can be close to each other." Could this be referring to Guan Zhong? 12.2 (authorial; discursive). How could he be considered "cowardly to see what is right and not do it"? As for his remonstrances, which offended the ruler, this is what is meant by "when advancing, think of being loyal; when retreating, think of making amends"! If Yanzi were still alive, I would gladly serve as his whip-bearer.
[99 BC]
[98 BC]
[97 BC]
[96 BC]
[95 BC]
[94 BC]
[93 BC]
[92 BC]
[91 BC] [Sima Qian, Shiji 5 — Qin Shijia] 72 (Grand Historian’s comment; composition-era approx.). The Grand Historian Sima Qian said: The ancestors of Qin were of the Ying surname. Later, they were enfeoffed and took the name of their state as their surname, including the Xu, Tan, Ju, Zhongli, Yunyan, Tuqiu, Jiangliang, Huang, Jiang, Xiuyu, Baiming, Feilian, and Qin clans. However, Qin took the name of their ancestor Zaofu, who was enfeoffed in Zhao City, as their surname, Zhao.
